headline: Bridge Trial Focuses on Christie’s Political Tactics
abstract: The Port Authority was seen as a key bank of favors to be doled out in return for endorsements, according to testimony by David Wildstein, a former aide to Chris Christie.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Fourteen months before Chris Christie was up for re-election as governor of New Jersey, officials in his administration were already discussing his 2016 bid for the White House.

headline: El Cajon Police Release Video of Fatal Shooting
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Footage from a civilian’s cellphone and a restaurant surveillance camera show the shooting of Alfred Olango by a police officer and the moments before it.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in El Cajon, Calif., on Friday released video footage of an officer fatally shooting an unarmed black man, as part of an effort to quell what has been growing unrest in the community since the episode on Tuesday.

headline: Arnold Palmer’s Presence Is Felt at Ryder Cup’s Opening
abstract: Five days after the death of Palmer, the golf world turned its attention to the event that brought out the best in Palmer, who won 22 of his 33 matches in the competition.
lead_paragraph: CHASKA, Minn. — A soupy fog hung over Hazeltine National Golf Club like a mourning veil on Friday. It was a fitting mood setter for the 41st Ryder Cup, a usually raucous affair being contested with heavy hearts this year by competitors on both sides. Davis Love III, the United States team captain, set the tone at the opening ceremony the day before when he described Arnold Palmer as the captain here “working for both teams.”

headline: Carli Lloyd on Rio, Rapinoe and Equal Pay
abstract: Lloyd, the U.S. national team star, discussed her new book, her relationships with several teammates and what she might do if the national team goes on strike.
lead_paragraph: Carli Lloyd has been a member of the United States women’s national soccer team since 2005, and there has been a certain symmetry to the biggest moments of her career. She scored the game-winning goals that gave the Americans the gold medal at the 2008 and 2012 Olympics, and she scored a hat trick in the 2015 Women’s World Cup final as the United States won the sport’s showpiece for a third time.

headline: Is There a ‘Ferguson Effect’?
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: According to new studies, the answer isn’t yes. But it isn’t no, either.
lead_paragraph: This week, the F.B.I. released its official tally of crime in the United States in 2015. As expected, the numbers show an uptick in violence. In the nation as a whole, violent crime rose 3.9 percent last year. Homicides were up 10.8 percent, aggravated assaults 4.6 percent, robberies 1.4 percent.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra Walks Out on Opening Night
abstract: Philadelphia is now the third orchestra to go on strike this season. Pittsburgh’s and Fort Worth’s orchestras are also walking picket lines.
lead_paragraph: The musicians of the fabled Philadelphia Orchestra went on strike on Friday just before their season-opening gala concert, rattling the classical music world and silencing one of the nation’s great ensembles a little more than four years after it emerged from bankruptcy.

headline: After Disappointing Postseason, Rangers Have Several Newcomers
abstract: The Rangers’ roster has a decidedly different look from the team that was eliminated in the first round of the playoffs last season.
lead_paragraph: With several star players arriving late to training camp because of the World Cup of Hockey, Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault has had plenty of time to evaluate the team’s many new faces.

headline: Extremist Imam Tests F.B.I. and the Limits of the Law
abstract: Suleiman Anwar Bengharsa has endorsed ISIS and is suspected of plotting violence on its behalf. But there is no clear evidence that he has broken the law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than a decade, Suleiman Anwar Bengharsa has served as a Muslim cleric in Maryland, working as a prison chaplain and as an imam at mosques in Annapolis and outside Baltimore. He gave a two-week course in 2011 on Islamic teachings on marriage at the Islamic Society of Baltimore, where President Obama made a much-publicized visit this year.

headline: Why Try Out for Nets’ New D-League Team? It Beats Playing in Mongolia
abstract: About 150 players showed up for an open audition with the hope of landing an invitation to training camp.
lead_paragraph: BROOKVILLE, N.Y. — Several weeks before the start of the team’s inaugural season, officials from the Long Island Nets of the N.B.A. Development League decamped to Pratt Recreation Center on the campus of L.I.U. Post here for the most inclusive form of community engagement imaginable: an open tryout.

headline: Orioles Set Off on Road to Playoffs, With Plenty of Detours Expected
abstract: Baltimore is leading a complicated wild-card race as the Orioles strive for another shot at their first championship since 1983.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Schoop finished his interview in the Baltimore Orioles’ clubhouse Friday night, then peeked over the heads of the reporters by his locker. The televisions in the middle of the room were showing the final inning of the Toronto Blue Jays’ game in Boston. The Jays were down to their last out.

headline: Hoboken Terminal, With Flair and Grandeur, Is a Survivor
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Stations and Terminals (Passenger)']
abstract: The architectural elements that made the elegant station a landmark were apparently undamaged in the train crash that killed a woman and injured over 100 others.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen years ago, the writer Robert Klara landed an assignment for a travel article in a magazine, only to grumble that the editors did not have a more glamorous destination in mind. “They asked me to write about Hoboken,” he said.

headline: Trial Offers Rare View of Wildenstein Family and Fortune
abstract: The art dealer Guy Wildenstein and his financial advisers are facing charges of tax fraud and money-laundering in a French court.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Guy Wildenstein, the billionaire international art dealer, is most accustomed to his company’s regal limestone headquarters on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. But for the last few days, he has stood at a wooden dock in an ornate courtroom here, fending off questions about inheritance taxes and a maze of financial trusts that a French judge described as part of the family’s DNA.

headline: Donald Trump Opens New Line of Attack on Hillary Clinton: Her Marriage
abstract: In an interview, Mr. Trump said he was reconsidering whether he would back Mrs. Clinton if she became president.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump unleashed a slashing new attack on Hillary Clinton over Bill Clinton’s sexual indiscretions on Friday as he sought to put the Clintons’ relationship at the center of his political argument against her before their next debate.

headline: How Could Anyone Vote for Trump?
abstract: It’s time for Republican leaders to exercise a little leadership.
lead_paragraph: That first debate seems to have helped Hillary Clinton move ahead of Donald Trump in the polls. However, I know that many of you are asking yourselves: Why is this even a question?

headline: Shirley Jaffe, Geometric Artist of Joyful Forms, Dies at 92
abstract: An American who settled in Paris, Ms. Jaffe moved from Abstract Expressionism to a style rich in color and energy, finding a new audience in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Shirley Jaffe, an American painter working in Paris whose brilliantly colored, dancing geometric forms found an appreciative new audience when she began exhibiting in New York in the 1990s, died on Thursday in Louveciennes, France, near Versailles. She was 92.

headline: Trump Infrastructure Plan’s Fatal Flaw
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Tax', 'Income Inequality', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Republican nominee has proposed, in effect, to cut spending on infrastructure as part of his plan to borrow for spending on infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump agree that the nation’s roads, bridges and other infrastructure need an expensive overhaul. But voters should not assume that the candidates are equally capable of delivering results.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, October 1, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “The agency has developed an acute case of the slows, and it could not be a more critical moment.”

headline: Husband of Hoboken Crash Victim Struggles to Tell Their Child
abstract: Adrianus de Kroon and his family had moved to Hoboken, N.J., from Brazil not long ago. On Thursday, his wife was killed when a train crash caused a portion of the station’s ceiling to collapse, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The man waited outside a day care center in Hoboken, N.J. He had a question for the owner: How was he going to tell his daughter that she would never see her mother again?

headline: Next Stop, Farley Station
abstract: Governor Cuomo needs to develop a plan to regain what the city lost when the old Penn Station was destroyed.
lead_paragraph: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan’s dream of a grand train station rising in the vanished shadow of the old Pennsylvania Station — on the west side of Eighth Avenue, in the James A. Farley Post Office — is finally coming true. But the existing Penn Station, that underground rat maze below Madison Square Garden, is going to stay where it is, still serving the same subway riders and most of the commuters it serves now.

headline: New York Lawyer Gets Prison Time for Stealing $5 Million From Clients
abstract: Stuart A. Schlesinger, who practiced for half a century, was sentenced to six and a half years in prison for theft that involved about two dozen clients.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer who practiced for half a century in New York and built one of the city’s leading personal injury practices was sentenced to six and a half years in prison on Friday for stealing more than $5 million from clients.

headline: Quid pro Quo
abstract: David Woolf’s Saturday puzzle is a lively challenge.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — What is more disarming than facing off against a Saturday crossword, the hardest puzzle of the week, and having it open with a clue about cuddling? Nothing, I say, and I especially loved its entry, BIG SPOON, which makes its debut today.

headline: Why Don’t You Just Call the Cops?
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Nine-One-One (911) (Emergency Phone Number)']
abstract: After news of a police beating spread through Milwaukee, crime reports in black neighborhoods dropped precipitously.
lead_paragraph: SINCE the year began, police officers have killed 804 people, roughly three a day. In recent weeks, police officers fatally shot Terence Crutcher in Tulsa and Alfred Olango in a San Diego suburb. Both men were black and unarmed.

headline: Policing the Banks Is an Inside Job
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Whistle-Blowers', 'Consumer Protection', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Whistle-blowers could have revealed the scheme at Wells Fargo, but bank regulators are constrained from using them.
lead_paragraph: As we now well know, Wells Fargo not only opened millions of unauthorized client accounts, but the bank also fostered a corporate culture so toxic that an astounding 5,300 employees have been fired for their involvement in the companywide multiyear scheme.

headline: Congress Has Itself to Blame for 9/11 Bill
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'September 11 (2001)', 'United States International Relations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Immunity from Prosecution', 'Vetoes (US)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The ill-conceived measure, passed by some now-regretful lawmakers, has harmed American interests and should be repealed.
lead_paragraph: Congress seems determined to set a new standard for craven incompetence. Less than 24 hours after the Senate and House delivered a stinging rebuke to President Obama by overriding his veto of a bill that would let the Sept. 11 families sue Saudi Arabia, Republican leaders raised the possibility of a do-over.

headline: Joakim Noah, Averse to Wars, Skips Knicks Event at West Point
abstract: The center did not attend a team dinner with cadets at the United States Military Academy but emphasized that he is not “anti-troops.”
lead_paragraph: Joakim Noah, the Knicks center, said he had skipped a team dinner at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., on Thursday because he is against war.

headline: Suzanne Mitchell, 73, Dies; Made Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders a Global Brand
abstract: Working for Tex Schramm in the 1970s, Ms. Mitchell replaced a squad of high school bobby-soxers with a scantily clad chorus line.
lead_paragraph: Suzanne Mitchell, who replaced a squad of high school bobby-soxers with a scantily clad chorus line that became a choreographed global brand called the Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders, died on Tuesday at her home in Fredericksburg, Tex. She was 73.

headline: Battered but Persevering, Mets Reach the Threshold of the Postseason
abstract: By defeating the Phillies on the road Friday night, the Mets’ magic number for a National League wild-card berth stood at a single game.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Mets’ improbable, topsy-turvy season has tiptoed to the edge of a crucial moment. With their 5-1 win over the Philadelphia Phillies on Friday night, the Mets stood one victory away from securing a playoff berth that seemed impossible to attain six weeks ago.

headline: David Budbill, a Poet of Small-Town Vermont, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Budbill’s fictional creation Judevine, Vt., raised some hackles locally.
lead_paragraph: David Budbill, whose pared-down, plain-dress poems about his remote corner of northern Vermont found a national audience thanks to Garrison Keillor, died on Sept. 25 at his home in Montpelier, Vt. He was 76.

headline: Tiger Woods Opens Up at the Ryder Cup
abstract: Woods, whose record shows his unease as a team player, is forging new connections as a vice captain of the American team.
lead_paragraph: CHASKA, Minn. — Tiger Woods was standing behind Dustin Johnson on the driving range at Hazeltine National Golf Club last week when his posture stiffened. Years of celebrity have given Woods the ability to sniff out a camera like a bloodhound.

headline: Corrections: October 1, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, October 1, 2016.
lead_paragraph: SPORTS

headline: The Bloody Truth About Cricket
abstract: At its dark heart, this “gentleman’s game” is animated by the threat of brutal violence.
lead_paragraph: London — Twenty thousand Englishmen baying at the enemy. Screaming themselves hoarse, urging their champion to strike flesh. And then, it happens: The enemy is hit. Yes! Unwilling to show pain, he removes his helmet. Blood — the sight most keenly craved for — trickles down. His entourage runs to assist him — he attempts nonchalance, but concussion is an issue. The crowd is ecstatic.

headline: LeBron James Urges the Cavaliers to Re-Sign J.R. Smith
abstract: James said Smith, a shooting guard who is a free agent, had done his part.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James commented Friday on the Cleveland Cavaliers’ contract impasse with his unsigned teammate J .R. Smith, saying Smith “did his part” and the Cavaliers now “just need to get it done.”

headline: Oscar Brand, Folk Singer Whose Radio Show Twanged for Decades, Dies at 96
abstract: Mr. Brand wrote books and scores for musicals and films, but was best known for WNYC’s “Folksong Festival,” the longest-running radio show in history with a single host.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Brand, the lanky, affable, gravelly-voiced folk singer and songwriter whose weekly on-air hootenanny was the longest-running radio show in history with a single host, died on Friday at his home in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 96.

headline: What If Your Stress Level Was Visible for Everyone to See?
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Wearable Computing', 'Computer Chips', 'Biofeedback']
abstract: In collaboration with Intel, Hussein Chalayan created glasses and belts that tracked his models’ stress levels, then shone the visual projections on the wall.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Hussein Chalayan is a fashion designer with an eye for innovation. In the last decade, he has unveiled outfits that changed shape thanks to microchips and animatronics, gowns embedded with more than 15,000 LEDs to recreate a pixelated screen, and overcoats that dissolved into dresses when showered with water on a runway.

headline: Paris Fashion Week, Day 5: Conceptualists, Romantics and Gamines
abstract: As the shows reach the halfway point, Comme des Garçons, Haider Ackermann and Nina Ricci present collections.
lead_paragraph: Everybody’s workin’ on (not for) the weekend. Paris Fashion Week rounds the halfway point and keeps on charging. Here’s what to keep an eye on today:

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Deadpool’ and ‘Amanda Knox’
abstract: “Deadpool,” a Marvel Comics movie with a self-mocking wink, arrives on HBO. And Netflix presents the documentary “Amanda Knox.”
lead_paragraph: “Deadpool,” a Marvel Comics superhero movie with a wealth of self-mocking winks, arrives on HBO. And Netflix presents “Amanda Knox,” a documentary about the American student accused of murder in Italy.

headline: At Valentino, Pierpaolo Piccioli on His Own
abstract: After 26 years as half of a duo (with Maria Grazia Chiuri, now at Dior), the designer works on a solo collection.
lead_paragraph: ROME — One sunny day in September, Pierpaolo Piccioli, the creative director of Valentino, was sitting behind a modern light-wood desk in the brand’s headquarters on the Piazza Mignanelli, the square off the Spanish Steps, when the strains of a Frank Sinatra song drifted in through an open window from an accordion player busking on the cobblestones outside.

headline: New Drug for Severe Eczema Is Successful in 2 New Trials
abstract: Atopic dermatitis causes itching so extreme that many patients consider suicide. In trials, most patients said symptoms waned in the first two weeks of taking a new drug.
lead_paragraph: The disease is characterized by an itching, oozing rash that can cover almost all of the skin. The constant itch, to say nothing of the disfigurement, can be so unbearable that many patients consider suicide. There has never been a safe and effective treatment.

headline: ‘The Voting Booth ... Is Simply NOT the Place to Protest’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers debate, well, the debate, as well as The Times’s presidential endorsement and addiction risk in children.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: A Peek at the Secret English Farm Where Amazon Tests Its Drones
abstract: The e-commerce giant has big plans to use autonomous aircraft to deliver packages, and is testing the devices in rural England. We went to find them.
lead_paragraph: WORSTED LODGE, England — After hours of searching, I pulled onto a dirt track here in the rolling hills of Cambridgeshire and spotted a small dot whirring across the blue sky, gently swaying in the breeze as it steadily flew about 200 feet above the ground.

headline: The Best TV Shows and Movies New to Netflix, Hulu and More in October
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for October.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of movies and TV shows to their libraries. And at the beginning of every month, we’ll send you a newsletter with a list of the ones we think are most interesting, broken down by service. Everything mentioned is available to stream starting today, Oct. 1, unless otherwise indicated.

headline: A Curious Plan to Fight Climate Change: Buy Mines, Sell Coal
keywords: ['Coal', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Reclamation of Land', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Trees and Shrubs', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Tom Clarke, a nursing home owner, concocted a strategy to cut carbon emissions by gaining control of millions of tons of coal reserves and multiple mines.
lead_paragraph: FAIRVIEW, W.Va. — The coal was piled about as high as it could go, spilling down to the railroad tracks and towering over the elevator shaft. A yellow bulldozer pushed the mound to make room for more. From a distance on this rainy day, the black heap looked like a giant whale about to swallow the mine whole.

headline: The Home Designers Who Actually Move In
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Design', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Do It Yourself']
abstract: Beloved by blogs and clients, the couple behind the Jersey Ice Cream Company inhabit the spaces they transform, meticulously imprinting their modern, DIY aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: CANAAN, N.Y. — Tara Mangini brushed the sawdust off a picnic table, plunked down a package of Good & Plenty and started talking, very fast.

headline: The Art of Condolence
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Social Media', 'Death and Dying', 'Grief (Emotion)']
abstract: The rules of expressing sympathy have become muddied at best, and concealed in an onslaught of emoji at worst.
lead_paragraph: Recently a teenage boy in my community committed suicide. I immediately sat down to write the parents a sympathy note. I pulled out a monogrammed card, placed it on the desk in front of me, and proceeded to stare at it blankly for the next two hours.

headline: Carroll Wainwright Jr., ‘Silk-Stockinged Stowaway,’ Dies at 90
abstract: An 8-year-old Mr. Wainwright, a scion of one of the wealthiest families in the United States, made headlines after he sneaked aboard a ship from Bermuda to New York.
lead_paragraph: He hid below deck until the boat was well out to sea — too far out to return to port.

headline: Portland’s Small-House Movement Is Catching On
abstract: The Oregon city has developed solutions to the lack of affordable housing for the middle class, and the ideas are being embraced in other cities.
lead_paragraph: A simple 800-square-foot cottage in Portland, Ore., has helped focus attention on the need for affordable housing that can be wedged into existing urban spaces.

headline: The Other Trump
abstract: Unlike her prominent half siblings, Tiffany Trump has rarely been seen on the presidential campaign trail in 2016. But that may be about to change.
lead_paragraph: Like place cards at a society wedding or the lineup at a Soviet May Day parade, the seating at a campaign event is a GPS map of rank and favor. At the first presidential debate at Hofstra University on Monday night, Bill and Chelsea Clinton, along with Chelsea’s husband, Marc Mezvinsky, were on one side of the room; the extended Trump clan on the other.

headline: Supreme Court Faces Volatile, Even if Not Blockbuster, Docket
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Intellectual Disabilities', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Short-handed since Justice Antonin Scalia died in February, justices say they are determined to avoid deadlocks. That will require resolve and creativity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, awaiting the outcome of a presidential election that will determine its future, returns to the bench this week to face a volatile docket studded with timely cases on race, religion and immigration.

abstract: The label’s spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 collection.

abstract: The label’s spring 2017 rtw collection.

headline: A Portrait of Arhuaco Life in Colombia
abstract: An intimate look at Arhuaco life in Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, Colombia.
lead_paragraph: An intimate look at Arhuaco life in Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, Colombia.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Lindsay Pistilli and Joseph Camerata: Location, Location, Location
abstract: A couple, who now both work in real estate, find love after their long-ago play dates on the other side of the fence.
lead_paragraph: Lindsay Ann Pistilli, the daughter of Jamie G. Pistilli and Joseph Pistilli of Armonk, N.Y., was married Oct. 1 to Joseph Mario Camerata, the son of Susan L. Camerata and Fred J. Camerata of Manhattan. Msgr. David L. Cassato performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan.

headline: Rory Kennedy and David DiCamillo: In the Gym, Moving Very Quickly
abstract: A granddaughter of Robert Kennedy and of Frank Gifford weds a Citibank executive.
lead_paragraph: Rory Gifford Kennedy, a daughter of Victoria Gifford Kennedy of Washington and the late Michael LeMoyne Kennedy, was married Sept. 30 to David Francesco DiCamillo, a son of Leslie A. DiCamillo and Ottavio DiCamillo of Port Washington, N.Y. Daniel DiCamillo, the groom’s brother, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Montauk Yacht Club in Montauk, N.Y.

headline: Rachel Helson and Josh Banks: Auditioning New Love
abstract: Their first kiss was an act, or was it?
lead_paragraph: Rachel Annette Helson, the daughter of Jan M. Helson and Timothy D. Helson of Louisville, Ky., was married Oct. 1 to Josh Banks , the son of Cheryl A. Hutnak of North Providence, R.I., and Frank Hutnak of Pembroke, Mass. Jackson W. Helson, the bride’s brother who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated in the Shakespeare Garden of Central Park in New York.

headline: Mugler: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 rtw collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 rtw collection.

headline: Interviewing Shimon Peres at 90
abstract: In his later years, he was passionate about the “borderless” worlds of science and technology.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this article, Isabel Kershner, a Times correspondent in Jerusalem, recalls a two-hour interview in 2013 that she and Jodi Rudoren — The Times’s Jerusalem bureau chief at the time — conducted with Shimon Peres on the occasion of his 90th birthday.

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Interest in Twitter From Disney? Unlikely.
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Mars (Planet)', 'Social Media']
abstract: Twitter news, including a prolific tweeter’s hiatus. Also: A human sacrifice is needed for Elon Musk’s Mars shot. By popular acclamation, it’s Farhad.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: New Hillary Clinton Ads Look to Expand Lead With Hispanic Voters
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Advertising', 'State Legislatures', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The Clinton team has made Hispanic outreach a cornerstone of its advertising, and results are showing: In Florida, a poll shows her as having a 35-point lead.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s campaign and the main group supporting it, Priorities USA, hit the airwaves this week with new Spanish-language ads as they look to increase their lead among Hispanic voters in key swing states. An ad called “Disappear,” from Priorities, focuses on deportation.

headline: Construction Noise Complaints
abstract: How should a homeowner handle noise complaints during a renovation?
lead_paragraph: Q. We are renovating our attached rowhouse in Park Slope, Brooklyn. A neighbor has been complaining about noise starting before 8:30 a.m. on weekdays. It is normal construction noise, nothing out of the ordinary. Our crew arrives no earlier than 8 a.m. on weekdays and finishes around 5:30 p.m., with no weekend work. My understanding is that we are complying with city rules. What can, or should, we do?

headline: On the Trail: Week of Sept. 25
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump traded barbs at the first general election debate of 2016 and then hit the road campaigning.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump traded barbs at the first general election debate of 2016 and then hit the road campaigning.

headline: Fashion Week Photo Diary: Christian Dior and Loewe
abstract: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in Paris on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in Paris on Friday.

headline: Granting Shares for Fares: An Uber Rival’s Play for Drivers
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Employee Stock Ownership Plans (ESOP)']
abstract: Juno, currently operating only in New York City, is luring drivers with a lower commission and the promise of stock that can be cashed in if the company is sold or goes public.
lead_paragraph: When Kathleen Boylan walked into an orientation meeting last spring for a new ride-hailing company called Juno, held at its 1 World Trade Center office, she liked what she heard. Ms. Boylan, a New Jersey mother of two teenagers, had been driving for Uber and Lyft since last year, and while she appreciated the flexibility of the work, she wanted to earn more money.

headline: Crash, Then Listen Carefully: Secrets of a Cymbal Master
abstract: A master cymbal maker and tester spent years honing his ability to hear the overtones, octaves and chords that discerning drummers are looking for.
lead_paragraph: Paul Francis, 48, is a master cymbal maker and tester and director of research and development at Avedis Zildjian in Norwell, Mass.

headline: Inside Venezuela’s Crumbling Mental Hospitals
abstract: The state-run El Pampero Hospital in Venezuela has almost no drugs left for its tormented patients, let alone food and clothing, amid the nation’s economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: The state-run psychiatric hospital here in Barquisimeto, Venezuela, has long been a forgotten place, filled with forgotten people.

headline: Between the White House and the Capitol, a Slice of California
abstract: Edith Ramirez, chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission, has brought hints of her West Coast background to an office with views of the Capitol dome.
lead_paragraph: Living history

lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 rtw collection.

headline: Variety Puzzle: The Acrostic
abstract: Apologies in advance to a certain population.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — First, an apology to anyone who might be solving this puzzle on the great and glorious continent of Australia. The quote by Steve Hely is a totally humorous joke and we didn’t mean it.

headline: After Trump-Clinton, Vice-Presidential Debate Isn’t Exactly ‘the Return of Elvis’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton drew a record television audience for their first debate. By comparison, their running mates, Mike Pence and Tim Kaine, may be heavier on policy than on pizazz.
lead_paragraph: Psst, there is another debate on Tuesday.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: At a Loss for Meds, Venezuela’s Mentally Ill Spiral Downward
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Shortages', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Food', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources']
abstract: Amid the nation’s economic collapse, psychiatric hospitals are running out of medications, food and other supplies. Thousands of patients are drifting into despair and psychosis.
lead_paragraph: MARACAY, Venezuela — The voices tormenting Accel Simeone kept getting louder.

headline: How Love Inspired the Voice of the Dodgers to Rise in Song
abstract: Vin Scully’s wife, Sandi, who has been a powerful force on decisions large and small in his life, wove together a family from pieces forged by life’s hardships.
lead_paragraph: For years, whenever Vin Scully was asked if he would return for another season as the voice of the Los Angeles Dodgers, he responded that he needed the blessing of his wife, Sandi.

headline: Timber Company Tells California Town, Go Find Your Own Water
abstract: Residents of Weed, Calif., are battling a timber company for the rights to water that has been piped to houses in the area for more than a century.
lead_paragraph: WEED, Calif. — The water that gurgles from a spring on the edge of this Northern California logging town is so pristine that for more than a century it has been piped directly to the wooden homes spread across hills and gullies.

headline: Comme des Garçons: Spring 2017

headline: To the N.F.L., 40 Winks Is as Vital as the 40-Yard Dash
abstract: In the never-ending search for an edge, teams have opened their eyes to sleep as a priority, backed up by science that increasingly points to its importance for physical and mental health.
lead_paragraph: RENTON, Wash. — The players filed past a table and picked up the electronic wristbands as casually as any of other piece of equipment designed to make the Seattle Seahawks perform at their peak.

headline: Don’t Like the Candidates? Vote Anyway
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting and Voters', 'Elections', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Elections (US)']
abstract: Low turnout means too many Americans don’t get to vote. Here’s how to fix the problem.
lead_paragraph: To secure the right to vote, Americans have been beaten, jailed and tortured. Some even died. Yet in the 2012 presidential election, less than 54 percent of the eligible population turned out to vote. That’s 93 million people who didn’t bother to weigh in on who would lead their country.

headline: Serving Up Health Care
abstract: Readers comment on “Football Team at the Obamacare Buffet” (Sept. 25).
lead_paragraph: “Football Team at the Obamacare Buffet,” by Margot Sanger-Katz (The Upshot, Economic View, Sept. 25), looked at the difficulty the health insurance markets have with pricing to account for healthy and sick customers — a problem likened to that faced by an all-you-can-eat buffet when a high school football team arrives.

headline: Donald Trump’s Pathetic Fraternity
abstract: Chris Christie and Rudy Giuliani once had pride. Now they have an orange overlord.
lead_paragraph: Over decades of writing about politics, I’ve crossed paths with many candidates and office holders who impressed me, but few who blew me away.

headline: Girl Talk at Trump Tower
abstract: Stay tuned for “Really Desperate Housewives of Trumpworld,” featuring Newt Gingrich, Chris Christie, Roger Ailes and Rudy Giuliani.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — LET’S stop being so hard on Donald Trump.

headline: Trump and the Intellectuals
abstract: A case for Trump’s ideas that ignores the man himself.
lead_paragraph: THE Republican Party’s politicians have mostly surrendered to Donald Trump. The Republican Party’s entertainers have mostly been enthusiastic about his candidacy. But the conservative intelligentsia — journalists, think-tankers and academics — has been conspicuous in its resistance.

headline: Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s Advice for Living
abstract: “It helps sometimes to be a little deaf” is wise counsel for marriage or for the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: “Did you always want to be a judge” or, more exorbitantly, “a Supreme Court justice?” Schoolchildren visiting me at the court, as they do at least weekly, ask that question more than any other. It is a sign of huge progress made. To today’s youth, judgeship as an aspiration for a girl is not at all outlandish. Contrast the ancient days, the fall of 1956, when I entered law school. Women accounted for less than 3 percent of the legal profession in the United States, and only one woman had ever served on a federal appellate court.

headline: When Whites Just Don’t Get It, Part 7
abstract: Racial discrimination remains ubiquitous in America: Blacks are at a disadvantage even at crosswalks.
lead_paragraph: LET me raise an uncomfortable topic: We all know that in some fundamental way, this presidential campaign is in part about race.

headline: Donald Trump Is Seen as Helping Push Asian-Americans Into Democratic Arms
abstract: Asian-Americans are identifying as Democrats at a quicker pace than any other racial group, and many Republicans worry this election is accelerating that trend.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — On paper at least, Asian-Americans seem like perfect Republicans. Many are small-business owners. Their communities tend to be more culturally conservative. And a lot of them, having fled oppressive Communist governments, found comfort in the Republican Party’s aggressive anti-Communist policies.

headline: Report That Donald Trump Did Business in Cuba Ups the Ante in Florida
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Cuban-Americans']
abstract: Revelations that Mr. Trump may have violated the ban on American companies operating in Cuba come as the presidential race is heating up in the state.
lead_paragraph: As the race between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump teeters on a razor’s edge in Florida, their campaigns are scuffling over business that Mr. Trump may have conducted in Cuba while American companies were barred from operating there.

headline: Tom Brokaw: Learning to Live With Cancer
abstract: Three years ago I was told I had an incurable cancer. The disease is in remission, but my life has changed.
lead_paragraph: For most of my adult life I have answered the question “Occupation?” with one word: journalist. I still do, but now I am tempted to add a phrase.

lead_paragraph: There is an award for the best relief pitcher in each league. It was first given by Major League Baseball in 2014. The American League’s honor is named for Mariano Rivera, the National League’s for Trevor Hoffman. Rivera, Hoffman and other decorated former closers do the voting.

headline: Pope Francis Navigates Orthodox Georgia’s Rocky Terrain
abstract: The Georgian Orthodox Church was once hostile to the Vatican, and the former Soviet republic remains pulled between East and West.
lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia — Pope Francis, accustomed to huge, usually adulatory crowds during his international trips, got an early taste of how his two-day visit to Georgia would be a bit different, courtesy of David Isakadze, a passionate anti-papist and a priest in the Georgian Orthodox Church.

headline: Colombians See Vote as a Means to Secure Peace, if Not Justice
abstract: A referendum on Sunday on a peace deal with FARC rebels is viewed as either “a blasphemy” or a chance “to put an end to so much violence.”
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — After 52 years of armed conflict, there are hopes of peace in Colombia.

headline: 15 Years in the Afghan Crucible
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: After 15 years of American military involvement, there are glimmers of a better future despite the enduring threat of the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — There is an end-of-an-era feel here these days. Military helicopters rattle overhead, ferrying American and Afghan officials by air rather than risk cars bombs in the streets. The concrete barriers, guarding against suicide attacks, have grown taller and stronger around every embassy and government building, and whole streets are blocked off from the public.

headline: Jamaica, Long Opposed to Marijuana, Now Wants to Cash In on It
abstract: After easing laws against the drug last year, the government is looking to create a “wellness tourism” with legal marijuana businesses at its core.
lead_paragraph: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica — Jamaica has long bemoaned its reputation as the land of ganja.

headline: For Orchestras in the U.S., So Much Depends on Their Communities’ Fortunes
abstract: On top of endemic challenges like rising costs and weakening demand, each ensemble faces its own obstacles.
lead_paragraph: The orchestra world’s Black Friday began on Sept. 30 with the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra going on strike in the morning and ended across Pennsylvania that evening with the Philadelphia Orchestra walking out as patrons gathered for its opening-night gala. The Fort Worth Symphony Orchestra musicians, who were already on strike, sent their support on Twitter.

headline: The Monster Sorority of Women Voters
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Women and Girls', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Age, Chronological']
abstract: The danger of focusing on the differences between men and women is that it assumes all women are the same.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the gender gap has been yuge and sometimes more modestly endowed, but for months now men have remained pretty much for Donald J. Trump and women for Hillary Clinton. Last week’s debate, when Mrs. Clinton got a chance to bring up her opponent’s habit of calling women pigs, slobs and dogs, did nothing to narrow that divide.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers responded to the deaths of the Miami Marlins pitcher and the golf champion Arnold Palmer.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: How to Get Nina Ricci’s Sultry Slicked-Back Hair
abstract: It all begins with dry, unwashed strands — and culminates in an effortless, vacation-inspired look.
lead_paragraph: This season, “I don’t know if it’s really a hair style. It’s more of a feeling,” said the hairstylist Paul Hanlon, backstage at Nina Ricci’s spring/summer 2017 show. He was describing the ease and carefree attitude of being on vacation — specifically in the case of this season’s Nina Ricci woman, on holiday in South America. To embody that attitude, Hanlon created a look that evoked a steamy tropical environment: hair, moist from the humidity, but also with a bit of a dry, wavy texture from the air and salt water — and spontaneously pulled back. “It looks like she’s just been running her hands though her hair, pulling it off her face, off her shoulders,” Hanlon said. (The makeup artist Diane Kendel seemed drawn to the feverish South American nights too, most especially with the eyes, which she shadowed in shimmering shades of bronze and aquamarine-turquoise blue.)

headline: Mets Overcome a Season of Adversity and Claim a Wild-Card Berth
abstract: Their victory over the Phillies also ensured that they will host a wild-card game on Wednesday at Citi Field against the Cardinals or the Giants.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Mets Manager Terry Collins was in the middle of a television interview near the entrance to the visitors’ clubhouse at Citizens Bank Park when Jose Reyes dumped beer on his boss’s head.

headline: Corruption in the Soprano State
abstract: The Bridgegate scandal that has tarnished Governor Christie seems to underscore a point he once made: New Jersey politics will always have corruption.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago New Jersey’s new governor, Chris Christie, walked into a movie theater with a political ally named Bill Baroni and several actors from “The Sopranos.” The film they were there to see was “The Soprano State,” a documentary on political corruption in New Jersey, filled with tales of no-show jobs, cash-stuffed envelopes passed across linoleum diner tables and government contracts won with pay-to-play campaign donations.

headline: Rookie of the Year Is a Two-Horse Race in the American League
abstract: Detroit Tigers starter Michael Fulmer started fast but faded, while the Yankees slugger Gary Sanchez dazzled for two solid months.
lead_paragraph: The regular season wraps up this weekend, and the race for the American League Rookie of the Year Award has narrowed to Michael Fulmer, a starting pitcher for the Detroit Tigers, and Gary Sanchez, the slugging catcher for the Yankees. Solid arguments can be made for either player, but with just a little more time, the choice might have been far easier to make.

headline: New Jersey Transit Was Under Investigation Before Fatal Crash
abstract: The Federal Railroad Administration began an audit of the railroad in June after an increase in safety violations, an official said.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Railroad Administration began investigating safety problems at New Jersey Transit before a fatal train crash last week, a federal rail official confirmed on Saturday.

lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 rtw collection.

headline: Medicating a Prophet
abstract: Psychosis can be rewarding; take it away, and the patient realizes he’s a homeless man with AIDS.
lead_paragraph: Philadelphia — In the middle of the night in my second year of psychiatric residency, 13 years ago, I was awakened to see a prophet. The man, in his early 50s, had been living on the streets. He was a college graduate from a middle-class family. But on Christmas Eve three decades earlier, the Archangel Michael had come to him in a vision and demanded that he spread God’s word.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Positive Message? That Was the Plan, at Least

lead_paragraph: Is it wrongful “cultural appropriation” when authors invent characters unlike themselves?

headline: Anti-Semitism at My University, Hidden in Plain Sight
abstract: Students protest hate crimes against Muslim Americans and bias against black people in politics, but they dismiss attacks on Jews.
lead_paragraph: Providence, R.I. — Last semester, a group came to Providence to speak against admitting Syrian refugees to this country. As the president of the Brown Coalition for Syria, I jumped into action with my peers to stage a counterdemonstration. But I quickly found myself cut out of the planning for this event: Other student groups were not willing to work with me because of my leadership roles in campus Jewish organizations.

headline: His Father’s Easiest Pass Was Giving Martin Truex Jr. the Keys
abstract: Martin Truex Sr. handed over the family car to his son after they had just one race together. He hasn’t regretted it since.

headline: A Rabbi’s Enduring Sermon on Living Your Last Five Minutes
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Rosh Hashana', 'Yom Kippur', 'Death and Dying', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Challenger (Space Shuttle)']
abstract: “Can you imagine knowing that in a few moments death was imminent?” a rabbi said, speaking of the crew of the Challenger shuttle. Three years later, he lived his words.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, amid the somber prayers of Judaism’s holiest day, Rabbi Kenneth Berger rose to deliver the Yom Kippur sermon. He spoke to his congregants about a tragedy many of them, including his daughter, had witnessed eight months earlier in the Florida sky: the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

headline: Jets Face a Simple Test Against Seahawks, Knowing How Hard It Is
abstract: In each of the last four seasons, Seattle has yielded the fewest points in the N.F.L. No team this year has been stingier on third down, or given up fewer total yards and first downs.

headline: Why Some Wars (Like Syria’s) Get More Attention Than Others (Like Yemen’s)
keywords: ['War and Revolution', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Some of the reasons are obvious; the scale of Syria’s war is catastrophic and much worse than Yemen’s. But attention is about more than numbers.
lead_paragraph: It is a truth universally acknowledged by every war correspondent, humanitarian aid worker and Western diplomat: Some wars, like Syria’s, receive tremendous public attention, which can translate into pressure for resolution. But many others, like Yemen’s still raging but much ignored conflict, do not.

headline: Women’s Emergence as Terrorists in France Points to Shift in ISIS Gender Roles

lead_paragraph: PARIS — There was the parked car stuffed with gas canisters near the Notre Dame Cathedral, a possible effort to set off an explosion in the heart of Paris. There was the suspected plot to attack a train station in the Paris area. There was the effort by one of the Islamic State’s most prominent propagandists to recruit two young people in Nice, where an attacker had killed 86 people in July by running them down in a truck.

headline: Clemson Slows Lamar Jackson and Halts Louisville
abstract: Clemson secured a narrow win by stopping a late drive, with a pass on a fourth-and-12 from Jackson, a Heisman Trophy front-runner, going for an 11-yard gain.
lead_paragraph: CLEMSON, S.C. — In a matchup between division rivals both ranked in the top five nationally, Clemson beat Louisville on Saturday night by 6 points, 42-36, but also by about one yard.

Andresen of San Francisco. The Rev. Terry Newberry, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in West Tisbury, Mass.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, October 2, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “That is the doomsday scenario, in some respects, of having an eight-member court.”

headline: The Forger
abstract: As a teenager, Adolfo Kaminsky saved thousands of lives by forging passports to help children flee the Nazis. He spent his life helping others escape atrocities around the world.
lead_paragraph: As a teenager, Adolfo Kaminsky saved thousands of lives by forging passports to help children flee the Nazis. He spent his life helping others escape atrocities around the world.

headline: Christine D’Souza, David Gelb
abstract: The couple met in 2011 at her office in Los Angeles while discussing the release of his documentary.
lead_paragraph: Christine Esmeralda D’Souza, a daughter of Judge Bernadette Gomes D’Souza and Dr. Terence C. D’Souza of New Orleans, was married Oct. 1 at her parent’s home to David Gelb, a son of Donna Daniels Gelb and Peter Gelb, both of New York. The bride’s mother, who sits on the Civil District Court of New Orleans, officiated.

headline: ‘If I Sleep for an Hour, 30 People Will Die’
abstract: A World War II hero saved the lives of rebels and refugees. Now it’s our turn.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It’s 1944, in occupied Paris. Four friends spend their days in a narrow room atop a Left Bank apartment building. The neighbors think they’re painters — a cover story to explain the chemical smell. In fact, the friends are members of a Jewish resistance cell. They’re operating a clandestine laboratory to make false passports for children and families about to be deported to concentration camps. The youngest member of the group, the lab’s technical director, is practically a child himself: Adolfo Kaminsky, age 18.

headline: Paris Fashion Week, Day 6: The Big Names Come Out
abstract: What will Valentino look like now that Pierpaolo Piccioli is on his own? Can Demna Gvasalia repeat his success at Balenciaga? And other vital questions.
lead_paragraph: A handful of big names come out Sunday, for one of the biggest back-to-back days since the start of Paris Fashion Week. And as a bonus, it’s Sunday — so no traffic! Here’s what to look for:

abstract: HBO introduces its latest big-budget drama, “Westworld.” And “The Fourth Phase” has its premiere on Red Bull TV.
lead_paragraph: HBO introduces its latest big-budget drama, “Westworld,” a sci-fi adventure. And Red Bull TV offers a free premiere of “The Fourth Phase.”

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Begins a New Season With Alec Baldwin as Donald Trump
abstract: Kate McKinnon returned as Hillary Clinton in the much-anticipated opening sketch, a parody of the first presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: There was a too-eager invocation of “Trumped-up trickle-down economics”; a repeated, awkward pronunciation of China; some audible sniffling and a vehement complaint of a broken microphone; a plea to call Sean Hannity; and a gleeful shoulder shimmy.

abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.

headline: 1941: Aid to Russia is Vital
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The British ambassador Viscount Halifax meets President Roosevelt to discuss sending aid to Russia and the Middle East in October 1941.
lead_paragraph: Washington — Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, saw President Roosevelt for fifty minutes at the White House today [Oct. 2], in his first visit since his return from a month’s absence in England.

headline: Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton, Hoboken: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: How to Save Money on Car Rentals
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Automobile Renting and Leasing', 'Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Budget Travel']
abstract: To get a good deal on a rental car, avoid picking up at the airport and consider lesser-known brands.
lead_paragraph: Why is it that a car rental might cost you as much as $300 one weekend and just $50 the following one with the same company? Such price variations are common in the car rental industry, according to Gary Leff, the founder of the travel deals site viewfromthewing.com. “Car rental prices constantly go up and down in big leaps,” he said.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Talks Will Start by End of March, Theresa May Says
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The prime minister’s timeline, the most detailed so far, could set the stage for Britain to leave the European Union by spring 2019.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, England — Outlining a timetable for Britain to leave the European Union in the spring of 2019, Prime Minister Theresa May on Sunday put immigration at the center of her strategy for withdrawal, suggesting that Britain could be headed for a “hard Brexit,” or clean break, from the bloc.

headline: Daniel Ricciardo Wins Malaysian Grand Prix in a Red Bull Sweep
abstract: Ricciardo took advantage of a blown engine in Lewis Hamilton’s Mercedes as the Red Bull team scored its first 1-2 victory since 2013.
lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — With 15 laps left in the Malaysian Grand Prix, the engine of the Mercedes that had led the 41 previous laps, under the team that won all but one race this season, went “bang” and spat flames, ending Lewis Hamilton’s until-then perfect drive.

headline: Balenciaga: Spring 2017
abstract: Demna Gvasalia’s designs for spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: Demna Gvasalia’s designs for spring 2017 collection.

headline: For Knicks’ Joakim Noah, Principled Stand Isn’t a Novelty
abstract: Noah’s decision to skip a team dinner at the U.S. Military Academy, which came amid prominent protests by other athletes, sprang from long-held pacifist beliefs.
lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, N.Y. — As a student at Poly Prep Country Day School in Brooklyn, Joakim Noah often took the bus to school from his home in Manhattan, circumnavigating construction on the site of the World Trade Center, which had been demolished in the attacks of Sept. 11. It was a daily reminder for him of violence, of the cruel capabilities of man.

headline: Celine: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 collection.

headline: A Fragrance Debut? First, It’s Lights, Camera, Action
abstract: For a perfume to be a true success story these days, its introduction must be accompanied by a slick film.
lead_paragraph: Fashion perfumes originated in Belle Époque Paris, and for generations, it was their intoxicating scent that proved to be their most effective selling tool. A cloud of tuberose hanging in the air, for example, might prompt a woman to head out in search of Robert Piguet’s Fracas.

headline: ‘They Keep Finding Bodies’: Gang Violence in Long Island Town Fuels Immigration Debate
keywords: ['Gangs', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: In Brentwood, MS-13, a gang with roots in Los Angeles and El Salvador, is suspected in the killings of four teenagers in two weeks.
lead_paragraph: BRENTWOOD, N.Y. — Four dead teenagers. Two weeks. One town. And a ruthless gang, the authorities say, was most likely responsible for the toll. Again.

headline: Hungary Votes Against Migrants, but Too Few to Clear Threshold
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Referendums']
abstract: The result gave the country’s autocratic prime minister, Viktor Orban, a partial victory, though what Mr. Orban plans to do now remains a mystery.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Hungarians handed the country’s autocratic prime minister, Viktor Orban, a partial victory on Sunday by overwhelmingly voting “no” in a national referendum on whether to accept more migrants, but without giving him the turnout for a valid result. What Mr. Orban intends to do now, however, remains a mystery.

headline: 1966: Demonstrators Disrupts Wilson’s Talk
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'GREAT BRITAIN', 'Police', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Demonstrators disturb Prime Minister Harold Wilson at a church service in Brighton in October 1966.
lead_paragraph: BRIGHTON — Prime Minister Harold Wilson was shouted down by demonstrators and scuffles broke out in a church here today [Oct. 2] as he mounted the pulpit to read the lesson. White-helmeted policemen stationed outside were called to break up the demonstration in the packed Dorset Gardens Methodist Church. Hymn books went flying and members of the congregation were crushed against the pews as the officers struggled in the aisles to drag the demonstrators out. They were mostly young men and girls and were led out shouting ‘‘you hypocrite’’ and ‘‘murderer’’ at the prime minster.

headline: The Time I Found Donald Trump’s Tax Records in My Mailbox
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Income Tax', 'News and News Media', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of']
abstract: A manila envelope led to old-style investigative journalism involving a meeting in a bagel shop and an IBM Selectric typewriter.
lead_paragraph: In this article, Susanne Craig, a New York Times Metro reporter who covers government and politics, reveals one of the lesser-known benefits of “snail mail.”

headline: N.F.L. Recap: Who Said Anything About a Quarterback Controversy?
abstract: The rookie quarterback Dak Prescott bounced back from a bad start to get the Cowboys to 3-1. The Patriots, with a rookie quarterback of their own, crashed without Tom Brady.
lead_paragraph: After four weeks of playing catch in his back yard, Tom Brady can finally rejoin the New England Patriots, who suddenly look like they could really use him. Here’s what we learned in N.F.L. Week 4:

headline: Paris Fashion Shows: Comme des Garçons, Balenciaga, Céline and More
abstract: Plus looks from the Haider Ackermann, Junya Watanabe, Nina Ricci, Undercover, and Emanuel Ungaro spring 2017 shows.
lead_paragraph: Plus looks from the Haider Ackermann, Junya Watanabe, Nina Ricci, Undercover, and Emanuel Ungaro spring 2017 shows.

headline: Balenciaga and Comme des Garçons Play Different Games in Paris
abstract: One suits up in spandex, while the other offers an emotional workout.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For the last few days, the Place du Palais-Royal, the gracious square abutting the Louvre in Paris, has been almost entirely occupied by a big black tent with a swoosh on the side and the words “We Run Paris” emblazoned on the front.

headline: Donald Trump and His Allies Struggle to Move Past Tax Revelation
abstract: Mr. Trump’s campaign lurched between refusing to acknowledge that released 1995 tax records were bona fide to insisting that his not having paid taxes was evidence of his unrivaled business prowess.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and his allies struggled on Sunday to move beyond the revelation that he might have been able to legally avoid nearly two decades of federal income taxation, putting new pressure on the candidate just as he tries to recover from a lackluster debate performance.

abstract: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in Paris on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in Paris on Saturday.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Revel in the pleasures of cooking ahead for the week, then learn about the term “subtweet.”
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: A Family Seeks Answers in the Other Manhattan Explosion
abstract: The police are offering a reward for information leading to an arrest in the July 3 blast in Central Park that injured a 19-year-old college student.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Golden was in Virginia when he received the call from Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan, the day before the Fourth of July. His son was on the line.

headline: Valentino: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 collection.

headline: At Valentino, Pierpaolo Piccioli’s Metamorphosis
abstract: Pierpaolo Piccioli shows his first solo collection for Valentino.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When it was announced, back in July, that the design team of Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pierpaolo Piccioli, whose vision of Valentino-after-Valentino had propelled the brand to billion-dollar status, was breaking up, and that Mr. Piccioli was going to be in sole charge of the house, there were a number of raised eyebrows. Industry watchers immediately began to play the guessing game of “who did what,” and wonder how things may change as a result.

headline: Jacksonville Jaguars Beat Indianapolis Colts in London
abstract: Colts quarterback Andrew Luck led a spirited comeback, but the Jaguars improved to 2-2 in London.
lead_paragraph: The Jacksonville Jaguars started the season 0-3 in the United States, but after holding off a valiant comeback attempt by Andrew Luck and the Indianapolis Colts, they are 1-0 at their home-away-from-home London on Sunday. A game filled with penalties, big hits, and 28 combined points in the fourth quarter, ended with the Jaguars on top, 30-27.

headline: A Strong Opening for a Film by Tim Burton, Who Needed a Win
abstract: The director’s movie “Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children” was No. 1 at the domestic box office, but turning a profit is still a challenge.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Had they cost half as much to make, their box office debuts would be considered marvelous. But with price tags of more than $100 million (before marketing costs), “Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children” and “Deepwater Horizon” will have to fight to avoid going down as disappointments.

headline: A Dominant Defense Fuels the Vikings’ Surge
abstract: Minnesota (3-0) will face the Giants on Monday night with a defense that led the N.F.L. in sacks going into Week 4.
lead_paragraph: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn. — In a three-week span beginning late in training camp, the Minnesota Vikings lost three key offensive starters: quarterback Teddy Bridgewater (dislocated knee), the three-time N.F.L. rushing champion Adrian Peterson (meniscus tear) and left tackle Matt Kalil (hip surgery).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Oct. 3
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Next Big Tech Corridor? Between Seattle and Vancouver, Planners Hope
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Foreign Workers', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Commuting']
abstract: American tech giants stand to benefit from Canada’s smoother immigration process, and Vancouver is looking to feed its own homegrown tech ambitions.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Seattle and Vancouver are like fraternal twins separated at birth. Both are bustling Pacific Northwest coastal cities with eco-conscious populations that have accepted the bargain of dispiriting weather for much of the year in exchange for nearby ski slopes and kayaking and glorious summers.

headline: 2 Friars’ Mission: Reviving a Brooklyn Church in a Religious ‘Dead Zone’
abstract: On the brink of closing a church on the border of Williamsburg and Greenpoint, the Diocese of Brooklyn called in two Franciscan friars, who are reintroducing Catholicism to the area in unconventional ways.
lead_paragraph: The two Franciscan friars, complete with floor-length robes, stood behind the bar outside the 100-year-old church taking cash and slinging cans of Coors and Lime-A-Ritas in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

headline: Google, Lagging Amazon, Races Across the Threshold Into the Home
abstract: Google is unveiling its answer to Echo, an artificially intelligent home device that vaulted Amazon ahead of Google in a race to build technology that interacts as humans do.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Amazon introduced its Echo device in late 2014, Google executives were caught off guard. For years, they had predicted the creation of a virtual assistant that would answer questions or help accomplish tasks, and they focused on building that capability into smartphones and tablets.

headline: Spaniards, Exhausted by Politics, Warm to Life Without a Government
abstract: All year, Spain has plodded along without an elected national government. For some Spaniards, this is a wonderful thing. “No government, no thieves,” one said.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — For the past 288 days, Spain has plodded along without an elected national government. For some Spaniards, this is a wonderful thing.

headline: Taking the Temperature Inside the (Feverish) Cloud
keywords: ['Cloud Computing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Enterprise Computing', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows']
abstract: At annual presentations in San Francisco, tech companies deluge potential customers with data on their progress in cloud computing, machine learning and artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Autumn is a good time to see what is happening next in the $3 trillion business technology market. In particular, it’s a good time to check out what’s new in corporate paranoia.

headline: Who Is the Real Elena Ferrante? Italian Journalist Reveals His Answer
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: An investigative journalist said financial and real estate records indicate that the Italian translator Anita Raja is behind the best-selling author of four novels set in Naples.
lead_paragraph: In the latest twist in one of the most intriguing literary mysteries in recent history, an Italian investigative journalist says financial and real estate records indicate that the Italian translator Anita Raja — daughter of a Polish Jewish mother and Neapolitan father — is behind the best-selling author Elena Ferrante.

headline: Cam Newton Sustains Concussion in Panthers’ Loss to Falcons
abstract: Carolina’s star quarterback was taken out of the game after being hit while rushing for a 2-point conversion in the fourth quarter.
lead_paragraph: Carolina Panthers quarterback Cam Newton, who absorbed several eyebrow-raising hits to the head in the season-opening game against the Denver Broncos, sustained a concussion on Sunday and left the game against the Falcons in Atlanta.

headline: Riccardo Muti, Indulging a Passion for Overlooked Italian Composers
abstract: Martucci never wrote an opera, but that is just fine with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and its leader.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When Riccardo Muti learned that I would be attending his concert here with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra on Friday afternoon he earnestly invited me to drop backstage afterward — first, so we could finally meet, but also so he could tell me all about Giuseppe Martucci.

headline: U.S. Captures Ryder Cup, Ending Europe’s Streak
abstract: The Americans clinched their first victory in the biennial event since 2008 when Ryan Moore, the last man named to the team, won his singles match.
lead_paragraph: CHASKA, Minn. — Ryan Moore was the last player to gain a spot on the teams for the 41st Ryder Cup. On Sunday, exactly a week after he found out he had made the United States team, he was 2 down with three holes to play in his singles match against Lee Westwood when two of his teammates, Patrick Reed and J. B. Holmes, showed up on the 16th hole in a show of support.

headline: Missed the ’80s? Nena, and ‘99 Luftballons,’ Alights Live in America
abstract: The German singer Nena is on a mini-tour of the United States three decades after her hit the American Top 10.
lead_paragraph: Building up anticipation is well and good, but most musical acts with a smash American single don’t wait 32 years to tour the United States.

headline: Givenchy: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 collection.

headline: Review: in ‘Conviction,’ a Woman Helps the Wrongly Convicted, Baggage in Tow
abstract: The crime-and-punishment genre gets yet another new wrinkle, with Hayley Atwell starring as the leader of a new unit that looks into bad justice.
lead_paragraph: Television’s efforts to wring every possible permutation out of the crime-and-punishment genre results in another bland series with “Conviction,” premiering Monday night on ABC.

headline: Pressing for a Win, the Jets Push the Wrong Buttons Against the Seahawks
abstract: Even with Seattle quarterback Russell Wilson slowed by leg injuries, the Jets’ defense gave up 309 yards and three touchdowns as the team’s record slipped to 1-3.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Jets do not have a dynamic running game. Their quarterback has thrown seven fourth-quarter interceptions during the past two weeks. They struggle to cover running backs, wide receivers and tight ends.

headline: Review: ‘M.S. Dhoni: The Untold Story’ Recalls a Cricketer’s Ascent
abstract: The life of the captain of the winning 2011 World Cup team is recounted in this biopic from Neeraj Pandey.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to understand cricket to enjoy a good cricket movie. “Lagaan” (2001), whose centerpiece was a rousing match of underdog (Indian) versus overdog (British colonials), got the heart pounding, even if you couldn’t follow all the ins and outs of the game. It was the rare Bollywood movie to reach across the aisle, as it were, attracting moviegoers beyond the faithful.

headline: Review: From Mark Morris, a Tale of Love Refracted and Multiplied
abstract: Teaming with the Silk Road Ensemble, the choreographer has turned the classic transcultural story “Layla and Majnun” into a multi-mirrored dance-drama.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — “My soul is on fire because we are apart. My only wish is to perish in the world of love. My true love knows every sliver of sorrow in my heart.” “Dear God, let me feel even more despair for my love.” “The true purpose of love is sacrificing oneself.”

headline: Review: In Cirque du Soleil’s ‘Kurios,’ a Frisson of Novelty
abstract: This spectacle combines the troupe’s familiar pinpoint precision with surprises and a dash of exoticism.
lead_paragraph: Important public service announcement: There are no scary clowns in the latest show from Cirque du Soleil, “Kurios,” which is being staged in a grand, old-school big top on Randalls Island.

headline: Review: In ‘Timeless,’ a Time-Traveling Trio and a High-Stakes Chase
abstract: Crated by Shawn Ryan of “The Shield” and Eric Kripke of “Supernatural,” the science-fiction show has a nifty premise that helps overcome its banal moments.
lead_paragraph: “Timeless,” a good-natured science-fiction adventure series beginning Monday on NBC, manages the not inconsequential trick of being educational dumb fun. Each week (based on the first two episodes) its team of time travelers zap back to some pivotal moment in the past and engage in highly implausible, don’t-think-too-hard-about-it derring-do to save the present as we know it.

headline: Google to Unveil New Devices, and Labor Dept. Will Report on Jobs
abstract: Google is expected to reveal Google Home; and the Labor Department will report the penultimate jobs report scheduled before the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead:

headline: After Board Upheaval, Bronx Museum Regroups and Affirms Plans
abstract: The director, Holly Block, and her supporters defend her global view, in the wake of criticism from trustees who resigned in August.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard enough for a New York City museum outside Manhattan to generate continuing support among visitors and donors, let alone raise money for a major building expansion.

headline: Review: These Short Stories Ask, How Does Technology Affect Us?
abstract: “Children of the New World,” by Alexander Weinstein imagines the world and technology evolving in complex and morally challenging ways.
lead_paragraph: In 1974, the philosopher Robert Nozick proposed a thought experiment that launched a thousand stoner bull sessions.

headline: Perform an Inverted Feat
abstract: Jacob Stulberg brings back childhood memories.
lead_paragraph: Is there anyone who hasn’t played the schoolyard game or sung the nursery rhyme, “London Bridge is Falling Down”?

headline: The Unintended Consequences of Taking a Hard Line on School Discipline
abstract: “Zero tolerance” policies in schools have resulted in the suspension of three million students each year, and are shown to have a disproportionate effect on minority students.
lead_paragraph: It did not take long for school safety agents in New York to find their first gun of the new school year. Day 1 had barely begun at a Brooklyn high school last month when the officers stopped a 15-year-old student who had stowed a loaded .22-caliber pistol in his backpack and thought he could pass it through a metal scanner.

headline: How Donald Trump Turned the Tax Code Into a Giant Tax Shelter
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Tax', 'Corporate Taxes', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: If Mr. Trump’s pattern of generating losses and using them to offset other income has continued, as seems likely, it’s obvious why he has not released his tax returns: because he hasn’t paid any taxes.
lead_paragraph: Now we know: Donald J. Trump racked up losses so huge in the early 1990s that he wouldn’t have had to pay federal or New York State income tax on nearly a billion dollars in income.

headline: Alicia Machado vs. Donald Trump’s Machismo
abstract: For the former Miss Universe from beauty pageant-crazy Venezuela, sexism and fat-shaming would be all too familiar.
lead_paragraph: Venezuela isn’t only the country with the most Miss Universe winners, a whopping seven crowned since 1979. It is also fanatical about the contest in ways that run deep in the nation’s culture. The 1996 winner, Alicia Machado, with whom Donald J. Trump has been keeping up a very public feud, is considered a dissenter in that culture, in which she is both cherished and vilified.

headline: One Season Ends and Another Begins: Baseball Playoff Matchups Are Set
abstract: The postseason will begin on Tuesday with the American League wild-card game between Baltimore and Toronto. The Mets host the Giants on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The baseball gods spend six months twisting the sport into a knotty lump. No one knows quite how to untangle it, and then the final week zips by. All those possibilities, resolved just like that. The season rushes to the end.

headline: Rudy Giuliani, Continuing Rebuke of Hillary Clinton, Says ‘Everybody’ Commits Infidelity
abstract: Mr. Giuliani’s remarks, on NBC’s “Meet the Press,” were the latest in a string of attacks on the Clintons, and struck many people as hypocritical.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, a former New York mayor and an ally of Donald J. Trump’s, suggested on Sunday that “everybody” commits infidelity, setting off a backlash on Twitter.
