keywords: ['Federal Lands', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: After Ammon and Ryan Bundy staged an armed takeover of an Oregon wildlife sanctuary in January, their call to shift federal land to local control has softened to a whisper.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — It has been a difficult few months for the Bundys.

headline: Colombia Peace Deal Is Defeated, Leaving a Nation in Shock
keywords: ['Referendums', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Voters narrowly rejected an agreement, signed just days before by the president and rebel leaders, that would have ended the country’s 52-year civil war.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — A Colombian peace deal that the president and the country’s largest rebel group had signed just days before was defeated in a referendum on Sunday, leaving the fate of a 52-year war suddenly uncertain.

headline: Deutsche Bank’s Appetite for Risk Throws Off Its Balance
abstract: Deutsche has cultivated bankers with expertise in cutting-edge financial instruments, but that could be a liability in today’s market.
lead_paragraph: The global banking giants — think of JPMorgan Chase or HSBC — make a nice return by capturing their share of the trillions of dollars that course through financial markets each day.

headline: The Online Video View: We Can Count It, but Can We Count on It?
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Social Media', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: A push is underway to standardize some forms of measurement across websites that host video, information that is now largely self-reported.
lead_paragraph: ONE OF THE great promises of online videos was the potential to measure precisely how effective they were: Audiences reported not through inexact ratings and surveys but directly, down to the person and the millisecond he or she spent watching.

headline: On Twitter, Hate Speech Bounded Only by a Character Limit
keywords: ['Cyberharassment', 'Social Media', 'Censorship', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: Founded on the ideas of openness and free speech, Twitter pulses with venom, much of it from pseudonymous accounts — the white hoods of our time.
lead_paragraph: If you go by what some Twitter users have to say, it’s a wonder I can string together a sentence. I don’t know how I ever manage to get myself to the office given what a “dumb ass” I am — a Jew, no less, and someone who soils his pants out of fear of a Trump presidency. And if you don’t believe that last bit, someone using a pseudonymous Twitter account was kind enough to provide a graphic photograph of the supposed soiling, but not his or her actual name, because it’s just so much easier to hurl bile while cowering behind anonymity.

headline: For Mahmoud Abbas, a Gesture. For Critics, a Betrayal.
abstract: Attending Shimon Peres’s funeral has brought heavy backlash to Mr. Abbas from within his own party, across social media and in the Palestinian streets.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, what was intended as a gesture of respect for a man of peace has brought him anything but peace back home.

headline: N.J. Transit Engineer Has No Memory of Fatal Train Crash, Officials Say
abstract: The engineer, Thomas Gallagher, also told investigators that the train was traveling about 10 miles an hour when it entered Hoboken Terminal, contradicting initial reports that it was moving faster.
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J. — The engineer of the New Jersey Transit train that crashed into Hoboken Terminal on Thursday, killing one person and injuring more than 100 others during the busy morning commute, felt well rested and was unaware of any mechanical problems in the moments before the accident, federal investigators said on Sunday.

abstract: Fox Searchlight has aimed a grass-roots campaign at churches, schools and pockets of political influence to ease the provocative film into communities on edge.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The coming film “The Birth of a Nation,” which recounts a violent 1831 slave rebellion and includes scenes that evoke present-day outrage over fatal police shootings of black men, has been marketed as an urgent call to action.

headline: Disney’s Hot Streak Stalls, Prompting Rumors That It’s Looking to Grow
abstract: Robert Iger, chief of the mass media company, has a history of reinvigorating the company by making deals, but despite a string of good decisions, shares are dipping and investors are getting antsy.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — This is new territory for Robert A. Iger.

keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A prominent Dutch photojournalist who had once been taken hostage by Islamist extremists in Syria was fatally shot on Sunday by an Islamic State sniper in the coastal city of Surt, a Libyan government spokesman said.

headline: Ailing Obama Health Care Act May Have to Change to Survive
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: With plans too expensive and inaccessible for many, the law will almost certainly need to evolve. The election is likely to determine how.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fierce struggle to enact and carry out the Affordable Care Act was supposed to put an end to 75 years of fighting for a health care system to insure all Americans. Instead, the law’s troubles could make it just a way station on the road to another, more stable health care system, the shape of which could be determined on Election Day.

headline: Vin Scully’s Final Call: ‘I Have Said Enough for a Lifetime’
abstract: Vin Scully closed his 67-year career as the Los Angeles Dodgers’ broadcaster.
lead_paragraph: After 67 baseball seasons behind the microphone, Vin Scully delivered his final words as the Dodgers’ play-by-play announcer on Sunday afternoon in San Francisco. The Dodgers had already won the National League West title, so the game meant more to the Giants, who clinched a wild-card berth with a 7-1 win.

headline: Photos: Valentino Spring 2017 Collection.
abstract: The back story was baroque and involved (as usual) and connected Brancusi and portraits of London youth from the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: The back story was baroque and involved (as usual) and connected Brancusi and portraits of London youth from the 1970s.

headline: A Death on Staten Island Highlights Heroin’s Place in ‘Mainstream Society’
abstract: The fatal overdose of Jonathan Ayers, 27, was the latest in a record number of heroin deaths in the borough. With his diary, he left behind a chronicle of his addiction.
lead_paragraph: The man entered the Red Robin restaurant inside the Staten Island Mall two minutes after 6 p.m. on a Friday. He walked straight past the booths and tables and entered the men’s room.

headline: Kashif, R&B Singer, Songwriter and Producer, Dies at 59
abstract: A deft experimentalist, Kashif was in the stylistic vanguard of R&B in the 1980s and played a key role in the creation of Whitney Houston’s earliest recordings.
lead_paragraph: Kashif, whose contributions as a singer, producer and songwriter were vital to the post-disco development of R&B in the 1980s, and who played a crucial role in the creation of Whitney Houston’s earliest recordings, died on Sept. 25 at his home in the Playa del Rey neighborhood of Los Angeles. He was 59.

headline: How Hillary Clinton Grappled With Bill Clinton’s Infidelity, and His Accusers
abstract: Bill Clinton’s 1992 presidential campaign used aggressive tactics to combat claims about his extramarital conduct. Here is a look at Mrs. Clinton’s role.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton was campaigning for her husband in January 1992 when she learned of the race’s newest flare-up: Gennifer Flowers had just released tapes of phone calls with Bill Clinton to back up her claim they had had an affair.

headline: Pope Francis Notes Azerbaijan’s Religious Tolerance, Not Rights Abuses
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Religion and Belief', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The pope focused on diplomacy in meetings with leaders of other faiths, and the nation’s president, later expounding on other topics, like advice for American Catholic voters.
lead_paragraph: BAKU, Azerbaijan — Pope Francis on Sunday finished his visit to the conflict-torn Caucasus region with a stop in Azerbaijan, a predominantly Shiite Muslim country, where he pleaded with leaders of all religious faiths to leave future generations “a better world than the one we have received.”

headline: Yankees Give Mark Teixeira a Handshake and Embrace the Future
abstract: The team bid farewell to Teixeira, who battled injuries in the final season of his career. Now its rebuilding effort goes into full effect.
lead_paragraph: When there was one out in the top of the seventh inning, Tyler Austin emerged from the Yankees’ dugout with his glove in hand and jogged to first base. He was there to replace Mark Teixeira.

headline: Fate Catches Up to a Cultural Revolution Museum in China
abstract: A memorial site, a labor of love and loss that took decades to open, has been covered with propaganda posters and shut down after 11 years.
lead_paragraph: SHANTOU, China — The idea to build China’s first museum dedicated to the Cultural Revolution — the political campaign begun by Mao Zedong that killed more than a million people — was always risky.

headline: Review: A Minor Brian Friel Play, With 2 Major Performances
abstract: “Afterplay,” in its New York debut, could seem slight were it not for the superb pairing of Dermot Crowley and Dearbhla Molloy in this Irish Rep production.
lead_paragraph: Loneliness is never far away and the past is always close by in “Afterplay,” Brian Friel’s melancholy, pocket-size play at the Irish Repertory Theater. Though there are just two characters onstage, neither can take a step without bumping into an old regret.

headline: The Mets and Noah Syndergaard Ready for the Giants and Madison Bumgarner
abstract: A loss to the Phillies marked the end of the Mets’ regular season. A high-stakes duel comes on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — As the Mets packed quickly in the visitors’ clubhouse at Citizens Bank Park after Sunday’s meaningless 5-2 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies, the televisions were off. The Mets already knew that the San Francisco Giants had a large lead on the Los Angeles Dodgers in their season finale and were poised to claim the remaining National League wild-card spot. They had to suspect what was coming.

abstract: Musicians in the orchestra agreed to a three-year contract on Sunday. They had walked off the job two days earlier, just before a season-opening gala, upset over pay and benefits.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia sound will sound again.

headline: ‘Westworld’ Series Premiere: Life Finds a Way
abstract: Dense with information and emotion, the series premiere of “Westworld” indicates that we’re in for a pretty grim show.
lead_paragraph: The 1973 sci-fi/western “Westworld” was the feature filmmaking debut of Michael Crichton, who wrote and directed the film soon after having established himself as a genre novelist, mostly under a pseudonym. The premise of his breakthrough novel, 1969’s “The Andromeda Strain,” about an alien microorganism that evolves to threaten humanity, served as the DNA for many of the fictions that made him a household name. In Crichton’s alarmist science-fiction, one small glitch in the system can trigger irreversible chaos on a mass scale, and he rarely passed up the opportunity to send his readers into a panic.

headline: Colombians Around New York Vote on Peace Accord
abstract: Colombians in New York and New Jersey were among those who voted Sunday on a peace deal between the Colombian government and the country’s largest rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as FARC, that unexpectedly went down to defeat.
lead_paragraph: Colombians in New York and New Jersey were among those who voted Sunday on a peace deal between the Colombian government and the country’s largest rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as FARC, that unexpectedly went down to defeat.

headline: Men Who Found Bomb Were Following a New York Tradition
abstract: Two men who took a rolling bag on West 27th Street in Chelsea, possibly disabling the bomb inside, were following a long tradition of repurposing items discarded on city streets.
lead_paragraph: It was an odd side story to the bombing in New York last month: Two passers-by spotted a bag on West 27th Street in Chelsea, opened it, removed the pressure cooker inside and took the bag with them. In doing so, the authorities have said, they may have defused a second bomb.

headline: ‘Fear the Walking Dead’ Season 2 Finale: All Thumbs
abstract: The “Fear the Walking Dead” season finale was fine, but the penultimate episode delivered possibly the most gruesome zombie death yet.
lead_paragraph: So, how about those thumbs?

headline: 9 Times Donald Trump Complained About Taxes
abstract: On Twitter, Mr. Trump has denounced tax avoiders, complained about misuse of his own tax dollars and warned of the significant pain that paying taxes had caused him or others.
lead_paragraph: The revelation on Saturday that Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, could have avoided paying taxes on nearly a billion dollars in income over two decades drew criticism and commentary from around the country. Democrats seized on the news to discredit Mr. Trump’s supposed business acumen — the tax opportunity stemmed from a $916 million business loss in 1995 — and criticized his commitment to working-class taxpayers. But Mr. Trump’s campaign and his allies were quick to defend his tax avoidance: Only a genius businessman, they said, could have worked the tax code to such advantage.

headline: Without Tom Brady, New England Patriots Crash Back to Reality
abstract: With Jacoby Brissett at quarterback, the Patriots failed to score against Rex Ryan’s Bills.
lead_paragraph: In New England’s final game without Tom Brady at quarterback, reality finally intruded on the Patriots’ dream start to the season. Jacoby Brissett played like a rookie, and every break seemed to go against New England, and they fell to the Buffalo Bills, 16-0, on Sunday.

headline: LeBron James, Calling for Hope and Unity, Endorses Hillary Clinton
abstract: The N.B.A. star said on Sunday that Mrs. Clinton would champion children’s causes and “address the violence” in African-American communities.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James, who last season led the Cleveland Cavaliers to their first N.B.A. championship, endorsed Hillary Clinton for president on Sunday.

The mayor of Paris condemned the attack, and a police spokesman said that investigators were treating it as a serious crime.

abstract: American officials said resources were being diverted to Kunduz, while the Taliban made gains in a separate assault in Helmand Province in the south.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban overran central neighborhoods in the critical Afghan provincial capital of Kunduz on Monday, planting their flag in the city’s main roundabout and shaking the Afghan government in a repeat of the insurgents’ assault on the city a year ago.

headline: The Case for Bureaucracy
keywords: ['Taxation', 'Government Employees', 'Tax Evasion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: We need more professionals in government, not fewer.
lead_paragraph: In a recent speech, Donald J. Trump revived a Republican plan to reduce the federal work force in part by replacing only some of the employees who retire as a way to pay for increased military spending and to avoid exceeding limits on the size of the federal budget. He also said he wanted to raise money by eliminating waste, collecting unpaid taxes and stopping improper tax payments.

headline: Ushering in a Safe, Driverless Future
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Editorials']
abstract: Voluntary guidelines for self-driving cars are a good start, but the government will eventually need to develop mandatory regulations.
lead_paragraph: The idea of getting into a car that drives itself — and may not even have a steering wheel — is enough to scare anyone who’s had a bad experience on the road or with technology. Those fears were made all the more real by a fatal crash involving a Tesla Model S that was traveling on autopilot in May. But if regulators and carmakers get it right, driverless cars have the potential to save tens of thousands of lives every year.

headline: ‘Poisonous Smoke’ in Darfur
abstract: New allegations of chemical-weapons use in Darfur should stir governments and activists to seek an end to the blood bath.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when “Save Darfur” was a rallying cry to end one of the cruelest conflicts in Africa. In 2010, the International Criminal Court charged Sudan’s president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, with genocide for his army’s conduct in the rebellious region of Darfur, and the United Nations deployed a huge peacekeeping force to the region.

headline: Trump’s Fellow Travelers
abstract: Profiles in cowardice and fecklessness.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has just had an extraordinarily bad week, and Hillary Clinton an extraordinarily good one; betting markets now put Mrs. Clinton’s odds of winning almost as high as they were just after the Democratic convention. But both Mrs. Clinton’s virtues and Mr. Trump’s vices have been obvious all along. How, then, did the race manage to get so close on the eve of the debate?

headline: Donald Trump: Terroristic Man-Toddler
abstract: He’s an immature bully who lashes out when he should be embarrassed.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is a domestic terrorist; only his form of terror doesn’t boil down to blowing things up. He’s the 70-year-old toddler who knows nearly nothing, hurls insults, has simplistic solutions for complex problems and is quick to throw a tantrum. Also, in case you didn’t know it, this toddler is mean to girls and is a bit of a bigot.

headline: A Crippled Supreme Court’s New Term
abstract: Seven months after President Obama nominated Merrick Garland, the court remains short-handed and unable to decide the nation’s most pressing issues.
lead_paragraph: This is American politics in 2016: the normalization of the deeply abnormal, the collapse of customs of behavior and respect, and the creation of an environment so toxic and polarized that the nation’s leaders struggle to carry out the most basic tasks of government.

headline: Update the Nobel Prizes
abstract: The Nobel Prizes fail to recognize the seismic shifts science has undergone since the awards were conceived in the late 19th century.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-1960s, Robert Paine, a scientist at the University of Washington in Seattle, discovered a hidden organizing principle in the coastal ecosystem he was studying. When a certain species of starfish was present, a panoply of algae, limpets, barnacles, anemones and mussels lived in delicate, dynamic balance. But when he removed the starfish and tossed them into the ocean, that balance collapsed and one kind of mussel took over.

headline: If War Can Have Ethics, Wall Street Can, Too
abstract: The calls for a “moral economy” should not be dismissed as idealism.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a decade after one of the most devastating financial collapses in modern history, Wall Street appears as corrupt as ever. Evidence is not hard to come by — most recently, the Wells Fargo scandal, in which employees of the company, spurred by perverse incentive structures, opened two million fraudulent accounts in their customers’ names. The bank had put intense pressure on employees to meet sales goals; some employees who reported the wrongdoing were fired, along with 5,300 more, after the scandal broke. All this is but one reminder of how far major actors in the economy have strayed from any reasonable standard of moral behavior.

abstract: For decades, being Latino in Florida almost always meant being Republican. But the demographic mix is changing, and many now register as Democrats or independents.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — For decades, being Latino in Florida almost always meant being Republican. Miami was the undisputed capital of Cuban exiles who had fled the Communist government — they were most of the state’s Latinos — and by the 1980s a large majority had registered with the Republican Party.

headline: President Obama, the Ultimate Tourist, Ticks Down His Bucket List
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Perhaps more than his predecessors, Mr. Obama has seized the opportunity as the world’s most powerful leader to see the world’s most amazing sights.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Snorkeling in the crystal-blue Pacific waters off Midway Island. Check. Strolling through the enigmatic columns of Stonehenge. Check. Visiting the Bob Marley Museum in Jamaica, the pyramids in Egypt and the Great Wall of China. Check, check and check.

abstract: The Anti-Defamation League has added a once innocuous frog meme to its list of hate symbols.

abstract: The combined company would be worth about $6 billion based on market capitalization and would have a diversified and global presence.
lead_paragraph: The Janus Capital Group and the Henderson Group, a large London-based investment manager, said on Monday that they would merge in an all-stock deal that would create an asset manager with greater global scale and about $320 billion of assets under management.

headline: A Vibrant Life Amid the Ruins of Rio
abstract: Peter Bauza was so taken by the lives of squatters forced to live in a half-finished apartment complex in Rio de Janeiro that he moved into their struggling, yet vibrant, community.
lead_paragraph: An abandoned apartment complex in the Campo Grande neighborhood of Rio de Janeiro shocked Peter Bauza when he encountered the ghostly scene. Six large concrete shells — paused in midconstruction 30 years ago — were surrounded by mud and garbage. Yet the complex was not bereft of life: Colorful curtains covered the openings where windows should have been, hinting that the buildings were occupied.

headline: Vin Scully’s Last Time on the Air for the Dodgers Is Another Solo Flight
abstract: Scully wrapped up his 67-year career as the voice of the team by broadcasting a loss at San Francisco, where Willie Mays was present for the dedication of a plaque in Scully’s honor.
lead_paragraph: Vin Scully’s final game on Sunday was something close to a miracle in sportscasting — an 88-year-old man performing a solo act, conversing with us for more than three hours, keeping track of the game while telling stories, invoking memories and reminding us that he did this single job for 67 consecutive seasons.

headline: Need to Land a Plane? In Australia, They Break Out the Toilet Paper
abstract: For the Royal Flying Doctor Service to arrive and land on a remote runway at night, about 30 cans with flaming rolls sometimes have to be lined up.
lead_paragraph: It’s quite a sight to herald the arrival of a lifesaving doctor: 30 flaming rolls of toilet paper.

headline: The Cultural Revolution in Tibet: A Photographic Record
abstract: The writer Tsering Woeser interviewed people who appeared in photographs her father, a People’s Liberation Army officer, took during the upheaval.
lead_paragraph: In 1999, the Tibetan writer Tsering Woeser came across Wang Lixiong’s book “Sky Burial: The Fate of Tibet.” On finishing it, she sent Mr. Wang photographs taken by her father, who was with the People’s Liberation Army when it entered Tibet in the 1950s and documented the early years of the Cultural Revolution in Lhasa in the 1960s. Mr. Wang wrote back, saying, “It’s not for me, as a non-Tibetan, to use these photos to reveal history. That task can only be yours.”

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal Budget (US)']

headline: Newt Gingrich Says Trump Can Win if He Makes ‘Real Change’

lead_paragraph: The former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, a top adviser to and supporter of Donald J. Trump, is openly pleading with him to modulate his style, saying that he is at risk of gravely wounding his candidacy.

headline: The Two Mysteries of Medicare
abstract: Traditional Medicare spending growth has slowed, bucking historical trends and expectations. But it would be helpful to know why.
lead_paragraph: A growing proportion of Medicare beneficiaries are opting out of the government-run insurance program. They are instead choosing a private plan alternative, one of the Medicare Advantage plans. The strength of this trend defies predictions from the Congressional Budget Office, and nobody can fully explain it.

headline: The Trump Possibility
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It’s the last chance to prevent a lazy and limited man who lies and cheats and thinks he has “great genes” from demeaning the Oval Office.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is a thug. He’s a thug who talks gibberish, and lies, and cheats, and has issues, to put it mildly, with women. He’s lazy and limited and he has an attention span of a nanosecond. He’s a “gene believer” who thinks he has “great genes” and considers the German blood, of which he is proud, “great stuff.” Mexicans and Muslims, by contrast, don’t make the cut.

headline: Men Get Osteoporosis, Too
abstract: Men are more likely than women to be permanently disabled by osteoporosis and twice as likely to die.
lead_paragraph: Listen, men, this is important, important to your current and future health and perhaps your life. Osteoporosis is not just a woman’s disease. Men get it too, albeit some years later in life than most women.

abstract: Marvel Comics and ABC News teamed up on this project, a free download that chronicles a real-life Syrian’s world in Madaya, Syria.
lead_paragraph: “Today our one meal was rice and bean soup. Our bodies are no longer used to eating.”

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Veterans', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Cyberattacks from foreign governments “constitute one of our most critical national security concerns,” Mr. Trump told a group of military veterans in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: HERNDON, Va. — Donald J. Trump on Monday called for strengthening the nation’s defenses against cyberattacks, saying that as president he would create a joint law enforcement task force to handle both cybersecurity as well as offensive cyberwarfare.

headline: America’s Gray Ghosts: The Disappearing Caribou
abstract: A herd in the Selkirk Mountains near the Canadian border is down to about a dozen, threatened by wolves and a larger problem: development.
lead_paragraph: BONNERS FERRY, Idaho — The only caribou left in the contiguous United States are here in northern Idaho where they number about a dozen and live deep in the forests of the jagged Selkirk Mountains, near the Canadian border. Because they are so rarely seen, the caribou — America’s version of reindeer — are known as gray ghosts.

headline: 1941: British Rations to Rise
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The United States decides it will send more food rations to Britain, especially of sugar and fat, during World War II in October 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The people of Great Britain will get four more ounces of sugar and two more ounces of fat every week beginning Nov. 17, thanks to supplies received recently from the United States, it was announced here today [Oct. 2]. The planned increases were made known to the House of Commons by Major Gwilym Lloyd George, son of former Prime Minister David Lloyd George.

lead_paragraph: As part of our Civil Conversation Challenge, we have opened student forums on some of the biggest issues dividing Americans this campaign season.

headline: Montreal’s Pit Bull Ban Is Suspended Until Wednesday
abstract: Critics of the new rules say the dogs are being unfairly singled out, and a lawsuit has been filed against the regulations.
lead_paragraph: A Canadian judge on Monday temporarily suspended a new Montreal law that would have prevented residents from adopting or buying pit bulls and would have required anyone who already owns one of the dogs to register the animal, the Associated Press reported.

headline: Donald Trump Trashes Nafta. But Unwinding It Would Come at a Huge Cost.
keywords: ['North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Abandoning the free-trade deal with America’s neighbors would mean upending major industries and a generation’s worth of economic integration.
lead_paragraph: When you buy an “American-made” car, you are probably buying a car that has an immensely complicated mix of components that were also made in Mexico and Canada. The same is true for many electronics, and advanced textiles like carpeting. The beef in your grocery store might be from a cow that was fattened and slaughtered in the United States, but that was very likely born across the border in Mexico.

headline: California Today: A Shift in the Child Sex Trafficking Trade
abstract: Monday: Measures shield victims of sex trafficking, residents battle a timber company over water rights, and Vin Scully says farewell.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Trump’s Tax (Avoidance) Plan
abstract: He is running for president partly to help more wealthy people be like him – and avoid paying taxes.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: Bob Bradley Joins Swansea as Premier League’s First American Manager
abstract: Bradley, who impressed Swansea City officials with his experience, his sense of purpose and his “leadership qualities,” was appointed to replace Francesco Guidolin.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Bob Bradley’s answer to one question, in particular, stood out. As Swansea City’s owners conducted a handful of discreet interviews with potential replacements for Francesco Guidolin as manager, they asked each candidate for a detailed explanation of how, precisely, he might set the team up for his first game in charge, at Arsenal on Oct. 15.

headline: Remembering Sonia Rykiel, in Fashion’s Own Words
abstract: As the French designer’s house prepares its first runway show since her death, former models, editors and retailers recall her style.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A little more than a month ago, Sonia Rykiel, she of the pyramid of red hair and the famous “poor boy” sweaters, died from complications of Parkinson’s disease. She had been a trailblazer in her own cast, who stocked her shops with literature as well as striped knitwear; who designed for women’s real lives, not just for their fantasy lives. Her clothes favored function: They reversed to become new outfits and came with straps to be carried if not worn. “They are clothes for everyday life,” she said in 1987.

headline: The Problem With the Islamic Apocalypse
abstract: Too many Muslims, not just radicals, believe that the end times are near. They should instead focus on this lifetime.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The cover of the most recent issue of Dabiq, the slick magazine that the Islamic State distributes online, shows an image of a jihadist fighter with the group’s notorious black flag behind him. He appears to be on the roof of a church, knocking over a cross. Below him, a headline reads, “Break the Cross.”

headline: From Mondale to Palin, the Hits From Past Vice-Presidential Debates
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: As Gov. Mike Pence and Senator Tim Kaine prepare to take the stage, we take a look back at how some of their vice-presidential debate predecessors have fared.
lead_paragraph: Vice-presidential debates tend not to get the same billing as the top of the ticket ones, but that does not mean they don’t matter.

headline: Death Penalty Loses Majority Support for First Time in 45 Years
abstract: A recent poll shows that only 49 percent of Americans support capital punishment, down from a peak of 80 percent in 1994.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in almost half a century, support for the death penalty has dipped below 50 percent in the United States.

abstract: Indonesia’s capital is working to dredge its network of rivers and canals, long blocked with garbage and a central contributor to chronic flooding.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Standing at his post at a floodgate in the middle of Jakarta, Bejo Santoso says he has seen it all.

headline: Vladimir Putin Exits Nuclear Security Pact, Citing ‘Hostile Actions’ by U.S.
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Citing a “radically changed environment” of hostility and threats, Mr. Putin withdrew from a 2000 agreement on the disposal of plutonium.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Saying relations with the United States have deteriorated in a “radically changed environment,” President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia withdrew Monday from a landmark nuclear security agreement, in a troubling sign that the countries’ cooperation in a range of nuclear areas could be threatened.

headline: Outrage Over Fish Kill in Vietnam Simmers 6 Months Later
keywords: ['Fishing, Commercial', 'Water Pollution', 'Chemicals', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: Thousands of demonstrators swarmed a steel factory in Ha Tinh Province over the weekend, echoing the street protests in the country’s major cities in April.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Six months after a chemical spill killed tons of fish and devastated fishing communities along Vietnam’s central coast, anger over the episode is still raw, posing a challenge for a government that has struggled to address it.

headline: Judges Who Are Elected Like Politicians Tend to Act Like Them
keywords: ['Elections, Courts and the Judiciary', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. of the Supreme Court has advised all judges to ignore public sentiment, but studies have found that elections can affect judicial behavior.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “Judges are not politicians, even when they come to the bench by way of the ballot,” Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wrote last year in a case from Florida that took a small step toward insulating elected judges from political pressure.

headline: Millions at Risk of Deportation as Justices Refuse to Rehear Case
abstract: The Obama administration had argued that the immigration case, which left the Supreme Court deadlocked at 4 to 4, should be resolved by a nine-member court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A short-handed Supreme Court on Monday turned down a request from the Obama administration to reconsider a major immigration decision, dooming for now President Obama’s plan to spare millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation.

headline: Bass Pro Shops to Acquire Cabela’s, a Rival Outdoor Retailer
abstract: The deal to buy Cabela’s for $5.5 billion in cash will merge two companies known for selling hunting and fishing gear to outdoor sports enthusiasts.
lead_paragraph: Across much of the United States, it is not just a credit card; it is a Cabela’s credit card.

headline: 1966: Ibos Saved From Massacre
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: Men from the Ibo tribe are saved from massacre in northern Nigeria in October 1966.
lead_paragraph: NIGERIA — An emergency airlift was organized in Nigeria today [Oct. 3] to rescue hunted Ibo tribesmen from widespread tribal violence in the Northern Region. More than 1,000 Ibos from the neighbouring Eastern Region have been killed in week-long rioting throughout the north, and the final death toll may climb above 2,000.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear a case about whether the N.C.A.A. is violating federal antitrust laws by restricting what college athletes can earn.

headline: Hammond Addresses ‘Brexit’ Turbulence With Hints of Policy Shift
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Referendums', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: The chancellor of the Exchequer promised to take “whatever steps are necessary to protect this economy” as the country prepares to leave the European Union.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, England — Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, Philip Hammond, on Monday promised investment in infrastructure projects and pledged to step in to mitigate “turbulence” resulting from the country’s decision to withdraw from the European Union, a significant shift in British economic policy.

headline: This Is Probably the Least You’ll Weigh All Year. Sorry.
abstract: This week and next are the low points, according to data from wireless health-monitoring scales in the United States, Japan and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Congratulations. If you are anything like the Americans in a study by a Cornell University professor, your weight will reach an annual low this week or the next. But don’t get too excited — you’ll most likely get fatter soon.

headline: At 0-4, the Browns Are Alone at the Bottom
abstract: Cleveland, which hasn’t been blown off the field but is the only remaining winless team in the N.F.L., will next play the Patriots as Tom Brady makes his return.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday at 1 p.m. Eastern, Tom Brady will make his long-awaited return to the New England Patriots after a four-game suspension for his role in the Deflategate scandal.

lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

lead_paragraph: MAUNA KEA, Hawaii — Little lives up here except whispering hopes and a little bug called Wekiu.

headline: The Thriving Designers Who Dominate Beirut’s Flourishing Scene
abstract: Despite the area’s chaos, or perhaps because of it, creativity thrives in this Middle Eastern metropolis.
lead_paragraph: Beirut, in the words of one designer I talked to recently, is like a third world country that’s put on some makeup.

headline: Paris Fashion Shows: Stella McCartney, Givenchy and More
abstract: Looks from the Stella McCartney, Givenchy, Sacai and Giambattista Valli spring 2017 shows.
lead_paragraph: Looks from the Stella McCartney, Givenchy, Sacai and Giambattista Valli spring 2017 shows.

headline: Crime and Catharsis at Givenchy and Stella McCartney
abstract: Kim Kardashian West was robbed following the Givenchy show at Paris Fashion Week, but the shows must go on, though the mood was muted — and so were the iPhones.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Fashion woke up Monday to the news that Kim Kardashian West had been the victim of armed robbers at her temporary residence in Paris. It made for an unsettling beginning to the last days of shows. Ms. Kardashian West had, after all, been something of a constant presence here until that point. On Sunday alone she popped into Balenciaga in the morning, kibitzed with Courtney Love at Givenchy in the evening (the designer Riccardo Tisci made the wedding dress for her marriage to Kanye West) and then attended a dinner hosted by Surface magazine in honor of Azzedine Alaïa, held in the designer’s kitchen. We have all been complicit in advertising those facts.

headline: Still Waiting to Hear From Yahoo
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Mail']
abstract: The company’s recent announcement of a large-scale security breach has many people asking questions.
lead_paragraph: Q. I have a Yahoo account. I have changed the password and taken other recommended security steps but I have yet to hear from Yahoo. Does the company have any obligation to inform its users of the breach? Shouldn’t Yahoo have been the first to send out information instead of letting us find out about the hacking from the news?

headline: Brand to Know: A Line of Pieces Woven From Unusual Materials
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Textiles', 'Coats and Jackets', 'Wool and Woolen Goods', 'Art']
abstract: Amy Revier, an American artist who works in London, uses bamboo, paper and stainless steel to make coats, jackets and other garments.
lead_paragraph: “What I’m really interested in is actually being defiant,” says Amy Revier, a Texan artist who has made north London her home for the last five years. She is sitting by a rack of the muted clothes that she weaves by hand, at the London concept store Hostem — and yet, she doesn’t see herself as a fashion designer at all.

headline: Turkey Detains Brother of Fethullah Gulen, Cleric Accused of Plotting Coup
abstract: Kutbettin Gulen was said to have been arrested in the west of the country in connection with membership in an “armed terror organization.”
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey has detained a brother of Fethullah Gulen, the Pennsylvania-based cleric whom the government accused of organizing a  coup attempt in July and who is now the source of a diplomatic confrontation with the United States.

headline: A Genuine Bordeaux Caviar to Pair With Champagne
abstract: Sturia, a farmed caviar from southwestern France, is now available in New York.
lead_paragraph: Farmed caviar has been produced in the Bordeaux region of France for decades. One brand, Sturia, has finally made its way to the United States. Sturia offers several grades of baeri, the Siberian sturgeon caviar, delineated by age. The youngest is the mildest tasting; the flavors become stronger and earthier as the eggs mature. The company is also selling genuine osetra, a somewhat nuttier and paler variety, with a very good texture: 30 grams (about an ounce), from $100 for the Primeur (young) baeri to $162 for genuine osetra at Le District, Brookfield Place, 225 Liberty Street (West Street), 212-981-8588, ledistrict.com, sturia.com.

headline: As Navy Heads to Haiti, Hurricane Matthew Threatens U.S. Coast
abstract: Haiti, the country in the Caribbean least able to handle a big storm, girds for a powerful blow from Hurricane Matthew.
lead_paragraph: In its 11 a.m. update, the National Weather Service said “confidence [is] increasing” that Matthew will significantly affect the southeast coast of the United States:

headline: Haiti Braces for Catastrophe as Hurricane Matthew Makes Landfall
abstract: The Category 4 storm brought winds of up to 145 miles an hour and rainfall that could exceed three feet in some areas.
lead_paragraph: Haiti braced for a possible catastrophe on Tuesday as Hurricane Matthew, a dangerous Category 4 storm, made landfall, delivering winds of up to 145 miles an hour and rainfall that could exceed three feet in some areas.

headline: A Banquet of Chinese Experience
abstract: At the Museum of Chinese in America, an exhibition on Chinese food and identity.
lead_paragraph: An exhibition at the Museum of Chinese in America examines the immigrant and second-generation Chinese and Asian experience through food. More than 30 home cooks and professional chefs, including Ken Hom, Anita Lo, Susanna Foo, Danny Bowien and Michael Tong are profiled. Their experiences and interpretations of regional cuisines are presented through video installations, and objects illustrating the chefs’ stories are displayed on an oversize dinner table: “Sour, Sweet, Bitter, Spicy: Stories of Chinese Food and Identity in America,” Oct. 6 to March 26, 2017, Museum of Chinese in America, 215 Centre Street (Grand Street), 855-955-6622, mocanyc.org.

headline: Daily Report: Google’s Slow Response to Amazon’s Echo is a Warning
abstract: Wildly successful tech companies often can’t see the next big thing because they’re too busy making money. Even Google can be prone to this condition.
lead_paragraph: Google, for all its financial success and world-beating technology, has a problem: It often lags or is never even a player in markets it could have dominated.

headline: The Prisoners’ Paradox
abstract: After a short conversation with a guard, a prisoner thinks he is more likely to be pardoned. Could this be true? A challenge from the Futility Closet.
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge was suggested by Greg Ross, creator and curator of the Futility Closet, the online miscellany of compendious amusements. The puzzle is from the first of his two eponymous book-form compilations of closet tidbits, which I happened to pull off the bookshelf recently and completely derail an evening. Let’s try —

headline: A Brooklyn Caterer Expands
abstract: Cobblestone Catering in Boerum Hill moves to a larger space.
lead_paragraph: If you’re not hungry when you enter the new shop for Cobblestone Catering, which just moved to a larger location after 10 years, a glance at the alluring, colorful display of prepared foods will be enough to whet the appetite. How to decide among a toss of golden spaghetti squash, a verdant broccoli salad, roasted cauliflower, fried chicken, tangy Moroccan carrots, apple pastries and fruit-filled crostatas? The shop and its catering division, on the second floor of the building, are owned by Linsey Snyder Wachalter and her husband, the chef Jeremy Wachalter: Cobblestone Catering and Fine Foods, 220 Atlantic Avenue (Court Street), Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, 718-222-1661, cobblestonecatering.com.

headline: Steven Alan’s Goals: Subtlety and Quality
abstract: After more than 20 years in fashion, he has become the world’s friendly neighborhood designer and shopkeeper.
lead_paragraph: In the 22 years since he opened his first store, the designer and retailer Steven Alan has built a brand that serves as a bridge between the stalwarts (Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein) and the upstarts (Hood by Air, Public School). His line of casual, elevated pieces is sold in 32 namesake locations worldwide, with two scheduled to open in South Korea next year, and no two look alike. “We try to make each store into a neighborhood experience,” he said.

headline: An Italian-Style Aperitif With a California Twist
abstract: Bruto Americano is a brash American take on the aperitif.
lead_paragraph: The initial attack in this garnet-hued aperitif from St. George Spirits, an artisanal producer in California, is deceptively sweet. Then gradually, the complex layers of flavor unfold, ending with a bitter swagger. There are hints of citrus — Seville oranges are what the company uses — as well as herbaceous notes. It’s an American take on typical Italian aperitifs like Campari: Bruto Americano, $29.99, Astor Wines and Spirits, 212-674-7500, astorwines.com.

headline: Thai Sausages From Olympia Provisions and Pok Pok
abstract: The Portland, Ore., butcher is making sai ua sausages in collaboration with Pok Pok’s Andy Ricker.
lead_paragraph: To give that tailgate platter or an autumn stir-fry a twist, consider searing these sai ua sausages. Olympia Provisions in Portland, Ore., makes the Thai links in collaboration with Andy Ricker of the Pok Pok restaurants there and in New York. Along with fish sauce, lemongrass, garlic and shallots, these sausages are infused with galangal, chiles and lime leaf. Asian napa cabbage slaw would be great to serve alongside: Olympia Provisions Sai Ua Sausage, $10 for three 4-ounce sausages, olympiaprovisions.com.

headline: Nobel Awarded to Japanese Biologist
keywords: ['Nobel Prizes', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'ANATOMY AND PHYSIOLOGY', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Fellow Japanese reacted enthusiastically after Dr. Yoshinori Ohsumi was awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine on Monday for his pioneering work on how cells recycle their content.
lead_paragraph: Fellow Japanese reacted enthusiastically after Dr. Yoshinori Ohsumi was awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine on Monday for his pioneering work on how cells recycle their content.

headline: A Cold-Brew Coffee to Drink Year Round
abstract: The bottled coffee, from Zingerman’s in Ann Arbor, Mich., is smooth, strong and shelf-stable.
lead_paragraph: Cold-brew coffee was big this summer, and as fall begins the popularity of coffee made this way, best suited for serving iced, shows no signs of slacking off. This smooth, strong, full-bodied cold brew is bottled without preservatives or sweeteners by Zingerman’s Coffee Company, a division of the diverse food emporium in Ann Arbor, Mich. A special process gives it a year’s shelf-life unrefrigerated (before opening). Well-made cold brew has minimal acidity. This one fits the profile: Zingerman’s Cold Brew Coffee, $3.99 for a 10-ounce bottle; a case of 16, $56, zingermanscoffee.com.

headline: Why Colombia’s Peace Deal With the FARC Failed
abstract: Colombians defied opinion polls on Sunday by voting against a peace agreement to end 52 years of war with the country’s largest rebel group, the FARC.
lead_paragraph: Colombians defied opinion polls on Sunday by voting against a peace agreement to end 52 years of war with the country’s largest rebel group, the FARC.

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
abstract: We asked readers — without any context — to caption a photo that ran in The New York Times. Here’s how they responded.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

headline: Shimon Peres: The Peacemaker Who Wasn’t
abstract: The true legacy of Shimon Peres is as the dove who gave cover to Israel’s hawks.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Now that the funeral of Shimon Peres, the former Israeli president and prime minister, is over and the effusive praise of world leaders has subsided, it’s time for a critical look at his legacy. While many remember him as a courageous and tireless advocate for peace, Palestinians recall a different man — one who was very good at talking peace but not so good at walking the walk.

headline: Hermès: Spring 2017
abstract: Designs by Nadège Vanhee-Cybulski for spring 2017.
lead_paragraph: Designs by Nadège Vanhee-Cybulski for spring 2017.

headline: Elena Ferrante’s ‘My Brilliant Friend’ Goes From Page to Stage
abstract: The Kingston Rose Theater in London says it’ll present the first stage adaptation of the novels that made the mysterious Ms. Ferrante a global name.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A day after a New York Review of Books article about the possible real identity of the best-selling author known as Elena Ferrante, the Rose Theater Kingston  here announced Monday that it would present the first stage adaptation of the four novels that have made Ms. Ferrante an international literary name.

headline: Nutanix I.P.O. Creates Opening for Others
abstract: The warm welcome that was extended to new companies in September, combined with decreased venture-capital funding, may lead others to pull the trigger.
lead_paragraph: Nutanix, the cloud data-storage firm that made its market debut last week, has jammed open the window for initial public offerings.

headline: How to Get the Stunning Red Lips From Giambattista Valli
abstract: A bare, matte face and imprecisely painted pout evoked youthful experimentations with makeup.
lead_paragraph: The spring/summer 2017 makeup look at Giambattista Valli was a departure from the designer’s usual aesthetic in two distinct ways. First, models’ faces were matte (“Normally at Giambattista there’s always a little bit of shine somewhere,” said the makeup artist Val Garland). Second, they were devoid of color — with one exception: a tomato-red lip. “I don’t think we’ve had a red lip in years,” she noted, after finishing Gigi Hadid’s makeup.

headline: Och-Ziff May Face Consequences Beyond Fine in Bribery Case
abstract: The hedge fund may encounter collateral consequences and reputational damage after settling charges of violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.
lead_paragraph: Defendants often point to the collateral consequences of a prosecution and civil enforcement action when arguing that they should not be punished too severely. The settlement by the hedge fund Och-Ziff Capital Management and its founder, Daniel S. Och, for paying bribes to obtain natural resource deals in Africa tests how much they will endure beyond the settlement’s fines and disgorged profits.

headline: Fashion Week Photo Diary: Balenciaga, Céline and Givenchy
abstract: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in Paris on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in Paris on Sunday.

headline: A Roller Coaster Remedy for Kidney Stones?
abstract: Research shows that an amusement park ride that makes the heart leap and fingertips tingle may also help you pass small stones.
lead_paragraph: There are visceral reactions most of us expect during a roller coaster ride: a drop in the gut, a leap of the heart, a tingle in the fingertips.

headline: Shawn Mendes Is a Familiar Face at No. 1
abstract: The 18-year-old singer, whose debut album topped the Billboard chart a year ago, has returned to No. 1 with his new album, “Illuminate.”
lead_paragraph: A year and a half ago, a fresh face topped the Billboard album chart: Shawn Mendes, a 16-year-old Canadian, who had drawn a big online following with six-second cover videos before being signed to a major label, Island Records.

headline: In Upstate Congressional Race, a ‘Classic Boxers’ Match’ That Is Virtually Tied
abstract: In some ways, the race in New York’s 19th District — between the Republican John J. Faso and the Democrat Zephyr Teachout — is the presidential race turned inside out.
lead_paragraph: NEW PALTZ, N.Y. — The two candidates, current and former, stood with arms around each other, an American flag behind them, an adoring crowd before them.

headline: State Attorney General Orders Trump Foundation to Cease Raising Money in New York
abstract: Eric T. Schneiderman, the attorney general, said a charities bureau had determined that the Donald J. Trump Foundation was not registered to solicit donations under state law.
lead_paragraph: The office of the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, has issued a “notice of violation” to Donald J. Trump’s foundation, ordering it to immediately stop soliciting charitable donations in the state.

headline: Letter to Trump Foundation From New York Attorney General’s Office
abstract: The office of Eric Schneiderman, New York's attorney general, has issued a “notice of violation” to the Donald J. Trump Foundation, ordering it to immediately stop soliciting donations in New York. It said that the office's charities bureau had determined that the charity had been fund-raising in New York this year when it was not registered to do so under state law.

You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

headline: A Brief History of the Single-Elimination Wild-Card Game
abstract: With the wild-card game entering its fifth year, some trends are starting to develop. For instance, with teams using their aces, the games have on balance been low scoring.
lead_paragraph: When Major League Baseball introduced the wild-card game in 2012, it was a new phenomenon. For the first time, there would be regularly scheduled single-elimination games in the postseason.

headline: The ‘Veep’ Head Writer David Mandel Builds a Private Museum
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'Memorabilia and Souvenirs', 'Television', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: Welcome to comic geek heaven: a Los Angeles apartment stuffed with original comic-book art and ‘Star Wars’ memorabilia.
lead_paragraph: When David Mandel, the showrunner of HBO’s “Veep,” accepted the Emmy for best comedy series last month, he gave a shout-out to the old neighborhood: “This is for chubby Jews from the Upper West Side. Wherever you are, thank you.”

headline: A Lieutenant in Eradicating Smallpox Remembers the General
abstract: How Dr. Donald A. Henderson, who died in August, turned a flailing measles program into a first in medicine.
lead_paragraph: When I worked at what is now the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta in 1964, my boss, Dr. Donald A. Henderson, sent me to West Africa to help with an immunization program aimed at eradicating measles in eight countries.

headline: In Greek Warrior’s Grave, Rings of Power (and a Mirror and Combs)
abstract: Archaeologists believe that elegant gold rings and engraved gemstones were not looted from Crete, but were signs of the growth of Minoan culture from the island.
lead_paragraph: A trove of beautifully engraved gold rings and gemstones, found in the untouched grave of an ancient Greek warrior last year, were possessions from his culture, not loot from the nearby island of Crete, archaeologists now believe.

headline: Next From David Byrne: Neuroscience in an Art Gallery
abstract: The exhibition “The Institute Presents: Neurosociety” will recreate science experiments “in more entertaining or theatrical ways,” Mr. Byrne said.
lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Instead of just reading about the latest mind-bending experiments in neuroscience, David Byrne said he prefers, when possible, to participate in them. And he’s hoping others feel the same.

headline: This Store Still Needs a Name
abstract: Benjamin Albucker suffers from an exacting aesthetic sense that pushed him to open his own store. If only he could name it.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Albucker is, by his own description, an exacting, opinionated, slightly neurotic aesthete. He has a refined eye and a drive to sharpen it further.

keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Presidential Election of 2016']

abstract: Copper surfaces are valuable, but not infallible, in killing disease-causing microbes left on them.
lead_paragraph: Q. How good are copper doorknobs at protecting patients from germs in hospitals?

keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Travel and Vacations']

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Just after midnight on Monday, Kim Kardashian West left an intimate Fashion Week reception and dinner in the Marais section of Paris, at which truffled scrambled eggs, white fish and copious amounts of Champagne were served.

headline: How I Created My Very First Garden From Scratch
keywords: ['Trees and Shrubs', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Flowers and Plants']
abstract: I had gardened for years, but never planned an entire project. New York’s High Line was one inspiration for the yard around my California cottage.
lead_paragraph: MILL VALLEY, Calif. — “Remind me again why we bought this house?” my husband asked. He was standing on the front porch a few days after we finally moved into our cottage here, after the three-year odyssey of buying it, renting it out while an architect drew plans for an addition and, finally, living like nomads with various friends as the promised four months of construction stretched into six.

keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Plutonium', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Nuclear Weapons']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States on Monday suspended talks with Russia over the protracted conflict in Syria, accusing the Kremlin of joining with the Syrian Air Force in carrying out a brutal bombing campaign against the besieged city of Aleppo.

headline: Kevin Hart’s Fashion Sense Is No Joke
abstract: The comedian, actor and rapper (as Chocolate Droppa) has a mature, monochromatic look, with a touch of David Beckham.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Hart is one of the most successful comedians on earth, but his sense of style is no joke. With a new stand-up concert movie, “What Now?” out Oct. 14 and a debut album from Motown Records as his hip-hop alter ego Chocolate Droppa expected later in the fall, Mr. Hart, 37, will have plenty of opportunities to showcase his largely monochromatic look. He took a moment to discuss his five fashion favorites and the styling tip he picked up from David Beckham.

headline: Cantor Fitzgerald Gambling Affiliate Settles Investigation
abstract: The subsidiary, a large sports book runner in Las Vegas, agreed to pay about $22.5 million to settle accusations of illegal gambling and money laundering.
lead_paragraph: A business financed by Cantor Fitzgerald that became one of the biggest sports book runners in the country has agreed to pay about $22.5 million to settle allegations of illegal gambling and money laundering, authorities announced on Monday.

headline: Review: An Unsatisfying Opera (or Is It a Lecture?)
abstract: The saving grace of Donnacha Dennehy’s opera “The Hunger” is its heroine: an American witnessing Ireland’s suffering in the Great Famine.
lead_paragraph: Op-eds don’t make good operas. That much was clear from Friday’s performance of “The Hunger” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, a fully staged work by the composer Donnacha Dennehy about the Irish famine of 1845-52, in which at least one million people died and another million were driven to emigrate. The subject could make a compelling background to a drama peopled with flesh-and-blood characters. But “The Hunger” is more of a lecture than an opera: Dramatically static and musically amorphous, the work is interspersed with filmed interviews in which academics invoke the evils of capitalism and colonialism.

headline: Voices From Abortion Bill Protests
abstract: A proposal to ban abortions in Poland, even in cases of rape and when a woman’s life is in danger, sparked so-called Black Monday rallies in several European cities.
lead_paragraph: A proposal to ban abortions in Poland, even in cases of rape and when a woman’s life is in danger, sparked so-called Black Monday rallies in several European cities.

abstract: The Taliban began an assault on Kunduz, Afghanistan, on Monday and residents continued to worry about the poor security in their city.
lead_paragraph: The Taliban began an assault on Kunduz, Afghanistan, on Monday and residents continued to worry about the poor security in their city.

headline: Review: In ‘No Tomorrow,’ a Romantic Rejoinder to All the Naysayers
abstract: CW’s new comedy stars Tori Anderson as a woman in a rut who falls for a man (Joshua Sasse) who thinks the world will be destroyed in eight months and wants to seize the day.
lead_paragraph: Last year CW scored one of the big successes of the television season with the nervy-cute musical comedy “Crazy Ex-Girlfriend.” This year it’s offering another hourlong comedy about a young woman going to extremes to find what’s missing in her life, “No Tomorrow.”

abstract: An accountant, a girl on a train and Tom Cruise come to theaters this month.
lead_paragraph: An accountant, a girl on a train and Tom Cruise come to theaters this month.

headline: In Las Vegas, Rising Murders Strain a Police Force Used to Solving Them
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Police']
abstract: The city has an enviable record for clearing cases, but is fighting to keep up with the pace. “I’ve got a lot of tired people,” one officer said.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — In the seven months since Heriberto Diaz Marcial was shot and killed walking home from his job as a casino porter on the Vegas Strip, church volunteers have knocked on hundreds of doors in his neighborhood and handed out fliers seeking information. The police released blurry security footage of a gray sedan tied to his three killers. His wife, Maria Diaz, has gone on television to plead for help.

headline: Reader’s Guide to This Fall’s Big Book Awards
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'National Book Awards', 'Man Booker Prize']
abstract: A closer look at the finalists for the Booker Prize and National Book Awards, and the contenders for the Nobel Prize.
lead_paragraph: It’s that time of year when the literary world hands out its biggest prizes. Next week’s announcement of the Nobel Prize in Literature will be followed by the awarding of the Man Booker Prize later in October and the National Book Awards in November. Here’s a guide to the finalists for the honors — and the chatter about who might win the Nobel.

headline: The Problem With Google’s ‘Star Trek’ Computer
keywords: ['Artificial Intelligence', 'Chess', 'Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Google Phone', 'Privacy', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Space and Astronomy', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: An always-on computer like the one on “Star Trek” could pose privacy concerns, said a NASA engineer and “Star Trek” aficionado.
lead_paragraph: Google is hoping to develop its Assistant, a Siri-like technology to be included on the company’s new smartphones and other products, into something like the computer on “Star Trek.” For those who aren’t “Trek” fans, that would mean the Assistant could understand and execute complex spoken commands (though tasks like opening a subspace channel would have to wait for other technologies to catch up).

headline: Dabbling in Provocation at the Fall for Dance Festival
abstract: What used to feel like a celebration of dance has become more of a competition for the best audience roar — but this season, even that seemed strained.
lead_paragraph: The wow moment in most Fall for Dance Festival programs comes in a propulsive unison finale or a virtuosic solo. But last Wednesday at City Center, the “wow” was more of a “whoa” as Wendy Whelan, the esteemed ballerina, sauntered across the stage wearing only a white button-down shirt with black nylons, garters and high heels. She stopped, stared and stubbed out a cigarette on her tongue.

lead_paragraph: Sarah Burton’s designs for next spring.

lead_paragraph: Prada and Dior Homme put sailor caps and beanies on the runway, and the options don’t end there.

headline: Two Brothers, Both August Wilson Stalwarts, Play the Same Role on Opposite Coasts
abstract: Brandon and Jason Dirden discuss how their different strengths go into playing Levee, the angrily striving trumpeter in Wilson’s “Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom.”
lead_paragraph: The work of August Wilson has for years sustained Brandon and Jason Dirden, actor brothers who have found themselves turning again and again to his plays for meaning and inspiration.

headline: Roman Artifacts Found in Okinawa Castle
abstract: It’s unclear how ancient Roman coins ended up buried in the ruins of a 12th-century castle in Okinawa.
lead_paragraph: Archaeologists have found ancient Roman coins buried in the ruins of a 12th-century castle in Okinawa, and no one knows how they got there.

headline: Review: In This ‘Ring’ Cycle, Gods Dwell in an Old Theater
abstract: Our critic on David Pountney’s staging of “Das Rheingold,” the first installment in Wagner’s “Ring” cycle, at the Lyric Opera in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — David Pountney is hardly the first director to assert that his production of Wagner’s epic “Ring” cycle will focus on telling the story, rather than telling audiences what it means. Yet is it possible to tell any story without interpreting it, even inadvertently?

headline: Hillary Clinton, Seizing on Tax Returns, Says Donald Trump Embodies ‘Rigged System’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Tax', 'United States Economy', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: In Ohio, Mrs. Clinton said revelations that Mr. Trump could have avoided paying income taxes for up to 18 years showed he put “his own interests ahead of the country’s.”
lead_paragraph: TOLEDO, Ohio — Hillary Clinton seized on revelations that Donald J. Trump could have avoided paying income taxes for up to 18 years to unleash a new torrent of criticism of her opponent, saying he pretended to help working Americans even as he personified “the same rigged system he claims he will change.”

headline: Protesters in Poland Rally Against Proposal for Total Abortion Ban
abstract: As many as 24,000 Poles, dressed in black, took to the streets in Warsaw to protest the proposed legislation. “Let them have their fun,” the foreign minister said.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Despite pouring rain and a chill in the air, Anna Pietruszka-Drozdz, together with as many as 24,000 other Polish women and men, skipped work on Monday and instead came to Castle Square in Warsaw, dressed in black, to protest a sweeping new anti-abortion bill.

headline: Louise Bourgeois, in Her 90s
abstract: A new exhibition features intimate etchings made between 2006 and the artist’s death in 2010 at age 98 — along with portraits made of her during the same period.
lead_paragraph: A new exhibition features intimate etchings made between 2006 and the artist’s death in 2010 at age 98 — along with portraits made of her during the same period.

headline: In the English Countryside, Intimate Works by — and of — Louise Bourgeois
abstract: A new show of the artist’s work includes candid etchings she made in the four years before her death — and portraits by Alex Van Gelder, from the same period.
lead_paragraph: Somerset, in the west of England, is old farming country: a gently rolling, leafy landscape dotted with livestock. Here, in a suite of renovated agricultural buildings, Hauser & Wirth has its two-year-old out-of-town gallery, coupled with a working farm and a bustling art-lined restaurant serving local produce. With a salt-walled meat locker on public display and a loamy, autumnal smell floating in from surrounding pastures, the space has an earthy sensibility that might have appealed to Louise Bourgeois. The French-born, New York-based artist was noted for her forthright treatment of issues of the body and the mind; and in a series of little-known etchings now on view at the gallery-cum-country estate, she fuses the human body with botanical elements.

headline: A Milestone for Carbon Dioxide in the Atmosphere
abstract: Scripps said that levels had recently risen above 400 parts per million, and were likely to stay that way “for the indefinite future.”
lead_paragraph: Climate science reached an unhappy milestone last week. And then things went a little crazy.

headline: Review: ‘Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea,’ With a Message on the Environment
abstract: A take on a classic by Jules Verne at the New Victory Theater uses actors, props and projections to teach children and adults about threats to ocean life.
lead_paragraph: Theatergoers, there’s no need to pack scuba gear or even a snorkel mask to plunge into the ocean deep. In Craig Francis and Rick Miller’s “Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea,” a frisky adaptation of the Jules Verne sci-fi saga at the New Victory Theater, a few actors, a few more props and some extremely nifty projections send the audience right to the seafloor. Hey, look out for that squid!

headline: Maria Grazia Chiuri and the History of Women at Dior
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: With a long line of powerful women there, the heart of the French house, writes Alexander Fury, has always been female.
lead_paragraph: Gabrielle “Coco” Chanel never did things by halves. When asked her opinion on Christian Dior’s “New Look” — the shorthand for the wasp-waisted, full-skirted silhouette Dior introduced to furor, acclaim and near universal adoption in his debut collection of 1947 — she snapped: “Look how ridiculous these women are, wearing clothes by a man who doesn’t know women, never had one, and dreams of being one.”

headline: Review: ‘Rogue Heroes,’ the Birth of Britain’s Elite Special Forces
abstract: Ben Macintyre tells the story of mavericks who formed a commando unit that would become the model for special forces around the world.
lead_paragraph: Ben Macintyre’s suspenseful new book, “Rogue Heroes,” about the founding of Britain’s S.A.S. during World War II, reads like a mashup of “The Dirty Dozen” and “The Great Escape,” with a sprinkling of “Ocean’s 11” thrown in for good measure. Like earlier Macintyre books set during that war (“Double Cross: The True Story of the D-Day Spies” and “Operation Mincemeat: How a Dead Man and a Bizarre Plan Fooled the Nazis and Assured an Allied Victory”), this volume features an ensemble of eccentrics, mavericks and malcontents. And, in this case, one visionary, David Stirling, who invented an elite commando unit that would become the prototype for a new kind of modern warfare, and the model for special forces around the world, including the Navy SEALs and the Army’s Delta Force.

headline: Review: Movable Roots Jam Brings a Philadelphia Festival to New York
abstract: Whether they’re America’s house band or a living spectrum of soul to hip-hop, Roots rocks.
lead_paragraph: For a certain stripe of older fan, the Roots are exceptionalists who embody all of hip-hop’s potential as an extension of the soul music tradition, and who keep hip-hop viable as live performance. For a newer generation of fans, who come to them via their gig on Jimmy Fallon’s late-night show, they are America’s house band, polymaths who collaborate with stars on quirky viral videos and offer up musical cheers, jeers or arched eyebrows as the circumstance dictates.

headline: Donald Trump, Aleppo, FARC: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Women Shun the Maternity Smock, and Stores Race to Catch Up
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: The maternity aisle is looking more like a high-end boutique as cultural attitudes about pregnancy shift from bigger and baggier to sleeker and stretchier.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than 25 years since Demi Moore bared her pregnant belly on the cover of Vanity Fair, but retailers are finally catching up to the fact that pregnant women do not always want to hide under a muumuu.

headline: Scrutiny of Commercial Real Estate Loans Chills Small Lenders
abstract: Some local banks are unwinding or selling off property loans that are under regulators’ microscopes, and bankers say they are wary of making new loans.
lead_paragraph: Financing commercial property has been local banks’ bread-and-butter business for years, but a postcrisis push for loan growth prompted regulatory warnings about lax lending standards, and small banks are now shying away from the market.

headline: Judges Push Brevity in Briefs, and Get a Torrent of Arguments
keywords: ['Legal Profession', 'Appeals Courts (US)', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: A proposal to cut the maximum word count of appellate briefs by 1,500 words, to 12,500, had lawyers fuming.
lead_paragraph: The Constitution of the United States clocks in at 4,543 words. Yet a number of lawyers contend that 14,000 words are barely enough to lay out their legal arguments.

headline: O’Bannon Ruling Stands, but N.C.A.A.’s Status Quo May Yet Collapse
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Basketball (College)']
abstract: The Supreme Court turned down Ed O’Bannon’s case, which in the end effected little legal change but brought renewed attention to outdated rules governing college athletes.
lead_paragraph: The chances that the United States Supreme Court would ever agree to hear the O’Bannon case were always low.

headline: Protest Started by Colin Kaepernick Spreads to High School Students
keywords: ['Football', 'National Anthems', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Education (K-12)', 'Interscholastic Athletics']
abstract: Like the San Francisco 49ers quarterback, football players across the country are silently taking a knee during the national anthem to protest racism.
lead_paragraph: AURORA, Colo. — Vicqari Horton dropped a knee to the grass. The varsity choir piped out “The Star-Spangled Banner.” And in the bleachers at a sun-soaked football stadium here on Saturday, parents clenched their teeth in anger or raised their fists in support.

headline: As Maria Sharapova’s Case Winds Down, Reduced Penalty Is a Possibility
abstract: Sharapova appealed her two-year suspension for positive tests for meldonium. And since a disciplinary panel determined her violation was unintentional, Tuesday’s ruling may go in her favor.
lead_paragraph: Maria Sharapova, the Russian tennis star, received a two-year suspension from international competition for a doping violation this year. Sharapova has appealed that decision, calling it unfairly harsh. On Tuesday, her final penalty will be made public. Here is what you need to know.

headline: Four From BuzzFeed Politics Defect to CNN
abstract: Andrew Kaczynski and his team, which has made headlines unearthing audio and video on the campaign trail, leave BuzzFeed short-handed in the final weeks before the election.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Kaczynski, the BuzzFeed reporter whose scoop about Donald J. Trump’s early support for the invasion of Iraq surfaced in the presidential debate last week, is leaving to join CNN, just a month before the election.

headline: Resurrecting Colombia’s Peace Deal
abstract: There is a slim window of opportunity to get the peace process back on track if politicians are willing to compromise.
lead_paragraph: By narrowly rejecting an agreement between the government of Colombia and the nation’s largest guerrilla group, Colombian voters have thrown a four-year-long peace process into turmoil.

headline: With a Single Baseball, Seeking to Connect All 312 Hall of Famers
abstract: A New York City baseball fan has spent six years traveling with a faded ball, hoping to pay homage to all the inductees of the Baseball Hall of Fame, living and dead.
lead_paragraph: The wooden sign for Section 39 flapped in the wind and rain as Ralph Carhart walked past it and headed for a grassy expanse in Calvary Cemetery in Queens where, decades ago, poor parishioners were given charity burials in unmarked graves.

headline: With Tim Kaine and Mike Pence, Faith Is Back in the Mix
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'Religion and Belief', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: This campaign has largely been absent of the social issues that were at the heart of the country’s political divide for decades. That might change at Tuesday’s vice-presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The descent of the 2016 presidential campaign last week into the realm of sex tapes and marital infidelity was remarkable enough in its own right, but it also offered a reminder of what has been largely absent from the race: a debate about issues of public morality that for decades have been at the heart of the country’s political divide.
