keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Insurance', 'International Study and Teaching', 'Americans Abroad']
abstract: Road crashes are the biggest threat to students who travel abroad, but taking a few precautions can reduce the risk.
lead_paragraph: Terrorism, infectious disease, crime and plane accidents are typical worries when students travel abroad. But road crashes are the biggest threat by far.

headline: Elena Ferrante and the Power of Appropriation
abstract: It seems you can, in fact, imagine the lives of people unlike yourself.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, readers awoke to the news that one of the world’s outstanding literary mysteries may have finally been solved. In an article published on the website of The New York Review of Books, and simultaneously in French, German and Italian publications, the journalist Claudio Gatti wrote that Elena Ferrante — the pen name for an Italian novelist whose true identity was a closely guarded secret — is actually a Rome-based translator named Anita Raja. Using financial records, Mr. Gatti makes a seemingly irrefutable case that Ms. Raja is the author of the books that made the name Elena Ferrante famous around the world, including her four Neapolitan novels.

headline: France’s Hope for 2018 Ryder Cup: If We Host It, They Will Come
abstract: The competition will be held in Continental Europe for only the second time, giving France an opportunity to popularize a sport its citizens have not strongly embraced.
lead_paragraph: CHASKA, Minn. — The 41st Ryder Cup was remarkable in scope and in outcome, with the American team ending a three-match losing streak against Europe on Sunday in front of large and occasionally over-the-top home crowds at Hazeltine National Golf Club here.

headline: How a Simple Tax Rule Let Donald Trump Turn a $916 Million Loss Into a Plus
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Tax Shelters']
abstract: More than 500,000 individual taxpayers took advantage of the same tax rule as Mr. Trump in 1995. Their average loss: just $97,600.
lead_paragraph: It is among the least controversial parts of the federal tax code, almost as old as the income tax itself: A business, big or small, can escape taxation if it lost money in a previous year, a rule that helps businesses weather tough economic times, and hopefully thrive again.

headline: Donald Trump’s Business Decisions in ’80s Nearly Led Him to Ruin
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Tax forms and public records show how debt that Mr. Trump amassed fueled enormous losses.
lead_paragraph: Abraham Wallach thought he had scored a major career break when Donald J. Trump hired him in 1990 for a senior executive role. Based on Mr. Trump’s boasting and gaudy lifestyle, Mr. Wallach imagined he would soon be leading impressive construction projects around the globe.

headline: Terry Collins, Author of Mets’ Playoff Run, Acts as an Open Book
abstract: On the way to a wild-card berth, the candid Collins, at times searing and at times serene, inspired his players by telling them exactly what they needed to hear.
lead_paragraph: In the revelry of the Mets’ playoff celebration on Saturday, one moment resonated. A group of players, led by Jerry Blevins, Jose Reyes and James Loney, formed a circle around Mets Manager Terry Collins and jumped up and down, hooting and hollering as they sprayed him with Champagne and beer.

headline: Mr. Trump’s Government Bailout
abstract: No ordinary citizen could benefit from the tax code like Donald Trump did, and his tax proposal would give people like him even more advantages.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, Donald Trump has said his genius as a businessman makes him uniquely qualified to fix the country’s problems. We can dispense with that fiction now that we know that he claimed a $916 million loss on his 1995 tax returns. Such a mammoth loss amounts to an epic failure, not runaway success.

headline: Who Is Elena Ferrante? Supporters Say NOYB
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'News and News Media', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Writers and critics from many quarters responded quickly to an Italian journalist’s excavation of financial records in an effort to identify the author who writes as Elena Ferrante.
lead_paragraph: The readers of Elena Ferrante are devoted — and fiercely protective — of that anonymous Italian author. That much was clear from the swift and unforgiving backlash after an investigative journalist used financial documents to suggest in an article  published on Sunday that Anita Raja, an Italian translator, was behind Ms. Ferrante’s books.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, October 4, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “We see police do us wrong. We see our teachers give up on us and expect us to fail. We’ve always seen this. Once we saw somebody else stand up against it, we just fell in line.”

headline: Gloria Naylor, Whose Honored Novel Was Set in a Housing Project, Dies at 66
abstract: Ms. Naylor’s “The Women of Brewster Place” won a National Book Award and was adapted for a mini-series.
lead_paragraph: Gloria Naylor, whose debut novel, “The Women of Brewster Place,” won a National Book Award and was adapted into an acclaimed mini-series that starred and was produced by Oprah Winfrey, died on Wednesday near her home in Christiansted, V.I. She was 66.

headline: For Dust You Are
abstract: Sam Buchbinder welcomes us all to the table.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Today’s crossword by Sam Buchbinder reminded me of school lunches where, instead of eating what one’s parents had packed, everyone would dump their food in the middle of the table and we would all pick and choose from the pile what we wanted to eat. That way, if you were not so much a bologna sandwich kind of person but someone else at the table was, you could easily get out of eating your sandwich while someone else enjoyed it. And you could joyfully dine on the Ho-Hos that someone else contributed.

headline: Gordon Davidson, Artistic Director of Mark Taper Forum, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Davidson helped establish Los Angeles as a West Coast capital of regional theater.
lead_paragraph: Gordon Davidson, who as artistic director of the Mark Taper Forum for nearly 40 years helped establish Los Angeles as a West Coast capital of regional theater and challenged audiences with socially conscious plays, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 83.

Trump’s running mates debate the issues. And “Dheepan,” Jacques Audiard’s tale of survival, is almost prophetic in its portrayal of the European refugee crisis.

headline: What Lies Behind French Conservatives’ Love of Putin?

lead_paragraph: PARIS — It is not too hard to explain the love affair between the Kremlin and the National Front, the far-right party in France. They share positions on a wide range of issues — national sovereignty (for), the European Union (against), Russia’s annexation of Crimea (for) and an American role in Europe (against).

headline: Trump, Taxes and Citizenship
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Taxation', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Income Tax']
abstract: Citizens enrich society and themselves when they pull their fair share.
lead_paragraph: You can be a taxpayer or you can be a citizen. If you’re a taxpayer your role in the country is defined by your economic and legal status. Your primary identity is individual. You’re perfectly within your rights to do everything you legally can to look after your self-interest.

headline: Third-Party Voters Know What They Want

headline: In Rural Bangladesh, Solar Power Dents Poverty
abstract: Microfinance and small rooftop panels can transform lives in a country where the electric grid reaches just 25 percent of the population.
lead_paragraph: KAKHIN BIMILE, Bangladesh — Kismat Ali is a 33-year-old mason living in Kakhin Bimile, a village a few hours drive from Dhaka, Bangladesh’s crowded capital. He lives in a large brick home on a dirt road with his wife, son, parents and five brothers. This semirural area is off the main electrical grid, so residents rely on kerosene lamps and electricity from wires strung across the village to a noisy privately owned diesel generator. It runs about five hours each night.

headline: Why It’s So Hard to See Politicians’ Financial Data

lead_paragraph: “You don’t learn much from tax returns,” Donald J. Trump said last week in the first presidential debate. That line may become as famous a gaffe as Gerald Ford’s claiming in a 1976 debate that Eastern Europe wasn’t under Soviet domination.

headline: Senator Kaine and Gov. Pence: Face-Off in Farmville!
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Editorials', 'Editorial Observer']
abstract: O.K., it won’t rival the Trump-Clinton rumble for excitement, but the vice-presidential debate could be an important comparison of policy visions.
lead_paragraph: It’s safe to say Tuesday’s vice-presidential debate won’t rival the Hillary Clinton-Donald Trump rumble for great television moments. It features two middle-aged, white, Midwest-raised politicians who call themselves “boring” (Tim Kaine) and “B-list” (Mike Pence). And running mates play an even smaller role than usual in 2016, given the outsized personalities at the top of the tickets. But if these two men are willing to seriously engage the issues (and the rest of us are willing to stay awake), they could provide useful insights into their sharply contrasting plans for the future.

headline: Not One New York Police Officer Has a Body Camera
abstract: The halting pace of the camera effort is striking for an agency that has pledged to make itself a model of technology-driven policing.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department once seemed poised to be an early adopter of body cameras. A federal judge thought the technology could curb unwarranted stops and searches of black and Hispanic men. So in 2013, after finding the department’s stop-and-frisk practices unconstitutional, the judge ordered that a pilot program be established in at least five precincts.

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan officials said on Tuesday that their commando forces had reclaimed the main city square in Kunduz from the Taliban and were making gains elsewhere in the vital provincial capital, where the insurgents overran central neighborhoods on Monday.

headline: Why Are Politicians So Obsessed With Manufacturing?
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Service Industries', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: They should instead focus on the jobs Americans actually have: service work.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump landed in Pittsburgh a few weeks ago, the city was buzzing about Uber’s deployment of the world’s first fleet of driverless taxicabs. Political leaders were thrilled that Silicon Valley was hiring highly paid workers and investing hundreds of millions of dollars in western Pennsylvania. Local taxi drivers were understandably less excited that robots were coming for their jobs.

headline: Aasif Mandvi Knows How to Make America Great Again
keywords: ['Muslim Americans', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Web-Original Programming', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The actor and writer on Trump’s anti-Muslim rhetoric, his decade on “The Daily Show” and playing Michael Jackson.
lead_paragraph: In August, you characterized Donald Trump’s anti-Muslim rhetoric as “a gift to terrorists” — specifically, you said it’s like Christmas for ISIS. Would you care to extend that metaphor? Donald Trump is essentially tapping into the most fearful, racist, xenophobic, fear-based mind-set in this country, but he’s also justifying that in other parts of the world. Whether it’s ISIS or it’s Trump — what they’re basically saying is: There’s a reason you should be afraid, there’s a reason you should feel disenfranchised, there’s a reason that you should feel angry, and it’s because of those people, over there.

headline: ‘We Are a Big Family’: Dealers Unite Against Thefts of Rare Books
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The theft of two 16th-century books from a Manhattan shop illustrates how the close-knit world of antiquarian booksellers keeps its treasures safe.
lead_paragraph: In Nantucket-red trousers and loafers, the customer looked the part of an upscale antiquarian book collector as he browsed 16th-century Italian texts on display in a chandelier-decked showroom inside a landmark brownstone on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. But it was a conspicuous outfit for a thief — moments after the man entered on that day last spring, cameras caught him stuffing two texts worth a total of more than $20,000, according to a bookseller, into an elegant case.

headline: In Juan Gabriel Vásquez’s Novel, a Political Cartoonist Answers to the Past
abstract: In Vásquez’s “Reputations,” a political cartoonist reconsiders events involving a former target and an attack that may not have occurred.

headline: How Republican Politicians Learned to Love ‘Working Mothers’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Family Leaves', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Child Custody and Support', 'Child Care', 'Parenting', 'English Language']
abstract: Once they were considered pariahs by the right. Now everyone wants their vote.
lead_paragraph: A generation ago, when Republican politicians held stay-at-home motherhood as the ideal, they often treated women who broke the traditional mold as slightly radioactive. So the speech that Donald Trump gave on Sept. 13, if nothing else, stands as a marker of how much the party’s campaign rhetoric has changed.

headline: A Debate Stage in Virginia, With Racial ‘Scar Tissue’ as the Backdrop
abstract: Farmville, the site of Tuesday’s vice-presidential debate between Tim Kaine and Mike Pence, has links to progress and setbacks in the civil rights movement.
lead_paragraph: FARMVILLE, Va. — When Tim Kaine joyously proclaimed that “Old Virginny is dead” the day after Barack Obama was elected president in 2008, he was on to something. Virginia, the birthplace of American slavery and the state that provided the intellectual foundation more than 300 years later for “massive resistance” to integration, had just voted for a black man to go to the White House. But Virginia’s support for Mr. Obama that year was not an aberration.

headline: Lee Child: No. 1 in America
abstract: Is Jack Reacher the fifth Beatle?
lead_paragraph: Objectively I was one of the luckiest humans ever born. In 1954, Britain was a stable postwar liberal democracy, at peace, with a cradle-to-grave welfare system that worked efficiently, with all dread diseases conquered, with full employment for our parents, with free and excellent education from the age of 5 for just as long as we merited it.

headline: Vice-Presidential Debate: What You Missed
abstract: Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia and Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana faced off at Longwood University in Farmville, Va., in their only debate.
lead_paragraph: Right Now: Here’s how we analyzed in real time the only vice-presidential debate between Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia and Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana. Plus, check out our fact checks and our email exchanges with Walter F. Mondale, the 42nd vice president of the United States.

headline: A Mets Fan’s Daughter Catches the Bug
abstract: A longtime fan who has shared his passion for baseball with three male friends, mainly through an email conversation, embraces his daughter’s entry into the fold.
lead_paragraph: I talk about baseball every day. I talk about it in the spring and summer. I talk about it in the fall and the winter, during the season of relentless trade and free-agent gossip, and then into early spring, when I count down the days until pitchers and catchers report south to round themselves into shape for the coming season. Then, as in the eternal ritual of the reading of the Five Books of Moses, I start all over again.

headline: Toxins Linger in Homes Long After Smokers Quit

lead_paragraph: Houses where smokers have lived remain polluted with tobacco smoke for at least six months after the smoker has quit and may continue to pose a threat to nonsmokers who live there, a new study found.

headline: 11 Essential Drinks at 11 Great Cocktail Bars
keywords: ['Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Bartenders']
abstract: Robert Simonson, author of the new cocktail history “A Proper Drink,” on the 11 drinks you have to order at bars from New York to Melbourne.
lead_paragraph: Getting a great cocktail at a great bar is a wonderful experience. But getting a cocktail of noted repute, at the bar where it originated or from the bartender who created it, contributes a certain extra level of special. There aren’t that many places where you can pull off this trick, but the modern cocktail revival has added to the number of such destination bars. For the intrepid boozehound with some frequent flier miles to burn, here’s a list of a few to hit.

headline: How to Have a Luxury Vacation for Less
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: If you want a high-end but affordable getaway, use credit card points at upscale hotels and travel when the peak season has passed.
lead_paragraph: Who doesn’t like the idea of a luxury vacation? Ponying up the money for an upscale getaway, on the other hand, isn’t nearly as appealing as going on one. Fortunately, says Joel Widzer, an expert on saving money on travel and the author of the book “The Penny Pincher’s Guide to Luxury Travel,” there are ways to cut the cost of a fancy trip. Here, he shares tips for a lavish getaway on a limited budget.

headline: Art Deco Los Angeles
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ART DECO']
abstract: The architectural treasures scattered throughout the city are no skyscrapers, but they still soar.
lead_paragraph: California’s broad landscape suggests endless possibility, a chance to realize your dreams. You can backpack in the Klamath National Forest within Siskiyou County. You can find a slice of Denmark in the Santa Ynez Valley. headline: A British Architect Finds Her Solo Voice
abstract: After the death of her ex-husband and partner, Amanda Levete has pushed her practice into high gear, with major commissions in London, Lisbon and Paris.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Amanda Levete’s architecture studio is lodged in an old transport depot on a street neighboring Pentonville Prison here. One is tempted to step in through sliding glass windows, but an overlaid pattern of Ben-Day dots spells out “This Is Not a Door” and directs visitors instead to a portal lacquered in neon orange, set centrally on a graphite gray wall. Theatrical but not grandiose, with an edge of humor, it’s a cannily judged introduction to the work of Ms. Levete and her practice, AL_A.

headline: Improvised Bomb Kills U.S. Service Member in Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: The service member, the third American killed in hostilities in Afghanistan this year, was on a mission against Islamic State fighters in Nangarhar Province.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A member of the American military was killed in Nangarhar Province in Afghanistan on Tuesday while on a mission against Islamic State fighters, the Pentagon said.

headline: Teaching Your Child Emotional Agility
abstract: Learning to handle negative emotions is critical for children, but parents tend to teach avoidance rather than acceptance.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to see a child unhappy. Whether a child is crying over the death of a pet or the popping of a balloon, our instinct is to make it better, fast.

headline: Prince’s Paisley Park Museum Opening Snared by Zoning Vote
abstract: The musician’s studio complex, said to showcase artifacts from his personal archives, has been granted a temporary permit to open for three dates.
lead_paragraph: The planned opening of a museum in Prince’s former studio complex outside Minneapolis has been complicated by a municipal zoning vote, just days before the facility was set to open its doors to the public.

headline: Review: Daughter and Father, Talking Across Time in CW’s ‘Frequency’
abstract: At first this new series seems as if were going to be a mere time-jumping drama tinged with nostalgia, but it morphs into something more complex.
lead_paragraph: The intriguing CW series “Frequency” starts out looking as if it were going to be a bittersweet, nostalgia-tinged time-travel drama in the Stephen King-”Twilight Zone” lineage, and that probably would have made for a comfortably satisfying show, the kind you can half-watch while doing something else. In the last third of the premiere, though, things take a joltingly different, more complicated path. Sorry, couch potatoes, but it looks as if you might have to keep both eyes on the screen for this one, which begins on Wednesday night.

headline: David Burke Opens an Upscale Tavern on the Upper East Side
abstract: Something of a comeback for the celebrated chef; Akashi opens in Greenwich Village; and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: TAVERN 62 BY DAVID BURKE This represents something of a comeback for David Burke, a celebrated chef who dropped out of sight for several months while he dealt with business issues, even though his name was still on a number of restaurants. He has teamed up with ESquared Hospitality, and is opening this upscale tavern in the Upper East Side townhouse that housed his restaurant Fishtail, which closed last winter. In its new incarnation, the ground floor is the bar, where an afternoon menu will focus on toasts with various toppings. The second floor has a spacious dining room, a smaller room and a greenhouse garden room that will open later. Mr. Burke’s signature use of slabs of Himalayan pink salt is everywhere, in the food and even to cover some walls. His menu can be counted on for inventive touches; there are scallops with corned beef cheeks, lamb carbonara and Peking pork shank. The executive chef is Ed Cotton. (Opens Saturday): 135 East 62nd Street, 212-988-9021, tavern62.com.

headline: Ken Thompson, Brooklyn District Attorney, Says He Has Cancer and Will Take Leave
abstract: Mr. Thompson, who was elected three years ago, said his chief assistant would take over when he was out for “treatment and recovery.”
lead_paragraph: Ken Thompson, the Brooklyn district attorney, said on Tuesday that he had recently learned he has cancer and would take a sick leave.

headline: A Look at Clinton’s Marriage Woes Raises a Question: Really?
abstract: A case can be made, perhaps, for a close look at how Hillary Clinton responded to her husband’s infidelity. But not for this particular story.
lead_paragraph: Late last Saturday evening, The New York Times delivered an eye-popping scoop to its readers — tax documents of Donald Trump’s that showed he may not have paid taxes for 18 years thanks to a nearly $1 billion loss suffered by his business.

headline: With Devils Seeking More Offense, Taylor Hall Settles In
abstract: The Devils acquired Hall, 24, who scored 26 goals last season for the Oilers, to add more skill and panache to their offense.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — To get to and from Yankee Stadium to watch a baseball game last week, the new Devils forwards Taylor Hall and Vern Fiddler had to catch PATH trains to and from Hoboken, where Hall now lives.

headline: A Bee Gees Survivor: Barry Gibb Reflects in a Solo Album
abstract: With his new album, “In the Now,” Mr. Gibb aims to put his life, including the loss of his brothers, in perspective.
lead_paragraph: “All I think about is yesterday,” sings Barry Gibb at the start of his first solo album in 32 years, in a staccato familiar from his decades in the Bee Gees. “I need you here in the now.”

headline: Hedge Fund Targets Companies’ Weakness: The Gender Gap
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Boards of Directors', 'Women and Girls', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Ides Capital, led by Dianne McKeever, aims to shake up boards at floundering firms, but it’s also tackling the “boys’ club” mentality it says holds companies back.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive at a plastics company was playing golf. A lot of golf.

headline: Goldman Sachs Deal Maker John Vaske to Retire
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Mr. Vaske has been with the investment bank 28 years and is now a co-chairman, with Tim Ingrassia and Paul G. Parker, of the mergers and acquisitions team.
lead_paragraph: A senior deal maker at Goldman Sachs, John Vaske, will retire from the investment bank after 28 years, the company announced on Tuesday.

headline: Facebook Marketplace Goes Wrong: Sex, Guns and Baby Hedgehogs
abstract: The social media giant says a technical issue allowed inappropriate content to be offered for sale.
lead_paragraph: On Monday morning, Facebook introduced Marketplace, a new section on its mobile app that allowed its users to buy and sell things with their friends and strangers.

headline: Supreme Court Case to Test Prosecution of Insider Trading
abstract: The government’s campaign against insider trading has been tortuous with mixed and murky results.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission’s 40-year campaign against insider trading faces another big test on Wednesday when the Supreme Court is scheduled to hear oral arguments in an obscure case that challenges the enforcement of what the petitioner correctly describes as a “judge-made law.” Congress, as it turns out, has never defined the crime of insider trading, leaving it to the courts and the regulators to draw the line between what is legal and what isn’t.

headline: Los Angeles Police Release Video of Fatal Shooting; Say Man Had Gun
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The Police Department agreed to the release on Tuesday after two days of protests following the death of Carnell Snell Jr., 18.
lead_paragraph: After two days of protests and speculation surrounding a police shooting that killed an 18-year-old black man this weekend, the Los Angeles Police Department on Tuesday released video surveillance footage Tuesday it said proved that the man, Carnell Snell Jr., had been carrying a handgun.

headline: Faces in the Crowd: Sichun Ma and Bai Baihe
abstract: Young actresses from China take in the Chanel show.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Fashion weeks may be rooted in change, but some things stay the same — namely, the clustering of beautiful young actresses at Chanel, one of the blockbuster shows of the season.

headline: Talking Broadway With ‘Hamilton’ Star Lin-Manuel Miranda
abstract: Mr. Miranda spoke with Gilbert Cruz, The Times’s television editor, at a Viva Broadway event in September.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into news, features and opinion at The New York Times.

headline: Canadian Philosopher Wins $1 Million Prize
abstract: The philosopher, Charles Taylor, has won the first Berggruen Prize, which is to be given annually to a “thinker whose ideas are of broad significance for shaping human self-understanding.”
lead_paragraph: The Canadian philosopher Charles Taylor has been named the winner of the first Berggruen Prize, which is to be awarded annually for “a thinker whose ideas are of broad significance for shaping human self-understanding and the advancement of humanity.”

abstract: Readers discuss how Mrs. Clinton reacted to her husband’s infidelity.

headline: German Prosecutors Side With Satire, Not Turkish President
abstract: Prosecutors saw no crime in a satirical poem about Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the Turkish president, and dropped charges against a German comedian.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In the end, German prosecutors decided that a satirical poem was just that, an act of hyperbole in the name of art — not a criminal attempt to insult a foreign leader, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey.

headline: How Do You Say ‘Email’ in Yiddish?
abstract: The first full-fledged English-to-Yiddish dictionary in 50 years is designed to carry Yiddish into the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: In a thousand-year-old language like Yiddish, with many of its words rooted in the ancient Bible, how would you say “email”? Or “transgender”? Or “designated driver”? Or “binge watch”?

headline: Wallpaper That’s More Like a Painting
abstract: At a time when many wallpaper companies are embracing digital printing, some producers are painting paper by hand.
lead_paragraph: Cosmos from Sarkos is a wallpaper of uncommon beauty, with a hazy wash of watery blue or smoky charcoal blasted by a spray of gold-leaf points resembling stars in the night sky. There is no pattern repeat – the shimmering dots seem to cluster or spread out at random – and the texture is similar to a painting.

headline: IBM Is Buying Consulting Firm for Its Washington Connections
abstract: The Promontory Group has become a safe haven for former financial regulators looking to jump-start their post-Washington career.
lead_paragraph: What do you do if you are IBM, supposedly one of the most reliable of blue-chip companies, and you want to acquire another company that is, shall we say, a little more ethically and morally challenged? You convince everyone that the new acquisition will allow IBM to advance the practical applications of the supercomputer named Watson, its mysterious and envelope-pushing entry into the exploding world of artificial intelligence.

headline: Union Boss (and Former Miss America) Hits the Road in ‘Fun Home’
abstract: Kate Shindle will portray lesbian cartoonist Alison Bechdel in the traveling production of the Tony-winning musical while also leading Actors’ Equity.
lead_paragraph: Kate Shindle is compiling quite the résumé. Once she was Miss America. Now she’s a labor leader, the president of Actors’ Equity. And this week she began playing the nation’s most famous lesbian cartoonist, Alison Bechdel, in the touring production of the Tony-winning “Fun Home.”

headline: The Rise of the ‘Bromosexual’ Friendship
keywords: ['Friendship', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Men and Boys', 'Television', 'Books and Literature', 'Sex']
abstract: The issues that once kept straight men and gay men apart are dissolving, in real life and in popular culture.
lead_paragraph: A recent ad for the Bravo TV show “Shahs of Sunset” finds two of its male stars lazing on lounge chairs at the beach. Amid a scene of scantily clad sun worshipers, the best friends Reza Farahan and Mike Shouhed gaze at different objects of desire: Mr. Farahan at musclebound guys, Mr. Shouhed at voluptuous women.

headline: A Confrontation With Charlotte Police
abstract: Two videos released by police and two by bystanders offer multiple perspectives on the shooting of Keith Lamont Scott, 43. They show how police surrounded Mr. Scott's car and the fast-moving events that led to his death. Here are the four videos synchronized.
lead_paragraph: Two videos released by police and two by bystanders offer multiple perspectives on the shooting of Keith Lamont Scott, 43. They show how police surrounded Mr. Scott's car and the fast-moving events that led to his death. Here are the four videos synchronized.

headline: Review: ‘Homeland: Iraq Year Zero’ Chronicles a War-Torn Family
abstract: This two-part film from Abbas Fahdel gives a before-and-after account of his relatives’ lives around the time of the 2003 conflict.
lead_paragraph: Saddam Hussein’s regime in Iraq was despotic, oppressive, criminal and worse. Yet something that Westerners can recognize as “ordinary life” took place in certain sectors of Iraq during his rule. The Iraq-born filmmaker Abbas Fahdel, who has long resided in France, chronicles his own extended family’s everyday life in Iraq in 2002 in the first half of his two-part film, “Homeland: Iraq Year Zero,” opening on Thursday. Shooting on video in his brother’s home near Baghdad, he shows his niece and nephews watching television one morning; a piece of state propaganda referring to Hussein as “Beloved Leader” soon gives way to a Looney Tune cartoon featuring Foghorn Leghorn.

headline: In a Range of Tastes, Books to Inspire Redecorating
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Design', 'Books and Literature', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: A new crop of home design books offer inspiration and escapism.
lead_paragraph: As temperatures drop and Canada geese catch thermals, one’s thoughts turn to redecorating for the indoor months ahead. This fall’s crop of home design books offers the usual inspiration and escapism.

headline: George Barris, Photographer Who Captured the Last Images of Marilyn Monroe, Dies at 94
abstract: Monroe and Mr. Barris had been friends for almost a decade. He told numerous interviewers over the years that he did not believe her death was a suicide.
lead_paragraph: George Barris, who took the last professional photographs of Marilyn Monroe, just weeks before her death in 1962, died on Friday at his home in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 94.

headline: Then and Now: Hollywood Remakes as Election-Year Players
abstract: Race, gender, the disenfranchised: Just like their originals, movies like “The Magnificent Seven,” “Ghostbusters” and “Creed” refract the country’s political realities.
lead_paragraph: Entertainment’s golden rule: Whatever worked once may work yet again. Most movie remakes are produced to make money. A few have an agenda.

headline: A French Dancer’s Hip-Hop Moves Are Tested in New York
abstract: Anne Nguyen, who is known for rethinking conventions, brought “Graphic Cyphers” and “Autarcie (.…)” to the city in the Crossing the Line Festival.
lead_paragraph: Anne Nguyen is a French b-girl and choreographer. In her home country, she’s gained a reputation for rethinking the conventions of hip-hop dance and how the form might best be transferred from street to stage. She’s hardly the first choreographer to address these issues, but over the past two weeks, the Crossing the Line Festival offered New Yorkers their first chance to see what new ideas Ms. Nguyen might have — both on the street and on the stage.

headline: Review: Nell Zink’s ‘Nicotine’ Is Hard to Put Down, Despite Its Unruly Plot
abstract: Zink’s latest novel is a sexy tale about young activist squatters who are forced to leave their home and disperse across the country.
lead_paragraph: Nell Zink’s surname, which seems to combine the words “zing” and “sink,” happens to be a nice distillation of her prose style. She’s a deadpan comedian, her sentences funny yet plump with existential dread. Her novels give you that zinking feeling.

headline: New for Fall: Preppy Sweaters Gone Haywire, Custom Italian Loafers and More
abstract: Items from Gant, Raf Simons, Calvin Klein and others offer updates to your uniform this season.
lead_paragraph: Items from Gant, Raf Simons, Calvin Klein and others offer updates to your uniform this season.

headline: We Know What Lipstick You’ll Wear This Fall
abstract: A rundown of the season’s key makeup trends.
lead_paragraph: What’s new for fall? For one thing, the colors are intense, subversive even. When it comes to lips, that’s not exactly a surprise, for goth glam was the breakout look on the fall runways (see the black lips at Dior and Marc Jacobs or the matte merlot at Marni and Rodarte).

headline: Tim Kaine, Mike Pence, Donald Trump: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: A Head-Shot Truck Comes to New York
abstract: After a successful start in on-the-go portrait services, a Los Angeles company takes its show on the road.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon in Hell’s Kitchen, a pink and orange Chevrolet Stepvan, pulled up to the curb. It looked suspiciously like a food truck peddling Miami-fusion tacos, but the only thing cooking inside was a generator, pumping power into a 12-foot photo studio in the back.

headline: A Computer Guy of Interest to the F.B.I. Walks Into a Bar, in Siberia
abstract: In the internet age, you can live near Mongolia and still be at the center of the highest-profile computer-hacking story in America in years.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, The Times’s Moscow correspondent, Andrew E. Kramer, follows a long trail of digital sleuthing into U.S. election-related cyber attacks to a 26-year-old snowboarder in an isolated Siberian town near Mongolia.

headline: Fannie and Freddie Investors Win Round in Suit Against U.S.
abstract: A mutual fund that is suing the government had sought documents regarding the 2012 decision to seize profits from Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
lead_paragraph: The United States government improperly withheld documents from investors who were suing the government over its decision in 2012 to seize all of the profits of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage finance giants, a federal judge has ruled.

headline: Gomez Addams, Donald Trump and the Art of Failing
abstract: The patriarch of TV’s “The Addams Family” was called a “failure at failing” by his wife. That means he, like Mr. Trump, might have been able to report taxable income of less than zero.
lead_paragraph: One of the towering characters of 1960s television comedy, Gomez Addams, the pencil-mustachioed patriarch of the Addams Family, had a certain genius for business.

headline: Trinh Thi Ngo, Broadcaster Called ‘Hanoi Hannah’ in Vietnam War, Dies
abstract: The soft-spoken radio announcer both entertained and reproached American forces.
lead_paragraph: Trinh Thi Ngo, a soft-spoken radio announcer known as Hanoi Hannah who entertained American forces during the Vietnam War while trying to persuade them that the conflict was immoral, died on Friday in Ho Chi Minh City. She was believed to be 85.

headline: Once Damaged Goods, Mets’ Josh Smoker Returns to the Top Shelf
abstract: A first-round draft pick by the Nationals in 2007, the left-handed Smoker had multiple shoulder operations and was released, but he eventually earned a second chance elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: This was three years ago, before Josh Smoker made his long-shot major league debut with the Mets this season, before he became a possibility for the team’s bullpen in Wednesday night’s wild-card game.

headline: Google Introduces the Pixel, Its Own Smartphone
abstract: Google’s new strategy of controlling both hardware and software puts it more directly in competition with Apple and many of its own Android partners.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For all the bells and whistles of Google’s new smartphone, the biggest point of emphasis is tucked away in small type on the back of the device: “Phone by Google.”

headline: After Another Giants Loss, the Talk Is All About Odell Beckham Jr.
abstract: Beckham is having a tough season, and his coach and his quarterback are trying to deal with his frustration.
lead_paragraph: For the second consecutive week, after a second straight Giants defeat, the emotional outbursts of wide receiver Odell Beckham Jr. dominated the conversation about what the Giants must do to get back on a winning track.

headline: Xi Jinping May Delay Picking China’s Next Leader, Stoking Speculation
abstract: The apparent plan by the Chinese president has unsettled the party elite and created uncertainty over whether Mr. Xi will try to stay in power beyond the usual two terms.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese president, Xi Jinping, appears prepared to defy the Communist Party’s established script for transferring power and delay the designation of his successor until after a party congress next year, unsettling the party elite and stirring speculation that he wants to prolong his tenure.

headline: Post-Romance Cognac
abstract: A poet writes of hearing about a former partner, sitting at a bar and trying to drink away the memories.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

lead_paragraph: Maurice R. Greenberg, a former chief executive of the insurance giant American International Group, said on Tuesday that he was not aware of certain repayment terms in a reinsurance deal that lies at the center of his civil accounting fraud trial.

headline: Donald Trump Would Have Trouble Winning a Suit Over The Times’s Tax Article
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Some legal experts point to a 2001 Supreme Court case in which justices ruled in favor of a radio station that broadcast a surreptitious recording.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 20 years ago, a surreptitious recording of a cellphone conversation arrived at a Pennsylvania radio station. A federal law made it illegal to broadcast such recordings, but the radio station aired it anyway.

headline: Colombia and Rebels Want Peace, but How Has Never Been Less Clear.
abstract: After the defeat of a peace deal, the range of possibilities is dizzying, from quick talks to produce an amended agreement to an effort to rewrite the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: MEDELLÍN, Colombia — What comes next has never been so unclear.

headline: Obama Hails Enforcement on Trade Deals to Win Support for T.P.P.
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Actions have been taken against Chinese grain exports, India’s barriers to solar-panel parts, European subsidies for airliner manufacturing and foreign fishing subsidies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has used a flurry of tough-sounding trade enforcement announcements in recent weeks to counter complaints from the left and right that free trade is not fair trade — and to assist President Obama in the struggle to win approval of his trade pact with 11 Pacific Rim nations.

headline: As Baseball Playoffs Begin, an Issue That Has Not Left the Park
abstract: This year’s home run explosion might have seemed fairly subtle. Yet only one season featured more home runs.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The postseason began here on Tuesday with two fitting representatives of baseball in 2016. The Baltimore Orioles led the majors in home runs. The Toronto Blue Jays ranked second in homers among playoff teams. Each team had six players with 20 or more homers.

headline: Sharapova’s Case Shows How Unforced Errors Hurt Cleanup Efforts
abstract: The athlete, her handlers and tennis officials all bear some blame for the doping suspension of one of the sport’s biggest stars.
lead_paragraph: With her doping suspension reduced  to 15 months, from two years, Maria Sharapova and her legal team sounded triumphant on Tuesday.

headline: Syndergaard Is Mets’ Logical Choice to Face Giants and Bumgarner
abstract: Noah Syndergaard, the last healthy pitcher of five young starters the Mets began the season expecting to get major contributions from, has also been dominant.
lead_paragraph: The Mets’ season-opening rotation had Noah Syndergaard slotted in between Matt Harvey and Jacob deGrom. Steven Matz, and eventually, Zack Wheeler would be the two other starters, making for what many figured to be the most imposing group of pitchers in baseball.

headline: An ‘Evolving’ Episcopal Church Invites Back a Controversial Sculpture
abstract: When a female Christ figure was shown at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in 1984, a church official ordered its removal. Now it has returned as the centerpiece of a new exhibit.
lead_paragraph: Edwina Sandys had seen this before: the 250-pound bronze statue of a bare-breasted woman on a translucent acrylic cross being installed in the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, October 5, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Who said that the battle of ideas would be easy? Let’s keep dreaming.”

headline: Donald Trump as Role Model? G.O.P. Senator ‘Absolutely’ Has Second Thoughts
abstract: Senator Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire found herself apologizing for praising her party’s presidential candidate as a good role model.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When you are a United States senator running for re-election who has to apologize for saying your nominee for president is a role model for children, things may be going subpar for you.

headline: Kaine and Pence’s Debate: Analysis
abstract: We analyzed the only vice-presidential debate between Tim Kaine and Mike Pence in real time.

headline: U.S. Election Cycle Offers Kremlin a Window of Opportunity in Syria
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin, analysts say, is advancing goals in the Syrian conflict while President Obama is on the way out and his replacement is undetermined.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia is using the waning days of the Obama administration to strengthen President Bashar al-Assad’s hold on power, expand the territory he controls in Syria and constrain the options of the next American president in responding to the civil war, according to a number of American officials and Russian analysts.

headline: Fact Checks of the Vice-Presidential Debate

headline: President Duterte, the Wild Card in U.S.-Filipino Relations
abstract: In his three months in office, President Rodrigo Duterte has found many ways to damage his country’s ties to America.
lead_paragraph: Hardly a day goes by that President Rodrigo Duterte fails to come up with some new way to poison the relationship between the Philippines and the United States.

headline: Messaging With Mondale: Real-Time Reactions From an Ex-Vice President
abstract: Walter F. Mondale, the country’s 42nd vice president, chatted with us via emails throughout the debate.

Mondale, the 42nd vice president of the United States: Mr. Mondale chatted with us via emails sent from his home in Minneapolis, sharing his thoughts. headline: The Vice Presidential Debate

lead_paragraph: Tonight saw a proxy war between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, fought by Mike Pence and Tim Kaine. Here’s my take on the debate, not as a formal article but simply fact-checking and commentary in the form of play-by-play tweets as the battle unfolds.

headline: Classic Root Beer
abstract: Michael Dewey quenches our thirst.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — For the longest time while solving Michael Dewey’s Wednesday crossword, I thought we were supposed to be cooing the word “AW,” as in “Isn’t that cute?”

headline: Joshua Wong, Hong Kong Democracy Leader, Is Detained at Bangkok Airport
abstract: Mr. Wong, 19, said after returning to Hong Kong that he had been held with little explanation from Thai officials, who he said had “mentioned a blacklist.”
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Joshua Wong, who was a prominent leader of the 2014 pro-democracy rallies in Hong Kong, was detained at the international airport in Bangkok early Wednesday while trying to enter Thailand, he said after being put on a plane and flown back home.

headline: Joseph Verner Reed Jr., 78, Dies; Envoy Became White House Chief of Protocol
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: While under President George Bush, Mr. Reed was part of ‘the talking hat’ affair, a slip-up that entered the annals of diplomatic history.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Verner Reed Jr., who was under secretary for four secretaries general of the United Nations and, as chief of protocol under President George Bush, presided over one of the more colorful diplomatic gaffes in recent history, died on Thursday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 78.

headline: Jack Kirrane, Captain of U.S. Gold Medal Hockey Team in 1960, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Kirrane also played on the 1948 American Olympic team, which did not win a medal, and he had the longest span between appearances on United States Olympic hockey teams as a result.
lead_paragraph: Jack Kirrane, who was the youngest player on the United States Olympic men’s hockey team in 1948 and, 12 years later, the team’s oldest member and captain when it captured America’s first gold medal in that sport, died on Sept. 26 in Quincy, Mass. He was 86.

headline: Video May Contradict Ex-ISIS Member’s Claim on Rejecting Violence
abstract: Harry Sarfo, a German jailed in his home country, appears to be shooting toward a man on the ground, although the view is partially blocked.
lead_paragraph: A previously unreleased video clip brought to light in a news report on Tuesday raised questions about the claim by a former Islamic State member that he had refused to kill while with the group in Syria.

headline: Pence and Kaine in Vice-Presidential Debate
abstract: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana and Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia scrambled to defend the policies of their running mates in their only debate at Longwood University in Farmville, Va. The Times reporter Michael D. Shear weighs in on their defensive maneuvers.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana and Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia scrambled to defend the policies of their running mates in their only debate at Longwood University in Farmville, Va. The Times reporter Michael D. Shear weighs in on their defensive maneuvers.

headline: Tim Kaine and Mike Pence Clash Sharply Over Their Running Mates
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: No. 2 candidates always use their debates to promote and defend the top of the ticket, but Mr. Pence’s role came after a week of outbursts from Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: FARMVILLE, Va. — Senator Tim Kaine and Gov. Mike Pence repeatedly threw each other on the defensive over their running mates’ policies and character at the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday night, with Mr. Pence making little effort to directly rebut the near-constant attacks on Donald J. Trump’s fitness for the presidency.

headline: Mike Pence’s Galling Amnesia
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: Donald Trump’s running mate made no apologies during a tense vice-presidential debate.

Superblooms can bring impressive palettes to deserts across the world, but few erupt as consistently or on schedule as the flower show in South Africa’s Namaqualand.

I made a mental note to drive next time.

headline: Beyond Kitsch in Skopje
abstract: A controversial urban renewal project has left an odd stamp on the city’s legacy. Here’s how to find the real Macedonian capital.
lead_paragraph: From my hotel room’s balcony, Skopje, the capital of Macedonia, lay before me like a curiosity shop at the crossroads of antiquity and absurdity. Its shelves were crammed with symbols of long-gone epochs, genuine collectibles and dubious tchotchkes. An Eiffel Tower topped one building. A Statue of Liberty adorned a hotel. Beyond them, authentic monuments like the crenelated Kale Fortress, with sixth-century foundations, the minimalist Museum of Contemporary Art and the domed St. Clement of Ohrid Church crowded the vista.

headline: 1966: TV Effects on Children
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A Florida expert on the effects of light declares that television can cause lethargic behavior in children due to radiation beams, in October 1966.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The lethargic behaviour of children who watch television many hours every day could be due partly to radiation beams from the picture tube, an experimenter said here today [Oct. 5]. A Florida nature photographer, Dr. John N. Ott, who has spent 15 years studying the sometimes weird effects of visible and invisible light on plants and animals, reported on his experiments at the 100th meeting of the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers. In one experiment, Dr. Ott placed three-month-old rats directly in front of a color television set. Within ten days, he said, rats protected only by black paper showed abnormal activity, and by 30 days, were extremely lethargic. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Oct. 6, 1966

headline: Could Officers Have Avoided Shooting Keith Scott? Experts Weigh In

A growing number of law enforcement agencies have endorsed the concept, but commitment to it varies widely by department, and even by officer.

headline: White Schools vs. Black Hair in Post-Apartheid South Africa
abstract: How can Nelson Mandela’s dream of a Rainbow Nation be realized when institutional racism still runs through education?
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — I was too young — barely old enough to have had a full head of hair for two years — to remember the African National Congress’s 1994 election campaign poster depicting a smiling, grandfatherly Nelson Mandela, surrounded by a group of children of all races. This picture of Tata Madiba, South Africans’ term of endearment for Mr. Mandela, was appropriate for the Rainbow Nation he was hoping to preside over. The mastermind behind the election effort was the Clinton presidential campaign consultant Stan Greenberg, who advised the A.N.C. to abandon its image as a liberation movement and adopt a new role as “change agents.”

headline: Vice-Presidential Debate: How Do You Fact-Check a Headshake?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Television']
abstract: Our chief television critic and our media columnist discuss how the debate played on the screen.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, the vice-presidential nominees, Senator Tim Kaine and Gov. Mike Pence, held their only debate of the 2016 campaign, moderated by Elaine Quijano of CBS. Our chief television critic, James Poniewozik, and our media columnist, Jim Rutenberg, caught up with each other on Wednesday morning to discuss how the bottom-of-the-ticket debate played onscreen.

headline: Art by Salvatore Scarpitta, From Vivid Paintings to Fast Cars
abstract: The Luxembourg & Dayan gallery is putting paintings and sculptures on view from this American artist, who died in 2007.
lead_paragraph: The American painter and sculptor Salvatore Scarpitta has always seemed like the lost man in the lineup of durably famous artists — Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Cy Twombly, Frank Stella — championed by the legendary dealer Leo Castelli. Scarpitta, who was raised in Los Angeles and died in 2007, never quite took off as a postwar pioneer. But then again, he never pursued anything resembling a standard art career: He was an unconventional painter who became an untrained car manufacturer. Opening Oct. 14 at the Luxembourg & Dayan gallery, “Salvatore Scarpitta 1956-1964” will trace his evolution, from his traumatized-looking paintings made with bandages and bulges to a turn in his sculpture toward the mid-1960s in which his automotive fascinations began to spawn racecars, a few of which actually worked (and were actually raced). (Through Dec. 23; 212-452-4646, luxembourgdayan.com.)

headline: A Manor House Near a Forest Outside Warsaw
abstract: The house, just outside Kampinos National Park, is on the market for 8 million zlotys ($2,088,773).
lead_paragraph: The house, just outside Kampinos National Park, is on the market for 8 million zlotys ($2,088,773).

headline: A Museum About Rights, and a Legacy of Uncomfortable Canadian Truths
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Indigenous People']
abstract: Backers of the Canadian Museum for Human Rights say it starts important conversations about injustice, but some aboriginal people say it plays down their continuing plight.
lead_paragraph: WINNIPEG, Manitoba — The Canadian Museum for Human Rights offers many opportunities for contemplation. A glass display case holds the bloodstained salwar kameez worn by Malala Yousafzai, the activist for girls’ education in Pakistan, during an assassination attempt by the Taliban. Video testimonials from survivors of the genocides in Rwanda, Ukraine and Bosnia aim to teach tolerance.

headline: Sarah Jessica Parker Returns to HBO With ‘Divorce’
abstract: But don’t expect Carrie Bradshaw in the suburbs. This time, Ms. Parker plays a woman navigating a failing marriage.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years after the women of “Sex and the City” swilled their last cosmos, Sarah Jessica Parker is returning to HBO with a new series — one that might suggest her alter ego’s long-awaited “I love you” didn’t work out quite as planned. But don’t expect Carrie Bradshaw in the ’burbs. In “Divorce,” debuting at 10 p.m. on Sunday, Oct. 9, Ms. Parker plays Frances, an arty type turned corporate recruiter navigating marital purgatory in Westchester County with her husband, Robert (Thomas Haden Church), a flailing real-estate developer, and their two children. But when a friend’s 50th-birthday party turns amusingly violent, life’s niggling disappointments explode into vivid relief, and some serious navel-gazing ensues. The show’s title pretty much sums it up as Frances and Robert deal with each other’s infidelities — hers physical, his emotional — and the flatlining of their union, and conclude that they’re better off apart. If only they could make a clean break. The discourse, achingly knowing and bracingly comical, will ring familiar to fans of Amazon’s “Catastrophe” and its gloriously sniping Sharon Horgan, this series’s creator.

headline: Danish Dance Theater at the Joyce, With a Sci-Fi Look
abstract: Tim Rushton’s “Black Diamond,” a two-act work with science-fiction touches, will be performed at the Joyce Theater several times.
lead_paragraph: Tim Rushton’s “Black Diamond” begins with an explosion, filling the stage with silver confetti and the members of Danish Dance Theater — some masked and resembling science-fiction aliens, others wrapped in (and seeking to extricate themselves from) enveloping fabric. As the two-act piece proceeds, audiences may wonder if that big bang is one of apocalyptic destruction. Maybe. But maybe not. The human spirit may ultimately triumph, as dancers aspire toward a shining ball of light: the light of truth, perhaps?

headline: St. Paul Chamber Orchestra Comes to New York
abstract: Its program at the 92nd Street Y will include new work by the composer George Tsontakis, and the pianist Jeremy Denk as a soloist.
lead_paragraph: To inaugurate the St. Paul (Minn.) Chamber Orchestra’s new concert hall in 2015, the composer George Tsontakis wrote a piece titled “Coraggio” — “courage” in Italian. That quality was much in demand while the classical music scene in the Twin Cities weathered fiscal storms and labor strife. Now happily sailing in smoother waters, this excellent ensemble makes an overdue visit to New York at the 92nd Street Y.

headline: Tidal Has Another Starry Charity Show Planned in Brooklyn
abstract: This music streaming service has Beyoncé, Nicki Minaj, T.I., Alicia Keys and more slated to perform at Barclays Center. Proceeds benefit education.
lead_paragraph: A music streaming service owned by Jay Z was never going to have a problem wrangling star power. Since its Avengers-like introductory news conference — Madonna! Jack White! Kanye! Daft Punk! — Tidal has staked its reputation on access to A-list acts, a muscle it is flexing again for its second annual charity concert on Saturday, Oct. 15, at Barclays Center. (Proceeds from ticket sales benefit education nonprofits.) Returning from last year’s event, which raised $1.5 million, are Beyoncé, Nicki Minaj and T.I.; Alicia Keys and Lauryn Hill are also to perform. A more eclectic bunch of Tidal allies — the Latin pop singer Prince Royce, the singsong rapper Lil Yachty, the political indie-pop project Blood Orange — also fit under this big tent of artist activism, and may have more to prove. (tidal.com/us/1015.)

headline: Who Is Buying What at Paris Fashion Week?
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: After four major debuts in Paris this week, four front-row retailers deliver their verdicts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For a sector that pretends to welcome change, fashion can be steadfastly resistant to it. So the collective appearance of four new designers at four big-name luxury houses in Paris this season — Anthony Vaccarello at Yves Saint Laurent, Bouchra Jarrar at Lanvin, Maria Grazia Chiuri at Christian Dior and Pierpaolo Piccioli, solo for the first time, at Valentino — had the potential to trigger a sizable creative and commercial ripple effect, especially among the front-row coterie of buyers from the world’s best-known luxury department stores, boutiques and e-commerce sites.

headline: It’s Rachel Weisz’s Turn in ‘Plenty’ at the Public Theater
abstract: Ms. Weisz is following in the footsteps of Meryl Streep, Cate Blanchett and Kate Nelligan in David Hare’s drama.
lead_paragraph: When the drama “Plenty” was first produced in New York at The Public Theater in 1982, its British playwright David Hare had been active for over a decade but was known, if at all, in America as a plucky newcomer. The year before, Mel Gussow of The New York Times described him as part of a wave of young, politically righteous dramatists, and since then, Mr. Hare has grown into the role of liberal drama’s éminence grise. “Plenty,” a time-jumping drama, remains not only one of his finest and most popular plays but also one of the great modern vehicles for ambitious actresses. The four-time Tony nominee Kate Nelligan originated the role (an English secret agent, who worked for the French resistance, adjusting to a tepid postwar life), which has now been played by Meryl Streep and Cate Blanchett. Part of the fun of the new revival, once again at the Public, will be to see how Rachel Weisz follows in their footsteps. David Leveaux directs. (publictheater.org, 212-967-7555.)

headline: ‘Lord of the Flies’ and More From Peter Brook at BAMcinématek
abstract: A nine-day retrospective also includes “The Mahabharata,” a TV treatment of Mr. Brook’s theatrical adaptation of the Sanskrit epic poem.
lead_paragraph: The revered theater director Peter Brook has made only a handful of films, but they include one cinematic classic: “Lord of the Flies,” his 1963 adaptation of William Golding’s apocalyptic fable of British schoolboys on a desert island, and of how quickly a civilized veneer can crack into barbarism. It’s the highlight of BAMcinématek’s nine-day retrospective “Peter Brook: Behind the Camera,” starting Monday, Oct. 10.

headline: Renovating Fashion’s House
abstract: Even as the industry grapples with changes at the top and the “see now, buy now” trend, sometimes — as at Louis Vuitton — it’s just about the clothes.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Paris shows began in a building site — Yves Saint Laurent’s new headquarters on the Rue de Bellechasse — and they ended in one too: Louis Vuitton’s new maison on the Place Vendôme, due to open next July. At the moment it is five floors of raw concrete with floor-to-ceiling windows looking onto the square. Bernard Arnault, the chief executive of LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, was busy taking photos of the view with his iPhone.

headline: Theresa May, British Premier, Urges Conservatives to Claim ‘New Center Ground’
abstract: Mrs. May, speaking at her party’s convention, sought to court disaffected working-class voters and vowed to rein in abuses by big business.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, England — Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain capped the Conservative Party’s convention on Wednesday by breaking with the domestic agenda of her predecessor, courting working-class voters and promising to use the power of government to rein in abuses by big business.

headline: Transformative Juilliard President Will Step Down After Three Decades
abstract: Joseph W. Polisi instituted sweeping changes and expanded the school’s international influence. He plans to leave his post in 2018.
lead_paragraph: One of the most influential offstage figures in the New York arts world is stepping down. Joseph W. Polisi, who transformed the Juilliard School during three decades as its president, announced on Wednesday that he plans to leave the post in June 2018.

headline: In Paris, the Shoe Designer Who Collects Dolls
keywords: ['Dolls', 'Barbie (Doll)', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: Fabrizio Viti — who designs women’s shoes for Louis Vuitton and who recently launched his own footwear label — finds inspiration in the world of Barbie.
lead_paragraph: Fabrizio Viti, the 50-year-old Italian who has designed Louis Vuitton’s women’s shoes for a dozen years, shares his home with approximately 600 women. They are all dolls. “You have your own little model,” he says, toying with an original 1960s Barbie in the room devoted to housing his collection. “And the agency doesn’t call her back!”

headline: 1941: Freedom of Worship
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: Religious freedom is very different in Soviet Russia and in the United States in October 1966, a Yale Divinity School professor says in October 1941.
lead_paragraph: Religious freedom as defined in the Soviet constitution and as practiced in Russia is in sharp contrast to the traditional right of free Americans, Dean Luther A. Weigle, of the Yale University Divinity School, said in a statement yesterday [Oct. 4]. The Soviet constitution does not guarantee the same freedom for religion that it guarantees for anti-religion. This means, then, that the right of propaganda is recognized for the forces that oppose religion but not for religion itself, which is robbed even of its proper means of defence. — New York Herald Tribune, Oct. 6, 1941

headline: After Bucharest, a Ballet Power Couple Move On
abstract: Alina Cojocaru and Johan Kobborg, who will perform this week at Fall for Dance, discuss their brawl with the Bucharest National Opera ballet.
lead_paragraph: The world of ballet is not without its moments of high drama, even beyond the stage lights. (The acid attack against the Bolshoi’s artistic director Sergei Filin is just the most extreme example.) Often, it’s a case of jostling for power behind the scenes; sometimes nationalism, too, gets in the way. Both seem to be factors in recent events at the Bucharest National Opera ballet, where Alina Cojocaru and Johan Kobborg were unceremoniously pushed out in a messy and protracted brawl with the management of the opera.

headline: Madison Bumgarner: Postseason King
abstract: Bumgarner, who pitches tonight for the Giants against the Mets in the National League wild-card game, is just about the best postseason pitcher since Christy Mathewson.
lead_paragraph: While there is understandable excitement among Mets fans for their trip to the 2016 postseason, few of them can be excited about the Giants pitcher they have to face in their do-or-die game on Wednesday night: Madison Bumgarner.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund did not bring up Deutsche Bank’s name when it warned in its financial stability report that cash-poor banks in Europe with outdated business models posed a threat to the financial system.

headline: Vladimir Kagan’s Final Show
abstract: Three pieces represented his vision without the constraints of manufacturing limitations or cost.
lead_paragraph: The furniture designer Vladimir Kagan never ran out of creative fuel, and he was still at work on new projects when he died in April at 88. Now, Carpenters Workshop Gallery is presenting three of his final designs at its Manhattan gallery. Named Annecy, after one of the designer’s granddaughters, the collection includes a wall-mounted console, a sofa and a coffee table that were produced by the gallery’s workshop in France. “We wanted him to express himself without the constraints” of manufacturing cost, said Julien Lombrail, a founder of Carpenters Workshop Gallery. “They’re functional sculptures.”

headline: Different Dancing Sweets, and Richard Strauss, for Ratmansky’s New Ballet
abstract: Alexei Ratmansky’s “Whipped Cream” is based on a ballet that was called “Schlagobers” in 1924; sets and costumes will be by Mark Ryden.
lead_paragraph: In recent years the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky has often delved into the past to create historically informed stagings of classical ballets.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Trailers for high-profile movies usually arrive with as much noise as studio marketers can manufacture.

headline: N.S.A. Contractor Arrested in Possible New Theft of Secrets
abstract: The F.B.I. is investigating whether Harold T. Martin III, a National Security Agency contractor, stole and disclosed highly classified computer code, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. secretly arrested a former National Security Agency contractor in August and, according to law enforcement officials, is investigating whether he stole and disclosed highly classified computer code developed by the agency to hack into the networks of foreign governments.

headline: Security Council Backs António Guterres to Be Next U.N. Secretary General
abstract: The Security Council announced that Mr. Guterres, a former Portuguese prime minister and former chief of the United Nations refugee agency, had strong support.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council reached a surprisingly swift consensus Wednesday on its choice for the next secretary general of the United Nations: António Guterres, a former prime minister of Portugal.

headline: After You Strengthen Your Passwords, Here’s How to Store Them
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Computer Security', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Strong passwords are vital to digital security because they’re tougher to hack — but they’re also harder to remember. These secure apps can help.
lead_paragraph: THE recent revelation that the account information of at least 500 million Yahoo users was stolen in 2014 was a big reminder that we all need to be smarter about our digital security. That includes our smartphones, which are increasingly the repositories for all sorts of information about our digital lives.

headline: What’s the Longest Humans Can Live? 115 Years, New Study Says
abstract: The study, in Nature, suggests that humans “will never get older than 115.” But critics think we can grow much older.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 4, 1997, Jeanne Calment passed away in a nursing home in France. The Reaper comes for us all, of course, but he was in no hurry for Mrs. Calment. She died at age 122, setting a record for human longevity.

headline: Doing Good at Bloomingdale’s: Donald Robertson Signs Sweatshirts to Aid Breast Cancer Research.

lead_paragraph: On Saturday, kick off Breast Cancer Awareness Month with a Pure Yoga class ($10) at Bloomingdale’s 59th Street at 8:30 a.m., before the store opens. Then at noon, the illustrator Donald Robertson will be signing sweatshirts he designed for the store’s October Pink campaign ($40), with $15 from each sale benefiting the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. … That same day, head to the #GiltLife House, the flash-sale site’s pop-up experience, from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., to enjoy culinary demonstrations by the James Beard Award-winning chef Chris Fischer and check out fall fashions, like a Marc Jacobs mini suede cross-body ($456), that are available to shop during October. At 4 Centre Market Place. Tickets ($5 for Gilt members) are available at gilt.com. On Sunday, from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m., Kit and Ace, will host a shopping event to celebrate the debut of Love Stories TV, an online platform for wedding videos. The site’s founder, Rachel Jo Silver, will be on hand to help brides-to-be pick honeymoon travel pieces like an easy silk shirtdress ($248). At 255 Elizabeth Street. … Throughout October, Loeffler Randall is inviting customers to shop the showroom at its new SoHo headquarters, where you’ll find pretty fall bits like a flap bucket bag ($350) and silver tassel oxfords ($395). At 588 Broadway, Suite 1203. To book an appointment, visit www.LoefflerRandall.com.

headline: Randi Malkin Steinberger’s “No Circus” Photos

lead_paragraph: The photographer’s new book features the vivid tents that mark Los Angeles homes being gassed for termite infestations.

headline: A Bizarre, Colorful California Rite of Passage, in Photos
abstract: In “No Circus,” Randi Steinberger captures the incongruously cheerful fumigation tents that cover buildings being treated for termites.
lead_paragraph: In the 1960s, Ed Ruscha, the poet laureate of the weird contours of Los Angeles, began taking pictures of the city’s gas stations, apartment complexes and parking lots — the mostly banal things one would encounter while going for a drive — and compiling them into inexpensively produced booklets. He eventually formed not only a taxonomy of Southern California’s architectural vernacular — but its languorous temperament, too, and the ways of living people (who rarely figured in the pictures) choose for themselves.

headline: Federal Warning on Possible Florida Strike by Hurricane Matthew
abstract: Rick Knabb, director of the National Hurricane Center, warns Floridians that Hurricane Matthew could hit as a Category 4 storm late Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Rick Knabb, director of the National Hurricane Center, warns Floridians that Hurricane Matthew could hit as a Category 4 storm late Thursday.

headline: Sarah Jessica Parker, Molly Shannon and Jerry Seinfeld at HBO’s Premiere of ‘Divorce’

lead_paragraph: The erstwhile Carrie Bradshaw celebrates her new show: a dark comedy about middle-age suburbanites and their crumbling marriage.

headline: On Epic Spawning Migration, Eels May Travel at Their Own Pace
abstract: For a century, scientists have assumed that European eels synchronize their journeys to breed in the Sargasso Sea. A new study suggests otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Every year, when the autumn chill sets in, eels start to transform. Their skins thicken, donning a coat of mucus and changing from a muddied yellow to a gunmetal silver. Their stomachs shrivel and turn white. Their eyes expand, so they can see better in the dark. On moonless, stormy nights, when the rivers flow fast, they travel downstream until they reach the sea. Then, they disappear.

headline: How Much Is It Worth to Hold Your Newborn? $40, Apparently
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: A man posted a bill to Reddit showing that he and his wife were charged $39.35 for holding their son after a C-section.
lead_paragraph: After holding his newborn son for the first time at a Utah hospital last month, a man found a strange charge on his bill: $39.35.

lead_paragraph: Captivating gems that give the green light.

lead_paragraph: Having conquered their respective fields, the actress Sarah Jessica Parker and the journalist Ta-Nehisi Coates are heading into the literary unknown.

headline: Homeopathic Teething Gels May Pose Risks
keywords: ['Teeth and Dentistry', 'Babies and Infants', 'Alternative and Complementary Medicine', 'Children and Childhood', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: Throw away any homeopathic teething tablets and gels you may be using, the Food and Drug Administration is advising.
lead_paragraph: Parents should throw away any homeopathic teething tablets and gels they may be using, since they may pose a risk to infants and children, the Food and Drug Administration is warning.

headline: Ava DuVernay on Modern Slavery in America
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'New York Film Festival', 'Movies', 'Thirteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The director of “13th,” a documentary about race and mass incarceration, explains how prisoners are being enslaved while those at the top make money off punishment.
lead_paragraph: Ava DuVernay’s new documentary, “13th,” opened the New York Film Festival last week with a thunderclap, relating the damning story of how, in the age of mass incarceration, prisons have largely become plantations, disproportionately warehousing and exploiting African-American men. The title of the film, which reaches theaters and Netflix on Friday, refers to the 13th Amendment to the Constitution abolishing slavery except as punishment for a crime, a crucial loophole that, in Ms. DuVernay’s forceful telling, has been used for political gain and profit.

headline: F.B.I. Criminal Complaint Against Harold Martin, N.S.A. Contractor
abstract: The F.B.I. secretly arrested Harold T. Martin III, an N.S.A. contractor, and is investigating whether he stole and disclosed highly classified information.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. secretly arrested Harold T. Martin III, an N.S.A. contractor, and is investigating whether he stole and disclosed highly classified information.

abstract: I’m sure she could have handled it. Yet the campaign was subliminally suggesting that somehow she couldn’t.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: An Alarming 10% Rise in Traffic Deaths in the First Half of 2016
abstract: Auto fatalities rose to 17,775 in the first six months of the year from 16,100 in the same period in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Traffic deaths in the United States rose 10.4 percent in the first half of this year compared with the same period in 2015, maintaining a steady climb.

lead_paragraph: Blue Origin, the rocket company started by Jeffrey P. Bezos, the billionaire chief executive of Amazon, successfully separated a crew capsule from a rocket after it had lifted off on Wednesday, an important step toward Blue Origin’s goal of carrying tourists into space.

lead_paragraph: The Atlantic magazine has made only two presidential endorsements in its 159-year history: one for Abraham Lincoln in 1860 and one for Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964.

lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — At 6 feet 5 inches and 235 pounds, Buffalo Sabres goaltender Robin Lehner is big even by N.H.L. standards, able to block much of the net by using his bulk.

abstract: “That Mexican thing” pops up on social media, a new poll shows a tight race in Ohio, and the Republican ticket appears split over how to handle the Russian president.
lead_paragraph: The vice-presidential debate may be in the books, but the post-debate spin goes on.

headline: Rocket Test: A Step Toward Space Tourism

lead_paragraph: Blue Origin, a rocket company owned by Amazon’s Jeff Bezos, successfully launched and landed a capsule and booster, putting the company closer to its goal of carrying tourists into space.
