headline: The Supreme Court Plays Goldilocks on Insider Trading
abstract: In oral arguments on Wednesday, the justices appeared to search for a middle ground in deciding what constitutes a benefit to a tipper.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the Supreme Court is a bit like Goldilocks, looking for a ruling that will be like a perfect bowl of porridge — not too hot, not too cold, but just right.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Miss Peregrine’s’
abstract: Tim Burton narrates a sequence from “Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children.”
lead_paragraph: Tim Burton narrates a sequence from “Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children.”

headline: A Few Medics Hold the Line in Kunduz, Their Hospital Also a Casualty
abstract: Under fire for four days, Afghan hospital staff members are short on food and medicine as Taliban and Afghan forces fight for the city.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — When the Taliban’s attack on central parts of Kunduz began before dawn on Monday, the doctors and nurses at the northern Afghan city’s only government hospital knew they were going to be needed.

headline: One Model, 36 Beauty Looks
abstract: The Russian model Odette Pavlova’s season of hair and makeup, in pictures.
lead_paragraph: The Russian model Odette Pavlova’s season of hair and makeup, in pictures.

headline: Tim Burton Narrates a Scene From ‘Miss Peregrine’s Home’
abstract: The director discusses an underwater sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: Tim Burton’s fantasy adventure “Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children” includes a number of eye-popping sequences. But the toughest one for the director to shoot takes place under the sea.

headline: In a Montana Bear Attack, Lessons on Hope, Survival and First Aid
abstract: After Todd Orr was attacked twice by a female bear, he recorded video of his injuries and in social media posts took stock of how he made it out alive.
lead_paragraph: A 50-year-old man was attacked by a bear in the wilderness of southwest Montana. Alone and injured, he walked — then drove — for miles to save himself.

headline: What It’s Like to Be Trapped by a Category 5 Hurricane
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Lizette Alvarez, a Times reporter, recalled her night in Florida City, Fla., in 1992 when Hurricane Andrew destroyed most of the motel she was staying in.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When you are born in Miami, your hurricane experiences tend to start early. Mine began in utero — my mother was pregnant with me when Hurricane Cleo touched down in Miami. Two weeks before my arrival, Hurricane Isbell set its sight on the Everglades. And just as I neared my first birthday, she hurriedly pushed my baby carriage down the street with my brother and sister to seek shelter at my godfather’s house. Hurricane Betsy, a doozy, was headed to Miami (It landed in Key Largo).

headline: For New York’s Police, Talk Down, Not Take Down
abstract: The N.Y.P.D.’s deputy commissioner of training writes that the department is schooling officers in crisis communication and de-escalation techniques.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: They’ll Perform and Talk to Remember Those Killed by AIDS
abstract: “Platform 2016: Lost and Found,” a six-week series organized for Danspace Project, includes performances, conversations and more.
lead_paragraph: One day in the middle of the 1980s, John Bernd took a taxi to St. Mark’s Church in the East Village, where he did a solo show for Danspace Project. Then he took a taxi back to where he had come from: New York University Hospital, a few blocks away. A friend had to sneak him out for his performance. Mr. Bernd had been sick with AIDS since 1981, before the syndrome had a name.

headline: Simon Halsey, Preaching to, and for, the Choir
abstract: Mr. Halsey, perhaps the world’s most sought-after choral conductor, is slowly making his presence felt in New York.
lead_paragraph: Since the dawn of the jet age, the globe-trotting maestro has been a familiar feature of the classical music scene — conducting all over the world and often holding positions with orchestras in several nations at once. But jet-setting chorus masters? They are altogether rarer.

headline: Taller Than the Trees
abstract: Japanese men haven’t traditionally been caregivers. But for Masami Hayata, it’s a crucial part of raising his family.
lead_paragraph: Japanese men haven’t traditionally been caregivers. But for Masami Hayata, it’s a crucial part of raising his family.

headline: Taller Than the Trees
abstract: Japanese men haven’t traditionally been caregivers. But for Masami Hayata, it’s a crucial part of raising his family.
lead_paragraph: Japan is a hyper-aging society. People are living longer, and the birthrate is extremely low. For a culture steeped in oya-koko, or filial piety, fewer children has led to a crisis in caregiving. Elder care has traditionally fallen to family members and specifically to daughters and daughters-in-law. With more women working, an unprecedented number of men are breaking with tradition to take hands-on caregiving responsibilities for their families. They often do so in the prime of their careers and many are unable to reconcile their devotion to family with Japan’s intensely competitive workplace culture.

headline: The Next Generation of French Winemakers
abstract: Ahead of the first Paris Wine Weekend, here are some of the top young producers to know, by region.
lead_paragraph: Wine may have always been a cornerstone of French culture and gastronomy, but today, the industry is experiencing a marked wave of change, driven largely by up-and-coming producers. Josh Adler, owner of the four-year-old Paris Wine Company, a Paris-based wine exporter with a special focus on young producers, says it’s truly the golden age of winemaking in France. “You see people taking over family domaines or starting their own, despite the inherent challenges. On top of that, they’re focused on organic farming and all natural wines.”

headline: Want to Know the Crucial Areas for Clinton? Follow Michelle Obama
abstract: The popular first lady, who limits her campaign appearances, is being dispatched to places and constituencies where the campaign is facing the greatest pressure.
lead_paragraph: Four taps of the microphone were all Michelle Obama needed to take down Donald J. Trump.

headline: The Gallery of Everything
abstract: The inaugural exhibition at the outsider-art aficionado James Brett’s newest venture, the Gallery of Everything, comes with an assist from Jarvis Cocker.
lead_paragraph: The inaugural exhibition at the outsider-art aficionado James Brett’s newest venture, the Gallery of Everything, comes with an assist from Jarvis Cocker.

headline: A Britpop Star, a Curator and a Former Barbershop
abstract: Jarvis Cocker, of Pulp, and James Brett have collaborated on a show of alternative artists in London at Brett’s new space, the Gallery of Everything.
lead_paragraph: The friendship between the musician Jarvis Cocker and the curator James Brett first flowered some six years ago in a onetime recording studio in Primrose Hill, London. It was here that Brett, a certified Pulp fan, first displayed the dizzying assortment of self-taught art that drew more than 35,000 visitors to the Museum of Everything, following its opening in 2009. Among the wondrous works on display was a screening of the little-known ’90s television documentary “Journeys Into the Outside,” in which Cocker had tracked down some of the marginalized creators of so-called outsider art. Ever curious, Cocker came along to the museum: “I’d heard that they were putting together an exhibition at the studio where I used to record,” he recalls by phone from France. “I liked the way Brett mixed everything together. He seemed to have found a good way to show that type of art that kept the spirit alive. It doesn’t work if it’s too reverential. The museum had an entertaining aspect to it, not too serious or formal. It was an occasion to go there.”

headline: Where to Go Next: The Most Underrated City in Germany
abstract: Consider Cologne, rich with aesthetic delights: from one of the best concert halls in Europe to galleries, major museums and brewhouse taverns.
lead_paragraph: Consider Cologne, rich with aesthetic delights: from one of the best concert halls in Europe to galleries, major museums and brewhouse taverns.

headline: Practical Tips for Surviving a Hurricane, Learned the Hard Way
abstract: If they tell you to get out — get out. Water rises swiftly and is more powerful than most people could imagine. And put valuables in the refrigerator.
lead_paragraph: Four years after Hurricane Sandy, my condominium development at the Jersey Shore is finally fully back. Many of the residents around us in Ortley Beach — a Toms River beach town that was described as New Jersey’s “ground zero” in the hurricane — are still struggling through recovery, and some have abandoned their efforts and property.

headline: Brutalism Is Back
abstract: The complicated revival of the simply honest brand of architecture.
lead_paragraph: IN THE RANK OF UNFLATTERING monikers for an artistic style, “Brutalism” has got to score near the top. Like the much kinder-sounding “Fauvism” or “Impressionism,” it was a term of abuse for the work of architects whose buildings confronted their users — brutalized them — with hulking, piled-up slabs of raw, unfinished concrete. These same architects, centered on the British couple Alison and Peter Smithson, enthusiastically took up Brutalism as the name for their movement with a kind of pride, as if to say: That’s right, we are brutal. We do want to shove your face in cement. For a world still climbing gingerly out of the ruins of World War II, in need of plain dealing and powerful messages, this brand of architectural honesty was refreshing.

headline: Man Charged With Stealing Rare Books Worth $20,000 From Manhattan Dealer
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Gabriel Hundiashvili, a former fashion photographer, admitted to detectives that he had stolen the two texts, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A man has been arrested and charged with stealing two valuable books last spring from a rare-book dealer on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the police said.

headline: In Balanchine’s ‘Serenade,’ Rituals and Gestures of Autonomy
abstract: The Times’s chief dance critic breaks down the opening tableau of Balanchine’s ballet, which returns to repertory at New York City Ballet on Friday.
lead_paragraph: At the start of George Balanchine’s “Serenade,” the curtain rises on an extraordinary image: a tableau of 17 stationary women, dressed in blue calf-length dresses. The orchestra has already begun to play the slow descending scales of Tchaikovsky’s Serenade for Strings, but for a long while these women don’t move.

headline: Dealing With Ma’s Dementia, and That Trip Out West
abstract: A salami sandwich was heavy with expectations.
lead_paragraph: I don’t mean to be a downer, but have you readers of a certain age noticed how many conversations we’ve all been having about making an early exit?

headline: Early Book Praising Hitler May Have Been Written by Hitler
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Documents about a biography published two years before “Mein Kampf” and credited to an aristocrat suggest that Hitler had designs on power earlier than historians have thought.
lead_paragraph: In the early fall of 1923, when Adolf Hitler was still mostly known for his frenzied speeches at Munich beer halls, a slim biography was published that lauded him as the savior of the German nation and even compared him to Jesus.

headline: Minnesota Mall Attacker’s Killing by Police Was Justified, Prosecutors Say
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Security footage showed Dahir Adan advancing toward an off-duty police officer in a premeditated attack, probably prompted by his radicalization.
lead_paragraph: Dahir Adan, the man accused of stabbing 10 people at a Minnesota mall last month, slashed an electronics store employee and later advanced toward an off-duty police officer even after sustaining gunshot wounds, security footage released on Thursday showed.

headline: New York City Sells Landlords’ Debts, but Buildings Fall Into Limbo, Critics Say
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Landlords', 'Affordable Housing', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: A growing number of housing advocates and officials are urging the city to rethink its practice of selling the debt of apartment buildings in severe disrepair.
lead_paragraph: The apartment building on St. Johns Place in the Crown Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn is a mess. Repeated flooding has curdled the paint and caused mold to bloom on the walls. The temperature inside is freezing in the winter and sweltering in the summer. New York City’s housing agency has sued the owner of the eight-unit apartment building nine times to try to force repairs. And the landlord owes $20,000 in fines and more than $235,000 in unpaid interest and water, sewer and other bills.

headline: Review: In ‘Being 17,’ 2 Boys Teeter Between Animosity and Attraction
abstract: André Téchiné’s film centers on schoolyard combatants whose violent tussles begin to have an undertone of repressed desire.
lead_paragraph: To fight or to fall in love: That is the choice two antagonistic high school classmates face in “Being 17,” a touching drama about raging hormones, bullying and sexual awakening — and the strongest film in many years by the post-New Wave French director André Téchiné.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Oct. 7, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “The Birth of a Nation,” “Being 17” and “The Girl on the Train.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “The Birth of a Nation,” “Being 17” and “The Girl on the Train.”

headline: Review: ‘Insecure,’ or How to Negotiate Love and Commitment
abstract: This HBO comedy, created by Issa Rae with Larry Wilmore, focuses on best friends and satirizes their workplaces, too.
lead_paragraph: The writer and actress Issa Rae has said that she was happy that the experience of making her new series for HBO, “Insecure,” was “regular.” This seems to mean something like keeping things everyday, staying within herself, not being defined by her work and not letting her work be defined solely by its blackness.

headline: Pakistan Toughens Laws on Rape and ‘Honor Killings’ of Women
keywords: ['Honor Killings', 'Law and Legislation', 'Sex Crimes', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', "Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The Pakistani Parliament passed legislation to increase sentences for the crimes and to end a loophole that had allowed those who commit such killings to go free.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Parliament on Thursday passed laws to increase sentences for rapists and those who commit so-called honor killings of women, and closed a loophole that allowed many of the killers to go free, after hours of heated opposition from Islamist lawmakers.

headline: In ‘Divorce,’ Sarah Jessica Parker Wants to Ditch Mr. Medium
abstract: Ms. Parker’s new HBO series is not as dewy-eyed as its forebear, “Sex and the City,” but it can be a caustic pleasure.
lead_paragraph: In 1998, playing the relationship columnist Carrie Bradshaw in “Sex and the City,” Sarah Jessica Parker helped usher in HBO’s golden age and define a Manhattan gilded age. So it’s unavoidable to wonder if her new HBO series, “Divorce,” is “Sex and the City” 18 years later.

headline: Review: Growing Up Fast in ‘London Town’ Amid Punk and Thatcherism
abstract: The music of the Clash is a driving force in this film, and Jonathan Rhys Meyers appears as Joe Strummer.
lead_paragraph: It’s the late 1970s in “London Town,” where 14-year-old Shay (Daniel Huttlestone), a fragile-looking kid in neatly pressed bell-bottoms, is about to be catapulted into adulthood. Punk and Thatcherism are at loggerheads and the far-right group known as the National Front is peddling white supremacy on street corners. But for Shay, the most pressing problem is his falling-apart family.

headline: Train Was Traveling at Twice the Speed Limit Just Before Hoboken Crash
abstract: An event recorder from the New Jersey Transit train showed that it was going about 21 miles per hour, higher than the 10-m.p.h. limit for trains entering the terminal, federal officials said.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey Transit train that crashed in Hoboken last week accelerated to about 21 miles per hour just before it smashed into the terminal, killing a woman and injuring more than 100 other people, federal investigators said on Thursday.

headline: Review: The Golden Girls, Back Again as Wisecracking Puppets
abstract: Jonathan Rockefeller’s puppet play at DR2, ‘That Golden Girls Show! A Puppet Parody,’ features the familiar sitcom characters, doing what they always did.
lead_paragraph: It has been almost 25 years since “The Golden Girls” ended, but its four wisecracking housemates reconvene in “That Golden Girls Show! A Puppet Parody,” a harmless homage that respects the beloved television series but also underscores its limitations.

headline: Leaked Videos Pull Back Curtain on Mormon Leadership
keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Marijuana']
abstract: Footage of briefings to the second-highest leadership body revealed the clubby exchanges between the Mormon Church and Mormon politicians.
lead_paragraph: In this era of leaks and hacks, secrets have been stolen from organizations as varied as the Democratic Party, the Vatican, Sony Pictures and Yahoo. Now comes “Mormon Leaks,” a breach of the inner sanctum of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints that has provided a rare glimpse into the workings of the church’s leadership and its cozy relationship with Mormons in politics.

headline: Snap Sketch: The Faces of Paris Fashion Week
abstract: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers draws the models, designers, buyers, bloggers — and looks — at the spring/summer 2017 collections.
lead_paragraph: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers draws the models, designers, buyers, bloggers — and looks — at the spring/summer 2017 collections.

headline: The Cubs Confront the Curse: Is This the Year?
abstract: Anxiety and excitement are in the air in Chicago with the Cubs still seeking their first World Series title since 1908.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — “There is no curse; that’s crazy talk,” the chairman of the Chicago Cubs, Tom Ricketts, said the other day in his office.

headline: Review: ‘The Late Bloomer,’ About a Sex Therapist Who Missed Puberty
abstract: This comedy, directed by Kevin Pollak, searches somewhat desperately for laughs in the premise of 30-year-olds acting like frat boys.
lead_paragraph: How old is too old to be subsisting on a steady diet of sex jokes, sex talk and sex fantasies? Your answer to that question will determine whether you find anything funny in “The Late Bloomer,” a comedy directed by Kevin Pollak. If this were a frat-house movie, then sure, you’d expect the preoccupation with crotches. Here, though, the title character, Pete (Johnny Simmons), is 30, and so are his various friends.

headline: The Eight Best Shoes of Paris Fashion Week
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: Highlights from the runways.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from the runways.

headline: Desert Trip Festival Woos Classic Rock Fans (Emphasis on ‘Classic’)
abstract: The Rolling Stones, Bob Dylan, Paul McCartney, Neil Young, the Who and Roger Waters of Pink Floyd are among scheduled performers at the festival in Indio, Calif.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often a mother tries to persuade her teenage son to attend a music festival with her. But Desert Trip is not your average festival.

headline: The Seven Best Bags of Paris Fashion Week
abstract: Highlights from the runways.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from the runways.

headline: The Eight Best Jewels of Paris Fashion Week
abstract: Highlights from the runways.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from the runways.

headline: Strauss’s ‘Elektra’ Sure Seems to Resemble Another Work
abstract: Parts of Richard Strauss’s “Elektra” are uncannily close to “Cassandra,” written by Vittorio Gnecchi. That opera will receive a rare performance on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: In June, the plagiarism trial about one of the most recognizable guitar solos in rock history ended in a “not guilty” verdict when a jury found there was no evidence that Led Zeppelin had knowingly lifted the opening to its “Stairway to Heaven” from an earlier song by the band Spirit.

headline: Review: Contortions en Route to Resurrection in Shen Wei’s ‘Neither’
abstract: At the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Mr. Shen ambitiously interprets a dissonant work by Samuel Beckett and Morton Feldman from 1977.
lead_paragraph: Morton Feldman and Samuel Beckett claimed not to like opera, but they made one anyway, collaborating on “Neither” for the Rome Opera in 1977. The work, for orchestra and a lone soprano, with an 87-word libretto by Beckett, has been called an anti-opera, or “an hourlong art song,” as The Village Voice put it after its first New York performance.

headline: Bill Cosby’s Lawyers Say Prosecution’s Delay Violated His Rights
abstract: Many issues surrounding the criminal sexual assault case, taken together, show that a trial is unfair, the lawyers say.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Bill Cosby filed a motion on Thursday in a renewed effort to have criminal sexual assault charges against him dismissed. They argued that the delay of more than 10 years in bringing charges against him, among other issues, meant that prosecutors in Pennsylvania were denying him the right to a fair trial.

headline: Player Who Sold Pills to Derek Boogaard Is Sentenced to Probation
abstract: Jordan Hart, who admitted to providing Boogaard with prescription painkillers, had pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor in a case that has angered Boogaard’s family.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Hart, a former minor league hockey player who sold thousands of dollars of illegally obtained prescription painkillers to the N.H.L. star Derek Boogaard in the months and weeks before Boogaard died of an overdose in 2011, was sentenced on Thursday to one year of probation and 100 hours of community service.

headline: Debates Past, and Debates Future
abstract: Readers urge the presidential candidates to go beyond attacks and sound bites, and reflect on the role of faith in the vice-presidential race.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Squirrel Stole My Underpants,’ and Therein Hangs a Tale
abstract: Bonnie Duncan uses a clothesline as both set and plot device in this solo family show about a battle of wits between a little girl and a mischievous rodent.
lead_paragraph: Titles count.

headline: The Joy of Reading Between Agnes Martin’s Lines
abstract: A retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum gathers together more than 100 works from the artist and places them in the museum’s rotunda.
lead_paragraph: To be honest, I wonder what a lot of people see in abstract painting. I love it, the idea of it and the experience of it, because it’s been in my life for decades. But what if you don’t have that information? How do you approach an art empty of figures and evident narratives? How do you find out what, if anything, is in it for you? What do you do to make it your own?

headline: ‘Doomocracy’ Puts the Politics of Fear on Display in Brooklyn
abstract: Produced by Creative Time, Pedro Reyes’s political and satirical haunted house explores industries and systems that seem beyond anyone’s control.
lead_paragraph: The artist Pedro Reyes is a biting social critic whose pieces often hold out hope — in the face of overwhelming evidence to the contrary — that things will get better.

headline: Collectors Still Savor Shirley Temple Black Memorabilia
abstract: The plucky child star turned diplomat remains an indelible pop culture figure, and her costumes and other possessions are in demand.
lead_paragraph: Shirley Temple Black, the plucky child star turned diplomat, remains an indelible pop culture figure, and her costumes and other possessions are in demand. While parts of her estate are being dispersed, new owners of her possessions are unearthing the objects’ histories.

headline: Review: ‘The Great Gilly Hopkins,’ a Child’s Story Elevated by Grown-Ups
abstract: Although this film centers on an unruly foster child adapting to a new home, the real heart of the movie lies in the performances of Kathy Bates and Glenn Close.
lead_paragraph: The title character is a child, but two adult actors, Kathy Bates and Glenn Close, really give “The Great Gilly Hopkins” its considerable heart. This movie, though uneven, is affecting because of these two reliable stars.

headline: Syria, N.S.A., Michelle Obama: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: David McDermott and Peter McGough’s “Velvet Rage, Flaming Youth and the Gift of Desperation” and Lynda Benglis’s “New Work” are among the new shows.
lead_paragraph: James Fuentes 55 Delancey Street Through Oct. 23

headline: Review: In ‘Theo Who Lived,’ a Journalist Tells of His Capture by Al Qaeda
abstract: A documentary follows Theo Padnos as he recreates his kidnapping and detainment by anti-American forces in Syria.
lead_paragraph: In the imaginative and affecting documentary “Theo Who Lived,” the writer and journalist Theo Padnos walks the viewer through his nearly two years of captivity in the hands of Al Qaeda. A self-described “dumb American,” Mr. Padnos, who went by the name Peter Theo Curtis at the time, crossed the border into Syria from Turkey in October 2012, looking for a story. He was kidnapped almost immediately.

headline: At Frieze Art Fairs, No Frenzy but a Sense of Steady Activity
abstract: Dealers seemed cautiously gratified by sales so far at Frieze Masters and at Frieze London, a contemporary fair, at Regent’s Park in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The art dealer Robert Mnuchin was testing his theory of parallels between the painter Willem de Kooning and the sculptor John Chamberlain by juxtaposing their work in his booth at Frieze Masters, the major art fair that opened here this week.

headline: Reimagining the Divine Art of Asia at the Philadelphia Museum of Art
abstract: The museum has re-lit and recast its galleries devoted to South Asian art, and reopened them to the public. Here’s what to look for.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Philadelphia Museum of Art’s renowned collection of South Asian art had a problem: Despite a dazzling array of artifacts that thrilled scholars and absorbed curators, it made no sense to the general public.

headline: Review: ‘37,’ a Fictional Retelling of the Kitty Genovese Story
abstract: This version of the story returns to the popular, but discredited belief that dozens of people deliberately ignored the cries of Ms. Genovese.
lead_paragraph: There is a conceit to Puk Grasten’s drama “37” that must be addressed up front. The film assumes that the oft-repeated circumstances surrounding the rape and murder of Kitty Genovese in Kew Gardens, Queens, in March 1964 are true — that 37 witnesses (actually, 38) did nothing to intervene. But the facts are otherwise, as “The Witness,” an effective documentary released in June that follows Ms. Genovese’s brother Bill as he investigates the crime, proved. The popular belief that neighbors ignored her cries, a notion, based on police claims, reported in a New York Times article at the time (and since reconsidered by the paper), was an exaggeration. Alas, a closing intertitle quotes the piece.

headline: Review: In Henry Jaglom’s ‘Ovation,’ the Action Is Backstage
abstract: The setting for this director’s lighthearted 20th feature is a stage production of “The Rainmaker,” whose cast is a hairbreadth from unemployment.
lead_paragraph: Henry Jaglom’s movies are like artisanal cupcakes: The shape is sometimes weird, the flavors unpredictable, and the frosting occasionally overdone. Always reliable, though, are the baseline ingredients, and his 20th feature, “Ovation,” doesn’t disappoint. Dependably genuine, and suffused with Mr. Jaglom’s increasingly mellow intelligence, this lighthearted backstage drama will feel to his fans like a gathering of familiars.

headline: Review: In ‘Mirzya,’ Echoes of ‘Romeo and Juliet,’ Lushly Shot
abstract: Fine leading performances lift this film, which is based on a Punjab folk tale of star-crossed lovers.
lead_paragraph: “Mirzya” is one gorgeously shot movie, and the filmmakers slow down some scenes to make sure you know it. They needn’t have bothered. Most everything in this easy-to-like story is hard to miss.

headline: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading by book critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The latest round of books we like are meaty, weighty, often serious — and very, very good. This week, in an exciting new addition to the list, we’re incorporating favorites from our daily book critics, Michiko Kakutani, Dwight Garner and Jennifer Senior, all of whom bring their enthusiasms to bear on what they’ve read recently, and all of whom have piqued my interest in what they’ve been reading.

headline: After Congressional Grilling, Wells Fargo Is Berated in Newspaper Ads
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION']
abstract: Lacy Harber, a wealthy Texas businessman, took out ads in four papers to denounce the bank, which is under fire over its phony accounts scandal.
lead_paragraph: Former bank tellers and angry customers. Democrats and Republicans in Congress. State treasurers in California and Illinois. Even Hillary Clinton. They have all lambasted Wells Fargo in recent weeks over the phony accounts scandal.

headline: Review: In ‘Newtown,’ Understated Eloquence but No Peace
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Gun Control', 'Movies']
abstract: Kim A. Snyder’s documentary chronicles survivors of a Connecticut school massacre almost four years after one of the worst mass shootings in American history.
lead_paragraph: “Newtown” is as hard a documentary to watch as you’re likely to encounter. It needed to be; anything less would have been too dismissive of one of the most traumatic American tragedies in recent memory.

headline: 5 Years Later, Jon Corzine May Avoid Trial With $5 Million Settlement
abstract: The tentative deal would settle a suit by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission over the collapse of the brokerage firm MF Global.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly five years after Jon S. Corzine presided over the collapse of the brokerage firm MF Global and became a target of federal investigations, his legal ordeal might be drawing to a close.

headline: Review: In ‘Blue Jay,’ Returning to Romantic Roads Not Taken
abstract: In Alex Lehmann’s film, Sarah Paulson and Mark Duplass play high school sweethearts who run into each other two decades later.
lead_paragraph: “Blue Jay,” Alex Lehmann’s amiable black-and-white film about ex-lovers who meet by chance two decades after breaking up, has the inestimable benefit of Sarah Paulson’s emotional electricity zapping through it. When Ms. Paulson’s character, Amanda, runs into her former high school boyfriend, Jim (Mark Duplass, who wrote the screenplay), at a supermarket in Crestline, Calif., there is a moment of shocked recognition. Crestline is a faded resort town 80 miles east of Los Angeles, in the San Bernardino Mountains. It sets the tone of a movie drenched in nostalgia and regret for what might have been.

headline: Review: ‘Voyage of Time,’ the Cosmology of Terrence Malick (the Short Version)
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Imax (Movie Process)', 'Movies']
abstract: Brad Pitt narrates a 45-minute Imax version of Mr. Malick’s documentary, a tour of astrophysics, biology, philosophy and religion. A feature-length cut will be released later to conventional theaters.
lead_paragraph: “I’m hip about time,” Peter Fonda’s character said in “Easy Rider.” But nobody, alive or dead, real or imagined, is quite as hip on the subject as Terrence Malick, one of modern cinema’s great masters of distended and compacted chronology. His recent work — a flurry of productivity after an extended silence — has embedded his fascination with the cosmic and ephemeral dimensions of time in individual stories. The consciousness of his characters has been a screen on which inquiries about the nature of the universe and the place of human beings have been projected.

headline: Racist Objects: A Painful Past Still Present
abstract: Help us shape a new interactive project that examines everyday racism through everyday objects from mammy saltshakers to ‘Ghettopoly.’
lead_paragraph: Help us shape a new interactive project that examines everyday racism through everyday objects from mammy saltshakers to ‘Ghettopoly.’

headline: Archaeological Victims of ISIS Rise Again, as Replicas in Rome
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Sculpture', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', '3-D Devices and Effects', 'Colosseum (Rome)']
abstract: Modern technology is used to reproduce artifacts that were destroyed in Iraq and Syria; the results are on display at the Colosseum in Rome.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A statue of a human-headed winged bull from the Northwest Palace in Nimrud, Iraq, that was bulldozed by the Islamic State last year to great outcry has been faithfully recreated using modern technology and put on exhibit at the Colosseum in Rome to spur discussion of the possible reconstruction of war-torn archaeological sites.

headline: De Blasio Snubs New York Post Reporter and Calls Paper a ‘Right-Wing Rag’
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio took his disdain for The New York Post to a new level at a news conference Thursday, pointedly ignoring the tabloid’s City Hall bureau chief and sharply criticizing its coverage.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, Mayor Bill de Blasio has barely disguised his disgust for the coverage of his administration in The New York Post. He has referred to the newspaper as “propaganda” and suggested recently during his weekly radio call-in show that right-thinking New Yorkers would do well to ignore what he called The Post’s “fabricated” front-page stories.

headline: Review: An Undetonated Missile and Evil Spirits Lurk in ‘Under the Shadow’
abstract: In this horror film, a woman with a husband away on the front is left with her daughter, an unexploded missile and possibly a supernatural visitor.
lead_paragraph: The creaking and shrieking inside a haunted-house movie often turn on evil spirits, restless ghosts or sometimes just human madness. It takes time before the creepy noises are fully revealed in the quietly nerve-pricking horror flick “Under the Shadow,” though there’s already plenty to worry about before the first real boo erupts. Bad juju is one thing, but in Tehran in 1988 — the final year of the eight-year Iran-Iraq war — danger comes from every direction: the prying nosy neighbors, the patrolling morality police, the hurtling enemy missiles.

headline: One of the New York Film Festival’s Best Movies Isn’t at the Main Event
abstract: Among the noncommercial and avant-garde works in the festival is a gem from Robert Beavers, “From the Notebook of …” Our critic calls it a masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: In my dream New York Film Festival, some of the wonderments in Projections — the section dedicated to avant-garde and experimental material — would be programmed alongside the titles in the main slate. It’s laudable that the festival continues to show noncommercial fare like you find in Projections (starting Friday), yet segregating these titles from the main event continues to marginalize works that merit a larger audience. And, as it happens, one of the best films in this year’s festival is in Projections: Robert Beavers’s “From the Notebook of …,” a 48-minute masterpiece.

headline: Health Care: Decoded
abstract: Informed by research, Austin Frakt and Aaron Carroll explore and explain the changing landscape of health care.
lead_paragraph: Informed by research, Austin Frakt and Aaron Carroll explore and explain the changing landscape of health care.

headline: Hurricane Matthew: How The Times Prepares for a Coming Storm
abstract: Two veteran journalists discuss the challenges inherent in covering hurricanes.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. Marc Lacey, the national editor, and Peter Applebome, a deputy national editor in charge of the South, have covered dozens of natural disasters between them, going back decades. They are overseeing coverage of Hurricane Matthew, deploying correspondents up and down the coast. Here they discuss the challenges inherent in covering hurricanes.

lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The head of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police struggled to keep his composure as he publicly apologized Thursday to hundreds of women who were bullied, sexually harassed or discriminated against as officers or employees of the force.

headline: Asian-American Fighters Return to Ancestral Homelands, and Find Fans Waiting
abstract: Promoters have found that fans in the Philippines, Singapore, Myanmar and elsewhere support Asian-American fighters who have embraced their heritage.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — Brandon Vera was recently pinned in a corner by an excited mob at a shopping mall in the Philippines, and briefly thought that he might have to fight his way out. But instead of brandishing weapons, the crowd was armed with pens and cellphones, hoping to get autographs and selfies with Vera, one of Asia’s most popular mixed martial arts fighters.

headline: At Booz Allen, a Vast U.S. Spy Operation, Run for Private Profit
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Booz Allen Hamilton, the firm that employed the contractor accused of stealing secrets from the National Security Agency, earns billions of dollars each year in intelligence work.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the six weeks since federal agents raided a suburban Maryland home and arrested Harold T. Martin III on suspicion of stealing classified information from the National Security Agency, another organization has quietly prepared to face the fallout: Booz Allen Hamilton, Mr. Martin’s employer.

headline: A Raw Deal for Chickens, as Jews Atone for Sins
abstract: Though the practice has its critics, Hasidic Jews will sacrifice about 50,000 chickens this week as part of a penitential ritual.
lead_paragraph: A hen squirmed in Joel Lubin’s hands, but he held on and raised it over the head of his wife at noon on Thursday, as they stood on a sidewalk in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

headline: Army General Used Government Credit Card at Strip Clubs, Pentagon Says
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Strip Clubs and Strippers']
abstract: A report by the Defense Department inspector general alleges that Maj. Gen. Ronald F. Lewis visited strip clubs overseas and had improper interactions with women.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An Army general who was previously the senior military assistant to Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter used his government credit card at strip clubs in Rome and Seoul and had inappropriate interactions with women, according to a Pentagon investigation released Thursday.

headline: First Round in Clash of Unlikely Rivals Goes to the Blue Jays
abstract: There is nothing that would fuel a rivalry between the Blue Jays and the Rangers except one thing: These teams have it in for each other.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Texas Rangers and the Toronto Blue Jays play in different divisions and different nations. They have made no significant trades with each other. A few stars have passed through both places — Al Oliver, Jose Canseco — but not many. The Blue Jays were the guests for Nolan Ryan’s last no-hitter, but there was no shame in that; he had thrown six before.

headline: Ramzan Kadyrov, Chechen Strongman, Criticized Over Televised Child Fights
abstract: Ramzan A. Kadyrov bragged about the ring exploits of his three sons, ages 10, 9, and 8, who won mixed martial arts bouts.
lead_paragraph: Ramzan A. Kadyrov, the leader of the Russian republic of Chechnya, has long sought to project himself as a muscle-bound brawler. He scares critics, wears camouflage and orders women to stay home. Now Mr. Kadyrov is publicly indoctrinating his three young sons in how to show off his model of Chechen manhood.

abstract: The email documented a call from the mayor of Fort Lee, N.J., to a young staff member in Gov. Chris Christie’s office, in which the mayor complained about public safety hazards from the shutdowns.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — As the scandal over the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge mushroomed in December 2013, Bridget Anne Kelly called a co-worker one evening in a panic.

abstract: A former Badgers captain and N.H.L. coach, Tony Granato was hired to replace Mike Eaves. But before he could assume the job, Granato had to agree to complete his undergraduate degree.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — Zigzagging through campus on the 15-minute walk to his 8 a.m. class in Nancy Nicholas Hall, a black backpack slung over one shoulder and sporting a red University of Wisconsin warm-up jacket, Tony Granato looks like an average college student.

headline: Millions Flee or Brace as Hurricane Matthew Barrels Toward Florida
abstract: People fled inland or barricaded themselves in their homes on Thursday to escape what could be dangerous flooding, blackouts and 140-mile-per-hour winds.
lead_paragraph: TITUSVILLE, Fla. — As Hurricane Matthew barreled toward Central Florida, the most powerful storm to hit the region in decades, millions of people fled inland or barricaded themselves inside their homes on Thursday to escape what could be dangerous flooding, widespread blackouts and 140-mile-per-hour wind capable of turning debris into deadly missiles.

keywords: ['Prostitution', 'Human Trafficking', 'Online Advertising', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes']

headline: N.S.A. Suspect Is a Hoarder. But a Leaker? Investigators Aren’t Sure.
abstract: Harold T. Martin III, described by his ex-wife as a hoarder, broke rules by taking home top-secret material, officials said, but they struggled to connect him to leaked documents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a half-dozen occasions in the last three years, top-secret information has leaked from the National Security Agency and appeared on the web. Government analysts concluded with alarm that the documents, including intercepted communications from Europe and Japan and the computer code for the N.S.A.’s hacking tools, had not come from the huge collection taken by Edward J. Snowden.

headline: At the Boiling Point With Israel
abstract: The latest Israeli settlement in the West Bank makes it more urgent for the United Nations to help forge a peace agreement with the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: If the aim of the Israeli government is to prevent a peace deal with the Palestinians, now or in the future, it’s close to realizing that goal. Last week, it approved the construction of a new Jewish settlement in the West Bank, another step in the steady march under Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to build on land needed to create a Palestinian state.

abstract: The 30-year-old slugger could opt out of his contract and test the market. And seven other Mets are eligible for free agency.
lead_paragraph: The Mets’ improbable season ended so abruptly late Wednesday night that it took a while for the feeling of shock to subside and for the players to finally reflect on what they had accomplished in even reaching the National League wild-card game. And ultimately, they did so.

headline: Bing Thom, Daring Architect With a Sense of Place, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Thom‘s swooping, playful design for the Arena Stage company enlivened Washington’s dreary southwestern waterfront.
lead_paragraph: Bing Thom, a Hong Kong-born Canadian architect whose swooping, playful design for the Arena Stage company’s Mead Center for American Theater enlivened Washington’s dreary southwestern waterfront and drew critical acclaim, died on Tuesday in Hong Kong. He was 75.

headline: Bertrand M. Bell, Who Strove to Reduce Medical Trainees’ Grueling Shifts, Dies at 86
abstract: Dr. Bell was a key voice in limiting medical school graduates’ workloads after an 18-year-old’s death at a Manhattan hospital in 1984 led to calls for reform.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Bertrand M. Bell, who was instrumental in reducing the grueling shifts worked by interns and residents being trained in American hospitals, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: The New-Look Knicks Seek an Identity
abstract: A lopsided loss in the preseason opener produced a mix of optimism and disappointment for a team with a slew of new players.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Most of the Knicks returned to work on Thursday to review some recent missteps and then take part in a post-practice yoga session.

headline: Auto Shop Owners Forced Out of Willets Point Struggle to Rebuild in the Bronx
keywords: ['Evictions', 'Relocation of Business', 'Automobile Service and Charging Stations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Building (Construction)']
abstract: The construction of Sunrise Cooperative, a warehouse that is being converted into an auto mart, has stopped because the group has ran out of funds.
lead_paragraph: Mario Chasi stood in the middle of one of the 45 corrugated steel stalls that line the former warehouse in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx where he hopes to re-establish his body shop.

headline: Mets or Giants? In Wrigleyville Bar, It Didn’t Matter
abstract: Of all the things Cubs fans could have felt while waiting to learn their opponent for the next round, the strangest may have been confidence.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When Friday afternoon rolls around, barricades will go up on the streets around Wrigley Field, garbage cans will be removed from the sidewalks, the police will be out in force and many bars will begin serving drinks only in plastic cups — no cans, bottles or glasses.

headline: Some Advice for a Balding Announcer: Let It Go, Joe
abstract: Joe Buck, citing fears of losing his job, has had numerous hair transplant operations. One of them caused him to lose his voice.
lead_paragraph: The Fox Sports announcer Joe Buck lost his voice five years ago and blamed it on a virus that had attacked a nerve in his left vocal cord. He told this story to me and others. It was quite believable. But it was a lie. He didn’t really have a virus.

headline: Communication Problems
abstract: Robyn Weintraub starts our solving weekend with a lively themeless that she calls “swoopy.”
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — It always surprises me how serious some people are about their crossword puzzles, because from construction through solving, the whole kit and kaboodle is essentially about play. We play with words, we play with grids; in fact, Robyn Weintraub has done just that. In order to keep herself motivated to build puzzles, she changed things up a bit, and that sort of creativity and willingness to experiment is to be encouraged.

headline: Review: ‘Holiday Inn’: It’s Beginning to Look a Lot Like a Recycled Movie
abstract: An old chestnut, tweaked for the stage, resurrects Bing Crosby and company in an Irving Berlin musical.
lead_paragraph: The Christmas season seems to start earlier every year, it is often noted — or lamented. Will we soon be hearing sleigh bells in spring? This year, the Roundabout Theater Company has obliged all whose hearts are already pining for candy canes and mistletoe by presenting “Holiday Inn,” a perky but bland stage adaptation of the 1942 movie that is fondly remembered for Bing Crosby’s crooning “White Christmas,” which has been a seasonal favorite ever since.

headline: When Donald Trump Went to Washington and Got Himself a Tax Break
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Taxation', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: In less than two years, a set of provisions was passed that stood to be enormously lucrative to Mr. Trump and the rest of the real estate industry.
lead_paragraph: Speaking in a flurry of words, without notes, Donald J. Trump painted the matter in apocalyptic terms. Unless Congress did as he urged, he said, the United States would face catastrophe. “We are not different right now than the Soviet Union,” Mr. Trump said. “They have no incentive, and we have no incentive.”

headline: Derrick Rose’s Accuser Testifies During an Emotional Day in Court
abstract: Rose’s ex-girlfriend testified about a night of drinking at the player’s Beverly Hills mansion and the incident that led her to file a lawsuit saying she was raped.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The woman who has accused Derrick Rose and two of his friends of rape spent several hours on the witness stand Thursday, appearing soft-spoken and jittery as she gave her first testimony in the civil trial.

headline: Blue Jays Pummel Cole Hamels, the Rangers’ Big-Game Ace
abstract: In his last five postseason starts, Hamels had given up six earned runs. In a 10-1 loss to Toronto, he gave up six earned runs in less than four innings.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Among the millions watching Madison Bumgarner’s virtuoso performance this week was at least one man who could relate: Cole Hamels, the ace left-hander for the Texas Rangers.

headline: Review: ‘Middle School,’ Where the Principal Is Mean and the Pranks Messy
abstract: This movie, adapted from a book from James Patterson’s library, follows a protagonist struggling with life in a new school and a nasty administrator.
lead_paragraph: The latest entry in the revenge-on-the-educator genre — extending at least as far back as “Matilda” — is the slick, harmless “Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life,” from CBS Films and adapted from the novel out of the James Patterson book factory. Directed by Steve Carr (“Paul Blart: Mall Cop”), the movie borrows a trick or two from the Disney XD series “Kirby Buckets,” with a dollop of “A Beautiful Mind” for dramatic heft.

headline: CIT Group Plans to Sell Its Aircraft Leasing Unit for $10 Billion
abstract: The sale to Avolon Holdings, a Chinese-owned competitor, signifies a step by CIT to slim down in the face of pressure from investors.
lead_paragraph: The CIT Group, a commercial lender, agreed on Thursday to sell its aircraft leasing business to a Chinese-owned competitor for about $10 billion, signifying a big step by CIT to slim itself down in the face of pressure from investors.

headline: Red Sox Muster Threat After Rick Porcello Stumbles, but Indians Hold On
abstract: Porcello, who won 22 games during the regular season, gave up three home runs in a four-hitter span in the third inning.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — In the days leading up to the Cleveland Indians’ playoff opener, Manager Terry Francona sidled up to some of his relievers, one by one, for brief conversations. Francona knew that they had routines, that they stretched their arms and loosened their shoulders before warming up, and he did not want them to be surprised when they were needed.

headline: Hurricane Matthew Avoids Direct Hit on Florida, Continues North
abstract: The storm weakened slightly, to Category 3, with winds of about 120 m.p.h. It was pushing north toward South Carolina, moving just off the coast.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Matthew churned north along the coast of Florida on Friday, staying far enough offshore to spare the state a direct hit, but still caused flooding, wind damage and power failures. By Friday evening, it was a Category 2 storm, with sustained winds of up to 110 miles per hour, and government officials and forecasters shifted their focus to the threat of more serious damage on Saturday as the storm approaches Savannah and Charleston.

headline: Europe May Finally End Its Painful Embrace of Austerity
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Taxation', 'Government Bonds']
abstract: After years of failing to generate economic growth by cutting government spending, Europe is reassessing austerity.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Europe has grappled with the trauma of a devastating financial and economic crisis, policy makers have consistently relied on one approach to managing the damage — budget austerity.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: Ava DuVernay’s ‘13th’ and Lewis Black in ‘Black to the Future’
abstract: Ms. DuVernay rails against the American industrial prison complex in “13th.” And Mr. Black waxes dyspeptic about politics in “Black to the Future.”
lead_paragraph: In “13th,” Ava DuVernay addresses what she sees as a different form of slavery in the United States: the mass incarceration of African-American men. And PBS ponders the state of the American dream.

headline: The G.O.P. Ticket; Fox News in Chinatown
abstract: A look at how the businessman at the top of the ticket is relying on the professional politician at the bottom. And in New York, a Fox News piece crudely mocks Chinese-Americans.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s biggest selling point when he entered this campaign was that he’s not a professional politician but a crack deal maker who can fix what’s broken in Washington. So who are Republicans relying on to salvage his candidacy as poll numbers drop? The professional politician Mike Pence.

headline: Reefer Republic
abstract: Soon all of the West Coast, from Alaska to San Diego, will likely be a confederacy of state-regulated marijuana use.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The budtenders of the Rose City are relentlessly helpful with tips pairing a marijuana strain that is “equal parts fruity and musky” with a stimulating Sichuan dish. As Oregon, the place where empires once clashed over the global trade of beaver furs, glides into a second year of legalized recreational pot, the state is determined to show the world that a certain kind of drug prohibition belongs in history’s Dumpster.

headline: Intimacy for the Avoidant
abstract: What is phone addiction doing to friendship?
lead_paragraph: Over the past generation there seems to have been a decline in the number of high-quality friendships.

headline: Canada’s Trudeau Steps Up on Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs', 'Editorials', 'Carbon Dioxide']
abstract: The prime minister’s plan to put a price on carbon emissions is a significant environmental step, and leaves provinces with choices on how to carry it out.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada promised to make climate change a priority when he campaigned for office last year. This week he made progress on that promise with a plan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by putting a price on carbon. This marks a big turning point for his country, whose previous government resisted aggressive steps on climate change because it wanted to protect the oil industry.

headline: What About the Planet?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Why is the media not raising climate change as part of the presidential race?
lead_paragraph: Our two major political parties are at odds on many issues, but nowhere is the gap bigger or more consequential than on climate.

headline: Politicians Place a Bet on a Stadium, and Vegas Pays for It
abstract: The N.F.L. has a history of holding cities hostage to pay for stadiums. We’re the next victim on the list.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The fight to get professional football to Nevada is actually a story of inside baseball.

headline: A Mother Is Shot Dead on a Playground, and a Sea of Witnesses Goes Silent
abstract: Jessica White died shielding her children from gunfire on a Bronx playground in June. Few witnesses have emerged, frustrating overworked detectives, and her killer eluded the police.
lead_paragraph: To the right of where the hooded gunman paused and lifted his revolver, Jessica White’s three young children were twirling down a pockmarked metal slide.

headline: The Pound’s ‘Flash Crash’
abstract: A look at the British pound’s sharp plunge on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A look at the British pound’s sharp plunge on Friday.

headline: Pound Drops Sharply in Asian Trading Amid ‘Brexit’ Fears
abstract: Though the currency quickly gained back much of its ground, the mysterious plunge came at a time of broad nervousness over Britain’s economic prospects.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British pound plunged suddenly in the early hours of trading in Asia on Friday before just as quickly making back most of its losses, puzzling currency trading experts but underscoring investor skittishness over Britain’s prospects as it moves to break away from the European Union.

headline: Third Piece of Debris Confirmed to Be From Missing Malaysian Jet
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Australia said the debris had serial numbers and marks similar to those on another piece identified as part of the jet, which disappeared in March 2014.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian government said on Friday that a piece of debris that washed up on the Indian Ocean island of Mauritius in May was from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: I.P.O. Values Innogy Unit of German Utility RWE Around $22 Billion
abstract: The company said it had priced its offering of 138.9 million shares on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange at the top end of its expected range.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Innogy, the renewable energy unit of the German utility company RWE, debuted on the stock market on Friday after it was valued at 20 billion euros, or about $22 billion, the largest initial public offering in Germany since 2000.

headline: Pool of Sprinkles
abstract: Use your imagination and write the opening of a short story inspired by this image and post it in the comments.
lead_paragraph: All we will tell you about this photo is that the ground is covered in ice cream sprinkles.

headline: Inspired by a Book Long Buried in the Garden
keywords: ['Art', 'Books and Literature', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: An artist draws meaning from a hidden source.
lead_paragraph: I left my home in Damascus for a life in Europe decades ago, long before the migrant waves of today. At the time, I was an active member of the political left in a country run by the military and the secret police, so I had no real future in Syria. But my main motive for going to Paris in my 20s was to study at the École des Beaux-Arts and become an artist.

headline: You Say ‘Anguria,’ I Say ‘Cocomero’: Italy’s Many Dialects
abstract: The country has hundreds of local variations on language, each with its own quirks of pronunciation, inflection and vocabulary, which can make daily interactions confusing.
lead_paragraph: Say you’re shopping at a farmer’s market in Rome, and you’d like to pick up some nice, ripe watermelon. The signs at some stands call it “anguria”; others say “cocomero” or “melone d’acqua.”

headline: How to Bluff at Cards
abstract: Lie logically. Avoid amateurs and rich people.
lead_paragraph: Build lies on logical narratives. “You can’t be telling a murder mystery that all of a sudden ends as a comedy,” says Chris Moneymaker, who as an amateur bluffed his way to the $2.5 million first-place prize at the World Series of Poker Main Event in 2003 with what one ESPN commentator called “the bluff of the century.” In poker, a bluff is a bet or raise that gives the false impression of a stronger hand. Bet erratically — in ways that are inconsistent with your pattern of play in previous hands or that don’t make sense given the cards on the table — and your “story” becomes irrational, which will pique opponents’ curiosity and prompt them to call you out.

abstract: Readers respond.

headline: Letterman Has No Love for ‘Damaged’ Trump
abstract: In an interview, Mr. Letterman gave his thoughts on the Republican presidential nominee and why he considers him “a person to be shunned.”
lead_paragraph: In his 33 years as a late-night entertainer, David Letterman was both a host and an antagonist to politicians of every stripe. He took a centrist approach to NBC’s “Late Night” (which he starred in from 1982 to 1993) and at CBS’s “Late Show” (where he was the M.C. from 1993 until his retirement in 2015), holding wide-ranging conversations with President Bill Clinton or Senator John McCain on a given evening, then bringing the satirical hammer down on them the following night.

lead_paragraph: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

headline: Ladies and Gentlemen, Mr. Broadway – Nathan Lane!
abstract: Newly married at 60, the actor who knows how to deliver a one-liner throws himself into a fast-talking comedy. But there are darker roles ahead.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Lane knows how to make an entrance, and this is not just a cliché but an understatement. Bursting forth variously over the years in pinstriped suit, in Roman tunic, or in Barbara Bush jumbo faux pearls and softly curled wig, he has earned perhaps the best perk of Broadway stardom: a welcoming round of applause from Jane and John Q. Public.

headline: U.S. Economy, Showing Resilience, Added 156,000 Jobs Last Month
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: A bright spot in a fairly steady report was the participation rate, which rose as almost 500,000 people entered the labor force.
lead_paragraph: Amid a presidential campaign marked by fears about the country’s economic future, the American jobs machine keeps chugging.

headline: At Graft Scandal’s Center, a Lobbyist With a Long History in the Cuomo Orbit

headline: U.S. Set to Open a Climactic Battle Against ISIS in Mosul, Iraq
abstract: Some former officials and aid groups worry that President Obama will begin a ground campaign without a comprehensive plan for what happens afterward.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Iraqi and American troops prepare to try to retake the city of Mosul from the Islamic State, the Obama administration is describing the battle as the last major hurdle before declaring victory against the extremist Sunni militancy — in Iraq, at least.

headline: Keeping It Local
abstract: It’s not just the commute that improves when you open a business near home. You see your children. You meet the neighbors.
lead_paragraph: For some New Yorkers, becoming part of the community means participating in a greenest block competition or shoveling a neighbor’s driveway. But for other, more enterprising locals, a way into their neighborhood is to open a business.

headline: Alabama Is Hard on Opponents. On Itself, Even Harder.
abstract: For the top-ranked and unbeaten Crimson Tide, who were to enter a brutal four-game stretch Saturday, there is always room for improvement.
lead_paragraph: Alabama Coach Nick Saban wore a countenance both of sorrow and of anger as he emerged from the locker room after his team’s season opener last month.

headline: On the Trail With Gary Johnson
abstract: Mr. Johnson will be the first third-party presidential candidate in 20 years to appear on the ballot in all 50 states. But he is rarely recognized as he hustles through airport taxi lines, wheeling his own luggage.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Johnson will be the first third-party presidential candidate in 20 years to appear on the ballot in all 50 states. But he is rarely recognized as he hustles through airport taxi lines, wheeling his own luggage.

headline: Colombia’s President, Juan Manuel Santos, Is Awarded Nobel Peace Prize
abstract: The committee recognized Mr. Santos “for his resolute efforts to bring the country’s more than 50-year-long civil war to an end.”
lead_paragraph: The president of Colombia was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday for pursuing a deal to end 52 years of conflict with a leftist rebel group, the longest-running war in the Americas, just five days after Colombians rejected the agreement in a shocking referendum result.

headline: Teaching With: ‘Supreme Court v. the American Voter’
abstract: This short documentary explores how this year’s election will be the first in over 50 years without the full protection of the Voting Rights Act.
lead_paragraph: This short documentary explores how the 2016 election will be the first in over 50 years without the full protection of the Voting Rights Act. Has the United States succeeded in making voting a universal and equal right for all American citizens age 18 and over? Did the Voting Rights Act accomplish its goals so it’s no longer needed? Or, is voter discrimination and suppression still taking place?

headline: As Copenhagen’s Noma Departs, a Welcome Arrival
abstract: Just a summer plum’s toss from Noma’s back door, René Redzepi has opened 108, a stylishly casual alternative that’s a third of the price, yet far more than half as good.
lead_paragraph: Ever since René Redzepi announced that he’d be closing what’s been possibly the most celebrated restaurant in the world, the only thing harder to find at Noma than out-of-season vegetables are reservations. Fortunately, there’s a workaround. Just a summer plum’s toss from Noma’s back door, Mr. Redzepi has opened 108, a stylishly casual alternative that’s a third of the price, yet far more than half as good. Prep cooks run ingredients back and forth between the two kitchens, but a Noma alumnus, Kristian Baumann, is firmly at the helm.

headline: In Splintered Georgia, 200 Political Parties Find Unity Against Russia

But one dignitary whose handshake is not on photographic display in the office of Nino Burjanadze is a leader who, more than any other, has shaped — and helped destroy — her political fortunes.

headline: Traveling With a Special Diet? Hotels and Cruises Are Ready
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Cruises', 'Food', 'ALLERGIES', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Gluten']
abstract: For travelers with dietary restrictions, from food allergies to kosher meals, cruise lines and hotels have created special kitchens and menus.
lead_paragraph: As a travel adviser selling luxury trips, Stacy Small, 46, the owner of the Los Angeles-based consultancy Elite Travel International, spends more than half the year traveling for her job, but her severe celiac allergy, diagnosed in 2001, has made life on the road challenging — at least in the past. “It wasn’t too long ago that finding food without wheat was nearly impossible, even at upscale hotels,” she said.

headline: 1891: Death of Parnell
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: Dublin and Ireland mourn after the death of Irish politician and nationalist Charles Stewart Parnell in October 1891.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The death of Charles Stewart Parnell took place at half-past eleven last night [Oct. 7] at his residence, Walsingham Terrace, Aldrington, near Brighton. The news of Mr. Parnell’s death caused a great sensation in Dublin, where the people are standing about in groups discussing the situation. A large number of leading Parnellites are assembled at the National League offices, their only topic of conversation being the death of their leader. All seemed deeply impressed by the calamity which has overtaken them.

headline: Group Questions Donald Trump’s Lock on Evangelical Voters

headline: Balance, Trump and Lies
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Is any equivalence of the treatment of Clinton and Trump “false” because they are not compatible, any more than, say, harassment and murder?
lead_paragraph: This is an atypical election. Donald Trump has moved the needle. As Eugene Robinson put it in The Washington Post, “Trump lies the way other people breathe.” For Jacob Weisberg of Slate, this campaign is not the usual apples versus oranges. It’s “apples versus rancid meat.”

abstract: Generations of Jewish experience are explored in two films, comically in “Where’s Poppa?” and in documentary form in “Papirosen.”
lead_paragraph: A small but distinct tendency within the Hollywood New Wave of the late 1960s and early 1970s was the dark, sometimes daringly tasteless comedy featuring urban neurotic protagonists and ethnic themes, often directed by a Jewish comedian.

headline: Your Boycott Won’t Help Iranian Women
abstract: Outsiders may think they know best. That’s at the heart of what’s worst about policing how Muslim women dress.
lead_paragraph: When the World Chess Federation designated Iran host of the 2017 Women’s World Chess Championship games, Mitra Hejazipour was thrilled. She is a women’s grandmaster. She learned chess at 6, played in her first formal championship at age 9, and, now 23, she has spent her life traveling the world for chess tournaments and returning to the Islamic Republic of Iran with shiny medals.

headline: Letter of Complaint: Cards Against Humanity
abstract: The “party game for horrible people” lives up to its motto.
lead_paragraph: “Cards Against Humanity” is a pun, of sorts, on “crimes against humanity” — which isn’t really funny. But if you got a half-dozen people to vote on it, they’d probably say it was. Individual taste becomes awful in groups, and nothing demonstrates this phenomenon better than Cards Against Humanity, a party game for horrible people. That’s not even my opinion; it says so right on the box: “A party game for horrible people.” The website elaborates: “Unlike most of the party games you’ve played before, Cards Against Humanity is as despicable and awkward as you and your friends.”

headline: How This Jobs Report Can Help Clinton, and Trump
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The numbers are such that Hillary Clinton can argue that the economy continues to improve, and Donald Trump can argue that things haven’t improved enough.
lead_paragraph: Most of the time, the release of monthly employment numbers is important because the figures tell us something about Americans’ prospects for finding a job, whether the economy is slowing down or speeding up, and perhaps what the Federal Reserve is likely to do at coming meetings.

headline: ‘The Greasy Strangler’: Just Maybe the Weirdest Movie Ever

headline: A General’s New Mission: Leading a Charge Against PTSD
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Depression (Mental)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Traumatic Brain Injury', 'Military Bases and Installations']
abstract: It took 12 years for Brig. Gen. Donald C. Bolduc to deal with the mental trauma he sustained in eight combat tours. He doesn’t want others to wait.
lead_paragraph: STUTTGART, Germany — It might have been the 2,000-pound bomb that dropped near him in Afghanistan, killing several comrades. Or maybe it was the helicopter crash he managed to survive. It could have been the battlefield explosions that detonated all around him over eight combat tours.

headline: How to Improve Your Retirement Income if You Haven’t Saved
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Social Security (US)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Personal Finances', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans']

lead_paragraph: Michael Kitces sees it regularly in his financial planning practice: clients who are close to retirement but haven’t saved.

headline: At Frieze Art Week, All Eyes on the Pound

lead_paragraph: “Great price, great picture!” exclaimed the auctioneer Jussi Pylkkanen, under a screen that showed “GBP 6,200,000” above conversions into a range of currencies that had strengthened against the pound in the last few months — and days.

headline: Hugh Laurie Is Playing Doctor Again. But Don’t Quiz Him.

headline: Sending Potatoes to Idaho? How the Free Market Can Fight Poverty
abstract: The experience of the food distributor Feeding America demonstrates the power of markets when they are used as a tool for fulfilling people’s needs fairly.
lead_paragraph: Skepticism about capitalism and free markets is rising. A survey by the Harvard Institute of Politics found that a majority of 18-to-29-year-old Americans do not believe in modern capitalism at all.

headline: Young, Transgender and Acting on TV
abstract: Agents, writers, producers and parents are gingerly exploring a frontier within a frontier as they bring young transgender actors into the fold.
lead_paragraph: In a recent episode of “Modern Family,” two children, a boy and a girl, play a round of broom hockey in a living room. In those 12 seconds, the first openly transgender child appeared as a transgender character in a mainstream sitcom.

headline: 1966: Russia Expels Chinese
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The Soviet government expels all students from Communist China from Russia in October 1966.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Soviet government today [Oct. 7] ordered all students from Communist China to leave the country before Nov. 1. It did so in retaliation against the recent ouster of Soviet students from China. The Soviet government expressed “regret” that China had unilaterally broken a ten-year cultural exchange agreement. It told the Chinese embassy it would consider resuming the student exchanges “as soon as the Chinese side displays a readiness” to do so. Communist China last month suspended for a year training of all foreign students in China.

headline: The Second 2016 Presidential Debate: A Place for Student Predictions and Reactions
abstract: We invite students to share their predictions before the debate. Then, starting at 9 p.m. Eastern on Oct. 9, we invite them to share reactions as we live-moderate.

headline: New Picture Books Create Strange but Believable Worlds
abstract: Three picture books involve creatures — bears, bugs and turtles — in strange but believable worlds.
lead_paragraph: One of the wonders of literature is its potential to generate worlds that are strange and unreal and yet entirely believable. “I wish I could be there!” we say with a mix of excitement and yearning when we are immersed in such an imaginary place. But it is difficult to create a world, even a tiny one, and some authors are more successful than others at playing demiurge, as three new picture books show.

headline: Southern Bands That Are Politically Progressive, and Proud of It

abstract: In many ways, the South is still a bastion of conservatism, but groups like Drive-By Truckers and Shovels & Rope still carry the banner of progressives.

headline: Making Financial Management Both Spouses’ Job
abstract: Many couples share financial information sparingly, but death, disability or divorce could make such a decision catastrophic.
lead_paragraph: Mark and Penelope Greene took what was once considered a fairly traditional path in marriage. They both worked outside the home until they had children. Then Mrs. Greene stayed home, running a small consulting business between parenting obligations, and Mr. Greene continued working as an economist.

headline: Daily Report: Salesforce Has Had Its Eye on Twitter. But Why?
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: They may both be technology companies, but their businesses are vastly different. And history tells us combining very different tech outfits is risky.
lead_paragraph: October in San Francisco is a special time. The fog lifts. The temperature rises. The Blue Angels buzz overhead for Fleet Week as tens of thousands of business technology types descend on the city for Salesforce.com’s annual conference.

headline: On Brink of Sale, Family Shop in Chinatown Stays in Family
abstract: Narrowly averting the end of five generations of family ownership, an increasingly rare species in this city of rising towers and rents, Wing on Wo & Co walks away from millions.
lead_paragraph: When the narrow streets of Chinatown overflow on weekends, a few tourists always end up in Wing on Wo & Co. to browse porcelain antiques and jade ornaments. But they rarely stay long, quickly leaving to join dozens in the line outside a trendy new ice cream shop down the block.

headline: Eight Bold and Beautiful Bookends

lead_paragraph: Whether providing heroic assists or standing on their own, these simple shapes make an artful statement.

lead_paragraph: After 33 years of friendship, Susan Graham, the opera singer, and Clay Brakeley, a designer of theatrical lighting, were married Sept. 17 at the Las Campanas Country Club in Santa Fe, N.M.

headline: An Opera Star Finds the Right Duet

lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, Susan Graham has made the world her stage, her sumptuous mezzo-soprano and magical presence celebrated at the Metropolitan Opera in New York, the Royal Opera House in London and the Théâtre du Châtelet in Paris.

headline: My Dad Set the Precedent Donald Trump Is Flouting
abstract: In 1967, my father convinced George Romney to release 12 years of tax returns, helping to establish a precedent that Donald J. Trump, so far, has defied.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Gardiner Harris, The Times’s White House Correspondent, discusses a campaign precedent that his father helped establish.

headline: N.F.L. Schedule: Here’s Who We Think Will Win in Week 5
