lead_paragraph: The list of unbeaten teams has narrowed to three, and it does not include the New England Patriots. As the N.F.L. prepares to welcome back Tom Brady, the Vikings, the Broncos and the Eagles want to remind everyone that nobody has figured out a way to beat them. Here is a look at Sunday’s matchups and who we think will win them:

headline: TV Presidents: Heroes, Schemers and Buffoons
abstract: Nick Nolte is just one of the latest actors to portray a fictitious commander in chief on series television. Here are other administrations past and present.
lead_paragraph: This fall, as one of the most dramatic presidential elections in recent memory unfolds, television audiences are finding themselves overrun with fictional commanders in chief. On ABC’s “Designated Survivor,” Kiefer Sutherland is a lowly cabinet secretary thrust into the most powerful position on earth. Keith Carradine plays a soothing, idealistic president on CBS’s “Madam Secretary.” And CW’s “Supergirl” will soon introduce a president played by Wonder Woman herself, Lynda Carter.

headline: Many Florida Beach Residents Shrug Off Evacuation Orders
abstract: As Hurricane Matthew approached the Jacksonville area in northern Florida and many residents left, many others who live on barrier islands decided to stay and ride out the storm.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE BEACH, Fla. — Scott Holmes, a surf-camp instructor from nearby Ponte Vedra, was at Home Depot early Thursday buying a generator, one of the remaining that the store had.

headline: Billy Bob Thornton Plays a Lawyer in ‘Goliath.’ A Drunkard, Too.
abstract: David E. Kelley’s new legal series represents a change of venue from broadcast TV. Making it for Amazon, he says, means “characters can have more time and room.”
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, CALIF. — Say what you will about Ally McBeal — and, over the years, people have said a lot — she was a likable character, or at least she was intended to be. Same with Bobby Donnell, the morally squishy senior partner on “The Practice,” and the womanizing Alan Shore, of both “The Practice” and “Boston Legal.” David E. Kelley, the creator and prolific writer of many of TV’s most celebrated legal dramas, made them that way, partly for his own sanity.

headline: Mark Rothko, Son of Oregon, to Be Honored With Museum Wing
abstract: The Portland Art Museum has announced an expansion in honor of the artist, in partnership with his children, who will put their paintings on loan.
lead_paragraph: Under the heading of local-boy-makes-good, the painter Mark Rothko and Portland, Ore., have never really been paired in the public imagination. Rothko, whose family emigrated to Portland when he was 10 from what is now Latvia, left for Yale and then New York and returned only infrequently to his hometown during his lifetime.

headline: A ‘Keeper of Earth and Time’
abstract: Bill Dilworth has a dual caretaker’s role, tending a roomful of dirt (an art exhibit) and an old clock (in an 1832 church tower).
lead_paragraph: Bill Dilworth’s business card, which reads “Keeper of Earth and Time,” refers to his two longtime caretaker’s positions.

headline: Rents Rise in Northwest Queens
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Rent data from August shows median rent increases for the northwest section of the borough.
lead_paragraph: Median rental prices for most apartment sizes in Manhattan and Brooklyn slipped in August compared with a year earlier, as landlords increased concessions to fill vacancies. But prices in northwest Queens, including Long Island City, Astoria, Sunnyside and Woodside, rose across all apartment categories.

abstract: If the recent Wells Fargo scandal has left you disenchanted with giant banks and ready to switch to a smaller one or a credit union, here’s what you should know.

lead_paragraph: As long as there have been slaves, there have been slave rebellions.

abstract: The writer shares the titles she would most want with her on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is Maggie Nelson, author of “The Argonauts” and a 2016 MacArthur fellow, who shares her list exclusively with T.

headline: Spicy Green Beans, at the Center of the Plate
abstract: A richly seasoned dish with cashews and coconut makes a satisfying vegetarian main course.
lead_paragraph: Just as soon as I had devoured the sautéed celery with mustard seeds and coconut that my friend Linta made for dinner one night, I immediately wanted to make a version of it at home.

headline: The Story Behind This Week’s Best Sellers
abstract: In “Weapons of Math Destruction,” No. 5 on the education best-seller list, Cathy O’Neil says our reliance on algorithms exacerbates whatever inequality already exists.
lead_paragraph: Tyrant in the Machine: Cathy O’Neil had been working as a quant at a hedge fund for about a year when the global economy collapsed. In her introduction to “Weapons of Math Destruction,” No. 5 on the monthly education list and longlisted for the National Book Award, O’Neil — who holds a Ph.D. in mathematics from Harvard — recounts how the 2008 crash made her realize the enormous havoc that could be wreaked “by mathematicians wielding magic formulas.” The crisis showed that computer technology could combine with mathematics “to multiply the chaos and misfortune,” yet years later we continue to be enthralled by algorithms. We use them in teacher evaluations, hiring decisions, even sentencing rulings in the criminal justice system. We rely on Big Data more than ever before.

headline: Redefining the Lower East Side
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: Sales have begun at 242 Broome, a 14-story condo that is part of the massive Essex Crossing redevelopment project on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: At the corner of Broome and Ludlow Streets, amid the tenement buildings of the Lower East Side, condominium sales began last month at a 14-story anodized aluminum and glass tower that will open in 2018. With a champagne hue to its facade, the building, 242 Broome, is just one piece of Essex Crossing, a $1 billion redevelopment project that will redefine the character of an area that lay fallow for nearly 50 years.

headline: In Exile With ‘Don Quixote’
abstract: “Don Quixote” was born out of a defining experience: a five-year captivity by pirates.
lead_paragraph: Of the myriad times since adolescence that I have returned to the story of Don Quixote de la Mancha, there is one I choose to remember — that I cannot help but remember — as we commemorate the 400th anniversary of the death of Miguel de Cervantes. That reading, in October 1973, took place among a distraught group of captive men and women who, like me, had sought asylum in the Argentine Embassy in Santiago, Chile, after the coup that overthrew the democratic government of Salvador Allende.

headline: Colombia’s Proof That Democracy Doesn’t Work
abstract: The Colombians who didn’t vote on the deal to end five decades of war are the ones who decided the future.
lead_paragraph: The article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: The Latest in Science Fiction and Fantasy
abstract: A runaway princess is called to rule a space empire; Death’s daughter hunts down the Reaper of War; summer in Seattle is disrupted by a mysterious mythic figure; and an exorcism goes creepily wrong.
lead_paragraph: In the distant future, the powerful Indranan Empire has just lost most of its royal family to betrayal and ­assassination. One heir remains, but there’s a problem: She fled the centers of power 20 years before, hid her identity and has been doing quite well as the head of a criminal outfit. When her empress mother has her hauled home, nobody’s happy — least of all the gunrunning princess herself.

headline: Five Paintings Stolen in 2005 Return to Dutch Museum
abstract: The Dutch Golden Age works, among 24 taken from the Westfries Museum in Hoorn, the Netherlands, were found in Ukraine last year.
lead_paragraph: HOORN, The Netherlands — On Thursday morning, officials at the Westfries Museum here used crowbars to pry open wooden crates containing five Dutch Golden Age paintings that had been stolen from the museum more than a decade ago. The crates had been delivered early that morning from Ukraine, where they were discovered in the hands of an ultranationalist militia group last year.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: A Terrible Stomachache Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a 43-year-old woman who is wasting away from wrenching abdominal pain.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to figure out why a 43-year-old woman had such terrible abdominal pain that she lost more than 10 percent of her original body weight over the course of just a few weeks. There were two important clues in her case. First, her pain came on after she ate. And second, the pain improved when she brought her knees up toward her chest. More than 250 of you responded, but only five of you got it right.

lead_paragraph: Gloria Steinem started her career as a C.I.A. operative, got her break as a Playboy Bunny, married Christian Bale’s father and now produces a show for the cable television channel Viceland, the home of “Balls Deep” and “Action Bronson Watches Ancient Aliens.” Beyond that, there are some gaps in her résumé.

headline: Kosovo: The Road Team
abstract: Competing in World Cup qualifying matches for the first time, Kosovo’s soccer team finds a politically fraught landscape.
lead_paragraph: SHKODER, Albania — The gleaming Loro Borici Stadium was deserted. Children played on the empty turnstiles. Adults milled about a vegetable market on the edges of the stadium here. There was little to suggest that, later Thursday, it would be the stage for a soccer game of historical importance to the host nation, Kosovo: No posters, flags or other paraphernalia were in evidence. But then again, Shkoder is in Albania, not Kosovo.

lead_paragraph: Julie Verhoeven has customized the public washrooms at this year’s Frieze London, and will serve as an attendant for the duration of the weekend.

headline: Why One Artist Is Spending Frieze London Hiding in the Bathroom
keywords: ['Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Art', 'Frieze Art Fair', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness']
abstract: Julie Verhoeven is taking her (self-imposed) duties as a washroom attendant very, very seriously.
lead_paragraph: “Are these toilets unisex?” asks a bemused Frieze London fairgoer who inadvertently wanders into the fair’s ladies’ room, and his confusion is understandable: The artist Julie Verhoeven has turned the public bathrooms into the unlikely site for an art intervention. Disruption is very much the intention behind “The Toilet Attendant… Now Wash Your Hands,” in which Verhoeven act as a washroom attendant alongside the art collector Valeria Napoleone. “The carpet is confusing everyone,” says Verhoeven, gesturing to the gender-disorienting hot pink floor covering in the men’s washrooms, and the royal blue in the women’s. “It’s quite telling about the way we’ve all been brought up. I thought we were all supposed to be ‘art’ and visually astute. There is signage,” she adds gleefully. “I guess the pink and blue thing is deeply bred into the psyche.”

headline: Russia Seeks to Reopen Military Bases in Vietnam and Cuba
abstract: The Russian deputy defense minister said that the Kremlin was working to re-establish the former bases, which closed in 2002.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia is working to re-establish its former military bases in Vietnam and Cuba, a senior official said on Friday, reflecting Moscow’s growing ambition to reassert itself on the world stage.

headline: Ammon Bundy Case as Inkblot Test: What Will Jurors See in His Words?
abstract: What the jury makes of him, and whether his steadfast beliefs come across as arrogance or sincerity, could decide his fate when deliberations start this month.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The beard and cowboy hat that defined Ammon Bundy’s image to Americans on those cold mornings in January are gone. He is cleanshaven now and dressed in ill-fitting jailhouse blue. The federal wildlife refuge that he and other armed militia members occupied for six weeks in Oregon’s high eastern desert has returned to normal.

headline: Why Stews Always Beat Steaks
abstract: A fish stew offers extraordinary flavor for minimal effort.
lead_paragraph: I think that a stew is more interesting than a steak, whether it’s a beefsteak, a cauliflower steak or a fish steak. In terms of flavor complexity and satisfaction delivered to the diner, a stew always wins, at least for me. The steak is one-dimensional; the stew transcends the sum of its parts.

headline: Founder of Overheard LA, Which Pokes Fun at the City’s Pretensions, Is Unmasked
abstract: He started the Instagram account after eavesdropping on Angelenos in juice bars, yoga classes and fair-trade coffeehouses.
lead_paragraph: After decades as the butt of jokes by Johnny Carson, by Steve Martin, by Larry David — basically, by everyone — Los Angeles may seem beyond satire. But over the last year, the West Coast capital of excess has been a target for parody from an unlikely source: random citizens, courtesy of an Instagram feed called @overheardLA.

headline: Your Public Service Ad? Not Here
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'AIRPORTS', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: An advocacy group wanted to place a billboard at Newark Liberty International Airport which explained that requiring a passenger to switch seats based on gender was illegal. It was rejected.
lead_paragraph: Last year, on a Turkish Airlines flight bound for Istanbul from Tel Aviv, Jo-Ann Mort encountered an agitated Hasidic man who had been assigned the seat next to hers. Ms. Mort overheard him ask another man, a Reform rabbi in the next seat of their row, if they could switch places. Adhering to the strictest interpretation of Jewish law, the Hasidic man did not want to sit beside a woman who was not his wife. The rabbi said no, so the man asked several other passengers to change seats with him until one young woman finally agreed. Writing about the episode later in Haaretz, the Israeli newspaper, Ms. Mort described a sense of profound irritation that left her scolding the young woman for her submission.

headline: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.

headline: At Harlem Cycle, Fitness Classes That Speak to the Soul
abstract: A new boutique cycling studio in Harlem offers classes and music inspired by the neighborhood’s history and character, as well as a brick wall.
lead_paragraph: When Tammeca Rochester met with the fitness instructor Charles Tyler to discuss opening the first boutique cycling studio above 92nd Street, the two clicked immediately, she said.

headline: Is the N.F.L.’s Concussion Settlement Broken?
abstract: A look at the landmark deal, and whether it’s good for all retired N.F.L. players, or just those currently suffering from obvious brain damage.
lead_paragraph: The neuroscientist Robert Stern gave a keynote address at a scientific conference in Boston recently. He is the director of clinical research at Boston University’s Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy Center, which has been at the forefront of the research linking C.T.E. — a disease characterized by mood swings, uncontrolled anger, depression, suicidal tendencies and eventually dementia — to repeated head trauma. A focus of the center’s research has been on professional football players.

headline: Park Slope, Illustrated
abstract: Evan Sklar’s images begin with a photograph. He then uses an iPad app to draw from the original photograph, creating an illustrated version of his neighborhood in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Evan Sklar’s images begin with a photograph. He then uses an iPad app to draw from the original photograph, creating an illustrated version of his neighborhood in Brooklyn.

headline: Evan Sklar, a Photographer, Paints Brooklyn Without a Brush
abstract: A photograph is just the first step when Evan Sklar sets out to make an image.
lead_paragraph: Milton Glaser, the graphic artist, once said that drawing was for him a way of distinguishing what was real in the world from his preconceptions of it. “If I look at you now and make a decision that I’m going to draw you, I suddenly see you for the first time,” he said. “I haven’t seen the gradations of color between the bottom of your nose and the top of your lip, but when I decide to draw you, I have to. And so drawing becomes the means by which I understand what I’m looking at.” For the photographer Evan Sklar, drawing was a reaction to the images he saw on Instagram, which had all started to look the same to him.

headline: Another Celebrity Perk: Free Wedding Dresses
keywords: ['Dresses', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Celebrities', 'Shopping and Retail', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Some buy gowns while others seek a free dress as part of a marketing relationship.
lead_paragraph: The next time you click through a wedding feature on a celebrity website, or flip through a weekly gossip magazine, you may consider that the glamorous, sinfully expensive gown being featured may have been given to, not purchased by, the star wearing it.

headline: How Courtney Lavine, a Ballerina, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: For an American Ballet Theater dancer, Sundays are about friends, food, Netflix and a Maltese named Oopsie.
lead_paragraph: It’s going to be a busy fall for Courtney Lavine, a ballerina. Ms. Lavine, a corps de ballet member with American Ballet Theater, is scheduled to perform in Twyla Tharp’s “Brahms-Haydn Variations” and Benjamin Millepied’s “Daphnis and Chloe” at Lincoln Center. She will also appear in an advertising campaign for Avon’s new fragrance, Prima. Ms. Lavine, 27, lives with her Maltese, Oopsie, on the Upper West Side.

headline: Review: This Sublime New Dance Work Embraces Wonder
abstract: The choreographer Deborah Hay unveils her latest, with help from the Cullberg Ballet, as part of Peak Performances at Montclair State University.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The choreographer Deborah Hay has been known to ask, of herself and her dancers, “What if?” A Hay classic: “What if where I am is what I need?” That spirit of wondering — and of letting a question dangle — infuses her latest work, “Figure a Sea,” which had its American premiere at Peak Performances here on Thursday. Performed by 20 dancers of the Cullberg Ballet, with an original score by Laurie Anderson, it’s one sublime hour of asking without needing to know.

headline: ‘A Doll’s House, Part 2’ to Open on Broadway
abstract: The play, by Lucas Hnath, follows Henrik Ibsen’s heroine Nora Helmer after she leaves her husband and children; Sam Gold will direct.
lead_paragraph: One of Henrik Ibsen’s most famous heroines, Nora Helmer, is returning to Broadway — but not in “A Doll’s House.”

headline: U.S. Says Russia Directed Hacks to Influence Elections
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The government formally accused the Kremlin of stealing and disclosing emails from the Democratic National Committee and other sources.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday formally accused the Russian government of stealing and disclosing emails from the Democratic National Committee and a range of other institutions and prominent individuals, immediately raising the issue of whether President Obama would seek sanctions or other retaliation.

headline: David Bowie as Muse? Why One Composer Says So
abstract: Glenn Branca, who thinks of Bowie as an inspiration of sorts, will debut “The Light (for David)” at Roulette.
lead_paragraph: “I always write pieces right up to the last minute,” the composer Glenn Branca said in mid-September.

headline: At Carnival Fresh Market in Brooklyn, a United Nations for the Palate
abstract: From Uzbeki raisins to Russian sour-cream cakes, the three-year-old Carnival Fresh Market in Kensington offers nonstop access to international foodstuffs.
lead_paragraph: From the outside, Carnival Fresh Market looks like any other corner produce store. Crates filled with onions, peaches and four-for-$5 mangoes sit stacked, end to end, under a red-and-yellow striped awning.

headline: Trump Campaign Shifts $1.8 Million in Ads to Larger Markets
abstract: In key battleground states next week, the campaign is taking ad money out of small markets and putting it in higher density areas.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s campaign is shifting more than $1.8 million in advertising planned in key battleground states for next week, taking money out of small markets and reinvesting in larger markets, according to several media buyers who track political advertisements.

headline: Paying $15 Billion for Twitter Will Be Hard for Anyone to Justify
abstract: Suitors are falling away, and there is no way conventional financial analysis can help any company rationalize an acquisition of the company.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s openness to being sold has set off a tweetstorm with a direct message: It will be hard for a new owner to make buying the $15 billion social network stack up.

headline: Wells Fargo Isn’t the Only Firm That Needs a Lesson
keywords: ['Private Equity', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Some top private equity firms have been accused of putting their interests ahead of their clients’, but state pension officials still do business with them.
lead_paragraph: Under siege for setting up thousands of phony customer accounts to generate fees, Wells Fargo has taken a beating in Congress and the court of public opinion. Several states have piled on, announcing that they are temporarily cutting their business ties with the bank.

headline: Review: ‘Fit for a Queen’ Sees ‘Dynasty’ Centuries Before the TV Show
abstract: This play, by the Classical Theater of Harlem at 3LD Art & Technology Center, finds Egyptian royalty behaving like divas in the 15th-century B.C.
lead_paragraph: For those of you who can’t wait for the promised reincarnation of the prime-time soap de luxe “Dynasty” on CW, there’s plenty of glamorous backstabbing, diva dissing and sexual double-crossing in downtown New York these days, courtesy of an uptown establishment. And far more than any swanky 1980s television reboot, this production has every right to claim the name “Dynasty” for itself.

Among them was the “Modern Painters” editor Scott Indrisek, who tweeted this afterward:

headline: Voices From a Worsening Afghan War
abstract: Fifteen years after the American war in Afghanistan began, many Afghan families say the fighting and daily fear are worse than ever before.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — On this day 15 years ago, the United States began a costly war in Afghanistan that in several ways is more grim now than ever before. Now, even as the European Union is preparing to send tens of thousands of Afghan migrants back, war, intimidation and dislocation are a daily reality for many families in Afghanistan.

headline: How Many Times Have Both Parties Nominated New Yorkers for President?

lead_paragraph: Q. Unless Gary Johnson, the Libertarian Party candidate, starts to catch fire, we seem certain to elect a president from New York this year. How many times have both major parties nominated New Yorkers as candidates, and do those elections share any themes with this year’s raucous campaign?

headline: Mylan to Settle EpiPen Overpricing Case for $465 Million
keywords: ['Medical Devices', 'Epinephrine (Drug)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'ALLERGIES', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Medicaid', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: The government said Mylan had wrongly claimed EpiPen as a generic, leading Medicare and Medicaid to overpay for it. The company said the settlement included no admission of wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: Mylan, the maker of the allergy treatment EpiPen, said Friday that it had reached a $465 million settlement with the Justice Department and other government agencies over questions on whether the company had overcharged Medicaid for the treatment by improperly classifying it as a generic drug.

headline: T’s 50 Best Photos of Fashion Month
abstract: Highlights from the spring/summer 2017 season — on and off the runway.

headline: A Ballerina Goes From Baby Bump to High Jumps
abstract: The New York City Ballet dancer Ashley Bouder has returned five months after giving birth to a daughter.
lead_paragraph: The hashtag #bouderbump was familiar to the many followers of the ballerina Ashley Bouder’s Instagram account. And on May 4, a baby girl followed it:  Violet Storm de Florio. Before that we had seen Ms. Bouder, a technical powerhouse and a principal at New York City Ballet, executing whipping fouetté turns four days before her due date. Now, five months after giving birth, she is reclaiming her roles.

headline: Fiddling While Venezuela Starves? Bolívar Symphony Opens Carnegie Season
abstract: The country’s spiraling crisis once again puts the orchestra — which is opening Carnegie Hall’s season with three concerts — and its maestro in the hot seat.
lead_paragraph: Can music do anything when there’s nothing to be done?

abstract: A vulgar discussion recorded in 2005 on a soap opera set added to evidence that Mr. Trump has a record of sexist behavior.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump issued an unusual videotaped apology early Saturday after a 2005 recording surfaced that showed him speaking in extraordinarily vulgar terms about women, setting off an uproar in the Republican Party.

headline: Review: In Mahler, Philadelphia Orchestra Finds Beauty Amid the Grit
abstract: Conducted by Simon Rattle, who followed what seem to have been this composer’s final wishes, the ensemble gave a stunning account of the dark Sixth Symphony.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Despite its financial and administrative travails in recent years, including a bankruptcy filing in 2011, the Philadelphia Orchestra has maintained a remarkably high level of artistry. This was never more evident than on Thursday evening, when Simon Rattle led it in a stunning account of Mahler’s Sixth Symphony here at Verizon Hall.

lead_paragraph: When a family of whales from the Eastern Caribbean socializes they make up to 22 different types of codas, some of which can be heard in this recording of several whales.

headline: Solange Knowles’s Stylist Will Do Anything to Hunt Down a Look
abstract: Including calling designers’ dads and DM-ing their sons. Shiona Turini reveals the secrets behind the singer’s latest videos and challenges like tracking down vintage velour tracksuits.
lead_paragraph: “We just gravitated toward each other” is how Shiona Turini, a freelance stylist and an editor for New York Magazine, described connecting with Solange Knowles in 2012 at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: ‘Fire at Sea’ Strikes a Nerve on the Migrant Crisis: ‘What Can I Do?’
keywords: ['New York Film Festival', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies']
abstract: The New York Film Festival will show this documentary, which focuses on how two residents of the Italian island of Lampedusa live amid waves of migrants from Africa.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For a film that makes use of long silences, Gianfranco Rosi’s documentary “Fire at Sea,” about the tiny Italian island of Lampedusa — for years the European point of arrival for boatloads of North African migrants — has made some noise.

headline: The Top 10 Moments From Paris Fashion Week
abstract: There were big debuts, ’80s trends all over the runway — and a shocking crime.
lead_paragraph: There were big debuts, ’80s trends all over the runway — and a shocking crime.

headline: Review: This Dance Is a Jolt at the Joyce Theater
abstract: RoseAnne Spradlin’s “X,” along with works by Loni Landon, Tere O’Connor and Pam Tanowitz, are part of the “NY Quadrille” festival.
lead_paragraph: There was a long moment during the recent premiere of RoseAnne Spradlin’s “X” at the Joyce Theater when I wondered if the entire audience would walk out. For the final third (or was it half?) of the 70-minute piece, Kayvon Pourazar, Connor Voss and Asli Bulbul carried metal ballet barres and one another back and forth across the space, over and over. At some point, an audience member yelled, “Stop!” But the dancers didn’t, and it became a live question whether they ever would, as more and more people made a break for the exits.

headline: What Happened to North Carolina?
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: How a state with some of the mildest politics in the South became a magnet for national partisanship.
lead_paragraph: In late September, the skies opened over North Carolina. The remnants of Tropical Storm Julia crashed into Bertie County, on the Albemarle Sound inside the barrier islands of the Outer Banks, sending cascades of muddy water into homes and stores and forcing officials to release a herd of bison kept at a local zoo. Gov. Pat McCrory diverted his increasingly struggling re-election campaign to tour the soggy town. He had barely had time to do so before another storm, 130 miles inland, sent several feet of water from the Cape Fear basin racing through Fayetteville.

headline: Someone Mailed Feces to Four Philosophers: A Disquisition
abstract: The recipients were all professors who had taken issue with what they regard as the field’s hostility toward women and minorities, and its sometimes brutal arguments.
lead_paragraph: Philosophy is generally concerned with higher truths. But this week, conversation in the profession turned to decidedly lower-order functions, after word emerged that four philosophers loosely connected through a long-running, multisided argument with one of the field’s most vocal figures had been sent packages filled with excrement.

abstract: Thanksgiving in Canada has never reached the status it enjoys in the United States, but Canadians are still passionate about the holiday.

Tell us what you think and what you’d like to see at CanadaToday@nytimes.com. And, using the link below, please subscribe to the email newsletter version.

headline: Libya Starts Expanding Oil Exports — for Now, at Least
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: A militia has allowed Libya’s National Oil Company to export through ports it controls. The increase in production, however, could offset much of the cuts planned by OPEC.
lead_paragraph: Little more than a week after the OPEC cartel moved to reduce oil supplies on the glutted global market, embattled Libya has reopened a major seaport terminal for oil exports and has announced that it intends to expand production through the rest of the year.

headline: Obama Votes in Chicago While on a Fund-Raising Trip

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — President Obama cast his ballot here Friday, joking with staff members of the Chicago Board of Elections about being 20 years younger than he is.

headline: Finn Wittrock: The First Time I Started a Theater Company
abstract: Lots of kids like to put on a show, but few try Shakespeare on a professional stage. To Mr. Wittrock, acting was an outlet for pure energy at a young age.
lead_paragraph: Wolfe and I can hear the audience gathering on the hill, but we are busy in the Rose Garden, choreographing our sword fight with fresh sticks we’ve procured from the woods. “Head, leg, leg, stab, spin move,” Wolfe says.

headline: Sweeping Limits on Police Use of Weapons Proposed in Chicago
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Firearms', 'Stun Guns', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The policy would limit officers’ use of firearms and stun guns in an effort to address criticisms of the use of police force, especially against African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Police officials here proposed sweeping policy changes on Friday that would limit officers’ use of firearms and stun guns and emphasize the “sanctity of life” in an effort to address criticisms that officers have been too quick to fire their weapons and use force, especially against African-Americans.

headline: Costa Rican Soccer Official Pleads Guilty in FIFA Corruption Case
abstract: Eduardo Li, whose conviction is the 18th announced by the United States in its world-soccer corruption case, promised to forfeit $668,000 and faces up to 60 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Eduardo Li, the former president of Costa Rica’s soccer association, pleaded guilty to racketeering and corruption charges on Friday, with his conviction the 18th announced by the United States in its criminal prosecutions involving FIFA, the international governing body of soccer.

headline: De Blasio, Frustrated, Chooses to Take His Private Feuds Public, Again
abstract: The mayor condemned The New York Post in a news conference and in an interview with The New York Times on Thursday. Last year, he spoke openly about his divisive relationship with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: It had the flavor of a City Hall confessional: For 15 minutes, Mayor Bill de Blasio took pains in a nighttime phone interview to explain why the leader of the nation’s largest city would embark on a seemingly hopeless war with The New York Post, one of the most recognizable tabloid newspapers in the world.

headline: Jane Pauley Is Back — Again
abstract: Ms. Pauley was quick to point out the fairly incredible timing of her “Sunday Morning” debut: It will occur almost 40 years after her first day as a co-host on “Today.”
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Jane Pauley’s daytime talk show was canceled 11 years ago, she thought that might be it for her.

lead_paragraph: Conservatives are deeply split over the rise of Donald J. Trump. Some see it as apocalyptic; others as refreshing. But two pieces of conventional wisdom are largely unchallenged by either side.

headline: John Kerry Calls for War Crimes Investigation of Russia and Assad Government

headline: Brock Yates, Writer and Rebel Who Created the Cannonball Run, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Yates wrote more than a dozen books about cars and motor sports, and during the 1970s, began a cross-country race that inspired a movie starring Burt Reynolds.
lead_paragraph: Brock Yates, an automotive journalist who founded an anarchic, cross-country road race in the 1970s, then fictionalized it in the script for the 1981 Burt Reynolds film “The Cannonball Run,” died on Wednesday in Batavia, N.Y. He was 82.

headline: For Britain’s ‘Brexit’ Bunch, the Party Just Ended
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'British Pound (Currency)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A sickening drop in the pound signals that all the illusions around the vote to leave the European Union have been shattered, and that Britain will pay a price.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For those blithely inclined toward the view that Britain would somehow find a way to sever its relationship with the European Union free of drama or financial consequences — like canceling a car rental reservation, with a tad more paperwork — Friday was a sobering day of reckoning.

headline: In Rare Encounter, a Private U.S. Delegation Visits North Korea
abstract: Last month’s trip, organized by the Richardson Center, suggested a possible opening with the world’s most isolated country.
lead_paragraph: A private American delegation visited North Korea last month — two weeks after the country’s most recent nuclear bomb test — in a low-key humanitarian mission carried out with the Obama administration’s support, the organizer and the White House said Friday.

headline: As Hurricane Matthew Blows Past, Florida Sighs With Relief
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Power Failures and Blackouts']
abstract: The storm passed with out the catastrophic effects forecasters had predicted, and on Friday, residents began to return to areas that had been evacuated.
lead_paragraph: HUTCHINSON ISLAND, Fla. — As Hurricane Matthew doused the north Florida coast with floodwaters, high winds and rain, the mood across much of the state shifted from alarm to relief on Friday as the worst of the storm passed by without the catastrophic effects forecasters had predicted and some residents began to return to areas that had been evacuated.

headline: Cubs Enjoy Coveted Time Slot for Story Line 108 Years in the Making
abstract: If the Chicago Cubs capture the World Series this year, a team known for its tradition of day games will be seen in prime time.

abstract: In a 2005 recording obtained by The Washington Post before the presidential election, Donald J. Trump talks about women in vulgar terms to Billy Bush, then the host of “Access Hollywood.”
lead_paragraph: In a 2005 recording obtained by The Washington Post before the presidential election, Donald J. Trump talks about women in vulgar terms to Billy Bush, then the host of “Access Hollywood.”

headline: Detroit House Preserves Memories of a Little-Known Part of Rosa Parks’s Life
abstract: The artist Ryan Mendoza will create an exhibit using a house where Ms. Parks struggled after her courageous civil rights stand.
lead_paragraph: When Rosa Parks stayed there in the late 1950s, the house on South Deacon Street in southwest Detroit was modest — two stories high, with white shutters and a chimney peeking from the top.

headline: Toll Rises by Hour in Haiti Amid Ruin Left by Hurricane Matthew
abstract: Some estimates said that more than 800 people had died in the storm, and passage to many areas remained blocked, thwarting efforts to help survivors.
lead_paragraph: LES CAYES, Haiti — A hospital now a shambles, its floors swamped with garbage and water, absent electricity. People living in the streets, camped in front of their broken homes. Buildings smashed into splinters. Farm fields flattened, portending a hard year ahead.

headline: A Bill of Rights for Housecleaners
keywords: ['Domestic Service', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation', 'States (US)']
abstract: Domestic workers like me have long been excluded from federal labor protections. But states are changing that.
lead_paragraph: Chicago — For eight years, I worked as a housecleaner for a millionaire who lived in the Gold Coast neighborhood of Chicago. I took the bus across town three times a week, often to work in an empty house because my employer was frequently away, traveling for business.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, October 8, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “You know I’m automatically attracted to beautiful — I just start kissing them. It’s like a magnet. Just kiss. I don’t even wait.”

headline: No Hockey or J.Lo, but Vladimir Putin Still Gets 450 Roses for His Birthday
abstract: The Russian president celebrated turning 64 with a bouquet of flowers, one from each member of the State Duma, or lower house of Parliament.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia celebrated his 64th birthday on Friday with an outsize gift from his country’s Parliament: a bouquet of 450 roses, one from each member of the State Duma, or lower house of Parliament.

headline: Jim Kilroy, Real Estate Developer Renowned as a Yachtsman, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Kilroy, a former aviation executive, applied aerodynamic principles in winning five Maxi Yacht World Championships.
lead_paragraph: Jim Kilroy, a prominent California real estate developer who gained even wider renown for his exploits at sea, as a champion yachtsman sailing the largest class of racing boats, died on Sept. 29 in Los Angeles. He was 94.

headline: Period of a Revolution
abstract: Julian Lim delivers a lively Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Saturday crossword puzzles are tough, but the reward, after you’ve untangled the knotty clues, are long strips of lively entries that are fun to put into the grid. Add back in the satisfaction of actually untangling those knotty clues and you have one terrific puzzle.

headline: Howard Dean: How to Move Beyond the Two-Party System
abstract: The major parties have a stranglehold on our elections. A different form of voting would give minor parties a bigger voice in campaigns.
lead_paragraph: I stand with Hillary Clinton in the presidential race. Others will back Donald J. Trump. But polls suggest that almost one in 10 voters are making a different choice by supporting the Libertarian candidate, Gary Johnson, the Green Party candidate, Jill Stein, or another candidate.

headline: President of City College Quits Abruptly Amid Scrutiny of Her Finances
abstract: The administrator, Lisa S. Coico, announced her resignation a day after The New York Times contacted officials with questions about the handling of more than $150,000 of her personal expenses.
lead_paragraph: Lisa S. Coico, the president of the City College of New York, the flagship of the largest urban public university in the country, abruptly resigned on Friday, a day after The New York Times contacted officials with questions about her administration’s handling of more than $150,000 of her personal expenses.

headline: Elaine Lustig Cohen, Designer Who Left Her Mark Everywhere, Dies at 89
abstract: Ms. Cohen’s design career began almost accidentally when she inherited the job of creating the signs for the Seagram Building.
lead_paragraph: Elaine Lustig Cohen, whose prolific graphic design career began — almost accidentally — with signage for the celebrated Seagram Building in Manhattan, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

headline: New Jersey’s Gas Tax Won’t Be the Second-Lowest in the U.S. For Long
keywords: ['Gasoline Tax (US)', 'Wills and Estates', 'Law and Legislation', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: A 23-cent tax increase will go into effect Nov. 1 or 15 days after Gov. Chris Christie signs it.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON, N.J. (AP) — Gas in New Jersey is about to get more expensive after lawmakers voted on Friday to raise the state tax on it by 23 cents per gallon to replenish an expired transportation trust fund.

headline: Dale Schenk, Who Saw Immune System as Weapon Against Alzheimer’s, Dies at 59
abstract: Dr. Schenk tested the novel idea that the immune system, which fights infection, might be enlisted to fight Alzheimer’s through vaccines and other immune-based treatments.
lead_paragraph: Dale B. Schenk, a scientist and industry leader whose discoveries opened new paths into research on Alzheimer’s disease, died on Sept. 30 at his home in Hillsborough, Calif. He was 59.

headline: Walter Darby Bannard, Artist of the Color Field Movement, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Bannard spent his career exploring color, form and the physicality of paint.
lead_paragraph: Walter Darby Bannard, a Color Field painter whose elegant, severe abstract paintings of the late 1950s and early ’60s were the springboard for a lifetime’s exploration of color, form and the physicality of paint, died on Sunday in Miami. He was 82.

headline: Austin Kalish, a Writer of ‘Maude’ Abortion Episode, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Kalish, a TV writer who wrote extensively for comedy series in the 1960s and ’70s, took on sensitive social issues when working with Norman Lear.
lead_paragraph: Austin Kalish, a television writer who took on sensitive social issues in his scripts in the 1970s, including the fiercely debated abortion episode of the Norman Lear sitcom “Maude,” died on Wednesday in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 95.

headline: The Magic of That Wiffle Ball Sound
abstract: Control what you can, and don’t sweat the rest.
lead_paragraph: I grew up a St. Louis Cardinals fan in rural Mattoon, Ill., and played baseball in the backyard with friends. But there was a fence, and an angry dog behind it. If a baseball sailed into the neighbor’s yard, it was lost. And the cost of lost baseballs added up fast.

headline: Dodgers Defeat Nationals in a Pitchers’ Duel That Wasn’t
abstract: Clayton Kershaw labored through five innings, but the two home runs that Max Scherzer surrendered proved critical.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The natural inclination with every passing base runner against Clayton Kershaw in the fourth and fifth innings on Friday was to look at the visitors’ bullpen in left field at Nationals Park, which was an odd feeling with the best pitcher in the sport on the mound.

headline: Broadcast Booth Blues
abstract: Could it be that calling the play-by-play for a ballgame is tougher than playing major-league center field?
lead_paragraph: With the end of Major League Baseball’s 2016 regular season came a special kind of silence: Dodgers fans who had been listening to the golden voice of Vin Scully since 1950 will no longer hear his poetic descriptions harmonizing with baseball’s artistry. One of the great broadcasters in sports has retired (he won’t be doing the Dodgers’ post-season, which begins this weekend).

headline: Leaked Speech Excerpts Show a Hillary Clinton at Ease With Wall Street
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: According to documents posted online by WikiLeaks, Mrs. Clinton displayed an easy comfort with business and embraced unfettered trade in paid speeches to financial firms.
lead_paragraph: In lucrative paid speeches that Hillary Clinton delivered to elite financial firms but refused to disclose to the public, she displayed an easy comfort with titans of business, embraced unfettered international trade and praised a budget-balancing plan that would have required cuts to Social Security, according to documents posted online Friday by WikiLeaks.

headline: Donald Trump: King of the Old Boys’ Club, and Perhaps Its Destroyer
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: A taped conversation involving the Republican nominee shows a world women rarely see, and may not forget before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: “Lewd” was apparently not a strong enough word for the editors of The Washington Post when they tried to describe the contents of a recording they had acquired, in which Donald J. Trump is heard in a 2005 conversation with Billy Bush, the Access Hollywood host; they went with “extremely lewd” in their headline.

headline: Haiti’s New Catastrophe
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Global Warming', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms']
abstract: All those along Hurricane Matthew’s path need aid. But the Haitians need it most.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Matthew battered Florida and points north on Friday, having already wreaked deadly havoc in the Bahamas, Jamaica, Cuba and Haiti. All those along its path need aid and protection and, when the wind and rain end, swift help in rebuilding.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Media Freeze-Out
abstract: New York’s mayor can’t insist on his integrity and openness while refusing to take questions he doesn’t like.
lead_paragraph: If Mayor Bill de Blasio has decided that he is going to answer questions only from “real media outlets,” and not The New York Post, why doesn’t he just go all the way? Revoke The Post’s credentials, and bar its reporters from City Hall and make an example of them. Let the other reporters learn not to offend His Honor. And if they don’t learn, he can stop taking all questions.

headline: Queens Prosecutor Releases 71-Page Report on a Fatal Police Shooting
abstract: An announcement that no charges would be filed against officers involved in George Tillman’s death came with a detailed account of the investigation.
lead_paragraph: When a New York City police officer uses lethal force, prosecutors routinely examine the circumstances leading up to the death and whether the officer had operated lawfully. Often what they release to the public is limited to a brief statement saying whether they had decided to press charges. Or, if the matter is taken to a grand jury, the process is cloaked in secrecy.

headline: Hurricane Matthew Blamed for 11 Deaths in U.S.; Carolinas and Georgia Hit With Severe Flooding
abstract: Matthew came ashore in McClellanville, S.C., as a Category 1 storm. Officials in Georgia, North Carolina and Florida reported deaths tied to the storm.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Matthew made landfall Saturday morning near McClellanville, S.C., about 40 miles northeast of Charleston, as a Category 1 storm with sustained winds of 75 miles per hour. Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina were lashed with torrential rains as the storm sideswiped those states on its path up the coast.

headline: Corrections: October 8, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, October 8, 2016.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Cubs’ Jon Lester Shuts Door on Giants, Who Once Came Knocking for Him
abstract: Lester showed how important a 2014 recruiting battle turned out to be, leading Chicago to victory over San Francisco in the opener of their N.L. division series.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Within a month of winning their third World Series in five years in 2014, the San Francisco Giants sent eight people to Jon Lester’s house in Atlanta to make a pitch for the prized pitcher on the free-agent market.

headline: Joan Marie Johnson, of the Singing Trio the Dixie Cups, Dies at 72
abstract: A founder of the group, Ms. Johnson helped catapult it to the top of the charts in 1964 with “Chapel of Love,” supplanting the Beatles’ “Love Me Do.”
lead_paragraph: Joan Marie Johnson, a founding member of the musical trio the Dixie Cups, whose hit “Chapel of Love” unseated the Beatles from the top of the Billboard 100 in 1964, died on Sunday at her home in New Orleans. She was 72.

headline: Transcript: Donald Trump’s Taped Comments About Women
abstract: Mr. Trump was filmed talking to Billy Bush of “Access Hollywood” on the set of “Days of Our Lives” in 2005 when Mr. Trump repeatedly made vulgar remarks about women.
lead_paragraph: Following is an unedited transcript of the tape in which Donald J. Trump repeatedly made vulgar comments about women. Mr. Trump was filmed talking to the television personality Billy Bush of “Access Hollywood” on the set of “Days of Our Lives,” where Mr. Trump was making a cameo appearance. They are later joined by the actress Arianne Zucker. The transcription is by Penn Bullock of The New York Times.

headline: Trump Responds in 2016 to Outrage Over Comments
abstract: In a statement, Donald J. Trump said that vulgar remarks he made in an “Access Hollywood” tape in 2005 about women “don’t reflect” who he is.
lead_paragraph: In a statement, Donald J. Trump said that vulgar remarks he made in an “Access Hollywood” tape in 2005 about women “don’t reflect” who he is.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘45 Years,’ ‘Carol,’ and Lin-Manuel Miranda on ‘S.N.L.’
abstract: Showtime devotes the evening to women in love, with Oscar-nominated performances in “45 Years” and “Carol.” And Mr. Miranda makes his “S.N.L.” hosting debut.
lead_paragraph: Showtime devotes the evening to women in love, with Oscar-nominated performances by Charlotte Rampling in “45 Years” and Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara in “Carol.” And Lin-Manuel Miranda makes his “Saturday Night Live” hosting debut.

headline: Transcript of Donald Trump’s Videotaped Apology
abstract: In a brief video early Saturday, Mr. Trump expressed regret for vulgar comments he made about women in 2005.
lead_paragraph: Following is an unedited transcript of Donald J. Trump’s statement early Saturday apologizing for vulgar comments in a video made public on Friday. The transcription is by Michael Gold and Penn Bullock of The New York Times.

headline: Donald Trump’s Apology That Wasn’t
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Apologies', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: In a video expressing regret over his lewd comments, Mr. Trump remained defiant, calling the disclosure a “distraction” and used it to renew political and personal attacks on Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: For hours on Friday night, the political world waited for the rarest of expressions from Donald J. Trump — a heartfelt apology.

headline: Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell Reject Donald Trump’s Words, Over and Over, but Not His Candidacy
abstract: How the two top Republicans in Congress have responded to Mr. Trump’s comments.
lead_paragraph: How the two top Republicans in Congress have responded to Mr. Trump’s comments.

headline: ‘Obviously, Marital Vows Mean Nothing to Him’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers discuss Donald J. Trump’s lewd comments, the vice-presidential candidates on abortion, and the Chicago Cubs’ chances.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: An Investor’s Plan to Transplant Private Health Care in Africa
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Medicine and Health', 'Private Equity', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: A private equity firm is aiming at an emerging middle class that can afford to hire private doctors and avoid the difficult conditions of public hospitals.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The eyes of the private equity investor lit up as he strode across the empty floor of a recently built hospital here. There was not much to see: a stretch of unfinished concrete, and steel bars pushed into a corner.

headline: Inside Swarovski’s World
abstract: At the Alpine headquarters of the 121-year-old crystal maker, sparkle now competes with Silicon Valley as the company refashions itself as an incubator.
lead_paragraph: At the Alpine headquarters of the 121-year-old crystal maker, sparkle now competes with Silicon Valley as the company refashions itself as an incubator.

headline: Swarovski, Maker of All Things Bejeweled, Tries On a Hoodie
keywords: ['Glass', 'E-Commerce', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: In a village in the Austrian Alps, Swarovski, which has been making crystals for more than a century, is refashioning itself as a tech company.
lead_paragraph: WATTENS, Austria — A group of millennial programmers swapped jokes recently in their office’s well-stocked kitchen while preparing salads for a weekly barbecue. Others mingled around a new foosball table, playfully arguing over the prospective teams.

headline: Portraits of Pot Pets
abstract: The cats and dogs (and one turtle) take medical marijuana for various ailments. Our photographer captured them soon after they had gotten a dosage.
lead_paragraph: The cats and dogs (and one turtle) take medical marijuana for various ailments. Our photographer captured them soon after they had gotten a dosage.

headline: Pets on Pot: The Newest Customer Base for Medical Marijuana
abstract: Some animal lovers have turned to cannabis-based products to treat their ailing dogs and cats.
lead_paragraph: When Lisa Mastramico needed relief for her ailing tabby, Little Kitty, she turned to an unlikely source: marijuana.

headline: W.N.B.A. Stars Try to Move Up to Fashion’s Front Row
abstract: Why hasn’t a female LeBron James — a star of the fashion tents as well as the hardwood — emerged from the W.N.B.A.?
lead_paragraph: It should have been a breakthrough moment: Swin Cash, a former forward for the New York Liberty of the W.N.B.A., was on the cover of Sports Illustrated last spring, wearing not a uniform, but a red silk chiffon Michael Kors dress and a Hollywood smile for its 2016 “Fashionable 50” roundup.

headline: Awkward Sex, Onscreen and Off
abstract: Awkward sex is now a staple of TV shows and may reflect a sea change in gender politics.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you’ve seen the new TV series whose pilot episode begins this way: A man and a woman are having sex, but something soon goes awry, and the whole production wraps up on an ungainly, awkward note.

headline: Memories of a Secret C.I.A. Prison
abstract: Khaled al-Sharif spent two years in a secret C.I.A. prison, accused of having ties to Al Qaeda. He tells New York Times correspondent Sheri Fink what happened there, and how the experience continues to affect him.
lead_paragraph: Khaled al-Sharif spent two years in a secret C.I.A. prison, accused of having ties to Al Qaeda. He tells New York Times correspondent Sheri Fink what happened there, and how the experience continues to affect him.

headline: How U.S. Torture Left a Legacy of Damaged Minds
abstract: Beatings, sleep deprivation, menacing and other brutal tactics have led to persistent mental health problems among detainees held in secret C.I.A. prisons and at Guantánamo.
lead_paragraph: Before the United States permitted a terrifying way of interrogating prisoners, government lawyers and intelligence officials assured themselves of one crucial outcome. They knew that the methods inflicted on terrorism suspects would be painful, shocking and far beyond what the country had ever accepted. But none of it, they concluded, would cause long lasting psychological harm.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Samsung’s Exploding Products and Twitter’s Fizzling Deal
abstract: Mike calls Yahoo’s surveillance predicament a “flaming garbage fire” and hopes Alexa and her A.I. ilk are friendlier than HAL. Soon, Farhad will be in Asia.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: To Redefine Homestretch, Hillary Clinton Cues the Children
abstract: “Measure,” a new ad that begins with girls checking their heights against wall rulers, aims to stand out near the end of a negative campaign season.
lead_paragraph: The negative tone and vicious political attacks that have cluttered commercial breaks disappear, replaced by soothing music and home videos of children marking their growth against wall rulers, in a new ad from Hillary Clinton’s campaign titled “Measure.”

headline: Can Condo Boards Ensure Secret Ballots?
abstract: The secret ballot may seem sacred, but condos and co-ops operate differently.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a small condominium in Baiting Hollow, N.Y., where everyone knows one another. When we vote at our annual meeting, two volunteer unit owners count the ballots, so our votes are not really secret. After last year’s election, I received a nasty anonymous letter in the mail about my vote. The lack of secrecy in our voting process hampers our ability to vote freely and affects our relationship with the board. Other condo communities have a secret double-envelope system similar to the one used for absentee ballots. Shouldn’t that be a legal requirement?

headline: Sign of Thaw With Iran: American Cellphones Ringing in Tehran
abstract: AT&T’s partnership with an Iranian company suggests that promises President Hassan Rouhani made long ago of welcoming Western businesses may at last be coming true.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Rushing for a plane to Tehran because of a family emergency, the Iranian-American businessman stuffed his mobile phone into his carry-on, forgetting to turn it off.

headline: Review: Bob Dylan and the Rolling Stones, Electric, Not Just Nostalgic, at Desert Trip
keywords: ['Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: Songwriters who first forged their reputations in the 1960s are the focus of this festival.
lead_paragraph: INDIO, CA — Two names from the baby-boomer pantheon, the Rolling Stones and Bob Dylan, opened the Desert Trip festival on Friday night, starting a weekend of six bands led by songwriters who first forged their reputations in the 1960s. Saturday brings Paul McCartney and Neil Young; Sunday, the Who and Roger Waters (whose 1960s band was Pink Floyd), and the whole lineup repeats next weekend.

headline: Conflict at Work? Empathy Can Smooth Ruffled Feathers
abstract: Researchers found that forgiveness was more likely to occur when a victim actively empathized with the person who inflicted the perceived harm.
lead_paragraph: The workplace, like almost all places where people interact, can be a petri dish of conflict. Offensive remarks, unrealistic demands, people taking credit for others’ work, bullying — the transgressions that occur can take many forms. They also have the potential to escalate out of control and permanently damage relationships.

headline: A Ship Inspector Who Brings a Bit of the Barre to the Bilge
abstract: Helen Gault, an apprentice inspector who reviews the welds in submarines and aircraft carriers, has found similarities between shipbuilding and ballet.
lead_paragraph: Helen Gault, 34, is an apprentice weld inspector for Newport News Shipbuilding in Newport News, Va.

headline: A Bean Bag Blowout, and Then a Deafening Silence
keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Personal Finances', 'Consumer Protection', 'Automobile Renting and Leasing', 'Wines', 'Credit Cards']
abstract: PBTeen, a Pottery Barn brand, gives a customer the runaround after a bean bag chair insert bursts, and updates on Payless Car Rental and Premier Cru.
lead_paragraph: In this episode, a Haggler intervention and then a pair of updates about previous columns. There is a lot of ground to cover and consumer justice to dispense. So let’s go.

headline: What Went Awry at Wells Fargo? The Beaten Path of a Toxic Culture
abstract: Employees at the bank and other companies that have been involved in scandals get their cues from what management signals, not what it says.
lead_paragraph: A company discovers that its employees have been behaving badly, even unethically. Regulators swoop in to investigate. Public outrage grows. Company executives express shock at the revelations and assert that they never directed the staff to act in such a reprehensible way.

headline: Variety Puzzle: Split Decisions
abstract: Fred Piscop urges us to make two from one.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — You don’t need me for this, but I hope you’ll try Fred Piscop’s Split Decisions. These variety puzzles are so much fun. Print it out and take it outside to solve, so you can enjoy the beautiful fall weather we’re having. Or set yourself up in a comfy place at home with a warm beverage and make this your morning activity. You won’t regret it.

headline: Paul Ryan, Reluctant Supporter, Weighs Response to Donald Trump’s Remarks
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Ryan uninvited Mr. Trump from a rally on Saturday, and said he was “sickened” by Mr. Trump’s remarks about women. But he did not withdraw his support.
lead_paragraph: For months, Speaker Paul D. Ryan had chosen to remain largely silent, hoping that his party’s nominee for president would simply get across the finish line, dragging congressional Republicans across with him.

headline: Selling Shampoo, Eye Cream and a Chemical Crackdown
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: Beautycounter, a start-up that offers natural creams and cleansers, is pressing Congress to tighten rules governing ingredients in personal care products.
lead_paragraph: The last time Congress thoroughly overhauled the regulation of personal care products like cosmetics and shampoo, World War II had not yet begun.

headline: Rangers’ Best-Laid Plans Go Awry When the Playoffs Begin
abstract: The Blue Jays, playing their best baseball lately, have jumped out to a 2-0 lead in their American League division series against Texas.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — This, it seemed, was the team the Texas Rangers had been trying for so long to build. They had two aces atop their rotation, a deep and versatile lineup, a healthy mix of youth and experience, and a stable bullpen, along with home-field advantage throughout the postseason.

headline: Lewd Donald Trump Tape Is a Breaking Point for Many in the G.O.P.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Pressure built on the candidate to withdraw from the presidential campaign as party leaders urged the G.O.P. to shift its focus to down-ballot contests.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican leaders began to abandon Donald J. Trump by the dozens on Saturday after the release of a video showing him speaking of women in vulgar sexual terms, delivering a punishing blow to his campaign and plunging the party into crisis a month before the election.

headline: Elizabeth Michelis and Benjamin Litman: An 8th Grade Flame, Relit
abstract: A couple who had a 10-day bout with puppy love reconnect when they rally around an ailing baseball coach.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Ann Michelis, a daughter of Dr. Mary Ann E. Michelis and Dr. Michael F. Michelis of Tenafly, N.J., was married Oct. 8 to Benjamin Stephan Litman, a son of Helena Litman of Manhattan and the late Jack T. Litman. Katherine Jeddah Vailakis, an interfaith officiant ordained by the New Seminary, officiated at Wave Hill, the public garden in the Bronx.

headline: A Guarded Culture’s Old and New Ways
abstract: In Bhutan, a small nation with centuries of Buddhist tradition in conflict resolution, a new law school will incorporate those values in its training.
lead_paragraph: In Bhutan, a small nation with centuries of Buddhist tradition in conflict resolution, a new law school will incorporate those values in its training.

headline: Centuries of Buddhist Tradition Make Room for Bhutan’s First Law School
abstract: In a nation with a long-held tradition of resolving disputes through conciliation, a legal education is being melded with old values.
lead_paragraph: HAA, Bhutan — Under the gaze of the Buddhist god of wisdom, embodied in the form of a craggy hillside here, an American academic stood in front of 500 teenagers and posed a simple question: “What does a lawyer do?”

headline: Jets Seeking a Sharpness They’ll Need Sunday
abstract: The Jets, plagued by miscommunication and missed assignments, face the 3-1 Steelers in Pittsburgh.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Despite off-season sessions, training camp and now one-quarter of the regular season, the Jets (1-3) have been plagued by miscommunication and missed assignments that they will have to fix to have any chance in Sunday’s road game against the Pittsburgh Steelers (3-1).

headline: Scenes From Hurricane Matthew’s Capricious Path
abstract: In Haiti, the Bahamas and Florida, the storm left behind stories of disaster and disaster narrowly averted. Here are some of them.
lead_paragraph: It was first noticed as a bit of meteorological arcana. An alert from the National Hurricane Center at 2 p.m. on Sept. 22 noted that a tropical wave had been detected moving off the west coast of Africa but gave it little likelihood of developing into a major storm.

headline: Abbie Sorrendino and Andrew Brenner: A Train Crash and a New Outlook
abstract: After surviving a deadly accident, a man begins to treasure his partner more than ever.
lead_paragraph: Abbie Marie Sorrendino and Andrew Ryan Brenner were married Oct. 8 in Ithaca, N.Y. Liam Fitzsimmons, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at Willard Straight Hall at Cornell University.

headline: What Options Does the U.S. Have After Accusing Russia of Hacks?
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Pentagon and intelligence officials have been debating how to deter future attacks while controlling the potential escalation of a cyberconflict.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Now that the White House has formally accused Russia of meddling in the presidential election with cutting-edge cyberattacks and age-old information warfare, devising a response might seem fairly easy: unleash the government’s cyberwarriors to give the Kremlin a dose of its own malware.

headline: Hurricane Matthew Loses Strength
abstract: Hurricane Matthew made landfall on Saturday morning about 30 miles northeast of Charleston, S.C., as a Category 1 storm with winds of 75 miles per hour. It was pushing toward North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Matthew made landfall on Saturday morning about 30 miles northeast of Charleston, S.C., as a Category 1 storm with winds of 75 miles per hour. It was pushing toward North Carolina.

headline: Healthy and Rested, Lynx Star Lindsay Whalen Is Primed for W.N.B.A. Finals
abstract: Whalen, a veteran point guard, skipped the overseas season to heal and also benefited from a specialized training program and a lighter workload.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The Minnesota Lynx never let birthdays pass quietly. Lindsay Whalen sees to that.

headline: Why Republicans Are Probably Stuck With Donald Trump
abstract: Unless he becomes incapacitated or quits, getting rid of him is, legally and logistically, “the equivalent of a triple bank shot.”
lead_paragraph: The recording that emerged on Friday revealing Donald J. Trump speaking in vulgar and demeaning terms about women prompted extraordinary backlash from Democrats and Republicans, raising questions about whether the Republican Party could dump its nominee at the last minute and find someone more viable a month before Election Day.

headline: I.O.C. Expands WADA’s Authority to Lead Antidoping Efforts
abstract: Olympic officials proposed a set of changes to the global antidoping system, affirming WADA’s role in the fight against cheating and voicing support for increasing its budget.
lead_paragraph: With the Russian doping scandal still roiling international sports and dividing its leaders, Olympic officials met in Switzerland on Saturday to discuss overhauling the world’s antidoping system. They emerged with a plan to increase the power of the World Anti-Doping Agency, affirming that organization’s central role in the fight against cheating.

headline: Nationals Build a Contender, a Neighborhood and a Legacy

headline: Among the Post-Liberals
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: The Western order finds internal critics.
lead_paragraph: THE Western system — liberal, democratic, capitalist — has been essentially unchallenged from the inside for decades, its ideological rivals discredited or tamed. Marxists retreated to academic fastnesses, fascists to online message boards, and Western Christianity accepted pluralism and abandoned throne-and-altar dreams.

headline: What’s God Got to Do With It?
abstract: Religion explains why Hillary Clinton is struggling to unify her party.
lead_paragraph: Chapel Hill, N.C. — The first debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump featured plenty of magical thinking, but it was a nonreligious event. Neither candidate mentioned God. The second debate may be no different: Voters see Mr. Trump as either a prophet or an angel of death, but the only religion that interests him is his own faith in his “winning temperament.”

headline: The Nobel ‘Give Peace a Chance’ Prize
abstract: With its award to President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia, the committee has wisely applied the founder’s bequest.
lead_paragraph: The history of second-guessing the Nobel Peace Prize is a rich one. The awards to Yasir Arafat, Yitzhak Rabin, Shimon Peres, Le Duc Tho (who refused to accept it), Henry Kissinger, Jimmy Carter, Al Gore and Barack Obama, among others, all caused a stir in their day.

headline: Racial Profiling in Preschool
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Education (Pre-School)', 'School Discipline (Students)', 'Racial Profiling', 'Editorials', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: A new study suggests that biases against black children, especially black boys, are creeping into classrooms filled with 4-year-olds.
lead_paragraph: That black adolescents receive harsher disciplinary punishments at school than their white peers for the same offenses is troubling enough. But federal data showing that even at the preschool level black students are nearly four times as likely to be suspended as their white peers is especially shocking. What it suggests is that racial biases are creeping into classrooms filled with 4-year-olds and that schools are effectively criminalizing black children, particularly boys, when they are barely out of diapers.

abstract: Conservation isn’t just about numbers; it’s also about species’ knowledge and traditions.
lead_paragraph: Aboard the Balaena, Caribbean — I am alone on deck, my headphones filled with the sounds of the deep ocean. I have been tracking the sperm whales since 4 a.m. Now the island of Dominica imposes its dark shape in front of the rising sun.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Poisoned Prize
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: She’ll most likely rescue us from Trump, but not from the political dysfunction that helped to create him.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps something extraordinary will happen in the second debate, or in the third. Maybe there’s some other surprise in the offing. Barring that, it really does look and feel as if Hillary Clinton is wrapping this thing up. I expect that on Nov. 9, the morning after the vote, we’ll be talking about the election of the first female president of the world’s most powerful nation.

The provision, which requires voters to present government-issued photo identification, strikes directly at people who don’t have driver’s licenses — the state’s poor and disabled, young adults and the elderly, and particularly minorities.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Divorce,’ ‘Insecure’ and the Second Presidential Debate
abstract: Sarah Jessica Parker returns to HBO with “Divorce” — but here she’s no Carrie Bradshaw. And Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump face off again.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Jessica Parker, an HBO legend, returns to that cable channel with “Divorce” — but this time she’s no Carrie Bradshaw. Issa Rae boldly follows her with “Insecure.” And Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump meet at the second presidential debate.

headline: Donald Trump the Showman, Now Caught in the Klieg Lights
abstract: Donald J. Trump deftly used the blending of news and entertainment to build a brand, and then a campaign. But all that drama has turned into a big, messy show.
lead_paragraph: Above all else, the success of Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign was made possible by the media environment in which it was spawned, and his canny ability to exploit it. Now that same environment could very well be the thing that destroys it.
