headline: Attack by Palestinian Kills 2 Israelis in Jerusalem
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: An attack near the national police headquarters was the latest in an area that has been the site of numerous knife, gun and car assaults over the last year.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian gunman made a brazen choice of location for a deadly rampage on Sunday: Driving a speeding car, he fired at civilians near a light rail stop opposite Israel’s national police headquarters, on the main road that runs between West Jerusalem and the predominantly Palestinian eastern part of the city.

headline: What to Expect From the Second Debate
abstract: The stakes are high for both Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump as they prepare for the second presidential debate, a town-hall-style event in St. Louis on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The stakes are high for both Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump as they prepare for the second presidential debate, a town-hall-style event in St. Louis on Sunday.

headline: Inside Trump Tower, an Increasingly Upset and Alone Donald Trump
abstract: Shunned by many Republicans over his lewd comments about women, Mr. Trump spent most of Friday and Saturday at his headquarters as his advisers pondered his next steps.
lead_paragraph: It has been his pride and his palace, a soaring black skyscraper overlooking Manhattan that seemed to match Donald J. Trump’s ambition and ostentatiousness.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: With football helmet on and groceries in the kitchen, it’s time to put the pots, pans and skillets to good use.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: How NBC Finished Second on the Trump Video Story
abstract: Top NBC officials learned early last week of the video of Donald J. Trump making vulgar remarks about women. But it was The Washington Post that broke the story.
lead_paragraph: Days after a blockbuster video emerged capturing Donald J. Trump, then a reality television host, making vulgar remarks about aggressively kissing and groping women, a question was still reverberating around media and political circles:

headline: N.F.L.: Cowboys Like Their New QB, Patriots Love Their Old One
abstract: Rookie Dak Prescott led Dallas to an easy victory over Cincinnati, while Tom Brady was nearly flawless in his return to the New England Patriots.
lead_paragraph: ■ On the Tom Brady Revenge Tour there will be no such thing as “enough” offense. The Patriots quarterback, fresh off of a four-game suspension, threw for 406 yards and three touchdowns in a blowout win over the Browns but spent his postgame interview talking about how rusty he felt.

headline: Tallying the Toll of a Staten Island Drug Wave in Flowers for Funerals
abstract: A surge in overdoses in one New York City borough has given florists and undertakers there a close view of the damage heroin can do.
lead_paragraph: They are not like other mourners. They are raw. “Hysterical crying,” said Jackie Berger, a florist.

headline: Hurricane Matthew Blows Away Couples’ Wedding Plans
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']
abstract: The storm caused at least two couples — one in Georgia and one in South Carolina — to make last-minute changes to their plans to walk down the aisle.
lead_paragraph: When Jessica Lewis, 32, and Jas Jeet Singh, 36, were tracking the early weather forecasts for Sunday, the day their wedding was to take place on Jekyll Island, Ga., they were disappointed to see that it was supposed to be 81 degrees and partly sunny.

headline: 33 Injured in Collision of L.I.R.R. Trains
abstract: The collision, involving a maintenance train and a commuter train, sheared chunks off the commuter train cars, several of which derailed just east of the New Hyde Park station in Nassau County.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-three people were injured, four seriously, when two Long Island Rail Road trains, one carrying about 600 people, sideswiped each other on Saturday night, the authorities said.

headline: 'This Storm Is Not Over For North Carolina'
abstract: Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina urged caution as Hurricane Matthew continued to hit the northeastern part of the state.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina urged caution as Hurricane Matthew continued to hit the northeastern part of the state.

headline: Revelation Surrounding Novelist Elena Ferrante Exposes Cultural Differences
abstract: A journalist’s attempt to unmask the pseudonymous author sparked a backlash against him, reflecting a divide over what inspires that anger.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The apparent unmasking of an Italian translator as the pseudonymous best-selling novelist Elena Ferrante has sparked a trans-Atlantic backlash against the publication of the  findings earlier this month. But the responses to those findings also reveal a telling divide over what inspires that anger.

headline: Taking Over a Hong Kong Street for Pleasure, Not Protest
abstract: During pro-democracy demonstrations that blocked off a congested area in 2014, many appreciated the respite from traffic and fumes. A pedestrian-only proposal aims to recapture that calm.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As Dennis Wu sat with hundreds of people in the middle of a busy Hong Kong street recently, the scene felt to him like the pro-democracy protests of 2014 all over again.

headline: Lyn Wilde, 93, Half of a Twin Act in Movies, Is Dead
abstract: In the 1940s, Lyn and Lee Wilde played roles in films with story lines that capitalized on their similar looks. Later, Lyn went on to appear in several films by herself.
lead_paragraph: Lyn Wilde, half of a twin-sister act who charmed moviegoers in the 1940s, died on Sept. 11 in Michigan City, Ind. She was 93.

headline: What We’re Seeing in the Second Presidential Debate
abstract: Trump v. Clinton on women, national security and all else. Times Opinion writers weigh in before, during and after.
lead_paragraph: Trump v. Clinton on women, national security and all else. Times Opinion writers weigh in before, during and after.

headline: Utah’s Top Mormons in ‘All-Out Revolt’ Against Donald Trump
keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Outrage among Republicans about Mr. Trump has allowed Democrats to contemplate what was once unthinkable: taking the state for Hillary Clinton in November.
lead_paragraph: As Republicans across the country contend with the fallout from a newly released recording in which Donald J. Trump made vulgar and sexually degrading comments about women, perhaps nowhere was reaction more swift and decisive than in Utah, home to a sizable Mormon population already deeply unsettled by a sense of the candidate’s moral shortcomings.

headline: Donald Trump Highlights Breitbart Interview With Clinton Accuser
abstract: On Twitter, the Republican candidate pointed to a new interview with Juanita Broaddrick, who claimed in 1999 that Bill Clinton had raped her.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump posted a tweet on Sunday morning highlighting a new interview with a woman who claimed in 1999 that she was raped by Bill Clinton, signaling that he may bring up the accusation at Sunday’s debate in an effort to counter criticism after the release of a recording showing him speaking of women in vulgar sexual terms.

headline: Donald Trump’s Loyalists Aren’t Fleeing the Latest Storm
abstract: The Republican candidate’s supporters are apparently standing by him despite the release of a 2005 recording of him speaking about women in vulgar terms.
lead_paragraph: The tension that had burned for months like a fuse in Donald J. Trump’s unorthodox campaign exploded over the weekend amid cascading revulsion over a videotape that exposed him as a boastful sexual predator. In a season of serial, seemingly candidacy-killing outrages, the overwhelming sense was that Mr. Trump had finally gone too far.

headline: Lin-Manuel Miranda Brings ‘Hamilton’ Flavor to ‘S.N.L.’
abstract: The composer hosted “Saturday Night Live,” using his opening monologue to rap about the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Lin-Manuel Miranda hosted the most recent “Saturday Night Live,” looking as giddy and grateful as he did on opening night of his musical “Hamilton.” Even with the mega-popularity of that show, Mr. Miranda, clean shaven and shorn of a ponytail since his days starring in “Hamilton,” acknowledged the rarity of having a musical-theater composer as host of “S.N.L.,” saying at the top of his monologue: “Most of you watching at home have no idea who I am.”

headline: Behind Duterte’s Bluster, a Philippine Shift Away From the U.S.
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The move is a radical departure for a country that has historically been the most dependable American ally in Southeast Asia, and could undermine President Obama’s foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — President Rodrigo Duterte has vowed to expel American troops from the Philippines, accused the C.I.A. of plotting to kill him and  insulted President Obama with an obscenity.

headline: ‘The Birth of a Nation’ Struggles at the Box Office
abstract: The film arrived to an estimated $7.1 million in ticket sales over the weekend, apparently unable to push past the controversy surrounding its director and star, Nate Parker.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Any lingering hope that “The Birth of a Nation” could push past a controversy surrounding its star, Nate Parker, to become a financial success and an awards contender appeared to end over the weekend, when it arrived to an estimated $7.1 million in ticket sales — flop territory, especially since the film was backed by an aggressive marketing campaign.

headline: $1.6 Million Bill Tests Tiny Town and ‘Bulletproof’ Public Pensions
abstract: When the hamlet of Loyalton, Calif., withdrew from the state’s pension system, it was told to pay up or its four retirees’ pensions would be slashed.
lead_paragraph: Until the certified letters from Sacramento started coming last month, Loyalton, Calif., was just another hole in the wall — a fading town of just over 700 that had not made much news since the gold rush of 1849. Its lifeblood, a sawmill, closed in 2001, wiping out jobs, paychecks and just about any reason an outsider might have had for giving Loyalton a second glance.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Oct. 10
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: On Their Own, Afghan Forces Strain to Combat Taliban Offensives
abstract: The inexperienced troops, operating largely without NATO, are trying to break the insurgents’ siege in Kunduz and defend areas in the south and west.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — As Afghan forces struggle to break a weeklong Taliban siege of central neighborhoods in the provincial capital of Kunduz, insurgents are also stepping up pressure on urban centers in western and southern Afghanistan, officials said Sunday.

headline: Patriots’ Tom Brady, After Weeks of Simmering, Returns to Roast the Browns
abstract: Brady, back from a four-game suspension, threw for 406 yards and three scores, illuminating just how much New England had missed him even as it started the season 3-1.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Tom Brady looked at no one, spoke to no one, nodded at no one as he stalked toward the New England Patriots’ locker room early Sunday morning.

headline: Trump and Clinton’s Second Debate: Analysis
abstract: Here’s how we analyzed in real time the second presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how we analyzed in real time the second presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump.

headline: A Decade of Failure in the War on Drugs
abstract: It is time for Mexico to try a different approach, starting with decriminalizing personal drug use.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In 2006, Felipe Calderón, then the incoming president of Mexico, vowed that change was coming to fix the problem of drug trafficking and drug-related violence. To fulfill this promise he sent the army into the streets and embarked on a full-on war against drug trafficking.

headline: Washington Should Stop Militarizing the Pacific
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: China’s leaders feel their country has the right to be the main power in the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Americans often assume that Chinese military aggression is increasing the likelihood of a clash between China and the United States. But many policy makers in Washington ignore that Beijing has good reason to be troubled by the United States’ military footprint in its neighborhood. President Obama’s “pivot” to Asia — which includes doubling down on Washington’s already-robust military presence in the region — further stokes the potential for conflict between China and the United States.

headline: The Victims of War Are Sick of War
abstract: My cousins were killed and I had to flee. I don’t want those days to return to Colombia.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — I grew up on a beautiful island on Colombia’s Pacific Coast called Tumaco. My life was rooted in the land of my ancestors. We fished and traded. We were poor, and black, and neglected by the state, but lived in peace and with joy.

headline: Ryan Fitzpatrick and Jets Avoid Turnovers but Can’t Evade Steelers
abstract: Fitzpatrick, who had thrown nine interceptions in the last two games, was efficient and faced modest pressure, but the Jets were shut out in the second half.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — This time there were no turnovers, but another second-half fade left the Jets with their third straight loss, a 31-13 defeat by the Steelers at Heinz Field on Sunday.

headline: Hold Onto Your Teeth: 2 New Shows Herald the Creepy Season
abstract: Syfy’s “Channel Zero” is a cerebral type of scary, while Hulu’s “Freakish” is more action-based and screamy.
lead_paragraph: The scary season is upon us, and it’s giving us a couple of very watchable series in the next two days, one cerebral and ominous, the other snarling and screamy.

headline: ‘Life and Death on the New York Dance Floor’ Charts a Kinetic Scene in the Early ’80s
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Tim Lawrence’s book depicts a gritty commingling of punk bands, graffiti artists and hip-hop D.J.s that sent sparks flying before economic forces remolded the city.
lead_paragraph: If Tim Lawrence had wanted his third book, “Life and Death on the New York Dance Floor, 1980-1983,” to go pop, he would have titled it “The World That Made Madonna,” picked a different cover, and added a chapter or two focusing on her. He wouldn’t need to do much more.

headline: Famous for Its Past, a New Jersey Town Struggles to Define Its Future
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Downtown Flemington, made famous during the trial of the man who kidnapped and killed the Lindbergh baby, has been named to a list of endangered historic places.
lead_paragraph: This may be the biggest news about tiny Flemington, N.J., since the Lindbergh baby kidnapping-and-murder case in the 1930s, which Damon Runyon called “the trial of the century.”

headline: Review: Paul McCartney and Neil Young Share a Bill, and Some Songs
abstract: At the Desert Trip festival, Mr. McCartney displayed an air of casualness as he played his hits. Mr. Young was more conceptual in sentiment and sound.
lead_paragraph: INDIO, Calif. — All six headliners at Desert Trip, the festival of renowned 1960s rockers, have long faced the same question: How to choose a concert set from a catalog that has been growing for up to five decades? Paul McCartney and Neil Young, who shared the lineup — and the stage — on Saturday, had two disparate answers, though both juxtaposed some of their oldest and newest songs.

headline: Jose Lobaton’s Unlikely Blast Helps Nationals Even Series With Dodgers
abstract: Lobaton, a light-hitting catcher playing because Wilson Ramos injured his knee last month, hit a game-changing, three-run homer in the fourth inning.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If not for the frailty of the human knee, Jose Lobaton would not have played for the Washington Nationals on Sunday. Lobaton spent most of the season as the backup to Wilson Ramos, the Nationals’ All-Star catcher, who was on the verge of a large payday in free agency.

headline: ‘The Mothers,’ a Debut Novel, Is Already Creating a Stir
abstract: The new novel from Brit Bennett, known for essays about racial injustice, is shaping up to be one of the fall’s biggest literary debuts.
lead_paragraph: When Brit Bennett started writing “The Mothers,” she was the same age as the novel’s young protagonist, Nadia Turner.

headline: Trying to Disrupt the Auto Industry With The Onion’s Help
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Online Advertising', 'Automobiles']
abstract: Bypassing more traditional media outlets, Elio Motors reached out to the satirical news organization known for outlandish social commentaries.
lead_paragraph: PAUL ELIO, the innovative engineer behind the commercial three-wheel car, had only a vague sense of what he wanted from his namesake company’s latest major advertising campaign.

headline: A Monstrous Name
abstract: Patrick Merrell returns to scare us.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — It’s not Halloween yet, but Patrick Merrell offers us a spooky theme to start our solving week. We haven’t seen him since January, yet here he is, jumping out of the shadows and filling our Monday grid with monsters.

headline: Fall for Dance Festival Is Short but Packed
abstract: This event at New York City Center lasted only two weeks but was a cornucopia of works by new artists and renowned names like Alvin Ailey.
lead_paragraph: Let’s begin this account of Fall for Dance’s final two programs just by dropping names. Alessandra Ferri and Herman Cornejo, international ballet celebrities, danced a world premiere by Wayne McGregor on Friday and Saturday nights. On Wednesday and Thursday night, Alina Cojocaru, Friedemann Vogel and Johan Kobborg, names of equal ballet consequence, danced a one-act drama by Frederick Ashton not seen complete in New York since 2004. Friday’s program began with an extended solo by Shantala Shivalingappa, one of the most renowned of all Indian classical dancers. The Wednesday-Thursday fare also included another remarkable one-woman vehicle, Alvin Ailey’s full-length solo “Cry.” The list is extraordinary.

headline: Yes, Even Fresh-Faced Fans Cheered the Rock Stalwarts of ‘Oldchella’
abstract: Michael Cervony Jr., 19, and Travis Kray, 18, both college students, were as pleased to be at the Desert Trip festival as fans from an older generation.
lead_paragraph: INDIO, Calif. — Immediately after promising not to make any age jokes at the classic rock festival teasingly referred to as ‘Oldchella,’ Mick Jagger welcomed the crowd to “the Palm Springs retirement home for genteel English musicians.” He was just warming up.

headline: Hating Hillary Clinton: Female Comics Skewer the Sexism of the Likability Trap
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Jena Friedman and Michelle Wolf joke about the lack of excitement and hostility toward Mrs. Clinton’s candidacy, mocking the double standards behind the dislike.
lead_paragraph: The stand-up comic Jena Friedman has suggested a new campaign slogan for Hillary Clinton: “Give uninspiring a chance: Settle for Hillary.”

headline: Review: Simón Bolívar Symphony Orchestra’s Evolution Raises Issues of Mission
abstract: Gustavo Dudamel led the orchestra in three demanding programs to open Carnegie Hall’s season. But difficult questions hover over the orchestra’s artistic endeavors.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, in a breakthrough appearance, the Simón Bolívar Youth Symphony Orchestra of Venezuela played two programs at Carnegie Hall. It felt as though an inspiring roster of dedicated, eager young artists, against great odds, had come from South America to jolt classical music with fresh purpose and energy. Under Gustavo Dudamel, their charismatic conductor, 26 at the time, they delivered electrifying performances of Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony and Bartok’s Concerto for Orchestra, among other works.

headline: A Guide to Enjoying the Final Stretch of the New York Film Festival
abstract: The festival, which runs through Oct. 16, tends to front-load its big premieres, but it has grown so large that attendees can still find plenty to watch.
lead_paragraph: Every festival has its own agenda, pulse and profile. Cannes rolls out the biggest red carpet, Sundance turns newbies into indie stars and Toronto cranks up the new fall season with world premieres. The New York Film Festival has institutional heft — it’s presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center — and an advantageous spot on the fall calendar, which allows it to present hotly anticipated new titles in North America before they’ve become old media news. And of course the festival also has New York, where audiences still turn movies into kinetic social events.

headline: Review: ‘Miles for Mary,’ a Sendup of the Interminable Meeting From Hell
abstract: This play from the Mad Ones company would send you bolting for the exit, screaming, if it weren’t so funny and unexpectedly touching.
lead_paragraph: Though Dante cataloged many forms of diabolical torture in his “Inferno,” a guided tour of hell, he somehow missed out on what could well be the most excruciating eternal punishment of all. I mean (ominous organ chords, please) the staff meeting that never, ever ends.

headline: Pope Francis Names 17 New Cardinals, Including 3 Americans
abstract: The moderates from the U.S., along with prelates from several developing nations, reflect an effort to set a pastoral tone and steer away from cultural battles.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis on Sunday named 17 new cardinals, including three Americans, adding prelates from developing countries to give them a greater voice in selecting the next pope. Francis’ American appointments elevate moderates in the church hierarchy, bypassing doctrinal conservatives from large archdioceses.

headline: North Carolina Resident Surveys Damage
abstract: A gallery owner in Nags Head, N.C., a beach community, surveys the damage to his shop after Hurricane Matthew.
lead_paragraph: A gallery owner in Nags Head, N.C., a beach community, surveys the damage to his shop after Hurricane Matthew.

headline: Apple and Samsung Clash in the Supreme Court, and Sony Goes Virtual
abstract: The justices will hear arguments about whether Samsung must pay Apple about $400 million for copying part of the iPhone’s design; Sony will offer the $399 PlayStation VR.

lead_paragraph: The Republican Party was at the brink of civil war on Sunday as Donald J. Trump signaled he would retaliate against lawmakers who withdraw their support from his campaign, and senior party leaders privately acknowledged that they now feared losing control of both houses of Congress.

headline: Billy Bush, Host on ‘Today,’ Is Suspended by NBC
abstract: The news is a reversal for NBC News, which had indicated the co-host would on Monday address the controversy over a recorded conversation with Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Billy Bush, a host on the “Today” show who has received stinging criticism for his role in a video with Donald J. Trump, has been suspended by NBC.

headline: Palm Springs Police ‘Awake in a Nightmare’ After Fatal Shootings
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A suspect, John Felix, was arrested after the shootings, which killed two officers and injured a third.
lead_paragraph: The police in Palm Springs, Calif., are mourning two officers who were shot and killed on Saturday while responding to a call about a domestic disturbance. One of the victims was a young mother and the other a veteran months away from retirement.

headline: Hollywood’s Queen of Reinvention Takes on ‘Rocky Horror’
abstract: Gail Berman, who has championed women throughout her career, is known for her resilience, audacity and taste.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — In the late 1990s, still the dark ages for female executives in Hollywood, Dolly Parton invited a young woman to lunch.

headline: Indians Manager Terry Francona Has a Knack for Stories as Well as Titles
abstract: Francona seems to revel in telling tales that make him look inept at certain things, as his championship experience speaks for itself.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — As a baseball lifer, Terry Francona is superb at telling baseball stories. Once, while managing the Boston Red Sox, he stood in a hallway of the visiting clubhouse in Port St. Lucie, Fla., before a spring training game and regaled his coaching staff and a visitor with a hilarious, self-deprecating tale about how he had just been stuck inside the bathroom of the team bus as it motored across the state.

abstract: Dozens were killed in Allende amid a drug gang’s feud, according to an activist’s account, which also raised questions about American involvement.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The killers went to the town of Allende one weekend in March 2011 with orders to exact revenge. They massacred 26 people in two days, including women and children, because of a feud among leaders of the feared Zetas drug gang.

headline: North Carolina, Saturated and Surprised, Reels from Hurricane Matthew
abstract: North Carolina residents had been hopeful that Hurricane Matthew would spare their state. Then the storm struck.
lead_paragraph: LUMBERTON, N.C. — Brittany Graham had been confident that Hurricane Matthew would bring no more than a few inches of rain to this inland city. But by Sunday afternoon, her grandfather’s small farm was underwater.

abstract: A trip to the president’s adopted hometown during his final months in office had the feeling of a valedictory tour as he met with many of his earliest supporters.

abstract: In another preseason of complications, Rose is tending to legal troubles in a California court, and Noah is sidelined by a sore hamstring.

Center Joakim Noah continues to work his way back from a hamstring injury, and point guard Derrick Rose will spend his foreseeable future in Los Angeles, dealing with his well-chronicled legal troubles. As Noah put it last week, “Nothing’s perfect.”

headline: Theodore Anderson, Mathematician Who Advanced Data Analysis, Dies at 98
abstract: Professor Anderson’s postwar work involved equations that would reveal underlying patterns in the economy.

headline: Peter Allen, a Voice on the Radio for the Met Opera, Dies at 96
abstract: Mr. Allen, who presided over 29 seasons of broadcasts, said introducing performances was, except for his marriage, “the richest experience of my life.”

Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump battled tonight in their second presidential debate, and here’s my play-by-play commentary in the form of selected tweets. This isn’t a column or even a formal blog post; just journalism on the fly. Here goes!

headline: Donald Trump Featured Paula Jones and 2 Other Women Who Accused Bill Clinton of Sexual Assault

abstract: About 70 bicycle messengers tested their skills in Brooklyn at the North American Cycle Courier Championship.
lead_paragraph: The messengers showed up in Bushwick, Brooklyn, on Sunday, laying their bicycles flat in the middle of Waterbury Street, then stepping back as someone distributed photocopied manifests, the term used for a list of pickups and deliveries.

headline: In Second Debate, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Spar in Bitter, Personal Terms
abstract: Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton accused each other of mistreating women and signaled that the final month of the presidential race would be an ugly political brawl.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton collided in an almost unremittingly hostile debate on Sunday night, a 90-minute spectacle of character attacks, tawdry allegations, and Mr. Trump’s startling accusation that Mrs. Clinton had “tremendous hate in her heart.”

headline: Blue Jays’ Secret Weapon: A Very Busy Rebuilt Rotation
abstract: A team known for high-profile sluggers — Jose Bautista, Josh Donaldson, Edwin Encarnacion — got to the playoffs with pitching more than power.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — If you want to guess which teams make the playoffs without looking at win-loss records, the workload of their starters often tells the tale. If a rotation is good enough to pitch a lot of innings, chances are, the team will thrive.

headline: Andrzej Wajda, Towering Auteur of Polish Cinema, Dies at 90
abstract: Among Mr. Wajda’s best-known films are a war trilogy made in the 1950s, along with “Man of Marble” and its sequel, “Man of Iron.” He won an honorary Oscar in 2000.

headline: ‘Insecure’ Series Premiere: Single Black Woman
abstract: The premiere is at its best when delving into the tangled notions of identity faced by people in their late twenties.
lead_paragraph: Early in the premiere of “Insecure,” Issa Dee (Issa Rae) finds herself in front of a classroom of apathetic minority teenagers in Los Angeles. She’s there on behalf of a nonprofit that focuses on reaching out to the city’s struggling youth, and she’s failing terribly at connecting with them. They’re more interested in dissecting her hairstyle, dating status, and why she “talks white.” It’s the sort of razor-sharp cruelty that teenagers are exceedingly good at.

headline: For Cubs Fans, Enemy Home Runs Come With a Duty: ‘Throw. It. Back.’
abstract: Sending caught balls back to the field is a beloved tradition for many Cubs fans. But to others, “a home run ball is a home run ball.”
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When the Chicago Cubs pitcher Travis Wood unexpectedly hit a home run Saturday night in Game 2 of his team’s National League division series against San Francisco, the baseball found a happy nesting spot in the left-field bleachers at Wrigley Field. The Cubs fan who snared it even returned it to Wood after the game rather than keep it as a memento.

headline: Donald Trump Goes Low
abstract: Sniffing and glowering, Donald Trump prowled behind Hillary Clinton. Once again, she was the only adult on the stage.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump boiled his decadent campaign down to one theme during the presidential debate on Sunday night: hatred of Hillary and Bill Clinton.

headline: Martha Raddatz and Anderson Cooper Steered Debate With Sharp Questions

lead_paragraph: They dug for revelations, extracting news nuggets — a rarity on a debate night — like Donald J. Trump’s admission that he had used a nearly billion-dollar loss to avoid paying federal income taxes for years.

headline: Donald Trump Talks at Debate, but Many Women Hear Only a 2005 Tape
abstract: Mr. Trump may have uttered words about unfair trade deals or threats to national security, but what some voters heard instead was his voice on that searing recording.
lead_paragraph: It was Donald J. Trump’s chance to sound contrite and mature, to explain away the sexually predatory boasts he was caught making on tape and to persuade Americans that — for all his no-apologies braggadocio — he was, in fact, capable of feeling shame.

headline: Unexceptional Packers Offense Is Good Enough to Beat Giants
abstract: Aaron Rodgers threw for two touchdowns, and Green Bay kept the Giants out of the end zone until an Odell Beckham Jr. score late in the game, as the Packers won their second straight.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — The ball popped loose from Green Bay running back James Starks’s grasp Sunday night after he made a catch with less than three minutes to play and the Packers leading by a touchdown. For the briefest of moments, Giants wide receiver Odell Beckham Jr. and Coach Ben McAdoo thought another frustrating night for the offense might be salvaged.

headline: Donald Trump Acknowledges Not Paying Federal Income Taxes for Years
abstract: The admission of using a loss to avoid future taxes came in response to a question at Sunday’s debate with Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump explicitly acknowledged for the first time during Sunday’s debate that he used a $916 million loss that he reported on his 1995 income tax returns to avoid paying personal federal income taxes for years.

headline: With Help From an Error, the Blue Jays Sweep the Rangers and Advance
abstract: Toronto completed a sweep over the Texas Rangers after Rougned Odor made a wild throw while trying to turn a double play in the bottom of the 10th inning.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — It was not an obvious moment of infamy — no ground ball through the legs, no fastball down the middle just begging to be a hit. But the record will show that the play that sent the Toronto Blue Jays to the American League Championship Series on Sunday was scored as an error against the most notorious member of the Texas Rangers.

headline: Predators in Arms
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Is there a partisan pattern here?
lead_paragraph: As many people are pointing out, Republicans now trying to distance themselves from Donald Trump need to explain why The Tape was a breaking point, when so many previous incidents weren’t. On Saturday, explaining why he was withdrawing his endorsement, Senator John McCain cited “comments on prisoners of war, the Khan Gold Star family, Judge Curiel and earlier inappropriate comments about women” — and that leaves out Mexicans as rapists, calls for a Muslim ban, and much more. So, Senator McCain, what took you so long?

Trump’s campaign appeared to be crumbling as he entered the second presidential debate against Hillary Clinton, with Republicans withdrawing support for his candidacy after the disclosure of a vulgar recording that showed him bragging about sexual assault. Facing a barrage of tough questions, the Republican nominee managed to scrape through, evading questions, fabricating answers and attacking his opponent in deeply personal terms.

headline: Debate Takeaways: Clinton Is Still Standing, and Trump Isn’t Going Away

headline: 1891: Serious Train Crash in France
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: Passengers leaped from carriages to escape a thundering train collision between Brunoy and Paris in October 1891.
lead_paragraph: A serious collision occurred yesterday morning at Brunoy Station, on the P.-L.-M. Railway. There is a daily service of trains running between Brunoy and Paris, and the early morning train had just been made up on a siding. It was shunted on to the main line to take up passengers, and the latter had taken their places, when a goods train from Melun came up at full speed, and ran into the rear of the train. The shock was tremendous. Two third-class carriages were literally smashed to pieces, and a first-class carriage was wrecked. The force of the collision was such that the passenger train was driven up the line a distance of more than one hundred yards.

headline: When the People Choose Gun Control
abstract: While lawmakers refuse to act, ballot initiatives in three states could promote gun safety.
lead_paragraph: The vast majority of Americans — about nine in 10 — support reasonable, common-sense gun regulations. The numbers are only slightly lower among gun owners and members of the National Rifle Association. And yet, year after year, lawmakers in Congress and in statehouses across the country, all beholden to the gun lobby, act as if the opposite were true.

headline: San Francisco Noir: Photos From the ’40s and ’50s
abstract: Fred Lyons’s longtime muse is his hometown, San Francisco, whose streets and people have always beckoned him to dive in with camera in hand, day or night.
lead_paragraph: Fred Lyon is 92 years old and has photographed his hometown, San Francisco, for more than 70 years. His rich black-and-white scenes conjure a bygone era, when flash powder still existed, being alone with your thoughts was common, and the famed cable cars were public transportation for locals, rather than rolling tourist traps headed to Fisherman’s Wharf.

headline: 1966: Older Officers Are Kept on the Job
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The U.S. Navy extends service limits to try to tackle a shortage of experienced officers in October 1966.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The navy, battling a serious shortage of experienced officers, now is permitting older officers twice passed over for promotion to stay on the job, sources revealed today [Oct. 9]. Such men normally are forced to leave active service. This was learned in the wake of the Navy’s announcement Friday that it will continue to extend the duties of an estimated 1,000 pilots and other highly skilled officers for another year to meet Vietnam needs. And, in Saigon, the U.S. military command announced that some selected officers in advisory and staff positions in the various services will serve up to two years, double the normal tour.

headline: Questioning Gender Amid a Chaotic East Village Childhood
abstract: iO Tillett Wright’s debut memoir, “Darling Days,” is about growing up in the bohemian East Village of the 1980s and ’90s.
lead_paragraph: DARLING DAYSBy iO Tillett WrightIllustrated. 385 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $26.99.

headline: New Memoirs Show How the Other Half Lives
abstract: Two new books and one recently discovered manuscript shine a light on the tribulations of life in neglected corners of white America.
lead_paragraph: It might be said that the presidential candidacy of Donald Trump has something in common with Hurricane Katrina. In exposing how a major American city can share traits with the developing world, the storm broke apart one of America’s prevailing ideas about itself: the myth that for all our inequities and intractable social blights, this is still fundamentally a land of equal opportunity. Trump, through sheer dint of his own bluster, has conducted his own version of this exposé. By forcing blue-state liberal types to reckon with a demographic they had long dismissed as a punch line — low-income, uneducated whites in economically depleted regions — he awakened them to the fact that the groovy progressive social values they had assumed were a national fait accompli were actually only half the story.

headline: I’m a Doctor. If I Drop Food on the Kitchen Floor, I Still Eat It.
abstract: Why are we so concerned with bacteria related to the five-second rule? Other surfaces are far more dangerous.
lead_paragraph: You may have read or heard about the study debunking the five-second rule. It said that no matter how fast you pick up food that falls on the floor, you will pick up bacteria with it.

headline: When You Have to Go, Japanese Rest Stops Won’t Keep You Waiting
abstract: Amenities like five times as many stalls for women, and monitors showing the vacant ones, aim to make sure traffic is the only delay to worry about.
lead_paragraph: The kids are hungry, the driver has a headache and everyone has to go to the bathroom. If you’re traveling by car on a holiday weekend, the last thing you want to find at a roadside rest stop is a long line for a toilet.
