headline: Some I.V.F. Experts Discourage Multiple Births
abstract: As cute as twins and triplets may seem, multiple pregnancies can be fraught with complications.
lead_paragraph: This summer Louise Brown, the world’s first “test tube” baby, celebrated her 38th birthday as a mother of two naturally conceived children. In the decades since Ms. Brown’s celebrated birth, the techniques of in vitro fertilization, or I.V.F., have improved tremendously, resulting in an estimated five million babies worldwide born to couples unable to conceive on their own.

headline: When Do You Worry About a Picky Eater?
abstract: Many children become picky around the age of 2, so it’s important to expose younger children to many foods, many times.
lead_paragraph: I saw one of the white-food kids a couple of weeks ago — a 9-year-old boy who lives on French fries, chicken fingers, white rice and white bread. Some white-food kids are so strict that their parents have to warn the restaurant that if there’s a little ceremonial dusting of parsley on the French fries, the child won’t eat them.

headline: A Frog Dies in Atlanta, and a World Vanishes With It
keywords: ['Frogs', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Biodiversity', 'Fungi', 'AMPHIBIANS']
abstract: The Rabbs’ fringe-limbed tree frog, discovered only in 2005, was probably a victim of the global trade in amphibians.
lead_paragraph: Atlanta — Two weeks ago, the last known Rabbs’ fringe-limbed tree frog died in a biosecure safehouse at the Atlanta Botanical Garden. Its distinctive, barklike call was last heard in the wild, as far as we know, in a Panamanian forest in 2007.

headline: Tourists Behaving Badly: Name-and-Shame Effort Fails to Fix China’s Image
abstract: Brawling, vandalism and other boorish acts at home and abroad have raised doubts about the effectiveness of a “tourism blacklist” set up last year.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Two young Chinese tourists carve their names on the Great Wall. Hundreds of picnickers leave their garbage moldering on the banks of the Yellow River.

headline: Trump’s Second Debate, in Brief
abstract: He just lies. Relentlessly.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: California Today: San Francisco Fields a Mental-Health SWAT Team
abstract: Monday: Trained clinicians will assist San Francisco officers, a town reels under a $1.6 million pension bill, and Desert Trip wraps up its first weekend with the legends of rock.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Taiwan’s President Calls for New Talks With Beijing
abstract: In her first National Day speech, Tsai Ing-wen emphasized that Beijing should acknowledge the island’s choice to become a democracy.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Taiwan’s president delivered a resounding affirmation of its freely elected government on Monday, noting that its deepening foothold on the island stands in stark contrast to the authoritarian government of mainland China.

headline: Britain’s Economy Was Resilient After ‘Brexit.’ Its Leaders Learned the Wrong Lesson.
abstract: The pound is falling, and the confidence that had built up that Britain would not shut itself off from Europe is starting to dissipate.
lead_paragraph: This article must begin with a mea culpa. When British voters decided in June that they wanted to depart the European Union, I agreed with the conventional wisdom that the British economy would probably slow and that uncertainty put it at risk of recession.

headline: What I Learned About a Vanished New York From Gloria Steinem
abstract: Feminist restaurants? Fireplaces in bathrooms? Who knew?
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, the Times Metro reporter John Leland reveals some of the many delightful nuggets of lesser-known New York City history recently shared with him by Gloria Steinem.

headline: Britain’s Nuclear Cover-Up
abstract: A ruinous plan for a nuclear power project is a stealth initiative to renew a fleet of nuclear submarines.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, England — Last month, the British government signed off on what might be the most controversial and least promising plan for a nuclear power station in a generation.

headline: Was That a Debate? Or Were the Candidates Just Trying to Go Viral?
abstract: Donald J. Trump needed to drown out his embarrassing “Access Hollywood” video from 2005. So he tried to bring back 1998, and the Monica Lewinsky scandal.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a rough night in the first presidential debate, Donald J. Trump congratulated himself for his restraint in not attacking his opponent with her husband’s sexual history.

headline: Women, Children and Razor Wire: Inside a Compound for Boko Haram Families
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Women and Girls', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Arguing that “we can’t just release them into society,” a governor in Nigeria is operating a detention center for former wives and children of commanders of a militant group.
lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — Beyond the tall, concrete walls of a fortified compound, the authorities are holding a special group of detainees: the wives and children of Boko Haram commanders.

headline: 1966: Two U.S. Satellites Collide
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Two U.S. satellites collide in outer space, reported at the Astronautical Congress in 1966.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Two unmanned U.S. satellites collided in outer space last year [1965] but survived the five-mile-per-second crash, a U.S. space official told the 17th Astronautical Congress here today [Oct. 10]. The announcement was the most sensational statement on the opening day of the congress, in which 1,200 scientists from 30 countries are taking part.

headline: At a Christian College, Student Journalism Gets Religious
abstract: Administrators at Wheaton urge students to live righteously from an academic pulpit. We students hold them to high spiritual standards, as well.
lead_paragraph: If you choose to enroll at my small evangelical liberal arts college in Illinois, you’ll learn quickly that the Wheaton community is very much into prayer.

headline: The Best Team in the N.F.L.? Right Now, It’s the Vikings
abstract: While indicators don’t suggest the Vikings are a superteam, there is more to the Minnesota’s 5-0 start than a surprising offense.
lead_paragraph: Five weeks have been played in the N.F.L. season. The Denver Broncos, the reigning Super Bowl champions, have lost. So have the Green Bay Packers and the Pittsburgh Steelers. Playing without Tom Brady, the New England Patriots also lost.

headline: Paul Ryan Turns Focus From Donald Trump to House Races, Roiling G.O.P.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: The House speaker told Republicans that he would focus on defending the party’s majority in Congress, while hard-liners urged colleagues to keep backing Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: The House speaker, Paul D. Ryan, dealt a hammer blow to Donald J. Trump’s presidential candidacy on Monday, dashing any remaining semblance of Republican unity and inviting fierce backlash from his own caucus by announcing that he would no longer defend Mr. Trump.

headline: 1891: Steel Mills Clogged
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Steel and Iron']
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Steel mills struggle to fulfill mass orders in Pittsburg and Chicago in 1891.
lead_paragraph: Steel mills are reported to be more concerned about inability to make appreciable headway against the mass of orders already upon the books than in obtaining new contracts. Domestic consumers’ needs for the first half of next year are far from being satisfied, and the foreign demand for commercial forms would take up a large, additional tonnage if mills could promise shipments before July, 1917. Russia continues negotiating for 60,000 tons of barbed wire, and the closing of contracts for 7,500 more railroad carriages, requiring 75,000 tons of steel, is imminent. The great activity was in the Pittsburg and Chicago districts. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Oct. 11, 1891

headline: With Colombia’s Peace Deal in Doubt, a Battered Town Fears a Return to War
abstract: “We’re tired of so much violence,” said a resident of rural Bojayá, where 14 years after a guerrilla mortar killed dozens inside a church, 96 percent of voters supported an accord.
lead_paragraph: BOJAYÁ, Colombia — Of all the acts of violence that have scarred Colombia during five decades of armed conflict, few have cut so deep for so many as the slaughter that occurred in this municipality 14 years ago.

headline: What 50 Years of Earthquakes and Volcanic Eruptions Look Like
abstract: A new interactive app illustrates the connection between the natural disasters and Earth’s hot interior.
lead_paragraph: Earth has a violent heartbeat.

headline: Holiday Cooking
abstract: All the recipes you need to celebrate with a delicious meal.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Dozens Believed Killed as Violence Erupts in Myanmar
keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: The bloodshed in Rakhine State, home to members of the Rohingya Muslim minority, was set off by attacks on police posts.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — At least 24 people were believed on Monday to have died in western Myanmar after unknown assailants attacked police outposts on Sunday near the border with Bangladesh.

headline: Spending More Just to ‘Save’ Money Is a Self-Defeating Strategy
abstract: Letting the savings tail wag the spending dog is not a good plan, a financial adviser writes.
lead_paragraph: Just over a week ago, we learned that in 1995 Donald Trump “claimed almost a billion dollars in operating losses that could be used to avoid future federal income taxation.” On Sunday night during the presidential debate, he bragged about his tax expertise.

headline: Is Ralph Lauren Going to Be Hillary Clinton’s Dresser in Chief?
abstract: The designer and the candidate are forging a public alliance that could be image-changing.
lead_paragraph: Has Hillary Clinton found her dresser in chief? It would appear that way.

headline: Hurricane Matthew’s Toll Rises; Flooding Strands 1,500 in North Carolina
abstract: North Carolina’s governor said a levee breach in Lumberton had forced residents onto rooftops, with helicopters and boats sent to rescue them.
lead_paragraph: ■ Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina said Monday that an urgent rescue effort was underway in Lumberton, where a levee breach in the wake of Hurricane Matthew forced people to their rooftops.

headline: Daily Report: Your Choice of Computer Voice is Predictable
abstract: If your new talking computing device has the voice of a young woman, don’t be surprised. Most artificially intelligent devices sound that way.
lead_paragraph: Let’s face it: You’re probably not thinking about technology right now. You’re watching highlights of Sunday night’s presidential debate. You’re tweeting about it. Reading about it. Captivated by the latest outrage that makes Nixon’s flop sweat in the Kennedy debate seem, well, not exactly a big deal.

headline: In Haiti, a City’s Race Into the 21st Century Is Ruined by a Hurricane
abstract: Along with hundreds of lives, the storm wiped out much of the progress that the isolated city, Jérémie, had been making.
lead_paragraph: JÉRÉMIE, Haiti — Things had been looking up in Jérémie, a coastal city marooned on the tip of Haiti’s southern peninsula. It had recently gotten its first decent road link to the rest of the country, a new highway through the rugged mountains that brought development. Cellphone service had finally begun, enabling farmers and businesses to flourish. The city was racing into the 21st century, dreaming of advanced agriculture and tourism in one of Haiti’s few nature preserves.

headline: Trump Campaign Tried to Seat Bill Clinton’s Accusers in V.I.P. Box
abstract: An extraordinary backstage confrontation between Mr. Trump’s campaign and the staff of the Presidential Commission on Debates unfolded just minutes before the debate on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: An extraordinary backstage confrontation between Donald J. Trump’s campaign and the staff of the Presidential Commission on Debates unfolded just minutes before the debate on Sunday night after Mr. Trump tried to give seats in his V.I.P. box to a group of women who have accused former President Bill Clinton of making unwanted sexual advances.

headline: Solange Edges Out Bon Iver to Secure Her First No. 1 Album
abstract: “A Seat at the Table” beat “22, a Million” thanks to more impressive streaming numbers.
lead_paragraph: In an unusual face-off on the Billboard chart, Solange and Bon Iver competed for this week’s top spot with highly acclaimed, left-of-center new albums, and Solange won by a nose.

headline: Horse Racing
abstract: How many races do you need to identify the fastest five horses in a group of 25?
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge was inspired by Todd Unger, chief digital officer and chief marketing officer of the Daily Racing Form, horse racing’s dominant multiplatform media and e-commerce company. Let’s experience a bit of that equestrian energy with —

headline: Ken Bone's Debate Moment
abstract: Ken Bone, an audience member who asked a question about energy policy at the second presidential debate on Sunday, has become an internet sensation.
lead_paragraph: Ken Bone, an audience member who asked a question about energy policy at the second presidential debate on Sunday, has become an internet sensation.

headline: Donald Trump, Barbarian at the Debate
abstract: We have to stop grading this man on a curve.
lead_paragraph: What the hell did I just watch in that presidential debate last night?

headline: Freeing the Gmail New Message Window
abstract: When it suits you, you can unlock the New Message form from the corner of the browser and compose your thoughts in a different window.
lead_paragraph: Q. When using Gmail on the web, is there a way to occasionally make a new message a free-floating window that I can move around the screen, instead of having it anchored down at the bottom of the inbox?

headline: Coke and Pepsi Give Millions to Public Health, Then Lobby Against It
keywords: ['Soft Drinks', 'Beverages', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Children and Childhood', 'Obesity', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A new report documents the beverage industry’s deep financial ties to health groups as part of a strategy to silence critics and gain unlikely allies.
lead_paragraph: The beverage giants Coca-Cola and PepsiCo have given millions of dollars to nearly 100 prominent health groups in recent years, while simultaneously spending millions to defeat public health legislation that would reduce Americans’ soda intake, according to public health researchers.

headline: From ‘Locker Room Talk’ to ‘Muslims Report Stuff,’ the Internet Strikes Back
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Social Media', 'Debates (Political)', 'Muslim Americans', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Twitter has become the forum for three notable threads fueling public blowback to the presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: As the presidential election comes down to the wire, it seems as if Americans are grasping at anything to cope with the deluge of vitriol emerging from an increasingly bitter campaign.

headline: What You Should Watch: ‘Atlanta’ and ‘Supergirl’
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

headline: At River Café, Breakfast as a Celebratory Event
abstract: The restaurant on the Brooklyn waterfront serves a leisurely breakfast on weekdays.
lead_paragraph: At the River Café, on the East River, a goal is to provide a classic high-level breakfast “in the style of the grand hotels of Europe,” said the owner, Michael O’Keeffe. Though he is still tweaking the menu, his weekday eye-opener features choices like smoked salmon Benedict or avocado toast with poached eggs, and wines, Champagne and gentle pastel-hued cocktails. “Everyone stays for a long time, an hour and a half or two, relaxing away from the hustle of the city in a celebratory setting, ordering cocktails, Champagne and a surprising amount of caviar,” he said: Breakfast 8:30 to 11:30 a.m. Monday to Friday, the River Café, 1 Water Street (Old Fulton Street), Fulton Ferry, Brooklyn, 718-522-5200, rivercafe.com.

headline: West Side School Rezoning
abstract: A New York City councilwoman writes that “New York City has one of the most segregated school systems in the country.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Dizzying, Beautiful Stack of Pearls
abstract: One diamond-rimmed roller coaster is a meditation on the passage of time.
lead_paragraph: The multifaceted Parisian designer Pierre Hardy says the bold jewelry he creates for the house of Hermès is inspired by shape and feeling rather than particular gemstones. This dizzyingly sinuous cuff, nearly three inches high, is a diamond-rimmed roller coaster of 150 pearls in varying sizes, as well as a meditation on the passage of time. Within the curvilinear rose-gold armature, the pearls seem to flow from day into night, shifting in shade from the luminous white of a snowy morning to the bottomless gray-black of midnight.

headline: A Private Solution to Deutsche Bank’s Public Woes
abstract: The idea that Germany’s corporate titans might take stakes in the lender to help it manage a $14 billion fine from American regulators is not as nutty as it sounds.
lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank’s sliding share price and capital shortfall call for some creative solutions. And they do not get much more out of the ordinary than an idea that Germany’s corporate titans might take stakes in the lender to help it manage the impact of a potential $14 billion fine from American regulators, as Handelsblatt reported on Oct. 6. It is a less nutty concept than it sounds.

headline: Cheese Made in Switzerland but Aged in Queens
abstract: Annelies, from Murray’s Cheese and the Swiss cheese producer Walter Rass, is tart and nutty.
lead_paragraph: Murray’s Cheese often buys young cheeses from artisanal producers and ages them in its “caves” in Queens. The latest is an Appenzeller-style mountain cheese from Walter Rass in Switzerland, whose mild, immature wheels are usually sold only in his village. At Murray’s, Mr. Rass’s cheeses are stored for nine months, acquiring a nutty, robust grassiness. They’re tart, with hints of caramel, and beg for a glass of sauvignon blanc: Annelies, $34.99 a pound, Murray’s Cheese shops, murrayscheese.com.

headline: Premier League Stars Score the Goals. He Scores Everything Else.
abstract: To hundreds of players in English soccer over the past 20 years, Charles Porter and his staff have been indispensable in providing the Premier League lifestyle.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, England — Charles Porter and his staff of eight work from his office in a converted riding school on the grounds of Aske Hall, an old manor house set in the gentle, rolling hills of North Yorkshire. His Australian Labradoodles, Bertie and Cybil, spend their days lounging on a leather sofa by a roaring fire.

headline: Ken Bone Is Closer to Deciding, After Debate
abstract: Many people were fascinated by Mr. Bone, the undecided voter in the red sweater who asked a policy question Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: A desperate America seeking distraction from an ugly political climate may have found a new sweetheart. He is Kenneth Bone, an undecided voter in a bright red sweater.

headline: Why Doesn’t the United States (Finally) Get Rid of the Penny?
abstract: Coining pennies is a money-losing proposition, and people don’t really need them anymore.
lead_paragraph: Ask The Times, a Times Insider feature, draws on New York Times expertise to answer questions about current events, science, sports, culture and whatever else is making headlines.

headline: Stomping Grapes in Brooklyn
abstract: Participants can stomp grapes on the sidewalk in front of Little Mo Wine in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens.
lead_paragraph: Stomping on grapes for wine has gone the way of the horse and buggy, but on occasion it is brought back for a touch of the past and some freewheeling fun. That’s what Mark Schwartz will try in front of his Brooklyn wine shop this weekend. Tubs of grapes will be hauled out for willing participants to try their hand — er, foot — at crushing, either barefoot or wrapped in plastic: Grape stomp, noon to 5 p.m. on Saturday, Little Mo Wine & Spirits, 1125 Nostrand Avenue (Midwood Street), Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, 718-363-2101, littlemowine.com.

headline: Katharine Hayhoe, a Climate Explainer Who Stays Above the Storm
abstract: “If you begin a conversation with, ‘You’re an idiot,’ that’s the end of the conversation, too,” says the Texas Tech scientist, an evangelical Christian spreading a gospel on warming.
lead_paragraph: LUBBOCK, Tex. — A member of Katharine Hayhoe’s church asked her a question after services a couple of weeks ago: “Do you feel our weather is getting more extreme?”

headline: In Experiment, Apes Have Humans Figured Out
abstract: After watching a scenario between an actor and a man in a King Kong suit, apes appeared to know what the actor believed.
lead_paragraph: Apes know what you’re thinking. Or at least an experiment suggests they do.

headline: Warming Relations in Person, Putin and Erdogan Revive Pipeline Deal
abstract: At an energy conference in Istanbul, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia agreed with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey to proceed with the suspended Turkish Stream pipeline project.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Amid increasingly tense relations with the United States over Syria, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia took advantage of a routine meeting in Istanbul on Monday to advance the Kremlin’s reconciliation with Turkey, including an agreement to revive a suspended natural-gas pipeline project.

headline: Cancer in Retreat on One Front: Fewer Children Are Dying
abstract: Deaths from childhood cancer fell 20 percent in the United States from 1999 to 2014. Clinical trials have led to small changes in practice, one expert said.
lead_paragraph: Children are dying less often from cancer, with substantial declines in all races and age groups, according to a new report from the National Center for Health Statistics.

headline: Why’d You Do That? Printing Donald Trump’s Vulgarities
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The Times’s political editor Carolyn Ryan discusses the decision to print the exact language Donald Trump was captured uttering on tape.
lead_paragraph: Coverage of the leaked 2005 audio tape of  Donald Trump speaking in lewd language about women has produced an onslaught of reader mail, mostly because of the vile words contained in the coverage. The majority of those writing in are asking how the decision was made rather than complaining about the choice to include such words. I went to the Times political editor Carolyn Ryan to ask some of the readers’ most frequent questions.

headline: Hatch Chiles in Mild, Medium or Hot
abstract: Zia Green Chile Company sells New Mexico chiles jarred or fresh roasted.
lead_paragraph: New Mexico is known for its chiles from the Hatch Valley in the southern part of the state; chiles with varying heat levels are grown there and labeled Hatch. Zia Green Chile Company of Brooklyn sells jars of medium-hot or hot green chiles from Hatch, along with mild red; all are simply cooked, diced and preserved with lime, garlic and salt. The medium-hot green is vegetal and smoky, the hot is powerful, and the red has more fire than you would expect. They’re worth keeping in the refrigerator as a go-to condiment or spicy addition to recipes. The company also sells fresh roasted chiles from New Mexico; the 2016 harvest is ready for pre-order for shipping in coming weeks: Zia Green Chiles, 16-ounce jars, $10; roasted chiles, $35 for five pounds, www.ziagreenchileco.com.

headline: After Nearly 44 Years, and 3 Major Terrorism Trials, a Judge Leaves the Bench
abstract: Judge Kevin Thomas Duffy, who retired last month, is best known for presiding in three of the country’s biggest federal terrorism trials, two of them stemming from the 1993 World Trade Center attack.
lead_paragraph: From his seat on the bench, Judge Kevin Thomas Duffy listened patiently to the man he would soon put in prison for the rest of his life.

headline: First a Room, and Now a Book of Chocolate
abstract: This new cookbook from a small Brooklyn cafe is chockablock chocolate.
lead_paragraph: Grab that offset spatula, some parchment paper, many slabs of chocolate (60 to 100 percent cacao) and extra-large eggs, and you’re ready to tackle this new collection of recipes from the Chocolate Room, a cafe in Park Slope, Brooklyn, with a branch in Cobble Hill. Consider making a three-layer blackout-style cake (with the thoughtful option of a single layer), a classic chocolate cream pie, a flourless cake baked in a water bath, insanely rich chocolate ice cream or simple dark chocolate and walnut cookies. For each, the equipment needed is thoroughly detailed, as is the shelf life for the results, which can be surprising, like three to four days in the refrigerator for the chocolate cream pie: “There’s Always Room for Chocolate: Recipes From Brooklyn’s the Chocolate Room,” by Naomi Josepher, Jon Payson and Georgia Freedman (Rizzoli $32.50).

headline: Highlights From the Clinton Campaign Emails: How to Deal With Sanders and Biden
abstract: The latest leaked emails reveal the careful deliberations aides engaged in on even small details and showed a bitter dispute between the Clintons’ daughter and a top aide.

headline: Jamaican Rock Iguanas Get a Shot at a New Home in the Wild
abstract: A decision on the siting of a seaport could improve the prospects of the restoration of the lizards, which were once believed to be extinct.
lead_paragraph: Meet the Jamaican rock iguana. Its scaly body stretches around two feet long, tail not included. Slate blue spikes stick up along its spine, and a saggy sac of loose skin wraps around its head like a hoodless cowl. When cornered, it strikes with its front claws — one reportedly ripped an eye from a dog.

headline: Letters: Vast Majority of N.F.L. Retirees Favor Concussion Settlement
abstract: N.F.L. lawyers involved in the case say the agreement spares former players a lengthy and costly litigation and guarantees them generous compensation.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Learning From Dogs as They Sniff Out Their World
abstract: A walk in the park with an author and her pet also gives insight as to why canines avidly sniff things like toes, rears and corpses.
lead_paragraph: Our daily tug of leash war goes like this. I tell Chico we’re taking a left. He yanks right, wet black nostrils burrowing in loamy leaf piles. Me versus a 15-pound Havanese, incensed by scent.

headline: What Story Did Debate Night Body Language Tell?
abstract: Donald Trump’s hovering over Hillary Clinton was seen as an attempt to exert dominance, and the candidates showed that their differences had become personal.
lead_paragraph: From the opening handshake that did not happen to the stone-faced stares and surly scowls, it was evident from watching Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton share a debate stage on Sunday night that their political differences have become personal and that the mutual distaste that they feel is very real.

headline: Review: The Philharmonic Revisits an Early Triumph of Its Director
abstract: Alan Gilbert, nearing the end of his tenure as director of the New York Philharmonic, injected some humor in a program of Ligeti and Beethoven.
lead_paragraph: Alan Gilbert, approaching the end of his tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic, briefly revisited an early triumph last week in the orchestra’s subscription concerts at David Geffen Hall. In 2010, Mr. Gilbert collaborated with the director Doug Fitch on an innovative staging of Gyorgy Ligeti’s satirical opera “Le Grand Macabre” (1978), an absurdist take on nothing less than the end of the world.

headline: Climate Change Blamed for Half of Increased Forest Fire Danger
keywords: ['Wildfires', 'Global Warming', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Drought']
abstract: A study found that human-caused warming was responsible for 55 percent of the rise in the dryness of the landscape in the western United States.
lead_paragraph: Forest fires are burning longer and stronger across the western United States, lighting up the landscape with alarming frequency. Residents are forced to flee, homes are incinerated, wildlife habitats are destroyed, lives are lost. Last year, the Forest Service spent more than half its annual budget fighting fires.

headline: For G.O.P. Candidates, Renouncing Donald Trump Carries Dire Risks
abstract: In interviews, many Trump supporters in Arizona and New Hampshire spoke witheringly of incumbents who have withdrawn their support for the party’s presidential nominee.
lead_paragraph: Paula Barche Rupnik, a Republican from Scottsdale, Ariz., was planning to vote for Senator John McCain in his re-election campaign this year. But she changed her mind this weekend, after he rescinded his support for Donald J. Trump.

headline: Deutsche Bank and Walmart Face Same Gambit With Justice Dept.
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities']
abstract: Recent efforts by corporations to settle criminal cases have all the hallmarks of the kind of posturing seen at a poker table.
lead_paragraph: When companies are caught up in an investigation, the question is almost always about how much they will have to pay the government to resolve the case. The negotiations can seem like a poker game, with one side throwing out a number while the other claims it would rather fight than agree to such a sum.

headline: Home and Work: Nata Janberidze and Keti Toloraia
abstract: Inside the homes and studio of a pair of emerging Georgian designers, who playfully spin the future out of their uneasy Soviet past.
lead_paragraph: Inside the homes and studio of a pair of emerging Georgian designers, who playfully spin the future out of their uneasy Soviet past.

headline: Georgia’s Emerging, Avant-Garde Designers to Know
abstract: Nata Janberidze and Keti Toloraia draw inspiration from their Soviet past — to make beautiful, timeless things. Here, inside their homes and studio.
lead_paragraph: Strictly speaking, Nata Janberidze and Keti Toloraia began their creative collaboration in a vacuum. When they started designing objects and interiors a ­decade ago, fresh out of art school, their hometown Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia, a small country on the Black Sea that spent much of the 20th century as part of the Soviet Union, had no creative community for two young designers to gain inspiration from, or any local market for the one-of-a-kind groundbreaking pieces they designed under the distinctly Western, purposefully plain name Rooms.

headline: Donald Trump, ‘Locker-Room Talk’ and Sexual Assault
abstract: “The casual, behind-closed-doors sexism that Mr. Trump excuses directly feeds male entitlement and rape culture,” one reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tiger Woods Postpones Return, Saying He’s ‘Not Ready to Compete’
abstract: Three days after committing to play, Woods withdrew from the Safeway Open, the PGA Tour’s season opener, as interest in his comeback intensified.
lead_paragraph: Three days after Tiger Woods committed to his first PGA Tour event in 14 months, he abruptly withdrew, leaving this week’s Safeway Open with twice as many tickets sold as a year ago but a fraction of the star power.

headline: #MyRunLooksLike: Show Us Your Marathon Training
abstract: We want a glimpse of your road to the marathon start line. Share your photos on Instagram using #MyRunLooksLike.
lead_paragraph: We want a glimpse of your road to the marathon start line. Share your photos on Instagram using #MyRunLooksLike.

headline: Review: In ‘American Housewife,’ a Plus-Size Mom in the Land of Fitbits
abstract: This ABC sitcom stars Katy Mixon as a mother of three who doesn’t quite fit in, in wealthy Westport, Conn., and is proud of it.
lead_paragraph: “American Housewife,” an awful attempt to transplant “Roseanne” into the age of economic inequality, mistakes sophomoric for subversive. The show, which begins Tuesday on ABC, seems to be angling for what it views as an underserved demographic, all those malcontented Americans we keep reading about in connection with the presidential election, the ones who are stuck in a can’t-get-ahead life because the privileged class has mucked things up and taken all the money. In this show’s interpretation, the down-and-outs spend their days telling potty jokes, thinking the whole world hates them because of their weight, and in general emitting contempt for everyone and everything, including their own children.

headline: Tyson Foods, a Meat Leader, Invests in Protein Alternatives
abstract: Tyson is investing an undisclosed amount for a 5 percent stake in Beyond Meat, which makes the plant-protein Beyond Burger.
lead_paragraph: Tyson Foods appears to be the first big meat company to invest in a business that, among other things, aims to reduce consumption of chicken, beef and pork by replacing it with plant proteins.

headline: Review: ‘Godzilla’ Returns, Again, With a Wink
abstract: “Shin Godzilla” puts Tokyo in peril. Can the bumbling bureaucrats get their act together in time?
lead_paragraph: You either like your “Godzilla” movies slick and high-budget, like the 1998 American version that starred Matthew Broderick, or you like them with a rickety, 1950s feel that evokes the original.

headline: Yale Rep Celebrates Its 50th Amid Nostalgia (and a Few Worries)
abstract: The company honored its milestone last weekend with visits from past figures who lauded its history while expressing concern for regional theater’s future.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — Leave it to Robert Brustein, the outspoken founding director of Yale Repertory Theater, to raise tough questions at a celebration of the theater’s 50th anniversary this weekend.

headline: The Trees of New York City
abstract: Why do I see only deciduous trees, not evergreens, planted along New York City streets?
lead_paragraph: Q. Why do I see only deciduous trees, not evergreens, planted along New York City streets?

headline: 5 One-Liners That Sum Up a Fiery Trump-Clinton Debate
abstract: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton let the zingers fly as they clashed over how he and former President Bill Clinton have treated women in the past.
lead_paragraph: The second presidential debate was one of the nastiest ever. There was no shortage of eye-rolls, sighs and gestures of faux politeness that dripped with sarcasm. After weeks of throwing flames from afar, Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton let the zingers fly on Sunday night.

headline: Members of Congress Ask N.H.L. for More Concussion Information
abstract: Representatives from the Committee on Energy and Commerce want more answers from the commissioner of the N.H.L. about what the league is doing about concussions.
lead_paragraph: Four members of Congress want more answers from Gary Bettman, the commissioner of the N.H.L., about what the league is doing, or not doing, about concussions in hockey.

headline: Species, Interrupted – Why it Matters When Extinction Silences a Tree Frog
abstract: The wider meanings in the apparent extinction of an obscure but remarkable tree frog from Panama.
lead_paragraph: When someone notable attains a certain age, newspapers assign reporters to draft advance obituaries, with just the top two or three paragraphs to add when the inevitable happens. As news spread late last month of the death of “Toughie,” the last known Rabbs’ fringe-limbed tree frog, I used Twitter to muse on whether media will have to start doing the same thing for species of living things that are on the brink of extinction:

headline: Musicians to Know: An R&B Duo With Indie-Film Cred
abstract: Brian Marc, of Denitia and Sene, is an actor on the rise who’s recently started directing the band’s music videos — including a moody clip premiering here.
lead_paragraph: “The reason we don’t have a band name is just because we never expected it to pop like it did!” explains the musician and actor Brian “Sene” Marc. So when he makes R&B with the vocalist Denitia Odigie, they simply go by their names: Denitia and Sene.

headline: Donald Trump vs. Hillary Clinton: More a Brawl Than a Debate
abstract: Readers criticize a lack of substantive issues, the “in-the-gutter level of discourse” and a “big, alpha male bully stalking the debate stage.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Soothing Ruffled Guests: Hotels Meet Threat of Bad Reviews
abstract: It might feel like blackmail. But when guests brandish the specter of a negative posting on a travel website, the hospitality industry takes notice.
lead_paragraph: Pam and Larry Willis had recently purchased the Gables Wine Country Inn in California’s Sonoma wine region four years ago when they received it: their first TripAdvisor threat.

headline: Snooping in the Bathroom to Assess Credit Risk in China
keywords: ['Credit Scores', 'Credit and Debt', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Personal Finances', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Extensive consumer databases are not in place for lenders to check, but companies are scrambling to crack the credit code.
lead_paragraph: KUNSHAN, China — Banks and other lenders typically look at borrowers’ credit histories, tax forms and other financial information to determine whether they will get paid back. In China, lenders also look at their bathrooms.

headline: Review: At Desert Trip, Rocking Beyond the Hits With a Vengeance
abstract: At this festival in Indio, Calif., the Rolling Stones, Bob Dylan, Paul McCartney, Neil Young, the Who and Roger Waters played as if they still have something to prove.
lead_paragraph: INDIO, Calif. — The past loomed, long and weighty, over Desert Trip, a three-night festival here with a lineup of baby boomers’ rock heroes. It was simply two sets a night: the Rolling Stones and Bob Dylan on Friday, Paul McCartney and Neil Young on Saturday and Roger Waters and the Who on Sunday. That lineup is to be repeated Friday through Sunday and perhaps never again.

headline: The Donald Trump We Always Knew
abstract: Neither Sunday’s debate nor the 2005 video showed us anything new about the Republican nominee.
lead_paragraph: Watching Republican leaders and talking heads spin themselves dizzy over the second presidential debate would be entertaining if the situation was not so tragic.

headline: Review: Elena Ferrante Wants Privacy. Her New Book Implies Otherwise.
abstract: In “Frantumaglia,” a collection of essays, letters and interviews, she undermines her declaration that her work is “self-sufficient” and that she should be anonymous.
lead_paragraph: This month, an article by the Italian journalist Claudio Gatti was published, offering a theory about the identity of the real writer behind the pseudonym Elena Ferrante, based on “a monthslong investigation.”

headline: Nadia Murad, Yazidi Woman Who Survived ISIS Captivity, Wins Human Rights Prize
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)']
abstract: Abducted by Islamic State militants in Iraq in 2014, she has become a good-will ambassador for victims of human trafficking.
lead_paragraph: Fighters for the Islamic State abducted a young Yazidi woman named Nadia Murad, her siblings and their mother from their village in northern Iraq more than two years ago. Barely in her 20s, Ms. Murad was separated from her family, beaten and sexually assaulted.

headline: Letter From Congress to Gary Bettman
abstract: Members from the Congressional Committee on Energy and Commerce sent a letter to N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman regarding the league's concussion protocol.
lead_paragraph: Members from the Congressional Committee on Energy and Commerce sent a letter to N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman regarding the league's concussion protocol.

headline: Taylor Mac’s Pop Marathon
abstract: The show “A 24-Decade History of Popular Music” began on Saturday at noon and ended at the same time on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The show “A 24-Decade History of Popular Music” began on Saturday at noon and ended at the same time on Sunday.

headline: Review: Taylor Mac’s 24-Hour Concert Was One of the Great Experiences of My Life
abstract: I’ve slept on it, and I’m sure. “A 24-Decade History of Popular Music” is sublime.
lead_paragraph: So after almost 21½ hours and two centuries’ worth of singing, dancing, and jiggling; after all 650 of us had been asked to re-enact everything from the Civil War and the Oklahoma land rush to white flight to the suburbs; after a narcotically swampy rendition of “Amazing Grace” and a production of “The Mikado” that glowed in the dark because its minstrelsy might make sense if it was set on Mars; after visionary drag-queen costumes that called to mind descriptions like geisha Andrews Sister and Tiki apocalypse; after we’d stood in lines for small portions of bread and split pea soup at 3 a.m. and not many people took the bread (because even during a poignant Depression homage some people will still refuse to eat a carb); after we’d batted around an enormous stars-and-stripes penis balloon whose design really did look more like the flag of Puerto Rico and then made a funeral procession for Judy Garland’s corpse; after a mash-up of the Bee Gees’ “Stayin’ Alive” and Led Zeppelin’s “Kashmir”; after Taylor Mac, the performance artist who dreamed this whole thing up, had cavorted onstage and in the laps and arms of strangers; after all of this — the delirium, the mania, the possibly simulated sex — it might have been the balloon that broke us.

headline: Billy Joel-Loving Academics Get in a Piano Man State of Mind
abstract: A Billy Joel symposium called “It’s Still Rock and Roll to Me” at Colorado College explored his music and lyrics and included a telephone Q. and A. with the star.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Morgan Jones, a high school music teacher from Swaziland, was holding court at a Steinway baby grand in the atrium of the Cornerstone Performing Arts Center at Colorado College. What the group of listeners had in common with the man at the piano was a love and near-encyclopedic knowledge of the Piano Man: Billy Joel.

headline: A YouTube Star Is All In, Professionally and Personally
abstract: Colleen Ballinger of the new Netflix series “Haters Back Off” uses videos extensively to address fans who demand access to her life, including its raw moments.
lead_paragraph: The Netflix series “Haters Back Off” (which begins streaming on Friday) opens with the YouTube character Miranda Sings — an aggressively awful aspiring entertainer played by the writer and comedian Colleen Ballinger — looking into a camera and saying, “Hey, guys.” She’s seated, centered in the screen, with an overstuffed closet open behind her. It’s a note-perfect evocation of the handmade, homemade YouTube aesthetic by an artist who has forged a successful career from affectionately parodying the medium that has brought her fame.

headline: Special Tax on Women: Trump Tape Is a Reminder of the Cost of Harassment
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes', 'Gender', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The boorish and aggressive behavior of some men isn’t just offensive; it results in real opportunity costs to women.
lead_paragraph: The leaked footage of Donald J. Trump boasting of sexually harassing and assaulting women is just one particularly notable example of an all-too-common phenomenon: Far too many men treat women’s bodies as if they are fair game for anyone who happens to encounter them.

headline: How to Cook a Roast Sous Vide
abstract: This method produces juicy, tender meat that you can quickly sear, sauté or stir-fry for a weeknight meal.
lead_paragraph: This method produces juicy, tender meat that you can quickly sear, sauté or stir-fry for a weeknight meal.

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
abstract: We asked readers — without any context — to caption a photo that ran in The New York Times. Here’s how they responded.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

headline: Making Sous Vide Simplify Work for You
abstract: The key to embracing the often-lengthy process: Think beyond the single steak.
lead_paragraph: Increasingly affordable and easy to do, sous-vide immersion cooking has become trendy among food nerds who want precise control over the doneness of their meats.

headline: Donald Trump, Samsung, Yemen: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Beetle Battle
abstract: The bigger the mandibles, the more likely a male is to defeat a challenger for the attention of a female on a rotting log.
lead_paragraph: The bigger the mandibles, the more likely a male is to defeat a challenger for the attention of a female on a rotting log.

abstract: The bigger the mandibles, the more likely a male is to defeat a challenger for the attention of a female on a rotting log.
lead_paragraph: You’ve heard of the Jaws of Life. How about the mandibles of power?

headline: Reginald K. Brack Jr., 79, Dies; Led Time Inc. Into Entertainment Era
abstract: Over almost four decades, Mr. Brack introduced lifestyle magazines like Discover and InStyle and broke down walls between the business and editorial sides of publications.
lead_paragraph: Reginald K. Brack Jr., who as a top executive at Time Inc. helped shepherd the company’s sometimes uneasy transformation from a primarily journalistic enterprise into a multimedia and entertainment company, died on Oct. 4 at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 79.

headline: The Presidential Debate in Song: Who’s Gonna Work It Out?
abstract: Joseph Gordon-Levitt and the Gregory Brothers team up to present a musical mashup of highlights from the second 2016 presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Gordon-Levitt and the Gregory Brothers team up to present a musical mashup of highlights from the second 2016 presidential debate.

headline: The Presidential Debate in Song: Who’s Gonna Work It Out?
abstract: Joseph Gordon-Levitt and the Gregory Brothers team up to present a musical mashup of highlights from the second 2016 presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: Absurd. Surreal. Farcical. Freakish. Unfathomable. These are just a few of the words that we’ve heard used to describe the 2016 election, plus several synonyms that we just looked up in a thesaurus to make the list look even longer and more weighty.

headline: Buffett Calls Trump’s Bluff and Releases His Tax Data
abstract: Accused of a “massive deduction,” Warren E. Buffett released data from 2015, showing mostly deductions for charitable donations and state tax.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett is not running for president. But on Monday, Mr. Buffett, the billionaire investor, volunteered more detailed information about his income taxes than Donald J. Trump, the Republican nominee, ever has.

headline: Photos and Detailed Maps Reveal Hurricane Matthew’s Brutal Aftermath in Haiti
abstract: The storm killed hundreds of people and left a path of destruction in western Haiti. Entire towns were turned into a mix of mud and debris.
lead_paragraph: The storm killed hundreds of people and left a path of destruction in western Haiti. Entire towns were turned into a mix of mud and debris.

headline: Ratings for Second Debate Dive 20 Percent
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Television', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The audience for Sunday night’s bout between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump fell sharply from their first debate.
lead_paragraph: Maybe Americans are starting to get fed up with the ugly tone of this strange presidential election. Maybe viewers are tired of R-rated video clips and scorched-earth attacks.

headline: A Partisan Crowd Watches the Debate at the New Trump Hotel
abstract: Sunday’s debate drew a crowd to the bar of the month-old Trump International Hotel in Washington, where the TVs were turned to Fox and free wine was flowing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Outside, a ribbon of lights swept up Pennsylvania Avenue toward the Capitol, and there was not a protester in sight. Inside the month-old Trump International Hotel, a Romanesque Revival structure just as grand, the second presidential debate had begun.

headline: Ranchers Tote Guns as Tribes Dig In for Long Pipeline Fight
keywords: ['Pipelines', 'Native Americans', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: As dozens more protesters were arrested, Native Americans in North Dakota prepared for a long fight over the Dakota Access pipeline.
lead_paragraph: CANNON BALL, N.D. — Ranchers are arming themselves before they climb onto tractors or see to their livestock. Surveillance helicopters buzz low through the prairie skies. Native Americans fighting to prevent an oil pipeline near the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation are handing out thick blankets and coats and are building maple-pole shelters that can withstand North Dakota’s bitter winter.

headline: ISIS Media Output Drops as Military Pressure Rises, Report Says
keywords: ['Propaganda', 'Social Media', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Research']
abstract: The Islamic State is releasing fewer propaganda items and has shifted its message away from that of a well-run caliphate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The vaunted propaganda operations of the Islamic State, which helped lure more than 30,000 foreign fighters to Syria and Iraq, have dropped off drastically as the extremist group has come under military pressure, according to a study by terrorism researchers at West Point.

headline: Seinfeld’s ‘Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee’ Is on Market
abstract: Losing the popular show that put it on the map would be a blow to Crackle, Sony Pictures Entertainment’s streaming service.
lead_paragraph: In a potential blow to Crackle, the fledgling Sony Pictures Entertainment streaming service, Jerry Seinfeld’s hit online series “Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee” is on the market.

headline: A Gift for the City of New York
abstract: The first day at an after-school job creates some momentary confusion.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Emails Show How Clinton Aides Stage-Managed Her Keystone Shift
abstract: The campaign emails released on WikiLeaks illustrate the degree to which aides stage-managed and agonized over her changed positions on issues like the Keystone XL oil pipeline.
lead_paragraph: The Clinton campaign emails that were made public by WikiLeaks on Monday show the degree to which Hillary Clinton’s aides stage-managed her policy announcements, and the extent of their anxiety as they tried to explain her changed positions on certain issues. The following exchange reflects one example: her shift on the Keystone XL oil pipeline.

headline: Threat to Jail Clinton Smacks of ‘Tin-Pot Dictators,’ Experts Say
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'E-Mail']
abstract: The assertion takes its place in a litany of Mr. Trump’s statements that many legal specialists have portrayed as a threat to the rule of law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As president of the United States, Donald J. Trump would wield the power to carry out his vow to have a special prosecutor reopen the investigation into Hillary Clinton’s emails — if not to guarantee his threat to her that “you’d be in jail” if he ran the country.

headline: Ex-President of Brazil Faces New Corruption Charges
abstract: Charges have been filed against Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva concerning dealings in Angola, but he is still a leading contender for president in 2018.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Federal prosecutors filed new corruption charges on Monday against Brazil’s former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, raising pressure on him and his family over dealings in Angola, the oil-rich country where Brazilian companies have aggressively raised their profile over the last decade.

headline: Car Attacks in Denmark Spread ‘Like an Infection’
abstract: Nearly 190 cars have been set ablaze in Copenhagen this year, a violent outburst that is upsetting a country that prides itself on its social harmony.
lead_paragraph: The arsonists appear to operate with little deference to class, equally at ease scorching a shiny new BMW or Mercedes as they are setting a battered old van ablaze.

headline: Hillary Clinton Aides Kept de Blasio at Arm’s Length, WikiLeaks Emails Show
keywords: ['Endorsements', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail']
abstract: The messages suggest that the wariness of Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign toward Mayor Bill de Blasio dated back years and grew worse as the primary contest wore on.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio came into office in 2014 telling a tale of two cities, where the poor and the working class were finding it increasingly hard to get by, while the moneyed elite got more moneyed by the day. He envisioned himself as a leader of a growing liberal movement both in New York City and across the nation.

headline: Wells Fargo Reshuffles Top Ranks, Rallying Around Its No. 2
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Under fire for a scandal in which employees set up sham accounts, the bank solidified its leadership structure under the chairman’s heir-apparent.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo, under fire from all sides because of a long-running scandal in which employees set up illegal accounts to meet sales quotas, announced a restructuring of its top management on Monday, solidifying the leadership structure beneath Timothy J. Sloan, who is widely expected to succeed John G. Stumpf, the bank’s embattled chairman and chief executive.

headline: Jacob Neusner, Judaic Scholar Who Forged Interfaith Bonds, Dies at 84
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Professor Neusner, a leading historian of Jewish rabbinical texts, published over 900 books devoted to comparative religion, history and legal theory.
lead_paragraph: Jacob Neusner, a religious historian of enormous breadth and productivity and one of the world’s foremost scholars of Jewish rabbinical texts, died on Saturday at his home in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 84.

headline: What Exactly Is ‘Locker-Room Talk’? Let an Expert Explain
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: A lifetime spent in locker rooms has meant overhearing good, bad and amusing conversations. But nothing close to descriptions of sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: My father was a coach and the manager of a sporting goods store that installed and maintained equipment at athletic facilities. By the time I was in third grade, I had already spent countless days and nights in locker rooms — at colleges, high schools, prep schools, private adult clubs, you name it.

headline: Were He Seeking Any Other Job, Trump Would Be Flagged by H.R.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Workplace Environment', 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity']
abstract: Recordings of his vulgar boasts would make the Republican nominee a major legal liability, and many companies consider such language a firing offense.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump describes himself as a businessman. And he says he wants to run the government more like a business.

headline: Twitter Is Said to Be in Continued Talks With Salesforce
abstract: The company tries to forge ahead despite a constantly shifting chess match of deal discussions and considerations.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the last week, Twitter’s fate has appeared to be murkier than ever. The troubled social media company, which has been engaged in talks to sell itself, seemed to be running out of potential buyers.

headline: Mark Burnett Says He Can’t Release ‘Apprentice’ Video of Donald Trump
abstract: Mr. Burnett, who created the reality show, says he has no authority to release material from “The Apprentice.”
lead_paragraph: Mark Burnett, the reality show impresario, has faced mounting demands in recent days to release old video from his series “The Apprentice,” on speculation that Donald J. Trump was captured on camera making vulgar remarks during his 11 years as the show’s host.

headline: Fleeing the Coast Before the Storm, Only to Be Trapped Inland
abstract: After Hurricane Matthew dropped torrential rain, the worst damage occurred inland, in places that might typically be havens.
lead_paragraph: CERRO GORDO, N.C. — Diamond Hansen and Darryl Clark rented a room in a Super 8 for a month, hoping it was a springboard to a fresh start in Myrtle Beach, S.C. Then the evacuation order came for Hurricane Matthew, so they climbed into Mr. Clark’s Volvo and drove to a place that seemed safe, his uncle’s house well inland in rural North Carolina. But it was far from the haven they expected.

headline: Abby Wambach, Retired U.S. Soccer Star, Reflects on Her Addiction
abstract: Wambach, now six months sober, revealed in a memoir her struggles with depression and her abuse of painkilling medications and alcohol.
lead_paragraph: Abby Wambach retired from the United States women’s national soccer team in December, ending a career that included two Olympic gold medals, a Women’s World Cup title and 184 goals, the most by any American player — male or female — in history.

headline: Henrik Lundqvist and Rangers Are Renewing Title Quest After Long Off-Season
abstract: Lundqvist, who led the N.H.L. in saves last season and was Sweden’s goaltender in the World Cup of Hockey, hopes the Rangers can make up for their fast exit from the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Goaltender Henrik Lundqvist, the oldest Ranger, joined his teammates in a team-building exercise this weekend, which included visiting the National September 11 Memorial & Museum and participating in a Police Department tactical-training session.

headline: For Many Women, Trump’s ‘Locker Room Talk’ Brings Memories of Abuse
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'Social Media']
abstract: When she first posted a message on Twitter, Kelly Oxford, a social media powerhouse, didn’t expect many replies. She got millions.
lead_paragraph: It was the author Kelly Oxford, a social media powerhouse, who got things started on Friday night.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, October 11, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “It smacks of what we read about tin-pot dictators in other parts of the world, where when they win an election their first move is to imprison opponents.”

headline: Despite Ken Thompson’s Short Stint as Brooklyn Prosecutor, Agenda May Endure
keywords: ['District Attorneys', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Mr. Thompson, who died on Sunday of cancer, embraced and advanced the shifting roles that district attorneys play in the criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: In New York politics, the city’s district attorneys have long been the edifices of elective office: legal lions presiding for years — often decades — over courthouse fiefs beyond the influence even of City Hall.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Campaign Strained to Hone Her Message, Hacked Emails Show
abstract: Thousands of messages released by WikiLeaks offered a look inside an operation that misread the electoral mood, throwing Mrs. Clinton’s campaign off course.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of the New Hampshire primary in February, a longtime aide to Bill Clinton was worried. Hillary Clinton was about to go down to defeat in the state, and the former president was despondent.

headline: New York City May Double Number of Food Vendor Permits
abstract: The City Council intends to consider legislation that would gradually increase the number of permits issued over the course of seven years.
lead_paragraph: For eight years, Julia Chimborazo has sold Italian ice on the streets of Brooklyn and Queens, doing what she can to support her two young children and send money to a third, who still lives in her native Ecuador.

headline: Elizabeth F. Rohatyn, Supporter of Education and the Arts, Dies at 86
abstract: Ms. Rohatyn was a former chairwoman of the New York Public Library and a board member of Lincoln Center, and helped low-income students go on to higher education.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth F. Rohatyn, a major supporter of numerous arts and educational organizations, including the New York Public Library, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 86.

headline: Herbert Irving, Sysco Co-Founder and $300 Million Hospital Donor, Dies at 98
abstract: Mr. Irving co-founded the food services giant Sysco in 1969 and, with his wife, donated heavily for cancer care and research.
lead_paragraph: Herbert Irving, a co-founder of the food services giant Sysco Corporation and a philanthropist who donated more than $300 million to NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center, died on Oct. 3 at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

headline: Nationals Take Series Lead Over Dodgers After Battle of Bullpens
abstract: Washington outlasted Los Angeles in a game that featured 11 relievers, moving to within one win of its first playoff series win since relocating in 2005.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The way modern baseball has evolved, relievers have become invaluable, and in painstakingly slow fashion Monday at Dodger Stadium, the Washington Nationals and the Los Angeles Dodgers highlighted the need for dominant bullpens that are smartly deployed.

headline: In Debate on Syria, It’s Trump vs. Pence, and Clinton vs. Obama
abstract: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton struggled to explain how they would handle the war, but both broke from their allies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than a year, Syria’s civil war has vexed and divided the Obama administration. Now, barely a month before the election, those tensions are finally spilling into the presidential race.

headline: Review: ‘Oh, Hello on Broadway’ Stars an Even Odder Couple
abstract: This stupendously entertaining play centers on the comedians Nick Kroll and John Mulaney, who have created geriatric alter egos as roommates.
lead_paragraph: The dirty old men have occupied Broadway. They are an army of only two, yet they seem destined to conquer and slay anyone who ventures into the Lyceum Theater, where they have set up their festering — and, admit it, stupendously entertaining — camp.

headline: Pep Squad Member’s Lament
abstract: Samuel Donaldson and Doug Peterson collaborate on a fun Tuesday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — If you wind up with a bad case of earworm after you finish solving today’s puzzle by Sam “Not the Newsman” Donaldson and Doug Peterson, you have only them to blame. I solved their puzzle fairly swiftly, but came away with the song “CHEESE SO FINE” stuck in my head. And now I can’t get it out and all I want is cheese on a fancy cracker.

headline: ‘Go Back to China’: Readers Respond to Racist Insults Shouted at a New York Times Editor
abstract: An article about a racist attack on a Times editor led to a flood of responses from Asian-Americans sharing stories about prejudice, insults and ignorance
lead_paragraph: It certainly felt like something of a moment for Asian-Americans in this country: an article about racist insults flung at one of their own, featured prominently in The New York Times, shared, posted and commented on thousands upon thousands of times.

headline: Theranos Sued by Investor Who Accuses It of Securities Fraud
abstract: Partner Fund Management, a San Francisco hedge fund, filed the suit on Monday in Delaware, according to a letter sent to its investors.
lead_paragraph: Theranos, the beleaguered Silicon Valley blood-testing company, is being accused of securities fraud by a major investor who has sued contending “myriad deceptions, falsehoods and fraudulent conduct.”

headline: Australia’s Labor Party Blocks Referendum on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Referendums']
abstract: The party voted unanimously to block a nonbinding plebiscite proposed for early next year, calling it “the wrong path to achieve marriage equality.”
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia’s opposition Labor Party voted to block legislation to allow a public referendum on same-sex marriage, Bill Shorten, the party’s leader, said on Tuesday, effectively killing the nonbinding plebiscite that Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull had proposed for early next year.

headline: Cleveland Indians Are Rewriting a Hard-Luck Tale
abstract: Despite being rejected by one All-Star and missing a few others, Cleveland took another step toward its first World Series title in 68 years by dominating its divisional series against Boston.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The Cleveland Indians are not used to this. Their past is tortured, their present tattered. They have waited 68 years for a World Series title. Their chances seemed grim before this division series with the brawny Boston Red Sox.

headline: Indians Sweep Aside Ortiz’s Last Bit of Magic
abstract: Ortiz, a prolific slugger, endured a quiet end to his career as Cleveland swept the Boston Red Sox to advance to the American League Championship Series.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Each time David Ortiz walked to the batter’s box, the fans at Fenway Park stood and cheered, a gesture that was partly a salute to his remarkable career and partly an entreaty to save the day once again.

headline: For New York City’s Homeless Children, Getting to School Is the Hard Part
abstract: A new report that draws largely on data from the 2013-14 school year vividly maps out just how difficult it is for students who live in homeless shelters to get an education.
lead_paragraph: Family workers carrying caseloads of 256 children at a time. A girl who had transferred to four different schools, one of them twice, by age 11. Attendance reports from multiple agencies, but with none held responsible for making sure that students actually went to school.

headline: Greylock Partners Says It Raised a $1 Billion Fund
abstract: The Silicon Valley venture capital firm’s fund-raising, which it says took less than three months, increases its assets under management to $3.5 billion.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Greylock Partners, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm, said it has raised a $1 billion fund as investors increase venture firm funding to highs not seen since the dot-com boom last decade.

headline: Telescope to Seek Earthlike Planet in Alpha Centauri System
keywords: ['Telescopes and Observatories', 'Planets', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: A scientific research consortium plans to build a telescope that will seek out an ocean-covered world in a neighboring star system.
lead_paragraph: A scientific research consortium on Tuesday announced plans to build and launch a privately financed telescope the size of a small washing machine in hopes of finding an Earthlike planet in the Alpha Centauri system, one of our closest cosmic neighbors.

headline: Hurricane Matthew’s Toll Rises; Flooding Hits North Carolina
abstract: The storm’s death toll in the United States passed two dozen as rivers in North Carolina continued to overflow their banks.
lead_paragraph: ■ The storm’s death toll in the United States has climbed to more than two dozen. Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina said Tuesday that the state had recorded 14 fatalities. At least six people died in Florida, and the authorities in Georgia and South Carolina reported three deaths in each state.

headline: Atlantic Names Jeffrey Goldberg Its Editor in Chief
abstract: Mr. Goldberg, who has written for The New Yorker and The New York Times Magazine, is the magazine’s 14th top editor since its founding in 1857.
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic said on Tuesday that it had named Jeffrey Goldberg, a correspondent for the company since 2007, its next editor in chief, drawing an extensive search to a close.

headline: As Time Expires, a Buccaneers Kicker Finds Redemption
abstract: Roberto Aguayo lifted the Tampa Bay Buccaneers over the Carolina Panthers, 17-14, with a late 38-yard field goal after missing twice earlier in the game.
lead_paragraph: Roberto Aguayo kicked a 38-yard field goal as time expired, and the visiting Tampa Bay Buccaneers defeated the Carolina Panthers, 17-14, on Monday night.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Channel Zero: Candle Cover’ and ‘Prescription for Change’
abstract: Syfy adds an anthology horror series about child murders to its lineup. And Macklemore speaks with President Obama about the country’s opioid crisis.
lead_paragraph: Just in time for Halloween, Syfy adds an anthology horror series to its lineup, this one about child murders. “Frontline” examines the status of the fight against ISIS. And Macklemore speaks with President Obama about the country’s opioid crisis.

headline: Fiat Chrysler Deal With Union Averts Strike in Canada
abstract: The last-minute settlement with the workers’ union, Unifor, mirrors the main points in a contract that workers reached last month with General Motors of Canada.
lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles avoided a strike late Monday night by about 10,000 employees at three plants in Canada.

headline: Building Collapse in Chinese City of Wenzhou Kills at Least 22
abstract: The toll makes it one of the deadliest episodes of its kind in recent years. Six people have been pulled from the rubble, including a 3-year-old girl.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese state news media reported Tuesday that at least 22 people had died in the collapse of four residential buildings in an eastern city the day before, a toll that would make it one of the deadliest cases of its kind in recent years.

headline: Zymergen Raises $130 Million in New Round of Financing
abstract: The new round of financing in the start-up, which has focused on helping genetically engineer tiny microbes, was led by SoftBank of Japan.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over its three-year life, Zymergen has focused on helping genetically engineer tiny microbes, while using advanced computing to help better automate the process.
