headline: In Queens, Seceding From the Homeless Crisis
keywords: ['Homeless Persons', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Affordable Housing', 'Group Homes and Supportive Housing', 'Editorials']
abstract: A plan to shelter some families in a local hotel prompts protests in a largely white, middle-class area.
lead_paragraph: “STOP the War on the Middle Class,” said one marcher’s sign. “Dump Communist de Blasio,” said another, the small “d” made from a hammer and sickle.

headline: Count Trump Among the Takers
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: He benefited from government without paying his dues.
lead_paragraph: Because Donald J. Trump hasn’t released his tax returns, we don’t know exactly what portion of his fortune he has sent the federal government. But in the second presidential debate, he confirmed that there were a number of years where he paid nothing at all.

headline: In Praise of Kenneth Bone
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Global Warming', 'Mines and Mining', 'Unemployment', 'Editorials', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: The overlooked issue of climate change gets some attention, thanks to an unlikely hero.
lead_paragraph: All hail Kenneth Bone! Mr. Bone was the fellow in a red sweater who rose to his feet near the end of Sunday night’s town hall debate. People are having a fine old time riffing on his genial manner, his festive sweater and the disposable camera he used to snap pictures after the event. But here’s the thing about Mr. Bone: He asked a smart question about energy policy, an issue largely overlooked in the debates so far, which in turn elicited from Hillary Clinton a mention of climate change, an issue that has been completely overlooked.

headline: Male Voters Finally Get Trump
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Editorials', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: How the Donald Trump tape has had a bigger impact on men.
lead_paragraph: The release of a 2005 recording showing Donald Trump gloating about sexual assault has cost him female voters. But by one measure, the tape has had a bigger impact on men. In an NBC News/SurveyMonkey poll conducted before the release of the tape, 45 percent of likely male voters said Mr. Trump does not respect women. Post-tape, that share rose to 55 percent.

headline: For Better Citizenship, Scratch and Win
keywords: ['Lotteries', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Income Tax']
abstract: Across the globe, a slim chance of winning in a lottery can get people to vote, pay taxes, drive slower or make sex safe.
lead_paragraph: China, with its largely cash economy, has a huge problem with tax evasion. Not just grand tax evasion, but the everyday “no receipt, please” kind, even though there have been harsh penalties: Before 2011, some forms of tax evasion were even punishable by death.

headline: When They Go Low, Do We Have to Go, Too?
abstract: Brooks and Collins on the debate we could be having and the one we are actually having.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Brooks: Hi, Gail. Well, the race has defied my expectations and hit a new moral low. Where to start — the insult-driven second debate, the sensational pre-debate press conference Trump held on Facebook with a jury of Bill Clinton’s accusers, the revelation that Mrs. Clinton told Wall Street bankers that one has to have “private” and “public” positions, or Trump’s videotaped Caligula impression from 2005 that has dominated the news since Friday? You choose.

headline: The Supreme Court Is Being Hypocritical
abstract: The justices tell other judges to act in ways they themselves don’t.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s motto may be “equal justice under law.” But sometimes it seems more like “do as we say, not as we do.”

headline: America’s Moral Duty in Yemen
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'United States International Relations', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Editorials']
abstract: President Obama must cut off military aid to Saudi Arabia unless it ends the carnage and returns to peace talks.
lead_paragraph: Airstrikes by a Saudi-led coalition that devastated a funeral in Yemen on Saturday make it clear that the United States must end its complicity in a civil war that has caused a humanitarian catastrophe in one of the world’s poorest countries and fueled extremism. It is within President Obama’s power to do so. Saudi Arabia and its Gulf state allies depend on Washington for aircraft, munitions, training and in-flight refueling. The United States also helps Saudi Arabia guard its borders.

headline: Donald Trump’s Sad, Lonely Life
abstract: Politics is an effort to make human connection, but Trump seems incapable of that.
lead_paragraph: The point of town hall debates is that regular voters get to ask questions. In every town hall I’ve seen, the candidate turns to the voter, listens attentively and directs the answer at least partially back to that person.

headline: A Great Fight of Our Times
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Inequality', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Economy', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Stagnation is the reality for much of the population.
lead_paragraph: Think, for a moment, about the stories that your family likes to tell about itself. They are probably miniature versions of the American story, with progress as the central theme.

headline: What the Nobel Peace Prize Prizes
abstract: Should the award only be given for actual achievements, or is it important to recognize those who aspire to peace?

headline: Henan Province, a Butt of Jokes in China, Gets a Champion in Court
abstract: After an aspiring TV celebrity ridiculed the province, a science journalist from the region resolved to sue for damages to his reputation as a resident there.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Henan has a P.R. problem, but Jing Changshui has an answer. He’s suing.

headline: On the Streets of Harlem, a Sense of ‘Erase and Replace’
abstract: Dawoud Bey’s large-scale photos of Harlem show the legendary cradle of African-American life confronting speculation, displacement and gentrification.
lead_paragraph: Dawoud Bey’s large-scale color photographs of Harlem vividly document a bustling and rapidly transforming neighborhood: a verdant Marcus Garvey Park; construction sites popping up for more luxury housing; street vendors hawking hats and used clothing; posters of black women’s hairstyles in the window of a hair weave distributor adjacent to a vacant lot; faded paper covering the windows of the legendary — and shuttered — Lenox Lounge; and white tourists intent on hearing gospel music waiting outside the Abyssinian Baptist Church.

headline: Sports Fans
abstract: What sports teams are you a fan of? How would you react if your team went on a 107-year losing streak? Do you think you would stay loyal?

headline: Jodi Picoult’s New Novel Reviewed by Roxane Gay
abstract: A black nurse and a white supremacist are the primary narrators of Jodi Picoult’s “Small Great Things.”
lead_paragraph: SMALL GREAT THINGSBy Jodi Picoult470 pp. Ballantine Books. $28.99.

headline: How Colin Kaepernick’s Protest Is Connecting Playing Fields to the Streets
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Football', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Athletics and Sports']
abstract: By kneeling during the national anthem, the 49ers quarterback has ignited a new era of activism by athletes.
lead_paragraph: A few days after the first presidential debate, LeBron James took a stand: He endorsed Hillary Clinton for president. The reasons he cited ranged from a belief that Clinton would “build on the legacy” of his “good friend” Barack Obama to her good works on behalf of children. James concluded with a passage about the “violence, of every kind, the African-American community is experiencing in our streets and seeing on our TVs.” He went on to say we need to be “unified” and “stand together — no matter where we are from or the color of our skin.” The measured tone was an echo of his appearance at the ESPY Awards in July, where he and his fellow N.B.A. stars Dwyane Wade, Carmelo Anthony and Chris Paul spoke out in a joint speech for “uniting communities” and ending violence.

headline: What’s Really Behind Trump’s Obsession With Clinton’s ‘Stamina’?
abstract: When a 70-year-old campaigns for the White House, it’s no surprise that questions of strength and vigor might be raised. And when his opponent is a woman, it’s no surprise that she’s the one accused of lacking it.
lead_paragraph: To Donald Trump, everything is negotiable, even getting old. At 70 — about 16 months older than Hillary Clinton — he would be the oldest person ever to step into the presidency, a fact he’s determined to talk his way around. “Here’s a woman — she’s supposed to fight all of these different things, and she can’t make it 15 feet to her car,” he told supporters at a recent rally in Pennsylvania. “She’s home resting right now.” He slackened his jaw and feigned stumbling across the stage, a dramatic re-enactment of the video that showed Clinton nearly collapsing from pneumonia in September. “Folks,” Trump announced, “we need stamina.”

headline: How Hillary Became ‘Hillary’
abstract: A 1980 defeat set in motion a process of endless revision, by herself and her opponents, that has defined her career.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after Hillary Clinton accepted the Democratic nomination for president, I flew to Little Rock, Ark., to visit a woman named Gay White. White is the widow of Frank White, a conservative Little Rock banker who in the spring, summer and fall of 1980 toured all 75 counties in Arkansas in a quixotic attempt to unseat the incumbent governor, Bill Clinton. Frank had no previous experience campaigning, but he proved to be an enthusiastic retail politician. Gay, then 32, accompanied him on his statewide tour of cattle auctions, courthouse squares, Walmart parking lots and chicken-processing plants. “Hi, I’m Gay White,” she would tell the people they met. “My husband’s running for governor, and I’d sure appreciate your vote.”

headline: Was it a Depressing Week in Politics for Women, or a Great One?
abstract: Jodi Kantor and Susan Dominus discuss Sunday’s debate, the Trump tape and the prospect of a first gentleman.
lead_paragraph: Dear Sue,

headline: A Man Booker Finalist: A China Where Music Was Life and Death
abstract: Madeleine Thien’s “Do Not Say We Have Nothing” spans seven decades and three generations to trace the effects of Mao’s Cultural Revolution.
lead_paragraph: DO NOT SAY WE HAVE NOTHINGBy Madeleine Thien473 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $26.95.

headline: Marina Abramovic: By the Book
abstract: The performance artist and author of “Walk Through Walls” doesn’t have a severe temperament: “I have a dark sense of humor which is very much from the Balkans — I love dirty jokes.”
lead_paragraph: The performance artist and author of “Walk Through Walls” doesn’t have a severe temperament: “I have a dark sense of humor which is very much from the Balkans — I love dirty jokes.”

headline: Tough Talk but Little Action From Lieberman as Israel’s Defense Minister
abstract: Having criticized the government five months ago for its handling of security, the hard-liner Avigdor Lieberman has not done much to reshape Israeli policies.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel has been challenged by land, sea and air in recent weeks, as security officials have braced for a wave of violence around the Jewish High Holy Days and the anniversary of the outbreak of Palestinian stabbing, shooting and automobile attacks that began a year ago.

headline: Trump’s Threat to Jail Clinton Also Targets Democracy’s Institutions
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: His claim at Sunday’s presidential debate was “a threat to the rule of law,” one political scientist said.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump told Hillary Clinton at Sunday’s presidential debate that if he were president, “you’d be in jail,” he was threatening more than just his opponent. He was suggesting that he would strip power from the institutions that normally enforce the law, investing it instead in himself.

headline: ‘I’m the Last Thing Standing Between You and the Apocalypse’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Inside the final weeks of Hillary Clinton’s cautious — and surprisingly risky — campaign.
lead_paragraph: There can be days in this presidential campaign, if not weeks or months or maybe the entire thing, where you find yourself completely lost in dueling or blurry realities. It’s easy to get caught up in whatever is dominating a given moment. Everything gets so big and loud, and the candidates — famous to begin with — cease to even exist as human beings in front of you.

headline: Early Voting Could Point to Hillary Clinton Victory Well Before Nov. 8
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Absentee Voting', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: Democrats are requesting more absentee ballots than Republicans in Florida and have returned more ballots in North Carolina, good signs for Mrs. Clinton.
lead_paragraph: With early voting already underway in many of the states that will decide the presidency, Hillary Clinton is beginning to reap the benefits of years of Democratic efforts to target and register voters, even as Republicans steadily close their disadvantage in party registration.

headline: ‘We Sleep Afraid, We Wake Up Afraid’: A Child’s Life in Yemen
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'vis-dispatch']
abstract: The bombs shake the house at night and blow open doors and windows. How can a father explain war to his children?
lead_paragraph: Mohammed al-Asaadi is a father of four in Sana, the capital of Yemen, which has been caught in a war between Iranian-backed rebels and Saudi Arabia for more than two years. He is a former journalist now working in communications for Unicef.

headline: This City Is 78% Latino, and the Face of a New California
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Spanish Language', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Voting and Voters', 'Series']
abstract: Santa Ana, in Orange County, has an all Latino City Council and stands in the vanguard of a California where Latinos have more influence in everyday life.
lead_paragraph: SANTA ANA, Calif. — Vicente Sarmiento remembers when the local Republican Party here posted uniformed guards at polling stations in a closely fought State Assembly race three decades ago and they hoisted signs in English and Spanish warning that noncitizens were prohibited from voting. The guards were removed after state elections officials threatened legal action.

headline: Were Donald Trump’s Comments on a 2005 Video Normal ‘Locker Room Talk‘?
abstract: If you are male, have you ever talked the way Donald Trump did, or heard men talking that way? If you are female, have you faced treatment like this?
lead_paragraph: By now, you probably have heard or read about videotaped remarks Donald Trump made in 2005 about women.

headline: Where Republicans in Competitive House and Senate Races Stand on Donald Trump
abstract: How the emergence of a 2005 recording of Donald J. Trump bragging about sexual assault is playing out in the tightest House and Senate races.
lead_paragraph: How the emergence of a 2005 recording of Donald J. Trump bragging about sexual assault is playing out in the tightest House and Senate races.

headline: In Face of ‘Brexit,’ Signs of E.U. Pulling Together
abstract: No other country has threatened to leave, and smaller states in particular seem to have developed a greater sense of the bloc’s worth.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — As the European Union ponders a future without Britain, its No. 2 economy and strongest military power, Hamlet’s state of Denmark seems an appropriate place to pose anew his existential question: In the 21st century, is the bloc to be, or not to be?

headline: Giants Prevail in a Marathon Thriller and Prevent a Sweep by the Cubs
abstract: Joe Panik’s run-scoring double ended the game in the 13th inning, long after both teams had blown late-inning leads, and forced a Game 4 in this National League division series.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When the baseball rattled off the wall in the vast right-center-field expanse of AT&T Park — and out of the elastic grasp of Albert Almora Jr. — it set off a race for home between Brandon Crawford, who had been anchored at second base, and the inhabitants of the San Francisco Giants dugout, who sprinted to mob him.

headline: Why Samsung Abandoned Its Galaxy Note 7 Flagship Phone
abstract: The unprecedented move by the South Korean electronics giant is an embarrassing reversal for a respected global brand.
lead_paragraph: When several Samsung Galaxy Note 7 smartphones spontaneously exploded in August, the South Korean company went into overdrive. It urged hundreds of employees to quickly diagnose the problem.

headline: Refugee’s Capture in Germany Is Said to Thwart Terrorist Attack
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: The head of the federal domestic intelligence service indicated that the likely target was a Berlin airport and that the suspect had ties to ISIS.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A major terrorist attack on a transportation hub in Germany was narrowly averted, the head of the country’s domestic intelligence agency said on Tuesday, after a 22-year-old Syrian refugee was arrested and more than three pounds of dangerous explosives was found at his home.

headline: How to Get a Good Deal on Flight Upgrades
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Frequent Flier Programs']
abstract: To find affordable business and first class tickets, buy direct from airlines — and upgrade with frequent-flier miles.
lead_paragraph: For value-conscious travelers, flying business or first class is increasingly within the realm of possibility. Prices for these seats are lower than in the past, said George Hobica, the founder of the air travel advice site airfarewatchdog.com. “Airlines used to upgrade passengers to first or business class for free,” he said, “but they’ve stopped doing that and are instead making these tickets more affordable and attainable.” Here, he shares his tips on how to snag a seat in these premium cabins without paying premium prices.

headline: A Grand Tour of Switzerland, Reluctant Son in Tow
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Families and Family Life', 'Language and Languages']
abstract: The plan was to explore cantons where each national language — French, Italian, German and Romansh — was spoken and celebrated. But would we make it to the end?
lead_paragraph: Most Sunday mornings, throughout my childhood near Geneva, my father would drive me to a spot we had never been before. Switzerland occupies about 16,000 square miles. Squeezed between France, Italy, Liechtenstein, Austria and Germany, it is divided into 26 cantons, each influenced by the country it is closest to. All are both fiercely independent and utterly loyal to the Swiss confederation. We explored much of the region where we lived, and that forged a nomadic spirit that has stayed with me.

keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Income Tax']
abstract: Salesforce is still in talks to buy Twitter, according to two people involved in the discussions, despite some of Salesforce’s largest shareholders indicating that they are against the deal.
lead_paragraph: Even though some of the largest shareholders in Salesforce.com have made it clear that they are against the deal, the company is still in talks to buy Twitter, according to two people involved in the discussions who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Vietnam Arrests Mother Mushroom, a Top Blogger, for Criticizing Government
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Censorship']
abstract: Nguyen Ngoc Nhu Quynh, a co-founder of the Network of Vietnamese Bloggers, has challenged leaders over topics including a dump of toxic chemicals.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The authorities in Vietnam said on Tuesday that they had arrested a popular blogger who has criticized the country’s one-party government over politically delicate topics, including a  dump of toxic chemicals that devastated fishing communities and set off protests.

headline: Actually, Many ‘Inner Cities’ Are Doing Great
abstract: A term Donald Trump used in Sunday’s debate has become a popular shorthand conflating cities, crime, poverty and minorities.
lead_paragraph: To hear Donald J. Trump tell it, America’s “inner cities” are on fire. They’re “a disaster education-wise, job-wise, safety-wise, in every way possible,” he declared in this week’s presidential debate.

headline: 1891: Parnell’s Funeral In Dublin
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald: Parnell is laid to rest in Dublin in October 1891.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Mr. Parnell was buried today [Oct. 11] amid warring elements, and in the presence of an immense assemblage. As a scene of great but suppressed excitement, and of still greater impressiveness, the funeral and its surroundings will never be forgotten by those who witnessed it, and it will long furnish a landmark in history for Ireland.

headline: Reporter Who Wrote of Military-Civilian Clash Says He Can’t Leave Pakistan
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The journalist said he had been placed on an “exit control list” days after reporting a confrontation over the military’s handling of Islamist groups.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A well-known Pakistani journalist said on Tuesday that he had been barred from leaving the country, days after he wrote that civilian officials had confronted the military over what they called a failure to act against Islamist groups.

abstract: Even before the most recent scandal involving Donald J. Trump, the Chinese news media has depicted him and Hillary Clinton as puppets of wealthy elites.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese state news media has already declared a winner in the scandal-stained race for the White House: one-party dictatorship.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Oct. 4-10, 2016
abstract: Have you been following the news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more.
lead_paragraph: Have you been following the news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more.

headline: Trumpism After Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: If the American anger and dread that fed Trump’s rise are not addressed, the consequences will be dire.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — If the United States escapes a disaster Nov. 8, it will have done so narrowly. Donald Trump, a dictator-in-waiting with a brat’s temper and a prig’s scowl, has won the support of tens of millions of Americans. It’s fortunate that we are less than a month from the election because we are running out of words to describe him: this phony, this liar, this blowhard, this cheat, this bully, this misogynist, this demagogue, this predator, this bigot, this bore, this egomaniac, this racist, this sexist, this sociopath. I will not go on. It’s pointless. Everyone knows, not least his supporters.

headline: Daphne Rubin-Vega Sings a Song From ‘Miss You Like Hell’
abstract: An exclusive video featuring a number from the new musical by Quiara Alegría Hudes and Erin McKeown, opening this month at the La Jolla Playhouse.
lead_paragraph: Musical theater has been rough on Daphne Rubin-Vega: She’s played a drug addict (Mimi in “Rent”) and an orphan-turned-prostitute (Fantine in “Les Miserables”). Now, in the new musical “Miss You Like Hell,” Ms. Rubin-Vega portrays another desperate woman on the verge, threatened with deportation from the United States and losing a relationship with her estranged daughter.

headline: Questions for: ‘If I Sleep for an Hour, 30 People Will Die‘
abstract: Why did Adolfo Kaminsky devote so many years to forgery?
lead_paragraph: Article: ‘If I Sleep for an Hour, 30 People Will Die’

headline: Ilham Tohti, Uighur Scholar in Chinese Prison, Is Given Human Rights Award
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Political Prisoners', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Mr. Tohti, who was jailed after speaking out against repression in his native Xinjiang, has been depicted by Beijing as promoting separatism.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Two years after the Chinese authorities sentenced the prominent Uighur intellectual Ilham Tohti to life imprisonment for promoting separatism and violence, a Swiss-based foundation awarded him a prestigious human rights prize on Tuesday for his efforts to foster dialogue and understanding.

headline: Notes on Brexit and the Pound
abstract: A weaker pound is part of the adjustment, and should be accepted.
lead_paragraph: The much-hyped severe Brexit recession does not, so far, seem to be materializing – which really shouldn’t be that much of a surprise, because as I warned, the actual economic case for such a recession was surprisingly weak. (Ouch! I just pulled a muscle while patting myself on the back!) But we are seeing a large drop in the pound, which has steepened as it becomes likely that this will indeed be a very hard Brexit. How should we think about this?

headline: California Today: Should You Have More Say Over Megaprojects?
abstract: Tuesday: A proposition on revenue bonds, the Giants survive to play another day, and San Diego’s brewers get big honors.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The Great American Stagnation
abstract: I think that the stagnation is the central political issue of our times.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: Putin in Syria: Chechnya All Over Again
abstract: The Kremlin wants to bomb Aleppo into submission and impose peace via a local strongman, just like it did in Grozny a decade and a half ago.
lead_paragraph: The difference between Aleppo now and Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, at the turn of the millennium is that Western leaders are at least trying to save the Syrians trapped in the besieged city. A decade and a half ago, there were precious few diplomatic missions for the Chechens. Within months of taking power, Vladimir V. Putin had moved decisively to regain control of Chechnya — which had broken free of Moscow’s control in a brief but nasty war in the mid-1990s — and world leaders mostly just looked on.

headline: Will Brexit Unravel the Peace in Northern Ireland?
abstract: Belfast is hip, progressive and calm. But its exit from the European Union could bring it all to an end.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — Progress, luckily, is often a self-accelerating force. But what about regression? I’m not alone in worrying about the self-perpetuating cycle of social setbacks; across Europe and America, I encounter more and more people concerned that today’s minor tension or flawed election might become tomorrow’s crisis.

headline: Cubs Lose, but It’s Too Early for Ghosts to Rise
abstract: Conor Gillaspie, once a nobody, has become a powerhouse for San Francisco, which won Game 3 in 13 innings with a double from another light-hitting Giant.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a postseason lesson for opponents of the San Francisco Giants: When Conor Gillaspie shrugs and says that he has no particular idea why he is hitting a ball or where it is going, you are advised to duck.

headline: Celebrating Seamus Heaney’s Legacy, at His Birthplace
abstract: A 21,000-square-foot arts center has opened in Bellaghy, Northern Ireland, where the Nobel Prize-winning poet was born.
lead_paragraph: BELLAGHY, Northern Ireland — “No such thing as innocent bystanding,” the actress Fiona Shaw said, staring fiercely at a group of people on a chilly, heavily misted morning in a farmer’s field here, filled with the sounds of lowing cattle and bird calls. The Irish-born Ms. Shaw was standing on top of a hay-filled trough, reading from Seamus Heaney’s “Mycenae Lookout,” and those words — which Heaney may have meant to refer to Ireland, as much as to Aeschylus’ “Oresteia” — took on a surprising, uneasy resonance when spoken out loud.

headline: Venezuela in a Vise
abstract: The government’s efforts to block a referendum against President Maduro are undemocratic and unconstitutional — and a betrayal of Hugo Chávez.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people are expected to fan out in protest across Venezuela on Wednesday to demand a referendum for the removal of President Nicolás Maduro: His government has overseen an economic crisis that has decimated livelihoods throughout the country.

headline: Tech Companies Expect Free High-Speed Internet for Poorer Americans to Pay Off Later
abstract: Tech companies like Sprint, Comcast and Facebook are increasingly working to make high-speed internet available to every American.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There is an axiom in technology: New products typically go to wealthy customers first, before prices eventually fall to reach the masses.

headline: Chappatte on Donald Trump and Lady Liberty
abstract: Has he gone too far, at last?
lead_paragraph: Has he gone too far, at last?

lead_paragraph: A story from the newsroom.

headline: Al Gore, With Hillary Clinton, Reminds Florida: ‘Every. Single. Vote. Counts.’
abstract: Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Gore discussed climate change and urged young adults to vote because, as Mr. Gore learned in Florida in 2000, every vote counts.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The guest of honor strolled across the stage — hair slicked back and grayed, no tie — embracing his host, briefly, before looking out on the campaign crowd.

headline: My Life in Pictures: Paula Cooper
abstract: The gallery owner shares images, and inspirations, from the past five decades.
lead_paragraph: The gallery owner shares images, and inspirations, from the past five decades.

headline: Conceptual Art’s Most Ardent Fan, 50 Years In
abstract: Paula Cooper’s love affair with minimalism began in the ’60s. From there, she pioneered a neighborhood and changed the art world.
lead_paragraph: Her love affair with minimalism began in the ’60s. From there, she pioneered a neighborhood and changed the art world.

headline: In Spain, Reviving Dishes That Disappeared in 1236
abstract: A new restaurant in Córdoba brings back a centuries-old style of cooking.
lead_paragraph: “Before, in Córdoba, you could see, hear and even smell our history, but you couldn’t taste it,” says the chef Paco Morales, explaining the inspiration for his new restaurant, Noor. Now, thanks to the 35-year-old Córdoba native, who has worked under Ferran Adrià and Andoni Luis Aduriz, you can eat modernized versions of delicacies that disappeared from the city after the Moors were exiled to Morocco in 1236. Three years of research into his hometown’s culinary past have resulted in three tasting menus, featuring overlooked ingredients like bitter oranges and dishes like maxixe cucumber with mint and shanklish, a type of clotted sheep’s milk cheese; a pudding of pine nuts, spring melon, Saharan sea urchin and fresh oregano; and little cheese pies called furniyya, flavored with carob.

headline: Rutgers’s Move to Big Ten Is a Win-Win Everywhere but the Field
abstract: Rutgers is 4-15 in conference games since joining the Big Ten in 2014, but lopsided losses aside, the numbers add up for the Scarlet Knights and the conference.
lead_paragraph: Fourth-ranked Michigan amassed 309 yards and scored six touchdowns Saturday in Piscataway, N.J., while holding Rutgers to 6 total yards — the result of one pass completion — on the way to a score of 43-0.

headline: ‘Rocky Horror’ Remake: Is It Time to Go Back to Camp?
abstract: The movie, which is set for broadcast on Oct. 20 on Fox, features Laverne Cox as Dr. Frank-N-Furter.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — In the predawn hours of a mid-April night, punky revelers weary from a spirited session of jumps to the left, steps to the right and vigorous pelvic thrusts were scattered on a ballroom floor at Casa Loma, a fearsome Gothic-style castle here. High above the bodies, elevated on a crane, stood a gyrating Laverne Cox, who was dressed in a black gown and an enormous disc-shaped headpiece. Gradually lowered to the ground, Ms. Cox met the path of a virginal couple trying to back away from the weirdness. There she extended a hand, covering a rhinestone-sequined glove, and sang her fateful first line: “How do you do?”

headline: A Choose-Your-Own-Adventure Cake
abstract: Customers select the frostings, fillings and decorations for the Milk ID cake from Milk Bar.
lead_paragraph: Do you prefer a chocolate malt or brown-butter cheesecake filling? Strawberry or chocolate-fudge frosting? Milk Bar’s well-stacked six-inch party cakes, with their confetti-studded layers, can now be ordered with custom frostings, fillings and crumb decorations. They are shipped frozen for arrival on a Thursday (the Saturday before is the cutoff for ordering): Milk ID customized birthday cake, $60, milkbar.goldbely.com.

headline: For Hindus on Long Island, a New Temple 3 Decades in the Making
abstract: The spiritual center in Melville, N.Y., which was completed mostly by volunteers, includes an assembly hall, a dining area, an indoor basketball court and classrooms.
lead_paragraph: MELVILLE, N.Y. — With each green chile prepared, the coughing grew louder. The smell, and kick, of Indian spices filled the kitchen air, as the volunteers prepared meals for the weekend.

headline: The Kenneth Bone Effect
abstract: The post-debate fashion conversation centered on an unlikely character.
lead_paragraph: After the dust from the second presidential debate settled on Monday morning, it turned out that the real sartorial shocker of the night had not been Hillary Clinton’s Ralph Lauren pantsuit or Melania Trump’s pussy-bow Gucci top. It was a red cable-knit cotton sweater with a quarter zip worn by Kenneth Bone, audience member, undecided voter and overnight sensation.

headline: Galaxy Note 7 Abandoned by Customers
keywords: ['Smartphones', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Consumers put their safety first after Samsung announced that it would stop selling its troubled Galaxy Note 7 smartphone following new reports of the phones catching fire.
lead_paragraph: Consumers put their safety first after Samsung announced that it would stop selling its troubled Galaxy Note 7 smartphone following new reports of the phones catching fire.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'London Fashion Week', 'Milan Fashion Week']

headline: A Food Hall Lures the Lunch Crowd in Chicago
abstract: Revival Food Hall in the city’s Loop offers a kaleidoscope of local foods.
lead_paragraph: The regional food hall — a kaleidoscope of local, artisanal purveyors that has been well established for decades in cities on the East and West Coasts — has finally made it to Chicago. But what took so long?

headline: The Wisdom Beneath the Steps of ‘Dances at a Gathering’
abstract: The how and why of an affecting work by Jerome Robbins.
lead_paragraph: Nobody speaks, is betrayed, dies or goes mad in Jerome Robbins’s ballet “Dances at a Gathering,” but this hourlong, pure-dance work, set to an anthology of Chopin piano pieces, is nonetheless a multilayered masterpiece of theater.

headline: Earth-Rattling Times at Samsung and Twitter
abstract: The Galaxy Note 7 smartphone maker halted production after some of the devices caught fire. And Twitter was facing an implosion in potential deal talks.
lead_paragraph: Samsung and Twitter are not tech companies whose names are often uttered in the same breath. But they are connected right now by the theme of explosions.

headline: Checking for the Windows 10 Anniversary Update
abstract: Microsoft pushed out a big update to its operating system this summer, and you can confirm whether your PC has it through a few quick steps.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do I get the Windows 10 Anniversary Update on my PC?

headline: A Caribbean Sun Shines at Sally Roots in Bushwick
abstract: Brooklyn gets a new restaurant for island specialties, and another for pizza.
lead_paragraph: SALLY ROOTS A sunny taste of the Caribbean — with jerk chicken, skewered shrimp slathered with garlicky mojo, codfish cakes and an array of tropical drinks — is the work of the partners Matthew Maddy, James Freeman and Johnny De Piper. Mr. Maddy is responsible for the look of the space, which includes a central bar and a patio. (The name is based on the label of an old Calypso recording, from Sally Ruth Records, that his grandmother owned.) This being Brooklyn, there’s a kale salad, but here it’s dressed with coconut. And if you fancy a slice of pineapple on your burger, you can have that, too: 195 Wyckoff Avenue (Harman Avenue), Bushwick, Brooklyn, 347-425-0888, sallyroots.com.

headline: Glamour on the Gowanus: Nets Really Call Brooklyn Home
abstract: Twelve of the 15 Nets players with guaranteed contracts live in Brooklyn; last year, with the team still practicing in New Jersey, there was only one.
lead_paragraph: Even Jeremy Lin lives in Brooklyn now.

lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump lashed out at Speaker Paul D. Ryan and other critics within his party on Tuesday in a barrage of Twitter posts deriding the highest-ranking Republican as a feckless leader and warning that those who have been disloyal risked handing the election to Hillary Clinton.

headline: Court Gives President More Power Over Consumer Agency Chief
keywords: ['Consumer Protection', 'Appeals Courts (US)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: An appeals court panel said the director of Consumer Financial Protection Bureau was too independent, so it gave the president the power to fire him at will.
lead_paragraph: In a significant blow to the authority of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday that the agency’s structure was unconstitutional but offered a fairly simple remedy: Give the president the power to fire the agency’s director at will.

headline: Pondicheri
abstract: An all-day Indian cafe, the first outpost from the Houston chef Anita Jaisinghani.
lead_paragraph: An all-day Indian cafe, the first outpost from the Houston chef Anita Jaisinghani.

headline: Pondicheri Makes Indian Flavors an All-Day Affair
abstract: A Manhattan cafe imported from Houston works for many occasions.
lead_paragraph: “This is the first place you’ve taken me where I’d come back and spend my own money,” a friend said in the middle of lunch at Pondicheri. He is highly sensitive to pretension and unjustified expense, so whenever I take him along on one of my hunting parties, I try to pick something with a high ratio of flavor to price. At Pondicheri, I finally hit his sweet spot.

headline: Can the U.S. Really Get Astronauts to Mars by 2030?
abstract: President Obama renewed his call to send Americans to the red planet, and White House and NASA officials outlined how they expected to get there.
lead_paragraph: In an essay published Tuesday on CNN’s website, President Obama renewed his call for American astronauts to visit Mars.

abstract: The strike is now in its seventh day, and workers marched on campus Tuesday in a clash with the nation’s wealthiest university.
lead_paragraph: A dispute over wages and benefits between Harvard and its cafeteria workers has led to a strike that is now in its seventh day, with no immediate resolution in sight, an official at the nation’s wealthiest university said on Tuesday.

headline: Aaron Pryor, Boxing Champion Who Defeated Addiction, Dies at 60
abstract: Pryor, a junior welterweight, was 39-1 professionally, and memorably battled Alexis Argüello. He later overcame a career-ending addiction to cocaine.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Pryor, whose erratic swings and stances won him the world junior welterweight boxing championship but also mirrored a career-ending struggle with cocaine addiction, died on Sunday at his home in Cincinnati. He was 60.

headline: Fighting for Water
abstract: Nine indigenous groups gathered in New York City to show solidarity with the Standing Rock protest in North Dakota. They are also urging the city to rename Columbus Day “Indigenous Peoples Day.”
lead_paragraph: Nine indigenous groups gathered in New York City to show solidarity with the Standing Rock protest in North Dakota. They are also urging the city to rename Columbus Day “Indigenous Peoples Day.”

headline: Iconic Fashion for a Good Cause
abstract: The resale site RE-SEE is putting clothing and accessories donated by Claudia Schiffer, Cindy Sherman and more on the block for charity.
lead_paragraph: “Today, everyone is kind of a tastemaker; with social media, things have moved so fast, and we talk more and more about ‘it girls,’” says Sofia Bernardin, one-half of the rare vintage and second-hand clothing site RE-SEE. She and her co-founder, Sabrina Marshall, who both defected from the magazine world and launched the Paris-based platform in 2013, are “all about the best of the past, those breakaway moments and collections that changed fashion.”

headline: Gunmen Attack Crowded Shiite Shrine in Kabul
abstract: The attack came on the eve of Ashura, one of the most solemn holidays on the Shiite calendar.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Gunmen disguised as police officers attacked a Shiite shrine packed with hundreds of worshipers in the Afghan capital late Tuesday, killing at least 14 people and wounding dozens, officials and witnesses reported.

headline: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Calls Colin Kaepernick’s National Anthem Protest ‘Dumb’
keywords: ['National Anthems', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People']

lead_paragraph: Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the Supreme Court justice who came under fire recently for lacerating comments about Donald J. Trump, has dropped another eyebrow-raising remark about a different figure in the news: the N.F.L. football player Colin Kaepernick and his protest surrounding the national anthem.

headline: Review: ‘Vice News Tonight,’ on HBO, Is New but No Game Changer

lead_paragraph: The “Tonight” in “Vice News Tonight” — Vice Media’s new weeknight newscast on HBO, which began on Monday — is a promise that the show kind of, sort of, doesn’t really keep.

headline: Newspaper Closes in Hungary, and Hungarians See Government’s Hand
keywords: ['Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Newspapers', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Censorship']
abstract: Nepszabadsag, Hungary’s largest opposition paper, has halted publication after years of financial losses. Some also say political interference played a role.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Roland Baksa, an investigative reporter at Hungary’s largest opposition newspaper, packed up his computer on Friday. The publication’s parent company had announced that it would move offices over the weekend, and the editor in chief had promised pizza on Sunday to celebrate the move.

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Among the oldest diamond districts in the country, the Jewelers Row section of this historic city has been a part of the engagement stories of couples in the region for generations.

lead_paragraph: As his campaign battles to stave off defections from within the Republican Party, Donald J. Trump has released a new ad attacking Hillary Clinton as “Dangerous” on foreign policy grounds and portraying her as physically incapable of meeting the demands of the presidency.

headline: Cuba and Curiosity at the New York Film Festival
abstract: Two selections at this event, “Memories of the Underdevelopment” and “Patria o Muerte,” cast a hard look at the island’s past and its present.
lead_paragraph: Cuba is a forbidden island no longer. It’s been almost two years since President Obama announced that the United States would normalize relations with Cuba. Regularly scheduled flights are taking off, and now you too can book a room there through Airbnb. A country that has been off limits for 50 years will inevitably lure the curious.

lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization on Tuesday urged countries to impose a tax on sugary drinks to battle the growing obesity epidemic and presented new data on the beneficial health effects of such a tax.

Trump as a fundamentally indecent person dangerously unsuited and unprepared for the presidency, imploring voters to “turn back the forces of racism and misogyny, and send a message for progress” by electing Hillary Clinton instead.

abstract: If the taxes had been paid instead, what the presidential candidate saved could have greatly benefited his fellow Americans.

headline: A Stand-Up Talks About Depression. He Hopes You’ll Laugh.
abstract: Chris Gethard’s new show, “Career Suicide,” which explores his anxiety as well as his public missteps, might seem like an odd choice for comedy.
lead_paragraph: The title of Chris Gethard’s new solo show, “Career Suicide,” and its accompanying poster — he’s seen with a cartoon noose around his neck — might seem like an odd choice for a comedy. But, as Mr. Gethard’s fans have come to learn, it’s an apt title for a comedian whose work often addresses his struggles with depression and anxiety and whose career has had its share of twists and turns.

headline: Colin Kaepernick to Start at Quarterback for 49ers

headline: In Jonathan Lethem’s ‘A Gambler’s Anatomy,’ a Hustler’s Luck Turns Cold
abstract: A backgammon player who can sometimes read minds shuttles among casinos across Europe and Asia. Too bad about the grim diagnosis.
lead_paragraph: Backgammon is exciting to play if you know what you’re doing, but it’s awful to read about. Even the classic works on the subject, such as “Backgammon: The Cruelest Game” (1974) by Barclay Cooke and Jon Bradshaw, build up to dramatic moments like this one, which read like Clausewitz’s “On War” by way of an Ikea instruction packet: “In Diagram 86, white has borne off 13 of his men, and in this position red rolls a 2-1.”

headline: Metaphorically Speaking, Men Are Expected to be Struck by Genius, Women to Nurture It
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Science and Technology', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Mathematics']
abstract: Research into the metaphors used to describe inventions found that they carried implicit associations about men and women’s stereotypical gender roles.
lead_paragraph: Try searching for “top inventors of all time” on Google. Start counting the images along the top of your search page, and you’ll go through 29 photos of men before you reach Hedy Lamarr, an Austrian actress from Hollywood’s golden age. In 1942, she shared a patent for a technology to prevent enemies from detecting messages in radio signals. This “Secret Communication System” eventually led to today’s mobile phone technology and to secure military communications.

headline: Wells Fargo’s Heir Apparent Has Ties to Scandal
abstract: It is not clear why an executive so closely linked to the scandal involving fake bank and credit card accounts should lead the company.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo is circling the stagecoaches around a top deputy.

headline: Yemen, Donald Trump, China: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

abstract: Cook with these squash varieties or use them to add color to your autumn décor.
lead_paragraph: Cook with these squash varieties or use them to add color to your autumn décor.

abstract: Sarah Frey of Frey Farms reigns supreme among the nation’s pumpkin farmers.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Frey of Frey Farms reigns supreme among the nation’s pumpkin farmers.

abstract: Sarah Frey, who has made a fortune farming the basic orange models, wants people to start eating the quirky heirlooms.
lead_paragraph: KEENES, Ill. — Sarah Frey is the undisputed pumpkin queen of America.

headline: An Orphaned Play Finds a New Home at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater
abstract: “My Name Is Gideon,” a production by All for One Theater that was canceled with the abrupt closure of Soho Rep’s theater, is back on.
lead_paragraph: The sudden closure of Soho Rep’s Off Broadway space in TriBeCa came at a bad time for All for One Theater.

headline: How Taylor Mac Trained His Vocal Cords for a Marathon
abstract: Five years of preparation, water with electrolyte drops, green tea and vitamin B shots helped this performance artist get through a 24-hour show.
lead_paragraph: From “Shenandoah” to “Born to Run,” from “Yankee Doodle Dandy” to “Purple Rain,” the performance artist Taylor Mac spanned more than two centuries last weekend in his spectacularly glittery, joyously excessive, drag-filled 24-hour journey through the history of America and its pop sounds, “A 24-Decade History of Popular Music.” Of the many feats he accomplished during the marathon at St. Ann’s Warehouse — queering the American Songbook, pitting Stephen Foster and Walt Whitman in a wrestling match — perhaps the most basic was the most crucial: His voice held up.

headline: Central Banks Consider Bitcoin’s Technology, if Not Bitcoin
abstract: Central banks view the technology behind the virtual currency as a possible way to compete and record transactions, or to issue their own currencies.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin was created by libertarian-minded programmers with a deep suspicion of central banks and the national currencies they issue.

headline: Donald Trump and the Havoc in the G.O.P.
abstract: Readers discuss Republican reaction to Donald Trump, his debate performance and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Bias and Secrecy in Jury Deliberations
abstract: The justices seemed to struggle over whether jury deliberations should stay secret when evidence emerges that they were marred by racial or ethnic bias.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an argument marked by testy exchanges, the Supreme Court on Tuesday struggled to decide whether it should make an exception to the usual rule that jury deliberations are secret when evidence emerges that those discussions were marred by racial or ethnic bias.

headline: In the Studio With One of Fashion’s Most Prolific Milliners
abstract: Stephen Jones, the British hatmaker who collaborates with the likes of Thom Browne and Rei Kawakubo, explains the appeal of top hats.
lead_paragraph: This season alone, Stephen Jones created hats for Christopher Kane (retro pieces in the shape of collapsed cones), Thom Browne (oversized animal heads), Anya Hindmarch (bandage-esque headbands) and Maria Grazia Chirui’s much-anticipated debut at Dior (sporty visors). The milliner also collaborated with the young London College of Fashion graduate Ryan Lo on marabou-trimmed tricorn hats, which recalled the swashbuckling styles John Galliano used on his Dior runways during his reign from 1996 to 2011 (which Jones also created). Today, Galliano helms Maison Margiela — and while the house’s collaborators and contributors are kept secret, let’s just say this season featured some irreverent skull caps and headsets on the runway.

headline: Review: In ‘Acoustically Speaking,’ a ‘Rent’ Duo Returns
abstract: Adam Pascal and Anthony Rapp, who starred in the original Broadway cast, team up to pay tribute to musical theater’s relationship with modern pop.
lead_paragraph: Among the many moments when Broadway show music and modern pop have bowed and curtsied to one another, Jonathan Larson’s score for “Rent” is arguably the flash point when they fell into each other’s arms and sealed a partnership that continues to this day. I know, I know; as far back as “Hair,” there were successful hybrids. But the “Rent” juggernaut signaled a generational shift and locked a merger whose success has had everything to do with a younger generation of performers weaned on rock and schooled in musical theater.

headline: Donald Trump Faltering? Die-Hard Fans Refuse to Buy It
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'News and News Media']
abstract: At Mr. Trump’s rallies, the candidate and the crowds draw energy and affirmation from one another, while dismissing any discouraging information.
lead_paragraph: WILKES-BARRE, Pa. — The line to see Donald J. Trump snaked back and forth on itself hours before his arrival. There was a carnival atmosphere with people in costumes, including one prison-striped man with a sign, “Don’t let the government-run media elect crooked Hillary.” A cavalcade of motorcycles roared up, and there were cheers and laughter for a man shouting, “Donald Trump is going to make America great! He hasn’t paid taxes in 20 years!”

headline: Putin Proposes Distinct Category for Athletes on Drug Exemptions
abstract: The Russian president suggested that athletes who require therapeutic use exemptions be barred from competing against those who do not.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia waded into the nuances of antidoping protocols in sports on Tuesday, criticizing the practice of allowing athletes to use prohibited drugs for legitimate medical reasons. He claimed that athletes given such waivers had an unfair advantage.

headline: Priest Wounded in South Africa Protest
abstract: The Rev. Graham Pugin was injured by a rubber bullet fired by the South African police during student protests in Johannesburg. The rally was the latest in a series of national demonstrations over university tuition.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Graham Pugin was injured by a rubber bullet fired by the South African police during student protests in Johannesburg. The rally was the latest in a series of national demonstrations over university tuition.

headline: Review: In ‘The God Projekt,’ He’s Old and Alone but Still Almighty
abstract: This play features Kevin Augustine as a broken-down heavenly father who is better at making promises than answering prayers.
lead_paragraph: God has a freezer in heaven’s basement where he keeps a severed arm. Gigantic and tattooed, it ends in a hand with long, manicured nails. When God holds the limb, he cradles it tenderly.

headline: Review: ‘Tower,’ About 1966, Before Mass Shootings Became Routine
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Movies']
abstract: Keith Maitland’s documentary on the University of Texas tower mass shooting breathes life into victims rather than dissecting the shooter.
lead_paragraph: The haunting documentary “Tower” revisits a 1966 mass shooting at the University of Texas at Austin that shocked the country. It may be difficult to comprehend the reaction to the horror of Charles Whitman, a 25-year-old student who shot more than a dozen dead, wounding more than twice as many. A cover story in Life magazine suggested just how alien the carnage seemed at the time, noting that during the rampage Whitman’s actions were “so outrageous, so hard to grasp, that people could not believe it.” Many more mass shootings later, it’s now tragically easy to believe.

headline: The Man Musicians Call When Two Tunes Sound Alike
keywords: ['Music', 'Forensic Science', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Peter Oxendale, considered one of the world’s leading forensic musicologists, got into the profession by accident.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Peter Oxendale, a onetime glam rocker (“We all have skeletons,” he says), is perhaps the world’s leading forensic musicologist, the person musicians call when they believe someone has ripped off their work. In a penthouse overlooking the English Channel, he analyzes songs, everything from pop hits to classical pieces, until he is sure there has been an infringement, or not.

headline: Uncertainty in Brazil, Vitality in Its Art
abstract: The São Paulo Biennial shows that it’s possible to learn from the problems of the region.

But where the Olympics are still a rather contained affair, art biennials are proliferating like art fairs, becoming homogeneous and forgettable.

headline: Donald Trump Tax Plan Would Add to Debt and Hillary Clinton’s Wouldn’t, Study Finds

headline: Trump and the Nuclear Keys

abstract: Nuclear launch officers count on the president to have sound judgment. That would not be possible under a President Trump.
lead_paragraph: As the 1973 Yom Kippur war between Israel and neighboring Arab states intensified, I was in an underground missile launch center in Montana with a crewmate when we received an emergency message to prepare for nuclear war with the Soviet Union. Only at the president’s behest would we ever turn keys to fire up to 50 nuclear-armed missiles that could extinguish millions of lives in less than an hour. Once we closed our eight-ton blast door to begin alert duty, we took orders from no one else.

headline: Russell Moore Can’t Support Either Candidate
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Evangelical Movement', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The preacher on Bible-belt racism, pro-Trump evangelicals and the relationship between the Republican Party and American evangelicalism.
lead_paragraph: You have a somewhat different approach than your predecessors at the Southern Baptist Convention. Your tenure has been marked by your advocacy for working with others with whom you can find common cause, particularly in regard to racial reconciliation, which you worked with Obama on. What influenced you to break the tradition? Growing up in Mississippi shaped my life in all sorts of ways, including seeing a Bible Belt, cultural Christianity that was often very tolerant of racism and bigotry. Much of the New Testament has to do with breaking down divisions. As time has gone on, the more I see my identity within the global church and the global body of Christ, so what hurts my African-American brother or sister hurts me.

headline: Generation Adderall
keywords: ['ADDERALL (DRUG)', 'Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder', 'AMPHETAMINES', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Like many of my friends, I spent years using prescription stimulants to get through school and start my career. Then I tried to get off them.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever been to Enfield? I had never even heard of it until I was 23 and living in London for graduate school. One afternoon, I received notification that a package whose arrival I had been anticipating for days had been bogged down in customs and was now in a FedEx warehouse in Enfield, an unremarkable London suburb. I was outside my flat within minutes of receiving this news and on the train to Enfield within the hour, staring through the window at the gray sky. The package in question, sent from Los Angeles, contained my monthly supply of Adderall.

headline: Can a Woman Pretend to Be a Lesbian to Get a Couples’ Discount?
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Philanthropy', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Alcohol Abuse']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on who is hurt when you bend the truth for a small personal gain, whether the punishment for breaking a resolution should ever be giving money to an organization you abhor and more.
lead_paragraph: My local pool offers memberships for single people, couples (defined as “significant others living together”) and family memberships. The couples and family memberships are discounted from the rates for single people. I am a woman married to a man. I wanted to join this pool, but my husband was not interested, so a female friend and I joined as a “couple” to obtain the discounted rate. On the application, I described my female friend as my “partner” and listed her address as my address.

headline: How Exercise May Turn White Fat Into Brown
abstract: Exercise may aid in weight control and help to fend off diabetes by improving the ability of fat cells to burn calories.
lead_paragraph: Exercise may aid in weight control and help to fend off diabetes by improving the ability of fat cells to burn calories, a new study reports. It may do this in part by boosting levels of a hormone called irisin, which is produced during exercise and which may help to turn ordinary white fat into much more metabolically active brown fat, the findings suggest.

abstract: The acts of defiance, directed at Beijing as some called for outright independence for the semiautonomous territory, seemed to augur a stormy legislative term.

On Wednesday, the protests moved into Hong Kong’s legislature, as newly elected lawmakers gathered to take the oath of office. The acts of defiance directed at Beijing, with some people calling for outright independence for Hong Kong, seemed to augur an especially stormy legislative term.

headline: The Russia-U.S. Partnership, Driven to a New Low
abstract: The next American president will have to recognize that Russia is less interested in a détente than in being a victor with no need to justify itself.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Whoever becomes the next president of the United States will have to deal with a Russia that seems both familiar and, increasingly, unfamiliar. For centuries, Russia has been a resource-exporting country, an economic laggard and a touchy partner, driven by a European culture and a decidedly un-European body politic. But now those constants have been joined by new factors: President Vladimir V. Putin’s political unpredictability and his readiness to use military force.

Lin-Manuel Miranda, who wrote the book, music and lyrics for the musical “Hamilton,” is a genial guide to both tales.

headline: Gardens by France’s Most Revered Landscape Designer
abstract: Louis Benech looks back on his seminal projects, testaments to his glorious gift and to the constant, occasionally heart-rending, effects of time.
lead_paragraph: Gardens are “an expression of faith” and “the embodiment of hope,” wrote the revered English landscape architect Russell Page in his memoir, “The Education of a Gardener,” in 1962. If you’re lucky, you start with a blank slate and some time in the future, years later, it may become something like what you had in mind. Gardens are forever evolving and growing, like children to adulthood, and like all things in nature, they can be hobbled by disease, or refashioned for the times or, on occasion, brutally destroyed before reaching maturity — life interrupted. They hold a beauty and a sadness — seasonally, of course, from those early sprouts pushing through the softened earth of spring, to the autumn, when the leaves fade and fall and the barrenness of winter sets in, but also in their impermanence. Gardens continually remind us of our mortality.

headline: Gibney Dance: A Polarizing Choreographer From Israel Returns
abstract: “Climax” explores the chaos, intimacy and experimental leanings of Yasmeen Godder’s 15-year career.
lead_paragraph: In the past decade or so, Israel has emerged as an exciting hub of contemporary dance with a physical style of extreme precision, palpable tension and sexy aggression. But Yasmeen Godder has embraced the awkward and the grotesque instead, becoming one of the country’s most important, and polarizing, choreographers. While other artists exert control, she celebrates chaos: To watch one of her shows is to watch a world slide into anarchy.

headline: Celebrations: The Juilliard String Quartet and John Zorn
abstract: The quartet is observing its 70th anniversary, while Mr. Zorn is receiving an expansive tribute.
lead_paragraph: Now containing no one who played with any of its original members, the still-glorious Juilliard String Quartet celebrates its 70th anniversary on Monday, Oct. 17, at Alice Tully Hall with its current complement: Joseph Lin and Ronald Copes, violins; Roger Tapping, viola; and Astrid Schween, cello. The program consists of two middle-period Beethoven quartets and Bartok’s moody Quartet No. 1. (7:30 p.m., juilliard.edu.)

headline: Mikhail Baryshnikov Prepares to Portray, What Else, a Dancer
abstract: “Letters to a Man” looks at Vaslav Nijinsky in a performance piece from Robert Wilson.
lead_paragraph: According to W. H. Auden, “What mad Nijinsky wrote about Diaghilev is true of the normal heart.” Empathetic theatergoers have a tantalizing opportunity to test Auden’s assertion this month, as one of the greatest male dancers of the 20th century, Mikhail Baryshnikov, interprets the tormented words of another, Vaslav Nijinsky, in “Letters to a Man” (the man being Nijinsky’s lover and mentor, the Russian impresario Sergei Diaghilev), which runs Oct. 15 to Oct. 30 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Shovels & Rope, Visiting New York With a Scrappy New Album
abstract: Cary Ann Hearst and Michael Trent, the married couple who make up this band, will perform at the Music Hall of Williamsburg and the Bowery Ballroom.
lead_paragraph: Cary Ann Hearst and Michael Trent, the married couple who make up Shovels & Rope, share a belief in the power of raw emotion. Their scrappy new album, “Little Seeds” (New West), draws loosely from folk rock, cowpunk and Southern gothic traditions, with stories to spare. “Mourning Song” is an intimate reflection on the toll of Alzheimer’s. “BWYR” proposes a shaky but honest unity in the face of mass violence. But Mr. Trent, typically heard strumming a guitar, and Ms. Hearst, chiefly the band’s drummer, can deliver as much punch with a lighter premise, singing in their rafters-raising harmony. “I Know” suggests a sneering put-down of a rival band’s pretensions, while “San Andreas Fault Line Blues” belongs to the ageless category of Los Angeles disillusionment narratives. (Music Hall of Williamsburg, Monday, Oct. 17; Bowery Ballroom, Oct. 18-19.)

headline: Corporate Board Diversity Gets Push From Business Leaders
abstract: The Business Roundtable has strongly endorsed a link between board diversity and board effectiveness and the creation of long-term shareholder value.
lead_paragraph: The job of the board nominating committee of large corporations just got harder. Chief executives have laid down a new marker that substantially increases the emphasis on promoting diversity in corporate boardrooms.

headline: Nick Cave: Sculptural, and Political, at Mass MoCA
abstract: Mr. Cave’s installation “Until” addresses recent lethal incidents of racial violence on an epic scale.
lead_paragraph: Nick Cave’s “Soundsuits,” wearable sculptural assemblages of fantastic complexity, are so compelling that it’s easy to forget they began as political protest. He made the first one in response to the 1991 Los Angeles police beating of Rodney King. Mr. Cave’s new installation at Mass MoCA, in North Adams, Mass., is political, too. It addresses more recent lethal incidents of racial violence — the killings of Michael Brown, Eric Garner and Trayvon Martin — on an epic scale. Titled “Until” — as in “guilty until proven innocent” — the installation (opening Saturday, Oct. 15) fills the museum’s football-field-size main space, functioning as a kind of walk-in soundsuit, composed of thousands of eye-catching found objects. But Mr. Cave cuts the high spirits with images of guns, bullets and targets. Besides being sculptural, the piece is architectural, meant to serve as an assembly hall/stage, where dancers, singers and poets will perform and community groups meet during the show’s yearlong run. (massmoca.org.)

headline: Survivor of Connecticut Plane Crash Tells of Argument in Cockpit
abstract: Arian Prevalla, a flight instructor, offered his account to officials looking into why the aircraft went down in East Hartford, Conn., killing his student, Fera M. Freitekh.
lead_paragraph: In the moments before a Piper PA-34 Seneca twin-engine plane plunged into a street in a suburban Connecticut town, tearing through power lines and narrowly avoiding people on the ground, the two men on board had a heated exchange, law enforcement officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Review: In ‘Falling Water,’ Real Life’s Hard. Dreams Are Worse.
abstract: This new USA Network drama follows three characters whose vivid dreamscapes complicate their already complex real lives.
lead_paragraph: Remember when the USA Network could be counted on for solid, nontaxing series that could be consumed without much mental effort? “Monk.” “Psych.” “The Dead Zone.”

headline: Daily Report: Planning to Cut the Cord on Cable? Let Us Help
abstract: The problem is too many options. Our reporter teamed up with the product recommendation site The Wirecutter on a guide to help you weigh your choices.
lead_paragraph: Cutting the cable cord might not be as easy as you think.

headline: How to Bid Adieu to Yahoo
abstract: When you decide it’s time to close your account and move on to another mail service, make sure you get all the files you need before you go.

headline: Toasting Art and Talking Politics
abstract: For guests attending the annual fund-raiser for the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles, angst over the presidential campaign was a theme of the evening.
lead_paragraph: For guests attending the annual fund-raiser for the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles, angst over the presidential campaign was a theme of the evening.

abstract: For guests attending the annual fund-raiser for the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles, angst over the presidential campaign was a theme of the evening.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Typically, museum fund-raisers in Los Angeles toast art, film and fashion. It’s a love triangle that attracts a diverse constellation of talent.

headline: Dismissal Denied, Derrick Rose’s Civil Rape Trial Continues
abstract: Two co-defendants concurred with Rose’s contention that the sex they had with the plaintiff in 2013 was consensual and that the woman was sober.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The judge in the civil rape case of Knicks guard Derrick Rose denied a motion by Rose’s legal team for a dismissal or mistrial on Wednesday, and the trial resumed with testimony from the two co-defendants, who are longtime friends of Rose’s.

headline: A New Horror Film Festival at Cinema Village
abstract: FearNYC, starting Oct. 21, will feature more than 65 films. Among them: family-friendly choices, frightening classics and new movies.
lead_paragraph: Horror fans are in for a macabre menu of varying flavors when FearNYC, a new film festival, makes its debut on Friday, Oct. 21, at Cinema Village. Among the offerings (more than 65 films) are family-friendly frights (“The Monster Squad”), oddball documentaries (“Unearthed & Untold: The Path to ‘Pet Sematary’”) and big servings of nightmare-inducing classics (“The Texas Chain Saw Massacre”).

headline: Disney Star Archetypes: 'A Miley, a Demi or a Selena?'
abstract: A look at some of Rowan Blanchard’s predecessors.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of Rowan Blanchard’s predecessors.

headline: Rowan Blanchard: The Unlikely Evolution of a Disney Star
abstract: Rowan Blanchard takes to Instagram and Twitter to help her overcome the child Disney star stereotype. And it seems to be working.
lead_paragraph: At the Metrograph theater on the Lower East Side of New York, Rowan Blanchard wore a knit pleated skirt overlaid by a pleated sleeveless tunic and chunky platform gold glitter shoes, all made and provided by the fashion house Kenzo. Holding a bag of salty popcorn and another bag of Swedish fish, she sat in one of the first few rows, just as a screening of a film she appeared in was about to begin.

headline: When Choosing Cheese, Low-Fat May Not Matter
abstract: Cheese with a regular fat content may be as healthy a choice as the low-fat version.
lead_paragraph: Regular-fat cheese may be as healthy a choice as the low-fat version.

headline: Lessons in the Delicate Art of Confronting Offensive Speech
keywords: ['Psychology and Psychologists', 'Discrimination', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Many people are left speechless when a companion uses ethnic, sexist or racist slurs. But researchers say there are ways to cut such remarks short.
lead_paragraph: What if Billy Bush had just changed the subject?

headline: Migrant Children, Alone and Desperate in Calais, Look to Britain With Hope
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: With the French government’s planned dismantling of the migrant camp looming, officials say Britain may finally be accelerating steps to admit dozens of children.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — About 1,000 unaccompanied children live in the filth of the Jungle, as the sprawling migrant camp outside Calais, France, is known. Alone, with no parents, they sleep in the same crowded, muddy tents as adults. Some are as young as 9. Many traveled on their own, often in the wake of family or friends.

headline: Elena Ferrante’s Picture Book Embraces the Dark Side
abstract: Complete with curse words — added by her English translator — Ferrante’s picture book tells the story of a lost doll’s utterly terrifying night at the beach.
lead_paragraph: THE BEACH AT NIGHTBy Elena FerranteIllustrated by Mara CerriTranslated by Ann Goldstein42 pp. Europa Editions. $13. (Picture book; ages 10 and up)

headline: In ‘Black Mirror,’ Sci-Fi That Feels Close to Home
abstract: Charlie Brooker, the show’s creator, and the executive producer Annabel Jones, explain how they constructed one of the show’s most iconic episodes.
lead_paragraph: When the British television series “Black Mirror” first debuted in 2011, it drew in viewers with its techno “Twilight Zone” vibes. Here was a dark, ultramodern anthology series that harnessed all of our technological anxieties and spun them into twisted parables on the relationship between man and machine. But over the past two seasons — and its wildly popular second life on Netflix — the show’s cult appeal has proved deeper than its digital gimmickry. Its stories are grounded close to home, in the very near future. The result is a human drama (and sometimes, satire) that feels considerably more visceral, immediate and human than your old-fashioned dystopian nightmare.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stung by a fierce backlash from Donald J. Trump’s ardent supporters, four Republican members of Congress who had made headlines for demanding that Mr. Trump leave the presidential race retreated quietly this week, conceding that they would still probably vote for the man they had excoriated just days before.

headline: Ronda Rousey Returning to U.F.C. With Title Fight Against Amanda Nunes

lead_paragraph: Ronda Rousey will return to the Octagon a year after losing her title in a monumental upset.

headline: In City Built by Immigrants, Immigration Is the Defining Political Issue
abstract: Many residents of Hazleton, Pa., who are losing ground, including Democrats, back Mr. Trump. Many who are prospering, including Republicans, support Clinton.
lead_paragraph: HAZLETON, Pa. — Thousands of Dominicans have poured into this little city in eastern Pennsylvania since 2001 to work in the food plants and warehouses on the edge of town, where the highway to New York meets the highway to Philadelphia.

headline: Raising Fears of a Flight from International Criminal Court, Burundi Heads for Exit
keywords: ['Legislatures and Parliaments', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The country’s lower house of Parliament has voted overwhelmingly to withdraw from the International Criminal Court, something that other nations have threatened to do.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The lower house of Burundi’s Parliament voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to withdraw the country from the International Criminal Court, a move that international justice advocates fear could open the floodgates for other countries to divorce themselves from what was already seen as a deeply troubled institution.

headline: Help for a Business Idea Trying to Catch Fire
abstract: Accelerator programs like New Venture Challenge in Chicago can be competitive, but can provide start-up owners with valuable advice and material help.
lead_paragraph: When Katlin Smith entered the New Venture Challenge business accelerator, she had developed an idea for making food that was “simple, healthy and delicious” but did not have a sense for what to do next.

headline: With a Fine Looming, Deutsche Bank Is Still Issuing Debt
abstract: A bond issue shows that the bank can get access to markets, reinforcing its €215 billion pile of liquidity.
lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank has received a cautious vote of creditor confidence. The German lender is issuing expensive debt. That shows it can get access to markets, despite a feared $14 billion American regulatory fine. It is less powerful a signal than buying debt back, as Deutsche Bank did in February — but at least it shows that investors do not fear losses that could eat into senior debt.

headline: ‘Ladies First’ Trailer
abstract: In Saudi Arabia, women still can’t drive. But they have been recently granted the right to vote and to run in an election. The Times’s Mona El-Naggar takes us inside the ultraconservative kingdom and into the largely inaccessible world of Saudi women.
lead_paragraph: In Saudi Arabia, women still can’t drive. But they have been recently granted the right to vote and to run in an election. The Times’s Mona El-Naggar takes us inside the ultraconservative kingdom and into the largely inaccessible world of Saudi women.

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: Constance Wu Reads ‘Marry a Man Who Loves His Mother’
abstract: The “Fresh Off the Boat” actress reads the story of a new bride, her judgmental mother-in-law and the husband (and son) who’s caught between them and a war.
lead_paragraph: In this episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the actress Constance Wu reads the essay “Marry a Man Who Loves His Mother,” about a mother and daughter-in-law whose grief brings them closer together.

headline: Brexit, Syria, Thai King: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
