lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin laid the groundwork this week for a possible shake-up of Russian sports leadership in the wake of a doping controversy that has implicated government officials.

headline: Fed Minutes See Rate Rise ‘Relatively Soon’
abstract: The case for a rate increase had “strengthened,” the Fed said, but it tempered that by saying it would be contingent on their outlook being correct.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve expects to increase its benchmark interest rate “relatively soon” if the economy continues to advance at a reasonable pace, according to an account published Wednesday of the bank’s most recent policy meeting.

headline: What Do You Think of Our New Site?
abstract: Take a quick, three-question survey and let us know.
lead_paragraph: What do you think of our new site?

headline: A 44% Pay Divide for Female and Male Law Partners, Survey Says
keywords: ['Legal Profession', 'Executive Compensation', 'Women and Girls', 'Gender', 'Men and Boys', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Male partners either bring in more big cases or get more credit for doing so, according to a survey from a legal research firm.
lead_paragraph: At big American law firms, there is a 44 percent difference in pay between female partners and their male colleagues, largely because men bring in more big-ticket legal cases, or are better at getting credit for doing so.

headline: Snap Is Said to Pick Bankers for an I.P.O.
abstract: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs would help lead the most eagerly awaited new internet stock offering since Twitter.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The newest generation of technology darlings has signaled that it is about to come of age: Snapchat, the messaging service beloved by teenagers, is preparing to step out into the public markets.

headline: Corbin Bleu, on Broadway and Dancing in Fred Astaire’s Footsteps
abstract: The “High School Musical” star straps on his tap shoes for “Holiday Inn,” a new musical take on the 1942 film.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, the actor Corbin Bleu was sifting through some old boxes, assembling materials to make a wedding gift for his fiancée (now his wife). Among the childhood photos, he found a school paper he had written in eighth grade about Fred Astaire. “Every generation to come will watch with open mouths at this amazing artist,” Mr. Bleu’s paper concluded. “To you, Mr. Fred Astaire, I tip my top hat.”

headline: Review: Christine Ebersole Has a Soundtrack for Starting New Chapters
abstract: The singer explores the options of a woman who suddenly finds her nest empty in “After the Ball” at Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: If it hadn’t already been taken, an alternate title for Christine Ebersole’s wonderful new show, her first engagement at Café Carlyle in four years, might be “The New Adventures of Old Christine.” It’s actually called “After the Ball,” from Charles K. Harris’s late-19th-century waltz, a blockbuster in its time and a perfect selection for a singer like Ms. Ebersole, who, as she showed on Tuesday night, has an affinity for operetta.

headline: Shouldn’t You Suit Up?
abstract: The spring runways reiterated the importance of owning a good suit. Here is how to get the look now, styled with some flair.
lead_paragraph: The spring runways reiterated the importance of owning a good suit. Here is how to get the look now, styled with some flair.

headline: Remembering Andrzej Wajda, Unflinching Observer of Modern Poland
abstract: Mr. Wajda, who died on Oct. 9, was a people’s artist in a manner that his native country’s former rulers could not have anticipated or suppressed.
lead_paragraph: Andrzej Wajda, who died this week at age 90, was Poland’s greatest filmmaker, as well as a union activist, a supporter of dissidents and for a time a senator, but he was something more.

headline: Even Punks Learn Regret. ‘Cody’ Is Joyce Manor’s Take on Aging
abstract: The pop-punk group’s fourth album tells stories about the gap between immaturity and the first steps beyond it.
lead_paragraph: Anxiety about aging courses inexorably through “Cody,” the fourth album by the sterling pop-punk group Joyce Manor, taking on many forms along the way: acknowledgment of the gap between what you like and what the kids like, acceptance that growing older does not always come with actual personal evolution, recognition that the exuberance of youth was just a performance, and so many more.

headline: It’s Almost Tax Day Again, for Those Who Postponed
abstract: With only a few exceptions, Oct. 17 is the deadline for those who requested filing extensions last April.
lead_paragraph: Attention, tax-filing slow pokes: Your time is almost up.

headline: Drug Coupons: Helping a Few at the Expense of Everyone
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Coupons', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Enabling patients to choose more costly alternatives can result in higher premiums, new research finds.
lead_paragraph: When a furor erupted over the rapidly rising price of EpiPens this summer, the drugmaker Mylan offered a solution: a coupon for the expensive drug.

headline: Review: In ‘News of the World,’ Unlikely Companions Bond on a Perilous Journey
abstract: During the Texas winter of 1870, a war veteran who works as a news reader agrees to bring a rescued orphan to San Antonio to find her closest living relatives.
lead_paragraph: Paulette Jiles was a poet before she became a novelist. And it certainly shows. Her new novel, the 2016 National Book Award nominee “News of the World,” has invited comparisons with both Charles Portis’s “True Grit” (because it involves a girl on a long journey with an older man) and John Ford’s film “The Searchers” (because it involves a man’s journey to “rescue” a white girl who has been kidnapped by Indians, and also involves a long journey). But it’s more like Ms. Jiles’s own “Enemy Women,” an exquisitely written Civil War epic about a woman’s long march to find her lover, or any fiction by Ron Rash, another poet who chooses each word with expert precision.

headline: The Oldest Bird Voice Box Ever Found
abstract: A researcher’s lucky discovery of a fossilized vocal organ offers new insights into sounds heard when dinosaurs ruled the world.
lead_paragraph: The Jurassic Park movies portrayed a prehistoric soundscape filled with brachiosaurus bellows, velociraptor shrieks and Tyrannosaurus rex roars. But because paleontologists have never found fossilized vocal organs from any of those dinosaurs, we don’t really know what their world sounded like.

headline: Review: ‘The Dudleys’: Dad’s in Control. From Beyond the Grave.
abstract: In Leegrid Stevens’s play, a dead, zombielike father plays on as his squabbling family surveys its present and re-enacts its past against a video-game background.
lead_paragraph: A vintage video game opens a portal into a fractured family’s past in “The Dudleys!,” a meandering, quirky comedy-drama by Leegrid Stevens presented by the Loading Dock Theater. In one corner of the set at HERE Arts Center is squeezed a facsimile of a typical teenager’s bedroom, complete with an old-style tube television and a game console. As the play begins, a character referred to only as the Gamer enters and fires up the controls.

headline: Wells Fargo Chief Abruptly Steps Down
abstract: He has been mired in a scandal involving sham accounts set up by bank employees. The bank’s president will succeed him.
lead_paragraph: The scandal engulfing Wells Fargo toppled its chairman and chief executive on Wednesday, as John G. Stumpf announced his departure from the company, effective immediately.

headline: Review: ‘Mascots’ Suffers From Mockumentary Fatigue Syndrome
abstract: Christopher Guest’s latest movie is fun, and features many of his usual suspects, but it isn’t as sharp as his previous films.
lead_paragraph: The clearest indication of artistic fatigue in Christopher Guest’s new mockumentary, “Mascots,” is the reappearance of the irrepressible Corky St. Clair. You may remember Corky, who was introduced in Mr. Guest’s film “Waiting for Guffman” (1997). A hyper-effusive, Broadway-besotted stage director with stereotypical gay mannerisms and delusions of artistic grandeur, he was in charge of a tacky community theater pageant in Blaine, Mo., celebrating the town’s sesquicentennial.

headline: Lil Wayne’s Album Is Stalled. His Opinions Are Still Flowing.
abstract: The rapper sits down to discuss his frustrations with his label, his guest appearances on others’ records and his aversion to political causes.
lead_paragraph: Lil Wayne, known for his relentless forward progress, is in something of a holding pattern. It’s not by choice.

headline: Afghan Forces, Their Numbers Dwindling Sharply, Face a Resurgent Taliban
abstract: A massacre of at least 100 police officers and soldiers on Tuesday, among the worst in a forgotten war, hits forces already demoralized and struggling to fill their ranks.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Outgunned and surrounded by Taliban fighters in a chronic combat zone of southern Afghanistan, the police officers and soldiers thought they had negotiated passage to safety. They had walked into a trap.

headline: A Slew of Store Parties to Hit Up in SoHo
abstract: The Proenza Schouler designers and Virgil Abloh visit Bergdorf Goodman, Outdoor Voices opens in SoHo, Warby Parker debuts new cat-eye frames, and more.
lead_paragraph: Canal Street Market, a new food hall and multivendor retail space, opens on Nov. 3. It will include Yori Nori, a new restaurant concept from the owners of the Korean taco truck Korilla and the Chelsea Market ramen shop Mokbar; more than 27 artist and brand booths, including Fox Fodder Farm Flowers; and a newsstand curated by Office Magazine. At 265 Canal Street.

headline: The Director of La Scala Ballet Resigns After Eight Months
abstract: Mauro Bigonzetti has left the company, citing health problems, after an increasing public rift with the dancers.
lead_paragraph: “That didn’t take long,” commented one Twitter observer of Mauro Bigonzetti’s resignation as director of La Scala Ballet just eight months after taking up the position. Mr. Bigonzetti’s departure, announced on Saturday by La Scala, was attributed to a severe back problem that he has had since early summer. The managing director of La Scala, Alexander Pereira, has appointed Fréderic Olivieri, a former director of the ballet company who is currently the head of La Scala’s dance school, as an interim director until February next year. Mr. Bigonzetti’s version of “Coppelia,” set to have its premiere at La Scala on Dec. 20, has been canceled. Another choreographer for the production will be announced next week, the theater said.

headline: U.S. Ship Off Yemen Fires Missiles at Houthi Rebel Sites
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: The strikes are the first time the United States has directly attacked Yemen’s Houthi rebels, who are fighting the Yemeni government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American warship stationed off the coast of Yemen fired cruise missiles on Thursday at radar installations that the Pentagon said had been used by Yemeni insurgents to target another American warship in two missile attacks in the last four days.

headline: ‘His Hands Were All Over Me’
abstract: Jessica Leeds, a businesswoman at a paper company, was sitting next to Donald J. Trump on a flight to New York in the early 1980s. She told The Times that he lifted the armrest and began to grope her.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Leeds, a businesswoman at a paper company, was sitting next to Donald J. Trump on a flight to New York in the early 1980s. She told The Times that he lifted the armrest and began to grope her.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']

lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump was emphatic in the second presidential debate: Yes, he had boasted about kissing women without permission and grabbing their genitals. But he had never actually done those things, he said.

headline: U.N. Picks Powerful Feminist (Wonder Woman) for Visible Job (Mascot)
abstract: The United Nations, which recently rejected seven female candidates vying to lead it, said it would appoint Wonder Woman as an honorary ambassador.

headline: WikiLeaks Emails Show Mayor de Blasio Venting at and Appealing to Clinton Campaign
abstract: The release of a second batch of John D. Podesta’s emails shows Bill de Blasio urging the campaign to engage left-wing Democrats.
lead_paragraph: The emails came morning and night, apparently unsolicited, often from the mayoral BlackBerry: messages from Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, who styled himself as an emissary from the liberal left, to a presidential campaign trying to elect Hillary Clinton in what felt like a Bernie Sanders world.

headline: Donald Trump’s Scary Election Day Gambit
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Minorities', 'Editorials', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: His warning of a stolen election sounds like an invitation to harass and intimidate minority voters.
lead_paragraph: “We have to make sure that this election is not stolen from us,” Donald Trump told an audience in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., on Monday.

headline: New York Colleges Unite for a Day, Hoping to Revive a Bygone Era
abstract: Eight midmajor schools from the area held a combined event for the news media, seeking more attention in a saturated sports market.
lead_paragraph: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. — Stony Brook’s Lucas Woodhouse enjoys studying 19th- and 20th-century United States history. Yunus Hopkinson of St. Francis is a fan of the soliloquies spun by the rapper Tory Lanez. Manhattan College’s Zavier Turner, originally from Indianapolis, said his “welcome to New York” moment came when he went out for a slice of pizza and encountered a rat the size of a cat.

abstract: When a subway rider’s shopping bag gets stuck in the closing doors, she thinks her latest purchase is gone for good.

headline: Florida Voter Registration Deadline Is Extended, a Win for Democrats
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms']
abstract: A federal judge ordered the deadline extended to Oct. 18 because of Hurricane Matthew, siding with voting rights advocates and the state Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has extended Florida’s voter registration deadline to Oct. 18, agreeing with voting rights advocates and the state Democratic Party that damage from Hurricane Matthew threatened to deprive some residents of their right to cast a ballot.

headline: Syrian Refugee in German Terror Case Kills Himself in Jail
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Jaber al-Bakr, 22, took his own life in a jail cell in Leipzig, where he had been taken after being arrested on suspicion of planning an imminent attack.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A 22-year-old Syrian who the authorities said planned an imminent terrorist attack in Germany but was detained by fellow refugees committed suicide in a jail cell on Wednesday evening.

headline: For John Stumpf, the Buck Stopped Where It Should Have
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']

headline: Donald Trump’s Toxic Masculinity
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Men and Boys', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: His offensive macho posture clicks with men who hear in him an echo of their own desperation.
lead_paragraph: STATESBORO, Ga. — Growing up in a factory family in small-town Indiana, I led an uncertain life with only a few constants: fear of losing it all, frustration with a world out of our control and the ever-present need to “be a man,” a phrase that always carried with it an air of responsibility and torment. To be a man was to maintain the appearance of toughness, to never let on that you were weak or in pain.

The news this month that another N.S.A. contract employee, Harold Martin III, removed a large volume of classified information from the agency shows that the government is still struggling to keep its secrets safe.

headline: Life in the Heart of New York’s L.G.B.T. Latino Community
abstract: From the backstage sanctuary at a drag club to defiant protests on the street, Joana Toro has documented life along La Roosevelt, the center of New York’s Latino L.G.B.T. community.
lead_paragraph: Roosevelt Avenue, in Jackson Heights, Queens, reminds my boyfriend of El Salvador, where he grew up. It reminds our friend Danny of where he grew up, in Mexico. And others of Colombia or Guatemala. That’s fitting, because it’s one of the vibrant centers of Latino culture in New York. A walk down La Roosevelt, as some call it, means taco trucks on every block, norteño and bachata music wailing from the pollo asado joints and barber shops that never close, and Spanish everywhere.

headline: A Misguided Attack on Charter Schools

lead_paragraph: The N.A.A.C.P., the nation’s oldest civil rights organization, has struggled in recent years to win over younger African-Americans, who often see the group as out of touch. The N.A.A.C.P.’s board will reinforce that impression if it ratifies an ill-advised resolution — scheduled for a vote this weekend — that calls for a moratorium on expansion of public charter schools, which receive public money but are subject to fewer state regulations than traditional public schools.

headline: The Obsession With Panda Sex
abstract: Why charismatic megafauna make the best salesmen for protecting the environment.
lead_paragraph: It is really no mystery why the giant panda’s puritanical sex life attracts lots of attention. The bear is amazingly cute, its numbers are perilously low, and it’s fun to read (and write) about the extraordinary efforts of zookeepers and scientists to fan the creatures’ passions in the inexplicably tiny annual window of opportunity — one to three days — that nature has allotted for generative panda lovemaking. Among the tricks resourceful humans have tried, according to a recent report in The Times, is “panda porn” — videos of pandas making love that male pandas watch in the privacy of their cages.

headline: The Professor Wore a Hijab in Solidarity — Then Lost Her Job
abstract: When Larycia Hawkins, the first black woman to receive tenure at Wheaton College, made a symbolic gesture of support for Muslims, the evangelical college became divided over what intellectual freedom on its campus really meant.
lead_paragraph: Three days after Larycia Hawkins agreed to step down from her job at Wheaton College, an evangelical school in Wheaton, Ill., she joined her former colleagues and students for what was billed as a private service of reconciliation. It was a frigid Tuesday evening last February, and attendance was optional, but Wheaton’s largest chapel was nearly full by the time the event began. A large cross had been placed on the stage, surrounded by tea lights that snaked across the blond floorboards in glowing trails.

The second involves a certain analytical distance, as the writer — wryly, perhaps, or with amusement — watches his younger self coming to terms with a society and an era, subjecting this immature version to the same meticulous scrutiny as the epoch in which he was raised.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Craps
abstract: Becoming hooked, by one throw of the dice.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of people live in Las Vegas, but few of them are actually from Las Vegas, and as a result Las Vegans don’t have much in the way of a regional identity — no accent, no slang, not even a foodstuff of local provenance to call our own. A lone exception to this rule might be the city’s shadow motto: “This town wasn’t built on winners.” The reminders are everywhere. You grow up seeing slots and video poker in grocery stores, pharmacies, gas stations, airports. Billboards advertising single-deck blackjack and sporting books pepper I-15, the city’s main artery. You see the desert clouds go purple on those rare rainy nights, their fluffy undercarriages lit by the city’s neon crown. And you grow up knowing: Don’t. Ever. Gamble. So I didn’t.

headline: A Legend of the International Culture Scene Makes His Mark on New York
abstract: Pierre Audi, the Park Avenue Armory’s new artistic director, is also directing new production Rossini’s “Guillaume Tell” at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Audi, the new artistic director of the Park Avenue Armory and the director of a production of Rossini’s “Guillaume Tell” that opens at the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday, Oct. 18, entered the Armory’s lobby on a recent afternoon. He blinked, hesitating. A group of young boys dressed in old-fashioned regimental uniforms tramped up a staircase and strode purposefully toward him, wooden rifles slung over their shoulders. With a smart left turn, they marched down the wood-paneled corridor.

headline: Five Places to Go in Milan
abstract: Isola used to be home to blue-collar workers and mobsters, and felt removed from Milan. It’s now home to Google in Italy, and is seen as radical chic.
lead_paragraph: Blue-collar workers and mobsters used to live side by side in Isola, or Island, the Milanese neighborhood that once felt removed from the city, separated by rail tracks and river boundaries. Just north of Milan’s historical center, the area today is seen by locals as radical chic and is home to Google’s Italian headquarters. Its mishmash of 19th-century Art Nouveau buildings with wrought-iron balconies next to high-rise towers, built for Expo 2015, the six-month-long world’s fair hosted by Milan, is the perfect expression of the alternative vibe that now defines Isola.

abstract: In an unusual meeting, the Chinese president said the Communist Party must take a greater role in the boardroom — despite earlier pledges toward reform.

headline: 21 Girls Kidnapped From Chibok School Released by Boko Haram, Nigeria Says

headline: Bhumibol Adulyadej, 88, People’s King of Thailand, Dies After 7-Decade Reign
abstract: The king, one of history’s longest-reigning monarchs, was a unifying figure in a deeply polarized country.
lead_paragraph: King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand, who took the throne of the kingdom once known as Siam shortly after World War II and held it for more than 70 years, establishing himself as a revered personification of Thai nationhood, died on Thursday in Bangkok. He was 88 and one of the longest-reigning monarchs in history.

headline: What the Death of Thailand’s King Means, and What’s Next

headline: Bollywood Goes to War

headline: Russia Is Vital to Protecting Antarctica’s Ross Sea
keywords: ['Oceans and Seas', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: A multinational effort to create a protective reserve in the Ross Sea off Antarctica has long been blocked by Russia. This year may be different.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica — The key to protecting Antarctica’s Ross Sea may well lie with Russia. On Monday the Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources, comprising 24 nations and the European Union, will discuss, once again, the creation of a large, marine protected area in the Southern Ocean. All but one of the commission members has supported safeguarding this vital region and its threatened inhabitants. The holdout has been Russia, which has blocked similar efforts in recent years.

In her mile-high heels and similarly elevated hemline, she sticks out like a sore thumb.

headline: When to Step In
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: His friend has a drinking problem; his family is nowhere in sight. Should he call them? A family wedding is too far to attend. What to do? And more.
lead_paragraph: A friend of mine got very drunk and nearly killed himself when he drove his car off the road. When I visited him at the hospital, days later, he was still sedated and hooked up to a number of machines. (His prognosis is good.) The night before the accident, he got his first D.U.I. Clearly, he is an alcoholic. His parents are dead, and his sister lives several states away. May I tell her that he has a drinking problem? I don’t want to tattle, but I’m not sure if she even knows about the accident. I don’t want him to keep drinking and driving, possibly killing himself and others.

headline: A Six-Day Walk Through the Alps, Inspired by Simone de Beauvoir
abstract: The feminist philosopher pursued hiking as intellectual enlightenment. In Provence, 77 years later, one writer retraces her steps.
lead_paragraph: Simone de Beauvoir started hiking in 1931, when she was in her early 20s and assigned to Marseille to teach secondary school. She wrote in her memoir “The Prime of Life” that she at first viewed her post with dread. It was 482 miles from Paris, from her friends and from Jean-Paul Sartre, her lover. But she was surprised that she liked the city, “the smell of tar and dead sea urchins down at the Old Port” and “the clattering trams, with their grapelike clusters of passengers hanging on outside.” And then she found an obsession, hiking, “transforming my exile into a holiday.”

abstract: Finally coming to terms with the enormity of its TB problem, India is preparing a radical overhaul and expansion of its national treatment program.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Finally coming to terms with the enormity of its tuberculosis problem, India is preparing a radical overhaul and expansion of its national treatment program to fight an affliction that kills more adults worldwide than any other infectious disease.

headline: Boston University Won’t Celebrate Yet (the Season Just Started)
abstract: The men’s hockey team has 11 players drafted by the N.H.L., but Coach David Quinn knows how easily a sure thing can be derailed.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — As the college hockey season enters its second weekend, Boston University Coach David Quinn is itching to learn the answer to a question: Are his players listening to him, or are they listening to the hype?

headline: One Day, Cars Will Connect With Your Fridge and Your Heartbeat
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Cars that direct drivers to appointments and stores — or even monitor the driver’s health — are coming, experts say.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Bruce Wayne rolled up to his Bat Cave, a roadblock dropped automatically, the camouflaged garage door swung open, the lights flickered on and Alfred was already standing by.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad; Andrew Rosenthal on the News
abstract: The columnist Andrew Rosenthal on Donald J. Trump, The Times’s series on the long-term mental health effects of U.S. interrogation tactics, and other news.
lead_paragraph: The columnist Andrew Rosenthal on Donald J. Trump, The Times’s series on the long-term mental health effects of U.S. interrogation tactics, and other news.

headline: The New York Times’s Lawyer Responds to Donald Trump
abstract: This is the letter David McCraw, vice president and assistant general counsel of The New York Times, wrote in response to a request from Marc E. Kasowitz, Mr. Trump's lawyer, to retract an article that featured two women accusing Mr. Trump of touching them inappropriately years ago, and issue an apology.
lead_paragraph: This is the letter David McCraw, vice president and assistant general counsel of The New York Times, wrote in response to a request from Marc E. Kasowitz, Mr. Trump's lawyer, to retract an article that featured two women accusing Mr. Trump of touching them inappropriately years ago, and issue an apology.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
abstract: The columnist Andrew Rosenthal on Donald J. Trump, The Times’s series on the long-term mental health effects of U.S. interrogation tactics, and other news.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, Andrew Rosenthal, a Times Op-Ed columnist, talks about the news — the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.

headline: World Cup Could Expand After FIFA Vote in January
abstract: FIFA’s president, Gianni Infantino, has pushed to expand the field to as many as 48 nations from its current size of 32.
lead_paragraph: FIFA, world soccer’s governing body, is expected to decide in January whether to expand the World Cup finals from a 32-team tournament to include as many as 48 countries, the organization’s president, Gianni Infantino, said Thursday.

headline: One Photographer’s (Calmer, Quieter) Imagined New York City
abstract: Marc Yankus manipulates his images — removing people, skewing angles, distorting light and color — to create a “peaceful, dreamlike” vision of the city.
lead_paragraph: Marc Yankus manipulates his images — removing people, skewing angles, distorting light and color — to create a “peaceful, dreamlike” vision of the city.

headline: Dutch Law Would Allow Assisted Suicide for Healthy Older People
abstract: Proponents say there are valid reasons besides terminal illness to choose to die, among them loss of independence, deterioration and loneliness.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the Netherlands, a country vaunted for its liberalism, a proposal to legalize assisted suicide for older people who are generally healthy but feel they have led a full life has stirred up an ethical storm in some quarters.

headline: Bombing Suspect Pleads Not Guilty in Shootout With New Jersey Officers
abstract: Ahmad Khan Rahami, 28, who is accused in explosions in Manhattan and New Jersey, appeared in court via video conference from his hospital bed.
lead_paragraph: ELIZABETH, N.J. — More than three weeks after the bombings in New York City and at the Jersey Shore, the man accused in the attacks pleaded not guilty on Thursday to charges relating to the attempted murder of police officers.

headline: A Grateful Hungarian Refugee
abstract: One such refugee writes to thank the West for providing shelter.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cecily Brown’s Repeated Images Tell a Story About Drawing
abstract: This artist’s influences include William Hogarth’s debauchery and internet pornography.
lead_paragraph: The London-born painter Cecily Brown is known for stormy, intensely colored canvases, usually abstract, which depend for their effect not on any overall argument or scheme but on a sheer profusion of rapid, discontinuous strokes.

headline: Landmarks Commission O.K.’s Natural History Museum’s Science Center
abstract: The New York City commission has approved the $325 million Richard Gilder Center for Science, Education and Innovation, designed by Studio Gang.
lead_paragraph: The American Museum of Natural History’s proposal to build a new science center has been approved by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission. The plan initially stirred controversy among area residents but received unanimous support from the commission at a hearing on Tuesday and the museum intends to open the building in 2020.

headline: All Things Agnes Martin at the Guggenheim
abstract: Behind the scenes, reshaping a London show in New York.
lead_paragraph: True, the Agnes Martin retrospective that opened at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum last week originated at the Tate Modern in London and traveled to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen in Düsseldorf.

headline: Review: In ‘Haters Back Off!’ a Cringe-Worthy Star Is Born
abstract: A critic recommends a sort of reverse binge-watching: taking in tiny bites at a sitting, with frequent breaks.
lead_paragraph: Netflix helped popularize the binge-watch. With “Haters Back Off!,” which begins streaming on Friday, it introduces the cringe-watch.

headline: Trump Versus Twitter
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Sex Crimes', 'Social Media', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Mr. Trump’s descriptions of sexual assault — and new allegations against him — have inspired inventive social-media responses.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump and his advisors have spent much of the last week peddling weak excuses for Mr. Trump’s offensive comments about women on a 2005 tape. But defenses of Mr. Trump’s descriptions of sexual assault have fueled more outrage — and inspired inventive social-media responses.

headline: Dylan Onstage and in the Studio
abstract: Bob Dylan performed and recorded legendary songs over the decades.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan performed and recorded legendary songs over the decades.

headline: Klimt’s Women, Real and on Canvas
abstract: A show at the Neue Galerie, “Klimt and the Women of Vienna’s Golden Age, 1900-1918,” delves into a complex topic.
lead_paragraph: Among the most controversial issues roiling fin-de-siècle Vienna was “Die Frauenfrage,” or “the woman question.” As they were doing in many other cities and nations of Europe and North America, women were challenging a patriarchal society that judged them unworthy of the rights customarily accorded to men.

headline: Clash of the Cosmetics Titans: ‘War Paint‘ Is Coming to Broadway
abstract: Patti LuPone and Christine Ebersole are to star in the musical, which is to start previews on March 7 at the Nederlander Theater.
lead_paragraph: They were famous, they were successful, and they were archrivals.

headline: Thai King, Duterte, Bob Dylan: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Twain and Stowe Homes Being Renovated for Historical Accuracy
abstract: Harriet Beecher Stowe had a shopping problem, but managed to keep her house. Mark Twain made bad investments and had to rent out his home next door.
lead_paragraph: Harriet Beecher Stowe and Mark Twain lived on adjoining properties in Hartford, and they each agonized over decorating choices and related expenses. The two expansive brick homes, built in the early 1870s on a hillside near the leafy grounds of a mental hospital, were turned into museums decades ago, and the curators keep updating the décor in pursuit of greater historical accuracy. Rooms at both sites are being restored, and the artifacts going on view convey how Stowe and Twain created peaceful hide-outs for writing.

headline: And a Little Child Shall Lead Them (at Least at This Museum)
abstract: The Children’s Museum of Manhattan has opened “I Approve This Message,” a show about the presidency that invites little visitors to play commander in chief.
lead_paragraph: In one of the country’s most fraught, contentious and bitterly polarizing presidential election years, it’s hard to imagine a situation in which the person about to enter the Oval Office inspires unequivocal support.

headline: Review: ‘Ordinary World’ Puts Billie Joe Armstrong in the Bland Lane
abstract: The Green Day frontman plays an ex-punk rocker who is having trouble accepting a run-of-the-mill existence.
lead_paragraph: Billie Joe Armstrong of Green Day is usually pretty appealing when he dabbles in acting, and he’s appealing again in “Ordinary World.” But after a promising start the script lets him down, and the film turns into a predictable midlife-crisis yarn.

headline: Review: Fireworks in ‘Sky Ladder: The Art of Cai Guo-Qiang’
abstract: Kevin Macdonald’s documentary follows the Chinese artist as he tries to realize his 20-year dream of creating an incendiary ladder to the skies.
lead_paragraph: Some of Cai Guo-Qiang’s art exists for mere moments. But my, how long it sticks in the mind. That enchantment is at the center of “Sky Ladder: The Art of Cai Guo-Qiang,” a documentary that is as rewarding as this artist’s work.

headline: Review: In ‘Miss Hokusai,’ an Apprentice to the Artistic Life
abstract: This extraordinary film is a lively inquiry into the life of the daughter of the 19th-century Japanese painter Katsushika Hokusai.
lead_paragraph: Japanese animated film practically teems with plucky, inventive girls, but pictures depicting emotionally credible young women are relatively rare. That “Miss Hokusai” does this very thing, and does it beautifully, is only one of the extraordinary things about it.

headline: Bacteria on Device Said to Infect at Least 12 Patients in Pennsylvania
abstract: A C.D.C. inquiry found that a machine used in open-heart surgery at a hospital was probably tainted at the plant in Germany where it was made.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A device used during open-heart surgery that infected at least 12 patients at a Pennsylvania hospital last year was probably tainted at the plant in Germany where it was made, a federal investigation has found.

headline: Step Inside a Satirical Haunted House
abstract: Pedro Reyes’s “Doomocracy” is a mobile drama with rapid pacing, where visitors encounter a variety of fright-inducing short acts.
lead_paragraph: Pedro Reyes’s “Doomocracy” is a mobile drama with rapid pacing, where visitors encounter a variety of fright-inducing short acts.

headline: At ‘Doomocracy,’ It’s Fright Night in Brooklyn
abstract: You know that Pedro Reyes’s political house of horrors in the Brooklyn Army Terminal is theater, but some acts make your pulse jump and disarm your defenses.
lead_paragraph: Halloween started early this year. I’d put the date at July 18, opening night of the 2016 Republican National Convention. Trick-or-treating has been nonstop since. The tricks have included a couple of Creature Feature debates, email scandals, xenophobic rants and personal attacks, all of which have too often been received as sordid but tantalizing treats by audience and news media alike.

headline: 7 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading by book critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: It’s literary award season and publishers are rushing out editions of books that have been longlisted and shortlisted for the season’s prizes. Two of the books on our list of recommendations this week fit that category: David Szalay’s “All That Man Is” is on the shortlist for the Man Booker Prize; the winner will be announced Oct. 25. And Cathy O’Neil’s “Weapons of Math Destruction” was longlisted for the National Book Award in nonfiction. It didn’t make the final cut for the shortlist — but we still like it.

headline: Review: ‘Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise,’ a Life Well Lived
abstract: Photographs and film footage, as well as interviews with her son and artists who worked with her, add another dimension this documentary of a storied life.
lead_paragraph: “Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise” covers so much ground that it’s usually easy to forgive the filmmakers for not digging deeper. This is a documentary interested in breadth rather than depth, and on those terms it succeeds.

headline: Review: In ‘Little Sister,’ an Aspiring Nun With a Love of Goth Visits Her Troubled Family
abstract: The atmosphere can be oppressive in this story of a dysfunctional family, but it’s countered with humor and empathy for each broken character.
lead_paragraph: A strange, spiky movie that refuses to beg for our affection, “Little Sister,” the fifth feature from Zach Clark, molds the classic homecoming drama into a quirky reconciliation between faith and family.

headline: Review: The Anti-Clinton Brigade’s Four-Letter Word Obsession
abstract: Edward Klein’s “Guilty as Sin,” Gary J. Byrne’s “Crisis of Character” and other books suggest that Hillary Clinton curses like a sailor. And they take umbrage.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been bingeing on a lot of anti-Hillary Clinton books lately. Some of their gripes are legitimate and verifiable; some are halfway down the six-lane expressway to bonkersville. But of all the unlikely themes to emerge from them, of all the conspiracies they propose and the outrages they cite, the strangest of all is quite straightforward: that Mrs. Clinton is a potty mouth.

headline: Review: For ‘Jack Goes Home,’ Cue the Horror Soundtrack
abstract: Rory Culkin plays a magazine editor who returns to his hometown after his father is killed in a car crash, and delves into a past that’s deeply troubled.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Dekker’s chiller “Jack Goes Home” gets off to a fine start. Rory Culkin plays Jack Duncan, a magazine editor looking forward to the birth of his child with his pregnant fiancée (Britt Robertson). But when he learns that a car crash has claimed the life of his father, and that his mother has survived, the neutral, unemotional tones with which he announces the news suggest that something in his past is deeply amiss.

headline: Review: ‘Huntwatch’ Chronicles a Hard-Fought Battle to Protect Seals
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Seals (Animals) and Sealing', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Movies']
abstract: This film, one-sided in its approach, offers painful footage of the bludgeoning of pups in charting the decades-old movement against seal hunting.
lead_paragraph: Experienced seal hunters can club and skin a pup in just 30 seconds, according to the documentary “Huntwatch,” and Brian Davies has spent close to a half-century trying to slow them down. Born in Wales but destined for the vast snowscapes of the Canadian Atlantic coastline, Mr. Davies, founder of the International Fund for Animal Welfare (“Awful name,” he says, grimacing), seems loath to believe that his fight might be unwinnable.

headline: Review: Stranded Migrants Are Easy Marks for a Madman in ‘Desierto’
abstract: Lots of carnage and only a little back story equal a grim movie.
lead_paragraph: Jonás Cuarón and his cinematographer, Damian Garcia, make the desert look bleakly beautiful in “Desierto,” right from the opening landscape shot. But there’s nothing beautiful about the story the film tells, and nothing redeeming, either.

headline: Review: In ‘The David Dance,’ a Gay Man Sheds His Crippling Self-Doubt
abstract: Troubled by insecurity, the host of a radio show opens his heart to love, and slowly begins to accept himself for who he is.
lead_paragraph: “The David Dance” traces choreography in which a man steps closer to himself, then away; closer to love, then away again. Struggling with insecurity, David (Don Scimé) usually retreats from commitment. But on the airwaves, as the host of a gay radio show in Buffalo, he finds a clear, brave voice.

headline: What to See in New York Galleries This Week
abstract: Charles LeDray, Lillian Schwartz, Hans-Peter Feldmann and a group of artists whose works are based on Fritz Lang’s film “Scarlet Street” are among the new exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: Craig F. Starr Gallery5 East 73rd Street, ManhattanThrough Oct. 29

headline: Bob Dylan, Master of Change
abstract: “I’m a poet, I know it, hope I don’t blow it,” he once sang. He hasn’t.
lead_paragraph: The hero of Don DeLillo’s 1973 novel, “Great Jones Street,” Bucky Wunderlick, is a wildly famous musician so transparently inspired by Bob Dylan that it is a wonder the author was able to make the figure into his own character. Bucky — part prophet, part fraud — is hounded into seclusion by fans, hustlers, gangsters and the world at large. I had a hunch Mr. DeLillo would win the Nobel Prize for Literature this year; he can’t be surprised Bob Dylan did.

headline: Review: A Crooked Cop Is Caught Between 2 Brutal Masters in ‘Asura: The City of Madness’
abstract: This film offers diversion but not sociological scope. Blood flows freely.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean thriller “Asura: The City of Madness,” directed by Kim Sung-soo, is a tale of gangland loyalty distinguished mainly by its unrelenting cynicism. In the fictional city of Annam, where nearly everyone is on the take, Han (Jung Woo-sung), a detective, casts his lot with the corrupt mayor, Park Sungbae (Hwang Jung-min), who wields violence without mercy from behind a dignified, bespectacled facade.

headline: Review: ‘Coming Through the Rye’ Tracks Down J.D. Salinger
abstract: The film, written and directed by James Sadwith, is a fictionalized version of Mr. Sadwith’s meeting with J.D. Salinger.
lead_paragraph: With the glossy “Coming Through the Rye,” the director James Sadwith pays heartfelt tribute to both J. D. Salinger, the reclusive writer of “The Catcher in the Rye,” who died in 2010, and the book itself. He also affectionately fictionalizes his own past (he wrote the script), drawing from his actual meeting in adolescence with Mr. Salinger.

headline: Distant Ringed Object Could Be ‘Saturn on Steroids’
abstract: A potential planet detected by astronomers probably has rings that spin in the opposite direction of the object’s spin around its sun.
lead_paragraph: About 400 light years from our solar system, there is a celestial body that looks like Saturn on steroids.

headline: New York City Ballet’s Fall Season Bursts With Talent
abstract: Our critic reflects on the latest season of this company, which may be “heading for a period when it has more talent than it can comfortably present.”
lead_paragraph: New York City Ballet’s four-week fall season, which ends on Sunday, has belonged primarily to its music director, Andrew Litton. New last year, he has now committed himself to conducting the company’s central repertory of ballets by George Balanchine: familiar scores have returned with new immediacy. Details of orchestral phrasing have registered keenly, with a wealth of color; he gives many scores a strong pulse. For years, the best orchestral playing in American ballet has belonged outside New York; but this may well now be changing.

headline: Review: ‘Certain Women’ Are Worlds Unto Themselves
abstract: Kelly Reichardt’s film centers on a collection of women in a small town, and their individual tensions, sorrow and longing.
lead_paragraph: Though not technically a western, Kelly Reichardt’s “Certain Women” takes place in a region of broad skies, rocky landscapes and pent-up feelings. Human beings are sparse, and words are even scarcer. But Ms. Reichardt, a transplanted Easterner based in Portland, Ore., is a poet of silences and open spaces, and her plain-looking, taciturn films have their own kind of eloquence, the specific gravity of rare minerals.

headline: Bob Dylan, Donald Trump, Michelle Obama: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: In ‘Christine,’ Why Did She Pull the Trigger? We Don’t Know
abstract: In this dramatization of a true story, Rebecca Hall is riveting as Christine Chubbuck, a television news reporter who killed herself on the air.
lead_paragraph: Every so often, an actor takes possession of a role so thoroughly — turning each line, flickering look and gesture into an expression of being — that she becomes your way into the movie as well as the reason you keep watching. That’s the case with Rebecca Hall, the star of “Christine,” a period drama about a television reporter, Christine Chubbuck, that plays more like an autopsy than like a biopic. In 1974 Ms. Chubbuck shot herself on the air, possibly becoming the first person to commit suicide on live TV. The ancient Romans had the Colosseum; we have television.

headline: Review: In ‘Aquarius,’ a Widow Fights to Keep Her Home
abstract: A free spirit is tangled up in the political forces paralleling modern-day Brazil in this work from Kleber Mendonça Filho.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy enough to say what makes an apartment a home — fond memories, shelves full of cherished books and records, a heap of living — but it’s harder to specify what makes a home a metaphor. Kleber Mendonça Filho’s new film, “Aquarius,” takes place mostly in and around the apartment where its heroine, a 65-year-old music critic named Clara, has lived for much of her adult life. Its rooms are spacious and sunny (the Atlantic Ocean is right across the street), but an intimation of hidden significance drifts in with the light and the breezes, a hint that Clara’s home might also be a microcosm of modern Brazil.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Oct. 14, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “The Accountant,” “Christine” and “Aquarius.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “The Accountant,” “Christine” and “Aquarius.”

headline: Review: In ‘Goliath,’ Billy Bob Thornton Plays a Down-and-Out David
abstract: In this new legal series for Amazon by David E. Kelley and Jonathan Shapiro, Mr. Thornton portrays a seedy lawyer up against his old firm.
lead_paragraph: In the opening episode of the new Amazon series “Goliath,” Billy Bob Thornton, playing a Los Angeles lawyer who has seen better days, snaps: “I used to handle 20 cases at a time. I think I can handle two.”

headline: An Unlikely N.F.L. Collision Between Protest and Politics
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Football', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'National Anthems']
abstract: One game this weekend features 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick, who protests racial injustice, and Bills Coach Rex Ryan, who has ties to Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — There is the blustery coach who introduced Donald J. Trump at a rally. There is the quarterback whose peaceful pregame protests are the story of the N.F.L. season. There is the Supreme Court justice who called the demonstration “dumb” and “disrespectful.” And there is the smart, thoughtful, relevant reference to the scientific discourse of pathology (from, in case you were wondering, the quarterback).

headline: Sleaze Is No Disqualifier
abstract: Donald Trump’s comments about women won’t cost him the support of Gov. Paul LePage of Maine.
lead_paragraph: Paul LePage, the bombastic governor of Maine, will have no trouble casting his vote for Donald Trump in November. Though he concedes Mr. Trump may be a “slimeball,” he celebrates the candidate’s potential as an “authoritarian” ruler of the nation.

headline: Theater Listings for Oct. 14-20
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: ‘Carrie’ Is Back. Like a Bloody Hand From the Grave.
abstract: Brian De Palma’s “Carrie” (1976) is out on Blu-ray. It may not seem as scary today, but it did help the careers of Mr. De Palma and Stephen King.
lead_paragraph: Released a few days after Halloween in 1976, it’s considered one of the great American horror films. A box-office hit with two Oscar nominations for acting, it contains one of the genre’s most memorable images and an ending that has been ripped off dozens of times.

headline: Movie Listings for Oct. 14-20
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.
lead_paragraph: Read reviews of new releases and search our full database of thousands of films at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

headline: Israeli President Hosts Quiet Meeting of Muslim and Jewish Leaders
abstract: The highly unusual meeting was intended, according to organizers, to forge a joint effort against religious violence, and to promote peace and coexistence.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The guests who arrived at the Israeli president’s home on Thursday evening were an eclectic mix. They included the chief Sephardic rabbi of Israel, the president of the Sharia Court of the Palestinian Authority and two rabbis from a West Bank yeshiva.

headline: Classical Music Listings for Oct. 14-20
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

headline: Awarding a Photographer’s ‘Stubbornness’
abstract: Justyna Mielnikiewicz, who taught herself photography by studying the legendary photo essays of W. Eugene Smith, has won the Smith Fund’s 2016 grant in humanistic photography.
lead_paragraph: Justyna Mielnikiewicz, who taught herself photography by studying the legendary photo essays of W. Eugene Smith, has won the Smith Fund’s 2016 grant in humanistic photography.

headline: Awarding a Photographer’s ‘Stubbornness’
abstract: Justyna Mielnikiewicz, who taught herself photography by studying the legendary photo essays of W. Eugene Smith, won the Smith Fund’s 2016 grant in humanistic photography.
lead_paragraph: Justyna Mielnikiewicz, who taught herself photography by studying the legendary photo essays of W. Eugene Smith, has been awarded the W. Eugene Smith Fund’s 2016 grant in humanistic photography. She was recognized for her portrait of modern Russia as seen by Russians who have become ethnic minorities in former Soviet republics.

headline: ‘Lured’ and ‘A Scandal in Paris’: Douglas Sirk’s Costume Capers
abstract: Two of Sirk’s early Hollywood films, now in a two-disc set, reveal a finesse so fine as to be almost invisible.
lead_paragraph: Douglas Sirk was one of the 20th century’s more drastically displaced émigré artists. Born in 1897 to Danish parents living in Hamburg, Germany, he was a European intellectual who began his career directing classic plays in provincial Germany and wound up making florid, wide-screen Hollywood weepies like “Imitation of Life” (1959).

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Oct. 14-20
abstract: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.

headline: Watch Kevin Hart Tell a Joke. See Fans Laugh. At the Movies.
abstract: With Mr. Hart’s latest stand-up concert film arriving, comedians, directors and others talk about what works when taking comedy to the big screen.
lead_paragraph: Before walking onstage at the Terrace Theater in Long Beach, Calif., one December night in 1978 for a performance that would become “Richard Pryor: Live in Concert,” the first full-length stand-up comedy film, Pryor approached the director Jeff Margolis near his dressing room. “Make me look good,” he said. “Make magic.”

abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

lead_paragraph: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

headline: Patricia Barry, Actress on TV Since Its Early Days, Dies at 93
abstract: Ms. Barry’s career’s was dominated by appearances on soap operas and shows like “The Twilight Zone.”
lead_paragraph: Patricia Barry, a prolific television actress who appeared in more than 100 series and movies, beginning in the medium’s earliest days, died on Tuesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 93.

abstract: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: Melissa Mark-Viverito, New York Council Speaker, Reveals She Was Sexually Abused
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: Ms. Mark-Viverito said she was compelled to go public in reaction to a tape of Donald J. Trump boasting about foisting himself on women.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Mark-Viverito, the speaker of the New York City Council, revealed this week that she was the victim of sexual abuse as a child, saying at an emotional news conference that she was compelled to go public in reaction to the video in which Donald J. Trump is heard boasting about foisting himself on women.

abstract: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

headline: Companies Hurt by Treasury Crackdown Win Exemptions
abstract: Part of the Treasury’s goal was to clamp down on earnings stripping. But many multinationals with no history of inversions were affected by the rules as well.
lead_paragraph: After the Treasury Department announced new rules in April restricting companies from using certain tax-reduction strategies, the protests rang out loudly. Business lobbying groups, executives, tax experts and lawmakers argued that they went too far.

headline: Stephen Bollenbach, Who Spared Donald Trump From Personal Bankruptcy, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Bollenbach was long praised for his financial skills, having been the first Hilton Hotels chief executive outside of the Hilton family.
lead_paragraph: Stephen F. Bollenbach, an executive in the hotel industry whose financial skills were credited with sparing Donald J. Trump from having to file for personal bankruptcy, died on Oct. 8 in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: Ivy Hears Me in the Hall
abstract: A poem about a neighbor’s sweet potato pie.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Chappatte on Bob Dylan’s Nobel Prize for Literature
abstract: Maybe writers should aim to be rock stars.
lead_paragraph: Maybe writers should aim to be rock stars.

headline: Poor, Displaced and Anxious in North Carolina as Floods Climb After Hurricane
keywords: ['Floods', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Disasters and Emergencies']
abstract: Despite the start of state and federal aid after Hurricane Matthew, poor residents in shelters faced grim prospects as the water crept higher.
lead_paragraph: KINSTON, N.C. — At a community college turned hurricane shelter, Frednesa Pope, 37, wondered on Wednesday if the floodwaters from Hurricane Matthew, which are expected to crest here on Friday, would force her and her family out of an apartment they could barely afford.

headline: Baby Dies After Fall in Elevator Shaft at Troubled Brooklyn High-Rise
keywords: ['Elevators and Escalators', 'Falls', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Baby Carriages, Strollers and Carriers']
abstract: The tower in Coney Island has been the subject of almost 20 complaints for out-of-service elevators since January 2015, city records show.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of times a day, without a thought, every manner of New Yorker does it: We call an elevator to our floor, step aboard and go on our way.

headline: Prosecutors Rest Case Against 2 Ex-Christie Aides in Lane-Closing Trial
abstract: Jurors were shown testimony that Bill Baroni, a defendant along with Bridget Anne Kelly, gave to the State Legislature months after the lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge were shut.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Federal prosecutors in the George Washington Bridge lane-closing trial rested their case against two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Thursday with the words of the defendants themselves.

headline: Seizing the Moment to Save a Child Under Attack on the Subway
keywords: ['Subways', 'Children and Childhood', 'Assaults', 'Good Samaritans', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Jessamine Irwin, 26, pulled an 11-year-boy to safety as he was being assaulted in the space between train cars.
lead_paragraph: Going from one job to the next, and lulled by the No. 4 train as it rolled from the north Bronx toward Midtown Manhattan, Jessamine Irwin settled into a nap. No, maybe it was more of a doze, a nod toward sleep, a floating out of the present tense.

headline: Bob Dylan and His Poetic Gift
abstract: A look at Bob Dylan's contribution to the world of literature that brought him a Nobel Prize.
lead_paragraph: A look at Bob Dylan's contribution to the world of literature that brought him a Nobel Prize.

headline: Trepidation at City College in Wake of President’s Abrupt Exit
abstract: The resignation of Lisa S. Coico has created a leadership vacuum at the university amid two investigations, with a third looming.
lead_paragraph: When students at the City College of New York, the flagship of the largest urban public university in the country, showed up for classes on Thursday for the first time since an extended holiday break, they returned to a vastly different campus from the one they left last Friday.

headline: Yemen Sees U.S. Strikes as Evidence of Hidden Hand Behind Saudi Air War
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: American support of a Saudi-led coalition has come under greater scrutiny as reports mount of strikes on residential areas, markets, medical facilities and weddings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the United States, it was simple retaliation: Rebels in Yemen had fired missiles at an American warship twice in four days, and so the United States hit back, destroying rebel radar facilities with missiles.

headline: Nick Kyrgios Gives Up, and Tennis Gives Him an Easy Out
abstract: Kyrgios clashed with the umpire and fans during another uninterested performance on Wednesday, but a recent ATP rule change meant he only received a small fine.
lead_paragraph: I am all for giving youngsters time and tolerance as they grow up in the spotlight, but there are limits. At this stage, letting Nick Kyrgios off with a $16,500 fine and another round of outrage for throwing a tennis match is the wrong move for both tennis and for Kyrgios.

headline: Wells Fargo’s New Boss Is Same as the Old Boss to Congress
abstract: Critics were dismissive of Timothy J. Sloan’s ability to shift course, though analysts were inclined to give him the benefit of the doubt.
lead_paragraph: If Wells Fargo’s board had hoped John G. Stumpf’s resignation on Wednesday and the appointment of Timothy J. Sloan as the new top executive would instantly quell the bank’s numerous critics, they were mistaken.

headline: James F. Colaianni, a Theologian Opposed to Priest Celibacy, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Colaianni, who was an editor at Ramparts magazine in the 1960s, also campaigned against the use of napalm during the Vietnam War.
lead_paragraph: James F. Colaianni, a former radical lay theologian and senior editor of Ramparts magazine in the 1960s who crusaded against napalm as a weapon in Vietnam and celibacy as a prerequisite for Roman Catholic priests, died on Oct. 5 at his home in Galloway, N.J. He was 94.

headline: Verizon Says Yahoo Hack Could Reopen $4.8 Billion Deal Talks
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'E-Mail']
abstract: Verizon’s top lawyer said the hacking of 500 million Yahoo email accounts, made public after the deal was announced, could justify reopening sale discussions.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Verizon Communications may seek to renegotiate its $4.8 billion purchase of Yahoo’s operating business, dealing another blow to the struggling internet company.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, October 14, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “The prices are increasing for everything. Only a camel can live without electricity.”

headline: How Dylan Became Dylan
abstract: The Nobel honors an artist who had the ability to absorb a world of music and add his own strange, inexplicable touch.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan’s Nobel Prize in Literature is a blessed relief, a gift of something else to think about, or argue about, that isn’t dire and ugly like the other October surprises the month has thrown at us.

headline: Dr. Yutaka Yoshida, a U.S. War Hero of Japanese Descent, Dies at 104
abstract: Dr. Yoshida, who became a surgeon after earning a Silver Star during World War II, had been a police officer tasked with rounding up Japanese in Hawaii after the attack on Pearl Harbor.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Yutaka Yoshida, a native Hawaiian and a son of Japanese immigrants, was working as a police officer in Honolulu when Japan bombed the United States naval base at Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, plunging America into World War II.

headline: A New Zika Zone in Miami, but No Reason to Panic, Scientists Say
abstract: The announcement of a third zone, involving five cases, was not seen as a sign that the disease was out of control. In fact, as mosquito season winds down, their numbers are dwindling.
lead_paragraph: Florida announced a new Zika transmission zone on Thursday, saying that the virus had popped up in a mile-square patch of northern Miami and that five people had been infected.

headline: For One Fortunate Team, a Waiting Game Nears Its End
abstract: Every team left in the postseason has waited at least a generation since its last World Series triumph.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Washington Nationals fly four flags atop their scoreboard to honor three pennants won by the ancestors of … the Minnesota Twins. In Washington baseball, as in politics, the truth can be opaque.

headline: Cut Ties to Donald Trump, Big Donors Urge R.N.C.
abstract: Fearing damage to the Republican Party’s image, they called on the national committee to back away from the nominee, with one contributor citing “obvious moral failings.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Several of the Republican Party’s most generous donors called on the Republican National Committee on Thursday to disavow Donald J. Trump, saying that allegations by multiple women that Mr. Trump had groped or made inappropriate sexual advances toward them threatened to inflict lasting damage on the party’s image.

headline: After Donald Trump, Will More Women Believe Their Own Stories?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: This week’s wave of claims against the Republican nominee suggest the possibility of a shift in how women think about sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: A week ago, it would have seemed wildly unlikely to most people that Donald J. Trump, not Hillary Clinton, would be the candidate more likely to provoke a culture-wide shift in how we think of and talk about sexual assault. But since the release on Friday of a recording in which Trump essentially admits he has a habit of sexually assaulting women, a series of stories involving the Republican nominee seems to be doing just that.

headline: Ivanka Trump Hits Trail, With No Sign of Campaign Turbulence
abstract: On a stage-managed swing through the Philadelphia suburbs, Ms. Trump avoided mentioning accusations that her father had groped women.
lead_paragraph: IVYLAND, Pa. — When Donald J. Trump is in trouble with women voters, he has often called on his daughter Ivanka, an executive and entrepreneur as smooth as he is rough-hewed, as calming as he is potentially alarming.

headline: Trump Accuses Clinton of Guiding Global Elite Against U.S. Working Class
abstract: The remarks drew criticism from some who said they resembled prejudicial language used by anti-Semites.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump on Thursday accused Hillary Clinton of guiding a “global power structure” that has rigged the economy against the working class, language that some suggested echoed anti-Semitic themes.

headline: Judge Says Disney Didn’t Violate Visa Laws in Layoffs

lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Florida dealt a blow on Thursday to legal claims by American technology workers who were laid off by the Walt Disney Company and forced to train foreign replacements, dismissing lawsuits by two workers who said Disney had conspired with outsourcing companies to violate visa laws.

lead_paragraph: A criminal summons stated that Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey "knowingly refrained" from telling his staff to take action to re-open the closed lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge in 2013.

headline: Joseph L. Birman, Physicist Who Aided Dissident Scientists, Dies at 89
abstract: Dr. Birman was instrumental in the creation of a program that helped refugee scientists restart their careers in the United States in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Joseph L. Birman, a physics professor who was honored for his humanitarian work with scientists facing repression in the former Soviet Union and elsewhere, helping scores of them to come to the United States, died on Oct. 1 in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 89.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — SoftBank of Japan has already earned a reputation as one of the most ambitious technology companies around, unafraid to strike huge deals.

lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This will come as a surprise to regular readers of Wordplay, but many people believe that they are simply not capable of solving a New York Times Crossword.

headline: Review: ‘Heisenberg’ Features an Explosive Pairing of Actors
abstract: The play, making its transfer to Broadway with Mary-Louise Parker and Denis Arndt, finds a potentially psychotic American woman meeting a British butcher.
lead_paragraph: Though the play’s name is that of a theoretical physicist, chemistry — to be pronounced with a sizzling “s” — is the science that first comes to mind as you watch the splendid Broadway debut of Simon Stephens’s “Heisenberg,” which opened on Thursday night at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

headline: Review: In ‘Career Suicide,’ Laughing When It Hurts
abstract: Chris Gethard’s solo show grapples with his uncomfortable if often mordantly funny relationship to depression.
lead_paragraph: There’s New York-neurotic, with which many of us are familiar, ranging from the friend who insists on altering the most anodyne of food offerings, to the more serious cases, the acquaintances who pour forth the most appalling intimacies of their relationships with little filter.

abstract: Chris Kreider, a wily Rangers veteran at 25, had the go-ahead goal and an assist in the teams’ second opening-night meeting since 1972.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers exhibited a discernible air of freshness heading into their season opener against the Islanders at Madison Square Garden. For that matter, so did the visitors.

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Samsung Electronics said on Friday that it expected about $3 billion in operating profits to evaporate over the next two quarters because of its decision to ditch the troubled Galaxy Note 7 smartphone.

headline: Bhumibol, a King of the People, Leaves Them to the Generals
abstract: Democracy never was King Bhumibol’s goal for Thailand. Restoring the traditional influence of the monarchy was.
lead_paragraph: In November 1951, as Bhumibol Adulyadej, 23, was heading back to Thailand to take his throne, a group of generals overthrew the royalist government and stripped the Constitution of the substantial powers it accorded the monarchy.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Obesity and Diabetes Tied to Liver Cancer
abstract: For each 2-inch increase in waist circumference, the risk of liver cancer increased by 8 percent.
lead_paragraph: A large study has found that body mass index, waist circumference and diabetes are all associated with an increased risk for liver cancer. Liver cancer is the sixth most common cancer, and its incidence has tripled since the mid-1970s in the United States.

headline: Clayton Kershaw Saves a Game and Perhaps a Season
abstract: In his first relief appearance in seven years, the greatest pitcher of his generation earned his first save since he was 18 years old and sent the Dodgers to the N.L.C.S.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He will need to do more for the nickname to stick, because that is always how it is with Clayton Kershaw. More innings, more strikeouts, more awards. More playoff starts on short rest. Always more.

headline: Dodgers Forgo Convention and Outlast Nationals to Reach N.L.C.S.
abstract: Los Angeles scored four runs in the seventh inning to overcome a 1-0 Washington lead and then held on for a one-run victory as Clayton Kershaw recorded the final two outs for a save.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kenley Jansen, the Los Angeles Dodgers closer, was in the midst of the most exhausting outing of his career on Thursday. His right arm had already carried the weight of two innings as the Dodgers clung desperately to a one-run lead over the Washington Nationals in Game 5 of a National League division series.

headline: The Beauty of Big Books
keywords: ['Pagans and Paganism', 'Philosophy', 'Religion and Belief', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A law professor takes a swing at the mother of all questions.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, an astonishing book landed on my desk. It’s called “Confessions of a Born-Again Pagan” and it weighs in at an impressive 1,076 pages. The author is Anthony Kronman, the former dean of the Yale Law School.

headline: The Man Blocking Peace in Colombia
abstract: A former Colombian president who set the stage for peace talks with rebels holds the key to salvaging or thwarting the accord.
lead_paragraph: A history book about Colombia’s recent past would rightly credit former President Álvaro Uribe, who governed from 2002 to 2010, with setting the stage for peace negotiations with guerrilla groups by leading a crackdown on insurgents that drove them to the negotiating table. Yet, confoundingly, Mr. Uribe has emerged as the chief obstacle to a negotiated end to Colombia’s 52-year armed conflict.

headline: Burning Down the House
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Editorials', 'Discrimination', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: In the final days of a horrid campaign, an unshackled Donald Trump is more national threat than punch line. He’s determined to cause lasting damage.
lead_paragraph: A wounded bear is a dangerous thing. Detested and defeated, Donald Trump is now in a tear-the-country-down rage. Day after day, he rips at the last remaining threads of decency holding this nation together. His opponent is the devil, he says — hate her with all your heart. Forget about the rule of law. Lock her up!

headline: Erick Erickson: The G.O.P. After Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Voters are being held hostage by hollow promises from both parties. The Republicans have a chance to win back their trust.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Over the past few months, a cavalcade of Republican policy wonks, pundits and partisan strategists have beclowned themselves on national television trying to defend the indefensible: their party’s nominee. Free-trade advocates have become protectionists. Strategists are treating Drudge Report surveys as scientific endeavors while dismissing legitimate polls as Clintonian propaganda.

headline: The Clinton Agenda
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Law and Legislation', 'Global Warming', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A large margin of victory will be needed for an effective presidency.
lead_paragraph: It ain’t over until the portly gentleman screams, but it is, as intelligence analysts say, highly likely that Hillary Clinton will win this election. Poll-based models put her chances at around 90 percent earlier this week — and that was before the campaign turned totally X-rated.

headline: How to Help an Injured Bird
abstract: Prod its legs. Use a brown bag as an ambulance.
lead_paragraph: “Check out any bird that’s lying sideways on the ground,” says Rita McMahon, director of the Wild Bird Fund, who notes that the fall migration season is when a lot of birds fly into windows. Prod the unresponsive bird’s legs: If they move freely, there’s a chance of revival.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Idling an Engine While Pumping Gas
abstract: Unless you just robbed a bank or have the last name Diesel, take the extra second to turn it off.
lead_paragraph: Alison writes: My husband believes that you do not need to turn off your engine when you pump gas. Once, when I turned off the engine and got out to pump, he reached over, depressed the brake pedal with his hand and started it back up again. Which one of us is right?

headline: My Divorce, My Father, My Mistake
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Families and Family Life', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments']
abstract: Making assumptions about a parent’s silence.
lead_paragraph: I told my father about my divorce after midnight on a bus from Chicago to Iowa City. There was no sense postponing it; he was calling from Isfahan, Iran, and we spoke only every few months. He struggled for a response, his deep voice faltering. “Will you be O.K.?” he asked. “Do you have money?” In Iran, a divorced woman in her 30s might never marry again, and if she does, she may not do as well. She probably won’t have children, and if she already does, they are legally her husband’s. Her property might vanish. The notion of the happy divorced woman just doesn’t compute.

headline: The 10.2.16 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: RE: BALTIMORE VS. MARILYN MOSBY

headline: Does Technology Make Us More Alone?
abstract: Do you find yourself surrounded by people who are staring at their screens instead of having face-to-face conversations? Are you ever guilty of doing that, too?
lead_paragraph: Technology is supposed to make us more connected. We can stay in touch with our friends all the time on Facebook, Instagram and Snapchat, and, of course, by texting. But are our smartphones actually getting in the way of real socializing? Could technology be making us more alone?

headline: The Quiet Menace of Kelly Reichardt’s Feminist Westerns
abstract: Through her spare, often uncomfortably observant movies, the filmmaker tells the stories of women moving through an uneasy world.
lead_paragraph: Walking through a rapidly gentrifying neighborhood of Portland, Ore., in July, Kelly Reichardt noticed a group of teenage street punks. They had dreadlocks and dogs and dirty clothing emblazoned with hand-drawn anarchy symbols. Reichardt faltered for a moment, and then crossed the street. She told me that she suspected one of them had begun shooting up on a garage roof next door to the house where she was staying. “My instinct is to call the cops,” she said. “But then it’s like, God, whose side am I on?”

headline: He’s a Ballet Dancer. And a Singer. And a Drag Queen.
abstract: A look at the many faces of James Whiteside, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater.
lead_paragraph: Last Halloween, the American Ballet Theater principals James Whiteside and Daniil Simkin took a class dressed as stars from the troupe’s past, to the delight of observers. Mr. Simkin was Mikhail Baryshnikov. But Mr. Whiteside turned heads as the ballerina Gelsey Kirkland, with leotard and skirt, pointe shoes and fake hair in a bun. The choreographer Jessica Lang, scouting for dancers, was impressed: “He’s not afraid to push boundaries.”

headline: New York’s Secret Doors and Hidden Rooms
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Underground Railroad (19th Century)', 'Basements and Cellars', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
