lead_paragraph: I have a recurring real estate dream in which I find an extra room in my home, tucked behind a door I have never noticed before.

headline: Bob Dylan and New York: A Complicated, Fertile Romance
abstract: Mr. Dylan may have styled himself early on as a vagabond country boy, but those familiar with his life know he first rose to prominence as a driven folk singer in Greenwich Village coffeehouses.
lead_paragraph: In Bob Dylan’s “Don’t Think Twice, It’s All Right,” that rooster crowing “at the break of dawn” was probably a New York City chicken, not a rural farmyard bird.

headline: What’s Love? Don’t Ask the Answer Couple
abstract: A onetime advice columnist realizes that the more she learns about love, the less she seems to know.
lead_paragraph: I used to be one half of the Answer Couple in Glamour. The other half was my husband. This was 30 years ago, when newsstands were overflowing with glossy magazines.

headline: On London’s Fleet Street, the Presses Have Stopped for Good
abstract: Two employees of a Scottish paper who left recently were the last newspaper journalists actually working on the street that gave the British press its nickname.
lead_paragraph: Just as Savile Row does for lovers of custom tailored men’s wear, Fleet Street in London stands for something in the popular imagination: the British press.

lead_paragraph: The destruction is so complete that it obliterates even a sense of time. At a glance, the video shot from a drone could show Berlin in 1945 or Grozny, 2000. Mass death erases all distinctions.

headline: A Minneapolis Restaurant That Goes Medieval
abstract: By focusing on olden techniques like fermenting and roasting, Upton 43 is expanding the city’s eating scene and redefining the Swedish-American foods he grew up with.
lead_paragraph: If molecular gastronomy evokes science fiction (foams! liquid nitrogen!), Upton 43 in Minneapolis feels more like alternate history. To eat there is to imagine a world where the spice trade never really developed, a chef-driven culture built on the flavors of medieval Europe. By focusing on old-fashioned techniques like fermenting and roasting, Erick Harcey, the chef, is expanding the city’s eating scene and redefining the Swedish-American foods he grew up with.

headline: Syllabus for Bob Dylan Seminar
abstract: Prof. Richard F. Thomas teaches a Harvard freshman seminar about Bob Dylan, who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature. Take a look at the syllabus for the course, which Mr. Thomas has taught four times.
lead_paragraph: Prof. Richard F. Thomas teaches a Harvard freshman seminar about Bob Dylan, who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature. Take a look at the syllabus for the course, which Mr. Thomas has taught four times.

headline: Jeff Goodby: Work for Bosses Who Can Take a Joke
abstract: A founder of the ad agency Goodby Silverstein & Partners describes having to unlearn management skills to nudge creative people toward their best work.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Jeff Goodby, co-chairman and partner of the advertising agency Goodby Silverstein & Partners, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: In Paris, 8 New Tours, From Art to Shopping
abstract: Innovative new tours in Paris include private visits to an art museum, a shopping excursion, a nighttime food crawl, and mystery and history.
lead_paragraph: Peak tourist season in Paris may be winding down, but several new and innovative tours in the city are keeping it a vibrant destination in the fall and winter, too. Many of the sites these excursions cover aren’t new; the way to see them, on the other hand, is.

headline: Bob Dylan 101: A Harvard Professor Has the Coolest Class on Campus
abstract: Richard F. Thomas teaches a freshman seminar about Mr. Dylan. Here’s a look inside the class and his take on the Nobel Prize in Literature.
lead_paragraph: For the Harvard classics professor Richard F. Thomas, who has been gently teased by colleagues for teaching a freshman seminar about Bob Dylan — as well as for the students who sometimes get double takes for choosing the course — the announcement of the newest Nobel laureate in literature was hailed as vindication. And cause to break out celebratory cupcakes at the fortuitously timed Thursday afternoon session.

headline: I Crossed the World
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Exploration and Explorers']
abstract: How an accidental circumnavigation — with stops in Japan and Germany — awakened the spirit of exploration in me.
lead_paragraph: When imagining a journey around planet Earth, I never pictured the part where I crossed the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in a Toyota Camry with a pink Lyft mustache on the dashboard. Yet that was how I embarked on an accidental circumnavigation of the globe one recent sunny morning, Annie Lennox singing “I travel the world and the seven seas” on the car stereo as the Camry hurtled through the E-ZPass lane.

headline: How to Circle the Globe — on Purpose
abstract: Private jet trips at $135,000 and freighter cabins from $112 are two ways to make your way around the world.
lead_paragraph: We’ve come a long way from the era of the fictitious circumnavigator Phileas Fogg. Traveling around the world today can take far fewer than 80 days, especially by plane, as the following multimodal trips indicate. Here are some options for tourists who have enough of the spirit of exploration to try to circle the globe.

headline: 5 Underrated Pioneers in Circumnavigation
abstract: A Frenchwoman made it in the 18th century and so did a team who finished their mission on solar plane this year.

headline: ‘The Wall Is a Fantasy’
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Border Barriers', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: A week in the borderlands with migrants and guards.
lead_paragraph: NOGALES, Mexico — A few hundred feet from the American border, José Manuel Talavera contemplated his challenge with the focus, if not quite the physique, of an Olympic high jumper. A stocky coffee farmer from Honduras, he was fresh off La Bestia, or the Beast — the freight train network used by migrants to cross Mexico. Now he was preparing to vault into the United States, for the third time.

The painting had last been seen at auction in 1987, when it sold at Christie’s for £49,500.

Dogs woof at any stranger walking up the dirt path. Plainclothes detectives check his mailbox and tag along wherever he goes to protect him from possible assassins sent by North Korea, which openly threatens to kill him.

headline: The Story Behind This Week’s Best Sellers
abstract: Ruth Bader Ginsburg, whose anthology “My Own Words” is No. 12 in hardcover nonfiction, has something in common with Notorious B.I.G.
lead_paragraph: Notorious: Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg has been making the rounds lately to promote a new anthology of her writing, “My Own Words,” which hits the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 12. As you might expect, the interviews have centered largely on Ginsburg’s love of the law, her long, impressive career and the inner workings of the court. But Ginsburg has also become something of a pop culture superstar in recent years, ever since an admiring law student nicknamed her Notorious R.B.G. (a riff on the rapper Notorious B.I.G.). The meme went viral, and now Ginsburg’s stern face and big glasses show up on tote bags, baby onesies and coffee mugs bearing slogans like “The Ruth Will Set You Free.” So when Gwen Ifill talked with her for PBS’s “NewsHour Bookshelf” this month, the first question involved Ginsburg’s newfound status as a folk hero. “It is utterly amazing,” Ginsburg said. “Of course I didn’t see it coming. . . . But I certainly was given a tremendous boost into the public arena by the Notorious R.B.G. When I was asked about it, I said, well, it’s exactly right, because Notorious B.I.G. and I had something in common. . . . We were both born and bred in Brooklyn.”

headline: The Latest and Best in Crime Fiction
abstract: “His Bloody Project,” a finalist for this year’s Man Booker Prize, makes masterly use of the narrative form to tell a horrifying tale.
lead_paragraph: It’s only a story — or is it? Graeme Macrae Burnet makes such masterly use of the narrative form that the horrifying tale he tells in HIS BLOODY PROJECT (Skyhorse, $24.99), a finalist for this year’s Man Booker Prize, seems plucked straight out of Scotland’s sanguinary historical archives. Presented as a collection of “Documents Relating to the Case of Roderick Macrae,” which took place in 1869, the novel includes the jailhouse memoir of a 17-year-old Scottish Highlander being held in Inverness Castle, awaiting trial for three appalling murders.

headline: Misogyny Is Back. Did It Ever Go Away?
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Assaults', 'Hate Crimes', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s campaign is reminding women that there is still plenty to be frightened of.
lead_paragraph: On the night of Saturday, Sept. 10, between the hours of about 8 and 11, six women, each of them walking in Midtown Manhattan, were approached by a group of young men who sought to light them on fire. Although the attacks were mercifully unsuccessful — no one was injured — one woman, standing at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and East 54th Street had her skirt set aflame, while another, walking past a Valentino store, the police reported, felt something warm on her left arm, only to realize that her blouse was on fire. Six days later, a 14-year old boy was taken into custody, and charged with attempted assault and harassment. Given that everyone targeted for conflagration was female, the police have considered these hate crimes.

headline: Anatomy of a Media Conspiracy
abstract: How WikiLeaks made the author a talking point for Trump.
lead_paragraph: Look, Mom, there I am in WikiLeaks. Right there among the rest of the media sellouts, Clinton shills and biased tools of the MSM who are apparently bent on destroying Donald J. Trump. Sarah Palin tweeted about me, Trump himself derided my actions in a stump speech and I’m pretty sure Bill O’Reilly just called on me to resign, if I’m reading the barrage of Twitter mentions correctly — and it is a barrage (or was before I stopped reading Twitter).

headline: Success Spoils a U.S. Program to Round Up Wild Horses
abstract: The U.S. has struggled to limit wild horse populations since Congress passed a law in 1971 protecting the animals on public land in 10 Western states.
lead_paragraph: OSAGE COUNTY, Okla. — As the sun set on the honey-colored prairie here, a herd of wild horses grazed belly deep in Indiangrass and big bluestem. On the next ridge, a dozen more horses nibbled in the pasture, and beyond them even more, dotting the hills almost as far as the eye could see.

headline: Review: Danish Dance Theater, Pulse-Checking and a Rave for the Undead
abstract: The troupe’s “Black Diamond,” an American premiere at the Joyce, lurches and stumbles — and not on purpose.
lead_paragraph: As the curtain rises on “Black Diamond” by Danish Dance Theater, a man lies on the stage, menaced by two figures wearing mesh bags over their heads. As a sad little flurry of confetti falls, more figures slink in wearing long black coats, the men bare chested. Sometimes, they jerk like poorly programmed robots or their fingers scurry over their arms like spiders. It’s enough to make you wonder, “Exactly which bad movie is this trying to be?”
