headline: What's Behind the Spreading Creepy Clown Hysteria?
abstract: Many of the recent menacing clown sightings are hoaxes, but they appear to be inspiring copy-cat pranks and occasional acts of violence.

headline: Daily Report: Hacking on Yahoo May Knock Down Its Sale Price
abstract: Verizon, which was in talks to buy Yahoo’s core business for $4.8 billion, says the hacking materially reduced Yahoo’s value.
lead_paragraph: The aftereffects of an extensive hacking can linger for weeks and months — sometimes even years.

headline: Love On and Off the Rocks
abstract: Shaun Reed and Cassandra Ilich’s love of rock climbing solidified their union. The couple embarked on their latest adventure Sept. 24 at the bride’s family’s home in Ione, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Shaun Reed and Cassandra Ilich’s love of rock climbing solidified their union. The couple embarked on their latest adventure Sept. 24 at the bride’s family’s home in Ione, Calif.

headline: The Gift of the Goat Sealed the Deal
abstract: Shaun Reed, using an old Serbian country tradition, humorously asked Cassandra Ilich’s parents for her hand in marriage.
lead_paragraph: Last November, Shaun Reed, 32, drove up a winding road in Ione, Calif. In the back of the vehicle, unperturbed by the journey to the old gold-rush town, rode a flop-eared, cocoa-colored goat. Mr. Reed was sure it was the perfect gift for Heidi and Randy Ilich, who he hoped would soon be his in-laws.

headline: When Is Something ‘Carbon Neutral’?
abstract: Three experts discuss biomass energy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In a Queens Food Court, No More Dumplings, No More Ramen
abstract: In a new food, er, hall, it’s not enough to pay the rent. Each vendor has to offer a unique dining experience, too.
lead_paragraph: In our epicurean culture, the lowest species on the culinary food chain is the generic food court, and it has been marked for extinction. For many, the scariest-looking food truck is more desirable these days than a franchise outlet like Cinnabon or Taco Bell.

headline: What You Should Watch: ‘Carol’ and ‘The Durrells in Corfu’
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

headline: Duck to Devour
abstract: A true French-style braise, with meat gently simmered to tenderness with fresh plums, has many virtues.
lead_paragraph: I feel lucky to live near Manhattan’s Chinatown. It’s a short walk that always improves my spirits. No matter what I’m shopping for, I always end up stopping at the roast duck place.

headline: Among Donald Trump’s Biggest U.S. Fans: Hindu Nationalists
abstract: A small faction of Hindu Nationalists in India and the United States see Mr. Trump as the embodiment of the politically incorrect, strongman brand of politics they admire.
lead_paragraph: Your typical Trump rally this was not.

headline: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there’s much more where these came from.

headline: Stool Pigeons and Shlom Jobs: Revisiting the Days of Murder, Inc.
abstract: A new book explores the cinematic, sociological and political implications of contract killings, during an era of ethnic succession when Jewish gangs and Italian organized crime were dominant.
lead_paragraph: “Did your conscience ever bother you?” Burton Turkus, the crime-busting assistant Brooklyn prosecutor, asked Abe Reles, the homegrown gangster who organized Murder Inc. in the 1930s.

headline: New York Neighborhoods, Hot and Cold
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Where did New York City home prices rise and fall the most recently?
lead_paragraph: Where are home prices rising or falling the most in New York City? To find out, we looked at median sales prices in each of the city’s neighborhoods during the month of August and compared them to those six months prior. (Areas with fewer than 50 sales were not considered, and each neighborhood’s sales were aggregated over three months to smooth deceptive spikes.)

headline: With Sprint, Former Verizon Actor Says, You Can Hear Him Just Fine
abstract: After a role in commercials as the nameless “Test Man” looking for a cellular signal, Paul Marcarelli is playing himself.
lead_paragraph: ONCE, he was widely known as the Verizon guy, or the “Can you hear me now?” guy.

headline: Battle of the Sexes
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys', 'Gender', 'Fashion Shows']
abstract: As more and more labels add men’s wear to their women’s wear shows, who benefits? Two critics debate the question.
lead_paragraph: As more and more labels add men’s wear to their women’s wear shows, who benefits? Two critics debate the question.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Kehinde Wiley
abstract: “Giovanni’s Room,” “Regarding the Pain of Others,” “Love in the Time of Cholera” and more.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the artist Kehinde Wiley, who shares his list exclusively with T.

headline: Where’s the Love for Trump? Not in Ads for G.O.P. Candidates
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Advertising', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Some Republicans running for the House and Senate did not mention of Donald Trump in political advertising because it would hurt them with undecided voters.
lead_paragraph: As Republican candidates for the House and Senate have been rolling out their final round of political advertisements before Election Day, one thing has been conspicuously absent: love for Donald J. Trump.

headline: Can This Caterpillar Predict Winter Weather? Probably Not Very Well
abstract: Scientists doubt these woolly worms can forecast the future, but that won’t stop people from racing them in North Carolina this weekend.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, 25 vertical racing lanes will hang along a sun-drenched stage in Banner Elk, N.C., awaiting their athletes — thousands of fuzzy, brown and black banded caterpillars. Throughout the day, people will sign up their worms for the big race. An M.C. known as Mr. Woolly Worm will kick off the race wearing a pink and yellow suit infested with fake caterpillars. The first to reach the top takes home the grand prize: $1,000 and the honor of forecasting this year’s winter weather.

headline: Salesforce Rules Out a Bid for Twitter
abstract: Twitter shares tumbled as few deal-making options remained.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter may have to fix its problems on its own, at least for now.

headline: FIFA Decision Boosts U.S.’s Chance to Host 2026 World Cup
abstract: The governing body of soccer voted on Friday to bar Europe and Asia from bidding because those regions are hosting the next two World Cups.
lead_paragraph: FIFA’s governing council voted on Friday to bar countries in Europe and Asia, which will host the next two World Cups, from bidding to host the tournament in 2026. The decision significantly increases the chances that the event will take place in the United States, either as the sole bidder or in partnership with a neighbor such as Mexico or Canada.

headline: Gender Issues in Sharp Focus at The Times
abstract: Susan Chira, senior correspondent for gender issues, and Susan Dominus, a Times Magazine writer, talk about men, women and coverage of their changing roles.
lead_paragraph: Susan Chira, senior correspondent for gender issues, and Susan Dominus, a Times Magazine writer, talk about men, women and coverage of their changing roles.

headline: We May Be Leaving the Ken Bone Zone
abstract: The undecided voter in the red sweater was a hero for a few days, then journalists found his old Reddit posts. “I take full responsibility,” he says.
lead_paragraph: This is an obituary for a fictional persona: Ken Bone, America’s Red-Breasted Hero.

headline: Hal Holbrook, on ‘The Birth of a Nation’
abstract: The actor writes that he is finding it hard to accept the film’s apparent rebuff at the box office.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Expanding the Nobel Pantheon to Include Bob Dylan
abstract: Readers write about a well-deserved prize.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Evan McMullin’s Moonshot White House Bid Has Utah’s Attention
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Third-Party Politics (US)', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: A 40-year-old Brigham Young graduate has little money and no major-party backing, but he holds a certain appeal for “Never Trump” conservatives.
lead_paragraph: LOGAN, Utah — On a night when Donald J. Trump’s campaign was staggering under new accusations that he had groped and sexually assaulted women, 900 voters streamed into a middle school auditorium in this reliably Republican and mostly Mormon city, desperate to hear something different.

headline: Wells Fargo Needs to Make a Clean Break With the Past
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Critics say Timothy J. Sloan, the new chief executive, is not the person the bank needs to overhaul its system after the fraudulent accounts scandal.
lead_paragraph: Even after two big shuffles at the top, Wells Fargo is still working from the same playbook. And for the bank’s stockholders, that could mean more frustration lies ahead.

headline: Gender Issues in Sharp Focus at The Times
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Gender', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Susan Chira, senior correspondent for gender issues, and Susan Dominus, a Times Magazine writer, talk about men, women and coverage of their changing roles.
lead_paragraph: Susan Chira, formerly The New York Times’s deputy executive editor, has a new role, as senior correspondent for gender issues.

headline: 2010 | Trump Calls The Times His Forever Enduring ‘Partner’
abstract: Donald J. Trump appeared in a series of (unpaid) testimonial advertisements that ran in the Real Estate section of The Times.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times.

headline: In Sagaponack, Betting the Farm on Boutique Vodka
abstract: Potato growers find a new way to survive in one of the nation’s most expensive ZIP codes.
lead_paragraph: “The earth is gold to farm,” said Dean Foster, who learned before he was in kindergarten how to drive a tractor on his family’s potato farm in Sagaponack, N.Y. As a child, he never questioned going into the family business, which has been growing potatoes on the East End of Long Island for generations. “But now we have an influx of people who realize this earth is gold to build on.”

headline: Celebrating 35 Years of Carolina Herrera
abstract: Priyanka Chopra, Karlie Kloss and more gathered downtown to honor a new book about the designer.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday evening, Omar’s, a members-only dining club on West Ninth Street, was filled to its wood-paneled, mirrored brim with a cross section of New York City actors, models, financiers, socialites, activists, editors and artists.

headline: Presidential Policy Directive on Cuba
abstract: President Obama on Friday signed a new directive regarding United States policy toward Cuba, enshrining his push to normalize relations in a legally binding document.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Friday signed a new directive regarding United States policy toward Cuba, enshrining his push to normalize relations in a legally binding document.

headline: Striped Bass of the Hudson
abstract: The fish is found throughout much of the Eastern Seaboard and breeds in several river systems, but the majority of stripers in New York are a gift of the Hudson River.
lead_paragraph: With the jutting jaw of a mob kingpin and the pinstripes of a Wall Street executive, striped bass swim through the brackish waters of New York Harbor like old-school New Yorkers — as if they own the place.

headline: Morso’s Modern Family: Five Years Old, but Decades in the Making
abstract: Some regulars say they see Morso, a polished but unpretentious Italian restaurant on Sutton Place, almost as an extension of their homes.
lead_paragraph: It seemed as though the entire Sutton Place neighborhood had gathered at Morso on a recent Tuesday evening. The contemporary 95-seat restaurant, lined with vintage 1950s-style graphics, was packed with couples, groups of friends, families and a handful of solo diners.

headline: How Wall St. Regulation Pushed Up Libor, and Borrowing Costs
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)']
abstract: Regulators want to eliminate risk at Wall Street banks, and that will have unintended consequences – like higher interest rates — for everyone else.
lead_paragraph: Is there any significance to the fact that a short-term interest rate has nearly tripled in the last year, to 0.86 percent from 0.32 percent? The short answer, of course, is yes. But the more interesting answer involves what the change in the so-called three-month London Interbank Offered Rate, or Libor, says about the Federal Reserve’s new regulatory framework for Wall Street, which it has slowly but surely been rolling out since the worst days of the financial crisis eight years ago.

headline: Donald Trump Assails His Accusers as Liars, and Unattractive
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Mr. Trump attacked the women accusing him of inappropriate sexual advances, while claiming that the news media and Hillary Clinton were conspiring against him.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump wielded his presidential candidacy on Friday as a weapon for savaging detractors and venting personal grievances, attacking the women who have accused him of sexual assault and unwelcome advances and railing against what he described as a vast conspiracy against him by the news media and Hillary Clinton’s campaign.

headline: Soccer Player Ched Evans Is Acquitted of Rape Charges in Retrial
abstract: Evans, 27, spent two and a half years in prison but has already restarted his playing career, at Chesterfield F.C. in English soccer’s third tier.
lead_paragraph: Ched Evans, the Welsh soccer player whose career was derailed by his conviction on charges of raping a 19-year-old waitress in a hotel, and whose consistent protestations of innocence brought him both support and scorn, was found not guilty Friday after a retrial of the case.

headline: How Julia Wolfe and Michael Gordon, Workaholic Composers, Spend Their Sundays
abstract: For this high-achieving couple, the quiet of the day makes it a great time to work on music for four or five hours.
lead_paragraph: Julia Wolfe and Michael Gordon are two of the three founders and artistic directors of Bang on a Can, the genre-bending musical collective that will turn 30 next year. They’re also a married couple who raised two children in their TriBeCa loft, a former Romanoff Caviar factory. The two compose loud music at either ends of the loft, which they share with their daughter, Yael, 20, and a cockapoo named River. Ms. Wolfe, 57, who goes by Julie, just won a MacArthur fellowship to go with her 2015 Pulitzer Prize for her oratorio “Anthracite Fields,” about coal mining in Pennsylvania. “Amplified,” a guitar quartet by Mr. Gordon, 60, is scheduled to be performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave festival in December. They are workaholics who observe the Jewish Sabbath.

headline: Trump as Champion of Working Class? ‘Come On,’ Obama Says
abstract: President Obama implored voters to “reject a dark and pessimistic vision” offered by Donald J. Trump, who he said faked his concern for the working class.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — President Obama on Friday implored voters here to “reject a dark and pessimistic vision” offered by Donald J. Trump and urged a robust turnout on behalf of Hillary Clinton in a state where the presidential candidates are locked in a razor-thin contest.

headline: New York Bridal Fashion Week Recap
abstract: Designers like Monique Lhuillier, Reem Acra and Inbal Dror showcased their fall 2017 bridal collections.
lead_paragraph: Designers like Monique Lhuillier, Reem Acra and Inbal Dror showcased their fall 2017 bridal collections.

headline: A Peek at Bridal Fashion Week
abstract: What we saw on the runways at New York Bridal Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: This year at New York Bridal Fashion Week, designers like Monique Lhuillier, Reem Acra and Inbal Dror showcased their fall 2017 bridal collections. New looks that emerged on the runways included dramatic capes, intricate floral details, flamboyant ruffles and metallic gowns. Here’s a peek at some of the fashions that will be available for next year’s brides.

headline: Celebrating Three and a Half Decades
abstract: Actors, models and socialites gather to honor Carolina Herrera’s 35 years in fashion and a new book commemorating her time in the industry.
lead_paragraph: Actors, models and socialites gather to honor Carolina Herrera’s 35 years in fashion and a new book commemorating her time in the industry.

headline: Artist Asks Cubans to Imagine They Are Running for President
abstract: In an effort to open a political dialogue, Tania Bruguera has released a video proposing that anyone should be able to run for any job in Cuba.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Tania Bruguera, the Cuban artist whose high-profile performances challenging the limits of freedom on the island have drawn support from the art world, threw down another gauntlet to Cuba’s closed political system on Friday when she said that she would run for office — even for president.

headline: Cholera Deepens Haiti’s Misery After Hurricane
abstract: The disease is stalking the areas gutted by Hurricane Matthew on a remote stretch of the country’s southern peninsula.
lead_paragraph: RENDEL, Haiti — There is a plague on this town.

headline: Readers Go Electric Over Dylan’s Nobel
abstract: Fans (and a few foes) responded to news of Bob Dylan’s Nobel Prize with favorite lyrics and memories.
lead_paragraph: “Mr. Dylan, I have just one question,” Archy Techt from New York wrote. “How does it feel?”

headline: Review: ‘Eyewitness’ Tells of Whodunit, but Also Who Saw It
abstract: This 10-episode series on USA Network stars Julianne Nicholson as an upstate New York sheriff and follows characters who witness crime.
lead_paragraph: Not every role is a good fit for Julianne Nicholson, but Helen Torrance, the upstate New York sheriff she plays in the USA series “Eyewitness,” is well tailored. Duty bound, methodical and possessing only a nodding acquaintance with humor, Helen is someone you would probably like to know but wouldn’t necessarily want to hang out with. She’s perfect for Ms. Nicholson, an actress who seems to keep everything inside.

headline: The Nationals Can’t Escape Their Sad Endings
abstract: The Nationals have won their division in three of the past five years but once again could not get past the first round.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — You know what the Nationals’ clubhouse sounded like Thursday night, past midnight, after Washington lost the deciding Game 5 of its National League division series?

headline: Trump’s Comments Prompt Women to Speak Out
abstract: Since a 2005 recording of comments by Donald J. Trump about women went public, survivors of sexual assault are speaking out in unprecedented numbers.
lead_paragraph: Since a 2005 recording of comments by Donald J. Trump about women went public, survivors of sexual assault are speaking out in unprecedented numbers.

headline: Black Doctor Says Delta Flight Attendant Rejected Her; Sought ‘Actual Physician’
abstract: Dr. Tamika Cross of Houston wrote on Facebook about having her credentials questioned when she tried to help a sick passenger.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Tamika Cross, a black physician at the Lyndon B. Johnson Hospital in Houston, could not immediately come to the phone on Friday. She was busy delivering a baby boy by C-section.

headline: In Race for Millennials, It’s Time to Speed Up
abstract: The Times needs to adapt more quickly to an ecosystem that’s vastly different from what it was just five years ago.
lead_paragraph: Vice entered the nightly news business this week, delivering a rebel-style newscast on HBO with no anchor, no ads and none of the predictable tics and tricks of the broadcast old guard. The show is aimed at the very market segment that The New York Times is feverishly trying to reach — millennials.

headline: In Nigeria, Joy for Girls Freed by Boko Haram. What of the Rest?
abstract: The country celebrated the release of 21 girls whom Boko Haram had seized from their school in April 2014, but many others remain unaccounted for.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — People fanned out on bicycles and on foot across a remote region of northeastern Nigeria on Friday to notify the families of 21 girls that they had been liberated by Boko Haram, the Islamist extremist group, after two and a half years of captivity.

headline: Jordan Tones Down Textbooks’ Islamic Content, and Tempers Rise
abstract: An effort to help youths avoid drifting to extreme ideologies has provoked a backlash, with many viewing the curriculum tweaks as a declaration of war on Islamic values.
lead_paragraph: MAAN, Jordan — When Jordan’s school year began last month, educators began noticing tweaks in the curriculum.

headline: The Playlist: Pusha T Spurns the Doubters and Kendrick Lamar Tempts the Critics
abstract: Hear the 10 songs that caught our critics’ attention this week, from Emeli Sandé’s “Garden” to Priests’ “JJ.”
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing — in the Playlist. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this format? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter (coming soon!) here.

headline: Janet Yellen Says Labor and Inflation Complicate Fed’s Plans to Raise Rates
abstract: The Federal Reserve chief said policy makers were struggling to understand issues like the behavior of the labor market and the weakness of inflation.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, did not talk on Friday about the Fed’s plans for its benchmark interest rate. Instead, she talked about why those plans have been so hard to make.

headline: Wells Fargo Says Customers Shied Away After Scandal
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: The bank said customer loyalty had fallen as fewer checking accounts and credit card accounts were opened in September.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo disclosed on Friday that new account openings had taken a nose-dive since the scandal over illegal activity at the bank erupted: Bank executives said customers opened 25 percent fewer checking accounts and applied for 20 percent fewer credit cards in September compared with a year ago.

headline: Signs of Strain in the Stock and Bond Love Affair
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Government Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: The markets’ traditional moves may be altering, denting bonds’ appeal. But it’s not really dire. And remember: There’s always the safety of cash.
lead_paragraph: It has been easy for stock investors to love bonds as they have generated handsome returns while providing protection when the stock market falls.

headline: Palantir Faults Labor Dept.’s Data in Discrimination Suit
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: The Silicon Valley start-up says it hired its own experts, who found no bias at the company.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Palantir, a large and secretive Silicon Valley start-up recently sued by the United States Department of Labor for discrimination, contends that the government misread the way it hires employees.

headline: Review: ‘The Content Trap’ Rethinks Digital Media Strategy
abstract: Bharat Anand has taken his insights from years of teaching at Harvard to provide a framework for thinking more broadly in the face of digital disruption.
lead_paragraph: For 15 years, the business school cases written by Bharat N. Anand, a popular Harvard Business School strategy professor, have played a central role in framing students’ understanding of the media industry. Like all great business school cases, they tell an interesting story and provide the critical facts but leave it to the interactive classroom experience to draw out the relevant lessons.

headline: Stocks Climb Under Heavy Clouds
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Despite the prospect of higher interest rates, the imminent presidential election and heightened uncertainty in Europe, shares have for the most part risen.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve still hasn’t raised interest rates, though it insists that an increase is just around the corner. An even bigger decision that cannot be put off — it will be made by American voters on Nov. 8 — is stirring concern all over the world.

headline: How Regular Investing Smooths the Market’s Ups and Downs
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Retirement', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Dollar-cost averaging offers investors a way to avoid the risks of trying to time the markets, and to save gradually, at a reasonable price.
lead_paragraph: You may not realize you are doing it, but if you are salting away money every month in a workplace retirement plan, there is a good chance that you are practicing one of the most time-honored methods for long-term investors: dollar-cost averaging.

headline: Sticking With Stocks, Especially in Market Downturns
abstract: Mutual fund managers are holding their ground, which may be a stabilizing force in the market.
lead_paragraph: Call it confidence, or an unwillingness to try to time the market, or even complacency. But whatever the reason, some mutual fund managers with the best performances over the last five to 10 years say they are disinclined to sell their stock holdings — even if the overall market turns down.

headline: Picking a Portfolio With Pokéballs
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Pokemon (Fictional Characters)', 'Mutual Funds', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: If you can use augmented reality to find cartoon monsters, why not use it to capture weirdly enticing investments?
lead_paragraph: Oops! Didn’t mean to bump into you there. It’s just that I can’t stop playing Pokémon Go, the smartphone game.

headline: Canada Today: Economic Bright Spots, and Some Disquieting Mail
abstract: Thomson Reuters, the global digital information company, said it would move its senior executives to Toronto, and two automakers made deals with Canadian plants.
lead_paragraph: We’re trying something new: Canada Today, a weekly roundup for Canadian readers and anyone else interested in the True North. Tell us what you think and what you’d like to see, at CanadaToday@nytimes.com. And, using the link below, please subscribe to the email newsletter version.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Blurs the European Investment Outlook
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Though markets have stabilized since the vote for Britain to leave the European Union, where investors and businesses go from here is uncertain.
lead_paragraph: When the British voted in a referendum to leave the European Union, it clouded the political outlook across the region, and that made the economic and investment outlook far murkier, too.

headline: Three Excellent Books on Long-Term Investing
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Retirement', 'Personal Finances', 'Mortgages', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)']
abstract: As the market fluctuates, these books remind us to use common sense and stick to the basics when saving and planning for retirement.
lead_paragraph: It is easy to forget personal investing fundamentals when stock prices hit new highs one week, fall sharply the next and then rise again in no reliable pattern, as they have been doing this year. So now is an ideal time to reread — or perhaps pick up for the first time — three excellent books by people who are particularly good at explaining the building blocks of a solid portfolio.

headline: Autumn in New York, So Inviting
abstract: Top social events in the city recently included Carnegie Hall’s opening night gala, the N.A.A.C.P. New York State Conference’s 80th anniversary benefit and the Olana Partnership gala.
lead_paragraph: Top social events in the city recently included Carnegie Hall’s opening night gala, the N.A.A.C.P. New York State Conference’s 80th anniversary benefit and the Olana Partnership gala.

headline: Autumn in New York, So Inviting
abstract: Top social events in the city recently included Carnegie Hall’s opening night gala, the N.A.A.C.P. New York State Conference’s 80th anniversary benefit and the Olana Partnership gala.
lead_paragraph: The fall social season is in full swing, with notable New Yorkers out on the town almost every night. On Oct. 6, many gathered at the Waldorf Astoria for Carnegie Hall’s opening night gala, the first to feature its new chairman, Robert F. Smith. That same evening, the N.A.A.C.P.’s 80th anniversary benefit was held at the Sheraton Times Square, where Richard D. Parsons and Reginald Van Lee were the event’s chairmen, and Cicely Tyson was among the honorees. On Thursday, the Olana Partnership honored Washburn and Susan Oberwager.

headline: Louis Stettner, Who Photographed the Everyday New York and Paris, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Stettner, who considered the two cities his “spiritual mothers,” chronicled the poetry of daily life, with his subjects unaware of his presence.
lead_paragraph: Louis Stettner, a photographer who explored the streets of the two cities he called his “spiritual mothers,” New York and Paris, recording the daily lives of ordinary people, died on Thursday at his home in Saint-Ouen, France. He was 93.

headline: Review: In ‘Graves,’ a Politician Goes From Red to Blue to Gruff and Gray
abstract: Nick Nolte and Sela Ward star in a cheeky new political comedy on Epix.
lead_paragraph: You probably need to be left-leaning or at least politically neutral to enjoy the new Epix comedy “Graves,” which begins Sunday, though really everybody should savor Nick Nolte’s performance in it. The guy was born to be a growly old man.

headline: Why You Should Bet Against Your Candidate
abstract: It’s the logical thing to do. But I know you still won’t do it.
lead_paragraph: When your favorite sports team is defeated, you’re disappointed, even dismayed. The same is true when your preferred political candidate doesn’t win. It hurts when your side loses.

headline: The Assault Allegations Against Donald Trump
abstract: Readers continue to discuss Mr. Trump’s attitudes and behavior toward women.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Helping Homeless Students
abstract: A foundation writes that a new federal law offers an opportunity to address the problem.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Desus & Mero’: No Suits. And No Canned Sketches.
abstract: Desus Nice and the Kid Mero are bringing their hip-hop-inspired slapstick comedy to late-night television on Viceland.
lead_paragraph: This past Tuesday afternoon, in a conference room on the third floor of Vice’s sprawling Williamsburg offices, the comic team of Desus & Mero was going through its daily calisthenics.

headline: U.S. Athletes Reassured After New Russian Hack
abstract: The head of the United States Anti-Doping Agency says the cyberattack targeting its science director’s email account is meant to smear clean athletes.
lead_paragraph: The United States Anti-Doping Agency is seeking to reassure American athletes that their private medical information is safe after Russian hackers gained access to the email account of one of the agency’s officials.

headline: Review: A Choreographer’s Head-Spinning Turns as Self-Revelation
abstract: The French-Algerian dance-maker Rachid Ouramdane brings a more intimate work to New York in “Tordre (Wrought),” at the Crossing the Line Festival.
lead_paragraph: If I had to categorize the French-Algerian choreographer Rachid Ouramdane, I’d label him an expressionist minimalist. I can’t think of anyone else to whom that tag applies in dance, and Mr. Ouramdane reminds me of nobody else. His vocabulary is small, but it suggests that he has urgent points to make that go beyond dance. He’s original, peculiar, limited, irksome, haunting.

headline: Thailand Looks to Likely Future King With Apprehension
abstract: Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn’s lavish European lifestyle and tastes for airplanes, fast cars, women and the high life have caused anxiety.
lead_paragraph: TUTZING, Germany — For more than two years, the king of Thailand lay ill in a Bangkok hospital. During much of that time, his son, the heir to Thailand’s throne, was far from the kingdom, flying around Europe in his Boeing 737 and ensconced in luxury villas and hotels amid the misty lakes and mountains of southern Germany and Austria.

headline: Fall’s Muted (and Ruffled) Pastels
abstract: Fall usually brings to mind dark, cozy colors — but this season’s party dresses conjure a distinctly different mood.
lead_paragraph: Fall usually brings to mind dark, cozy colors — but this season’s party dresses conjure a distinctly different mood.

headline: Diver Recounts His Encounter With a Cage-Breaking Great White Shark
keywords: ['Sharks', 'Diving and Divers', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: “Honestly at that moment I don’t have time to get afraid,” Chan Ming, the diver, said of the encounter with a shark that broke through the bars of a diving cage.
lead_paragraph: A scuba diver who was on a diving tour of great white shark habitats narrowly escaped an encounter with one this month when it broke through the bars of a diving cage and thrashed for nearly a minute until it freed itself.

headline: Is It a Risk for the 49ers to Start Colin Kaepernick? Not for Them.
abstract: The Niners restructured their already team-friendly contract with their quarterback ahead of his start on Sunday, eliminating their financial exposure in case of an injury.
lead_paragraph: When the San Francisco 49ers play the Buffalo Bills on Sunday, Colin Kaepernick will make his first start of the season as the 49ers’ quarterback. Although Kaepernick is currently best known for refusing to stand for the national anthem — a protest against racial injustice that has spread across the sports landscape — it wasn’t all that long ago that he was the dynamic young quarterback who led his team to a Super Bowl appearance and a conference championship game in back-to-back seasons.

headline: Is G.O.P. Dodging a Landslide? Trump’s Polling Hasn’t Collapsed (Yet)
abstract: There aren’t yet many signs that the bottom has fallen out for either Mr. Trump or the Republican Senate candidates in key states.
lead_paragraph: The past three weeks could not have gone much worse for Donald J. Trump, or really the entire Republican Party for that matter.

headline: Wells Fargo’s Problems Go Beyond Sham Accounts Scandal
abstract: The bank has avoided large penalties for creating unauthorized products, but its competitors are leaping ahead in investment banking and trading.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup are hinting at broader woes for Wells Fargo. Wall Street helped the two diversified giant banks trounce third-quarter earnings expectations, while Wells Fargo just squeaked by. As Timothy J. Sloan, the new chief executive at Wells, contends with the sham accounts fiasco, he also will be tested by falling returns.

headline: Review: A Composer’s Mystical Music Gets the Space It Demands
abstract: The New York Philharmonic performed works by the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho inside the Park Avenue Armory’s cavernous drill hall.
lead_paragraph: Many of Kaija Saariaho’s orchestral pieces unfold with minute and seemingly constant shifts of subtle sounds and colorings. Dense chords murmur restlessly, as wavering melodic lines escape from sustained, quivering sonorities and spin off, sometimes disappearing into an ether. The instrumental writing is continually varied and wondrously strange.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Stacy Cowley, Quentin Hardy and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: To Lead or Disrupt?
abstract: No third-party candidate has made it to the White House. What makes politicians like Gary Johnson of the Libertarian Party or the independent Evan McMullin run for the presidency?
lead_paragraph: No third-party candidate has made it to the White House. What makes politicians like Gary Johnson of the Libertarian Party or the independent Evan McMullin run for the presidency?

headline: Fall Bridal Trends
abstract: The fall 2017 bridal collections included off-the-shoulder creations and even thigh-high satin boots.
lead_paragraph: The fall 2017 bridal collections included off-the-shoulder creations and even thigh-high satin boots.

headline: The Maverick Bride
abstract: Last week, designers introduced their fall 2017 bridal collections. Look for off-the-shoulder creations, perhaps even thigh-high satin boots.
lead_paragraph: Brides will be brides, or so convention has it, cherishing gauzy fantasies of alabaster princess gowns trailing regal yards of tulle.

headline: Review: ‘Berlin Station,’ the Hunt for a C.I.A. Whistle-Blower
abstract: In this new spy drama from Epix, the agency is battling its own Edward Snowden.
lead_paragraph: Olen Steinhauer is a successful espionage novelist (his latest is “All the Old Knives”) who’s now created a television series, “Berlin Station,” for the premium-cable channel Epix. It appears to be his first dramatic work, and as rookie efforts go, it’s more than solid.

headline: Clinton, Trump, Cuba: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: ‘Stuffed’ Details Fights Women Wage With Their Weight
abstract: The play, written by and starring Lisa Lampanelli, is a patchwork of standup comedy and monologues that are only loosely sewn together.
lead_paragraph: The strange thing about “Stuffed,” the new ensemble piece by Lisa Lampanelli, is that she’s the only one in its cast of four who is portraying a real person. Long established as an insult comic with a tough-broad stage persona, she plays herself in this WP Theater production, unveiling her issues with food and fat for public consumption.

headline: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Regrets Speaking Out on Colin Kaepernick
abstract: The justice, who had criticized the 49er quarterback’s on-field protests against racial injustice, said her comments were “inappropriately dismissive and harsh.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg issued a statement on Friday expressing regret for her critical comments on protests by San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick and other National Football League players seeking to draw attention to police brutality and racial injustice.

headline: Higher Prices Dim the Appeal of Dividend-Paying Stocks
abstract: As dividend-paying stocks have become more expensive, investors have been forced to seek other options.
lead_paragraph: Dividend-paying stocks have had a terrific run for the last five years and already have double-digit gains in the first three quarters of 2016.

headline: De Blasio’s Police Reform Pledges May Burden His Re-election Bid
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Bill de Blasio, caught between his soaring rhetoric as a candidate and the realities of being New York City’s mayor, is disappointing many who supported him.
lead_paragraph: As Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York turns toward his re-election fight next year, an issue that galvanized his first run — achieving significant police reform — is suddenly becoming a liability.

headline: Louis Stettner, Photographer of Everyday Poetry
abstract: Mr. Stettner, who died on Thursday at 93, had an unerring eye for life in New York and Paris, the two cities he called his “spiritual mothers.”
lead_paragraph: Mr. Stettner, who died on Thursday at 93, had an unerring eye for life in New York and Paris, the two cities he called his “spiritual mothers.”

headline: How Three Strong-Performing Funds Pick Stocks
abstract: Big, Small, American, Chinese: Different stocks produced outstanding results for investors and the funds that hold them.
lead_paragraph: Many stock-picking styles have sizzled lately, with growth and value and domestic and international investing all toting up gains. Three of the better-performing mutual funds of recent months found their winners among small- and large-cap growth stocks and Chinese shares.

headline: FM Stations That Don’t Reach Far, but Reach Deep
abstract: With broadcast ranges as little as five miles, Low Power FM stations are finding loyal niche audiences not afraid to touch that dial.
lead_paragraph: They would seem to make odd broadcasting bedfellows: the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and the Global Service Center for Quitting Chinese Communist Party. Yet the two organizations are partnering on the airwaves, with two radio stations starting next month at 105.5 FM in Queens.

headline: Trump’s Comments and Your Relationship
abstract: We’d like to hear how the allegations of sexual misconduct against Donald J. Trump are playing out in people’s relationships. Please share your story with us.
lead_paragraph: We’d like to hear how the allegations of sexual misconduct against Donald J. Trump are playing out in people’s relationships. Please share your story with us.

headline: Behind Putin’s Combativeness, Some See Motives Other Than Syria
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Some analysts believe the Russian leader’s strong response to criticism from Western leaders may be a way to deflect attention from simmering domestic problems.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Somewhat obscured by the volatile American presidential election this week was the implosion of relations between the Kremlin and the West.

headline: Death Sentences Require Unanimous Jury, Florida Supreme Court Rules
abstract: The State Supreme Court reached the decision after an earlier law requiring the assent of 10 of 12 jurors was ruled unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: The Florida Supreme Court ruled Friday that the death penalty cannot be imposed without the unanimous support of a jury, deepening the recent turmoil around capital punishment in a state with a long history of executions.

headline: There’s Such a Thing as Too Much Neuroscience
abstract: In mental health research, clinical studies deserve more funding.
lead_paragraph: The United States government recently announced its new director of the National Institute of Mental Health, Dr. Joshua Gordon. If you think that’s just bureaucracy as usual, think again. Mental health research, under the leadership of the previous director, Dr. Thomas Insel, underwent a quiet crisis, one with worrisome implications for the treatment of mental health. I hope Dr. Gordon will resolve it.

headline: Flush and Dominant, Australia’s Banks Come Under Pressure
abstract: Claims of misconduct have put big lenders under a spotlight and offer an example to global regulators scrutinizing “too big to fail” institutions.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Dr. Benjamin Koh felt it was obvious what his employer wanted: to avoid paying the claim of a terminally ill customer.

headline: Politics Trumps Gender in the Selection of a U.N. Leader
abstract: The candidacies of the seven women vying to become the next secretary general collapsed from what critics called a clubby culture dominated by men.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — In the end, politics trumped gender.

headline: The King Who Personified Thailand
abstract: King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who died on Thursday, was beloved for his leadership despite of political turmoil in his country during a 70-year reign.
lead_paragraph: He was a curious amalgam of modern and feudal: an American-born, Swiss-educated king who could not be criticized under Thailand’s stern lèse-majesté laws; an accomplished sailor, painter and saxophonist who once jammed with Benny Goodman, but before whom his subjects had to prostrate themselves; a constitutional monarch with limited powers who commanded a vast fortune and was accorded almost divine status; a head of state whose reign was punctuated by a progression of bad governments and coups, yet was loved by his countrymen.

headline: Team Sky Tried to Rise Above Doping and Landed in an Ethics Quagmire
keywords: ['Doping (Sports)', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: Many, including members of the successful British cycling team itself, believe it is pushing the rules by using the World Anti-Doping Agency’s therapeutic-exemption system to its advantage.
lead_paragraph: When Britain’s Team Sky made its debut in 2010, two things dominated its agenda. It planned to develop a British Tour de France winner within five years and to do so with a zero-tolerance approach to doping.

headline: 3 Held in Bomb Plot Against Somalis in Kansas
keywords: ['Muslim Americans', 'Somali-Americans', 'Terrorism', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: The men scouted out an apartment complex in Garden City, Kan., stockpiled guns and composed a manifesto about their anti-Muslim motives, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Three militia members plotted to detonate a bomb at a housing complex in western Kansas where Somali immigrants lived and worshiped, federal investigators said Friday.

headline: In New York City, Hundreds Become U.S. Citizens Just in Time to Vote
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: In three ceremonies on Friday, 685 people were sworn in as Americans, the latest in a national wave preceding the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: In a packed federal courtroom in Brooklyn on Friday, it was one-stop shopping for 262 New Yorkers: They became American citizens and registered to vote — all from their seats and just before the deadline.

headline: Pierre Étaix, Director and Slapstick Actor, Dies at 87
abstract: Legal issues prevented the films of Mr. Étaix from being screened for decades.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Étaix, a French director of seamlessly choreographed slapstick films, including “Happy Anniversary,” which won an Oscar for best live-action short subject in 1963, died on Friday in Paris. He was 87.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Governor Warns of Fiscal ‘Death Spiral’
abstract: Meeting in New York with the panel charged with addressing the island’s debt, Alejandro García Padilla asked help in lobbying Congress for assistance.
lead_paragraph: Reach for your wallets. It is going to be expensive to pull America’s largest territory out of its death spiral, Puerto Rico’s outgoing governor warned the island’s new federal oversight board on Friday.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, October 15, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I just want to send him to heaven. He did so much for us.”

headline: 2 Face Hate Crime Charges in Attack on Sikh Man in California
abstract: The two men punched the victim in the face and used a knife to cut up to 10 inches of his hair, which was unshorn by religious mandate, a prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: Two men in California were charged with hate crimes on Friday in connection with an attack on a Sikh man, punching him in the face and using a knife to cut up to 10 inches of his hair, which was unshorn by religious mandate, a prosecutor said.

headline: De Blasio Calls for Change in Law That Blocks Release of Police Disciplinary Actions
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio wants to alter a statute that has been an obstacle to sharing information on police misconduct.
lead_paragraph: In the face of mounting criticism of his record on transparency, Mayor Bill de Blasio called for changing a state law that the city has said blocks the release of details about disciplinary actions taken against New York City police officers.

headline: How Turned Off Are Voters? Check Out Tommy’s Diner
abstract: The Columbus, Ohio, establishment draws voters across the political spectrum. This year they share a distaste for both major-party candidates.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — So here we are, nearing the end of 2016’s he-said, she-said race to the bottom. Through it all, through his ugly caricatures of Mexicans and Muslims, through her pretzel contortions to explain her emails, through the Russian hacking and the 3 a.m. Twitter rants and the rest, this was always going to be a “hold your nose and vote” election.

headline: Donald Trump’s Barrage of Heated Rhetoric Has Little Precedent
abstract: His near-apocalyptic warnings, accusations and crude innuendo are nearly unheard-of in modern campaigns, unnerving Republicans and enraging Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There is a long tradition of presidential candidates ratcheting up their language when they are trailing in the closing weeks of an election.

headline: Tim Tebow Is a Hit With the Fans and Hitless on the Field
abstract: The former N.F.L. quarterback is clearly good for business, but whether baseball is good for him remains to be seen.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The player came to home plate, bat in hand, and was greeted by the opposing catcher, Nick Ciuffo, who is acquainted with most of his opponents in the Arizona Fall League from a youth spent on baseball diamonds.

headline: For New York’s Foulest Waterways, a Seat of Dubious Honor
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Rivers', 'Water', 'Sewers and Sewage', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: The annual Golden Toilet Awards recognize some of the most polluted waters in and around New York City. This year’s winner was the Bronx Kill.
lead_paragraph: “The hardware is here,” Rob Buchanan said, wheeling in the trophies on Thursday night for an unusual award ceremony.

headline: U.S. Deficit Increases to $587 Billion, Ending Downward Trend
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The Obama administration said that the six-year string of declining annual deficits came to an end with the fiscal year 2016.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration confirmed on Friday that a six-year run of declining annual budget deficits had halted: The shortfall for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 was $587 billion, an increase over last year in dollars and as a percentage of the economy.

headline: Relieve, and Achieve, in the Postseason
abstract: Dominant starters are no longer the norm, as playoff teams are relying more on an aggressive use of their bullpens to carry them to success.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The American League Championship Series opened here Friday with news that Trevor Bauer, who was scheduled to start Saturday for the Cleveland Indians, had sliced the pinkie of his pitching hand … while performing routine maintenance on a drone.

headline: Left Behind by a Fallen Soldier, and Fighting Flashbacks 10 Years Later
abstract: Since First Sgt. Charles Monroe King was killed in combat in Iraq, the writer has settled into a new normal, though the scars are still healing.
lead_paragraph: I have been fighting sleep every night this week to keep the flashbacks from flooding in. They are flashes of the day when two military officers showed up at my door. The day I screamed so loud I scared my baby and then collapsed onto the hardwood floor. The day my soldier, First Sgt. Charles Monroe King, was killed in combat in Iraq.

headline: Friday Night Music: I’m With Her Does Dylan
abstract: A bit of harmony for a disharmonious time.
lead_paragraph: I’ve posted other performances of this song by this band, but this is a good one — and topical this week!

headline: Dodgers’ Dave Roberts Isn’t Managing Like a Rookie
abstract: Whether going to his setup man in the third inning or his ace starter in the ninth, Roberts is making all the right moves.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Watching the thrilling theater of Game 5 of the National League division series against the Washington Nationals unfold on Thursday night, Los Angeles Dodgers General Manager Farhan Zaidi was filled with pride. His rookie manager, Dave Roberts, was pulling the right strings — some of them unconventional — to propel his team to the National League Championship Series.

headline: Nicolás Maduro Flexes New Budgetary Muscles in Venezuela
abstract: A legal expert called the budget “openly unconstitutional” after a Supreme Court decision stripped the National Assembly of its power of the purse.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuela’s new annual budget resembled those of past years. Millions of dollars were promised for social programs like housing and education. Money would be earmarked for local governments to police the streets and repair potholes.

headline: El Salvador Wins Dispute Over Denying a Mining Permit
abstract: An international arbitration panel ruled that the government did not have to pay compensation to Pac Rim Cayman for denying it a concession to drill for gold.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The government of El Salvador won a long-running legal battle on Friday when an international arbitration panel ruled that it did not have to pay compensation to a mining company that was denied a concession to drill for gold.

headline: The Coming Battle for Mosul
abstract: The hardest part may be putting in place effective long-term plans to maintain stability and rebuild the shattered city.
lead_paragraph: The coming battle to retake Mosul in northern Iraq could be a turning point in the American-led fight against the Islamic State. The city is the terrorist group’s stronghold in that country and critical to its claim to having established a caliphate.

headline: Help Teachers Before They Get to Class
abstract: Teacher-training programs in the United States are woefully inadequate.
lead_paragraph: The countries that have eclipsed the United States in educational achievement have far more effective systems for training teachers. Consider, for example, Finland’s system, which has consistently ranked among the best in the world. Decades ago, Finland moved teacher education out of teachers colleges and into universities, where students are given rigorous preparation and recruited from the top quarter of their graduating high school classes.

headline: N.J. Transit Getting Scrutiny and Pledges of Aid for Its Problems
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Transit Systems', 'Delays (Transportation)', 'Transportation', 'Gasoline Tax (US)', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Hudson River Tunnels Project']
abstract: State legislators set hearings on the agency’s woes, while a federal official said the process of lining up grants and loans for a new rail tunnel was underway.
lead_paragraph: State lawmakers in New Jersey moved on Friday to hold hearings focused on investigating the problems plaguing New Jersey Transit, and a top federal official announced that a key project meant to improve the railroad’s service was moving forward.

headline: Hen Tracks
abstract: Mark Diehl offers us a fun Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Once you take on the challenge of conquering — or at least trying — a Saturday New York Times crossword puzzle, it’s important to let go of the notion that your wheelhouse is always, reliably your wheelhouse. You’ll discover that you have a lot to learn, and that’s not a bad mind-set. Zen Buddhists call that shoshin, or Beginner’s Mind.

headline: Judge Dismisses Suit Against Gun Maker by Newtown Victims’ Families
keywords: ['Firearms', 'Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The lawsuit, filed by relatives of victims of the Sandy Hook Elementary School attack, questioned assault rifles’ availability to civilians.
lead_paragraph: A Connecticut judge has dismissed a lawsuit filed by relatives of victims of the Sandy Hook Elementary School attack, delivering a blow to an ambitious effort to hold accountable the makers of the assault rifle used in the 2012 massacre before the case ever went to trial.

headline: How to Get Away With Doping
abstract: The legal loophole of a doctor’s note is enabling athletes to cheat with performance-enhancing drugs. I know because I did.
lead_paragraph: Manchester, England — In 2004, I was in a French prison cell, arrested by a Paris drug squad on the order of an examining magistrate, a powerful official in the French criminal justice system. It was right that I should have been there: I had broken the law — as it turned out, not French law, but sporting law. I had taken performance-enhancing drugs and I had won some of the biggest races in the sport of cycling, including a World Championship title. I had cheated.

headline: On the Trail: Week of Oct. 9
abstract: The week began with the second presidential debate and ended with Hillary Clinton scaling back her schedule while Donald J. Trump accused her campaign and the news media of conspiring against him.
lead_paragraph: The week began with the second presidential debate and ended with Hillary Clinton scaling back her schedule while Donald J. Trump accused her campaign and the news media of conspiring against him.

headline: F.B.I. Memos on the Black Panther Party
abstract: These documents, made public during a civil suit brought by a former Black Panther, Dhoruba al-Mujahid bin Wahad, in the 1980s, show that the F.B.I. exploited press coverage in its efforts to undermine the group.
lead_paragraph: These documents, made public during a civil suit brought by a former Black Panther, Dhoruba al-Mujahid bin Wahad, in the 1980s, show that the F.B.I. exploited press coverage in its efforts to undermine the group.

headline: Accuser’s Acquaintances Testify as Derrick Rose Trial Nears End
abstract: Proceedings will resume on Tuesday with final witnesses and possibly closing arguments.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Derrick Rose’s civil rape trial concluded its second week Friday, with his fate undecided but nearing a resolution.

headline: By Limiting Damage, Indians Get off to a Fast Start Against the Blue Jays
abstract: Corey Kluber’s pitching and a sixth-inning two-run homer by Francisco Lindor allowed Cleveland to claim Game 1 in the American League Championship Series.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Toronto Blue Jays muscled their way to the American League Championship Series, blasting 10 home runs in four games before meeting the Cleveland Indians in Game 1 on Friday. The teams had played seven games in the regular season, and Toronto had homered in all of them.

headline: Christina Wang and Brian Lam: Smitten With Seafood, Beset by Bees
abstract: A couple meets over a delectable dish of king crab, and grows closer after a swarm of bees finds a target.
lead_paragraph: Christina Jessica Wang, a daughter of Daisy Wang and Peter Kin-Chung Wang of Hong Kong, was married Oct. 15 to Brian Sze-Tsung Lam, the son of Marie W. Lam and Shau Wai Lam of Summit, N.J. Bernard Lang, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Wauwinet Hotel in Nantucket, Mass.

headline: Corrections: October 15, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, October 15, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Louisville Sews Up Win After a Mistake by Duke
abstract: A roughing the kicker penalty on a missed field goal set up a touchdown run by Cardinals quarterback Lamar Jackson
lead_paragraph: Lamar Jackson provided a cushion with a 2-yard touchdown run with 1 minute 32 seconds remaining, and No. 7 Louisville held off visiting Duke, 24-14, on Friday night.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Captain Fantastic’ and Emily Blunt on ‘S.N.L.’
abstract: Viggo Mortensen goes off the grid in “Captain Fantastic.” And Ms. Blunt takes the “Saturday Night Live” stage.
lead_paragraph: Viggo Mortensen goes off the grid — and then comes back again — in “Captain Fantastic.” Sarah Paulson and Mark Duplass play former teenage lovers who unexpectedly reconnect in “Blue Jay.” And Emily Blunt takes the “Saturday Night Live” stage.

headline: Nations, Fighting Powerful Refrigerant That Warms Planet, Reach Landmark Deal
keywords: ['Hydrofluorocarbons', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A binding accord on a heat-trapping chemical used in air-conditioners and refrigerators could have a greater impact on global warming than the Paris pact of 2015.
lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — Negotiators from more than 170 countries on Saturday reached a legally binding accord to counter climate change by cutting the worldwide use of a powerful planet-warming chemical used in air-conditioners and refrigerators.

headline: Everybody Hates a Winner: A Brooklyn High School Football Coach Inspires and Exasperates
abstract: The dismissal of Bruce Eugene, the coach of the Grand Street Campus Wolves in Brooklyn, has locked players, parents and administrators in a bitter dispute.
lead_paragraph: Last December, on a cold, sunny morning at Yankee Stadium, Bruce Eugene, the head football coach of the Grand Street Campus Wolves, took his players on a slow walk through the grounds to calm their nerves. Though they would soon be playing for the Public Schools Athletic League championship, this field, he assured them, was no different than their turf back in Brooklyn.

headline: ‘I Regret Not Standing Up to Him for That’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: A reader recounts her unpleasant interaction with Donald Trump, while others discuss Bob Dylan’s Nobel Prize and racism against Asian-Americans.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: How Did Walmart Get Cleaner Stores and Higher Sales? It Paid Its People More
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Productivity', 'Vocational Training', 'Customer Relations']
abstract: Can the answer to what ails the global economy be found in the people in blue vests at your neighborhood Walmart?
lead_paragraph: BENTONVILLE, Ark. — A couple of years ago, Walmart, which once built its entire branding around a big yellow smiley face, was creating more than its share of frowns.

headline: Magnate’s Twin Goals: Fighting Climate Change and Electing Donald Trump
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: Andrew Sabin, who made a fortune recycling precious metals, is a political paradox, throwing his wallet behind climate change initiatives and the Republican nominee.
lead_paragraph: MONTAUK, N.Y. — On a sunny morning late this summer, Andrew E. Sabin was aboard his 60-foot yacht, “Above the Ground.” He had begun the day in Amagansett, a well-heeled enclave near East Hampton where he maintains a lush seven-acre compound replete with a menagerie featuring peacocks and an enormous pig. Now, on the eastern tip of Long Island, Mr. Sabin pierced a clam with a hook and dropped his fishing line 120 feet to the ocean floor, hoping to land some cod.

headline: The art of making (and not making) plans
abstract: If technology has made canceling plans too easy, how about a radically different approach? Make fewer to begin with.
lead_paragraph: Adult life is full of commitments: bills to pay, family to see and a job you probably have to show up for. But in a world where many of us complain of being overscheduled, there’s something uniquely depressing about having no control over the time once quaintly called “personal” and “free.”

headline: A Onetime BuzzFeed Wunderkind, Now at CNN
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Television']
abstract: Known for his campaign scoops, the digital boy wonder Andrew Kaczynski has grown up and moved on.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Kaczynski, the 26-year-old reporter who dug up evidence showing that Donald J. Trump had supported the invasion of Iraq before the war, was Google-chatting with Tim Miller, a Republican operative who was the communications director for the Jeb Bush presidential campaign.

headline: Houston’s Coach Pecks Away at Football’s Macho Culture, a Kiss at a Time
abstract: Tom Herman’s rite of kissing and hugging his players has earned praise from psychologists who say players are motivated by a desire to be in connected communities.
lead_paragraph: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — When the University of Houston’s football players arrive for a game, they know what to expect as a prelude to the coming hours of brutality as they file into the stadium: a kiss on the cheek from their head coach, Tom Herman.

headline: Scenes of New York
abstract: One photographer’s view of city residents in their element.
lead_paragraph: One photographer’s view of city residents in their element.

headline: As Seen on the Streets
abstract: It’s stylish — but don’t call it street style.
lead_paragraph: The photographer of this series, Daniel Weiss, 29, was born in New York City and grew up on the Upper West Side. He had two big interests, which fed each other: skateboarding and photography.

headline: The Power Pastor: How A.R. Bernard Built a New York Megachurch
abstract: The reverend’s intellectualism and distinctive brand of man-up Christianity draws a wide audience to his church, the largest in New York.
lead_paragraph: One Saturday in mid-September, the Rev. A. R. Bernard took to the blue carpeted stage of the Christian Cultural Center, the 96,000-square-foot megachurch he built 16 years ago at the edge of Starrett City, in Brooklyn, with his usual accouterments: a smartphone, a bottle of water and a large glass marker board that he would soon cover in bullet points drawn from the playbooks of marketing specialists. Mr. Bernard, 63, is tall and slender, and on this day he wore a distressed black leather jacket, a white polo shirt, bluejeans and white tennis shoes — casual Saturday attire. On Sunday, you would find him impeccably tailored in a light wool suit and tortoiseshell glasses, looking more like the banker he once was than the pastor of a congregation of nearly 40,000.

headline: Discounts on Ranch Vacations (Riding Included)
abstract: Horseback riding vacations can be pricey, but a number of ranches in the West offer notable deals.
lead_paragraph: Horseback riding has long been considered a costly pursuit, especially when payment for individual rides is required. Choosing an all-inclusive ranch is one way to keep costs down, and there is an additional value when those properties offer specials.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss the A Little Variety puzzles.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: How the U.S. Became More Involved in the War in Yemen
abstract: The United States has become more directly involved in Yemen’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: The United States has become more directly involved in Yemen’s civil war.

headline: Jim’s and Nick’s Week in Tech: Smoldering Phones, the Yahoo Markdown and Amazon Music
abstract: Sometimes people forget that old guys can be geeks. This week: How Samsung helped Apple, will Verizon win a discount, and a new riff on a classic excuse.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Jim Kerstetter, the deputy technology editor in San Francisco, and Nick Wingfield, technology reporter in Seattle, are filling in for Farhad and Mike this week.

headline: Is the Market for New York Apartments Softening?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Gone are the days when you could list your apartment and watch the offers roll in.
lead_paragraph: Q. Last spring, we put our Upper West Side apartment on the market. It is a two-bedroom in mint condition with wraparound views, and we listed it for a little over $2 million. Ten days later, our agent suggested lowering the price because she said the market was suddenly soft. After about four weeks, we took the apartment off the market. I have noticed that many comparable apartments are now off the market, too. Is the overall market soft? Are two-bedrooms the problem? Is it my neighborhood?

headline: Saudi-Led Coalition Says It Bombed Yemen Funeral Based on False Information
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The admission after the attack, which killed more than 100 people, was a rare acknowledgment by the coalition that it had hit a civilian site.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A Saudi-led military coalition involved in Yemen’s war acknowledged on Saturday that one of its jets carried out an attack on a funeral this month in the Yemeni capital, Sana, that killed more than 100 people and wounded hundreds of others.

headline: India Police Pressed to Act in Girl’s Death After Fast
abstract: The girl was a devoted follower of Jainism, a religion that celebrates radical acts of renunciation. Her parents may faces charges of culpable homicide in her death.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The police in south India are under increasing pressure to take action in the case of a 13-year-old girl who went into cardiac arrest after completing a 68-day religious fast.

headline: Rise of Saudi Prince Shatters Decades of Royal Tradition
abstract: Prince Mohammed bin Salman has quickly emerged as the most dynamic royal in the Arab world’s wealthiest nation, setting up a potential rivalry for the throne.
lead_paragraph: He has slashed the state budget, frozen government contracts and reduced the pay of civil employees, all part of drastic austerity measures as the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is buffeted by low oil prices.

headline: A Meeting Place Filled With Noted Designers
abstract: Andrew Cogan, chief executive of the furniture design company Knoll, decorated his office with current and archived pieces, and some that remained prototypes.
lead_paragraph: ‘Mad Men’ and MoMA

headline: Your Phone’s on Lockdown. Enjoy the Show.
abstract: Yondr, a lockable pouch, holds fans’ cellphones during a performance, making it impossible to take photographs, shoot videos or send text messages.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Dave Chappelle used to hate when fans would pull out smartphones during his act, record the performance and then post it on YouTube and social media before the show had even ended. To him, the fans seemed more interested in getting the perfect shot than in appreciating his stand-up routine.

headline: A Linguist Who Cracks the Code in Names to Predict Ethnicity
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Names, Personal', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Software', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: Lisa Spira is director of research and product development at Ethnic Technologies, which determines ethnic origins of prospective customers.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Spira, 30, is director of research and product development at Ethnic Technologies in South Hackensack, N.J.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon return to tell us what’s good for us.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Vitamins and nutrition happen to be an area of interest of mine, so I was happy to learn what I did from today’s quote in our acrostic. VITAMIN A really can be a MIRACLE CURE if it is made accessible to populations who are deficient in it.

headline: Let the Boss Leave the Book Club
abstract: Readers wonder if supervisors and workers can socialize comfortably (sometimes) and whether happiness at work should justify limited opportunities (maybe).
lead_paragraph: For over five years, I’ve been a member of a book discussion group that includes two co-workers from the midsize company I work for. The group is purely a social gathering and is not work related in any way. None of our other colleagues are members.

headline: The ExoMars Spacecraft Arrives at the Red Planet
abstract: The ExoMars spacecraft is now orbiting Mars.
lead_paragraph: The ExoMars spacecraft is now orbiting Mars.

headline: For Paul Ryan, a Long, Labored Path Leading Away From Donald Trump
abstract: The House speaker, no fan from the start, struggles to safeguard his party’s control of Congress while declining to defend the billionaire candidate’s every misstep.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He didn’t see it coming.

headline: With a Little Luck for a Change, the Cubs Amassed a Fortune
abstract: The Cubs’ revival as the best team in the majors arose in part because they had some breaks that allowed a center fielder, a pitcher and a manager to fall into their laps.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When Theo Epstein wanted to trade Ryan Dempster, one of the few coveted assets he had inherited when he signed on as the Chicago Cubs’ president of baseball operations, it did not appear as if Dempster was doing him any favors.

headline: Donald Trump and Other Animals
abstract: I compared him to an insect. But maybe that didn’t go far enough.
lead_paragraph: I once interviewed Donald Trump for a magazine story. The topic was rivalries, which seemed like a natural for him. But he was so bombastically short on specifics, so braggadociously vague, that in the end there was nothing to quote. I left him out of the story.

headline: As a Black Republican Senator, Tim Scott Faces a Unique Donald Trump Issue
abstract: Instead of defending Mr. Trump, Mr. Scott argues that Hillary Clinton and her fellow Democrats are just as bad on race matters.
lead_paragraph: CLEMSON, S.C. — The event, technically, was the screening of a documentary about conservative solutions to poverty. But the big draw for the nearly all-white audience of Clemson University students was Tim Scott, the only black Republican in the United States Senate — and the walking proof, to Republicans here, that they have moved beyond the old white tribalism that once defined them.

headline: Ang Lee’s Plea: Give ‘Billy Lynn’ a Chance
abstract: He gambled on hyperreal visuals for the drama, a look that has been heavily criticized before. At the New York Film Festival, the reaction was mixed.
lead_paragraph: “Please give this a chance. Have an open mind. Enjoy the show.”

headline: Minnows of the Sports World Nip the Titles From the Whales
abstract: Most of the titleholders in American professional sports are small-market franchises, a situation in need of correction.
lead_paragraph: The Cleveland Indians must be stopped, for the sake of equality, justice and proportional representation.

headline: Urging Blacks to Vote for Clinton for Obama’s Sake, and Their Own
abstract: A new ad for Hillary Clinton argues that a vote for her is a vote to preserve President Obama’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: With the Trump campaign seemingly taking on more water every day, Hillary Clinton is shifting into voter-turnout mode. This ad — aptly titled “Show Up” — seeks to persuade African-Americans to cast their ballots as if their lives, or at least their civil rights, depend on it.

headline: With Idols in Ranks, South Korean Army Steps to a K-Pop Beat
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Music']
abstract: Military service is compulsory for young men, even celebrities, who perform in military bands and at an annual promotional festival.
lead_paragraph: GYERYONG, South Korea — The audience applauded politely as the honor guard twirled its rifles, and oohed and aahed at the acrobatic taekwondo demonstration. But the real excitement began when the army band appeared.

headline: Listen to Bob Dylan’s Many Influences
keywords: ['Nobel Prizes', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Folk Music', 'Country Music']
abstract: As Bob Dylan has said, his songs “didn’t get here by themselves.” Here’s a sampler of his influences, from Woody Guthrie to the Kinks, alongside the tracks he made famous.
lead_paragraph: As Bob Dylan has said, his songs “didn’t get here by themselves.” Here’s a sampler of his influences, from Woody Guthrie to the Kinks, alongside the tracks he made famous.

headline: Nostalgia for the Grace of George H.W. Bush
abstract: The journey from Bush to Trump disproves Darwin.
lead_paragraph: The suggestion, the vice president told his 1988 campaign diary, was “strange and unbelievable.” Twenty-eight years ago, George H. W. Bush, fresh from securing the Republican presidential nomination to succeed Ronald Reagan, was about to choose a running mate of his own. His campaign manager, Lee Atwater, always on the lookout for the unconventional and the unexpected, had apparently had informal talks with Donald J. Trump, the New York developer.

headline: If Hillary Clinton Groped Men
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Discrimination', 'Gender', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Women and Girls']
