lead_paragraph: About 200 people walked out of an Amy Schumer show in Tampa, Fla., on Sunday after she criticized Donald J. Trump onstage, The Tampa Bay Times reported.

headline: A Deli Feast for Football Fans
abstract: A platter of corned beef, pastrami and other deli sandwich favorites is now available nationwide from Katz’s Delicatessen.
lead_paragraph: They say it feeds six to eight; I’d say a few more. Either way, it’s a pregame feast of New York deli specialties: corned beef, pastrami, Swiss cheese and rye bread, all sliced and ready to pile into sandwiches, with condiments and pickles included. Pigs in blankets and salami, too. The package is shipped for two-day delivery: Katz’s Delicatessen Game Day Package, $175, katzsdelicatessen.com/game-day-package.html.

headline: The Shadowy Line Between Friendly Sales Pitch and Deception
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Private Placements (Non-Public Offerings) and Mini IPOs']
abstract: The S.E.C. sued the Texas attorney general for securities fraud related to his role promoting Servergy, a tech company, but a judge rejected the agency’s claims.
lead_paragraph: When a friend or business acquaintance pitches an investment as a surefire winner, there can be a question about when that cajoling crosses over from mere sales talk to fraud. A recent case in Texas involving the state’s attorney general, Ken Paxton, shows finding that line can be difficult.

headline: Looks Like a Toolbox, Sizzles Like a Grill
abstract: This portable barbecue is a handy gadget for autumn tailgates and impromptu gatherings.
lead_paragraph: It’s fire-engine red and fitted with trays that fold out like a typical toolbox, but this grill is designed to hold smoldering charcoal briquettes along with a couple of rib-eyes, a dozen hot dogs or around six burgers on a series of stainless steel grates and racks. There’s even a warming tray for rolls. The air flow is adjustable, and it folds conveniently for carrying: Tool Box Grill, $125, Annie’s Blue Ribbon General Store, 232 Fifth Avenue (Carroll Street), Park Slope, Brooklyn, 718-522-9848, blueribbongeneralstore.com.

headline: ExoMars, Poised to Reach Red Planet and Gather Clues
abstract: The spacecraft is to arrive at the red planet on Wednesday, perhaps providing important clues about geological process, or even hints of life.
lead_paragraph: ExoMars 2016, a spacecraft launched by the European and Russian space agencies, is to arrive at the red planet on Wednesday and begin gathering data on gases that are barely present in the atmosphere but may provide important clues about geological processes, or even hints of life.

headline: Jared Kushner Talks of a Trump TV Network With a Media Deal Maker
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Television', 'News and News Media', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Mr. Kushner, Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law, informally reached out to a veteran media investment banker, who is also a friend, about setting up the channel.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law has discussed the possibility of a Trump-branded television network with a friend who has helped guide such deals.

headline: Planets Spinning the ‘Wrong’ Way
abstract: There are theories, but no certainty, for why Venus rotates clockwise. In the solar system, only Venus and Uranus do so.
lead_paragraph: Q. I read that Venus is the only planet to rotate clockwise. What dictates the direction of rotation?

headline: Dumpling Options Abound Downtown
abstract: Mimi Cheng’s and Nom Wah Tea Parlor open second outposts of their restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Two popular dumpling restaurants are expanding. The sisters Hannah and Marian Cheng are opening a spinoff of their East Village dumpling shop, Mimi Cheng’s, on Wednesday. It has a sleek counter where customers select freshly made dumplings (steamed or pan-fried), scallion pancakes, stir-fried greens, condiments and other specials assembled in bento box assortments to eat in or take away. Nearby, there are more dumplings at a pocket-size counter-service branch of the venerable Nom Wah Tea Parlor in Chinatown. You’ll also find scallion pancakes, soup dumplings, steamed ribs, noodle soups and the kohlrabi salad from Fung Tu restaurant, where Wilson Tang, the owner of Nom Wah, is a partner: Mimi Cheng’s, 380 Broome Street (Mulberry Street), 212-343-1387, mimichengs.com;  Nom Wah NoLIta, 10 Kenmare Street (Bowery), 646-478-8242, nomwah.com.

headline: What Would New York Police Body Cameras Record?
keywords: ['Cameras', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: For several months, the Police Department has been writing a policy for when the devices should be rolling, but many questions remain.
lead_paragraph: When should police officers turn their body cameras on? Should they record interviews with people who are witnesses to crimes? What about in people’s homes?

headline: Goldman Sachs’s Asia Pacific Chairman to Retire
abstract: Mark Schwartz’s departure comes as the bank faces challenges in Asia, particularly a slowdown in investment banking in the region for all Western firms.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One of Goldman Sachs’s top bankers in Asia is planning on retiring after nearly three decades at the firm.

headline: Andrew Lloyd Webber Names Producer to Oversee North American Shows
abstract: Mr. Lloyd Webber announced Monday that his company had hired the Broadway producer Ken Davenport to the new post of executive producer for North America.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Lloyd Webber, the storied musical theater mogul, has hired the Broadway producer Ken Davenport to oversee his resurgent North American presence.

headline: How to find the perfect throw pillow
keywords: ['Beds and Bedding', 'Textiles', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Patterned throw pillows are one of the simplest and least risky ways to change the feeling of a room.
lead_paragraph: Patterned throw pillows are one of the simplest and least risky ways to change the feeling of a room. “They can make a big impact, but are really easy to switch out,” said Rebecca Atwood, a Brooklyn textile designer and the author of “Living with Pattern: Color, Texture, and Print at Home,” published recently by Clarkson Potter. “They’re certainly less of a commitment than doing a patterned sofa.”

headline: For Clinton and Trump, There’s Little Debating a Climate Change Divide
abstract: Most Americans say they are interested in the issue, but it came up only once in the first two debates and is not among topics listed for the third.
lead_paragraph: The third presidential debate, scheduled for Wednesday, might seem like a rerun. Chris Wallace, the moderator and an anchor for Fox News, has chosen topics familiar from previous debates, including debt, immigration, foreign affairs, the economy and the Supreme Court.

headline: 2016 Electoral Map Forecast
abstract: The Upshot’s forecast for the presidential race, based on the latest national and state polls.
lead_paragraph: The Upshot’s forecast for the presidential race, based on the latest national and state polls.

headline: Showing Confidence, Hillary Clinton Pushes Into Republican Strongholds
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton hopes to extend her edge over Donald J. Trump and help other Democrats in what party leaders think could become an election that swamps Republicans at every level.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s campaign is planning its most ambitious push yet into traditionally right-leaning states, a new offensive aimed at extending her growing advantage over Donald J. Trump while bolstering down-ballot candidates in what party leaders increasingly suggest could be a sweeping victory for Democrats at every level.

headline: Why Mosul Is Critical in the Battle Against ISIS
abstract: Iraq’s second-largest city was once home to more than two million residents before the Islamic State claimed it as a stronghold of its self-proclaimed caliphate.
lead_paragraph: Iraqi security forces and Kurdish pesh merga fighters have begun an assault to dislodge Islamic State militants from the city of Mosul. Here are some reasons the city is strategically and symbolically vital.

headline: How to Take Care of a Cast-Iron Pan
abstract: Seasoning with oil gives the skillet a smooth, nonstick surface.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series aimed at helping you navigate life’s opportunities and challenges. What else should we write about? Contact us: smarterliving@nytimes.com.

headline: Trump Foundation Tells New York It Has Stopped Soliciting After State Order
abstract: The state attorney general’s office said the Donald J. Trump Foundation had also requested and was granted an extension for filing its financial paperwork.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s foundation informed Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York that it has ceased soliciting donations in the state, after a recent order to halt such fund-raising efforts, a spokesman for the attorney general’s office said on Monday.

headline: Haitians, Battered by Hurricane, Huddle in Caves: ‘This Is the Only Shelter We Have’
abstract: “It is our house that God created when we most needed it,” said one of the hundreds of villagers who fled into caves as Hurricane Matthew destroyed their homes.
lead_paragraph: LACADONIE, Haiti — When the rain comes at night in these distant mountains, the people flee what homes they have left. They race down hills threaded with stones and ragged palm branches, the earth the color of rust.

headline: Florida Man Who Fired at George Zimmerman’s Car Gets 20 Years in Prison
abstract: Matthew Apperson said he had fired at Mr. Zimmerman in self-defense in 2015.
lead_paragraph: A Florida man convicted of shooting at George Zimmerman’s car last year was sentenced on Monday to 20 years in prison, ending a trial that again put Mr. Zimmerman, who was cleared in the 2012 killing of the unarmed black teenager Trayvon Martin, back in the spotlight.

headline: What You Should Watch: ‘Jane the Virgin’ and ‘30 for 30’
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

headline: Venus: Inhospitable, and Perhaps Instructional
abstract: It is hoped that a Japanese space probe, Akatsuki, orbiting Venus will provide insights that could help in understanding Earth’s weather.
lead_paragraph: Venus is not a placid paradise — that much we know. In addition to searing surface temperatures, wind in the upper atmosphere howls at up to 250 miles per hour, carrying clouds around the planet once every four days.

headline: Creative Yiddish Spoken
abstract: A reader tells of her mother’s inventive rendering of “vegetarian.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: An Updated Uffizi Is Unveiled
abstract: Gallery officials have reordered Early Renaissance rooms for “a better flow” and aim to dissipate congestion in front of Botticelli’s heaviest hitters.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE — If awards were given out among Italy’s art-rich museums, the Uffizi Gallery here would certainly vie for the greatest-hits prize, with such an abundant collection of Renaissance artworks that visitors often bypass seminal paintings in their rush to gawk at people pleasers like Botticelli’s “Spring” or “Birth of Venus.”

headline: Bureaucracy: A Good Thing
abstract: A former civil servant writes that “bureaucracy is the institutionalization of national interests.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Kudos to L.A., a Climate Change Leader
abstract: A reader praises Los Angeles for moving away from fossil fuels in the wake of a major natural gas accident.

headline: ‘Guantánamo Diary’ Writer Is Sent Home to Mauritania
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Detainees', 'Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mohamedou Ould Slahi, whose memoir detailing abuse at the prison was a best seller, denied any involvement with terrorism and was never charged.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon on Monday announced that it had repatriated a prominent Guantánamo detainee who wrote a best-selling memoir recounting his abuse by American interrogators. The transfer reduced the remaining detainee population to 60.

headline: Tracy Morgan to Star in a New TBS Comedy
abstract: TBS gave the single-camera show, about a man returning to Brooklyn after 15 years in prison, a straight-to-series order.
lead_paragraph: Tracy Morgan will return to television in a new TBS comedy whose creators include Jordan Peele, formerly one half of “Key & Peele.”

headline: Creepy Crawly Chocolates for Halloween
abstract: Spiders and webs from a chocolatier from Chicago arrive just in time for the holiday.
lead_paragraph: Just one bite and you’re trapped — you may have to finish an entire one of these smart, generous treats. The four-inch chocolate webs, complete with spider, are fashioned by Veruca Chocolates in Chicago and come three flavors to the box. Gilded dark chocolate is tangy with sea salt, milk chocolate is brushed with silver and studded with crunchy candied bits, and caramelized white chocolate has salt and cacao nibs throughout: Spider Web Bars, box of three, $16.50, mouth.com.

headline: Official Apologizes for Police Role in Mistrust by Minorities
abstract: The apology represented an unusual yet symbolic step by law enforcement, which has often dismissed any role in the tense relationship with members of minority groups.
lead_paragraph: The president of one of the nation’s largest police organizations apologized to minorities on Monday for past mistreatment by the police that has helped fuel a deepening mistrust of law enforcement within predominately black and Hispanic communities.

headline: In Refrigerators, Tomatoes Lose Flavor at the Genetic Level
abstract: Once a tomato is picked from the vine, there’s only one thing you can do to preserve its flavor: Keep it out of the fridge.
lead_paragraph: The tomato hitching a ride home in your grocery bag today is not the tomato it used to be. No matter if you bought plum, cherry or heirloom, if you wanted the tastiest tomato, you should have picked it yourself and eaten it immediately.

headline: Today’s Climate Progress and Tomorrow’s Climate Challenges
keywords: ['Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Hydrofluorocarbons', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: While there’s diplomatic momentum on addressing climate change, analysts warn of a big reality gap if the hope is actually stopping global warming.
lead_paragraph: Tracking recent headlines, you might think the world is finally on a path toward controlling global warming. On Saturday, diplomats announced a new international agreement aimed at phasing out a family of climate-warming compounds called hydrofluorocarbons, or HFCs. And earlier this month an agreement was reached to start curbing the climate impact from aviation and enough countries formally accepted the Paris Agreement on climate change to set it on a path to take legal force on Nov. 4.

headline: Leo Beranek, Acoustics Designer and Internet Pioneer, Dies at 102
abstract: Bolt, Beranek & Newman, the company he helped found, built the first computer-based network, which paved the way for the creation of the internet.
lead_paragraph: Leo L. Beranek, an engineer whose company designed the acoustics for the United Nations and concert halls at Lincoln Center and Tanglewood, then built the direct precursor to the internet under contract to the Defense Department, died on Oct. 10 at his home in Westwood, Mass. He was 102.

headline: An Insult to Women at the U.N.
abstract: A reader writes, “We need real women in decision-making positions in the United Nations to empower women, not female cartoon characters.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mosul, Duterte, Hillary Clinton: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Christopher Kimball’s Milk Street Magazine Releases First Issue
abstract: Subscriptions will not begin until February of next year, but the charter issue is ready for newsstands.
lead_paragraph: The next act for Christopher Kimball, who is no longer at America’s Test Kitchen and Cook’s Illustrated, is the new Christopher Kimball’s Milk Street Magazine, named for the Boston address of his new venture, which also includes a cooking school and media studios. The magazine has no ads, a global outlook and color photography for recipes and techniques often tweaked by the staff to improve or simplify them. Creamy scrambled eggs are cooked in olive oil, and a newfangled pie pastry recipe with cornstarch is guaranteed not to shrink, although my test did a bit. The Milk Street recipe requires enough pie weights to fill the pastry three-fourths full. That got me thinking, so I blind-baked my usual pie crust recipe, filling the pastry shell to the top with weights, and there was minimal shrinkage. It’s about the weights, not the recipe: Christopher Kimball’s Milk Street Magazine, charter issue, $6.95 at newsstands starting Tuesday, or free from 177milkstreet.com (bimonthly subscription, $19.95), 866-400-0537.

headline: Donald Trump’s Charges of a ‘Rigged’ Election
abstract: Readers discuss claims of election fraud, allegations of sexual assault, email hacking and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How the First Farmers Changed History
abstract: Skeletons from ancient settlements in the Near East are providing answers about how agriculture, and society, arose.
lead_paragraph: Beneath a rocky slope in central Jordan lie the remains of a 10,000-year-old village called Ain Ghazal, whose inhabitants lived in stone houses with timber roof beams, the walls and floors gleaming with white plaster.

headline: Charges Against Sheriff Arpaio
abstract: Prosecutors have charged Sheriff Joe Arpaio with criminal contempt of court, saying he willfully defied a judge’s orders to stop targeting Latinos in traffic stops and other law enforcement efforts.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors have charged Sheriff Joe Arpaio with criminal contempt of court, saying he willfully defied a judge’s orders to stop targeting Latinos in traffic stops and other law enforcement efforts.

headline: Sheriff Joe Arpaio, Accused of Targeting Latinos, Is Charged With Contempt
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Racial Profiling', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Prosecutors said Sheriff Arpaio, of Maricopa County, Ariz., had willfully defied a judge’s orders to stop discriminatory policing.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Federal prosecutors on Monday charged Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County with criminal contempt of court, saying he willfully defied a judge’s orders to stop targeting Latinos — including citizens and legal immigrants — in traffic stops and other law enforcement efforts, behavior the judge said showed a pattern of discriminatory policing.

headline: Andrew Cyrille’s Late-Career Renaissance
abstract: With his two new albums, “The Declaration of Musical Independence” and “Proximity,” this jazz drummer displays his insight and ingenuity.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Cyrille opens one of his two new albums, “The Declaration of Musical Independence,” with a syncopated figure on a snare drum, as taut and riveting as a military cadence. Then he adds cymbals and kick drum, giving the phrase a sinuous curve just as the rest of the band enters. What they’re playing is “Coltrane Time,” an obscure piece by John Coltrane, and Mr. Cyrille shows the way forward with a regal, flowing self-possession.

headline: James Cartwright, Ex-General, Pleads Guilty in Leak Case
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of']
abstract: The retired Marine pleaded guilty to lying to the F.B.I. about his discussions with reporters about a cyberattack on Iran’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — James E. Cartwright, a retired Marine Corps general who as vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff served as a key member of President Obama’s national security team, agreed to plead guilty on Monday to lying to the F.B.I. about his discussions with reporters about Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Video Shows Siamak Namazi, American Businessman Held by Iran
abstract: The video showed the first images of Mr. Namazi — who is also a citizen of Iran — since his arrest a year ago, hinting that formal charges may soon be lodged.
lead_paragraph: An Iranian-American businessman arrested in Iran a year ago was seen publicly for the first time Monday in a video posted online by the country’s judicial news service, which seemed to hint that he would be accused of espionage.

headline: ‘Cansados Pies’
abstract: “Cansados Pies,” by Dúo Benítez Valencia
lead_paragraph: “Cansados Pies,” by Dúo Benítez Valencia

headline: Review: In ‘More,’ Dispatches From Hell by a Human Trafficker
abstract: This novel by Hakan Gunday is a vivid tour of the nightmares endured by refugees headed to Europe, told by a young smuggler who learns to exploit them.
lead_paragraph: This disturbing new novel by Hakan Gunday, one of Turkey’s leading young writers, is like a visit to a Hieronymus Bosch hell: terrifying scenes of suffering, starvation, sadism, depravity and the agonies associated with combat zones. “More” recounts the story of a boy named Gaza who works with his father, a human trafficker, and it conveys the suffering of refugees and migrants as they try to make their way from war-torn countries like Afghanistan and Syria through Turkey and eventually on to Greece and the wider world (that is, if they survive a cascade of perils, one more awful than the next). It is also the narrator’s coming-of-age story, starting at 9 — a dark fable that traces the metamorphosis of a bright schoolboy into an appalling monster.

headline: Remembering Bill Cunningham
abstract: Notables gather at Carnegie Hall to pay tribute to the photographer, who died in June at age 87.
lead_paragraph: In March 2010, when the film “Bill Cunningham New York” had its premiere at the Museum of Modern Art, the subject of the film — the longtime New York Times photographer Bill Cunningham — stood outside on the West 53rd Street sidewalk, snapping photos of attendees as they strode into the theater. But he never went inside to the screening itself, and he always maintained that he had never seen the documentary that made him famous.

headline: A $4.36 Million Gift to Boost Dance Education
abstract: The donation will allow Teachers College at Columbia University to establish a new doctoral program to train those who train dance teachers.
lead_paragraph: As the decline of arts education in recent decades has increasingly alarmed cultural institutions, a new $4.36 million gift aims to bolster dance education by taking a different approach. The gift, from Jody Gottfried Arnhold and her husband, John, will allow Teachers College at Columbia University to establish a new doctoral program to train those who train dance teachers.

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
abstract: We asked readers — without any context — to caption a photo that ran in The New York Times. Here’s how they responded.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

headline: Review: A White Light Festival to Re-energize Your Inner Self
abstract: Lincoln Center’s main fall offering began with “human requiem,” a theatrical performance by the Berlin Radio Choir.
lead_paragraph: From its founding in 2010, the White Light Festival, Lincoln Center’s main fall offering, has had listeners wondering what exactly its title is meant to signify. Is it about religion? Transcendence? Multiculturalism? The festival trades in a sort of secular spirituality, aimed at illuminating, in the words of Jane Moss, the center’s visionary artistic director, “the inner recesses of your interior life.”

headline: ‘They’re Lies’: Melania Trump Rejects Women’s Claims That Husband Groped Them
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Television', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Ms. Trump, who has shied from interviews since her plagiarized speech at the Republican convention, said a lewd recording of her husband was “not the man that I know.”
lead_paragraph: Melania Trump, who has been all but invisible as her husband confronts a campaign crisis over allegations that he sexually assaulted women, emerged on Monday to forcefully defend him and question the honesty of the women making the accusations.

headline: Review: In ‘The Loon,’ the Birds Can Coo. Can You?
abstract: The new piece from the dance and theater company Witness Relocation is a meditation on middle age that does not want to go gentle.
lead_paragraph: “The Loon,” a new piece from Witness Relocation, is dance theater, not musical theater, but it has a kind of overture anyway. As the audience filters in, calming classical music plays over speakers, underscoring a video on the large upstage screen. We glimpse its images only partly, inside letters spelling out the name of the show, but what we see there is nature: woodland and whatnot. Every so often, a female GPS voice provides a new instruction, lulling us deeper into the countryside.

headline: How to Have More Engaging Conversations in Everyday Life
abstract: Experts discuss the art of great discussion.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series aimed at helping you navigate life’s opportunities and challenges. What else should we write about? Contact us: smarterliving@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘The Maids’ in Puerto Rico, With Shifts in Power and Gender
abstract: This adaptation of the Jean Genet play puts two pairs of actors — one male, one female — in the title roles as servants yearning for freedom.
lead_paragraph: The servants are plotting to murder the mistress again, but in José Rivera’s new adaptation of Jean Genet’s “The Maids,” they won’t be bringing her some delicate cup of tea. Instead, it will be a tainted cup of Bustelo as big as your head — coffee, “hot and strong.”

headline: Found in Ecuador: A Time Capsule for the Ears
keywords: ['Music', 'Archives and Records', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: After his grandfather’s death, a music producer finds a trove of almost perfectly preserved audiotapes representing a vital chapter of Ecuador’s musical history.
lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — When Daniel Lofredo Rota began clearing out the apartment of his dead grandfather here in April 2014, he found several tons of newspaper, stacks of letters, broken typewriters and about 300 magnetic reel-to-reel tapes, almost perfectly preserved after 45 years in a cool, dry place.

headline: In François Mitterrand Letters, an Intimate Portrait of the Other Woman
abstract: France is enthralled by the publication of letters that President Mitterrand, who died in 1996, sent to Anne Pingeot, the love of his life.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In 1,218 letters over 33 years, he wrote her in graceful prose about art and culture, political struggles and foreign dignitaries — and his passionate desire for her body. France is enthralled by the publication of a collection of letters President François Mitterrand sent to Anne Pingeot, the love of his life and the mother of their out-of-wedlock daughter, Mazarine.

headline: Trump, Mosul, Republican Party: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Judge Rejects Riot Charge Against Amy Goodman of ‘Democracy Now’ Over Pipeline Protest
keywords: ['Pipelines', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The radio host had been facing charges over her reporting on demonstrations against the 1,170-mile pipeline in North Dakota in September, her lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: The radio journalist Amy Goodman spent the weekend with the threat of a riot charge hanging over her, arising from protests over a planned oil pipeline in North Dakota. But on Monday a judge rejected the case for lack of evidence.

headline: Assault on Aleppo Will Halt for 8 Hours, Russia Says
abstract: Russian and Syrian forces will pause their offensive on Oct. 20 to allow civilians and rebels to leave the city and to provide humanitarian relief, a Russian military official said.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian and Syrian forces will halt their offensive in the eastern districts of the Syrian city of Aleppo for eight hours on Thursday to allow civilians and rebels to leave the embattled city, the Russian Defense Ministry announced on Monday.

headline: In Donald Trump, Conspiracy Fans Find a Campaign to Believe In
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: At a conference honoring Lee Harvey Oswald and featuring Roger Stone, Mr. Trump’s longtime confidant, attendees expressed deep suspicions of a powerful elite.
lead_paragraph: KENNER, La. — “What the government tells you is rarely the truth, and it’s never the complete truth,” proclaimed Roger Stone, the veteran political operative and longtime confidant of Donald J. Trump.

headline: Why Trump Doubled Down on the Central Park Five
keywords: ['Central Park Jogger Case (1989)', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Interrogations', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The Republican nominee still says, despite all the evidence, that the five men confessed to sexual assault so they must be guilty. He’s not alone.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump rarely apologizes. When it comes to the case of the Central Park Five, he has never even come close.

headline: Pedals the Walking Bear Is Dead, New Jersey Officials Believe
abstract: A 333-pound American black bear with damaged forepaws like those of Pedals was killed during the state’s annual bear hunt.
lead_paragraph: The internet mourned over the weekend after unconfirmed reports that Pedals, a bear that walked upright on its hind legs and was often captured on video strolling around New Jersey suburbs, may have been killed by a hunter.

headline: Dalian Wanda of China Offers a Carrot to Hollywood
abstract: The Chinese conglomerate wants to be an entertainment superpower, and it would like to start by getting more American movies made in China.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Wang Jianlin, chairman of the Dalian Wanda Group, the Chinese conglomerate that is emerging — controversially — as a superpower in the entertainment business, sat in an opulent armchair at the Peninsula Hotel here on Sunday and discussed his business ventures with a casual efficiency.

headline: A PayPal Error, an Errant Punch and Warnings of UKIP in a ‘Death Spiral’
abstract: Steven Woolfe told the BBC that there is “something rotten” in the U.K. Independence Party, which is riven with “infighting.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nigel Farage had one of the great personal victories in British politics this year, pushing Britain, through his U.K. Independence Party, into voting in June to leave the European Union.

headline: HealthCare.gov Will Add ‘Simple Choice’ Plans in Effort to Improve Value
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'States (US)']
abstract: Many consumers will have a new option when the insurance marketplace opens in two weeks: standardized plans that cover basic services without a deductible.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Affordable Care Act’s health insurance marketplace opens in two weeks, many consumers will have a new option for the law’s fourth open-enrollment period: standardized health plans that cover basic services without a deductible.

headline: Bob Dylan, the Newest Nobel Laureate, Maintains His Reticence
abstract: The singer-songwriter has not had contact with the Swedish Academy, which bestowed his Nobel Prize for Literature, nor did he mention it in two performances afterward.
lead_paragraph: What does Bob Dylan think about winning the Nobel Prize?

headline: A Bittersweet Goodbye Below Ground
abstract: After exchanging pleasantries many times, a commuter and a newspaper hawker have an emotional moment.
lead_paragraph: Monday through Friday, my morning commute includes a trip on the downtown A train from Washington Heights to 42nd Street, where I make my way through the long passageway to the No. 7 to Grand Central Terminal.

headline: Start-Up Taking Aim at Bloomberg Terminals Hires Former Bloomberg Head
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Norman Pearlstine is tasked with building a news feed for Money.net that will be based on machine-generated news bulletins and stories.
lead_paragraph: A start-up looking to take on the financial information behemoth Bloomberg L.P. is hiring a former Bloomberg executive to begin a new financial news service.

headline: ‘Brexit’ May Hurt Britain Where It Thrives: Science and Research
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Relocation of Business', 'Research', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Science and Technology']

headline: The Government’s Addiction to ‘Secret Law’
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Law and Legislation', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Fewer and fewer of the rules and regulations coming out of Washington are made public.
lead_paragraph: The Central Intelligence Agency’s torture of detainees, and the National Security Agency’s warrantless wiretapping of Americans’ international communications, were two of the most controversial programs our government implemented after Sept. 11. Both are now widely considered to have been illegal, even though both were authorized by official legal analyses that were withheld from the public — a phenomenon known as “secret law.”

Granted, the plot twists are implausible — a candidate has a sex scandal four weeks before the election, is abandoned by his party’s leadership and then goes rogue! — but you gotta give the writers points for creativity.

But the election crept in, thanks to inspiration from Donald J. Trump’s vulgar boast from 2005. A hand-painted banner hung in front of one frat house read, “Grab Mizzou by the TIGER.”

headline: The Power of a Dinner Table

headline: Refugees Need a Nation’s Better Angels
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a time of fear about migrants, it’s worth remembering that finding and resettling the world’s neediest refugees is an American tradition.
lead_paragraph: Sixteen years ago, Sasha Chanoff faced a decision that could mean life or death for 144 people. Chanoff, then 29, was working for the International Organization for Migration. He was in the Democratic Republic of Congo on a mission, negotiated by the United States government, to arrange safe passage out of the country for 112 refugees — ethnic Tutsis who had been imprisoned, raped and beaten, and had witnessed family members massacred.

headline: Nat Turner’s Skull and My Student’s Purse of Skin
abstract: Americans have traded and passed down the remains of executed slaves for generations. It’s time to stop.
lead_paragraph: This month, Richard Hatcher, a former mayor of Gary, Ind., delivered what researchers suspect is the skull of Nat Turner, the rebel slave, to Turner’s descendants. The skull had been kept as a relic, sold and probably handed down through generations, for nearly 185 years. If DNA tests confirm that the skull is genuine, then Turner’s family will have the opportunity to lay their famous relative to rest.

headline: Have You Ever Had to Make a Sacrifice to Help Someone You Care About?

headline: Strangely Enough
abstract: What makes an image surreal is not the artful crafting of illusion but the eruption of the accidental into the everyday.
lead_paragraph: Look at the photograph by Graciela Iturbide of a small child held on someone’s lap. The child is a boy, and the person holding him is his older sister. What is the first impression the photograph gives? It isn’t one of sweetness or innocence, but rather of a strangeness that is difficult to identify. The boy’s eyes are closed. His head is thrown back at what could be read as an unnatural angle, but could just as well be read as perfectly natural. Something seems not quite right. Is he sick? The composition recalls paintings or sculptures of the Pietà, where the Madonna carries the dead Christ. But here, the girl is too small, too fragile, to be a mother, and that peculiarity of scale is odd, too.

headline: The Chosen Ones in This Novel’s Title Were Selected for Death
abstract: Steve Sem-Sandberg’s “The Chosen Ones” tells the story of a hospital in Nazi Vienna where 800 children were murdered.
lead_paragraph: THE CHOSEN ONESBy Steve Sem-SandbergTranslated by Anna Paterson561 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $28.

headline: How ‘Bias’ Went From a Psychological Observation to a Political Accusation
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'English Language', 'Police', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Research', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: One of this presidential election’s most profound disagreements is over what our unconscious judgments say, or don’t say, about who we are.
lead_paragraph: In 2004, 57 police officers of different races were divided into two groups for a simple experiment. Half of them were shown two photo lineups, one with an array of white faces and one with black faces. This group was more visually attuned to the white faces. A second group looked at the same lineups after words like “violent,” “crime” and “shoot” flashed on their screens, at the edge of their field of vision. This group of officers’ eyes were mostly drawn to the black faces. In a similar test, using pictures of guns and knives instead of words, a group of white college students exhibited a similar shift in attention.

headline: The Joy of Mass Intimacy: A Look at ‘Future Sex’
abstract: Emily Witt’s “Future Sex” is a young woman’s report on an experiment with alternative sexuality.
lead_paragraph: FUTURE SEXBy Emily Witt210 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.

headline: Should We See Everything a Cop Sees?
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Privacy', 'Cameras', 'Police']
abstract: Body cameras have been promoted as a solution to police misconduct. But the strange two-year saga of Seattle shows just how complicated total transparency can be.
lead_paragraph: On his first day on the job in the Seattle Police Department, Mike Wagers was invited to an urgent meeting about transparency. It was July 28, 2014, little more than a week after Eric Garner was killed on Staten Island, less than two weeks before Michael Brown was killed in Ferguson, Mo., and police departments around the country were facing a new era of public scrutiny. Wagers, who has a Ph.D. in criminal justice from Rutgers, was the Seattle department’s new chief operating officer, a 42-year-old civilian in jeans and square-rimmed glasses. He’d left his wife and two kids in Virginia and come alone to Seattle, a city he didn’t know — where it rained but cultural norms, he’d read, didn’t allow you to use an umbrella — because the job was what he called “the chance of a lifetime.” Seattle was the first big-city police department in a decade to have come under what is known as a consent decree — police reform by federal fiat — after a string of violent police actions against black, Latino and Native American people were caught on camera in 2009 and 2010. Wagers and his new boss, Chief Kathleen O’Toole, herself just arrived in Seattle, would use the best new thinking and the best new technology to lead the turnaround. And then Wagers would go home.

headline: Teaching Seventh Graders in a ‘Total Mess’ of an Election Season
abstract: In Wisconsin, a crucial swing state, one teacher has aimed for civility in class, but has struggled to discuss the shocking tone of the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: EAU CLAIRE, Wis. — Maybe it’s the talk of fat shaming, or adultery, or sexual assault, or bans on Muslims and walls to keep out Mexicans. But Brent Wathke is having a rough time teaching this presidential campaign to his seventh graders.

headline: Pearl Jam and Tupac Shakur Lead Nominees for Rock Hall of Fame
abstract: Of the 19 nominees, 9 were getting their first nods, including Pearl Jam and Mr. Shakur in their first year of eligibility.
lead_paragraph: Pearl Jam, Tupac Shakur, Jane’s Addiction and Depeche Mode lead the latest crop of nominees for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, raising the possibility of a sweep of 1980s and ’90s nostalgia for an institution that has been criticized for its devotion to the baby boomer generation.

headline: We Can Fix Corporate Taxes
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Evasion', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: It has so many loopholes that many companies end up paying relatively little.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie: Nigeria’s Failed Promises
abstract: In a country enamored of dark humor, a common greeting among the middle class now is “Happy recession!”
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — I was 7 years old the first time I recognized political fear. My parents and their friends were talking about the government, in our living room, in our relatively big house, set on relatively wide grounds at a southeastern Nigerian university, with doors shut and no strangers present. Yet they spoke in whispers. So ingrained was their apprehension that they whispered even when they did not need to. It was 1984 and Maj. Gen. Muhammadu Buhari was the military head of state.

headline: Is This Election Over?
abstract: We talk numbers with Nate Cohn, a reporter for The Upshot and our most trusted translator of polls.
lead_paragraph: The math is grim for Donald J. Trump: His rival, Hillary Clinton, has a 90 percent chance of winning the election, as of Monday afternoon.

headline: Roll Over Beyoncé: Chuck Berry Announces a Surprise Album
abstract: On his 90th birthday the rock and roll legend Chuck Berry says he’ll release a new record next year.
lead_paragraph: When you hear about surprise album releases these days, you probably think of Beyoncé, Frank Ocean, Kanye West.

headline: The Terrifying Impunity of Brazil’s Riot Police
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Protests are back with a vengeance since Dilma Rousseff’s impeachment, and the cops are cracking down.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — When I cover a street protest in Brazil, I make sure to bring a helmet, a gas mask and a pair of goggles as protection from tear gas. I wear running shoes so I can escape from the police, and long pants as protection from shrapnel and rubber bullets. I carry a digital camera and a lawyer’s phone number. My press card always hangs around my neck.

headline: From Russia (but Nowhere Else) With Love
abstract: Millions of Europeans support populist candidates. So why don’t they back Trump?
lead_paragraph: Sofia, Bulgaria — Americans may be divided between Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton, but the rest of the world isn’t. A recent WIN/Gallup International global poll conducted in 45 countries shows Mrs. Clinton decimating her opponent. She wins by a landslide almost everywhere — including Melania Trump’s native Slovenia — with two telling exceptions: Russia and the Palestinian Authority.

headline: Austria Seeks to Seize, and Possibly Tear Down, Hitler’s House
abstract: The government’s move to expropriate the building in Braunau am Inn, where Hitler was born in 1889, is intended to remove a site that has drawn neo-Nazis and tourists alike.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The Austrian government moved on Tuesday to seize the house where  Hitler was born, and it may tear it down, in an effort to demystify a site that has become a magnet for neo-Nazis as well as tourists.

headline: Michael Bloomberg Gives $50 Million to Museum of Science, Boston
abstract: The gift, the largest in the museum’s history, will rename the education center after Mr. Bloomberg’s parents, William and Charlotte Bloomberg.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg, the three-term mayor of New York and billionaire philanthropist, has said that throughout his life he has been most influenced by his parents. In second place: the Museum of Science, Boston.

headline: Surfing Under the Northern Lights
abstract: There’s a thriving surf scene in Norway’s Lofoten Islands, where the waves are cold and the air is colder.
lead_paragraph: UNSTAD, Norway — This was all new to Tim Matley, a thin and boyishly blond Australian, who found himself above the Arctic Circle for the first time in this remote village with as many surf shops (two) as sheep farms.

headline: California Today: Disneyland Is Changing a Ride, and People Are Howling

headline: BlackRock, With Strong Quarter, Passes $5 Trillion in Assets

lead_paragraph: BlackRock, the world’s largest publicly traded money manager, reported on Tuesday a slight increase in its earnings for the third quarter, thanks to strong flows into its exchange-traded funds business.

headline: Ecuador Cuts Internet of Julian Assange, WikiLeaks’ Founder
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The country made it clear it feared it was being sucked into an effort to “interfere in electoral processes” in the United States.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ecuador said Tuesday that it had cut off Julian Assange’s access to the internet in his exile in the country’s London embassy, making clear that it feared being sucked into an effort to “interfere in electoral processes” in the United States by the activities of the WikiLeaks founder.

headline: An 0-3 Hole Is Huge, but the Blue Jays Have Hope

lead_paragraph: When a team falls behind, three games to none, in a seven-game playoff series, as the Blue Jays did Monday night to the Indians, everyone considers it dead and buried. And history bears this out.

headline: Rebel-Held Areas of Aleppo Get a Break From Aerial Attacks
abstract: The halt by Russian and Syrian forces is a prelude to an eight-hour “humanitarian pause” that is scheduled to start on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Russian and Syrian warplanes halted their bombardment of rebel-held districts in Aleppo on Tuesday, in what Russia called a gesture of good will ahead of an eight-hour unilateral “humanitarian pause” it has promised for Thursday.

headline: Crown Prince of Thailand Is Close to Ascending Throne, Junta Chief Says

lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The crown prince of Thailand, who declined to become king last week, will ascend the throne soon, possibly as early as Friday, the head of Thailand’s military government said on Tuesday.

headline: A Fashion Tech Giant Makes a Commitment to London
abstract: Despite fears about the effect of Britain’s vote to leave the European Union, the Yoox Net-a-Porter Group announced a new technology hub in the British capital.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the last two decades, London has forged a reputation as the technology capital of Europe and as a global capital of the fashion technology sector — a competitor to New York and Silicon Valley, where creative, commercial and digital talent thrives in a single cosmopolitan place. Some of the biggest names in the fashion industry, especially in e-commerce — such as Asos, Farfetch, Lyst and Yoox Net-a-Porter — have headquarters in the British capital.

headline: Tehran Sentences Iranian-American Businessman to 10 Years, Report Says

lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — An Iranian-American businessman who has been held in Iran for more than a year, Siamak Namazi, has been sentenced to 10 years in prison for collaborating with a foreign government, a prosecutor told the Mizan news agency on Tuesday.

The burgers are ground to order and slapped on rolls fresh out of the oven; the hot dogs are squirted with proprietary condiments; the Tater Tots are enrolled in elite private day care.

Since the rest of the Richards family recently moved to New Zealand for a year, we’re all on what feel like crazy adventures.

headline: Sir Elton John Interviews One of His Favorite New Musicians
abstract: In a chat with Whitney’s Julien Ehrlich, the pop legend discusses his unusual road to fatherhood, music he loves now — and Bob Dylan’s Nobel Prize.
lead_paragraph: Until very recently, Max Kakacek and Julien Ehrlich, who record under the name Whitney, were best known as former members of the Chicago band Smith Westerns. Now, “Light Upon the Lake,” the band’s debut album, is one of Sir Elton John’s favorite records of the year — a metric of success that is surreal, bordering on unthinkable, for the duo. “I just fell in love with the music,” John said, after it was recommended by a friend, the Guardian writer Alexis Petridis. “I went on the website and I saw the video for ‘No Woman.’ It was fantastic. I thought it was so wistful and so plaintive and no one else sounded like that.”

headline: Tom Colicchio Opens Fowler & Wells at the Beekman Hotel
abstract: Chumley’s returns with a new menu, Flora Bar opens at the Met Breuer, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: FOWLER & WELLS The Beekman, a new hotel in a stunning landmark building steps from City Hall, has dining options that are bound to become downtown destinations. The atrium, a sprawling, comfortably upholstered bar and lounge, is flanked by this restaurant from Tom Colicchio, and another one, Augustine, from Keith McNally, that will open in a few weeks. Mr. Colicchio named his restaurant for two phrenologists who practiced their pseudoscience in the building. With his executive chef, Bryan Hunt, he has devised a seasonal menu with dishes like chicory salad with pears, candied walnuts and Roquefort cheese; sautéed foie gras with persimmons, pink peppercorns and bitter greens; and rabbit schnitzel with pistachios and lemon. Favorites from an earlier era, like lobster thermidor and beef Wellington, will be offered as specials. “I think of this as old New York modernized,” Mr. Colicchio said. The handsome brick-walled room with stained-glass windows combines polished vintage details with industrial elements. (Opens Thursday): 5 Beekman Street (Nassau Street), 212-658-1848, fowlerandwells.com.

headline: Stalled by Scandal, Pakistani Network Goes on the Air at Last

headline: An Experimental Choreographer Who Isn’t Afraid of Failure
abstract: Jérôme Bel, the focus of the genre-blurring Crossing the Line festival, uses nonprofessionals to help explore what constitutes a dancer.
lead_paragraph: When the French choreographer Jérôme Bel unveils “MoMA Dance Company” next week at the Museum of Modern Art, the 25 performers will have had just three rehearsals as a group. Mr. Bel is the first to acknowledge that the experiment, as he calls it, might not work.

headline: Those Lips! Those Eyes! That Stubble! The Transformative Power of Men in Makeup
abstract: A handful of “beauty boys” have primped and preened their way into the female-centric world of Instagram and YouTube makeup artistry — and the cosmetics industry wants in.
lead_paragraph: My favorite person on Instagram these days is a guy who matches his makeup to his snacks.

headline: Mosul, Obama, U.S. Presidential Race: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Prosecutors Set to Walk Through Details of Etan Patz Case Once Again
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Missing Persons', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: A jury has been seated for the retrial of Pedro Hernandez, who is accused of kidnapping and killing 6-year-old Etan in 1979. Opening statements are scheduled for Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The story of his disappearance was etched into the memories of many New Yorkers: Etan Patz, the 6-year-old boy who vanished when he walked alone for the first time to his school bus stop in Manhattan. His picture, with his sandy-brown hair and sweet smile, was splashed across televisions and newspapers, and was the first of a missing child to be printed on a milk carton.

headline: Advice for women who travel solo
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Women and Girls', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: An article on tips for young women who travel alone got a big response on Facebook — not all of it positive. Here‘s what readers had to say.
lead_paragraph: An article on tips for young women traveling alone got a big response on Facebook — not all of it positive. Readers had a range of alternatives to our advice. Here are some of the tips women shared, edited for length and clarity.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Richard Pérez-Peña, Sarah Lyall and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Pro-Clinton ‘Super PAC’ to Tie Embattled Senators to Donald Trump in Ads
abstract: The group, Priorities USA, will air ads attacking Republican senators in New Hampshire and Pennsylvania, a move made possible by Hillary Clinton’s lead over Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: A “super PAC” supporting Hillary Clinton will begin airing ads in New Hampshire and Pennsylvania that tether Donald J. Trump to embattled Republican senators there.

headline: In North Korea, an International Film Festival Where ‘Self-Reliance’ Is the Star
abstract: The Pyongyang International Film Festival gave outsiders a rare chance to mix with North Koreans while watching features promoting approved ideology.
lead_paragraph: PYONGYANG, North Korea — Sprawling 10 million square feet across a hilly expanse on the outskirts of this capital city, the Pyongyang Film Studio, said to be the world’s largest, features a variety of representations of foreign locales reflecting North Korea’s propagandized vision of the outside world.

headline: Review: In ‘Chance,’ Hugh Laurie Returns as a Tormented Doctor
abstract: The ghost of Hitchcock haunts the first episodes of this new Hulu series starring Mr. Laurie as a doctor who is losing his bearings.
lead_paragraph: “I’m a medical professional,” Hugh Laurie’s character says, indignantly, in the new Hulu series “Chance.” “I’m not some Raymond Chandler character.”

headline: Can Humans Go From Unintended Global Warming to Climate By Design?
keywords: ['Carbon Capture and Sequestration', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Earth', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Ice Age', 'Solar Energy', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: Analysts of geoengineering challenge the inevitability of millenniums of warming.
lead_paragraph: Geoengineering is in the wind more and more these days, particularly the use of sun-blocking aerosols as a cheap, temporary counterweight to greenhouse-gas-driven global warming.

headline: No time to work out? Try exercising on the job
abstract: For many young people, it can be hard to get to the gym. Here are ways to fit fitness into your work day.

headline: Cubs Made Los Angeles a Home Before the Dodgers Did
abstract: The Cubs and the Dodgers, vying for the National League pennant, share some surprising common ground.
lead_paragraph: AVALON, Calif. — Lolo Saldaña jumped on the Chicago Cubs’ bandwagon so long ago it may well have been a covered wagon.

headline: 70 Nobel Laureates Endorse Hillary Clinton
abstract: In a letter, the experts in science, medicine and economics argued for “a president who will support and advance policies that will enable science and technology to flourish.”
lead_paragraph: A group of the world’s leading experts in science, medicine and economics threw their support behind Hillary Clinton on Tuesday, endorsing the Democratic presidential candidate and arguing that her election is crucial for safeguarding freedom and preserving a constitutional government.

headline: Michael Kors, Anna Wintour, Kate Hudson and Blaine Trump at God’s Love We Deliver Gala
abstract: The event raised $2 million to help provide meals to vulnerable New Yorkers living with H.I.V. and other illnesses.
lead_paragraph: The event raised $2 million to help provide meals to vulnerable New Yorkers living with H.I.V. and other illnesses.

headline: Review: A Portrait of Living With Mental Illness in ‘The Pen’
abstract: The highlight of “Inner Voices,” a program of three musical monologues presented by Premieres at TBG Theater, is “The Pen,” sung by Nancy Anderson.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Anderson had been onstage for mere moments, performing a minimusical called “The Pen,” when I realized I was riveted and didn’t know why. All she was doing was aiming a couple of remotes at a tabletop television, trying to get out the door in the morning to go to work. That shouldn’t have been interesting, should it?

headline: Ford Plants Go to Mexico, but U.S. Jobs Stay Around
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Labor and Jobs', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks', 'Automobiles']
abstract: The American appetite for trucks and S.U.V.s is a reason to keep 3,700 jobs at a Michigan plant. But Ford can’t afford to build small cars there.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In the summer of 2008, with the Great Recession underway and Detroit’s auto industry in a free fall, Ford Motor took a big gamble: It would switch three of its North American assembly plants from building trucks and sport utility vehicles to making small passenger cars.

headline: Michael Kors, Anna Wintour, Kate Hudson and Blaine Trump at God’s Love We Deliver Gala
abstract: The event raised $2 million to help provide meals to vulnerable New Yorkers living with HIV and other illnesses.
lead_paragraph: God’s Love We Deliver held its fall gala on Monday night at Spring Studios, but the elephant in the room was the divisive presidential election.

headline: Review: David Salle’s ‘How to See,’ a Painter’s Guide to Looking at and Discussing Art
abstract: In a collection of essays, Mr. Salle is more interested in talking about nuts and bolts, about what makes contemporary paintings tick.
lead_paragraph: “So many poets have the courage to look into the abyss,” Kenneth Koch wrote in an appreciation of the French poet and diplomat Saint-John Perse, “but Perse had the courage to look into happiness.”

headline: Barack Obama, Presidential Race, Mosul: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing

headline: Short-Term Cease-Fire in Yemen Appears Likely
abstract: The rebels known as the Houthis said they would abide by the cease-fire if the Saudi military coalition halted attacks and lifted a blockade.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — War-torn Yemen took a tenuous step toward a short-term cease-fire on Tuesday, as the rebels who control the country’s capital said they would hold their fire if a military coalition led by Saudi Arabia stopped its attacks and lifted its blockade of rebel-held territory.

headline: How to Get Josephine Baker Waves, the Modern Way
abstract: Gone are the halos of tresses, messy topknots and undone waves. The most noteworthy hair at Paris Fashion Week was “done.”
lead_paragraph: Beauty has been trying hard to look effortless for a few years now. Unfussy hair, in the form of beach waves, undone updos and highlights that look deliberately grown-out, have dominated the runway and real world alike.

headline: Saudi Arabia Executes a Prince Convicted in a Fatal Shooting
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Royal Families', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The rare execution of a prince rocketed around social media, with some Saudis saying they never imagined such a thing would happen and others saying it showed the quality of their justice system.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia on Tuesday executed a member of the royal family for murder, the first time in four decades it had done so, after he was convicted of shooting another man to death during a brawl.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Answer Your Questions
abstract: Readers told us what issues they wanted to hear more about, and the campaigns responded.
lead_paragraph: In a campaign season in which public insults, tweets and political gaffes grab the biggest headlines, many of the issues and challenges the next president will face are being pushed aside. We asked readers to choose which of 15 questions for Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump were the most important to them. Nearly 90,000 readers responded, and they chose the three questions below, in order of popularity:

headline: Magazine Says Six People Corroborate Writer’s Claim Trump Assaulted Her
abstract: A People magazine article contains comments supporting the accusation of Natasha Stoynoff, a writer for the magazine.
lead_paragraph: People magazine published an article on Tuesday that quoted six people who claimed to corroborate the sexual assault allegation made against Donald J. Trump by the magazine writer Natasha Stoynoff, which both Mr. Trump and his wife, Melania, have angrily denied.

headline: Donald Trump Has Been Accused of Groping. But What Does the Law Say?
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'States (US)', 'Assaults', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: As women have come forward to accuse Donald Trump of groping them without their consent, the accusations have raised interest in the legal rules about such contact.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As women have come forward to say that Donald J. Trump groped them without their consent in places like New York and Florida, the claims have raised interest in the legal rules about such contact.

headline: John Good, Architect of F.B.I.’s Abscam Sting Operation, Dies at 80
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Abscam, Operation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: Mr. Good’s two-year inquiry resulted in bribery and conspiracy charges against a senator, six representatives and a dozen others.
lead_paragraph: John F. Good, who developed and directed the F.B.I.’s Abscam investigation, resulting in grainy black-and-white videotapes on the evening news that showed elected officials accepting bags and envelopes of cash from what appeared to be an Arab sheikh, died on Sept. 28 at his home in Island Park, N.Y. He was 80.

headline: Yahoo Says Traffic Rose Despite Hacking That Could Alter Verizon Deal
abstract: Third-quarter earnings were higher than analysts had expected, though revenue was down 15 percent.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If Verizon Communications really wants to renegotiate its $4.8 billion deal to buy Yahoo’s internet operations, it’s probably going to have a fight on its hands.

headline: No Reason to Rush Home
abstract: A matter-of-fact explanation for the end of an obligation.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A Complex Case Tests New York State’s Expanded Definition of Parenthood
abstract: A judge must decide whether a woman’s intentions and involvement with the child adopted by her former partner are enough to formally recognize her as a parent.
lead_paragraph: The two women avoided each other’s gaze in the compact courtroom last week, separated by their lawyers, file boxes and three-inch binders filled with old emails and documents. Somewhere in all the paper was the answer to a question that is being tested as never before in New York State: Were both women the parents of the energetic 6-year-old boy they loved? Or just one of them?

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, October 19, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “The only thing that — to me — enticed me about New Jersey was the gas.”

headline: Blue Jays Land Blow Against Indians and Promise They Have Fight in Them
abstract: Cleveland, which had won all six of its playoff games, missed a chance to clinch the A.L.C.S., with Toronto breaking open the game with two runs in the seventh.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — When the Toronto Blue Jays showed up for work on Tuesday, they felt boxed in by the dual threat of the Cleveland Indians and playoff history.

headline: Chris Wallace’s Debate Role Is a Bright Spot in a Dark Year for Fox
abstract: Recovering from accusations of sexual harassment, Fox News looks forward to the spotlight at the final 2016 debate.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — A flashy broadcast studio is making its debut at Fox News on Election Night, with LED floors and a sweeping view of Manhattan through bulletproof glass.

headline: How Kenley Jansen Went From Minor League Catcher to Major League Closer
abstract: Jansen struggled to hit for five minor league seasons, but the Dodgers organization saw potential in his arm, and a minor league coach helped him develop it.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The man who turned Kenley Jansen into a pitcher played 25 years in the major leagues. He would have played none if he had not adapted.

headline: The Rap Sheet Against Sheriff Arpaio
keywords: ['Racial Profiling', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Discrimination', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Editorials']
abstract: Sheriff Joe Arpaio embodies the racist policing of immigrants that Donald Trump has promised.
lead_paragraph: A thorough moral and political indictment of Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, Ariz., would spill far beyond this page. It would catalog the years of racial profiling, the tormenting of immigrants and Latinos, the physical mistreatment and humiliation of inmates and defendants, the beatings and neglect and deaths behind bars, the abuses of office — withholding records, harassing and persecuting elected officials and journalists, failing to investigate hundreds of unsolved sex crimes, squandering taxpayer funds on crime sweeps and “posses” and looney-tune vendettas, like the mission to expose President Obama’s supposedly forged birth certificate.

headline: The Secret Life of Krill
keywords: ['Krill', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Scientists are trying to learn what melting sea ice means for the pinkish, feathery-limbed crustacean that sustains penguins, sea birds and whales.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — On an August morning aboard the Nathaniel B. Palmer research vessel floating at the bottom of the world, Christian Reiss was listening for acoustic signals bouncing off krill, a pinkish, feathery-limbed crustacean that is the lifeblood of the Antarctic ecosystem.

headline: Donald Trump’s Call to Monitor Polls Raises Fears of Intimidation
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Minorities']
abstract: The candidate has issued dark warnings about a “stolen” election and voter fraud, using language that is leading to anxiety in minority communities.
lead_paragraph: Warning darkly of a stolen election, Donald J. Trump has called on supporters to turn out in droves on Election Day to monitor polling places, telling them they need to be vigilant against widespread voter fraud and a rigged outcome.

headline: Julian Assange of WikiLeaks Unplugged
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Editorials', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The anti-secrecy activist put his hosts at the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in an uncomfortable position with the United States.
lead_paragraph: Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, has lost some of his guest privileges at the Ecuadorean Embassy in London. After shielding the Australian anti-secrecy activist for more than four years from potential prosecution in Sweden, where he faces sexual assault charges, Ecuador cut off Mr. Assange’s access to the internet over the weekend, according to WikiLeaks.

headline: The Billy Joel Defense
abstract: The Long Island singer has an unexpected moment in the political spotlight.
lead_paragraph: Three guys in suits are standing around, having a laugh.

headline: Retaking Mosul From ISIS May Pale to What Comes Next
abstract: If the recaptures of Ramadi, Tikrit and Falluja are a guide, Iraqi officials will confront devastation and unexploded bombs once Mosul is reclaimed.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — The Iraqi military’s operation to retake the northern city of Mosul after more than two years of Islamic State occupation could require months, even with American help. But the recapture may turn out to be the easy part.

headline: New York’s ‘Most Hated Building’ Gets a Baby Grand
abstract: Sing for Hope, a nonprofit arts group, has lent the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan a baby grand piano that will be played by different people.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Port Authority Bus Terminal — New York City’s “most hated building,” according to the website Failed Architecture — are myriad gates for arrivals and departures at different times, more than 25 places that serve food and drinks of different strengths, and a couple of cash machines that dispense bills of different denominations.

headline: Donald Trump, Honing Outsider Message, Backs Term Limits for Congress
abstract: In a speech marked by several forays into other topics, Mr. Trump unveiled a policy proposal intended to strengthen his populist, anti-Washington appeal.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Donald J. Trump called for congressional term limits during a swing out West on Tuesday, part of an effort to push a raw outsider message in the closing weeks of the presidential campaign.

headline: Ted V. Mikels, Master of Low-Budget Cult Favorites, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Mikels cranked out an endless stream of bloody shockers, sci-fi thrillers, action films and jiggle-fests.
lead_paragraph: Ted V. Mikels, the producer and director of dozens of ultra-low-budget horror and exploitation films, notably the 1960s cult favorites “The Astro-Zombies” and “The Corpse Grinders,” died on Sunday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 87.

headline: Thom Jones, Janitor Turned Acclaimed Author, Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Jones was working as a school janitor when he mailed an unsolicited, fictionalized war story to The New Yorker. In short time he became a literary sensation.
lead_paragraph: Thom Jones grew up in a gritty Illinois factory town. His father abandoned the family and was later committed to a mental institution, where he hanged himself. When Thom was still a teenager, he joined the Marines. Savagely beaten in a boxing match at Camp Pendleton, Calif., and mistakenly given a diagnosis of schizophrenia, he was discharged — to his great good fortune: All the members of his reconnaissance unit but one were killed in Vietnam.

headline: Jury Hears Closing Arguments in Derrick Rose Case
abstract: A woman who has sued Rose and two others is not just seeking a payday, her lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A jury heard pointed closing arguments on Tuesday in a lawsuit accusing Derrick Rose and two friends of raping a woman in her apartment three years ago.

headline: Guiding Trump, an Ex-General Who Shakes His Fist at Washington
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn appears likely to emerge as the angry voice of what could best be described as the alternative right of the American national security establishment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before leading chants of “Lock her up!” and endorsing the “extreme vetting” of Muslim immigrants, Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn, a retired career intelligence officer and registered Democrat who is advising Donald J. Trump, was already denouncing what he saw as the Obama administration’s failure to tackle Islamist militancy and the many faults of Hillary Clinton.

headline: When a friend dies, what do I say to the family?
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']
abstract: When your words are honest and direct, stripped of pretense, you acknowledge the enormity of their experience.
lead_paragraph: For a young person, attending the first funeral for a peer can be very difficult. You may be grieving yourself, but also worried about what to say to your friend’s family.

abstract: It’s easier than ever to plan, troubleshoot and make the most of your trip, with niche-focused apps as well as the old-guard networks.

headline: Ex-F.B.I. Official Acknowledges Role in New Clinton Email Controversy
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail']
abstract: Brian McCauley said “all bets were off” on his offer to swap favors with a State Department counterpart once he found out a classification issue involved the Benghazi attack.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former F.B.I. official at the center of the latest controversy over Hillary Clinton’s private emails acknowledged on Tuesday that an offer to swap favors with a State Department counterpart on an email classification issue had originated with him — until he realized the deal involved Mrs. Clinton and the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: How to stop your period

abstract: More women are trying menstruation suppression to improve their quality of life.

headline: Working It
abstract: A fun Wednesday puzzle by Tom Pepper.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes a puzzle just hits your sweet spot.

headline: Review: ‘Sell/Buy/Date,’ Sarah Jones’s Futuristic Look at Sex Workers
abstract: This absorbing solo show is an eerily timely offering by a gifted writer and performer.
lead_paragraph: Given how the objectification and exploitation of women has become an ugly but central topic in the presidential campaign — I trust I don’t need to remind you of any details — “Sell/Buy/Date,” the newest show from the gifted writer and performer Sarah Jones, seems eerily timely.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Attacks on Police']

headline: Pluto May Have Clouds, New Data Indicate
abstract: Findings from NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft include images showing seven small, bright spots that might be clouds floating just above Pluto’s surface.

headline: At Previous Debates, Melania Trump and Bill Clinton Shook Hands. Not Anymore.
abstract: In response to a Trump campaign plan at the last debate to parade women who accused Mr. Clinton of sexual assault into the hall, the Clinton campaign has gained approval to change entry protocol.

headline: Parent Group Seeks More Integration in New York’s Schools
abstract: The organization challenged the New York City Education Department to take further steps to rezone schools on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: In the long-running battle over rezoning schools on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, the parent group that must ultimately approve a plan went on the offensive on Tuesday.

headline: Debate Course Aims to Help Rikers Inmates Lobby for Their Rights
abstract: Volunteers coached inmates in the intricacies of researching, organizing and presenting their cases no matter the topic or point of view.
lead_paragraph: Like so many followers of the circus that is the presidential election, the men housed at the Rikers Island jail complex watched in dismay over the past several weeks as the contest between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump descended into an unseemly spectacle of coarse threats, personal insults and rebuffed handshakes. The rancor and puerility have surprised even the most hardened crowd.

headline: In Bridge Scandal Trial, Prosecutors Liken Ex-Christie Allies to Film Villains
abstract: Prosecutors say Bill Baroni, a former aide to Gov. Chris Christie, and a colleague gleefully plotted together as closely as the two villainous traders in “Trading Places,” one of their favorite films.

Chris Christie standing trial in the George Washington Bridge lane-closing scandal confronted him with an image he had texted to a colleague. headline: How Eni Bet Big and Won Big on Natural Gas off Egypt
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Geology', 'Natural Gas', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: Claudio Descalzi, the chief executive, backed geologists’ hunches with computing muscle and money, and his “revolution” produced a massive discovery.
