abstract: Akintola Hanif’s photographs of public housing around Newark are his testament to residents he knows as honorable, loving and hardworking.
lead_paragraph: Akintola Hanif’s photographs of public housing around Newark are his testament to residents he knows as honorable, loving and hardworking.

headline: I Fight for Your Right to Vote. But I Won’t Do It Myself.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Voting and Voters', 'Elections']
abstract: Military officers have a duty to their profession to not be used as props by political campaigns.
lead_paragraph: Tonight, like millions of Americans, I will be glued to my television, watching the third and last presidential debate. But unlike them, and millions of others, whatever I hear tonight, I won’t be taking it with me into the ballot booth. I am a major in the United States Army, and I believe it is my professional duty — and that of my fellow officers, in all branches — not to vote.

headline: The Religious Right’s Trump Schism
abstract: “The world is getting a glimpse into the dark and rotting core of evangelicalism.”
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump had already roiled the religious right, casting the Republican Party’s most reliable voting bloc into an abyss of despair, recriminations and uncertainty about the future. Then the 2005 video surfaced of him boasting about his sexual predations and women began coming forward to accuse him of sexual assault.

headline: The Trump Afterlife
abstract: Keeping his movement going after November will be a challenge.
lead_paragraph: We are in the last days of Donald Trump, presidential candidate. But as his defeat becomes more assured, the anxiety about his political afterlife is mounting. Liberals fear a world where he refuses to concede and his supporters turn to violence. Conservatives fear a world where the Republican Party remains imprisoned in his short-fingered grasp. Fox News executives fear a world where Trump starts a cable channel and steals their audience out from under them. And his supporters imagine that like a populist Obi-Wan Kenobi, he will rise more powerful than before.

headline: Trump in a Bikini
abstract: He relentlessly scrutinizes others. Let’s conduct various examinations of him.
lead_paragraph: Is it too late for Hillary Clinton to surrender to Donald Trump’s demand that she take a drug test before this last presidential debate?

headline: Social Security at Stake on Nov. 8
abstract: Hillary Clinton has a rational plan for fixing Social Security. Donald Trump’s approach would inevitably lead to insolvency.
lead_paragraph: There is no overstating the extent to which Americans rely on Social Security. The program provides monthly benefits to some 60 million people, mostly retirees for whom the modest payments — about $1,300 a month on average — represent half to all of their income. As the population ages in coming decades, Social Security will only become more important — and, unfortunately, less reliable. According to the latest projections, the system will come up short in 2034, unless reforms are undertaken before then to strengthen its finances.

headline: WikiHillary for President
abstract: Hackers exposed Clinton as a smart politician with a vision and a pragmatic approach to getting things done.
lead_paragraph: Thank God for WikiLeaks.

headline: Taking On the Boys’ Club at the Art Museum
abstract: Leadership of top institutions has too long been denied to women.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The directors of two of the world’s most popular art museums recently announced their resignations. Martin Roth, the director of the Victoria and Albert Museum, will step down this year, and Nicholas Serota, the director of the Tate museums, both in Britain, will depart next year. These job vacancies, which search committees are now working to fill, offer an opportunity to correct the gender imbalance in art museum leadership in Britain, America and beyond.

headline: The Plant That Heals, or Kills?
abstract: Should kratom, an herbal pain reliever grown mostly in Thailand, be legal in the United States?

headline: Federal Inquiry Into Mayor de Blasio Is Said to Focus on Whether Donors Got Favors
abstract: An investigation into the mayor’s campaign fund-raising has zeroed in on whether donations were exchanged for beneficial city action in several cases, people with knowledge of the inquiry said.
lead_paragraph: A federal investigation into Mayor Bill de Blasio’s campaign fund-raising has zeroed in on whether donations were exchanged for beneficial city action in about a half-dozen cases, according to people with knowledge of the inquiry.

headline: Presidential Debate: What You Missed
abstract: As polls show Donald J. Trump losing in must-win states, he and Hillary Clinton debated one last time.
lead_paragraph: How we analyzed in real time and fact checked the last presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump.

headline: Review: ‘Michael Moore in TrumpLand’ Isn’t About Donald Trump
abstract: The film, which captures a live stage performance by Mr. Moore, is not a rollicking attack on the Republican nominee but a paean to Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: If the news that the documentarian Michael Moore was releasing a surprise film called “Michael Moore in TrumpLand” had you expecting a rollicking, full-force attack on Donald J. Trump, prepare to be disappointed. Mr. Moore, one of filmmaking’s best-known provocateurs, seems to be decidedly uninterested in provoking anyone with this new offering, which had its hastily arranged premiere Tuesday night at the IFC Center in Greenwich Village. The film is not an attack on Mr. Trump, but instead a paean to his opponent in the presidential contest, Hillary Clinton.

headline: ExoMars Spacecraft Enters Orbit Around Mars as Word From Lander Is Awaited
abstract: The joint mission of the European and Russian space agencies consists of an orbiter and a lander looking for methane and testing landing technologies.
lead_paragraph: Mars has a new visitor — at least, in orbit.

headline: Life, Love and Honor in Newark’s Housing Projects
abstract: Akintola Hanif’s photographs of public housing around Newark are his testament to residents he knows as honorable, loving and hardworking.
lead_paragraph: For some, the thought of Newark’s housing projects conjure up images of crowded brick high-rises with tight hallways and dangerous, dimly lighted corners. But Akintola Hanif sees a very different scene when he photographs there — a place where children play and people love and live their lives as a large community.

headline: Questions for: ‘Teaching Seventh Graders in a “Total Mess“ of an Election Season’
abstract: Why might teachers of middle school students be having a particularly hard time teaching about this year’s presidential election?
lead_paragraph: Article: Teaching Seventh Graders in a ‘Total Mess’ of an Election Season

headline: Terrifying Encounters
abstract: What creature terrifies you most? Have you ever had an encounter with one? What happened?
lead_paragraph: How scared are you of sharks?

headline: A Snack Tray to Gather the Family Around
abstract: Celery toasts and other simple bites provide occasions to linger together.
lead_paragraph: Last year I was on an evening flight from New York to West Palm Beach, delighted to find myself in first class. Across the aisle sat an older dame — 70s, maybe — in slacks, legs crossed, reading The Financial Times, which she’d folded in vertical fourths, exactly the way all the charcoal gray suits used to do back when bankers still rode the subway to Wall Street in the mornings. The steward came through with the cart, and each one of the Louis Vuitton bucket bags and the full-length foxes and the razor-thin silver laptops spilling out of the rows in front of us ordered their water, tomato juice, white wine, organic purple potato chips with Hawaiian sea salt — and in so doing, confirmed their classy virtues. The lady in seat 4F, though, the one in the light cashmere pullover reading the newspaper, she clicked the latch on her seat-back tray and said: “Double Smirnoff, on the rocks. And Doritos.”

headline: Living in Freeport, N.Y.
abstract: This incorporated village in the town of Hempstead took a beating from Hurricane Sandy four years ago, but it’s making a comeback and rebuilding.
lead_paragraph: This incorporated village in the town of Hempstead took a beating from Hurricane Sandy four years ago, but it’s making a comeback and rebuilding.

headline: Ulysses S. Grant: New Biography of ‘A Nobody From Nowhere’
abstract: In “American Ulysses,” Ronald C. White focuses on Grant’s virtues instead of his flaws.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN ULYSSESA Life of Ulysses S. GrantBy Ronald C. WhiteIllustrated. 826 pp. Random House. $35.

headline: Abbi Jacobson Didn’t Expect Hillary Clinton to Come on Her Show
abstract: The actress on working with her best friend, imagining what famous people carry in their bags and why she wouldn’t have wanted any other presidential candidate on “Broad City.”
lead_paragraph: You and your best friend, Ilana Glazer, are the creators and stars of Comedy Central’s “Broad City,” in which you play best friends. Does it feel weird whenever you’re not working with her? We’ve managed to create this really cool working relationship where our other projects inspire each other. But this is the longest we’ve gone where we haven’t seen each other. It’s been, like, a month and a half.

headline: The Third 2016 Presidential Debate: A Place for Student Predictions and Reactions
abstract: We invite students to share their predictions before the debate. Then, starting at 9 p.m. Eastern on Oct. 19, we invite them to share reactions as we moderate comments live.
lead_paragraph: Did you watch any of the previous two presidential debates between Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton? Do you plan on watching the third and final debate?

headline: Writer, Writer, Pants on Fire
abstract: All children lie. But when they do so in the service of a good story, aren’t they just budding writers?
lead_paragraph: There’s a Yiddish expression, bubbe meise, which my husband and I use when our children tell us a story we know to be untrue. The brilliance of this term is its utter lack of judgment. When we call something a bubbe meise, we’re not chastising them. We’re agreeing to go along with whatever tale they’ve spun, while acknowledging that it didn’t actually happen.

headline: How Donald Trump Hacked the Politics of Foreign Policy
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Scholars of American politics say Mr. Trump is using international issues as a medium to connect with voters’ gut-level fears and desires.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s foreign policy proposals, like forcing Mexico to pay for a border wall or withdrawing from NATO, have drawn unprecedented condemnations as incoherent, contradictory and unrealistic.

headline: Should You Tell a Man’s Fiancée That He Faked His Degrees?
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Lying', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Voting and Voters', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Dementia', 'ADULTERY', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Friendship', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on when to share information someone may not want to hear, whether you’re obliged to report a predatory professor and whether you can cast a vote for a relative with dementia.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I realized that a close friend was misrepresenting himself professionally as having multiple graduate degrees that he did not actually earn. When I confronted him in a compassionate way, he denied it, but could offer no evidence to the contrary. We have fallen out of touch, but he is now engaged to a woman I know. We have several mutual friends. I want nothing to do with this guy and have done my best to forget about his deception, but if I were his fiancée, I would certainly want to know. Thoughts? Name Withheld

headline: Whoever Wins the White House, This Year’s Big Loser Is Email
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Campaign Finance', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: The exposure of the Clinton campaign’s internal emails shows that a ubiquitous, and vulnerable, communication tool is ready for the scrap heap.
lead_paragraph: Every four years, pundits race to anoint this or that newfangled tech trend as the next disruptive force to forever alter the mechanics of American democracy. The 2016 campaign has already been called the Snapchat election, the Periscope election, the Meerkat election, the Twitter election, the Facebook election and the meme election. (If there were a vomit emoji, I’d insert one here. And then we’d have the emoji election.)

headline: The Anti-Helicopter Parent’s Plea: Let Kids Play!
abstract: A Silicon Valley dad decided to test his theories about parenting by turning his yard into a playground where children can take physical risks without supervision. Not all of his neighbors were thrilled.
lead_paragraph: It was a Friday afternoon at Mike Lanza’s house in Menlo Park, Calif., and the boys were going crazy. There were boys playing ball in the street, while in the backyard, boys were skittering along the top of the fence while others were wrestling on the trampoline. The house itself is nothing special — a boxy contemporary, haphazardly furnished — but even by the elevated standards of Silicon Valley, the Lanzas’ play space is extraordinary. It boasts a map of the neighborhood painted on the driveway, a fabulous 24-foot-long play river — an installation art piece, designed for children’s museums — and a two-story log-cabin playhouse with a sleeping loft, whiteboard walls inside for coloring and really good speakers, blasting Talking Heads.

headline: Rosemary and Time: Does This Italian Hamlet Have a Recipe for Long Life?
abstract: Researchers believe food choices and environmental factors could help explain exceptional longevity among the inhabitants of Acciaroli, Italy.
lead_paragraph: In and around Acciaroli, Italy, a particularly pungent variety of locally grown rosemary — said to smell 10 times as strong as the norm — is a daily part of the diet. Residents raise and consume their own rabbits. Anchovies hauled in by the town’s fishermen feature prominently on dinner plates.

headline: Freeport, N.Y.: A Waterfront Community Rebuilds
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Boats and Boating']
abstract: This incorporated village in the town of Hempstead took a beating from Hurricane Sandy four years ago, but it’s making a comeback and rebuilding.
lead_paragraph: When Al Grover, 89, moved to Freeport 80 years ago, commercial fisherman and baymen — “people who made a living off the water” — lived near the canals that slice into the southern edge of this incorporated village on the south shore of Nassau County on Long Island.

headline: 12 Questions We’d Like to Hear at the Presidential Debate
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'United States International Relations', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Times reporters shared their questions on the six scheduled topics: immigration, the Supreme Court, entitlements, the economy, foreign policy and fitness for office.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump will meet on Wednesday night at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, for their final debate of the presidential election. The moderator, Chris Wallace of “Fox News Sunday,” has divided the hour-and-a-half event into six 15-minute segments, to cover immigration, the Supreme Court, entitlements and debt, the economy, foreign policy and fitness for office.

headline: Think it’s cathartic to run angry? Think again
abstract: Exercising vigorously when you are emotionally distraught could be bad for your heart.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series aimed at helping you navigate life’s opportunities and challenges. What else should we write about? Contact us: smarterliving@nytimes.com.

headline: How to Be Mindful of Fall
abstract: Take a moment to appreciate the change of seasons.
lead_paragraph: “Fall is a feast for the physical senses, the perfect opportunity to step out of our thoughts and into the body, connecting with the world around us.” — Andy Puddicombe, co-founder of the meditation app Headspace.

headline: The Decline of the West, and How to Stop It
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: The liberal order guaranteed by the postwar trans-Atlantic partnerships between North America and Europe faces an existential crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For most of the last 70 years, the United States, Canada and much of Europe have constituted a vast zone of peace, prosperity and democracy. The trans-Atlantic community has grown to over 900 million inhabitants of more than 30 countries. It has set an example for regional cooperation in Africa, Latin America and Southeast Asia, and served as a mainstay of the liberal world order.

headline: Presidential Debate, ISIS, Arctic Surfing: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Morning Agenda: Yahoo Traffic Increased, Veterans Get Disruptive, China Slows
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Yahoo’s quarterly results revealed that traffic actually increased since it disclosed its hack in September. But there are still concerns over Verizon’s agreement to buy the company.
lead_paragraph: Fear not, Verizon, for the Yahoo user is loyal.

headline: What Chesley Sullenberger Never Travels Without
abstract: Whenever he flies, Capt. Chesley “Sully” Sullenberger, who safely landed a plane on the Hudson River in 2009, brings good running shoes and a paper map.
lead_paragraph: Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III is best known for his successful landing of a US Airways plane on the Hudson River in 2009, an event depicted in the Clint Eastwood-directed film “Sully,” now in theaters. Captain Sullenberger is currently the aviation and safety expert for CBS News, and he travels around the world speaking on topics related to airline safety and standards.

headline: The Dish on the Washington Power Dining Scene
abstract: With the presidential election just days away, power dining is heating up in old-school restaurants and at a cadre of new spots.
lead_paragraph: On a recent September evening in Washington, D.C., there wasn’t a seat to be had at Fiola Mare (fiolamaredc.com), a seafood-centric Italian restaurant in Georgetown. Smartly dressed visitors in the spacious dining room and at the patio tables savored the piercing sunset while tucking into towers of cold seafood and sipping Champagne and white wine.

headline: ‘Atlanta’ Walks a Line Between Magic Realism and Keeping It Real
abstract: For a show combining low-key naturalism and a steady helping of the surreal, you need actors who don’t seem as if they’re “working,” and this cast is one of the best on TV.
lead_paragraph: In the presidential debates and at campaign rallies, Donald J. Trump has indulged a fondness for the equation of black life and hell: Happiness is scarce, and misery, poverty and violence afflict all. That’s a certain white man’s view of black life, as seen on his TV set — in 1989, when the Huxtables were the only prominent African-Americans visible amid proliferating news images of “dangerous” black people. Television in 2016, with its bounty of black shows, both rebukes and complicates that dehumanizing assessment. And the show doing that with the most farcical tang, at the moment, is “Atlanta,” now in its first season on FX.

headline: New York Today: Cooking for One
abstract: Wednesday: Dining solo, home-brewed farm cider and a call for winter work.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:47 a.m.

headline: Family Behind Korean Conglomerate Lotte Is Indicted in Corruption Case
abstract: The head of the retail giant, Shin Dong-bin, and several of his relatives face criminal charges, including tax evasion and embezzlement.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The head of the South Korean retail giant Lotte, one of the country’s largest family-controlled conglomerates, was indicted on Wednesday on tax evasion, embezzlement and other criminal charges, the latest high-profile corruption scandal to hit big businesses here.

headline: Hong Kong Legislators Stop Pro-Independence Lawmakers From Taking Oath
abstract: A walkout led by Beijing loyalists followed a failed attempt by the government to get a court to immediately block two new representatives from assuming office.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Dozens of Hong Kong politicians loyal to the Chinese government prevented three newly elected lawmakers who support greater autonomy from Beijing from being sworn in to the local legislature on Wednesday.

headline: The Federal Government’s Latest Project: Squirrel GIFs
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Photography', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: A quirky collection created from images held by the National Archives and Records Administration is on view at the website Giphy.
lead_paragraph: The National Archives and Records Administration is the guardian of some of the nation’s most precious documents, like the parchment Declaration of Independence displayed under glass in its main building in Washington.

headline: Do Campaign Ads Matter? Donald Trump Offers a Rare Chance to Find Out
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Advertising', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Television']
abstract: Presidential rivals typically run roughly the same number of commercials. Donald Trump’s lack of advertising seems to be costing him.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump hasn’t done much TV advertising. He prefers a different style of campaigning, with rallies and the free media coverage of them, along with his frequent Twitter posts. Fund-raising has taken a back seat because, as Mr. Trump said: “I don’t even know why I need so much money. Why do I even need these commercials?”

headline: New York Times Names A.G. Sulzberger Deputy Publisher
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The selection, coming at a crucial moment for the company, positions him to succeed his father as publisher.
lead_paragraph: Since 1896, when Adolph S. Ochs bought The New York Times, the Ochs-Sulzberger family has controlled the newspaper. It led the company through two world wars, the publication of the Pentagon Papers, labor strife and severe financial challenges, striving to maintain the paper’s importance even as new forms of media threatened to overtake it.

headline: In Versace, Michelle Obama Sends a Powerful Message at Her Final State Dinner
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)']
abstract: The first lady’s choices, through eight years in the White House, have changed expectations about the role of dress at ceremonial occasions.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, at her final state dinner as first lady, Michelle Obama solidified her legacy as perhaps the most adept and successful practitioner of the art of political dressing that any administration has seen.

headline: Maddon and His Team Have Their Patience Rewarded
abstract: The Cubs broke out of a postseason scoring drought with a fourth-inning eruption on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — From the moment last fall when the Mets celebrated a pennant under the Wrigley Field lights, the Chicago Cubs had made it seem so easy. They bolstered their lineup and rotation. They charged to a 25-6 start. Their entire infield started the All-Star Game. They spent all but one day of the regular season in first place and then won their division series handily.

headline: In Colorado, Deals Before Ski Season Begins
abstract: Restaurants, hotels and spas in Colorado are offering discounts before the winter high season begins.
lead_paragraph: There is a period between summer high season (when hikers and families flood the state) and winter high season (when skiing is the main attraction) where locals in Colorado take a deep breath. Through approximately mid-November, crowds are notably absent and savings are abundant.

headline: Will the Fox News Debate Be a Partisan Affair?
abstract: I encourage you to watch for whether Chris Wallace bases his questions on reality.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: California Today: For Some U.C. Workers, Skipping Meals to Make Ends Meet
abstract: Wednesday: Hunger creeps into a university system’s work force, four students are shot outside a San Francisco high school, and assessing what Proposition 13 has meant for California.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Russian Hacker, Wanted by F.B.I., Is Arrested in Prague, Czechs Say
abstract: The suspect was captured on Oct. 5, two days before the Obama administration formally accused Moscow of stealing emails from the Democratic National Committee and others.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — A man identified as a Russian hacker suspected of pursuing targets in the United States has been arrested in the Czech Republic, the police announced Tuesday evening.

headline: In Western Myanmar, a Lockdown and Fears of More Violence
keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Attacks on Police', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: Aid work has ceased in the north of Rakhine State after attacks on police officers, and videos purporting to show local Muslims urging jihad have added to fears of unrest.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — More than a week after attacks on police officers began a wave of bloodshed in western Myanmar, a lockdown by security forces has prevented aid workers from operating in the area, and new videos of what appear to be local Muslims calling for resistance have raised fears of more violence.

headline: Don’t Blame ‘Wahhabism’ for Terrorism
abstract: Accusations against Saudi Arabia and Salafi theology distract us from the real causes of violent extremism.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The word “Wahhabism” has become a boogeyman in the West, deemed responsible for the radicalization of Muslims around the world. And since Wahhabism is a strain of Islam that has its origins in the Arabian Peninsula and is the dominant religious doctrine of Saudi Arabia, that country is often viewed as the prime culprit in the propagation of violent extremism.

headline: As California Water Use Rises, Some Ask: Were Limits Eased Too Soon?
abstract: Water conservation has declined since the state lifted a mandatory 25 percent cut after a relatively wet winter. And the drought has not gone away.
lead_paragraph: EAST PORTERVILLE, Calif. — This state slashed urban water use over 25 percent in the face of a punishing drought last year, exceeding a mandatory order issued by Gov. Jerry Brown and turning California into a model of water conservation. Californians tore out lawns, cut back landscape watering and took shorter showers as they embraced Mr. Brown’s call to accommodate what he warned were permanently drier times.

headline: What You Get for … $1,500,000
abstract: A condo in New Orleans, a contemporary in Colorado and a shingle-style house in Maine
lead_paragraph: A condo in New Orleans, a contemporary in Colorado and a shingle-style house in Maine

abstract: A condo in New Orleans, a contemporary in Basalt, Colo., and a shingle-style house in York, Me.

headline: ‘Symphonic Variations’: A Frederick Ashton Classic Returns
abstract: Our critic walks you through this pure-dance masterpiece, which will be presented beginning on Wednesday by American Ballet Theater.
lead_paragraph: In the great plotless classical ballets, the prime subject is dancing itself. That’s true of the British choreographer Frederick Ashton’s “Symphonic Variations,” one of the purest pure-dance classics ever made. Created by Ashton in 1946 as his first work for the Covent Garden opera house, today “Symphonic Variations” is danced all around the world. After a 10-year gap, it returns to repertory at American Ballet Theater on Wednesday.

headline: Russia Is Moving Ahead With Missile Program That Violates Treaty, U.S. Officials Say
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: Senior officials are expressing concern that Russia might be moving to produce an arsenal of cruise missiles in violation of the landmark treaty on Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces.
lead_paragraph: Russia appears to be moving ahead with a program to produce a ground-launched cruise missile despite the Obama administration’s protests that the weapon violates a landmark arms control agreement, according to American officials and lawmakers.

headline: Word + Quiz: obliterate
abstract: This word has appeared in 52 New York Times articles in the past year.

headline: Classes for Jedis Run Afoul of the Lucasfilm Empire
abstract: A man whose businesses offers private lessons and certifications for fine-tuning lightsaber skills is operating without the permission of the “Star Wars” owner.
lead_paragraph: Obsessed fans of “Star Wars” have long enjoyed a tolerant relationship with owners of the pop culture empire’s copyrights and trademarks.

headline: Siberian Town Stakes a Claim as Humanity’s Cradle
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Neanderthal Man', 'Denisova Hominid', 'Caves and Caverns', 'Evolution (Biology)', 'Fossils']
abstract: In a small cave in rural Russia, some scientists say there’s compelling data about evolution and the interbreeding of a variety of early humans.
lead_paragraph: SOLONESHNOYE, Russia — Wood smoke hangs like a mist over this town, nestled in a valley deep in Siberia. The log houses lean at jaunty angles, dogs bark in the yards and cows, their neck bells clanging, walk the dusty streets.

headline: A Contemporary Home on a Hillside
abstract: A four-bedroom five-bathroom home outside of Medellin, Colombia, is on the market for $889,800.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom five-bathroom home outside of Medellin, Colombia, is on the market for $889,800.

headline: House Hunting ... in Colombia
abstract: Homes in the valley city of Medellin, Colombia, sell at a discount compared to those in Bogotá and Cartagena, though sales are steadily increasing.
lead_paragraph: A MODERN FOUR-BEDROOM HOUSE OUTSIDE MEDELLIN

headline: The Trump Side of Canadian Immigration
abstract: Canada is regarded as a paragon of acceptance for immigrants and refugees, but politicians can exploit the country’s ambivalence toward newcomers.
lead_paragraph: The term “Canadian values” is normally a harmless cliché — a reminder that the planet’s second largest country by land mass is a Boy Scout-like bastion of tolerance and fairness. This trope regained some of its luster with last fall’s election of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, who might as well be the country’s Boy Scout in chief.

headline: Durable Designs for Women Who Wrangle and Weld
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Red Ants Pants, Gamine and Rosies Workwear are among a few businesses producing work clothes designed for comfort and safety for women who labor in fields that were long dominated by men.
lead_paragraph: Physically demanding jobs may not be restricted to men anymore, but the women entering such careers are still finding it challenging to break into one aspect: work clothes.

headline: As New Ukraine Talks Begin, What Is the State of Europe’s Only Active War?
abstract: A summit meeting in Germany was a test of whether President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will cut a deal to end the conflict while he also faces pressure over Syria.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — With soldiers dying daily in Ukraine, the site of the only active war in Europe, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany hosted a meeting on Wednesday to see whether President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was willing to cut a deal to end the conflict while he also faces pressure from the West over Moscow’s role in Syria.

headline: 1966: 500-Foot Skyscraper For Montparnasse
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The Montparnasse tower in Paris is under development in October 1966.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — American and French businessmen are teaming up to build a skyscraper in Paris that they claim will be the world’s biggest — and most expensive — commercial building. At slightly more than 500 feet high, it would also be the highest building in central Paris. It would cost $100 million and stand on the site of the old Maine-Montparnasse railroad station. Plans for the new Paris landmark include a 250-room hotel, several restaurants and boutiques, a theater, an ice-skating rink, a heliport on the roof and underground parking and, inside the building, 30 high-speed elevators.

headline: How Taking a Gap Year Can Shape Your Life
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Sabbaticals and Career Breaks', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Looking back, adults who took time off before or during college say they have no regrets.
lead_paragraph: If your teenager is talking about taking a year away from the classroom between high school and college, you may have Malia Obama to thank for that. But if they’re not yet talking about whether to follow her lead, they should be.

headline: Jean-Pierre Bemba, Congolese Politician Imprisoned for War Crimes, Is Convicted of Witness Tampering
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Witnesses']
abstract: Mr. Bemba and four others were found guilty by the International Criminal Court in The Hague.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Jean-Pierre Bemba, a Congolese politician who is serving an 18-year prison sentence for crimes against humanity and war crimes, was convicted on Wednesday of coaching and bribing witnesses to give false testimony.

headline: Big, Bigger and Biggest in Museum Shows
abstract: Coming up: Art openings for Mark Leckey, Kerry James Marshall and Pipilotti Rist.
lead_paragraph: It’s a great week to be in New York, especially if big, freshly-minted museum shows appeal. Things get rolling Sunday, Oct. 23, with the unveiling at MoMA PS1 of “Mark Leckey: Containers and Their Drivers,” the largest survey yet of this astute, often amusing perpetuator of video, installation, lecture-performance and photography. On Tuesday, the Met Breuer will debut “Kerry James Marshall: Mastry,” a survey of an artist whose ravishing, nuanced paintings confront the realities and history of black life in America. Wednesday brings “Pipilotti Rist: Pixel Forest,” a survey of a pioneering artist known for combining music and images of nature and the female body into some of contemporary art’s most lyrical videos and video installations. And Friday is the Whitney Museum’s turn with “Dreamlands: Immersive Cinema and Art, 1905-2016,” an expansive survey of a century-long relationship that will further explore the potential of the museum’s grand fifth-floor gallery.

headline: 1891: Pollution of the Seine
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The Council-General of Paris decides to get rid of the pollution in the Reiver Seine from Asnières to Suresnes in October 1891.
lead_paragraph: Dwellers in Paris, who, during the dry months of the year, are forced to drink Seine water or none at all, will be gratified to hear that a scheme for purifying the river, proposed six years ago, but abandoned on account of the cost, has been taken up again. The Council-General now proposes to divert all the sewer water that flows into the Seine and the Marne above Paris, convey it as far as Asnières, and there pump it up into a reservoir, whence it can be conducted on to the irrigation grounds at Achères.

headline: Tracey Ullman Returns to HBO
abstract: In her new six-episode sketch series, Ms. Ullman skewers British archetypes and celebrities.
lead_paragraph: HBO returns another dependable veteran to its fold with “Tracey Ullman’s Show,” a six-episode sketch series starring this British comedian, whose Emmy-winning “Tracey Takes On …” left the channel in 1999.

headline: Troy Schumacher’s BalletCollective Comes to N.Y.U.
abstract: Two pieces feature collaborations with the architects James Ramsey and Carlos Arnaiz.
lead_paragraph: New York City Ballet’s fall season just ended, but the corps de ballet dancer Troy Schumacher isn’t taking any breaks. Mr. Schumacher has been directing his own, much smaller company, BalletCollective, since 2010, and this spirited troupe returns to New York University’s Skirball Center for the Performing Arts on Thursday, Oct. 27, and Friday with two new works.

headline: Sia Furler, a Shy Woman Hiding Under a Big Wig
abstract: Her Oct. 25 show at Barclays Center also includes Maddie Ziegler, Miguel and AlunaGeorge.
lead_paragraph: Sia Furler, singer-songwriter turned megahit collaborator turned victim-to-victory pop belter, is shy onstage. She sings her hits, like “Chandelier,” in a torn, slurred voice while keeping still and hiding under a giant wig. But there’s action onstage: choreographic vignettes featuring the dynamo Maddie Ziegler, whose frenetic moves and flickering expressions ramp up the songs’ emotional stakes. Sharing a bill with her in Brooklyn is a decidedly more carnal performer: Miguel, who knocks himself out onstage like an old-school soul showman with a decidedly modern repertory, personalizing rock, R&B and hip-hop as he merges seduction with the pride of a cross-cultural outsider. Also on the bill is AlunaGeorge, which slips a streak of female empowerment into its dance tunes. (Tuesday, Oct. 25, Barclays Center; barclayscenter.com.)

headline: In Classical Music, a Double Serving of Youth
abstract: The fortepianist Kristian Bezuidenhout plays Zankel Hall, while Frank Huang solos on violin at David Geffen Hall.
lead_paragraph: Last October, when the compelling British tenor Mark Padmore riveted audiences at Alice Tully Hall by performing Schubert’s three major song cycles over three nights, his crucial partner on every step of this momentous marathon was the superb young South African fortepianist Kristian Bezuidenhout. New Yorkers can catch Mr. Bezuidenhout on his own recital at Zankel Hall when he performs Beethoven (including the brilliant Sonata No. 7 and the beloved Sonata “Pathétique”) and Haydn. (7:30 p.m., Monday, Oct. 24.)

headline: Two A. R. Gurney One-Acts at the Flea Theater
abstract: His “Ajax” and “Squash,” billed together as “Two Class Acts,” will be the last shows at the Flea’s White Street home.
lead_paragraph: The playwright A. R. Gurney and the Flea Theater have had a long, fruitful relationship, with many of Mr. Gurney’s plays starting at the TriBeCa space. So it seems fitting that he’s once again presenting new work at the Flea: His current pair of one-acts — “Ajax” and “Squash” (billed together as “Two Class Acts”) — will be the final shows at the Flea’s White Street home.

headline: At Film Forum, the Fastest Noodle Slurpers in the West
abstract: “Tampopo,” Juzo Itami’s 1985 spoof of spaghetti westerns, returns in a restored version.
lead_paragraph: “Tampopo,” Juzo Itami’s Japanese “noodle western” (1987), is an uproarious, tasty series of satirical sketches that celebrate an erotic connection between food and sex.

headline: A Walk Through The Pacific Crest Trail
keywords: ['Hikes and Hiking', 'Mountaineering', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Photography', 'Wilderness Areas']
abstract: Photos of the spectacular 2,650-mile-long dirt path.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written extensively about the joys of backpacking on the Pacific Crest Trail, so I thought I’d pass along these photographs and this text from the co-author of a new coffee table book about the trail. — Nicholas Kristof

headline: Attack in Afghanistan by Afghan Soldier Kills 2 Americans
abstract: At least three other Americans were wounded in the latest outbreak of “green on blue” violence, this time at a military depot near Kabul.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An Afghan soldier opened fire on a group of Americans at a military depot near Kabul on Wednesday, killing two and wounding another three in the latest outbreak of “green on blue” insider violence, American and Afghan officials said.

headline: ‘Jeopardy!’ Quiz: What Is ... The New York Times?
abstract: Test your knowledge of The New York Times with 10 questions from the archive of “Jeopardy!”
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of The New York Times with 10 questions from the archive of “Jeopardy!”

headline: Black Man Is Arrested While Walking, and Minnesota City Starts a ‘Conversation’
abstract: Officials said they would review police procedures after the arrest of the man for walking in the road to avoid sidewalk construction work prompted an outcry.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Edina, Minn., said officials were taking steps to improve relations between the police and minority residents after a white officer’s arrest of a black man who was walking in the street to avoid construction work on a sidewalk last week prompted an outcry.

headline: I’ll Take the Gray Lady for $2,000
abstract: The real prize for a stint on “Jeopardy!” was joining the newsroom’s unofficial roster of all-star trivia geeks. (Fear us at corporate competitions.)
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times. In this article, Flora Lee Peir — an assistant news editor and one of a handful of Times staffers who has competed respectably on “Jeopardy!” — takes us behind the scenes of the symbiotic, decades-old relationship between a news organization and an iconic television game show. Pay attention! There will be a quiz.

headline: In Quick Response, de Blasio Calls Fatal Shooting of Mentally Ill Woman ‘Unacceptable’
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The New York police sergeant who shot a woman, Deborah Danner, 66, in her Bronx apartment on Tuesday night was placed on modified duty and stripped of his gun and badge.
lead_paragraph: Deborah Danner’s essay recounted her long, aching struggle with schizophrenia, a battle that had begun some 30 years earlier.

headline: Where to See Celebrities Onstage This Fall
abstract: Our guide to some of the TV, film and pop stars appearing in plays and musicals in New York.
lead_paragraph: The star power on New York stages this season may not be as diverse as it was last year. But the wattage is still darn strong. Here’s our guide to some of the celebrities who will be taking bows this fall.

headline: Bake-Off!
abstract: Wednesdays are for reading about cakes and cooking without recipes.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Keeping the Political Wool From Being Pulled Over Your Eyes
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Statistics', '3-D Devices and Effects', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: These apps help you check facts, understand statistics and spot false arguments in this contentious election season.
lead_paragraph: DO you know a logical fallacy from a statistical improbability? Do you know correlations from causations?

headline: Faculty Members at 14 State Universities in Pennsylvania Go on Strike
abstract: A union representing more than 5,000 professors and coaches who teach more than 100,000 students has been without a contract since June 2015.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of faculty members went on strike Wednesday at 14 Pennsylvania state colleges and universities — a rare escalation in higher education, but one that reflects increasingly widespread tensions between administrators and their faculties.

headline: Philippines on Edge as Typhoon Haima Roars Ashore
abstract: A potentially devastating storm, Typhoon Haima has prompted thousands of evacuations and put aid agencies on high alert.
lead_paragraph: A potentially devastating typhoon made landfall in the Philippines late Wednesday with slightly less force than had been feared.

headline: Picasso’s life, portrait by portrait
abstract: An exhibition in London traces the arc of the artist’s career, and his relationship with women, through his portraiture
lead_paragraph: Sylvette David was a 19-year-old blonde with bangs and a ponytail when she became Pablo Picasso’s studio model. The artist, 72 at the time and living in the southern French town of Vallauris, spotted the young woman on her visits to the ceramics atelier next door. One spring day in 1954, he dangled a sketch of her over the garden wall, invited her in, and asked if she would pose for him.

headline: The New Blue and Red: An Educational Split Is Replacing the Culture War
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The traditional red-state, blue-state map of the 2000-2012 era was driven in part by cultural issues like abortion and same-sex marriage. Not this year.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has built a commanding lead over Donald J. Trump in national polls, but she still has one big weakness: white working-class voters, especially men.

headline: Dressing for Bill
abstract: Fashion personalities came dressed to for Bill Cunningham’s tribute at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Fashion personalities came dressed to for Bill Cunningham’s tribute at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Lawsuit Seeks to Halt New York Subsidies for Upstate Nuclear Plants
abstract: The suit argues that a deal to provide hundreds of millions of dollars per year to four plants oversteps federal authority to regulate energy prices.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — A collection of energy companies and trade associations have filed a lawsuit seeking to reverse a decision by the administration of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to subsidize several struggling upstate nuclear plants, arguing that the state overstepped federal authority to regulate energy prices.

headline: They Dressed for Bill
abstract: Social figures, fashion magnates, models, actors and rafts of the largely unsung turned out in all their finery on Monday to honor Bill Cunningham.
lead_paragraph: Among the luminaries assembled at Carnegie Hall on Monday to memorialize Bill Cunningham, who died on June 25 at age 87, was former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. Stepping briskly to the stage, Mr. Bloomberg reminded the gathering of more than 1,000 that few people knew better than Mr. Cunningham himself “that the best runways are the streets of New York.”

headline: He Can’t Drink, but Julio Urias Is Starting in the Postseason
abstract: Urias is set to become the youngest starter in postseason history. But what about other “youngest players”? What happened to them?
lead_paragraph: At 20 years 68 days old, the Los Angeles Dodgers’ Julio Urias became the youngest postseason starter ever by taking the mound against 37-year-old John Lackey and the Chicago Cubs on Wednesday night in Game 4 of the National League Championship Series.

headline: All the Victims of Boko Haram
abstract: The release of 21 kidnapped girls was both a joyous occasion and a sign of how much more it will take to defeat the extremist group.
lead_paragraph: The liberation of 21 of the more than 270 girls abducted from a Nigerian school in April 2014 is certainly to be celebrated. Yet, those heartwarming scenes of parents and girls joyously dancing and hugging are not the end of this terrible saga — not for the children still in the clutches of Boko Haram, the extremist Islamist group that has been spreading death and destruction across northeastern Nigeria for seven years, and perhaps not even for the girls who have been set free.

headline: Review: A New ‘Rocky Horror,’ Stripped of Subversive Magic
abstract: Laverne Cox stars in Fox’s remake of “The Rocky Horror Picture Show,” but neither she nor many other cast members will make you forget the original.
lead_paragraph: Some things can’t be replicated or recaptured, and thanks to Fox we now know that one of them is the subversive magic of “The Rocky Horror Picture Show.”

headline: Daily Report: Explaining Yahoo’s Unexpected Jump in Traffic
abstract: Yahoo said more people visited the site in September, the same month the ailing company disclosed that hackers stole data on 500 million users in 2014.
lead_paragraph: In its glory days, Yahoo had a garish mock hotel sign in San Francisco that billed the service as “a nice place to stay on the internet.” It may be again — but only after a fashion.

headline: Falling in Love With Italy’s Blissful, Rustic Aeolian Islands
abstract: Where simplicity is luxury, time slows to the roll of the Mediterranean and meals are rivaled only by the crisp white wine.
lead_paragraph: Where simplicity is luxury, time slows to the roll of the Mediterranean and meals are rivaled only by the crisp white wine.

headline: Donate Your Computer’s Spare Time to Science
abstract: With the right software, you can give your computer’s spare processing power to a research project (and maybe make the world a better place).
lead_paragraph: Q. I have heard about volunteer computing, but I am wondering how exactly it works and how secure it is. Would my computer be at risk?

headline: Ex-Fox Chairman Roger Ailes to be Subject of TV Mini-Series
abstract: Tom McCarthy, the writer and director of “Spotlight,” has agreed to be the executive producer of the project.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The former Fox News chairman Roger Ailes is coming back to television, but perhaps not in a way he will like.

headline: Monkeys Can Make Stone Tools, but They Don’t Use Them
keywords: ['Monkeys and Apes', 'Rock and Stone', 'Intelligence and Intelligence Tests (IQ)', 'Tools']
abstract: Researchers found capuchin monkeys in Brazil that bang stones together, producing flakes that look similar to early human tools.
lead_paragraph: The capuchin monkeys of Serra da Capivara National Park in Brazil are well known for using rocks. They use them as hammers to crack open nuts. They use them for digging. They even use them to show off to potential mates. Now scientists report that they also spend time banging stones together, for no clear reason, producing sharp-edged stone flakes that are just like some of the first tools of early humans.

headline: Steven Cohen May Return to Hedge Fund Industry When Ban Expires
abstract: The billionaire investor said a new firm he opened may begin raising cash from outside investors in early 2018.
lead_paragraph: Steven A. Cohen, a billionaire investor barred from managing money for others, is one step closer to making his return to the hedge fund industry.

headline: During a Social Media Break, Kim Kardashian West Offers ‘More Me’
abstract: An expanded version of the selfie-filled book “Selfish” follows the robbery in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The publication of the new, expanded edition of Kim Kardashian West’s 2015 book of self-portraits, “Selfish,” comes at an unusual moment for the reality star.

headline: Morgan Stanley Could Benefit From Some Fed Decisions
abstract: If the central bank allowed Morgan Stanley to buy back more stock, for example, the Wall Street bank’s return on equity could rival Goldman Sachs.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley is positioned for a liftoff, but the timing is in the hands of the Federal Reserve.

headline: Airbnb Proposes Cracking Down on New York City Hosts
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: The company told the city that it was willing to create a registry of hosts so it could track individuals renting out multiple homes.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb said on Wednesday that it was willing to crack down on individuals in New York City who rent out multiple homes, bowing to pressure from politicians and tenants’ rights groups who say the company has worsened affordable housing issues in the city.

headline: Dear A.G., Here Are Three More Problems for You
abstract: Judging by the public editor’s inbox, Times readers would like to pile a few more concerns onto the new deputy publisher’s plate.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times took a critical step toward crowning a new publisher on Wednesday, naming Arthur Gregg Sulzberger as deputy publisher and heir to the throne. He most likely will succeed his father, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., as publisher of The Times after an undefined apprenticeship.

headline: Right-Wing Video Suggests D.N.C. Contractors Schemed to Incite Chaos at Donald Trump Rallies
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The undercover video was the work of Project Veritas Action, which sends researchers around the country to spy on the inner workings of Democratic campaigns.
lead_paragraph: Two operatives who were working with the Democratic National Committee to help elect Hillary Clinton are no longer working in that role after an undercover video appeared to show them plotting to incite violence at Donald J. Trump’s rallies.

headline: Trade Sports Cards? He Paints Them
abstract: Jonas Wood, whose show of portraits at the Anton Kern Gallery in Chelsea runs through Oct. 29, finds inspiration in the unlikeliest corners of the sports world.
lead_paragraph: It is not often that David Hockney and Dwayne Schintzius come up in the same conversation.

headline: The A.C.L.U., on Transgender Students
abstract: The A.C.L.U. writes that school administrators include transgender students in common spaces “without any doomsday prophecies ever coming to pass.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: As Health Markets Struggle, 9% Average Rise in Enrollment Is Predicted
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The Obama administration is confident of an increase despite increases in the costs of premiums and several major insurers leaving.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Wednesday that it expected monthly enrollment in the Affordable Care Act marketplace to average 11.4 million next year, up 9 percent from the monthly average this year, despite rising premiums and the departure of major insurers from the marketplace in many places.

abstract: A reader writes, “The tax code is where the corrosive effect of our system of election campaign funding is most on display.”
