headline: Former Lincoln Center President’s New Post: At National Sawdust
abstract: Jed Bernstein, who was president of Lincoln Center till the spring, is now an adviser at National Sawdust, the new-music space in Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: Jed Bernstein, whose tenure as the president of Lincoln Center was cut short last spring after he failed to disclose a relationship with an employee, is crossing the river for his next post: He is now an adviser at National Sawdust, the new-music space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Peels NYC’s New Collection
abstract: The line of shirts and jackets, popular with skaters and fashion editors, was created last year by Jerome Peel.
lead_paragraph: The line of shirts and jackets, popular with skaters and fashion editors, was created last year by Jerome Peel.

headline: A Brand Inspired by a Hardworking Father
abstract: Jerome Peel, whose shirts have become popular with skateboarders and fashion editors, began by designing for his dad.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the suburbs of West Palm Beach, Jerome Peel spent hours watching his father fix old Hondas and dirt bikes. “He’d be wearing this work shirt,” Peel recalls. “Just that blue shirt, unbuttoned, with a tank top tucked into his jeans. That was the coolest look to me.” Last year, Peel was inspired to launch Peels NYC, a unisex line comprised of work shirts and utilitarian garments that pays homage to hard workers.

headline: Melania Trump Mimics Hillary Clinton to Defend Donald Trump
abstract: She’s parroting the arguments Clinton used decades ago about a “conspiracy” against Bill.
lead_paragraph: Melania Trump borrowed from Michelle Obama for her speech at the Republican convention where her husband was nominated for president. To defend him against charges of sexual harassment and groping, she had a different source: Hillary Clinton.

headline: Introducing The New York Times’s Next Big (Food) Thing
abstract: Our new dining map is one of the many projects that arose from Maker Week, a weeklong initiative for experimentation — and creation — at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: What We’re Seeing in the Final Presidential Debate
abstract: How Donald Trump vs. Hillary Clinton looks to Times Opinion writers — before, during and after.
lead_paragraph: How Donald Trump vs. Hillary Clinton looks to Times Opinion writers — before, during and after.

headline: Fight for Mosul Endangers Civilians
abstract: The Iraqi Army and coalition forces launched an offensive this week to retake Mosul from the Islamic State, and humanitarian workers worry that civilians will be caught in the crossfire.
lead_paragraph: The Iraqi Army and coalition forces launched an offensive this week to retake Mosul from the Islamic State, and humanitarian workers worry that civilians will be caught in the crossfire.

headline: Fashion’s New ‘It’ Kids
abstract: Meet the next generation of Kendall Jenners and Gigi Hadids: children of celebrities parlaying their parents’ fame and good genes into careers.
lead_paragraph: Meet the next generation of Kendall Jenners and Gigi Hadids: children of celebrities parlaying their parents’ fame and good genes into careers.

headline: A Haitian Warlord Meets His Match: Hurricane Matthew
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The storm has done what neither government nor armed forces have managed to accomplish: bring Guy Philippe to his knees as his community starves.
lead_paragraph: PESTEL, Haiti — Guy Philippe is among the most feared men in Haiti, a nation with a rich history of men worthy of fear.

headline: Review: A Musical Tour of Mendelssohn’s Europe
abstract: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center opened its season with a Mendelssohn-themed sketch of the performances to come.
lead_paragraph: Haydn’s “Surprise” Symphony gets its nickname from a fortissimo chord placed where it has no business being, at the end of the second go-round of a quiet little ditty that sounds like a nursery game played on tiptoes. Performed with conviction and a dose of mischief, it should make listeners jump.

headline: Just Being Himself, in a Professional Women’s Hockey League
abstract: He goes by a different name and pronoun now, but Harrison Browne of the National Women’s Hockey League says coming out as a transgender man has been freeing.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — He changed his voice mail recording and created a new email address. He updated his LinkedIn profile, too, to reflect his new name.

headline: Geno Smith Replaces Ryan Fitzpatrick as Jets’ Quarterback
abstract: Two days after saying Fitzpatrick would remain as the Jets’ starter, Coach Todd Bowles picked Smith to lead the offense Sunday against Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — On Monday night in Arizona, after the Jets lost their fourth straight game, Coach Todd Bowles quickly sought to stifle any suggestion that a change would be made at quarterback.

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: Rebecca Hall Reads ‘Take Me as I Am, Whoever I Am’
abstract: The star of the new movie “Christine” reads the essay of a woman whose romantic life seesaws from bold flirtation to fearful withdrawal.
lead_paragraph: In this episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the actress Rebecca Hall (“Christine”) reads the essay “Take Me as I Am, Whoever I Am,” Terri Cheney’s explanation of what it’s like to date while having bipolar disorder.

headline: On Debate Night, Celebrating a Book About Immigrants
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Photography', 'Books and Literature', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: A group will honor “Nuevo New York,” which features interviews with dozens of creative professionals of Latin American descent.
lead_paragraph: Just before the final debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump kicks off in Las Vegas on Wednesday night with immigration as a focus, a group will gather in New York to celebrate “Nuevo New York,” a book about creative professionals of Latin American descent. Included in it are well-known figures like Carolina Herrera, Maria Cornejo, Carlos Campos, Francisco Costa and Nina Garcia.

headline: Dancers Get Much Needed Recognition — and a Little Cash, Too
abstract: Nominees for this year’s New York Dance and Performance Awards received a $500 honorarium. It’s a start for these undernoticed and underpaid artists.
lead_paragraph: The hard work of dancing is too often undernoticed and underpaid. Enter the New York Dance and Performance Awards, better known as the Bessies, which bestow some much needed recognition and a touch of glamour on the profession once a year, if not a whole lot of money — though this year’s ceremony, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday, began with an announcement that all nominees would receive a $500 honorarium. (It’s a start?)

headline: Prayer
abstract: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.
lead_paragraph: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

headline: Understanding the Terms of Your Student Loans
abstract: A new report finds that students aren’t borrowing the federal limit before seeking private or state loans, which tend to have costlier terms.
lead_paragraph: As student debt for new graduates continues to climb, borrowers need to pay close attention to the type and the terms of the loans they seek, even if the loans come from state programs, a new report finds.

headline: Education Company to Pay $4.3 Million in Settlement With New York State
abstract: A special education preschool program based in Queens was treated as the personal ATM of the family that owns it, according to an agreement with the state attorney general’s office.
lead_paragraph: A for-profit network of schools and the family behind it have agreed to pay New York State more than $4.3 million in a settlement after having spent state funds, intended to pay for special education preschool, on credit card bills, maintenance of a boat and a son’s law school tuition, as well as claiming false tax deductions, the office of the state attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, said on Wednesday.

headline: The Centuries-Old Ceramics Techniques of Faenza
abstract: The artist Emma Hart’s Max Mara Prize residency has taken her to the Italian city, renowned for its ceramics since the 15th century.
lead_paragraph: The artist Emma Hart’s Max Mara Prize residency has taken her to the Italian city, renowned for its ceramics since the 15th century.

headline: Visiting Italy’s Ceramics Workshops With a Buzzy Multimedia Artist
abstract: As the Max Mara Prize winner Emma Hart reaches the end of a residency there, she takes T on a tour of workshops keeping an ancient ceramic tradition alive.
lead_paragraph: The artist Emma Hart is not a fan of the glossy, filtered visions of life offered by Instagram, at least as most people use it. Though she has a background in photography, Hart has issues with the medium’s tendency to make subjects look “good and smooth,” and favors instead a pursuit of the grubby and real. Her artworks draw on the vexations of modern life with mischievous humor, referencing ill-paid jobs in call centers, faceless bureaucracy, the travails of young motherhood and her own South London roots.

headline: They Write Plays for a Living. But How’s Their Handwriting?
abstract: We gave handwriting samples from five playwrights to a graphologist. Here’s what she saw, and how the writers reacted.
lead_paragraph: The brochure for the Playwrights Horizons season features the word “Playwrights” written eight times, by each of the featured theatermakers (seven writers and a collaborating director). The concept was to create a look that “would never be the same twice,” said Michael Bierut, a partner in the design firm Pentagram, which created a new brand identity for the Off Broadway company.

headline: Review: In ‘The Arab of the Future 2,’ Back to Syria in 1984
abstract: This second volume of the cartoonist Riad Sattouf’s graphic memoir returns to the small village where he and his family lived when he was a boy.
lead_paragraph: It is certainly possible to enjoy the second volume of Riad Sattouf’s graphic memoir, “The Arab of the Future 2: A Childhood in the Middle East, 1984-1985,” without having read its predecessor. Even without a shard of context, Mr. Sattouf’s story and storytelling would be irresistible.

headline: Jury Clears Knicks’ Derrick Rose of Liability in Rape Suit
abstract: A jury on Wednesday found in favor of the Knicks guard and two of his friends in a federal civil suit filed by a woman who had accused them of rape.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Knicks guard Derrick Rose was cleared on Wednesday in a lawsuit accusing him and two friends of raping a woman who had had a relationship with him. The verdict, from an eight-member jury in a federal civil trial, absolved Rose of wrongdoing, although the damage to his reputation remains to be seen.

headline: Review: A New, Abstract ‘Guillaume Tell’ at the Met Opera
abstract: Pierre Audi’s production of Rossini’s final masterpiece falls into some traps. But there is much to celebrate in the performances.
lead_paragraph: It sounded like a good idea.

headline: Trump and Clinton’s Last Debate: Analysis
abstract: Here’s how we analyzed in real time the last presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how we analyzed in real time the last presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump.

headline: Ex-N.B.A. Star Amar’e Stoudemire Rises as an Art Connoisseur
abstract: The former Knick collects art, advises pro basketball players and was tapped by Sotheby’s to be a liaison to high net-worth athletes.
lead_paragraph: Amar’e Stoudemire was inspecting art at Christie’s in Rockefeller Center on a sweltering afternoon in June. He was drawn to a tall piece by David Hammons, an influential artist whose work is in the permanent collection at the Whitney Museum of American Art. It was a smoky cloud scape created by bouncing a basketball covered in graphite and dirt on paper.

headline: Fresh Off Employing Evan Bayh, U.S. Chamber of Commerce Attacks Him
abstract: The chamber is spending millions in the Indiana Senate race to defeat Evan Bayh, a pro-business centrist who once lobbied for the organization.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Until just a few months ago, Evan Bayh was working for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. Now the chamber is working as hard as it can against him.

headline: Mosul, Philippines, U.S. Presidential Election: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Lady Gaga’s Stripped-Down New Album Fishes for Inspiration
abstract: In “Joanne,” the pop star may have aimed for transparency, but her songs are neither daring nor radical, and they feel like concepts in search of a home.
lead_paragraph: For almost a decade, Lady Gaga has been assiduously arguing the case that the external is the internal, that performance is authentic, that flamboyance is ideology. Her career has been predicated on demolishing conventional ideas about what it might mean to play a character — with Gaga, it was never play, always work, and always true.

headline: SoFi, an Online Lender, Is Looking for a Relationship
keywords: ['Student Loans', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Venture Capital', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: Social Finance Inc., or SoFi, takes a different approach to consumer lending, one that includes holding singles and networking events.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Alyson Casey recently received an invitation to a singles event in Manhattan from a start-up. But it didn’t come from a dating service. It came from the company that had recently refinanced her student loan: SoFi.

headline: Russia Sports Minister Promoted to Deputy Prime Minister
abstract: Before his elevation to the newly created position, Vitaly Mutko was denied admittance to the 2016 Olympics after revelations of Russia’s state-run doping.
lead_paragraph: Vitaly Mutko, the Russian sports minister who was denied admittance to the 2016 Olympic Games after damning revelations of state-sponsored doping, has been elevated to deputy prime minister of Russia.

headline: You’ll Want Some Velvet for Fall
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Hats and Caps', 'Backpacks']
abstract: Where has all the leather gone? This season is all about velvet.
lead_paragraph: Where has all the leather gone? This season is all about velvet.

headline: Vermont Governor Proposes Limits on Painkiller Prescriptions
abstract: To help combat his state’s drug crisis, Gov. Peter Shumlin would use severity and duration of pain to determine limits for prescriptions of opioids.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Peter Shumlin of Vermont on Wednesday announced proposed limits on the number of painkillers that could be prescribed, the latest measure his administration has taken to combat the opioid crisis that has ravaged the state in the last five years.

headline: No Justice in Iran
abstract: Iranian hardliners have intensified their anti-Western crackdown by sentencing two Iranian-Americans to 10 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Iranian hardliners have intensified their anti-Western crackdown by sentencing two Iranian-Americans to 10 years in prison on charges of cooperating with the United States. The unjust judgments, reported by Iranian media on Tuesday, mark the latest effort by the judiciary, controlled by the country’s hardline faction, to thwart improved ties with the United States and the West after the 2015 nuclear deal.

headline: Three Words Lead to a Battle Over ‘Great Comet’ on Broadway
abstract: The nonprofit theater Ars Nova and the commercial producers of “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812” are battling over the billing of the show.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, the small nonprofit theater company Ars Nova commissioned an up-and-coming composer to write his wacky dream project, a musical adaptation of one dramatic section of “War and Peace.”

headline: Smithsonian Seeks $300,000 to Save Dorothy’s Ruby Slippers
abstract: The institution hopes to raise the money in a Kickstarter campaign to repair the “Wizard of Oz” shoes and display them in a temperature-controlled case.
lead_paragraph: They are just a pair of shoes, but what a pair of shoes.

headline: In Push for G.M.O.s, China Battles Fears of 8-Legged Chickens
abstract: A Chinese firm’s $43 billion effort to buy Syngenta could upend the industry, but it faces widespread fears at home over modified food.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For many in China, the term “genetically modified food” evokes nightmares: poisoned seeds, contaminated fields, apocryphal images of eight-legged chickens.

headline: Review: New York Cabaret Convention Slips In Modern Flourishes
abstract: It represents the conservative uptown wing of a field whose downtown avant-garde is merging music with performance art, political satire and gender and genre bending.
lead_paragraph: Maureen McGovern was presented with the Mabel Mercer Award, the highest honor presented to a performer at Tuesday’s opening-night gala of the 27th New York Cabaret Convention at the Rose Theater. Ms. McGovern, who sang a pristine, unamplified rendition of “Over the Rainbow,” is a supreme exemplar of the American songbook tradition celebrated this year over four consecutive evenings through Friday.

headline: When Hillary Clinton Tested New Slogans — 85 of Them
abstract: Buried in the leaked emails of John D. Podesta is a message from August 2015, when the campaign was weighing prospective slogans. Some ring familiar.
lead_paragraph: Crafting the perfect political slogan is hard. Writing scores of unmemorable ones? Less so.

headline: Presidential Debate, Mosul, Putin: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Celebrate 75 Years With Coach, 20 Years With Jay Z
abstract: Shop vintage Moschino dresses, meet the Aquazzura designer at Bergdorf, check out the Gilt City Warehouse Sale and more.
lead_paragraph: Brush up on your fashion and music history. On Thursday, Coach will celebrate its 75th anniversary by putting 48 vintage bags up for auction, including a duffel (the brand’s most iconic style, introduced in 1971) that has been reworked with metallic patches and pins. The first $50,000 in sales will benefit the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Marijuana Lights Up State Ballots
abstract: Proposals to make the drug more available will go before voters in nine states, but federal laws remain out of step with such measures.
lead_paragraph: People in nine states, including California, Florida and Massachusetts, will vote Nov. 8 on ballot proposals permitting recreational or medical use of marijuana. These initiatives could give a big push to legalization, prompting the next president and Congress to overhaul the country’s failed drug laws.

headline: Indians Defeat Blue Jays and Reach First World Series Since 1997
abstract: Cleveland will be seeking its first championship since 1948 after knocking out Toronto in the American League Championship Series.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — For all the passion that Clevelanders pour into their sports teams, they have suffered a disproportionate amount of bitter misfortune. For decades, the city’s premier stadium was known as the Mistake by the Lake, and teams like the Browns, the Cavaliers and the Indians endured agonizing defeats — or were simply abject failures for generations at a time.

headline: German Police Officer Dies After Raid on Supporter of Far-Right Fringe Group
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: The gunman opened fire when the police came to seize his weapons, after he ignored repeated warnings, officials said.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A policeman has died of injuries suffered when a 49-year-old supporter of a fringe group that rejects modern Germany opened fire on officers sent to his home to confiscate his weapons, the authorities said on Thursday.

headline: Reported Cases of Sexually Transmitted Diseases Are on Rise
abstract: Progress in the fight against chlamydia, gonorrhea and syphilis has “unraveled,” the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There were more cases of sexually transmitted diseases reported in the United States last year than ever before, according to new federal data. Rates of chlamydia, gonorrhea and syphilis — three of the most common S.T.D.s — grew for the second consecutive year, with sharper increases in the West than other regions. And while all three diseases are treatable with antibiotics, most cases continue to go undiagnosed, potentially causing infertility and other problems.

headline: Bobby Shmurda, a Brooklyn Rapper, Is Sentenced to 7 Years in Prison
abstract: The musician, who had pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy and weapons possession, asked the judge to let him withdraw his guilty plea, saying his lawyer forced him to take the deal.
lead_paragraph: Just before a judge sentenced the Brooklyn rapper Bobby Shmurda to seven years in prison on Wednesday, he tried to take back his guilty plea, accusing his lawyer of forcing him to accept the deal.

headline: Bollywood Becomes India and Pakistan’s Latest Battleground
abstract: Tensions over an attack on an army base have led to a cultural battle as India and Pakistan ban each other’s film stars and television shows.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — India and Pakistan, longtime enemies with nuclear arsenals, have battled over borders, killed each other’s soldiers and fought three wars since the countries’ creation seven decades ago.

headline: Juno Hobbled but Healthy After Glitch, NASA Says
abstract: The spacecraft put itself into “safe mode” early Wednesday and restarted its computer, scuttling observations that were to take place as it passed 3,000 miles above Jupiter’s clouds.
lead_paragraph: Hours before a close flyby of Jupiter on Wednesday, NASA’s Juno spacecraft experienced a malfunction that scrambled plans for peering deep into the planet.

headline: How Silicon Valley Treats a Trump Backer: Peter Thiel
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Peter Thiel, who has drawn fire from fellow tech executives for supporting Donald J. Trump, plans to address the issue in a speech this month.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Peter Thiel made a relatively modest investment in the presidential candidacy of Donald J. Trump, but it is generating a major uproar in Silicon Valley.

headline: Taken for a Ride
abstract: A poem about waiting (and waiting) for a bus.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Raiders Owner Says He Is Firm on Moving Team to Las Vegas
abstract: With the approval of $750 million in public money for a new football stadium in Las Vegas, Mark Davis, the owner of the Oakland Raiders, reiterated his intention to relocate.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — With the recent approval of $750 million in public money for a new football stadium in Las Vegas, Mark Davis, the owner of the Oakland Raiders, said Wednesday that he was more determined than ever to move the team there.

headline: Trove of Stolen Data Is Said to Include Top-Secret U.S. Hacking Tools
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Investigators found that stolen documents in the possession of Harold T. Martin III included top-secret N.S.A. hacking tools that two months ago were offered for sale on the internet.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Investigators pursuing what they believe to be the largest case of mishandling classified documents in United States history have found that the huge trove of stolen documents in the possession of a National Security Agency contractor included top-secret N.S.A. hacking tools that two months ago were offered for sale on the internet.

headline: Another English Club Cracks Under Barcelona’s Pressure
abstract: Whenever an emissary of the Premier League meets Barcelona, a player is getting sent off. Manchester City showed it was no exception in a 4-0 shutout.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Claudio Bravo is not alone. He would have felt that way, of course, as he trudged off the field at Camp Nou, disconsolate and deaf to the warm ovation afforded him by Barcelona’s fans. He certainly felt that way in the locker room as the dust cleared on Manchester City’s humbling 4-0 defeat and even his manager, Pep Guardiola, acknowledged that Bravo, City’s goalkeeper, was “sad.”

headline: Brazilian Lawmaker Who Led Impeachment of President Is Arrested
abstract: Eduardo Cunha, the former speaker of Brazil’s lower house of Congress, is charged with corruption, accused of taking as much as $40 million in bribes for himself and allies.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Eduardo Cunha, the former speaker of Brazil’s lower house of Congress who engineered the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff this year, was arrested Wednesday on corruption charges, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Lawyer for Ex-Christie Aide Says She Was Made Scapegoat in Bridge Plot
abstract: The lawyer for Bridget Anne Kelly argues she has been unfairly blamed in a plot that involved nearly everyone in the governor’s office.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The George Washington Bridge lane-closing scandal crept closer to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, as lawyers for one of his former aides began her defense in federal court here on Wednesday.

headline: A Rape and Murder Prompts Thousands of Argentine Women to Protest
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: This was the third national protest organized by Ni Una Menos, a movement of women’s rights advocates, since the first was held in June of last year.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Women across Argentina stopped work for an hour on Wednesday and took part in mass demonstrations to demand more protection after an escalation in attacks against women and girls this month.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, October 20, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Not many people have 80-year-old shoes and want to preserve them forever.”

headline: Trump Debate Guests: Who Are Malik Obama and Patricia Smith?
abstract: Donald J. Trump invited two more attention-grabbing guests to his final presidential debate with Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump have both tried to rattle each other during the debates by inviting guests who might unsettle their opponent, but Mr. Trump, a talented showman running a scorched-earth presidential campaign, has excelled at inviting attention-grabbing guests.

headline: Children 14 or Under Need Fewer HPV Vaccine Doses
keywords: ['Human Papillomavirus (HPV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Cancer', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: 11-to 14-year-olds need only two doses, not the previously recommended three, to prevent cancers caused by the human papillomavirus.
lead_paragraph: Children 11 to 14 years old need only two doses of the HPV vaccine, not the previously recommended three doses, to protect against cervical cancer and other cancers caused by the human papillomavirus, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Wednesday.

headline: Fact Checks of the Third Presidential Debate
abstract: Reporters for The New York Times fact-checked the statements made by Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump during Wednesday’s presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: Reporters for The New York Times fact-checked the statements made by Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump during Wednesday’s presidential debate.

headline: Sparks’ Candace Parker Ignores Slights, Heeding Pat Summitt’s Lessons
abstract: Parker, left off the roster for the Rio Olympics and absent from the all-W.N.B.A. teams, has kept the focus instilled by Summitt, her college coach.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles Sparks forward Candace Parker has attained almost every accolade possible during her career.

abstract: Follow along, and discuss, with Frank Bruni, Roger Cohen, Ross Douthat and Elizabeth Williamson.
lead_paragraph: Follow along, and discuss, with Frank Bruni, Roger Cohen, Ross Douthat and Elizabeth Williamson.

headline: Philippine Police Van Rams Protesters at U.S. Embassy, Hurting Dozens
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Riot police officers roughed up people in a rally of about 1,000 activists in Manila who demanded an end to the United States presence in the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Dozens of protesters were hurt on Wednesday after a Philippine police officer used a van to ram into them during a demonstration against the United States in the capital.

headline: Fatal Police Shooting in Bronx Echoes One from 32 Years Ago
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: The fatal shooting of Deborah Danner had much in common with the shooting of Eleanor Bumpurs in 1984.
lead_paragraph: In a city as thick with history as New York, it is inevitable that some public events will echo the past. In the case of Deborah Danner, a mentally ill woman fatally shot by the police on Tuesday night in the Bronx, that echo was Eleanor Bumpurs.

headline: Eddie Applegate, a Sweetheart on ‘The Patty Duke Show,’ Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Applegate was best known for playing the boyfriend of the show’s character Patty Lane.
lead_paragraph: Eddie Applegate, an actor best known for playing Patty Lane’s steadfast high school sweetheart on the 1960s sitcom “The Patty Duke Show,” died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 81.

headline: A ‘Taco Wall’ to Protest Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Tacos', 'Debates (Political)', 'Food Trucks and Vendors', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Supporters of the Democratic nominee for president, Hillary Clinton, surrounded a Trump Hotel in Las Vegas with about 150 taco trucks on Wednesday and staged protests ahead of the final presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of the Democratic nominee for president, Hillary Clinton, surrounded a Trump Hotel in Las Vegas with about 150 taco trucks on Wednesday and staged protests ahead of the final presidential debate.

headline: A.G. Sulzberger: Leading Change at The New York Times as Journalism Evolves
abstract: Mr. Sulzberger, who was named The Times’s deputy publisher, is the author of a report calling for sweeping changes and a digital future for the paper.
lead_paragraph: [Update: A.G. Sulzberger will take over as publisher of The New York Times on Jan. 1, The Times announced on Dec. 14, 2017.]

headline: Clinton and Trump Do Battle in the Final Presidential Debate
abstract: Nicholas Kristof live-tweets and fact checks the showdown.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump faced off tonight in their final presidential debate. To me the big headline was Trump’s refusal to commit to honoring the result. That is unprecedented, more in keeping with a warlord than with a major party nominee, and it leaves me saddened. Here’s my play-by-play, a first draft of history, in the form of selected tweets.

headline: Phil Chess, Whose Record Label Elevated Unknown Blues Musicians, Dies at 95
abstract: Chess Records, the label founded by Mr. Chess and his brother, became successful by finding little-known performers and persuading radio stations to play their music.
lead_paragraph: Phil Chess, who with his brother founded Chess Records, a storied Chicago label that captured great blues musicians like Muddy Waters in their prime and helped power the musical fusillade of rock ’n’ roll with vibrant recordings by the likes of Chuck Berry, died on Tuesday at his home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 95.

headline: Yvette Chauviré, Ballerina and Symbol of French Culture, Dies at 99
abstract: Ms. Chauviré began as a child prodigy and went on to become one of the 20th century’s outstanding dancers.
lead_paragraph: Yvette Chauviré, one of the 20th century’s outstanding ballerinas and the most lustrous star of French ballet from the 1940s through the 1960s, died on Wednesday at her home in Paris. She was 99.

headline: Persistence of Memory
abstract: Will you know whether you’re coming or going in Alan Arbesfeld’s puzzle?
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — If you have never come across the term “palindrome,” it means something that is spelled the same reading from left to right as it is reading right to left. One of the most well known palindromes is “Madam, I’m Adam,” and people who love to play with words have contests called the Symmys (yes, that’s a palindrome too; what did you expect?) to see who can come up with the best one. There is even an online magazine edited by the Symmys champion Mark Saltveit devoted solely to this pastime.

headline: Review: In ‘Love, Love, Love,’ All You Need Is Selfishness.
abstract: A pair of soul mates obliviously advance from the ages of 19 to 64 in Mike Bartlett’s play, set in London.
lead_paragraph: Now here’s a couple who know how to grow old in style. Portraying a pair of soul mates in selfishness in Mike Bartlett’s “Love, Love, Love,” which opened on Wednesday night at the Laura Pels Theater, Amy Ryan and Richard Armitage advance from the ages of 19 to 64 with a galloping satirical wit that pulls you along, happy and appalled, through the decades.

headline: Want an Old Piece of the Statue of Liberty? This Is the Man to See.
keywords: ['Statue of Liberty', 'Copper, Brass and Bronze', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Salvage']
abstract: Rick Stocks is the self-appointed caretaker of discarded parts from the Statue of Liberty’s $87 million restoration in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: For more than three decades, Rick Stocks has been hoarding a mountain of construction debris — so much of it that he had to squirrel it all away in three different warehouses in Tennessee and Florida.

headline: Donald Trump Won’t Say if He’ll Accept Result of Election
abstract: “I will keep you in suspense,” Donald Trump said at a debate that began cordially but turned caustic. Hillary Clinton replied that his statement was “horrifying.”
lead_paragraph: In a remarkable statement that seemed to cast doubt on American democracy, Donald J. Trump said Wednesday that he might not accept the results of next month’s election if he felt it was rigged against him — a stand that Hillary Clinton blasted as “horrifying” at their final and caustic debate on Wednesday.

headline: Tesla Will Make Its Cars Fully Self-Driving, but Not Turn the System On Yet
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles']
abstract: Tesla said that all the vehicles would have hardware enabling fully autonomous driving, though it would not be activated without more testing.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Tesla Motors said on Wednesday that it would equip all of its new vehicles with technology that enables fully autonomous driving, but would not activate the system until it undergoes further testing.

headline: Retrial in Etan Patz Murder Case Revives 2 Views of Suspect
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Missing Persons', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: Prosecutors portrayed Pedro Hernandez as a vicious killer in the opening statements of his retrial, while his lawyer insisted on his innocence.
lead_paragraph: Pedro Hernandez was a man weighed down by what he had done, prosecutors said, and he felt compelled to unburden himself, confessing to a prayer group, a friend, his wife and eventually, years later, to detectives who suspected he was a child killer.

headline: Donald Trump’s Contempt for Democracy
abstract: In saying he was not sure if he’d support the election results, Mr. Trump added another reason he is not qualified to be president.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump turned, in the third and final presidential debate, from insulting the intelligence of the American voter to insulting American democracy itself. He falsely insisted there were “millions of people” registered to participate in the election who did not have the right to vote and declared he would not commit to honoring the outcome.

headline: The Debate in One Scary Answer
abstract: Donald Trump wouldn’t say if he’d accept the results of the election. He also cried foul when he didn’t win an Emmy for “The Celebrity Apprentice.”
lead_paragraph: O.K., Donald Trump won’t promise to accept the results of the election. That’s truly … good grief.

headline: Living With Schizophrenia
abstract: In an essay, Deborah Danner, who was killed in a police shooting, once described the challenges of living with mental illness, including interacting with law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: In an essay, Deborah Danner, who was killed in a police shooting, once described the challenges of living with mental illness, including interacting with law enforcement.

headline: Chris Wallace, Mixing Humor With Scolding, Guides Final Debate
abstract: While Mr. Wallace maintained a genteel presence, he also issued some sharply phrased questions that were sure to irk his skeptics.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The smart money on Wednesday’s matchup between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump was for a 12-round, no-holds-barred bout worthy of this city’s prizefights.

headline: 5 Days After Failed Missile Test by North Korea, Another Failure
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: North Korea has had a spotty record in test-launching the Musudan, its longest-range ballistic missile deployed.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea launched an intermediate-range ballistic missile on Thursday, but the test ended in failure, the United States military said. It was the North’s second failed attempt to flight-test that type of missile in five days.

headline: U.S. Presidential Debate, Syria, Mars: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Fantasy, Fights and Love: 500 Years of ‘Orlando Furioso’
abstract: The epic poem by Ludovico Ariosto, published in 1516 in Ferrara, Italy, is celebrated in an exhibition in one of the city’s finest palaces.
lead_paragraph: FERRARA, Italy — This city, once presided over by the Este dynasty, became one of the most brilliant of all the European courts and artistic centers of the Renaissance. It was an environment that spurred a richness in the visual arts and inspired such epic poems as “Orlando Furioso” (“The Madness of Orlando”), a fantastical mingling of medieval chivalric romance, classical literary elements and contemporary events.

headline: Exploring Daubigny, Through His Influence on van Gogh
abstract: The Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam traces Daubigny’s artistic development and the Impressionist painters he inspired.
lead_paragraph: In July 1890, about 10 days before Vincent van Gogh shot himself in the chest, he presented his just-completed “Daubigny’s Garden” to the widow of a French landscape painter he had long admired, Charles-François Daubigny.

headline: Buffet: A Life of Success, Rejection and Now a Celebration
abstract: The French painter achieved great wealth but was scorned for his lifestyle. A new Paris show now may restore his reputation and work.
lead_paragraph: Few artists have known the roller coaster of fame and shame that the French painter Bernard Buffet experienced during his life. Buffet, who was once hailed as the artistic successor to Picasso only to be reviled later as vulgar and the epitome of poor taste, was an immensely popular artist before falling into near oblivion. He committed suicide in 1999 at the age of 71.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Mocking and Taunting in Debate, Turns the Tormentor
abstract: In the third and final debate, Mrs. Clinton outmaneuvered Donald J. Trump with a surprising new approach: his.
lead_paragraph: She mansplained him. “Let me translate that if I can,” Hillary Clinton said dryly after Donald J. Trump talked up his tax plan.

headline: Europe’s Leaders Make Their Point Without Saying a Word
abstract: Managerial efficiency. A black belt. A dashing scarf. A look at the style and substance of E.U. leaders as they meet in Brussels.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — How do you like your leaders? Dashing? Fired up? Sober and controlled? At European Union summit meetings, 28 leaders project competing versions of what it means to be in charge as the bloc falters. Some examples of the stagecraft that will be on display at the next summit talks, beginning Thursday:

headline: Paris Fair Crosses the Road, Giving Art Room to Breathe
abstract: FIAC expands again, adding Petit Palais and Avenue Winston Churchill to the annual festival of contemporary art.
lead_paragraph: The Grand Palais and the Petit Palais, both built for the 1900 Universal Exposition in Paris, have long been separated by a wide and busy street that links this city’s Right and Left Banks.

headline: Speed Is In for the Rangers, Especially Chris Kreider
abstract: Before a 2-1 loss to the Detroit Red Wings on Wednesday, Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault said he was heartened by the fleetness of his four forward lines and younger defensive corps.
lead_paragraph: Speed is a constant theme for the new-look Rangers this season. It is not as if such an essential hockey element was not part of Coach Alain Vigneault’s approach the first three years of his Rangers tenure, but their dynamic burst from the gate this season has been noteworthy, with speed throughout the lineup pressuring opponents and creating scoring chances.

headline: Baylor Under Federal Investigation Over Possible Title IX Violations
abstract: The inquiry, by the Department of Education’s Office for Civil Rights, will examine whether Baylor violated the law in its handling of sexual assault claims on campus.
lead_paragraph: The federal government announced Wednesday that it was formally investigating whether Baylor University had violated Title IX in its handling of sexual assault on campus, the latest development in a scandal that included several accusations and convictions of sex crimes levied against Baylor football players and a damning university-commissioned report.

headline: Transcript of the Third Debate
abstract: Following is a transcript of the third presidential debate, on Wednesday, as transcribed by CQ Transcriptswire.
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of the third presidential debate, on Wednesday, as transcribed by CQ Transcriptswire.

headline: Kurds, Heading Into the Teeth of ISIS, Open a New Front
abstract: A U.S. soldier is among the dead in an expansion of the effort to retake Mosul, including moves by Iraqi forces and a new, village-by-village Kurdish thrust from the north.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Gordon, a New York Times military correspondent, is with Kurdish pesh merga forces on the northern approach to Mosul.

headline: Rodrigo Duterte and Xi Jinping Agree to Reopen South China Sea Talks
abstract: Meeting in Beijing, the Philippine and Chinese presidents signaled that they would seek bilateral solutions to the long-running dispute.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, agreed on Thursday to resume direct talks on disputes in the South China Sea after years of escalating tension, a sign of warming relations with Beijing.

headline: Cubs Thrash Dodgers to Even N.L.C.S. at Two Games Each
abstract: After being shut out two straight games, Chicago got homers from Anthony Rizzo and Addison Russell and piled up runs against a sloppy Los Angeles defense to win Game 4.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Faced with a moment of truth after being shut out in back-to-back games by the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Chicago Cubs had all eyes upon them, studying how they would react.

headline: The Debates Were a Failure of Journalism
abstract: How many questions were the candidates asked about climate change over their debates? Exactly zero.
lead_paragraph: Tonight wrapped up three weeks of presidential campaign debates. It was also a three-week period in which cities in at least 34 states reported record-high temperatures. New York reached 80 degrees today, and Nashville nearly hit 90.

headline: Giants Kicker Josh Brown Admitted Abusing Wife, Police Evidence Shows
abstract: Brown admitted to domestic violence against his wife in a journal and emails, according to police documents released in Washington State on Wednesday.

headline: Debate Takeaways: Donald Trump Had a Lot to Do, and He Didn’t Do It
abstract: Mr. Trump showed more discipline than in the first two debates, but a few stumbles left him far short of the decisive victory he needed to shift voters’ perceptions.
lead_paragraph: Last chance, no backsies. The third and final presidential debate, held in Las Vegas on Wednesday night, was the last real chance for either Hillary Clinton or Donald J. Trump to shift the momentum of the 2016 campaign. Wherever the race is now, it is highly likely to stay that way for the next 19 days. So what happened? Check out our takeaways.

headline: How to Ensure the Iran Nuclear Deal Survives the Next President
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: U.S.-Iran relations shouldn’t take place only at the highest levels.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With every presidential debate this year, Americans are reminded that the Iran nuclear deal remains as controversial as ever. Iranians, too, are watching the election, dreading the potential consequences for the deal — and for their country’s future.

headline: College Accreditors Need Higher Standards
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Graduation Rates', 'For-Profit Schools', 'ACCREDITATION', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Editorials']
abstract: The federal government’s hands-off approach to ensuring higher education standards has led to lax oversight by some independent organizations.
lead_paragraph: The federal government spends more than $180 billion a year to support higher education. But the system created by Congress to determine eligibility for federal dollars virtually guarantees that a portion of this money will be wasted by schools that have abysmally low standards, high dropout rates and, in many cases, saddle students with huge debt in exchange for useless degrees. Congress can remedy this problem by changing the way schools are accredited and by giving the Department of Education more say in the process.

headline: Australia’s Stranded Refugee Prisoners
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration Detention']
abstract: Australia’s abominable off-shore refugee detention system must be shut down.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, the government of Australia set out to stop migrants and refugees from reaching its shores by boat. It came up with a ruthlessly efficient policy under which people found at sea were sent to Manus Island in Papua New Guinea or to the nation of Nauru, each a tiny island in the Pacific, ostensibly the first step to being resettled.

headline: How to Vote as an Immigrant and a Citizen
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The American in me recognizes that we need to take care of Americans first.
lead_paragraph: “Are you a citizen?” the woman standing in front of my apartment building in Manhattan asked me this summer. She had a clipboard with a sign-up sheet in one hand, which she extended to me as I walked toward her. “I’m looking for registered voters who would like to sign a petition to ——” I took the clipboard before she was done explaining. “Are you an American?” she asked again. Smiling, I unhooked a pen as I told her, “Yes, I’m an American.”

headline: For These Americans, Clean Water Is a Luxury
keywords: ['Water', 'Native Americans', 'Sewers and Sewage', 'Rural Areas', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Navajo Indians', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: In some places around the country, families rely on buckets, bottles, even animal troughs.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Most Americans take safe water for granted: Turn the tap, and there it is. But recent protests against the Dakota Access pipeline on the Standing Rock Reservation in South Dakota are a reminder that some Americans still worry every day about having enough clean water to survive.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Choir
abstract: You can take a breath and escape physically and metaphysically, occupying and occupied by the music.
lead_paragraph: I sang in my college’s church choir every Sunday despite the occasional hangover. All that echo! The resounding nave wrung my heart out harder and better than any of the desiccated marijuana, clumsily mixed drinks or inept gropings of the nights before. We were Mormons and Baptists, Protestants who knew the Anglican hymns, Catholics who could translate the Latin, closeted baritones who were planning careers in music or the church or both.

headline: Miri Regev’s Culture War
keywords: ['Israeli Settlements', 'Arabs', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: The Israeli minister of culture and sports wants nothing less than an overthrow of the nation’s elite.
lead_paragraph: The Tel Aviv Museum of art is a somber slab of concrete built in the no-fuss brutalist style of the late ’60s. The architect who planned the museum also designed Israel’s nuclear reactor; such is the overlap between culture and political exigency in the country. One Sunday in March, a throng of artists, actors and writers clustered in the museum’s main auditorium. They were awaiting the arrival of Miri Regev, Israel’s culture and sports minister, of the ruling Likud Party. A year earlier, Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s prime minister and the chairman of Likud, secured a fourth term in office and swore in his ministers, a coalition widely regarded as the most right-wing in Israeli history.

headline: In Clinton Hill: Their First Apartment Together
abstract: Kelly Cho and Jaime Soriano wanted a one-bedroom for them and their cat.
lead_paragraph: In her first year as an architecture student at the Pratt Institute in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, Kelly Cho lived in the dorms. In her second year, she moved nearby with a good friend.

headline: Is It Time for Wonder Woman to Hang Up Her Bathing Suit?
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Wonder Woman (Fictional Character)', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Now that she is 75, a United Nations honorary ambassador and a symbol of female empowerment, the most famous female superhero may deserve a new look.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Wonder Woman turns 75, and she is getting a bang-up party. It will take place at the United Nations in the Economic and Social Council chamber, and special guests will include Diane Nelson, president of DC Entertainment (the company that owns DC Comics, which invented Wonder Woman); Lynda Carter, who embodied Wonder Woman in the 1970s television series; Gal Gadot, who has taken on the role in the forthcoming Wonder Woman film; and the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon.

headline: Sweet-Toothed Egypt Endures a Sugar Crisis: ‘People Are Going to Snap’
keywords: ['Sugar', 'Shortages', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Shortages of sugar, a staple of the national diet, and of other products have led to brewing anger against President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egyptians pile sugar into mugs of tea by the spoonful — or three or five. A staple long subsidized by the government for most of the population, sugar is the chief ingredient of the national pudding, Om Ali. It can feel like the only ingredient. It is also a prime reason that nearly a fifth of Egyptians have diabetes.

headline: Introducing Mahershala Ali: You’ve Surely Seen His Face
abstract: This actor’s rise, through roles in “House of Cards,” “Moonlight” and “Luke Cage,” is the result of deliberate choices.
lead_paragraph: Over breakfast one Sunday, the actor Mahershala Ali ordered a healthy egg-white omelet, studiously avoiding a basket of complimentary, carb-loaded pastries. Life is full of such choices, and as he described his decision to leave the Netflix drama “House of Cards,” it became clear that the career move represented a similar choice, between one immediately satisfying option and another that would ultimately be more sustaining.

headline: Five Places to Eat in Versailles
abstract: The culinary reputation of Versailles is in the midst of a delicious revival as talented chefs open restaurants so good they’re pulling Parisians.
lead_paragraph: Versailles, the third most-visited monument in France after the Louvre and the Eiffel Tower, has evolved into a seriously sublime food destination. Until recently, Versailles dining typically consisted of forgettable sandwiches and salads at tourist restaurants. Dining in this town 13 miles from Paris oddly paid little tribute to its most famous attraction, the magnificent, mostly 17th-century Château de Versailles. The palace, as it exists today, was largely built by Louis XIV, a notoriously epicurean monarch whose sumptuous meals included everything from deep-sea oysters and lobster aspic to wild duck croquettes and morel mushroom soufflé. Now, though, the culinary reputation of Versailles is in the midst of a delicious revival as talented chefs open restaurants so good they’re pulling Parisians.

lead_paragraph: Depressed fuel prices, the growth of low-cost carriers and tumultuous world events have combined to do one nice thing for travelers: lower airfares.

headline: Luxury Isn’t Having a Very Good Year

lead_paragraph: LONDON — One trend that has gone out of fashion in the luxury world this year? Stellar sales growth. The global market for high-end personal goods is headed for its weakest year since 2009.

headline: The Best New TV Series to Take a Chance On
abstract: We offer a few yearbook-style superlatives to help you sort through all the great television out there.
lead_paragraph: There’s too much good television right now. “There’s so much to choose from,” Jenna says on this week’s episode of Still Processing. “I feel like a kid in a candy store. Like you can literally choose to watch whatever you want to watch based on whatever mood that you’re in or whatever storyline you want to immerse yourself in. And that feels really new to me.”

headline: No Signal From Mars Lander, but European Officials Declare Mission a Success
abstract: The lack of a signal most likely means the planned “soft landing” failed, but the orbiter continues to gather and transmit data.
lead_paragraph: The Schiaparelli hasn’t landed, it appears. At least, not the way it was supposed to.

headline: Talking to Your Therapist About Election Anxiety
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Therapists say that some of the campaign issues — safety, secrecy and boundaries — play into our deepest worries.
lead_paragraph: It has been described as one of the most contentious, tawdry and angry presidential elections in history. And it’s taking a toll on our mental health.

headline: We Have Tried Every Kind of Death Possible
abstract: I rescue Syrians from the sites of airstrikes. I don’t want to do this work any longer.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — I am from a small town in northwestern Syria called Jisr al-Shughour. Before the war I used to buy and sell electronics. In 2013, I joined a small group of fellow Syrians to form the Syrian Civil Defense, better known as the White Helmets, a group of volunteers who rush to the scene of recent bombings to try to save people trapped beneath the rubble. In 2014, my colleagues, now numbering 3,000 men and women, elected me to lead the organization.

headline: Gretchen Rubin: By the Book
abstract: The author of “The Happiness Project” says she “can’t bear any book with the theme of unjust accusation — no ‘Atonement,’ ‘The Count of Monte Cristo’ or ‘Othello’ for me.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “The Happiness Project” says she “can’t bear any book with the theme of unjust accusation — no ‘Atonement,’ ‘The Count of Monte Cristo’ or ‘Othello’ for me.”

headline: The Falls Were Bad. The Diagnosis Was Worse.
abstract: My mother has a rare disease called P.S.P., and she can no longer walk or talk. But she’s still my mom.
lead_paragraph: “She was just standing there,” my dad told my sister, by way of explanation, “and she fell.” My mom managed a small smile, with her big swollen lip, like it was her fault, my sister told me. The three of them were living in a small apartment in Tokyo at the time. This was five years ago, in 2011, the year my mom started falling down.

headline: ‘Max Beckmann in New York,’ a Belated but Full-Blown Homage to a German Modernist
abstract: There’s not a single dud among the 39 works in a show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art about this Expressionist painter’s special connection to the city.
lead_paragraph: During the years of the Weimar Republic (1919-33), the Expressionist painter Max Beckmann was one of Germany’s most celebrated living artists. Then the Nazis designated him a degenerate artist and began confiscating his works. He and his wife, Mathilde, known as Quappi, left Germany in 1937 and moved to Amsterdam, where they stayed until 1947, when they were finally granted a visa to come to the United States. Here he remained, for two years teaching at Washington University in St. Louis, and for his last years, until his death in 1950, residing in New York City.

headline: In the Final Presidential Debate, the Trumps Go Dark
abstract: The reason many of the Trump women wore black wasn’t clear. But it made for a pointed contrast with Hillary Clinton’s white pantsuit.
lead_paragraph: After a relatively calm start to the final presidential debate on Wednesday, things took a turn for the nasty (with Donald J. Trump breaking in to call Hillary Clinton “a nasty woman” in one of the most-derided lines of the night). But perhaps we should have seen it coming. Not just because of his past behavior, but because it was signaled by those in the Republican candidate’s corner.

headline: Mark Duplass: The First Time I Fell in Love
abstract: Mr. Duplass, who wrote, produced and stars in the new film “Blue Jay,” recalls being a teenage romantic in New Orleans and falling head over heels.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t matter that we weren’t old enough to vote, drive or even rent movies without our parents. I knew that we would be together forever. And she knew it, too.

headline: A Scrappy Engine Powers the Dodgers’ Ride to the Playoffs
abstract: In Game 4, the Dodgers might have played their worst game of the season.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Farhan Zaidi came to the Los Angeles Dodgers from the Oakland Athletics, where he was an assistant to Billy Beane, the celebrated executive famous for finding undervalued assets to bolster his bargain roster. As general manager of the Dodgers, working under Andrew Friedman, Zaidi could take a small-market mind-set to a large-market payroll. His mentor may have created a monster.

headline: If Planet Nine Is Out There, It Tilts Our Solar System
abstract: Astronomers have yet to confirm another planet-size body lies deep in the solar system, but they offered new evidence of its effects on other bodies.
lead_paragraph: Most people think the eight planets in our solar system orbit the sun along a straight plane, like a disc on a record player. But actually, that plane is slightly tilted, and now astronomers think they know why: The elusive Planet Nine.

headline: Was That a Presidential Debate or a Pitch for Trump TV?
abstract: There were two Donald J. Trumps at the debate in Las Vegas: The presidential candidate, and the possible future media mogul.
lead_paragraph: Was Wednesday the final presidential debate of 2016 or the opening night of the Trump News Channel?

headline: Razing Hitler’s House
abstract: It is better to remove a symbol that risked attracting unrepentant Nazis.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Braunau am Inn, an Austrian city on the border with Germany, surrendered to the United States in May 1945, the Americans stopped a group of German soldiers from destroying the house where Adolf Hitler was born, which had served as something of a Nazi shrine during his dictatorship. Many in the city came to regret the American action.

headline: How ‘Cage-Free’ Hens Live, in Animal Advocates’ Video
keywords: ['Eggs', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Factory Farming', 'Chickens']
abstract: Direct Action Everywhere released a video of a stealth visit to a “cage-free” egg-producing barn in California that showed dead and injured chickens.
lead_paragraph: After years of pressure from animal advocates, dozens of food companies have committed themselves to “cage-free” eggs produced by hens not living in the cramped quarters known as battery cages.

headline: Watching the Kenyan Wind
abstract: The country’s huge investment in wind power could propel its own growth and motivate its neighbors.
lead_paragraph: The fierce winds blowing around Kenya’s Lake Turkana were long the bane of herders eking out a living in the arid, isolated hills. Now those winds are powering a wind farm whose grand promise and many problems are being closely followed across sub-Saharan Africa, where almost two-thirds of the population still has no access to electricity.

headline: Trump and the ‘Rigged’ Emmy Awards: A History of Snubs
abstract: “The Apprentice” has been nominated several times for Primetime Emmy Awards, and its losses have apparently weighed on Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: A vast conspiracy of well-connected insiders had colluded to rob Donald J. Trump of a prize that was rightfully his (or at least that is what he thought). The year was 2004. And then 2005.

headline: Hong Kong Tribunal Suspends Investor Who Criticized Chinese Firm
abstract: The five-year trading ban against the American investor, who had criticized the accounts of a Chinese property developer, raised concern over free speech in Hong Kong’s financial markets.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In a case that has raised concerns over freedom of speech in Hong Kong’s financial markets, a securities tribunal has issued a trading ban against an American investor who criticized the accounts of a Chinese property developer.

headline: A Remote Job Comes With Free Land and a Sense of Community. 50,000 Apply.
abstract: The unexpected response to an ad placed by owners of a store on Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia, might show how many people are hungry for a sense of community.
lead_paragraph: WHYCOCOMAGH, Nova Scotia — When a land-rich family in sparsely populated Cape Breton wanted to attract workers for its understaffed country store, it offered free land to anyone who would come and work for five years.

headline: Therapy Becomes Theater in ‘Wilderness’
abstract: The new multimedia piece, at the Abrons Arts Center, was based on the producer Anne Hamburger’s experience with placing her son in wilderness therapy.
lead_paragraph: DIXIE NATIONAL FOREST, UTAH — Standing off to the side of a dusty, unpaved road through the high desert, taking a break from a late-summer hike, the producer Anne Hamburger listened as a small gaggle of teenagers walked her through a favorite joke.

headline: Thousands of Men to Be Pardoned for Gay Sex, Once a Crime in Britain
abstract: The proposed Turing Law, named for the mathematician who was prosecuted in the 1950s, provides for posthumous pardons and allows men who are still alive to apply for pardons.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The men were convicted — tens of thousands of them — of crimes like buggery, gross indecency and loitering with intent. They had been arrested in bars, coffee houses and public bathrooms, and sometimes in the privacy of their homes and with their partners. In many cases, their only offense was seeking intimacy with another man.

headline: With Debates Done, Here’s What to Look For in Final Weeks
abstract: What would be signs of a Trump comeback? And can Republicans hold on to the Senate and the House?
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump entered the third presidential debate Wednesday night trailing by a wider margin in national polls than any modern candidate who has ever gone on to win the presidency.

headline: Donald Trump Says He Will Accept Election Outcome (‘if I Win’)
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: “Of course I would accept a clear election result, but I would also reserve my right to contest or file a legal challenge in the case of a questionable result,” Mr. Trump said.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump insisted on Thursday that he would not cede the right to contest the outcome of the presidential election, even as Democrats and Republicans expressed concern that his position threatened to upend America’s tradition of peaceful power transfers. But in a small gesture of civility, he suggested that he would not dispute the result if the outcome of the race was clear.
