headline: A Design Firm That Spins Modern Objects From Ancient Tales
abstract: The Italian duo behind Studio Formafantasma make interesting and conceptually rich pieces.
lead_paragraph: One summer holiday on the island of Sicily, home to Mount Etna, Andrea Trimarchi and Simone Farresin became obsessed with basalt, the volcanic rock created as lava cools. Trimarchi was born there and is well acquainted with the unpredictable power of Etna. “It’s like a mine without miners,” he says. “It’s always throwing out materials.”

headline: Nassau County Executive Is Arrested in Bribery Scheme
abstract: Edward P. Mangano, a powerful figure in Long Island Republican politics, was arrested along with his wife and the supervisor of the town of Oyster Bay in a scheme involving a local restaurateur.
lead_paragraph: The Nassau County executive, Edward P. Mangano, his wife and a local town supervisor were arrested and charged on Thursday with trading government contracts and official favors for free vacations, a no-show job as a food taster and other bribes — the latest in a series of corruption scandals to embarrass New York.

headline: How you can create space in a tiny home
abstract: With careful planning, a tiny home doesn’t have to be stressful.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series aimed at helping you navigate life’s opportunities and challenges. What else should we write about? Contact us: smarterliving@nytimes.com.

headline: How Much Graduates Earn Drives More College Rankings
abstract: The purpose of education is to stretch and elevate young minds, right? Now some rankings are including future earnings in their calculations.
lead_paragraph: PayScale introduced its first college salary report in 2008, and the College Scorecard from the federal government followed last year, ushering an elephant into the hallowed halls of college admissions: What do the schools’ graduates actually earn?

headline: N.C.A.A. Charges Louisville’s Rick Pitino With Rules Violations in Sex Scandal
abstract: The charges against the coach and other staff in the men’s basketball program were related to a scandal in which a university employee provided prostitutes to players and recruits.
lead_paragraph: The University of Louisville on Thursday confirmed that the N.C.A.A. had formally charged current and former staff members in its men’s basketball program, including Coach Rick Pitino, with major rules violations related to a scandal in which a university employee provided prostitutes who performed sexual acts with players and recruits.

headline: Donald Trump Heckled by New York Elite at Charity Dinner
abstract: At the Alfred E. Smith memorial event, a white-tie campaign-year ritual at the Waldorf, attempts at bonhomie went sour.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump began this quadrennial exercise in campaign humility and self-deprecation on Thursday by comparing himself to the son of God — just another “carpenter working for his father” in his youth.

headline: Sushi on Jones
abstract: A tiny open-air sushi bar sits on a NoHo lot once home to an auto repair shop.
lead_paragraph: A tiny open-air sushi bar sits on a NoHo lot once home to an auto repair shop.

headline: Omakase, on a Deadline, at Sushi on Jones
abstract: An open-air space in the Bowery Market food court may offer some of the best sushi made in the equivalent of a tollbooth. But don’t expect to linger.
lead_paragraph: It rained the first night I went to Sushi on Jones, a tiny open-air sushi bar on a NoHo lot once home to an auto repair shop. Someone had rigged two umbrellas and a tarp over the four-seat counter. The rain rustled on either side, like curtains.

headline: Spanish Court Overturns a Ban Against Bullfighting in Catalonia
abstract: The justices ruled 8 to 3 that lawmakers from the region could not prohibit a practice that they said was enshrined in the country’s cultural patrimony.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — The Constitutional Court of Spain overturned a ban against bullfighting on Thursday that had been approved by lawmakers in Catalonia six years ago, a decision that simultaneously outraged separatists in the region and animal activists.

headline: Kids of New York City
abstract: The Times asked a dozen young New Yorkers to share moments of their lives in a typical week. Here's what they sent.
lead_paragraph: The Times asked a dozen young New Yorkers to share moments of their lives in a typical week. Here's what they sent.

headline: I Don’t Want to Be ‘Inspiring’
keywords: ['Disabilities', 'Cerebral Palsy', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Down Syndrome', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT']
abstract: Forging an identity apart from my disability is hard enough. Misguided sympathy makes it harder.
lead_paragraph: One of my most memorable moments in high school came during my freshman year. A motivational speaker was addressing us in a huge assembly. I was seated with one of my best friends at the front of the auditorium, and the whole group was having an amazing time. The speaker was charismatic, exhibited a warm, jovial disposition and a wonderful sense of humor. I was smiling and laughing with the rest of the group. But at the end of the assembly, my friend and I were singled out by the speaker, who said something that people with disabilities hear often — that because I got around on crutches and she with a scooter, we were “inspiring.”

headline: ‘Lions Hunting Zebras’: Ex-Wells Fargo Bankers Describe Abuses
abstract: In legal filings and statements, former employees of the bank said immigrants, older adults, college students and Native Americans were targeted for fake accounts.
lead_paragraph: Mexican immigrants who speak little English. Older adults with memory problems. College students opening their first bank accounts. Small-business owners with several lines of credit.

headline: Voices From Wells Fargo: ‘I Thought I Was Having a Heart Attack’
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'E-Commerce', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Anxiety and Stress']
abstract: Former employees describe intimidation and ridicule tactics at the bank, which they said caused anxiety, panic attacks and other physical symptoms.
lead_paragraph: The scandal at Wells Fargo over the creation of unauthorized accounts shook its customers’ faith in the bank, but it took an even sharper toll on the company’s workers. A number of them say they faced a stark choice: Create new accounts by any means possible, or risk being fired for falling short of their sales goals.

headline: ‘Moonlight’: Is This the Year’s Best Movie?
abstract: Our critic A.O. Scott says this film about a young black man’s coming of age is both a disarmingly personal film and an urgent social document.
lead_paragraph: To describe “Moonlight,” Barry Jenkins’s second feature, as a movie about growing up poor, black and gay would be accurate enough. It would also not be wrong to call it a movie about drug abuse, mass incarceration and school violence. But those classifications are also inadequate, so much as to be downright misleading. It would be truer to the mood and spirit of this breathtaking film to say that it’s about teaching a child to swim, about cooking a meal for an old friend, about the feeling of sand on skin and the sound of waves on a darkened beach, about first kisses and lingering regrets. Based on the play “In Moonlight Black Boys Look Blue” by Tarell Alvin McCraney, “Moonlight” is both a disarmingly, at times almost unbearably personal film and an urgent social document, a hard look at American reality and a poem written in light, music and vivid human faces.

headline: What YouTube Red Gives You for $10 a Month
abstract: Google’s premium YouTube service carries a monthly subscription fee, but you get more videos and fewer ads with your membership.
lead_paragraph: Q. What does the paid version of YouTube offer? Do you get better video streaming than on the free site?

headline: Workplace Politics (the Trump-Clinton Kind)
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Dogs']
abstract: An employer weighs hiring a Trump supporter, while another urges her staff to vote for Clinton. Where to go for some peace? (Apparently not the dog run.)
lead_paragraph: I own a small bakery that’s taking off. (We make a crazy good coconut cake!) I put a sign in the window, looking for help, and asked the manager to set up interviews with the best candidates. On the morning of the interviews, I saw a woman park her car. It had a Trump bumper sticker on it. By coincidence, she turned out to be the first person I interviewed. How terrible would it be for me not to hire her on that basis alone? If it makes a difference, I am an American citizen, born here, but my mom is Mexican. I have felt attacked by Mr. Trump.

headline: Climate Silence Goes Way Beyond Debate Moderators
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Do the moderators of the presidential debates deserve scorn for leaving out climate change?
lead_paragraph: With three presidential debates and one for vice president behind us, David Leonhardt posted a helpful tally of debate questions — decrying the lack of a single question on one of the key issues facing humanity in this century and beyond: human-driven climate change. (The issue was touched on twice by Hillary Clinton in answers to other questions.)

headline: ‘Nasty Woman’ and ‘Bad Hombres’: The Real Debate Winners?
abstract: Two phrases uttered by Donald Trump at Wednesday’s presidential debate caught the attention of social media users and the online marketplace.
lead_paragraph: In one corner, we had “bad hombres.” In the other, “nasty woman.”

headline: Daily Report: Airbnb Faces a New York Showdown
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: It’s nice to be a king of the sharing economy. But the virtual hotelier may have to share something of its own: data on its members.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb is a marquee company of the so-called sharing economy, but that doesn’t mean it wants to share its own stuff.

headline: The Debate That Wasn’t: So Many Words, So Few About Policy
abstract: Many who care about taxes, immigration, the Supreme Court, health care and climate change were left with little to chew on from the three presidential debates.
lead_paragraph: The three presidential debates had no shortage of discussion about groping, beauty queens and Twitter habits. A question on energy policy this month was memorable only because it gave rise to a meme about the red sweater sported by the voter, Ken Bone, who asked it. Even on Wednesday, when the moderator made policy a priority, the discussion between Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton remained skin deep.

headline: Video Review: Hyundai Santa Fe’s Updates Deserve a Look
abstract: For 2017, the S.U.V. gets new wheels and fresh fascias front and rear. The interior’s center stack and many under-hood components are new, too.
lead_paragraph: PITY the shopper considering an S.U.V. or crossover these days. With so many excellent choices, knowing where to begin is vexing.

headline: The Fake Laugh
keywords: ['Laughter', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: How fake laughter — in politics, business and social life — can do more harm than good.
lead_paragraph: Eavesdrop on any conversation or pay close attention to your own and you’ll hear laughter. From explosive bursts to muffled snorts, some form of laughter punctuates almost all verbal communication. Electronic communication, too, LOL.

headline: Frick Collection Names Selldorf Architects for Its Renovation
abstract: The firm, whose projects include the Neue Galerie in Manhattan, will come up with a new design for the Frick, replacing Davis Brody Bond.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the Frick Collection yielded to public protest and abandoned plans for a six-story addition last year, curiosity has mounted as to how that museum would revise its renovation plans.

headline: Andrew Toles Goes From Frozen Foods to Dodgers’ Outfield
abstract: A $7.50-an-hour job at Kroger is a long way from Dodger Stadium.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The experience gap in the Dodgers’ starting lineup for its two National League Championship Series victories over the Chicago Cubs was so vast, the fleet-footed outfielder Andrew Toles would have a hard time covering it. On one end was Toles, in his fourth month in the majors, in left field. At the other was second baseman Chase Utley, who is in his 14th season. The Dodgers’ manager, Dave Roberts, said he liked the seasoning mix because all of his players, young and old, were tough.

headline: ‘Bandstand,’ From ‘Hamilton’ Choreographer, Heads to Broadway
abstract: Andy Blankenbuehler, who has won Tonys for choreography of “In the Heights” and “Hamilton,” will direct this production, slated for an April opening.
lead_paragraph: Broadway has its hip-hop musical, and soon it will have an a cappella show too. So why not swing?

headline: Making Promises We Cannot Keep
abstract: Even when the compassionate part of me aches to alleviate my patients’ fears, I should know better than to make promises I can’t keep.
lead_paragraph: Three-quarters of the way through inpatient rounds, my team and I stopped to see our patient, a woman in her 50s who had been given a diagnosis of acute lymphocytic leukemia and had been started on chemotherapy over three weeks earlier. She had been doing well and her blood counts were starting to recover, so she would soon go home.

headline: Benjamin Grosvenor Awarded Philharmonic’s New Piano Prize
abstract: The Ronnie and Lawrence Ackman Classical Piano Prize comes with $30,000 and opportunities to perform with the orchestra.
lead_paragraph: The young British pianist Benjamin Grosvenor, who has been making the leap from child prodigy to a maturing star, has been named the first recipient of a new $30,000 classical piano prize awarded by the New York Philharmonic, the orchestra announced Thursday.

headline: At 2 Georgetown Cemeteries, History in Black and White
abstract: There is an effort to restore Mount Zion, a run-down black cemetery in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, next to the lush Oak Hill, where a mostly white elite is buried.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is a tale of two cities of the dead. Two historic cemeteries lie side by side in Georgetown, separated by an overgrown dirt road, a rusting chain-link fence and two centuries of racial history.

abstract: A onetime Unicef official calls on the U.N. secretary general to take up the case of a former colleague.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: Investigators hoping for leads in a cold case released a sketch of the baby girl who may have been thrown from the second floor of an apartment building.
lead_paragraph: The emails arrive in reporters’ inboxes regularly: requests from the New York Police Department asking the news media to publicize details of a crime in the hope that it will generate investigative leads.

headline: Trump, 5; Clinton, 1: Statements at Odds With the Constitution
abstract: Over the course of the campaign, both candidates — though Donald J. Trump more frequently than Hillary Clinton — have made statements that are in tension with the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of the campaign, both candidates — though Donald J. Trump more frequently than Hillary Clinton — have made statements that are in tension with the Constitution.

headline: MetLife Grounds Snoopy. Curse You, Red Baron!
keywords: ['Life Insurance', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Logos']
abstract: The Peanuts character has been the insurer’s symbolic mascot for more than 30 years. Surveys encouraged the company to update the brand to attract global, diverse customers.
lead_paragraph: MetLife is firing Snoopy.

headline: Long-Toppled Statue of King George III to Ride Again, From a Brooklyn Studio
abstract: A workshop is recreating a statue that was torn down in 1776 and turned into ammunition, but this one is destined for the Museum of the American Revolution, now under construction in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: His Majesty’s protuberant eyes were fixed cruelly on his New York subjects. His voluptuous lips were set in steely resolve. Towering on a marble base above the Bowling Green, the gilded equestrian statue of King George III evoked a Roman emperor. With right arm upraised over the heads of the rabble, his message to a colony in revolutionary turmoil was plain enough: Don’t even think about it.

headline: A Playful Sneaker Brand — With Plenty of History
abstract: Originally a state-owned table-tennis footwear brand, Startas ceased production because of Croatia’s war of independence. Now, it’s ready for a comeback.
lead_paragraph: “You couldn’t buy Coca-Cola, but you could buy a bottle of Cockta, which is from Slovenia, and which I still love,” says the Croatian-American entrepreneur Robert Grgurev, recalling his childhood in the former Yugoslavia. Similarly, circa 1976, in lieu of Western sneakers like Converse and Superga, Croatia introduced Startas. The state-owned table-tennis footwear brand sponsored the 1987 World University Games in Zagreb; according to Grgurev, who is now the brand’s US-based president, “Every cool older kid or college student had at least one pair.” That is, until the 1990s, when production came to a brutal halt during Croatia’s war of independence, in which the one-industry town of Vukovar — home of the company’s headquarters — was ground zero.

headline: Evictions Mean Chaos for Calais Children
abstract: The French authorities plan to raze a makeshift camp for migrants outside the port city of Calais. Among those in the camp are about 1,000 unaccompanied children, raising questions over where they will be resettled.
lead_paragraph: The French authorities plan to raze a makeshift camp for migrants outside the port city of Calais. Among those in the camp are about 1,000 unaccompanied children, raising questions over where they will be resettled.

headline: Treating Diabetes
abstract: The Joslin Diabetes Center writes about the “motivational roadblocks of blame and shame.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Two Terra-Cotta Works Said to Be by Donatello and Verrocchio
abstract: The sculptures are at the Museo dell’Opera del Duomo with a question mark for the attribution; scholars have opened a discussion with their findings.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE — The Museo dell’Opera del Duomo here presented two little-known 15th-century terra-cotta sculptures on Thursday as the possible work of Donatello and Verrocchio (with, perhaps, the help of Verrocchio’s erstwhile assistant Leonardo da Vinci), proposed attributions that are expected to stir debate in Renaissance art scholarship.

headline: Another Trump Accuser Comes Forward
abstract: Karena Virginia says that Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, touched her inappropriately in 1998.
lead_paragraph: Karena Virginia says that Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, touched her inappropriately in 1998.

headline: How to break up with a friend
abstract: Take responsibility for ending the friendship rather than blaming the other person.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series aimed at helping you navigate life’s opportunities and challenges. What else should we write about? Contact us: smarterliving@nytimes.com.

headline: From ‘Lives’ to ‘Modern Love’: Writing Personal Essays With Help From The New York Times
abstract: Inspire your students by using Times models as “mentor texts” and finding advice on everything from avoiding “zombie nouns” to writing college essays.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a regular Times reader, you’ve no doubt enjoyed, and maybe even taught with, some of the 1,000-plus personal essays from the Magazine’s Lives column, which has run weekly for decades.

headline: How to throw a cheap (but elegant) dinner party
abstract: Three courses, 75 bucks and countless compliments.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series aimed at helping you navigate life’s opportunities and challenges. What else should we write about? Contact us: smarterliving@nytimes.com.

headline: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading by editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A psychic backgammon player, Eleanor Roosevelt’s other great love, Eisenhower’s Middle East crisis, and a massive new novel by the author of “Watchmen,” Alan Moore. These are just a few of the subjects that have editors this week at The New York Times Book Review madly turning the pages.

headline: Sayings and Doings of New York City Kids
abstract: The Times wants to know: Has your child, or a child you know well, said or done something recently that made you realize he or she is definitely a New York City kid? Tell us.
lead_paragraph: The Times wants to know: Has your child, or a child you know well, said or done something recently that made you realize he or she is definitely a New York City kid? Tell us.

headline: A 10th Woman Accuses Donald Trump of Inappropriate Touching
abstract: Karena Virginia said she was 27 when Mr. Trump approached her, grabbed her arm and touched her breast outside the U.S. Open tennis tournament in 1998.
lead_paragraph: The day after Donald J. Trump said accusations of inappropriate sexual contact with nine women were “totally false,” a new accuser came forward on Thursday and described an encounter in which she said Mr. Trump grabbed her arm and fondled her breast.

abstract: Readers discuss Donald Trump’s refusal to say he’ll accept the election results, the failure to ask questions about “the most important issue” and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Debating an Imprecise Gauge of Bank Performance
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The banking industry’s cost of equity is widely regarded as about 10 percent, but much has changed that supports reconsidering this important barometer.
lead_paragraph: A Goldman Sachs-led fight on bank returns will be hard to win.

headline: Donald Trump vs. American Democracy
abstract: He’s desperate for a reason to explain why he’s losing.
lead_paragraph: I’m just stunned.

headline: Wells Fargo Search Warrant and Affidavit
abstract: The California Department of Justice is investigating Wells Fargo, which has its headquarters in San Francisco, over the unauthorized accounts the bank opened in its customers’ names.
lead_paragraph: The California Department of Justice is investigating Wells Fargo, which has its headquarters in San Francisco, over the unauthorized accounts the bank opened in its customers’ names.

headline: The Innate, Ageless Appeal of Good Bordeaux
abstract: High prices are an issue, but decent vintages like 2011 are an opportunity to become acquainted with a historic region.
lead_paragraph: Nobody wants to talk about Bordeaux much these days, except for the people in the Bordeaux trade, who spend a lot of time discussing why nobody is talking about it.

headline: Review: In ‘Before the Flood,’ Leonardo DiCaprio Sounds the Climate-Change Alarm
abstract: A new documentary chronicles environmental degradation that leads to global warming and suggests steps to reduce it.
lead_paragraph: Even if you subscribe to the view that a problem isn’t a problem until a Hollywood celebrity tells you it is, “Before the Flood” feels out of phase. It’s a documentary in which Leonardo DiCaprio sounds the alarm about global warming, something that could not possibly have escaped anyone’s attention in recent years and is at this point probably beyond discussion: Either you think climate change is real or you don’t, and the battle lines aren’t likely to be shifted by an earnest movie star.

headline: Ai Weiwei Melds Art and Activism in Shows About Displacement
abstract: The activist Chinese artist has documented the struggles of migrants around the world, and now his work will be shown at three New York galleries.
lead_paragraph: When migrants were forced to evacuate the Idomeni refugee camp along the Greek-Macedonian border, the Chinese artist and dissident Ai Weiwei came to gather what they left behind.

headline: For Weight Loss, Water Beats Diet Soda
abstract: Water was more effective for weight loss than artificially sweetened beverages among overweight women with Type 2 diabetes.
lead_paragraph: Diet sodas may undermine weight loss efforts, a new study suggests.

headline: Review: ‘The Whole Truth,’ or a Slimmed-Down Version of It
abstract: Keanu Reeves is a lawyer for a teenager accused of killing his father. Renée Zellweger plays the boy’s mother in this drama that “trundles along.”
lead_paragraph: After a screening of “The Whole Truth,” a colleague remarked that it looked like a major studio release that had been tweaked to within an inch of its life, leaving only a sliver of the movie that might have been. How else to explain the involvement of two household-name stars (Keanu Reeves and Renée Zellweger) and an award-winning director (Courtney Hunt) in a plot so soulless and poorly dramatized that even the last-minute reveal is a yawn?

headline: Review: In ‘The Uncondemned,’ Rwandan Rape Survivors Seek Justice
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Sex Crimes', 'Movies']
abstract: Facing an uphill battle, a small legal team puts a former Rwandan mayor on trial for his role in encouraging and ordering rapes during the country’s 1994 genocide.
lead_paragraph: Words like justice and dignity aren’t used lightly in “The Uncondemned.” And while this sober documentary about rape during wartime treats those words and its subject with the required gravity, there are also moments of inspiration.

headline: Picking Apart 18th-Century French Furniture to Detect Forgery
abstract: Modern fakes identified in the 18th-century French furniture market have led to criminal charges — and scientific studies to help in detection.
lead_paragraph: The decorative arts adviser William Iselin recently led a team of specialists in Paris as it dismantled an early-1700s desk made by André-Charles Boulle. The piece, commissioned for a French politician, surfaced at auction in 2014 and sold for about $3 million to a private collector. The results of the analysis will help bring clarity to a field struggling with issues of authenticity.

headline: Review: Rob Zombie’s ‘31’ Traffics in Gore and Bad Taste
abstract: Instead of spoofing 1970s horror classics, this film goes overboard in trying to outdo them.
lead_paragraph: No one goes to a Rob Zombie movie looking for classy entertainment, and with “31” the director works harder than ever to reinforce that tradition. Awash in blood and revoltingly misogynistic dialogue, this latest redneck ruckus (his seventh feature) is a grindhouse slog of unrelenting bad taste.

headline: Review: ‘A Stray’ and a Muslim in Search of Acceptance
abstract: This Musa Syeed drama, starring Barkhad Abdirahman, is set in Minneapolis and shows why Mr. Syeed the storyteller is on the rise.
lead_paragraph: Adan, the young protagonist of “A Stray,” is the quintessential fellow who can’t catch a break. In this movie’s first scene he’s hanging out with other Somali immigrants, who chat in a mix of languages about their hard-knock lives — “You’re a Somali and a Muslim, no one’s gonna hire you,” one dourly observes — and he reacts badly when he’s singled out for mockery. Fleeing to the apartment where his mother lives, he’s barred entry, because she is convinced Adan has hocked some of her jewelry. Out on the streets he goes — he lives in a refugee-heavy section of Minneapolis. This city, and these people of it, are not much seen in contemporary American film.

headline: Review: In ‘Ouija: Origin of Evil,’ a Youngster Who Nails ‘Creepy’
abstract: In this prequel to “Ouija,” Lulu Wilson delivers chills as a girl with a psychic link to a malevolent board game.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you weren’t impressed with “Ouija,” the 2014 horror movie inspired by the Hasbro game. Critics certainly weren’t. But its new prequel, “Ouija: Origin of Evil,” is deliciously creepy, thanks largely to a terrific performance by the youngest of its stars.

headline: Tony’s Halal Truck Is an After-School Special in the Bronx
keywords: ['Halal Foods and Products', 'Food Trucks and Vendors']
abstract: Mohammed Wasifi has become the undisputed king of the food vendors in a corner of the borough, catering to teenagers from nearby high schools.
lead_paragraph: “Hi, Tony.”

headline: Review: ‘It Had to Be You’ Is a Witty Rom-Com With a 1950s Feel
abstract: Cristin Milioti plays an ambivalent woman weighing commitment in this film with a throwback touch.
lead_paragraph: In an age when movies and television are full of gay couples, gender-identity explorations, and strong and independent female characters, the romantic comedy “It Had to Be You” is a throwback in several ways, not all of them good. But Cristin Milioti (“How I Met Your Mother”) is so quirkily endearing in the lead role that she makes it easy to just go with the airy tale.

headline: Bottled Water or Tap: How Much Does Your Choice Matter?
keywords: ['Water', 'Plastic Bottles', 'Environment', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Recycling of Waste Materials']
abstract: What’s your daily plastic habit doing to the planet? Take this quiz and find out.
lead_paragraph: What’s your daily plastic habit doing to the planet? Take this quiz and find out.

headline: Conquering the Kick Plate
abstract: With some advice from a pro, our reporter does his best to navigate a simulation of hydroplaning in a Porsche Cayman GTS.
lead_paragraph: With some advice from a pro, our reporter does his best to navigate a simulation of hydroplaning in a Porsche Cayman GTS.

headline: A Father, a Son and the Porsche They Went In On Together
abstract: How a shared affinity for horsepower led to test runs on the racetrack, a joint lease and shared custody of a 2016 Cayman S.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — BUYING a new car is special. Buying a new sports car is very, very special. Buying a new sports car together with your adult son and then driving on a racetrack is an experience that lacks enough adjectives.

headline: Review: It’s Pornographer vs. Pornographer in ‘King Cobra’
abstract: Mr. Slater’s and Mr. Franco’s characters try to out-sleaze each other in this low-budget dark comedy.
lead_paragraph: Christian Slater and James Franco play rival producers of gay pornographic movies in Justin Kelly’s “King Cobra,” a sleazy dark comedy that aspires to be a low-budget, all-male answer to “Boogie Nights.” Based on the true story, reported in Rolling Stone, of Bryan Kocis, a maker of gay pornography who was murdered at his home in 2007, mostly it tries not to titillate with explicit images, although the dialogue is casually raunchy.

headline: What to See in New York Galleries This Week
abstract: Tomoo Gokita, Arlene Shechet, Lucky DeBellevue and “Wound: Mending Time and Attention,” a show focused on healthy communication, are among the new exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: Mary Boone Gallery 541 West 24th Street, ChelseaThrough Oct. 29

headline: Buy a New Ride and Take a Spin With a Pro
abstract: Ford and Mercedes are among the automakers who offer United States buyers a chance to drive on a course and receive free professional instruction.
lead_paragraph: Porsche and BMW are not the only automakers that offer United States buyers of their vehicles a chance to drive on a course and receive professional instruction at no charge.

headline: How Maria Shabalin, a Musical.ly Star, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: For the 14-year-old high school student, Sundays are for making videos, catching up with friends and sailing on Sheepshead Bay.
lead_paragraph: In summer 2015, Maria Shabalin was a typical tween, going to gymnastics class and hanging out with her friends in Coney Island. Then she discovered Musical.ly, the video-sharing app that has become a social media darling, especially for those in the middle-school age range. Or rather, Musical.ly discovered her, sharing her (mostly) comedic lip-syncing videos with its 30 million users (now its users total 130 million). “It was crazy and unexpected,” Maria said. The 14-year-old, who just started ninth grade at the Leon M. Goldstein High School for the Sciences in Brooklyn, now has over two million fans. She lives with her parents, Julia, 40, and Andrew, 50, her brother Anthony, 21, and four pets — a bunny named Oreo, a dog named Sarah, a Siamese cat named Kisa, and a parrot named Verdic — in a two-bedroom, six-floor walk-up in Brighton Beach.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘The Accountant’
abstract: Gavin O’Connor narrates a sequence from his film featuring Ben Affleck.
lead_paragraph: Gavin O’Connor narrates a sequence from his film featuring Ben Affleck.

headline: Review: ‘Keeping Up With the Joneses’ Might Not Be Worth It
abstract: This film about a spy couple has star power in Jon Hamm, but utilitarian construction and a lack of chemistry are downfalls.
lead_paragraph: One way to end the scourge of “TV is better than film” articles is to stop making movies like “Keeping Up With the Joneses,” a pedestrian comedy that almost seems intended as evidence for the cause. The plot invites comparisons to “The Americans”; the presence of Jon Hamm as a man of mystery prompts wistful memories of “Mad Men”; and the visual vocabulary — no one has bothered to address the abundance of overlit and sun-bleached shots — shows the indifference of a hasty live broadcast.

headline: Gavin O’Connor Narrates a Scene From ‘The Accountant’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from his film featuring Ben Affleck.
lead_paragraph: In “The Accountant,” a man on the autism spectrum is a number cruncher by day, while involving himself in seedier activities at night.

headline: Review: Albert Murray’s Symphonic Elegance Sings in a New Anthology
abstract: “Collected Essays & Memoirs” gathers writing from this great cultural critic, who was as fluent with literature as he was with jazz and the blues.
lead_paragraph: “It is always open season on the truth,” the great cultural critic Albert Murray wrote in his first and probably best book, “The Omni-Americans” (1970), “and there never was a time when one had to be white to take a shot at it.”

headline: Tumultuous Debate Draws Over 71 Million Viewers
abstract: Closing out the 14-month debate season, Wednesday’s presidential face-off drew more viewers than the last one, but far fewer than the first.
lead_paragraph: The fiery final presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump drew 71.6 million viewers, the third-highest total ever for a presidential debate, according to data from Nielsen released on Thursday.

headline: Karen Knorr’s “Gentlemen”
abstract: Between 1981 and 1983, the American photographer went inside some of London’s most exclusive gentlemen’s clubs and documented life there.
lead_paragraph: Between 1981 and 1983, the American photographer went inside some of London’s most exclusive gentlemen’s clubs and documented life there.

headline: Inside London’s Exclusive Gentlemen’s Clubs
abstract: In the ’80s, the American photographer Karen Knorr documented the sanctuaries for the wealthy, exploring themes of tradition, colonialism and social hierarchy.
lead_paragraph: When the American photographer Karen Knorr moved to London in the mid-1970s, she saw the city with an outsider’s clarity: She became fascinated by its class system, and in particular its gentlemen’s clubs, which functioned not only as exclusive sanctuaries for the wealthy, but as backdrops for discreet political networking.

headline: More New York City Schools Join Diversity Initiative
abstract: Twelve more public schools are joining a city program allowing them to alter admissions policies to enroll additional disadvantaged students.
lead_paragraph: To the disappointment of some activists, the de Blasio administration’s approach to school integration so far can be summed up in one word: incremental.

headline: 1935-1988 | How to Succeed in Business (At Least This One)
abstract: The fourth major transition of power in the Ochs-Sulzberger family is underway. Some earlier ones went smoothly. Others, less so.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historical insights from The New York Times. In this piece, David Dunlap, a Metro reporter, looks at the fourth major transition of power in the Ochs-Sulzberger family.

headline: Review: Don’t Mess With the Dog in ‘In a Valley of Violence’
abstract: A mysterious stranger rides into a decaying mining town with horse and collie. He didn’t mean to kick up trouble.
lead_paragraph: The most satisfying relationship in Ti West’s western homage, “In a Valley of Violence,” is between Ethan Hawke and a scene-stealing collie mix whose movie name is Abbie. As Keanu Reeves did a couple of years ago in “John Wick,” Mr. Hawke plays a newly reluctant killer who’s forced to exact revenge on the passel of villains who dared mess with his canine companion. As far as movies go, it seems that dogs are the new wives.

headline: $28 Billion Flows Out of Hedge Funds in Quarter Suffer Biggest Quarterly Outflow Since 2009
abstract: Under pressure, hedge funds are cutting better deals for those who stick around, a stark change in an industry known for minting billionaires overnight.
lead_paragraph: It has been a bruising year for hedge funds. Big bets have been disastrous, investors have voiced discontent and some managers have been forced to rewrite their playbooks or call it quits.

headline: I.M.F. Assessment Hints at Internal Struggles
abstract: A recent bout of infighting raises fresh questions about the institution’s culture and its promise to become more transparent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund has over the years been criticized for the byzantine intrigues of its workplace, where domineering department heads zealously guard their turf — to the detriment of the fund’s broader mission.

headline: Why it’s fine to job-hop for a few years after college
abstract: Changing jobs often is no longer a red flag, experts say — as long as you can convince potential employers that each move was wise.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series aimed at helping you navigate life’s opportunities and challenges. What else should we write about? Contact us: smarterliving@nytimes.com.

headline: Matthew Segal Wants Your Attn:
abstract: The 31-year-old started a popular news and topics site that targets progressive-leaning young people with highly shareable video content.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One Friday morning last month, Matthew Segal huddled around a table with producers and video editors from his millennial news and issues site, Attn:, whose street-level lobby here previously housed a thrift shop. As the baby-faced staff prepared to pitch video ideas, Ted Cruz finally endorsed Donald J. Trump.

lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, said on Thursday that his office would not investigate the fatal police shooting of a mentally ill woman this week in the Bronx.

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — It has come to this for the European Union: Its trade policy was being held hostage on Thursday by the Walloons.

headline: Meet the New Titanosaur. You Can Call It Wade.
abstract: Paleontologists say a newly discovered species, found in Australia, may provide insight into why these massive animals moved out of what is now South America.
lead_paragraph: David Elliott was herding sheep on his motorbike in Queensland, Australia, in 2005 when he came across a pile of fossilized dinosaur bones. He, his wife Judy and their children began piecing together tailbones, toe bones and bits of limbs.

headline: In a Promise to Lift a Curse, a Scheme to Steal Chinese Immigrants’ Savings
keywords: ['Chinese-Americans', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Elderly', 'Police', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: On Thursday, the Brooklyn district attorney’s office charged a woman in a so-called “blessing scam,” a scheme targeting Chinese immigrants.
lead_paragraph: A 61-year-old Brooklyn resident from China was walking on the street one day in April when a woman approached her and struck up a friendly conversation in Cantonese. She claimed to be a clairvoyant, and then she delivered a dire warning. “You or a family member will die soon because of a curse,” she said.

headline: Review: In ‘Creepy,’ a Cold Case Turns Red Hot, but Don’t Tell the Neighbors
abstract: Kiyoshi Kurosawa’s movie, blends elements of a detective story, horror film, domestic drama and psychological thriller to create a kind of existential dread.
lead_paragraph: A spine-tingler about love and death, the allure of mystery and its perils, “Creepy” is the latest from the prolific Japanese director Kiyoshi Kurosawa. True to its English-language title, the movie is thoroughly and utterly creepy, partly because Mr. Kurosawa knows how to slither under your skin, but also because his movies transcend the classifications (and limits) valued by critics and content providers. “Creepy” certainly works — looks and feels — like a horror movie, but it also has the conundrums of a detective story, the emotional currents of a domestic drama and the quickening pulse of a psychological thriller, a combination that creates a kind of destabilization. So, what is this movie, exactly?

headline: The Renaissance Artifact Collections That Are Back in Style
abstract: Wunderkammers were once a way for scholars and aristocrats to show off their impressive objects. Now, they’re prized by galleries and museums.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of the Renaissance, in the 16th century, aristocrats and scholars began to fill rooms with exotic artifacts from far-flung territories — horns said to have belonged to unicorns, brilliant red coral, animal skeletons, chalices made of silver or coconut shells — often displayed among Old Master paintings and sculptures. Over time, the practice of collecting items for one’s “wunderkammer” (“cabinet of wonders”) became more and more elaborate. Kings would gift extraordinary objects to other rulers to impress them with their wealth, such as a windup automaton that poured wine or a boat carved of gold and set with hundreds of precious stones. Perhaps one of the world’s greatest collections, which still exists, is the Green Vault, the treasure chamber of August the Strong, which reopened to the public in Dresden in 2004 and contains thousands of objects, from a cherry stone carved with over a hundred faces to the largest green-hued diamond in the world.

lead_paragraph: Moments from the photographer’s memorial at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Postscript: Bill Cunningham
abstract: The invitation for the photographer’s memorial said “Dress for Bill.” Some attendees certainly did.
lead_paragraph: On Monday afternoon, roughly four months after he died at age 87, more than 1,000 people gathered at Carnegie Hall to pay tribute to the longtime New York Times photographer Bill Cunningham. Fashion world notables like Ralph Lauren, Anna Wintour, Michael Kors, Vera Wang, Naomi Campbell and Jenna Lyons attended, but so did dozens of people — some famous, some decidedly not — whom Mr. Cunningham had photographed over the years for his weekly “On the Street” and “Evening Hours” columns. The invitation said “Dress for Bill.” Some attendees certainly did.

headline: One Fascinating Subculture, Four Photographic Perspectives
abstract: Several photographers in the artist collective Gasoline Pictures have contributed to its new project, which captures British darts competitions.
lead_paragraph: Several photographers in the artist collective Gasoline Pictures have contributed to its new project, which captures British darts competitions.

headline: Nintendo Switch Reaches for a New Market With Home-and-Mobile Console
abstract: The Nintendo Switch can connect to a television or go mobile, an unproven strategy and one that differs from rivals gearing up for virtual reality.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Throughout its history, Nintendo has alternated between bursts of innovation that redefined gaming and slumps where it fell behind rivals after misjudging trends. Now the company has revealed a big part of its plan for regaining its leadership in gaming.

headline: Review: ‘The Handmaiden’ Explores Confinement in Rich, Erotic Textures
abstract: This erotic fantasy from Park Chan-wook, set in Korea in the 1930s, tries to ravish your senses so thoroughly you may not notice its sleights of hand.
lead_paragraph: The art of the tease is rarely as refined as in “The Handmaiden.” Set in Korea in the 1930s, this amusingly slippery entertainment is an erotic fantasy about an heiress, her sadistic uncle, her devoted maid and the rake who’s trying to pull off a devilishly elaborate con. The same could be said of the director Park Chan-wook, whose attention to voluptuous detail — to opulent brocades and silky robes, luscious peaches and creamy shoulders — turns each scene into an invitation to ooh, aah and mmm. This is a movie that tries to ravish your senses so thoroughly you may not notice its sleights of hand.

headline: The Nickname Hillary Clinton Has Been Waiting For
abstract: Donald Trump’s epithet, as usual, sticks — but not the way he intended it to.
lead_paragraph: You could practically see the T-shirts emblazoned with the phrase before it left Donald Trump’s mouth on Wednesday night: “Such a nasty woman.” The hashtag #nastywoman started trending almost immediately on Twitter. “From one nasty woman to another, you were an inspiration last night,” Nancy Pelosi tweeted at Clinton. “RT if you’re a nasty woman and it’s made your life a freakin’ pleasure,” wrote Lena Dunham; by midday Thursday, 3,000 or so women had done just that.

headline: What to do — and not do — for perfect eyebrows
abstract: When it comes to grooming your brows, resist the urge to overdo it, says Sania Vucetaj, the owner of Sania’s Brow Bar.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series aimed at helping you navigate life’s opportunities and challenges. What else should we write about? Contact us: smarterliving@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘American Pastoral,’ Philip Roth’s Fiery 1960s at Low Heat
abstract: Ewan McGregor’s directorial debut is a shallow but watchable gloss on this Roth novel, conjuring a searing image of the disintegrating American dream.
lead_paragraph: First, the half-good news about Ewan McGregor’s streamlined screen adaptation of Philip Roth’s 1997 novel, “American Pastoral”: The movie is not a desecration but a severe diminution of a complex literary masterpiece. This shallow but watchable gloss on a book that conjures a searing image of the disintegrating American dream in the 1960s, especially as it pertains to Jewish identity and aspiration, amounts to not much more than a dutiful checklist of scenes from the novel. And its elegiac tone omits Mr. Roth’s bitterly sarcastic humor.

headline: Behind the Scenes of a Danish Star’s American Ballet Theater Arrival
abstract: Alban Lendorf made his debut as a principal dancer with Ballet Theater on Wednesday. We joined him as he took on two performances on his first night.
lead_paragraph: Alban Lendorf made his debut as a principal dancer with Ballet Theater on Wednesday. We joined him as he took on two performances on his first night.

headline: Adrenaline and Ease: Inside a Dancer’s Ballet Theater Debut
abstract: Alban Lendorf, a star of the Royal Danish Ballet, discusses his first performance as a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater.
lead_paragraph: Alban Lendorf has finally arrived. Already a star at the Royal Danish Ballet, Mr. Lendorf, 27, had joined American Ballet Theater as a principal dancer on the same day as Misty Copeland’s promotion, in June 2015. But no sooner had it been announced, than he was sidelined by a knee injury, frustrating audiences whose appetites had been whetted by two previous guest appearances.

lead_paragraph: Lest there remain any doubt, Leon Botstein, as music director of the American Symphony Orchestra, made clear in notes for a concert at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday, “Troubled Days of Peace,” that the program was aimed at politically minded listeners with the November presidential election in view. “That election will occur at a troubled and unstable moment,” Mr. Botstein wrote, “marked by discontent, an exceptional frustration with democratic politics, economic anxiety, mistrust and sharp divisions.”

headline: ‘Fire at Sea’ Is Not the Documentary You’d Expect About the Migrant Crisis. It’s Better.
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Movies']
abstract: Instead of raising awareness, Gianfranco Rosi cultivates alertness. His film is an impressionistic tour of an Italian island turned upside down.
lead_paragraph: There is a type of documentary — one of the most prevalent varieties these days — that earnestly acquaints its audience with a terrible problem and rewards our attention with a gold star of virtue. You know the kind of film I mean. We are presented with a tableau of human misery or global catastrophe that has been put together with the vague but unarguably noble intention of “raising awareness,” as if such awareness were itself a kind of solution. The rules of the genre, at least as observed by American filmmakers, dictate an upbeat conclusion. As grim as things may be, a solution can be imagined, and the simple act of watching is implicitly part of that solution.

headline: Trump Said Women Get Abortions Days Before Birth. Doctors Say They Don’t.
abstract: Mr. Trump alluded to abortions happening “on the final day.” Doctors say that scenario does not happen.
lead_paragraph: In the presidential debate Wednesday night, Donald J. Trump expounded on pregnancy and abortion, asserting that under current abortion law, “You can take the baby and rip the baby out of the womb in the ninth month, on the final day.”

headline: Rare Find in New York: A Teenage Birder
abstract: Kai Victor, a high school senior, grew up next to Central Park and has been fascinated with birds since infancy.
lead_paragraph: “You’re in for quite a show today,” said Kai Victor, stepping from the busy streets of Manhattan into Central Park, which during the fall migration season becomes a bird watcher’s paradise.

headline: Review: Tom Cruise Has a Familiar Furrow in ‘Jack Reacher: Never Go Back’
abstract: Mr. Cruise returns as this title character to fight menace in Edward Zwick’s film.
lead_paragraph: “Jack Reacher: Never Go Back” is the second movie that Tom Cruise has starred in as this title character. Let’s hope it’s the last. Mr. Cruise deserves better, as do his loyalists, who have stuck with him through the good and the bad, both in perfectly tailored roles that failed to impress audiences (“Edge of Tomorrow”) and in roles that were unworthy of all his work and our love (“Oblivion”). In recent years, only the apparently indestructible “Mission: Impossible” franchise has provided him with a steady vehicle for his talents as well as for a ride to box-office success.

headline: Kerry James Marshall’s Paintings Show What It Means to Be Black in America
abstract: The artist, who witnessed the civil rights movement, provides a history lesson with his retrospective at the Met Breuer.
lead_paragraph: People say we’re in the middle of a second civil rights movement, and we are. The only surprise is that the first one ever ended. The artist Kerry James Marshall was there for it. He was just a kid then, born in Birmingham, Ala., in 1955. But kids take in a lot.

headline: The Jewish Museum Is Giving Away Art. You Get What You Pay For.
abstract: The exhibition, “Take Me (I’m Yours),” is largely a look at the art movement known as relational aesthetics. There are plenty of free souvenirs.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the Jewish Museum seems bent on convincing people that contemporary art is nonthreatening. The museum’s group shows tend toward light and viewer friendly, nowhere more so than with its latest effort, “Take Me (I’m Yours).” A slight, playful exhibition with moments of interest, it consists almost entirely of artworks made of quantities of small inexpensive items that visitors can take home. In other words: free stuff!

headline: Guantánamo Detainee’s Conspiracy Conviction Upheld, but Legal Issue Lingers

headline: Late-Term Abortion Was the Right Choice for Me
abstract: Like so many others, I made a decision many politicians don’t think I should have the right to make.

It had stopped growing correctly around five weeks gestation, but the abnormality was not detectable until the 20-week anatomy scan. It was very unlikely that our baby would survive delivery, and if he did, he would ultimately need a heart transplant.

lead_paragraph: Successfully coaching any sport at any level requires a talent for managing players, but many of the country’s best college basketball coaches are particularly renowned control freaks. They must ensure that their athletes get decent grades. During games their chairs seem ornamental, so often are they on their feet, and they rarely allow their squads a single offensive possession without specifically instructing the point guard on how to run it.

Some like to make grids that are visually evocative, some people like to randomly add the suffix -ESQUE to entries and leave people to wonder if they should have paid more attention in school, and some people like to make themeless puzzles and stack long entries on top of each other, like lexiconic Legos.

He’s seething, because his numbers are cratering. And yet, in his mind he cannot be losing. So, everything is rigged.

Ms. McGinty seems on the upswing as Donald Trump’s campaign implodes, and now leads Mr. Toomey by less than a percentage point.

Gamers will have until March, the official launch date, to decide whether it’s a must-have. (Nintendo hasn’t set a price yet.) Investors got to weigh in faster, though, and the initial review was not encouraging. Nintendo’s share price fell 6.6 percent on Friday in trading in Tokyo.

abstract: A documentary series about corruption has been shown on state TV this week to underline that President Xi Jinping is serious about wiping out graft.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Feasts of crocodile tail. Pricey liquor by the bucketful. A nanny employed just to take care of pets. Bundles of jade bracelets worth millions. A free trip to the World Cup in Brazil.

headline: How to Protect Yourself From Sexual Assault on a Plane

abstract: To minimize the risk of being sexually assaulted on a plane, book an aisle seat and talk to a flight attendant if someone is making you uncomfortable.
lead_paragraph: Allison Dvaladze said she was on a flight from Seattle to Amsterdam in April when she was sexually assaulted.

headline: Hawaii Looks Back, and Ahead, as Its Presidential Spotlight Dims
abstract: With President Obama’s time in the White House almost up, a tour of Honolulu found residents proud of their native son but wistful about the coming loss of attention.
lead_paragraph: In Hawaii to monitor two hurricanes barreling across the Pacific, I took a detour to the neighborhood where President Obama grew up.

headline: Baking Cookies in My Mother’s Kitchen
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Cookies', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: I thought that by keeping my mother’s bakery open I wouldn’t have to face the truth that she was gone.
lead_paragraph: I keep a photo on my nightstand of my mom and me making handmade biscotti when I was little. I’m wearing an oversize apron, my cheeks as voluminous as her ’80s-style hot-rollered hair. The photo is a reminder of a joyful time when I still liked making cookies and I still had my mom.

headline: Partying in South Beach Like It’s $19.99
abstract: The bars and clubs of South Beach are notoriously expensive. Here’s how to get the best thump-thump for your dollar.
lead_paragraph: They had turned out the regular overhead lights at the Pearl Champagne Lounge, and now there was just black light, which lent an eerie fluorescence to the clubgoers’ white T-shirts and teeth, and the occasional glow stick. The bass-heavy thump was shaking the walls of the club, but the room was so packed it was difficult to dance. Unable to move their legs, dancers resorted to simply pointing to the ceiling in time to the music (“Do you want to get wasted, wasted”). At one point a huge, muscled gentleman pulled out a full-size trombone — if he didn’t work there, I’m not sure how he got that thing past security — and began playing along to the music.

headline: A Lisbon Food Court Housed in a Palace
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Palaces and Castles']
abstract: The two floors of Palácio Chiado offer seven stops, each spinoffs of existing restaurants, from casual tapas to fancy seafood.
lead_paragraph: As we entered under a stone archway hugging two oversize wooden doors, a nattily dressed man motioned us through a glass door, then thrust black pocket-size charge cards into our hands. Those cards (on which you run a tab and pay on the way out) at the ready, we set off to explore the 18th-century palace that houses Palácio Chiado, which opened to a lot of buzz in April.

headline: On the Water, and Into the Wild
abstract: The lakes and forests of Minnesota’s Boundary Waters transport you to a time when nature was not a thing at the edge of civilization, but a world unto itself.
lead_paragraph: There are no roads here. No towns or airports. There are no gas stations, businesses, cars, airplanes, electricity, phone service. There is water. And if you are not on it, you are in the woods.

headline: The Mission to Save Vanishing Internet Art
keywords: ['Art', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: A group sets out to preserve early digital works that are in danger of fading away.
lead_paragraph: In the 1990s, art found a new medium. Anarchic and unconstrained, the World Wide Web attracted an oddball collection of people ready to do almost anything and call it art. Often their work looked weird and amateurish, with pixelated graphics, tinny chiptune music and garish colors. But what it lacked aesthetically it made up for in conviction.

lead_paragraph: A few months ago, Sarai Gonzalez’s proudest distinction was being a funny older sister. She hammed it up during dance parties in her family room in Green Brook, N.J. She wore studded pink high-tops and baked a mean cupcake.

headline: Fighting for Indonesia’s Mentally Ill, and Counting Toilets as Progress
abstract: Whatever improvements that have come to the country’s mental health system are largely the result of the efforts of Nova Riyanti Yusuf.
lead_paragraph: BEKASI, Indonesia — Spike heels clacking on the concrete floor of the patients’ cells, Nova Riyanti Yusuf strode grandly into the Yayasan Galuh Rehabilitation Center. As she reached the bottom floor, dozens of patients circled around her, curious and confused. One man appeared to be having an episode, continually introducing himself by new names and cackling with laughter.

headline: Two ’70s Movies on Video Enter the Valley of the Cult Heroines
abstract: Eiichi Yamamoto’s animated “Belladonna of Sadness” is organically outré; Russ Meyer’s “Beyond the Valley of the Dolls” is intentionally so.
lead_paragraph: In late 1970, Alejandro Jodorowsky’s druggy, mystical western “El Topo” opened at the Elgin Theater in New York with no more fanfare than a small notice in The Village Voice. The film was to be screened only at midnight, according to the ad, because it was “too heavy to be shown any other way.”

Dozens of diners were loudly chatting at Kola House, a restaurant-cum-Pepsi-marketing space in Chelsea, when she took to a small stage at the end of the room.

lead_paragraph: Christopher Guest has mined quirky cultures like amateur thespians (“Waiting for Guffman”) and dog-show participants (“Best in Show”) and transformed them into cheerfully squirm-inducing comedy. Now he tackles the performers beneath the plush in “Mascots,” his first film in a decade, which is streaming on Netflix and also in limited theatrical release.

headline: Should You Let Your Dog Lick Your Face?
abstract: There are potential hazards. Some bacteria in dogs’ mouths are zoonotic, meaning the animals can pass them to humans and cause disease, experts say.

headline: The Siege Starts Without Warning
abstract: Twenty-four years ago I was a young man in Sarajevo. Now I watch Aleppo and imagine what life is like there.
lead_paragraph: ZAGREB, Croatia — I woke one morning 24 years ago to find a war all around me. The night before I had been at a concert for the Partybreakers, a punk band from Belgrade. I’d had too much beer and I had a headache. Bursts of gunfire were audible, along with the explosions of the mortar shells that would rain down on Sarajevo for the next three and a half years.

headline: Don’t Dress Your Age

headline: Henry Green’s (Latest) Comeback
abstract: New York Review Books Classics is hoping to restore the English novelist’s visibility for good.
lead_paragraph: The writer Henry Green’s fashionability has gone through more phases than the moon. As far back as 1960, Robert Gorham Davis was writing in the Book Review that Green “has shown more subtlety and virtuosity than any other novelist of his generation in England,” but had been kept from “the recognition he deserves.”

headline: The Story Behind This Week’s Best Sellers
abstract: Bryan Cranston, whose memoir is No. 9 on the hardcover nonfiction list, has a sense of humor about his fame: “It’s a little . . . odd to have your face tattooed on someone’s backside.”
lead_paragraph: Ink: Before Bryan Cranston became a TV star, as the father on “Malcolm in the Middle” and especially as Walter White in “Breaking Bad,” he spent decades just trying to make a living as an actor, hustling for bit parts and homely commercial work. To judge from the genial, disarming tone of his memoir, “A Life in Parts” (new at No. 9 on the hardcover nonfiction list), that journeyman experience has given him the perspective to stay humble in the face of fame — or at least to maintain a sense of humor about it. “I’ve seen ‘Breaking Bad’ T-shirts in cities and little outposts all over the world,” he writes toward the end of the book. “People dress as Walter White for Halloween. They dress their children and dogs in hazmat suits and Heisenberg hats. People have shaved my face into the back of their heads, they’ve inked it on their backs, their forearms, their legs, their asses. I’m the permanent resident of some guy’s left butt cheek. Next to Larry and Moe. I suppose I’ve taken the place of Curly, the third Stooge. It’s a little . . . odd to have your face tattooed on someone’s backside. I did not see that coming when I lied about my ability to mountaineer in order to get a Mars bar commercial.” Fame has other pitfalls, too, Cranston adds. “As an actor you need to be sensitive, to be open, to be able to observe people and study human behavior,” he writes. “But as a celebrity I am no longer the observer, I am the observed. I am not the one who knocks. I am the one who ducks and covers.”

headline: Paperback Row

lead_paragraph: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: Should Novels Aim for the Heart or the Head?
abstract: Is it a good thing for a novel to stimulate our emotions? Montaigne, Brecht and others thought not.
lead_paragraph: The devil is in the detail. Talking about moments when excruciating gallstone pains made him believe he was soon to die, Montaigne remarks: “When I looked upon death as the end of my life, universally, then I looked upon it with indifference. Wholesale, I could master it: Retail, it savaged me; the tears of a manservant, the distributing of my wardrobe, the known touch of a hand, a routine word of comfort discomforted me and made me weep.”

And since Mr. Burns is portrayed quite spectacularly by Nathan Lane as a man whose advice you ignore at your peril, I shall state right away — with the rattling fanfare of a hundred manual typewriters — that the revival of Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur’s 1928 classic, which opened on Thursday night at the Broadhurst Theater, is …

abstract: The Danish String Quartet also vacuums, turns the lights out at the end of the night, and is pretty good at music, too.

headline: N.F.L. Schedule: Here’s Who We Think Will Win in Week 7
abstract: The Seahawks look to bury the Cardinals in the N.F.C. West; the Steelers face the Patriots without Ben Roethlisberger. Here’s what to expect.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. season is not even at its halfway point, but Sunday night’s matchup could decide the N.F.C. West, as the Seattle Seahawks travel to Arizona with the hope of burying the Cardinals. It should be the game of the week after Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger’s knee injury spoiled a tantalizing matchup with Patriots quarterback Tom Brady on Sunday afternoon. Here is a look at Sunday’s matchups and who we think will win them.

headline: 50 Years On, Wales Honors Those Buried Alive in Aberfan
abstract: A mountain of coal waste and slurry from Welsh mines slid through the village after days of hard rain, killing 144, including 116 children.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There had been warnings from the village in South Wales, which lived off the state-owned coal mines and under the huge mounds of waste and tailings they produced, but the government ignored them.

headline: Escape the news to the Boundary Waters

headline: Making Her Operatic Debut, the Notorious R.B.G.

headline: Are You There? It’s Me, Reality: Grit Returns to Young-Adult Novels
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Issue-driven fiction is having a renaissance. Several new books are an outgrowth of the financial crisis, the rise of racial tensions and the increased animosity toward immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Growing up on Long Island in the 1970s, I kept a copy of Judy Blume’s “Are You There, God? It’s Me, Margaret,” in its classic lavender-tinted paperback edition, tucked away in a closet in my playroom with the vague intention of returning it to the local library, someday. As months went by and I read and reread the novel upward of a half-dozen times, it became clear that I would never give it up. I imagined thousands of dollars of fines accruing and ultimately an arrest followed by some period of detention. Wasn’t the involvement of law enforcement the only proper response to an abject refusal to relinquish something so precious?

abstract: There are three important steps: Identifying the problem, confiding in someone you trust, and creating a strategy.

headline: European collectors help bolster FIAC art fair

abstract: The crowd at FIAC’s Wednesday preview remained predominantly Francophone, but major international collectors were in town for the fair —and art was selling, provided it was by a validated name.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Last year, France was the world’s fourth largest market for art and antiques. The country generated a “stable” 6 percent of the $63.8 billion of global sales made in 2015 by auction houses and dealers, according to the Tefaf Art Market Report  , published in March.

headline: William G. Bowen, Princeton Educator Who Championed Poor and Minority Students, Dies at 83
abstract: Dr. Bowen was president of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation and also served as provost and president of Princeton, overseeing the admission of women and expanding the university academically.
lead_paragraph: William G. Bowen, a distinguished and influential educator who pressed elite colleges to give preference to poor and minority applicants, oversaw the first admission of women to Princeton University and expanded it academically, died on Thursday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 83.

headline: With Europe-Canada Deal Near Collapse, Globalization’s Latest Chapter Is History
abstract: As the agreement effectively died, it underscored the extent to which trade has become politically radioactive around much of the globe.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Even in this moment of fierce reassessment of the merits of free trade, the deal promoting commerce between the European Union and Canada seemed like a safe bet to secure political blessing on both sides of the Atlantic.

lead_paragraph: Scented candles. Fragrance sticks. Incense. Potpourri. Many of us spend a lot of time (and money) trying to make our homes smell pretty. Hotels have been dousing their lobbies with fragrances for years, hoping we’ll keep booking rooms at the Westin because it smells like White Tea.

headline: The Pharma C.E.O. Who Wants to Lower Drug Prices
abstract: Companies can drop prices and still make money, says the chief executive of GlaxoSmithKline.

The interview has been condensed and edited.

And let’s say this place also sold absolutely delicious, well-seasoned samosas for a pittance. And the place was really close to your house, a constant temptation but a kind of comfort, too.

abstract: Giving her version of events for the first time, Bridget Anne Kelly, the deputy chief of staff to Gov. Chris Christie, said in court the governor had signed off on the plan.

Chris Christie of New Jersey at the center of the political plot to close access lanes at the George Washington Bridge broke her long silence in federal court on Friday, saying that the idea to close the lanes had been sold to her as a policy matter to move traffic more rapidly across the Hudson River, and that the governor had signed off on it.

The next in the series is the director Christopher Guest, whose new film, “Mascots,” is out on Netflix now. He shares his list exclusively with T.

headline: Trump in April: If I Lose, ‘I’ll Let It All Out’
abstract: Making sense of the last days of an improbable campaign.
lead_paragraph: As Donald Trump’s improbable candidacy careens through its final month, it might be easier to list the public figures who haven’t suffered his slings and arrows than to list the ones who have. Among the latest is the House speaker, Paul Ryan, who told House Republicans last week that he was done defending Trump (though not rescinding his endorsement of him).

headline: Review: On Adult Swim, He’ll See You When You’re Sleeping
abstract: The new comedy “Dream Corp LLC” mixes live action and animation as it looks at the goings-on in a dubious therapy practice.
lead_paragraph: First watch a little of “Falling Water,” the earnest and somewhat indecipherable new USA drama about three people who experience vivid dreams. Then watch “Dream Corp LLC,” a daffy comedy about a dream-therapy company, that arrives Sunday night on Adult Swim.

headline: Over-Under Prediction: Oregon and Cal Will Light Up Scoreboard
abstract: The over/under for the Oregon-California football game, 89½, is the highest known total since 1980.
lead_paragraph: There are few sure things in sports, but this might be one: Oregon and California will score a lot of points when they play Friday night.

headline: Review: ‘Boo! A Madea Halloween’ Finds Tyler Perry in the Usual Costume(s)
abstract: Mr. Perry’s most popular character is back again to crack wise and deliver advice in this comedy. He plays some other people, too.
lead_paragraph: “Tyler Perry’s Boo! A Madea Halloween” is Mr. Perry’s 16th feature film as a director, and it shows him just barely more adept in this respect as he was for his first outing, “Madea’s Family Reunion” (2006). His shot composition is rudimentary at best, his blocking of action is practically indifferent, and his editing rhythms run the gamut from hobbled to stumbling.

headline: Mackerel, Milder Than Salmon and Just as Delectable
abstract: Long weighed down by a unpleasantly odoriferous reputation, this sustainable, meaty fish is an excellent choice for a quick weeknight dinner.
lead_paragraph: One of the greatest seafood mysteries is why an assertively flavored fish like salmon is vastly more popular than a milder one like Spanish mackerel.

headline: Dark Spot in Mars Photo Is Probably Wreckage of European Spacecraft
abstract: The remnants of the Schiaparelli lander seemed to appear on Mars in photos taken by a NASA orbiter, the European Space Agency said Friday.
lead_paragraph: A dark splotch on Mars most likely marks the remnants of a spacecraft that tried to land there this week, the European Space Agency said on Friday.

headline: What Door-to-Door Tradition Came Before Trick-or-Treating?
abstract: Many older New Yorkers recall dressing up and begging for treats on a day that now focuses on turkey and pies.
lead_paragraph: Q. Before Halloween trick-or-treating caught on, wasn’t there a different holiday in New York in which costumed children went around asking for treats?

headline: Formula One’s Blue Flags Leave Some Seeing Red
abstract: A racing rule aimed at making lapped racecars move aside to allow faster ones to pass has pitted the richer teams against the poorer ones.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — In the highly refined world of Formula One auto racing, there is little room for such lowly sentiments as road rage.

abstract: The cast recording of “Lazarus” has “Killing a Little Time,” and politics make appearances on Le Tigre’s “I’m With Her” and Randy Newman’s “Putin.”

You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist?  Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter (coming soon!) here.

headline: 35 Arrests in Long Island Gang Case as Another Body Is Found
keywords: ['Gangs', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The Suffolk County Police Department said it arrested 35 members of MS-13, the gang with roots in El Salvador and Los Angeles, after more skeletal remains were found this week in Brentwood.
lead_paragraph: With another body discovered in Brentwood, N.Y., this week, the Suffolk County Police Department has announced its response: the arrest of what it said were 35 members of MS-13, a gang with roots in El Salvador and Los Angeles that has long been terrorizing the Long Island town.

headline: Warm Nights of Fall
abstract: Last week’s top charity galas included the Frick Collection, Keep a Child Alive, the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, and the New York Women’s Foundation.
lead_paragraph: Despite summerlike temperatures, the fall social calendar was in full swing. The Frick Collection held its autumn dinner on Oct. 17 at its Upper East Side house. Keep a Child Alive, co-founded by Alicia Keys, hosted its annual ball on Oct. 19 at the Hammerstein Ballroom, raising $2 million for H.I.V. care in sub-Saharan Africa. The National Committee on American Foreign Policy held a dinner on Oct. 19 at the Metropolitan Club. And the New York Women’s Foundation, which bills itself as the nation’s largest women’s grant-making fund, presented its fall gala at the Plaza Hotel on Oct. 13.
