lead_paragraph: So what happened in Sunday night’s big N.F.C. West matchup between the Seattle Seahawks and the Arizona Cardinals? Did Carson Palmer put a big game together and lead Arizona to victory? Or did Seattle’s crack defense help win the game?

headline: 14 Recipes for Right Now
abstract: Own the morning and the night with these weekday recipes.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Lawyers for Adnan Syed, of ‘Serial’ Podcast, Ask Court to Free Him on Bail
abstract: If Mr. Syed is released while awaiting a retrial in the killing of Hae Min Lee, it would be his first time out of prison in over 15 years.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Adnan Syed, whose murder case was spotlighted on the popular “Serial” podcast in 2014, said on Monday that they had filed a motion in a Maryland court asking that Mr. Syed be released on bail.

headline: Election May Be a Turning Point for Legal Marijuana
abstract: Opinion polls point to the possibility that voters in California and four other states will legalize marijuana in what some call a vast experiment in public health.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — To the red-and-blue map of American politics, it may be time to add green. The movement to legalize marijuana, the country’s most popular illicit drug, will take a giant leap on Election Day if California and four other states vote to allow recreational cannabis, as polls suggest they may.

headline: The Best Sellers: Filed Under Sports
abstract: The best-selling sports books in September 2016, according to the New York Times best-seller list.
lead_paragraph: The best-selling sports books in September 2016, according to the New York Times best-seller list.

headline: New Oxford Shakespeare Edition Credits Christopher Marlowe as a Co-author
abstract: Marlowe is being listed on the three “Henry VI” plays, parts 1, 2 and 3, which have long been believed to be the work of more than one writer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Shakespeare may have had a little more help than previously suspected.

headline: Plan to Bail Out ‘Too Big to Fail’ Banks Raises Skepticism
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: There is something odd about adding yet another legal entity to the already complex corporate structure of banks.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, we have received the latest installment in the long-running — and some would say quixotic — attempt to explain how certain supersize American financial institutions would be addressed under the bankruptcy code if they were to fail.

headline: How to Clean a Dusty Picasso at MoMA: Use Your Spit
abstract: A new audio guide shifts the focus from works of art to the dust that coats them.
lead_paragraph: Anny Aviram has spent more than 40 years as a conservator at the Museum of Modern Art, often swabbing away dust and grime on priceless Picassos and other masterpieces.

headline: Ian Stewart: Calculating the Cosmos
abstract: A calculation challenge by the mathematician Ian Stewart, author of the newly released “Calculating the Cosmos: How Mathematics Unveils the Universe.”
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge was suggested by Ian Stewart, the world-class mathematician and best-selling author, whose Calculating the Cosmos: How Mathematics Unveils the Universe has just been published.

headline: Free Puzzle Alert! If You Build It, They Will Come
abstract: Print out a free puzzle to help congratulate the Cubs and the Indians to the World Series.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — This is an exciting week for baseball fans, and the prospect of lifting the “curse” off either the Chicago Cubs or the Cleveland Indians is enough to get even me watching the games.

headline: Adam Conover Turns a Skeptical Eye to the Presidential Campaign
abstract: Mr. Conover, the star of truTV’s “Adam Ruins Everything,” recently taped an election special. He just hoped events wouldn’t overtake it.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Adam ruins everything, but backstage late last month at the Trocadero Theater here, he was hoping that the tide of events wouldn’t ruin his coming truTV election special. And that was before the presidential campaign really turned wacky.

headline: Do Your Investments Actually Help You Reach Your Goals?
abstract: The answer to this basic question is the key to ensuring you’re on the right path, a financial adviser writes.
lead_paragraph: Recently, a financial adviser shared a story about a prospective client. The client had a problem. He didn’t like how heavily his portfolio was invested in the stock market. The risk just felt as if it was too much.

headline: The New York Times is looking for a Deputy Video Editor
abstract: We’re hiring the best talent to shape our on the ground and original reporting, experiment with new forms of video, and launch a new slate of shows and series.
lead_paragraph: We’re hiring the best talent to shape our on the ground and original reporting, experiment with new forms of video, and launch a new slate of shows and series.

headline: New York Times Company Buys The Wirecutter
abstract: The company also bought The Sweethome, a sister site. Both are product recommendation websites that offer guides on tech gadgets and home products.
lead_paragraph: As The New York Times Company transforms for the digital age, it has moved more into lifestyle journalism, with online products like Cooking, Watching and Well. Now, it has made another bet on so-called service journalism, with the acquisition of the product recommendation site The Wirecutter and its sibling, The Sweethome.

headline: City Hall Restaurant’s Chef Opens Wine Shop
abstract: Henry Meer, who closed his restaurant at the end of 2015, has opened a wine shop in the Oculus.
lead_paragraph: Henry Meer, the chef who ran City Hall restaurant for 17 years and closed it last December, now owns a wine and spirits shop in the Westfield development of the Oculus in the World Trade Center area. Unlike most of the retailers, like Stuart Weitzman, Sephora or Tumi, his is an independent store, not a chain. The shop, with a barrel stave ceiling and wood throughout, carries wines from $15 to $1,500. And it offers a consumer-friendly feature: a descriptive capsule of information on each of the wines on display. The tags show body and acidity on a sliding scale. Among the choices is Henry’s Glass, a smooth, earthy Bordeaux blend from Washington State, specially made for City Hall. The store has about 60 bottles left of the 2012 vintage, $18.99: Pure Liquid Wine & Spirits, Westfield World Trade Center, South Concourse, Balcony Level, 212-227-7777, drinkpureliquid.com.

headline: I’m 29 and I never learned how money works. It’s time to fix that.
keywords: ['Personal Finances', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Student Loans', 'Customer Loyalty Programs']
abstract: Simple answers to questions you’ve always had about money.
lead_paragraph: So here’s a mildly embarrassing personal truth I will admit: I’m 29 and I have no idea how money works.

headline: What 9 Shoppers Wore to the Whole Foods in Williamsburg
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: For some Brooklynites, style abounds, even while grocery shopping.
lead_paragraph: For some Brooklynites, style abounds, even while grocery shopping.

headline: A Guidebook to Chef Tattoos
abstract: Stories and drawings decode the popular adornments of the modern chef.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who encounters a chef while dining out is bound to have seen them: arms and other body parts covered in elaborate tattoos. Chefs of André Soltner’s generation did not covet them, but for younger cooks, the tattoo seems to have supplanted the toque as part of the uniform. They’ve been documented in a book with a sampling of ink adorning the bodies of dozens of chefs, male and female, precisely drawn by Wendy MacNaughton. Pigs are very popular; John Prescott of Eden East in Austin, Tex., has one on his head. Some, like the bee behind the left ear of Angie Mar, the chef and an owner of the Beatrice Inn in Manhattan, are discreet: “Knives & Ink: Chefs and the Stories Behind Their Tattoos (With Recipes)” by Isaac Fitzgerald and Wendy MacNaughton (Bloomsbury, $24).

headline: Police in India Kill 24 Maoist Rebels
abstract: A battle between officers and the rebels took place at what the police said appeared to be a training camp in a remote area of eastern India. An activist called it staged.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Indian police officials said they had killed 24 Maoist rebels early on Monday in a gun battle at what appeared to be a training camp in a remote area of eastern India.

headline: This Cheese Is Small, but Potent
abstract: St. Albans, from Vermont Creamery, is modeled after a French variety.
lead_paragraph: This innocent little disk of cheese, in its ceramic crock, has plenty of pungent power to unleash. It’s an aged cow’s milk cheese called St. Albans, named for the cooperative that provides the milk to Vermont Creamery. Within its tender white rind, it’s pure satin with deep flavor. The cheese is modeled after the French St.-Marcellin. You can warm it in its crock to make it easier to spread: St. Albans from Vermont Creamery, $8.99 at Whole Foods and Wegmans, vermontcreamery.com.

headline: CMV Is a Greater Threat to Infants Than Zika, but Far Less Often Discussed
abstract: Every year in the U.S., 20,000 to 40,000 infants are born with cytomegalovirus. Yet most doctors don’t talk with pregnant women about how to prevent it.
lead_paragraph: Laura Sweet had no idea that she had contracted a virus that would leave her daughter, Jane, deaf by her first birthday.

headline: American Couple Pledges Art Collection to the Musée D’Orsay
abstract: Marlene and Spencer Hays will gift more than 600 masterworks, the largest foreign donation to France in decades.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Two art collectors from the United States, Marlene and Spencer Hays, have pledged the Musée d’Orsay here the largest foreign collection of art to be donated to France since World War II — more than 600 masterworks from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including works by Pierre Bonnard, Edouard Vuillard, Amedeo Modigliani and Henri Matisse.

headline: Daily Report: Hackers Have New Tools to Bring Down Websites
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Home Automation and Smart Homes']
abstract: The so-called internet of things has the potential to connect billions of objects to the internet. That’s good news for troublemakers.
lead_paragraph: Some people are old enough to remember when websites went down because of incompetence, not malicious intent.

headline: Hard Ciders With New York Attitude
abstract: Four bottled ciders from the soon-to-open Brooklyn Cider House.
lead_paragraph: These rather elegant hard ciders, ideal to grace an autumn table or to be served year round, are the first releases from the Brooklyn Cider House, a cider-making facility and restaurant in Bushwick, Brooklyn, which has pushed back its opening until early next year. The ciders are made in upstate New York from Northern Spy, Rhode Island Greening, Goldrush, Spitzenburg and Ellis Bitter apples grown near New Paltz by the owner Peter Yi, the founder of P J Wines in Inwood. The choices are: Kinda Dry, winey with a dry finish; Half Sour, pale, tart and food-friendly; Still Bone Dry, austere, with slight carbonation; and Bone Dry, also austere with more vigorous spritz: Brooklyn Cider House ciders, in 750-milliliter bottles for around $10, and 12-ounce bottles for about $3 at stores in the Hudson Valley and New York City, with information at brooklynciderhouse.com.

headline: How to Design Your Own Postage Stamps
keywords: ['Stamps (Postal)', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: You can add a personal touch to your snail mail by creating custom stamps from your own photos.
lead_paragraph: Q. I recently saw a postage stamp that looked like it had a personal photo as the image. How do you get those?

headline: Welcome the Arrival of White Truffles
abstract: Truffle Lab on the Upper West Side celebrates the treasured delicacy.
lead_paragraph: It’s white truffle season, and the treasured tubers, which can fetch up to $150 an ounce, are perfuming plates of pasta in many restaurants. Urbani Truffles, a major supplier, has scheduled cooking classes at the Truffle Lab in its headquarters on the Upper West Side. Pasta with white truffles will be featured from 6 to 8 p.m. on Tuesday, Nov. 16 and Dec. 13; pizza with truffles will be taught from noon to 2 p.m. on Nov. 5 and Dec. 3; and a truffle brunch is scheduled from noon to 2 p.m. on Nov. 19. Each white truffle class includes a tasting with wine: Truffle Lab, $125 to $135, Urbani Truffles, 10 West End Avenue (West 60th Street), 212-247-8800, urbani.com.

headline: NYT's Turkey Text
abstract: Sign up here and Sam Sifton from NYT Cooking will text you menu, shopping and cooking tips.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here and Sam Sifton from NYT Cooking will text you menu, shopping and cooking tips.

headline: Kings of Leon Finally Land a No. 1 Album With ‘WALLS’
abstract: The band’s seventh album debuted at the top of the Billboard 200, ahead of new records by the Game and JoJo.
lead_paragraph: After seven albums and 13 years, Kings of Leon have finally made it to No. 1.

headline: Spray-On Tanning, Considered
abstract: Exactly how do such tanning products work, and do they work safely?
lead_paragraph: Q. How do self-tanning products change the color of my skin? Are they safe?

headline: AT&T and Time Warner Seek to Mollify Deal’s Critics
abstract: AT&T’s chief executive, Randall Stephenson, and his Time Warner counterpart, Jeffrey Bewkes, tried to address analysts’ concerns on Monday.
lead_paragraph: AT&T’s proposed $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner has no shortage of skeptics.

headline: Fighting Insider Trading Charges, Son Seeks Immunity for Father
abstract: Sean Stewart claims that prosecutors improperly threatened his father to keep him from testifying that there was no violation of the law.
lead_paragraph: There is a scene in the 1992 movie “My Cousin Vinny” in which the defense lawyer gets a courtroom bailiff to bring his girlfriend forward to testify over her vocal resistance. How much help the government has to give to the defendant to build a defense is the basis on which Sean Stewart, a former investment banker convicted in August of insider trading, is asking for a new trial. He claims that prosecutors improperly threatened his father to keep him from testifying that there was no violation of the law.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Ensuring Voters’ Rights
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A reader calls for changes such as automatic voter registration upon turning 18 and weekend voting. Readers are invited to respond.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Explosion Batters Neighborhood in China, Killing 14 and Wounding Nearly 150
abstract: It appeared likely that the blast, in the northwestern province of Shaanxi, was caused by dangerous substances stored haphazardly and too close to homes.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — At least 14 people were killed and nearly 150 wounded when a blast tore apart a neighborhood in a small town in northwestern China on Monday, battering nearby homes, shattering windows and sending residents streaming from the smoking ruins.

headline: A Butcher Adds a Pickle Stand to His Portfolio
abstract: Jake Dickson’s new Chelsea Market kiosk offers a selection of fermented delights.
lead_paragraph: Jake Dickson’s butcher shop in Chelsea Market now has a sibling: a little shop for pickles and other fermented products, more than 30 of them. Bright containers of everything from standard half-sours to Italian eggplant pickles, mole carrots, pickled eggs and kimchi are set out in containers and tubs on a counter, with toothpicks for sampling. Josh Halter (right), a chef and fermentation fanatic, is in charge of this kiosk. The pickle lineup may rotate, as Mr. Halter would like to add some Japanese and Russian specialties: Dickson’s Fine Brines, Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (West 15th Street), 347-262-8526, dicksonsfarmstand.com.

headline: What You Should Watch: ‘Humans’ and ‘Rectify’
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

headline: Freed Sailors Recount Years of Torture at the Hands of Somali Pirates
abstract: The crew members, released after four and a half years in captivity, recalled how they were beaten with poles and ate rats to survive in the desert.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The crew of the Naham 3, a longline fishing trawler, will never forget the day in 2012 when they disappeared.

headline: Gun Control | Gun Rights: Is Resolution Possible?
abstract: At a Times Insider event on Tuesday, Oct. 25, four New York Times journalists took part in a discussion about gun control and gun rights. Watch the discussion here — and read through the comments, posted in real-time, by New York Times readers.
lead_paragraph: At a Times Insider event on Tuesday, Oct. 25, four New York Times journalists took part in a discussion about gun control and gun rights. Watch the discussion here — and read through the comments, posted in real-time, by New York Times readers.

headline: Rodrigo Duterte Gets Closer to China, and the Neighbors Notice
abstract: Countries like Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam may now see the value in drawing closer to Beijing, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — After unleashing an anti-American tirade in Beijing last week, President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines left some Chinese, who like tightly scripted state visits, wondering if their unpredictable guest could be trusted.

headline: Kenya Spares the Lives of Everyone on Its Death Row
abstract: President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya commuted 2,747 convicts’ death sentences to life in prison on Monday, in a country that has not actually executed anyone since 1987.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — With a stroke of his pen, President Uhuru Kenyatta spared the lives of thousands of prisoners on Kenya’s death row on Monday by commuting their sentences to life in prison.

headline: Taking Down Dams and Letting the Fish Flow
keywords: ['Levees and Dams', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Animal Migration', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Rivers', 'Salmon']
abstract: On the Penobscot in Maine and other rivers in the U.S., several endangered species are rebounding with the reopening of spawning areas.
lead_paragraph: BANGOR, Me. — Joseph Zydlewski, a research biologist with the Maine Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Unit of the United States Geological Survey, drifted in a boat on the Penobscot River, listening to a crackling radio receiver. The staccato clicks told him that one of the shad that his team had outfitted with a transmitter was swimming somewhere below.

headline: Russian Sports Official Suspended Over Doping Resigns
abstract: As deputy sports minister, Yuri D. Nagornykh was the highest-ranking Russian government official suspended in the wake of accusations of a state-run doping scheme.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s deputy sports minister, who was suspended after accusations that he had coordinated a doping scheme at the 2014 Winter Olympics, has resigned, the government reported Monday.

headline: Sheikh Khalifa bin Hamad al-Thani, Former Emir of Qatar, Dies at 84
abstract: As the Gulf nation’s leader from 1972 to 1995, Sheikh Khalifa oversaw Qatar’s independence from Britain and the rapid modernization of its economy.
lead_paragraph: Sheikh Khalifa bin Hamad al-Thani, who as the emir of Qatar for 23 years oversaw its independence from Britain and the rapid modernization of its economy, died on Sunday. He was 84.

headline: N.B.A. Schedule: Here’s What to Watch This Week
abstract: The 2016-17 N.B.A. season kicks off on Tuesday with games between the Knicks and the Cavaliers, the Jazz and the Trail Blazers and the Spurs and the Warriors.
lead_paragraph: Finally. It’s back.

headline: Liberals Hope Elizabeth Warren Will Serve as Clinton’s Scrutinizer in Chief
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With polls showing that Hillary Clinton is likely to prevail in the election, liberal Democrats are beginning to exert pressure over her potential appointments.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren delivered a blistering rebuke of Donald J. Trump on Monday, warning him that “nasty women vote” and imploring a crowd to cast ballots for Hillary Clinton.

headline: AARP Sues U.S. Over Rules for Wellness Programs
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Privacy', 'Discrimination', 'Elderly']
abstract: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s rules allow employers to offer up to 30 percent off health insurance coverage for participants.
lead_paragraph: Employers have raced to offer workers a hefty financial incentive to sign up for programs meant to improve their health, submitting personal medical details in the process. But as these programs have spread, so has resistance from employees dubious about sharing that information with employers.

headline: Struggling for an Emmett Till Memorial That Withstands Gunshots
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Vandalism', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Signs recalling the murder of the black teenager in 1955, an event that fueled the civil rights movement, are continually stolen and vandalized, riddled with bullet holes.
lead_paragraph: Along a secluded gravel road that runs between a riverbank and cotton fields in the Mississippi Delta region, a purple sign marks the area where Emmett Till’s mutilated body was pulled from the Tallahatchie River in the summer of 1955.

headline: TD Ameritrade’s Deal With Scottrade Is a Temporary Fix
abstract: The merger of the online stockbrokers still leaves such companies vulnerable to the competition of index investing and automation of advice.
lead_paragraph: TD Ameritrade’s $4 billion takeover of Scottrade merely delays the inevitable. Uniting the two American online stockbrokers stacks up financially, because of cost cuts, a tax break and a sale of a banking unit. Income and margins should rise, too. But it still leaves TD Ameritrade and rivals like Charles Schwab facing the longer-term competition of index investing and robo advice.

headline: U.S.-Cuba Health Collaboration
abstract: Medicc, a nonprofit, writes that the embargo has “stymied mutual work on critical health problems, like Zika.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What’s in a Name? When It’s ‘Trump Place,’ It’s a Revolt
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Names, Organizational', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: At three large rental buildings on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, a movement is underway to rid the properties of Donald J. Trump’s name.
lead_paragraph: At three large rental buildings emblazoned with gold letters spelling out T-R-U-M-P P-L-A-C-E on the Upper West Side, the lobby rain mats embossed with the same name are being replaced, tenants say. The new versions, they have been told, will proclaim the buildings’ addresses, 140, 160 or 180 Riverside Boulevard.

headline: Home and Work: Kris Kim
abstract: The shopkeeper’s spare minimalism is consistent, from her New York apartment to her pristine store.
lead_paragraph: The shopkeeper’s spare minimalism is consistent, from her New York apartment to her pristine store.

headline: Inside a Designer and Entrepreneur’s Pristine Apartment and Store
abstract: In the stark TriBeCa world of La Garçonne’s Kris Kim, beauty comes from knowing precisely when to stop.
lead_paragraph: To be told you are making something out of nothing is to be criticized for being overly dramatic, and yet to make something lovely out of nothing, and with very little dramatic flourish, is a clever skill, and precisely what the entrepreneur Kris Kim does. You cannot recognize the designer behind the loose black T-shirt and flowing black linen pants she is wearing on a recent meeting, and that is how she likes it. In fact, she is the designer, and the pieces are from her label, Moderne, which she sells at her shop and 11-year-old commerce site, La Garçonne, as well as at other retailers. The Moderne line is so simple that inside the company it’s referred to as “the Nothing Label.”

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
abstract: We asked readers — without any context — to caption a photo that ran in The New York Times. Here’s how they responded.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

headline: Kathleen Kane, Former Pennsylvania Attorney General, Is Sentenced to Prison
abstract: Ms. Kane’s unlikely political career came to a humiliating close on Monday, when a judge sentenced her to 10 to 23 months in prison for perjury and abuse of her office.
lead_paragraph: NORRISTOWN, Pa. — The brief, unlikely political career of Kathleen G. Kane, Pennsylvania’s brightest rising star when she was elected attorney general less than four years ago, came to a humiliating close on Monday when a judge sentenced her to 10 to 23 months in prison for her conviction on charges of perjury and abuse of her office.

headline: At New Jersey Transit, a ‘Culture Change’ Is Called For
abstract: A former New Jersey Transit official and another reader discuss problems at that railroad and elsewhere in rail transportation.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: German Terrorism Case Highlights Europe’s Security Challenges
abstract: Governments are grappling with the potential threat from migrants amid unease over reliance on United States intelligence to head off attacks.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The warning came to the German security authorities in early September from “our best partners,” as they euphemistically refer to the American intelligence agencies: A terrorist assault might be in the works.

headline: Don’t Drink the Hand Sanitizer
keywords: ['Cleansers, Detergents and Soaps', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Bottles of hand sanitizer are ubiquitous and cheap, but they also contain high levels of alcohol and can be abused.
lead_paragraph: Alcohol-based hand sanitizer can be found in schools, offices, restrooms and restaurants and is great for cleaning hands in public places. But most of us would never think of drinking it.

headline: Brace Yourself for a Busy Holiday Season at Airports
keywords: ['Airport Security', 'Delays (Transportation)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'AIRPORTS', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Capping a year of lower ticket prices and growing numbers of passengers, the holidays could make airports more crowded than ever. It pays to start planning ahead.
lead_paragraph: With Thanksgiving less than a month away, airlines and airports — not to mention savvy travelers — are bracing for what could be a record-setting year-end holiday travel season in the United States.

headline: How to Make Your Holiday Air Travel More Bearable
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Airport Security', 'AIRPORTS', 'Luggage and Packing', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Holidays and Special Occasions']
abstract: Strategies for booking, packing and beyond that can help minimize the hassle of crowds and long lines at the airport.
lead_paragraph: There’s not much that any traveler can do about the crowds and long lines at airports during the holiday season. But there are ways to cope.

headline: A Manhattan Exhibit With Antiquity on the Clock
abstract: ”Time and Cosmos in Greco-Roman Antiquity,” at the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World, shows what shaped our need to be punctual.
lead_paragraph: In a Roman mosaic from antiquity, a man on a street studies the sundial atop a tall column. The sun alerts him to hurry if he does not want to be late for a dinner invitation.

headline: A John Zorn Weekend — 10-Hour Marathon Concert Included
abstract: The avant-garde composer’s music could be heard this weekend at Columbia’s Miller Theater, as well as at National Sawdust in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: As far as performance marathons go, the 10 hours of John Zorn’s bagatelles on Saturday at National Sawdust in Brooklyn may not have been the most sprawling. (Taylor Mac’s full day of drag-pop two weeks ago, for one thing, was more than double the length of this Zornfest.)

headline: Calais Jungle, Xi Jinping, European Union: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Review: Ballet With Intricate Geometry, and a Lot of Fun
abstract: Spirits, steps and wit sparkled in three George Balanchine pieces performed by Suzanne Farrell Ballet.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When she danced — from the early 1960s to the late ’80s — the ballerina Suzanne Farrell gave people so much else to see that they seldom remarked on her physical wit. And now, after she recently announced that her ballet company would close after the 2017-18 season, humor was the last thing to expect from its latest program.

headline: ‘We Are Ready to Leave’: France Clears Out Calais ‘Jungle’
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'vis-photo']
abstract: Migrants bused out of the sprawling camp in Calais will be dispersed to dozens of towns and villages all over France.
lead_paragraph: CALAIS, France — Hundreds of migrants, mostly young men from Africa or Afghanistan, lined up in the cold on Monday for buses to take them to temporary housing all over France, as the government set in motion a plan in the port of Calais to clear the sprawling migrant camp known as the Jungle once and for all.

headline: For Gordon Hamilton, a Life of Discovery and Danger
abstract: Dr. Hamilton, who was killed in Antarctica over the weekend, studied glaciers with our future in mind, and with a smile.
lead_paragraph: The helicopter hovered 30 feet above a fjord in Greenland, a thrumming red speck of human ingenuity in a vast wilderness of rock and ice.

headline: Election Chatter, With Two Weeks to Go
abstract: Readers discuss a list of those Donald Trump has insulted, along with his threats to sue his accusers and not accept the election results.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: At Least 59 Die as Militants Storm Police College Near Quetta, Pakistan
abstract: Three armed attackers attacked a police training school, trapping at least 250 cadets and staff members.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Wielding guns and explosives, three militants killed at least 59 people and wounded 120 at a police training college in southwestern Pakistan late Monday, before security forces, who mobilized outside, seized control of the campus, government officials said.

headline: Unicef Cuts Cost of Vaccine That Protects Against 5 Diseases
abstract: A deal with six manufacturers will make the so-called pentavalent vaccine more affordable and accessible to 80 of the poorest countries.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Children’s Fund has made a deal with six vaccine manufacturers that will cut in half the price of a shot that protects children against five diseases, the fund announced last week.

headline: Schubert’s Chilly Winter Journey, Told Two Ways
abstract: Two interpretations of “Winterreise,” one for a chamber group, the other a piano-and-voice performance, took alternate routes to its emotional depths.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Hall presented two performances of Schubert’s dark song cycle “Winterreise” (“Winter’s Journey”) over the past two Sundays.

headline: نهايةُ عقودٍ من تقاليد العائلة المالكة إثر صعودِ نجمِ أميرٍ سعودي
abstract: وهكذا وضع صعود نجم الأمير بن سلمان نهايةً لعقود من التقاليد التي طالما تمسّكت بها العائلة المالكة، والتي تَعتبر احترام الأقدمية ومشاركة السلطة بين فروع العائلة المالكة قيمًا راسخة. فلم يحدث من قبل في تاريخ المملكة أن استأثر وليّ وليّ العهد، الذي يحتل المرتبة الثانية على قائمة انتظار العرش، بكلّ هذا القدر من النفوذ. وهذه المركزية في السلطة كانت سببًا في إثارة غضب الكثيرين من أقاربه.
lead_paragraph: وهكذا وضع صعود نجم الأمير بن سلمان نهايةً لعقود من التقاليد التي طالما تمسّكت بها العائلة المالكة، والتي تَعتبر احترام الأقدمية ومشاركة السلطة بين فروع العائلة المالكة قيمًا راسخة. فلم يحدث من قبل في تاريخ المملكة أن استأثر وليّ وليّ العهد، الذي يحتل المرتبة الثانية على قائمة انتظار العرش، بكلّ هذا القدر من النفوذ. وهذه المركزية في السلطة كانت سببًا في إثارة غضب الكثيرين من أقاربه.

headline: Lorenzo Lamas Will Fly You to the Grand Canyon (After He’s Sung)
abstract: Mr. Lamas, now in “The Fantasticks,” talks about his life in and out of show business and what brought him back to the stage.
lead_paragraph: Fans of the actor Lorenzo Lamas can be forgiven for thinking that his latest role might be that of a guy who seduces a woman with one hand and fires a bazooka with the other. El Gallo, after all, sounds like one of the chiseled hotties Mr. Lamas has portrayed in action films like “Snake Eater” and “Bounty Tracker.”

headline: Review: In ‘Alfred Hitchcock: A Brief Life,’ Fear Drives a Master of Suspense
abstract: The latest biography by Peter Ackroyd examines what lurks behind the film director’s obsession with order and control.
lead_paragraph: “Luck is everything,” Alfred Hitchcock once remarked. “My good luck in life was to be a really frightened person. I’m fortunate to be a coward, to have a low threshold of fear, because a hero couldn’t make a good suspense film.”

headline: As Europe and Asia Hoard Cash, Economists See Echoes of Crisis
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Interest Rates', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Foreign investors are rushing to plow cash into the United States bond market, recalling a wave of investment in mortgage-backed securities in the 2000s.
lead_paragraph: European and Asian investors have been rushing into the United States bond market, spurred by a global glut of savings that has reached record levels.

headline: MetLife Again Faces Off With Regulators Over Its Too-Big-to-Fail Status
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Insurance', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: In a Washington appeals court, judges heard arguments about whether the insurance giant deserved to be labeled a systemically important financial institution.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three judges at Washington’s federal appeals court on Monday questioned the government’s analysis that led to MetLife’s designation as a “too big to fail” financial company, as the Justice Department appeals a lower court’s decision to strip the insurance giant of that label.

headline: The Big League Prospect Who Became a Mob Hit Man
abstract: Baseball scouts used to scrutinize Maury Lerner’s every move. Then F.B.I. agents were the ones watching.
lead_paragraph: The Buick sedan crawled the Providence streets. The April sky was baby blue, the air pleasant and cool. Perfect baseball weather. The man hunched in the back seat once lived for days like this.

headline: Fearing Trump, Bar Association Stifles Report Calling Him a ‘Libel Bully’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Libel and Slander', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: Critics of the American Bar Association said the decision was ironic since the group is supposed to explore issues about threats to free speech.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Alarmed by Donald J. Trump’s record of filing lawsuits to punish and silence his critics, a committee of media lawyers at the American Bar Association commissioned a report on Mr. Trump’s litigation history. The report concluded that Mr. Trump was a “libel bully” who had filed many meritless suits attacking his opponents and had never won in court.

headline: 35 Turks With Diplomatic Passports Seek Asylum in Germany
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: The aftermath of a failed coup in Turkey has complicated relations with Germany, amid tensions over the flow of refugees from Syria.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany has received nearly three dozen applications for political asylum from Turkish diplomats and their families, amid widespread purges of assumed opponents of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, following the failed attempt to overthrow his government, an official said Monday.

headline: Donald Trump Dismisses Latest Accuser: ‘Oh, I’m Sure She’s Never Been Grabbed Before’
abstract: Mr. Trump disparaged an actress named Jessica Drake, who over the weekend said that in 2006 he had groped and kissed her without her permission.
lead_paragraph: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. — Donald J. Trump on Monday disparaged the latest woman to accuse him of touching her inappropriately, dismissing her as a “porn star” and saying sarcastically, “Oh, I’m sure she’s never been grabbed before.”

headline: Geno Smith Has Torn Knee Ligament; Jets Turn to Ryan Fitzpatrick Again
abstract: Smith, who had replaced Fitzpatrick as the Jets starter last week, sustained a torn anterior cruciate ligament against the Ravens.
lead_paragraph: If this were another team, in another season, Monday’s news that a starting quarterback had sustained a torn anterior cruciate ligament might be considered an unfortunate setback.

headline: Clinton, Warren, Cubs: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Too Good to Be Ignored: Women Who Reached the Top in Sports
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Women and Girls', 'Books and Literature', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)']
abstract: A new book, “Game Changers: The Unsung Heroines of Sports History,” looks at women who overcame tremendous obstacles.
lead_paragraph: When AnnMaria De Mars was growing up in the 1960s and ’70s in Alton, Ill., a “short, fat little kid with real thick glasses,” as she described herself, there were few outlets for girls interested in sports. “Back then, Title IX hadn’t passed, so it was perfectly legal to say, ‘Girls can’t do this,’” she said. Nonetheless, her mother dropped her off at a local Y.M.C.A., with instructions to find an activity. “The options were swimming or sprinting,” Dr. De Mars recalled, and, thanks to one sympathetic instructor, judo.

headline: Women Are Drinking as Much as Men
keywords: ['ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Men and Boys', 'Women and Girls', 'Gender']
abstract: The gender gap in the use — and abuse — of alcohol is narrowing.
lead_paragraph: More men than women use and abuse alcohol, but the gender gap is narrowing.

headline: Could Hillary Clinton Win Texas? Some Democrats Say Maybe
abstract: The state has voted for the G.O.P. candidate in the past nine presidential elections, but Donald J. Trump may have created an opening for Mrs. Clinton.
lead_paragraph: SILSBEE, Tex. — The last time a Democrat won Texas in a presidential election was 1976, when voters chose Jimmy Carter over Gerald R. Ford. Carey Georgas was 22 back then, a disillusioned Democrat who voted for Eugene McCarthy, the independent candidate, and who was working at Cravens Insurance in this East Texas town.

headline: Bobby Vee, Pop Idol Known for ‘Take Good Care of My Baby,’ Dies at 73
abstract: One of a crop of dreamboat singers promoted in the late 1950s and early ’60s, he got his first big break when he filled in for Buddy Holly and others after their plane crashed.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Vee, who became a teenage idol in the early 1960s with infectious hits like “Take Good Care of My Baby” and “The Night Has a Thousand Eyes,” died on Monday in Rogers, Minn. He was 73.

headline: U.N. Addresses Cholera Crisis in Haiti
abstract: The United Nations has proposed a $400 million aid package, including cash payments to victims.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations has proposed a $400 million aid package, including cash payments to victims.

headline: Why AT&T Isn’t Sweating the Breakup Fee in Its Time Warner Deal
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: If antitrust officials reject the merger, AT&T owes Time Warner $500 million — a far smaller proportion of the deal’s value than is typical.
lead_paragraph: AT&T’s chief executive, Randall L. Stephenson, has been pretty casual about the costs of failing to push through the telecommunication giant’s proposed purchase of Time Warner.

headline: Remembering Gordon Hamilton – An Edge-Pushing Prober of Eroding Ice
abstract: The death of a prominent glaciologist in Antarctica illustrates how edge-pushing science sometimes poses existential risks.
lead_paragraph: Pushing the frontiers of science on tough questions is hard enough. But doing so when the effort requires research teams to face deadly hazards at the ends of the Earth takes things to another level.

headline: Cuba in All Its Natural Glory at the American Museum of Natural History
abstract: The museum is readying one of the largest exhibitions ever in the United States on Cuba’s biodiversity and culture.
lead_paragraph: It won’t be the old car or the thousands of tobacco leaves or even the leaping crocodile model that will greet visitors when they walk into “¡Cuba!,” the first major exhibition the American Museum of Natural History has ever organized about that island nation.

headline: With AT&T-Time Warner Deal Brewing, a Focus on Preserving CNN’s Integrity
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The difficulties of defending tough reporting and shielding journalists from powerful antagonists can be hard for any corporation to stomach. And AT&T has no journalistic lineage.
lead_paragraph: In its 130-year history, AT&T has transitioned from a telegraph service to a wireless provider to a global communications behemoth.

headline: Discovering Contemporary African Art, With a Curator as a Guide
abstract: Specialists are discovering artists, then empowering them to push boundaries, build networks and draw the public to their work.
lead_paragraph: For art to reach you, someone has to find it and believe that you need to see it. Someone like Bisi Silva, Hannah O’Leary or Kevin Dumouchelle, curators and specialists who are discovering, and showing to the world, the contemporary art of Africa.

headline: Some Health Plan Costs to Increase by an Average of 25 Percent, U.S. Says
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Consumers in some states will also find significantly fewer insurance companies offering coverage under the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Premiums for midlevel health plans under the Affordable Care Act will increase by an average of 25 percent next year, while consumers in some states will find significantly fewer insurance companies offering coverage, the federal government said Monday.

headline: Art Dealers Move Out of the Gallery and Into a Taco Bell
abstract: Weary of the high-flying approach of big galleries, artists are looking to display art in smaller ways. That might even include an old Taco Bell.
lead_paragraph: Stefania Bortolami still recalls, with cathartic exultation, the moment she decided to display her art in a slower, smaller way. It was May 2015, and Ms. Bortolami, the owner of the Bortolami Gallery in Manhattan, was at the art fair Frieze New York — her sixth such gathering of the year.

headline: AT&T-Time Warner Deal Is a Shot in the Dark
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Television', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Cable Television', 'Smartphones']
abstract: AT&T’s $85 billion deal for Time Warner is a ploy to do something — anything — in the face of a rapidly changing media landscape.
lead_paragraph: The official rationale for AT&T’s $85 billion deal to purchase Time Warner is that in uncertain times, bigger is better.

headline: A Wedding Night Upgrade at the Plaza
abstract: Recalling a night spent sleeping on a sofa where a Beatle was said to have sat.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: How an Aesthete’s Eye Can Help a Doctor’s Hand
abstract: With the goal of fostering diagnostic skills and empathy, more medical schools are battling skepticism to offer courses on viewing art.
lead_paragraph: For eight years, Bonnie Pitman has been battling a rare, incurable lung infection. Frequent hospitalizations took such a toll on her that she had to step down from her dream job as director of the Dallas Museum of Art, and she uses a breathing apparatus to open her airways several times a day.

headline: Consultant With Ties to Donald Trump Linked to Offer to Hide Source of Donations
abstract: A video by a British newspaper appears to show a former consultant to a pro-Trump super PAC offering to disguise the source of foreign contributions.
lead_paragraph: A video posted on Monday by a British newspaper appeared to show a Republican consultant with ties to Donald J. Trump offering to disguise the source of contributions to a “super PAC” intended to aid Mr. Trump’s presidential campaign.

headline: Letters on U.N.’s Response to Cholera in Haiti
abstract: Read the report from Philip Alston, a special United Nations human rights adviser, to the deputy secretary general Jan Eliasson, and Mr. Eliasson's response.
lead_paragraph: Read the report from Philip Alston, a special United Nations human rights adviser, to the deputy secretary general Jan Eliasson, and Mr. Eliasson's response.

headline: Code Names and Covert Meetings in AT&T’s Courtship of Time Warner
abstract: The secrecy surrounding the $85.4 billion merger was viewed as essential for a deal sure to raise concerns among lawmakers and consumer advocacy groups.
lead_paragraph: Soon after the wheels of the Time Warner private jet touched down at Dallas Love Field airport on Oct. 11, the media titan’s chief executive, Jeffrey L. Bewkes, and his top lieutenants cautiously made their way to the meeting room of a nearby hangar.

headline: Voters Increasingly Turning to Internet for Information, Survey Shows
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The takeaway for campaigns is that they will need to increasingly tailor approaches to the internet for what were once staples of television.
lead_paragraph: Voters have stepped away from the television and are digesting the presidential and Senate races through the internet, a new poll of persuadable voters in five Senate battleground states shows.

headline: A Chilly Reaction to AT&T-Time Warner Deal
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'News and News Media', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Television', 'Media']
abstract: A look at where the AT&T deal leaves other prominent media companies and what some think they might attempt to do in response.
lead_paragraph: The $85 billion AT&T deal for Time Warner won’t win regulatory approval. We will continue our current course even if it does. Will a line of major media consolidation dominoes — involving titans like Disney, Fox and Comcast — begin to fall? Not likely.

headline: Cleveland Indians Fans Hope That Ghosts of Past Are Put to Rest
abstract: A group of workers at an Ohio beverage warehouse are counting on Manager Terry Francona and players like Francisco Lindor and Andrew Miller to give them an overdue championship.
lead_paragraph: “Hello, Sid Monge,” Ralph calls.

headline: Justice Dept. Shakes Up Inquiry Into Eric Garner Chokehold Case
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The agency replaced its team after a dispute over whether to bring civil rights charges against the New York police officer who used a fatal chokehold on Mr. Garner in 2014.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has replaced the New York team of agents and lawyers investigating the death of Eric Garner, officials said, a highly unusual shake-up that could jump-start the long-stalled case and put the government back on track to seek criminal charges.

headline: Obama Urges Democrats to Turn Out in Force Against Donald Trump and G.O.P.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Obama said the coming election was a test of American values, with grave stakes for the country and for the next president’s ability to govern in a divisive time.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — President Obama portrayed Donald J. Trump as a threat to the survival of the republic on Monday as he beseeched Democrats to repudiate the Republican nominee and his message by turning out in large numbers to elect Hillary Clinton and sweep a tide of Republicans out of office.

headline: Next Job for Obama? Silicon Valley Is Hiring
abstract: The president, who has advocated cutting-edge research and built relationships with Silicon Valley companies, may be preparing for a role in the technology sector.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Staring intently at the dual screens inside a flight simulator this month at the University of Pittsburgh, President Obama tapped the controls in front of him, firing faux thrusters as he pretended to maneuver his space shuttle toward the International Space Station. Pulse up. Pulse to the right. Left. Down. Down. Left. Left.

headline: Once a Die-Hard Cubs Fan, Jason Kipnis Is Now Trying to Extend Their Misery
abstract: Kipnis, the Cleveland Indians’ second baseman, has ivy in his blood: “I dreamed about, as a kid, playing in the World Series at Wrigley Field.”
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When Jason Kipnis was a boy, long before he helped the Cleveland Indians earn a spot in the World Series, he attended St. Norbert School, 21 miles from Wrigley Field.

headline: LeBron James Remains a Rock Amid N.B.A.’s Changing Terrain
abstract: In a whirlwind off-season, Kevin Durant moved to the Warriors, and Dwyane Wade went to the Bulls. The Cavaliers look the same, and they’re thankful for that.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Great change, as it often does, swept through the N.B.A. during the off-season. It came in the form of the draft and trades and signings. Kevin Durant relocated to the Bay Area. Dwyane Wade went home to Chicago. Joakim Noah and Derrick Rose moved to New York.

headline: Promises, Promises From AT&T
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Cable Television', 'Editorials']
abstract: Antitrust regulators need to examine whether the AT&T-Time Warner deal would squelch competition or limit consumer choice.
lead_paragraph: AT&T’s $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner would transform it from a landline, wireless and satellite TV company into one of the most important media gatekeepers in the country, giving it a strong financial incentive to use its programming to hammer competitors.

headline: Turkey Barges Into the Mosul Fight
abstract: President Erdogan wants a direct role in the battle, but his real priority seems to be defeating Kurdish separatists.
lead_paragraph: It’s been clear from the start that the American and Iraqi-led battle to retake Mosul from the Islamic State presented a logistical and strategic puzzle — even a possible nightmare — in which the interests of multiple countries and sectarian groups had to be reconciled and their roles carefully coordinated. Without such coordination, the effort to defeat ISIS and liberate thousands of Mosul residents who have suffered horribly under the terrorist group for two years would be severely undermined.

headline: World Series Preview: For Cubs or Indians, Decades of Waiting Are Nearly Over
abstract: The Cubs have never played a World Series game on television, and the Indians are trying to extend Cleveland’s year of celebration.
lead_paragraph: It might as well be a matchup from a movie: the two teams with the longest title droughts in baseball paired in the same World Series. No wonder, then, that Joe Maddon has watched “Field of Dreams” since his Chicago Cubs clinched the National League pennant.

headline: Vatican to Act as Mediator Between Venezuela’s Dueling Sides
abstract: Government representatives and a leader of the opposition agreed to allow the Vatican to mediate in an effort to solve Venezuela’s political crisis.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — As President Nicolás Maduro flew to Rome for a hastily arranged meeting with Pope Francis, representatives of Venezuela’s government and a leader of the opposition agreed on Monday to allow the Vatican to mediate a dialogue intended to solve the country’s political crisis.

headline: Seeking Senate Majority, Cuomo Tries New Tactic: Stumping for Democrats
abstract: Despite having done little to help his fellow Democrats in recent years, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has multiple fund-raisers planned as the election draws to a close.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In 2014, while cruising to re-election, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s efforts to help his fellow Democrats were, to be polite, understated.

headline: Soldiers Struggling to Repay Enlistment Bonuses Issued in Error
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']
abstract: Current and former members of the California National Guard have struggled to repay extra money they received unwittingly. Now Congress may help.
lead_paragraph: After 21 years in the military, three deployments, and a roadside bomb blast that left him bleeding and unconscious, Christopher Van Meter got a letter from the Pentagon saying he improperly received enlistment bonuses and now owed the government $46,000.

headline: Cubs, Loaded With Talent, May Get Kyle Schwarber Back, Too
abstract: Schwarber, who tore a knee ligament in April, has had a faster-than-expected recovery, which could give Chicago a D.H. option in the World Series.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — On Monday, a day before the Chicago Cubs were to open the World Series against the Cleveland Indians at Progressive Field, team officials keenly watched the at-bats of Kyle Schwarber on live video feeds from Arizona.

headline: Yankees Plan Stadium Changes to Fight Attendance Drop
abstract: A children’s play zone and new and expanded open-air patio bars were among the changes to Yankee Stadium announced by the team, which will remove nearly 2,100 seats.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to stem plummeting attendance, the Yankees on Monday announced several changes to Yankee Stadium, including a play area for children and open-air patio bars. The enhancements aim to draw younger fans who have increasingly abandoned the team in recent years.

headline: Arian Foster, Worn Down by Injuries, Announces Immediate Retirement
abstract: Foster, a running back who had joined the Dolphins this year, said in a statement that his body “just can’t take the punishment this game asks for any longer.”
lead_paragraph: Arian Foster, a four-time Pro Bowler who was among the league’s top rushers in 2014, became the latest football player to leave the sport because of injuries, abruptly announcing his retirement on Monday after playing in only four games this season.

headline: Ex-Aide Says Christie Had ‘Memory Issue’ About Bridge Lane Closings
abstract: Bridget Anne Kelly testified she felt she was in “an alternate universe” when Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and his team disavowed having knowledge of the shutdown.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — In December 2013, Bridget Anne Kelly began to feel she was in “an alternate universe.”

headline: Review: In ‘The Harvest,’ a Crisis of Feeling for Young Evangelicals
abstract: This new play by Samuel D. Hunter centers on a group of 20-somethings who are exploring their problems as they prepare for a mission to the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Context is not everything when it comes to our experience of theater, but it’s not nothing, either. “The Harvest,” a new play by Samuel D. Hunter about a group of young evangelical missionaries in Idaho, has a serious context problem. These idealistic young Christians, all in their 20s, are heading off to save souls in a place referred to only as “the Middle East.”

headline: Review: In ‘A Life,’ Lonely and Looking to the Stars for Answers
abstract: David Hyde Pierce stars in this bleak new play by Adam Bock, which swerves suddenly from the mundane to the shocking.
lead_paragraph: A great fear of single urbanites comes unhappily true for the central character in “A Life,” a bleak new play by Adam Bock that opened on Monday at Playwrights Horizons. David Hyde Pierce stars as a 54-year-old gay man living in New York who has recently been dumped by his boyfriend — although that’s not the great fear I referred to.

headline: Offer at a Pub
abstract: John E. Bennett makes his return in the friendliest of ways.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — If I had to guess the concept behind John E. Bennett’s third New York Times crossword just by looking at the completed grid, I would have put money on it being called “Something About Drunken Pandas.” That’s what it looks like to me. The black squares look like a panda bear and there is alcohol all over its face.

headline: Report Highlights How Guns Flow Into New York From States With Weaker Laws
abstract: An analysis by the state attorney general’s office found that 75 percent of the weapons seized in crimes that could be traced were bought outside New York.
lead_paragraph: The .40-caliber pistol used to kill a New York City police officer last year was bought in South Carolina on Feb. 28, 2008.

headline: U.N. Plans to Pay Victims of Cholera Outbreak It Caused in Haiti
abstract: A proposed $400 million aid package comes two months after the United Nations acknowledged that it helped spread the deadly disease in the impoverished nation.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Ever since United Nations peacekeepers introduced a devastating cholera epidemic to Haiti in 2010, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon has insisted that the global body is immune from legal claims. In the past few months, he has acknowledged a “moral responsibility” for the epidemic, but he has stopped short of saying sorry.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, October 25, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “If we’re successful, it’s the beginning of the end of the war on marijuana.”

headline: Is This Election Rigged Against Trump?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2000', 'Presidential Election of 1960']
abstract: With Donald J. Trump's claims that the election is rigged against him, we take a look at past close and contentious elections.
lead_paragraph: With Donald J. Trump's claims that the election is rigged against him, we take a look at past close and contentious elections.

lead_paragraph: Miaomiao Lake Village is just one of the new communities built to accommodate the world’s largest environmental migration project. But residents are struggling to adapt.

headline: Calais Jungle, Mosul, Clinton: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Corrections: October 25, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, October 25, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Finding Dory’ and ‘The Adam Ruins Everything Election Special’
abstract: In “Finding Dory,” Ellen DeGeneres is back for another journey with everyone’s favorite clown fish, Nemo. And Adam Conover ruins presidential politics.
lead_paragraph: In “Finding Dory,” Ellen DeGeneres is back as the blue tang sidekick to everyone’s favorite clown fish, Nemo. And Adam Conover ruins everything you thought you knew about presidential politics.

headline: After Egypt’s Revolution, a New Start in American Exile
abstract: When a young Egyptian medical student’s dreams of democracy collapsed, he joined fellow expatriates in the United States, documenting their hopes for the future.
lead_paragraph: When a young Egyptian medical student’s dreams of democracy collapsed, he joined fellow expatriates in the United States, documenting their hopes for the future.

headline: Don’t Lock ’Em Up. Give ’Em a Chance to Quit Drugs.
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Police', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Seattle tries a program to reduce incarceration of addicts, and other cities begin to follow.
lead_paragraph: By the time the police found him smoking crack in a Seattle parking garage one afternoon in late 2013, Roland Vasquez had been arrested more than two dozen times. Once a paralegal in his hometown, San Antonio, Vasquez says he started using drugs about 16 years ago after helping to negotiate bail for a dealer — and receiving a half-pound of heroin as a “thank you.” A father of three young children, he moved to Seattle in the mid-2000s to be closer to his own dad and farther from the people who got him hooked. But his cravings soon overwhelmed him, and he resigned himself to cycling between jail and the streets.

headline: Your Facts or Mine?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'Social Media']
abstract: Voters do want to know the truth. They just want it to agree with them.
lead_paragraph: “Obama to Declare MARTIAL LAW If Trump Wins Election.” That was the teaser text that recently popped up on my Facebook news feed. It directed me to a post from a page called Nation in Distress, one of the many hyperpartisan Facebook pages that have gained in popularity this year.

headline: The Unhappy Warriors
abstract: Trump and Clinton do not appear to be having much fun on the campaign trail. Or anywhere else for that matter.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Two weeks, Arthur, two weeks! I’m not sure what the world will be like when this election is over. Unless, of course, we’re defending ourselves against a mutiny from the right, the revolt of Donald’s Deplorables. Although he doesn’t really strike me as a guy who has much taste for the barricades. What do you think of all the “rigged election” drama?

headline: North Carolina’s Noxious Pig Farms
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Pigs', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Floods', 'Bacteria', 'Editorials']
abstract: Lagoons of animal waste flooded by Hurricane Matthew are a public health danger that may be repeated over and over again.
lead_paragraph: The landscape of eastern North Carolina is dotted with giant pools of bright pink sludge. These are waste lagoons, where industrial farms across the state dispose of billions of gallons of untreated pig urine and feces every year.

headline: The Cubs Reach the Promised Land. Now What?
abstract: Can the team, and its fans, adjust to being winners?
lead_paragraph: Chicago — I went to my first Chicago Cubs game in 1975, over the objections of my father, who said a Cubs fan, coming to believe in the futility of human endeavor, will have a sad life.

headline: The Epidemic of Worry
abstract: The thing we have to fear is anxiety itself.
lead_paragraph: We’ve had a tutorial on worry this year. The election campaign isn’t really about policy proposals, issue solutions or even hope. It’s led by two candidates who arouse gargantuan anxieties, fear and hatred in their opponents.

headline: Dear Republican Voters ...
abstract: You are agonizing about what to do this year. Let me tell you about my grandparents.

headline: The Problem for Women Is Not Winning. It’s Deciding to Run.

abstract: The main reason women are so underrepresented at every level of politics is that they don’t run in the first place.
lead_paragraph: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York first decided she wanted to be a senator when she was 7 or 8. Two decades later, as a law firm associate, she went to an event featuring the first lady, Hillary Clinton, and heard her speech as a personal call to public service.

headline: Dreamworld Theme Park Accident Kills 4, Australian Officials Say

headline: After Egypt’s Revolution, a New Start in American Exile
abstract: When a young Egyptian medical student’s dreams of democracy collapsed, he joined fellow expatriates in the United States, documenting their hopes for the future.
lead_paragraph: I was a medical student and political activist when the revolution against the Mubarak regime in Egypt broke out in 2011. While studying in Alexandria, I assisted as a medic during clashes between demonstrators and government forces. A few days before the fall of Mubarak, a young man was shot dead while standing between my friend Hesham and me. We could not save him.

headline: Six Centuries of Madness: An Asylum’s History

lead_paragraph: THIS WAY MADNESS LIESThe Asylum and BeyondBy Mike JayIllustrated. 255 pp. Thames & Hudson. $45.

headline: Obama Brought Silicon Valley to Washington
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Computers and the Internet', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Social Media', 'Start-ups']
abstract: His administration embraced some of the tech industry’s best ideas — but also some of its worst values.
lead_paragraph: This October, the White House opened its doors to a few thousand people for South by South Lawn, a daylong event described as a “festival of ideas, art and action.” Both the event and its name were a nod to South by Southwest, the annual technology-and-music festival held in Austin, Tex., where Barack and Michelle Obama showed up as surprise keynote speakers earlier this year. The story goes that they were so impressed by their experiences, they decided to host their own microrendition before leaving office. Attendees at the White House version — the types of people who describe themselves in Twitter bios as “creator” or “innovator” — were told to dress casually, in clothes suitable for a picnic. The D.J. Beverly Bond, of Black Girls Rock, blasted Public Enemy’s anthem “Fight the Power” and Parliament’s “Flash Light” across the lawn, which was studded with coffee carts, Lego sculptures and virtual-reality stations. Enormous stages erected for the occasion housed a rotating cast of musical guests and speakers throughout the afternoon. As the sun began to set, volunteers handed out plaid blankets so people could stretch out on the ground.

headline: From ‘Hamilton’ to Donald Trump: Are All ‘Grievances’ Created Equal?
abstract: Airing and addressing them is a founding principle of American democracy. But what if a claim of injustice is just a grudge?
lead_paragraph: At the climax of the Broadway musical “Hamilton,” Aaron Burr and Alexander Hamilton exchange a series of increasingly hostile letters in the song “Your Obedient Servant.” Burr enumerates a litany of perceived insults: Hamilton has called him “amoral” and “a dangerous disgrace” and blocked his political aspirations. “Burr, your grievance is legitimate,” Hamilton replies dismissively. “I stand by what I said, every bit of it/You stand only for yourself/It’s what you do/I can’t apologize because it’s true.” An outraged Burr feels he has been doubly wronged — first he is bad-mouthed and then his complaint is answered with a shrug. These irreconcilable differences came to a head on July 11, 1804, in a fatal duel in Weehawken, N.J.

headline: Omarosa Manigault Changed Parties for Trump
abstract: The campaign official believes the Republican nominee can secure 15 percent of the African-American vote.
lead_paragraph: You’re a prominent member of Donald Trump’s presidential campaign, as the director of African-American outreach, after competing on “The Apprentice” in 2004. Statistically speaking, he does not seem to be having very much success with either women or minorities. Oh, my God, I disagree. When I took the position, we were polling at zero. Nationally, we’re at an average of 8 percent. Romney and McCain got around 6 to 7 percent of the African-American vote. Our goal is to get 15 to 20 percent of the African-American vote, and we still think that number is possible.

headline: Who Do You Want to Win the 2016 Presidential Election?
abstract: Who do you think would make the better president of the United States?
lead_paragraph: The presidential primaries, party conventions and televised debates are all over. In fact, early voting is already underway in many states. With only two weeks left until Election Day, we’re in the homestretch of what The Times has called “the most surreal presidential campaign in modern times.”

headline: New True-Crime Books for Fall
abstract: In this season’s true crime books, mysteries set in Indianapolis; Austin, Tex.; Louisiana; and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Not all true-crime books are created equal. Some explore the criminal mind. Others focus on the lives of the victims. And then there are the ones that look beyond the crime to the historical period and social conditions in which it’s rooted. But one thing can be said for them all: True crime is hardly ever boring.

headline: Voters Fear Their Ballot Won’t Count, Poll Shows

That is partly a reflection of current technological limits and the deep concerns that surround the development of thinking machines that can kill. Here is a selection of some of the works that are most often mentioned:

It was just an N.B.A. preseason game, but the check-your-phone-and-miss-it sequence sent the home crowd into a full-throated frenzy and made all the postgame highlights.

headline: As ID Laws Fall, Voters See New Barriers Rise
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'States (US)', 'Discrimination', 'Minorities', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Identification Devices']
abstract: Contrasting laws and rulings leave election officials and voters confused, and some court remedies fall well short of restoring previous access to the voting booth.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — It seemed a clear victory for voting rights advocates in July when a federal court invalidated much of Wisconsin’s restrictive elections law, concluding that it discriminated against minorities by requiring voters to produce photo identification cards that blacks and Latinos too often lack. The remedy was straightforward: Henceforth, the state was to “promptly issue a credential valid as a voting ID to any person” who applied for one.

headline: Trevor Noah: The First Time I Drove a Car. (I Was 6.)
abstract: Born and raised in South Africa, Mr. Noah talks about growing up poor there, and his mother’s beat-up, tangerine Volkswagen Beetle.
lead_paragraph: When I was 5 years old, we moved to Eden Park, a neighborhood adjacent to several black townships on the outskirts of Johannesburg — half-colored and half-black, my mother figured, like us. It was me and her, alone. There was this sense of the two of us embarking on a grand adventure. We weren’t just mother and son. We were a team.

lead_paragraph: Jake Gyllenhaal, you’ll be delighted to hear, can speak pointillism. Even more to the, uh, point, he can sing pointillism, which isn’t easy at all. It involves concentration and balance and order, not to mention being able to summon all those radiant flecks of color and light.

headline: The Enticing Power of Highly Plucked Brows
abstract: Returning to a face near you.
lead_paragraph: There is a pervasive myth that all women are born with caterpillar-like brows that we then destroy by our own hand. An online meme reads, “This could be us” — over a photo of a woman with gorgeous, prominent brows — “but we had tweezers in the 8th grade.” Not true: My own have always been thin and ashy blond. For the past two years, since the return of the power brow, I have tried willing them to grow via prayer and several tubes of $95 serum, the second ingredient of which was castor oil. I did not emerge looking like Cara Delevingne.

headline: Spain Moves From Deadlock to Gridlock

headline: A Project Mends a Gash in the Street Grid of Washington

headline: Seizing on Rising Costs, Trump Says Health Law Is ‘Over’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The Trump campaign, desperate for a winning political issue in the final two weeks of the race, mounted an offensive against the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, desperate for a winning political issue in the final two weeks of the presidential race, fiercely attacked Hillary Clinton on Tuesday over sharp premium increases that will hit some Americans covered under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: The Funfetti Explosion
abstract: Sweetened by nostalgia and fueled by social media, rainbow sprinkles have coated the entire world of baking.
lead_paragraph: When Candace Nelson opened the first Sprinkles bakery in Los Angeles in 2005, she did not actually have any sprinkles on hand. “I liked the word, but I thought of them as a supermarket pick, waxy and fake,” she said. “Not elegant, chic and modern.”

headline: Prince’s Paisley Park Is Cleared to Open as a Museum
abstract: After hitting a zoning snag, the musician’s studio complex will once again be open for tours starting on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Paisley Park, Prince’s storied recording lair outside Minneapolis, has finally cut through the red tape to become a museum.

headline: Why Does Fall Foliage Turn So Red and Fiery? It Depends.
keywords: ['Autumn (Season)', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Trees and Shrubs', 'Biology and Biochemistry']
abstract: Many of the hypotheses for why leaves turn red before they fall off trees in the autumn sound contradictory.
lead_paragraph: Leaves scream their final cries in color before dropping to the ground. Their shouts — in golden, crimson or scarlet — eventually fade to brown bellows, and their lifeless bodies dry up on the forest floor. It absorbs their crinkly corpses and that’s it — worm food. The fall of a leaf in autumn is an orchestrated death. A complex, brilliant, beautiful death.

headline: John John Florence Clinches His First World Surfing Title
abstract: The title almost seemed inevitable for the 24-year-old native of Oahu, Hawaii, who is known for his comfort in dangerous waves.
lead_paragraph: The surfing world knew John John Florence was the best. On Tuesday, he made it official.

headline: Mosul Fight Unleashes New Horrors on Civilians
abstract: The Islamic State is carrying out mass killings and using human shields. Refugees are being turned away over fears terrorist sleeper cells. Burning sulfur has sickened dozens.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — As security forces bear down on Mosul, the Islamic State has moved hundreds of civilians from villages around the city to use as human shields, and the United Nations said the militants may have killed nearly 200 people. To the east, near the Kurdish-controlled city of Kirkuk, Sunni Arabs who fled there to escape violence are being forcibly displaced as local officials worry about terrorist sleeper cells.

abstract: A lawyer is shocked that the American Bar Association did not publish a report about Donald Trump for fear being sued by him.
