headline: No Need to Rise at a de Blasio News Conference: He Will Be Sitting, Too
abstract: Mayors of all stature in New York City have held briefings on all sorts of matters, from all sorts of political viewpoints — but almost always standing. Bill de Blasio, 6-foot-5, prefers to sit.
lead_paragraph: Fiorello H. La Guardia and Abraham D. Beame, both 5-foot-2, stood for them. John V. Lindsay, at 6-foot-4, likewise, did not slouch away.

headline: A Vibrant Upstate New York Town, Set Against a Quaint Backdrop
abstract: For your next Hudson Valley getaway, consider Germantown.
lead_paragraph: When the husband-and-wife New York City restaurateurs Sarah and Nick Suarez left New York City to open their first restaurant upstate, the couple made a somewhat surprising choice in Germantown. Despite giving roots to one of America’s most powerful and well-known families — the Rockefellers — the quaint Columbia County town, home to a population of just 2,000, has remained relatively undiscovered compared to other buzzier Hudson Valley destinations such as Kingston and Hudson (though it benefits from its proximity to both).

headline: Health Law Tax Penalty? I’ll Take It, Millions Say
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: A lot of healthy people are defying predictions by the Affordable Care Act architects and refusing to enroll, throwing off the math behind the system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The architects of the Affordable Care Act thought they had a blunt instrument to force people — even young and healthy ones — to buy insurance through the law’s online marketplaces: a tax penalty for those who remain uninsured.

headline: Sunday’s Violent ‘Walking Dead’ Is a Ratings Smash
abstract: The Season 7 premiere of “The Walking Dead,” which spurred many violence complaints, was one of the most watched in series history.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes gimmicks pay off.

headline: How Donald Trump Used Hollywood to Create ‘Donald Trump’
abstract: Donald J. Trump has been a near-constant presence in TV shows, movies, documentaries, pageants and even professional wrestling events, since the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Most politicians have a public record of speeches and votes on issues of the day, but Donald J. Trump, the Republican nominee for president, has left a different type of record: a near-constant presence in TV shows, movies, documentaries, pageants and even professional wrestling events over 30 years.

headline: Danspace Project Remembers the Lost Unknown Ghosts of AIDS
abstract: Danspace’s “Platform 2016: Lost and Found” highlights a program dedicated to the work of John Bernd, who died in 1988.
lead_paragraph: As Danspace Project delves deeper into its “Platform 2016: Lost and Found,” which looks at the effect that AIDS has had on generations of dance artists, it features a program dedicated to the work of John Bernd, who died in 1988. One of the first choreographers to incorporate gay themes and AIDS into his work, Mr. Bernd will be honored in “Variations on Themes from ‘Lost and Found’: Scenes from a Life and Other Works by John Bernd” beginning Thursday, Nov. 3. Ishmael Houston-Jones, who along with Will Rawls organized “Lost and Found,” directs the work, which features a cast of seven young dancers as well as the collaboration of Jennifer Monson (who danced with Mr. Bernd in “Two on the Loose,” his last performance before he died), Nick Hallett and Miguel Gutierrez.

headline: Warren Beatty Wants Six Hours of Your Time. Or More.
abstract: Mr. Beatty’s “Rules Don’t Apply” is the first film he has written, directed and starred in since “Bulworth,” in 1998. And he’ll talk your ear off about it.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Lest there be any question about whether, at 79, Warren Beatty is still a force of nature, the interview for this article lasted more than six hours. Mr. Beatty could have kept going, but I, in exhaustion, begged off. “As you have learned,” Mr. Beatty said, as we emerged on a golden midsummer evening from his Beverly Hills mansion, where we had spent most of the day, “I bleed people dry.”

headline: Picture a Tupperware Party, but With Racier Products
abstract: In the British series “Brief Encounters,” it’s the 1980s, and would-be saleswomen take on sexual repression — or something like that.
lead_paragraph: It’s 1982, and times are hard in England. How does a woman help shore up the family finances? In the delicious British dramedy “Brief Encounters,” which begins streaming Monday, Oct. 31, on Acorn, the answer for several entrepreneurs is selling lingerie and sex toys to repressed women at Tupperware-like parties. The six-episode series may feel more 1950s than 1980s, but the results are often hilarious. “Allow me to introduce the Stallion,” one budding saleswomen says at her first party as she pulls a formidable marital aid from her bag. The prim-and-proper guests look on, stunned, until one asks, “Is that a food blender?” It isn’t. Yet there are plenty of serious moments, too: When they’re not peddling their products, these women face marital strife, social ostracism and more.

headline: Pentagon Halts Efforts to Claw Back California National Guard Bonuses
keywords: ['Bonuses', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: The Pentagon says it will suspend efforts to force the soldiers to give back incentives that were improperly paid out during the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Amid a furor of criticism, the Pentagon announced on Wednesday that it would suspend efforts to force thousands of California National Guard soldiers to pay back enlistment bonuses and other incentives that were improperly given during the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: World Series Game 2 Moved Up an Hour
abstract: First pitch will come about 7:08 P.M. because of threatened rain in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: Game 2 of the World Series on Wednesday night has been moved up an hour, to 7:08 p.m. Eastern, because of the threat of rain in Cleveland.

headline: The Festival of Praise Tour Arrives in Brooklyn
abstract: This gospel fest includes Fred Hammond, Karen Clark Sheard, Israel Houghton and the up-and-comer Casey J.
lead_paragraph: This year’s installment of the annual Festival of Praise Tour, at Kings Theater in Brooklyn on Wednesday, Nov. 2, is strong on 1990s and early 2000s heavy hitters: Fred Hammond, with his buttery, tender voice; the off-the-cuff powerhouse Karen Clark Sheard; the versatile worship leader Israel Houghton. These are stars of gospel’s maximalist period and occasional flirters with its pop-soul instincts. But the lineup offers a couple of surprises at the margins, too: Regina Belle, a soul star of the 1980s and ’90s who has turned to gospel over the last decade; and the youngest singer on the bill, the up-and-comer Casey J, whose appealing take on gospel is more sonically modest and internally complicated than the lions she joins on this tour. (kingstheatre.com)

headline: At the Classical New York Festival of Song, Music for Deciding a Vote
abstract: Songs by Richard Rodgers, Mary Rodgers and Adam Guettel at Merkin Concert Hall, and compositions by Gabriela Lena Frank at National Sawdust.
lead_paragraph: What does it mean to be American? As the election season lurches into its final stretch, the New York Festival of Song offers a chance to reflect on the question through music, and from different vantage points. On Tuesday, Nov. 1, and Thursday at Merkin Concert Hall, this cherished institution presents “Rodgers, Rodgers & Guettel: A Century of American Musical Theater,” a program that takes the temperature of the American dream as expressed in the songs by Richard Rodgers, his daughter Mary Rodgers (“Once Upon a Mattress”) and his grandson Adam Guettel (known for the score to “The Light in the Piazza”). The vibrant lineup includes the soprano Lauren Worsham, the mezzo-soprano Mary Testa and the baritone John Brancy. On Wednesday at National Sawdust, the organization’s new-music arm invites the Peruvian-American composer Gabriela Lena Frank to design an evening around her own folk-and-mythology-inspired compositions as well as works by the composers Avner Dorman and Derek Bermel. Performers include the soprano Amy Owens; the Momenta Quartet; and the festival’s associate artistic director, Michael Barrett, at the piano. (nyfos.org; nationalsawdust.org)

headline: What the Early Vote in North Carolina Means: A Daily Tracker
abstract: Our best estimate of the early vote in North Carolina, updated daily.
lead_paragraph: Our best estimate of the early vote in North Carolina, updated daily.

headline: U.S. Abstains in U.N. Vote Condemning Cuba Embargo
abstract: It is the first time the United States has not voted against the annual resolution condemning the half-century-old embargo.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Making a bit of history, the United States on Wednesday abstained for the first time in an annual General Assembly condemnation of the half-century-old American trade embargo against Cuba.

headline: Kristin Chenoweth’s Many Lullabies for Broadway
abstract: Ms. Chenoweth starts a series of concert performances at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.
lead_paragraph: Kristin Chenoweth, a Broadway baby if ever there was one, returns to the boards she’s trod off and on for almost 20 years in a series of concert performances at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater. But she hasn’t been away for long. Ever since she blazed onto Broadway with a Tony-winning, show-stealing performance in a revival of “You’re a Good Man, Charlie Brown” in 1999 (she officially made her Broadway debut two years earlier, in “Steel Pier”), Ms. Chenoweth has returned regularly, in revivals of “Promises, Promises” and “On the Twentieth Century,” but perhaps most memorably as the perkier witch in the long-running “Wicked,” chirping merrily about her popularity.

headline: ‘Demagogues’ Presents Political Kings and Kingmakers
abstract: A Film Forum series includes “A Face in the Crowd,” “All the King’s Men,” “Citizen Kane” and more, pegged to the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Cast a vote for insight at Film Forum, where the programmer Bruce Goldstein has lined up masterworks timed to the election. “Demagogues” (Nov. 4 to Nov. 11) offers the obvious like “Citizen Kane” and “All the King’s Men” and curiosities like Gregory La Cava’s “Gabriel Over the White House,” from 1933, with Walter Huston as a president who becomes a benevolent dictator after a car crash. Most devastating is Elia Kazan’s “A Face in the Crowd” (1957), which reunited Kazan and his “On the Waterfront” screenwriter, Budd Schulberg. Lonesome Rhodes, a charismatic Southern singing jailbird (Andy Griffith, surpassing his television roles), is groomed into a TV star by a reporter (Patricia Neal), eventually becoming a political kingmaker felled by his libido, raging hypocrisy and hollow populism. A mentor warns him about “the way you begin to shoot suddenly out of control,” but the seeds of Rhodes’s undoing appear the moment the reporter first asks him to sing. “Wait a minute,” he says. “What do I get out of this?” (filmforum.org)

headline: Sandstorms and Broken-Down Four-by-Fours: Drone Footage in the Tengger Desert
abstract: A Times photographer surmounts obstacles to record from above a land affected by climate change.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Josh Haner, a staff photographer and senior editor for photo technology, takes us to the Tengger Desert on a recent assignment for a continuing series about climate change.

headline: Can’t You Hear the 1948 Whistle Blowin’
abstract: Retracing part of the train route the Indians took in 1948 after winning their last World Series, on their way from Boston to meet the giddy denizens of Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: With all aboard, the Lake Shore Limited slips out of the perpetual Penn Station dusk and into the day’s waning light. The train is already late, which seems fitting since it stops in Cleveland and terminates in Chicago, two Midwest cities that have been denied baseball glory by the conspiring fates since forever.

headline: H.I.V. Arrived in the U.S. Long Before ‘Patient Zero’
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Research', 'Blood', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: The virus appeared in New York as early as 1971, according to a new genetic analysis, and spread from there to San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: In the tortuous mythology of the AIDS epidemic, one legend never seems to die: Patient Zero, a.k.a. Gaétan Dugas, a globe-trotting, sexually insatiable French Canadian flight attendant who supposedly picked up H.I.V. in Haiti or Africa and spread it to dozens, even hundreds, of men before his death in 1984.

headline: ‘Afghan Girl’ in 1985 National Geographic Photo Is Arrested in Pakistan
abstract: Sharbat Gula, whose piercing green eyes stared out from the magazine’s cover in 1985, was held after being accused of fraudulently obtaining national identity cards.
lead_paragraph: An Afghan woman whose photograph as a young refugee with piercing green eyes was published on the cover of National Geographic in 1985, becoming a symbol of the turmoil of war in Afghanistan, was arrested on Wednesday in Pakistan on charges of fraudulently obtaining national identity cards.

headline: How to dress like an adult
abstract: Defining what constitutes a mature wardrobe is a challenge in the age of the power hoodie. Here, three golden rules for grown-up garb.

headline: Vast Group of New Video Games and Hardware Jostle for Holiday Attention

headline: Donald Trump Praises Newt Gingrich for His Exchange With Megyn Kelly

Trump interrupted a promotion for his new hotel in Washington to shower praise on Newt Gingrich for confronting the Fox News host Megyn Kelly on Tuesday night, when the former House speaker said in an interview that she was  “fascinated with sex” in her reporting on Mr. Trump’s treatment of women.

headline: Junko Tabei, First Woman to Conquer Everest, Dies at 77
abstract: Ms. Tabei, a Japanese alpinist, was the first woman to reach the top of Mount Everest and the rest of the Seven Summits.
lead_paragraph: Junko Tabei, a Japanese alpinist who became the first woman to scale Mount Everest and to ascend the highest summit of every continent, died on Oct. 20 in a hospital near Tokyo. She was 77.

headline: Your Phone Can Help You Get Fit

lead_paragraph: The longtime owner of a Lower East Side vintage shop takes T on a walk around the ever-changing neighborhood.

headline: On the Lower East Side With a Beloved Vintage Dealer
abstract: For 14 years, Ellen Koenigsberg’s throwback finds have served up inspiration to labels like Marc Jacobs and Maryam Nassir Zadeh.
lead_paragraph: For 14 years, Ellen Koenigsberg has stocked her Lower East Side vintage shop, Ellen, with pieces that have served as inspiration for fashion labels like Marc Jacobs and Maryam Nassir Zadeh. “When I moved in, Brooklyn wasn’t an adjective and e-commerce didn’t really exist,” she says of her store’s first location, just across the street from her current one at 123 Ludlow. It was the summer of 2002 and only a handful of shops — like Marmalade, Foley and Corinna and TG-170 — existed. “They’re not here anymore, any of them,” she says sadly.

headline: Meeting ‘the Other’ Face to Face
abstract: With “The Enemy” project at M.I.T., the photojournalist Karim Ben Khelifa hopes to engender a form of empathy beyond the reach of traditional documentary film.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Sitting in a conference room at a hotel near the Massachusetts Institute of Technology here, I slip on large headphones and an Oculus Rift virtual reality headset and wriggle into the straps of a backpack, weighed down with a computer and a battery. It feels as if I were getting ready for a spacewalk or a deep-sea dive.

headline: TV Viewership Falls in N.F.L. and Premier League: A Blip, or Something Worse?
abstract: The startling, double-digital declines in TV viewership raise questions about whether the football and soccer leagues have reached their peak.
lead_paragraph: The two most successful sports leagues in the world, which bring in billions of dollars in revenue, the biggest corporate sponsors and mammoth audiences every game day, are now sharing an altogether different experience: The National Football League and the English Premier League are enduring startling, double-digital declines in television viewership this season.

headline: Employees, Do the Homework on Job-Based Health Coverage
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Personal Finances']

lead_paragraph: Employees with job-based health coverage are spending a greater share of their income on health insurance costs, even though those costs are growing more slowly in most states, a new report finds.

headline: Can You Save London From the Inferno of 1666?
abstract: A museum’s “Fire! Fire!” exhibit asks the question by recreating the blaze with the game Minecraft.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Disaster lurks in every corner of a Museum of London exhibition exploring that city’s great fire of 1666. How should would-be firefighters rescue an imaginary warren of houses? With leather buckets and grappling hooks? Or Minecraft maps?

headline: Text to Text | Colin Kaepernick’s National Anthem Protest and Frederick Douglass’s ‘What to the Slave is the 4th of July?’
abstract: We ask students to consider: Can protest be patriotic? How does a history of injustice affect our shared understanding of our national symbols?
lead_paragraph: What is the purpose of patriotism? Can protest be patriotic? And, how does a history of injustice and inequality in this nation affect our shared understanding of our national symbols?

headline: What You Should Watch Wednesday Night
abstract: Tonight is the fourth and final season premiere of “Rectify” on Sundance. Here’s why the meditative show shouldn’t be missed.
lead_paragraph: This is the fourth and final season premiere, and as much as I’d love to welcome more folks into the “Rectify” fold as quickly as possible, you absolutely need to start at the beginning. Which you can! It’s on Netflix. And there are only 22 total episodes in the previous three seasons.

headline: Officer Shoots Man Wielding a Knife in Brooklyn, Police Say
abstract: The man, Davonte Pressley, 23, was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where he was in critical condition, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A man wielding a knife outside a Brooklyn laundromat was shot three times by an officer responding to emergency calls on Wednesday, the police said.

headline: Weather (and Self-Image) Protectors
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Coats and Jackets']
abstract: The new Stone Island in SoHo makes slick performance clothing, as if the tactical sections of the military were induced to put on a runway show.
lead_paragraph: The puny width of your ambition becomes clear as soon as you walk into the new Stone Island store in SoHo. You are durable, sure, but not particularly rugged. You understand that man wasn’t built for the elements — or maybe it’s that man hasn’t evolved to keep up with the elements. You are tender, with your UberX rides and your cold-pressed juice and your membership at the local CrossFit gym, which you use, like, once or twice a week, because that’s just plenty, thank you.

headline: ‘I’m Scared These Men Will Kill Everyone’: ISIS Takes a Somalia Town
abstract: Dozens of men with machine guns and rifles marched into the town of Qandala, residents and officials said, opening another front in the battle between ISIS and the Shabab.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The black flag of the Islamic State went up over an old, crumbling coastal town in Somalia at dawn on Wednesday, the latest sign of a sharpening duel between Somalia’s top two militant groups.

headline: As Evening Commute Gets Darker, It Also Gets More Dangerous, Officials Warn
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Walking', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Commuting', 'Daylight Saving Time']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio will announce Thursday a new $1.5 million “dusk and darkness” safety campaign for New York’s drivers and pedestrians.
lead_paragraph: The end of daylight saving time next month will create a more dangerous evening commute as people find it harder to see on the streets, New York City officials say.

headline: Marilyn Minter’s Take on Sexuality, Dirt, Pimples and All
abstract: “Marilyn Minter: Pretty/Dirty” opens at the Brooklyn Museum. It holds a mirror up to our culture’s obsession with a sensuality that seems to deny the body.
lead_paragraph: “I’m trying to say it’s time to look at who we really are,” the painter Marilyn Minter once said. And for more than 40 years, her gorgeous, grimy, sexy, icky, sparkly, sweaty work — the subject of her first New York retrospective, “Marilyn Minter: Pretty/Dirty,” opening Friday, Nov. 4, at the Brooklyn Museum — has held an uncomfortable mirror up to our culture’s obsession with a sensuality that seems to deny the human body. In Ms. Minter’s paintings, based on exuberantly composed photographs, fashion tropes appear as if hauled under a truth-telling microscope, where hairs and pimples and dirt hold equal sway with makeup and bling. Her interest in pornography, and what Holland Cotter in The New York Times called a “pathology of glamour,” made for tough going in the 1990s, when she was criticized by some feminists as a sexualizer for its own sake. But at 68, she is seeing history come around to her way of thinking. In a video interview for the retrospective, she says: “My side won, basically.” (brooklynmuseum.org)

abstract: The New York Academy of Arts, founded by Andy Warhol in 1982, holds annual action and party at Sotheby’s.

headline: Resting Heart Rate May Predict Future Mental Ills
keywords: ['Heart', 'Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Schizophrenia', 'Blood Pressure', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Men and Boys', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: In young men, heart rates above 82 beats a minute were tied to increased risk of obsessive-compulsive disorder, anxiety disorder and schizophrenia.
lead_paragraph: Extremely high or low resting heart rates in young men may predict psychiatric illness later in life, a large new study has found.

headline: A Bonus Insult to Veterans
abstract: The nation owes a debt to those who faithfully served — not the other way around.
lead_paragraph: Indianapolis — Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter’s announcement on Wednesday that the Pentagon is suspending its program to claw back military signing bonuses is a welcome development amid a debacle that should never have happened. The hounding of nearly 10,000 California National Guard veterans to repay money that was mistakenly given for re-enlisting at the height of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars was not just ungrateful. It was poor strategy.

headline: The Vnyl, a Sprawling East Village Club, Brings Back the ’70s
abstract: The four-story night life emporium features a cafe, cocktail bar, food and vintage LPs chosen by Adrian Grenier.
lead_paragraph: As anyone who will spend this weekend in a sultry nurse uniform or a tangerine-hued Trump mask knows, it’s not a Halloween party without costumes. But for the rest of the year, can the Vnyl, a 1970s-themed club that opened in September and stands for “Vintage New York Lifestyle,” capture that era without bell-bottoms, sepia shades and disco?

headline: Clinton to Ring In Election Under a Real ‘Glass Ceiling’: Manhattan’s Javits Center
abstract: Dispensing with subtlety, the campaign said the candidate would await returns in the unglamorous glass fortress that is the Jacob J. Javits Convention Center.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has spoken for years of the “glass ceiling.” What’s one more night?

headline: 2 Kentucky Police Officers Win Pregnancy Discrimination Case
abstract: The Justice Department announced Wednesday that the city of Florence, Ky., would allow modified duty for pregnant employees and pay $135,000 in damages to two officers.
lead_paragraph: During her first pregnancy, Lyndi J. Trischler switched from her arduous duties as a police officer patrolling Florence, Ky., to a desk job. After she became pregnant again in 2014, she learned that the city had a new policy, and that there would be no “light duty”: She could keep working the streets or take time off.

headline: Individualized Ads on TV Could Be One Result of AT&T-Time Warner Merger
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Television Sets and Media Devices', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Television']
abstract: In a call with investors, the chiefs of the companies noted that the combined trove of their consumer data would be useful to marketers and consumers.
lead_paragraph: Targeting people with individualized TV commercials using cable or satellite boxes has been promoted as the future of television for at least a decade. But the business, known as addressable TV advertising, has remained on the fringes, usually limited to two minutes of local commercial time an hour on cable shows.

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: Live From New York
abstract: On this week’s podcast, Issa Rae (of the web series “Awkward Black Girl”) reads the story of a long-distance couple who grow so close on screen they decide to see if it will work in real life.
lead_paragraph: Did you miss “Modern Love Live”? No worries. In this week’s podcast, we’re highlighting performances from the event, which took place Oct. 20 at Town Hall in New York. Hosted by Ophira Eisenberg of NPR, the evening featured readings by the actors Kate Burton (“Scandal”), David Harbour (“Stranger Things”) and Amber Tamblyn (“Dark Sparkler”), comedy from Michelle Buteau and music by Lucius.

headline: At Juilliard, Can You Hear the Sprezzatura?
abstract: A concert aims to evoke a term coined in an Italian courtier’s 16th-century book, suggesting in music “something a little jazzier, more flexible.”
lead_paragraph: In recent times the Oxford Dictionaries Word of the Year designation has gone to terms like emoji, vape and selfie. I have a better one for 2016: sprezzatura.

headline: The Most Awkward Dinner Party of the Year
abstract: The carefully orchestrated seating arrangement on the dais of the Al Smith dinner offers an annual ranking of who’s who among New York’s power brokers.
lead_paragraph: Think Lenin’s Tomb on May Day, but without the medals. The only recognizable red was one skullcap and a few sleeveless dresses and, unlike the subtle rifts eyeballed by Kremlinologists, the only visible cleavage was that of the Fox News business anchor Maria Bartiromo.

headline: Review: In ‘The Great Indoors,’ Laughs at Everyone’s Expense
abstract: Joel McHale stars in this CBS comedy about an outdoors writer who suddenly finds himself office-bound with a bunch of tech-savvy millennials.
lead_paragraph: Several demographic groups could easily dislike “The Great Indoors,” a new CBS comedy starring Joel McHale, but the guess from this corner is that the series, which begins Thursday night, will have broad appeal. A recognizable star, clear and not very complex characters, well-turned jokes delivered at a brisk pace: Plenty of sitcoms have succeeded with those ingredients.

headline: Fall’s Most Interesting Trench Coats
abstract: With exaggerated proportions and unexpected silhouettes, the classic staple looks refreshingly new.

headline: An Annuity for the Teacher — and the Broker
keywords: ['401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'ANNUITIES', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Series']
abstract: A look inside the high-pressure job of selling workplace annuities to public schoolteachers.
lead_paragraph: Bradley Bergeron’s first professional job out of college was selling retirement savings investments to public schoolteachers in Connecticut. The applications he carried in his black leather briefcase, however, were for one type of product only: a high-priced variable annuity.

headline: Ana Gasteyer, Belting Out the Zany (With Kazoo, Too)
abstract: This saucy comedian and singer has a strong singing voice that can stir up quite a storm. At Café Carlyle, she is accompanied by a jaunty pop-jazz ensemble.
lead_paragraph: If you’re wondering what it means to be hip nowadays, the saucy comedian and singer Ana Gasteyer has an answer. Chirping a revised, up-to-the-minute version of the jazz standard “I’m Hip” at Café Carlyle on Tuesday evening, she urged fans to “follow me on Instagram,” and boasted of wearing “locally sourced vegan clogs,” tweeting from her bike, drawing zombie cartoons and collecting “my own eggs from my prize heirloom hens.”

headline: A ‘Gilmore Girls’ Festival
abstract: Fans of the TV show traveled from as far away as Brazil to gather in Washington, Conn., the small town that inspired Stars Hollow, the setting of the show.
lead_paragraph: Fans of the TV show traveled from as far away as Brazil to gather in Washington, Conn., the small town that inspired Stars Hollow, the setting of the show.

headline: For the Mad Ones, Bad Haircuts Make Good Theater

lead_paragraph: About a year before their company’s 2009 debut, members of the theater troupe that came to be known as the Mad Ones bonded at a screening of “Back to the Future.” You might call it foreshadowing.

headline: Fans Flock to Town That Inspired ‘Gilmore Girls’
abstract: As part of a festival, a rural town in Connecticut played host to more than 1,300 devotees, who endured rain to tour the town and meet stars from the show.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Conn. — In 1999, a television writer named Amy Sherman-Palladino vacationed at the Mayflower Grace, a five-star inn built high on a hill here. In true Hollywood fashion, Ms. Sherman-Palladino returned to her hometown, Los Angeles, and from her brief visit spun Stars Hollow — a charming New England small town with its own resident troubadour. Stars Hollow would become the setting for “Gilmore Girls,” her cultishly popular mother-daughter dramedy that ran for seven seasons on the WB (and later the CW).

headline: Prehistoric People Decorated With Cave Lion Pelts
keywords: ['Caves and Caverns', 'Lions', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: The discovery of nine fossilized claw bones suggests that prehistoric humans may have decorated with animal skins.
lead_paragraph: Some 16,000 years ago, prehistoric humans ventured deep into the La Garma cave in Spain to perform sacred rituals. Guided by lanterns made of animal fat, they navigated hundreds of feet through dark caverns and around thick stalagmites until they reached one of their circular stone huts, each of which had a horse skull at its center.

headline: Paula Vogel’s ‘Indecent’ to Open on Broadway
abstract: The work, by the Pulitzer Prize winning playwright, explores the real-life story of a play that was shut down in part because it depicted a lesbian relationship.
lead_paragraph: Paula Vogel already has a Pulitzer Prize. And now, after a four-decade playwriting career, she’s going to make her Broadway debut.

headline: What Else Is on the Ballot? Minimum Wage, Death Penalty and Guns
keywords: ['Referendums', 'States (US)', 'Gun Control', 'Voting and Voters', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Income Tax', 'Taxation', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Charter Schools', 'Capital Punishment', 'Minimum Wage']
abstract: Election Day measures include initiatives to raise the minimum wage, impose background checks on gun purchases and reinstate the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to big choices facing voters on Election Day, it’s not all about Hillary Clinton versus Donald J. Trump. Down the ballot are a variety of initiatives, from the raising of the minimum wage to the restriction of gun purchases to the reinstatement of the death penalty. Here’s a look at some of the hot-button issues Americans will decide on Nov. 8.

headline: ‘A New Start’ as Judge Halts Deliberations in Oregon Refuge Trial

abstract: One of the 12 jurors was dismissed on Wednesday after being accused of bias. The panel must now begin deliberations from scratch.

The move brought deliberations in the case, which were in their fourth day, to a temporary halt.

headline: Review: In John Grisham’s ‘The Whistler,’ a Serious Woman and Serious Crime
abstract: The Grisham formula hasn’t gotten old. When he’s on his game, as he is with his latest legal thriller, it really works.
lead_paragraph: John Grisham has now written 29 legal thrillers and fought harder for truth, justice and the American way than anyone this side of Superman. His values don’t change, and neither do his tactics, but the Grisham formula hasn’t gotten old. Or older. When he’s on his game, as he is with his latest, “The Whistler,” it really works.

headline: World Series: Here’s How the Chicago Cubs Won Game 2

The series now shifts to Chicago’s Wrigley Field, which hasn’t hosted a World Series game since 1945. Here’s a look at the important story lines after two games:

headline: No Walls Here: Between Tijuana and San Diego, an Art Ethos Thrives
abstract: This cross-border megalopolis is a hotbed for binational artists and works that explore the nature of boundaries and identity.
lead_paragraph: TIJUANA, Mexico — Marcos Ramírez, the ebullient artist known as ERRE, recently drove from San Diego to his workshop studio in Tijuana in a black Chevy Suburban riddled with bullet holes. The vehicle had a starring role in “La Suburban Negra,” or “The Black Suburban,” his 2012 installation and video about the drug trade, in which he plays a drug lord, a hit man and a cop.

headline: Tove Lo’s ‘Lady Wood’: More Professional Than Passionate
abstract: Ms. Lo’s new album, her second, finds her back with Max Martin, with songs that seem much the same as those on her debut, but far more coolly produced.
lead_paragraph: When pop works best, its mechanisms simultaneously shine and disappear. The music becomes a neat, irresistible package that delivers a burst of emotion — something so startling and immediate that it’s more welcome with every return of the chorus.

headline: Matthew Weiner to Create a Series for Amazon
abstract: The creator of “Mad Men” has signed on for an eight-episode series for the streaming service.

headline: Montenegro’s Prime Minister Resigns, Perhaps Bolstering Country’s E.U. Hopes

headline: Two Earthquakes Shake Up Central Italy
abstract: The earthquakes damaged buildings in several towns, two months after a quake killed nearly 300 people in the country.

headline: Party at Napoli’s? Indians Fans Hope He Brings the Celebration to Them
abstract: Mike Napoli, a free-spirited, 35-year-old former catcher, has helped lead three different American League teams to the World Series in the past six years.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When you talk to Mike Napoli, it is hard to avert your eyes from the top of his left hand. On it is a tattoo of spindly fingers crawling out of an eyeball. Napoli, the good-time first baseman for the Cleveland Indians, explained that he had to fill that space somehow.

headline: Donald Trump Offers His Version of ‘New Deal for Black America’

headline: With a Politician’s Flair, Khizr Khan Tries to Push Clinton to Finish Line

lead_paragraph: NORFOLK, Va. — With the polish of a seasoned politician, Khizr Khan strode through the door of a seafood restaurant to the serenade of clicking cameras, clasped hands with cheering Democratic lawmakers and, as he has become famous for doing, unflinchingly argued that Donald J. Trump must not be president.

headline: Brigham Young Students Who Report Sexual Assault Won’t Face Honor Code Sanctions
abstract: The university said that offering amnesty from potential punishment would help encourage students to report sex-related crimes.
lead_paragraph: Brigham Young University announced on Wednesday that it would spare students who report sexual assaults from facing punishment for violations of its honor code, such as drinking or extramarital sex, that may have happened near or at the time of the assault.

headline: Quotation of the Day

headline: 8 Nursing Home Killings Leave Ontario Asking: Why?
keywords: ['Serial Murders', 'Elderly', 'Nursing Homes', 'Elder Care', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: New details emerged about a nurse charged with eight counts of murder over a seven-year period, but a possible motive for the killings remained unclear.
lead_paragraph: WOODSTOCK, Ontario — As details emerged on Wednesday about what led the police in Ontario to link the deaths of eight nursing home patients to a nurse who had cared for them, relatives of the patients were left without an answer to the searing question: Why?

abstract: Hundreds of thousands of protesters in Caracas demanded a recall referendum that would expel the president from office.

headline: 2 Stations on New 2nd Avenue Line May Not Be Ready by December

lead_paragraph: Officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority remained committed on Wednesday to a December opening for the first leg of the Second Avenue subway, despite growing concerns that the project would not be finished on time.

headline: Donations to Foundation Vexed Hillary Clinton’s Aides, Emails Show
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: A new release by WikiLeaks reveals how efforts to limit potential conflicts led to infighting among advisers in the years before Mrs. Clinton announced her 2016 candidacy.
lead_paragraph: In the years before Hillary Clinton announced she would run again for president, her top aides expressed profound concerns in internal emails about how foreign donations to the Clinton Foundation and Bill Clinton’s own moneymaking ventures would affect Mrs. Clinton’s political future.

headline: Jonathan Lucroy’s Rejection of the Indians Paved the Way for Roberto Perez
abstract: Lucroy vetoed a trade to Cleveland and ended up with the Texas Rangers, setting Perez up to start the World Series opener behind the plate.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Watching Roberto Perez, the Cleveland Indians’ defense-minded catcher, smash two home runs in a Game 1 victory over the Chicago Cubs in the World Series on Tuesday night sparked the imagination. What if the All-Star catcher Jonathan Lucroy had not vetoed a trade to the Indians in late July?

headline: Jack T. Chick, Cartoonist Whose Tracts Preached Salvation, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Chick’s tracts were said to have sold more than 900 million copies while being attacked as instruments of hate speech.
lead_paragraph: Jack T. Chick, whose religious cartoons, known as Chick tracts, became known worldwide as tools of religious salvation, but which were also attacked as instruments of hate speech, died on Sunday at his home in Alhambra, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Jorge Batlle, Political Scion Who Led Uruguay, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Batlle was the first Latin American leader to propose the partial legalization of drugs as a way to reduce trafficking, money laundering and profiteering by cartels.
lead_paragraph: Jorge Batlle, the brash scion of a political dynasty who had been groomed to be president of Uruguay since he was a teenager, got elected to the post on his fifth try and then audaciously presided over a pro-American administration that survived a brush with bankruptcy, died on Monday in Montevideo. He was 88.

headline: Spooky
abstract: Milo Beckman returns with a phantasmic puzzle.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Well, this is both timely and brilliant. I know that it’s brilliant because in my first attempt at solving, I tanked pretty miserably.

headline: In ‘The Crown,’ a Young Queen, but a Young Woman, Too
abstract: The conflict between private and public is the central subject of this ambitious Netflix show about the reign of Queen Elizabeth II.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Queen, dressed in black, protected from the drizzling rain by a large umbrella, looked up at the statue on its plinth before her; it was draped in the British flag. Around her stood flocks of dark-suited dignitaries; below, in the wide avenue called the Mall, a massed crowd waited silently. She began a short speech in her distinctively high-pitched, clear voice, then tugged the string that would pull down the flag to reveal the statue. It began to slide, then stuck halfway. A team of helpers rushed in.

headline: ‘Designated Survivor’ Season 1, Episode 5: Who’s the Real Hero?
abstract: The country’s ultimate savior might not be President Kirkman, and that’s not necessarily a bad thing.
lead_paragraph: Welcome back to the White House! This week’s episode of “Designated Survivor” revolves around a military strike, and contains all the classic elements of the show we’ve come to know and (maybe) love: ominous lead-chasing, flirtatious-yet-strained banter, close-ups on widening eyes, thickly laid moral dilemmas. Most interestingly, it implicitly floats the idea that President Kirkman is not, in fact, the hero of this story.

headline: Cubs Pull Even in World Series as Indians’ Play Proves Sloppier Than the Weather

He threw a first-pitch strike to only half the batters he faced. He fired 98 pitches in all, but only 55 were strikes. He walked three batters.

Among the factors that worked against them in Game 2 of the World Series on Wednesday were a malfunctioning drone and an injury incurred during a postgame celebration.

headline: The Corrosive Election and the New Abnormal
abstract: This excruciating presidential campaign has challenged the resilience of our political system.
lead_paragraph: The only presidential inauguration I’ve attended was Bill Clinton’s first, on Jan. 20, 1993. I took two spare tickets from the office, and brought my 7-year-old daughter, bundled against the cold like a little abominable snowman and old enough, I figured, for a civics lesson.

headline: Gov. Christie’s Shadow Over Bridgegate
abstract: Whatever the trial verdict, the picture of the New Jersey governor’s administration that has emerged is devastating.
lead_paragraph: It has been a riveting few days in the tragicomic opera known as Bridgegate, now playing at the federal courthouse in Newark. Bridget Anne Kelly, whom we last saw disappearing under the wheels of a bus, shoved there by Gov. Chris Christie, re-emerged on the witness stand, testifying in her own defense. In an emotional climax to the six-week trial, she pointed the finger at her former boss as a bully and a liar.

abstract: Among white voters, the 2016 election will represent a complete reversal of the New Deal order between the rich and the poor.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Democratic presidential candidates have been making steady gains among upper income whites and whites with college and postgraduate degrees. This year, however, is the first time in at least six decades that the Democratic nominee is positioned to win a majority of these upscale voters.

keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Women and Girls', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)', 'Privacy', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Bathrooms and Toilets']

The lawsuit claimed that girls were subject to harassment, barred from participating in athletics, and forced to transfer schools rather than tolerate a hostile environment.

headline: For Real Community Policing, Let Officers Do Their Jobs
abstract: New York City does not need a special program to improve relations. Just treat the police as professionals.
lead_paragraph: All policing should be community policing. Police officers and residents work together every day, because it’s the only way to keep the streets safe. Over the past 30 years, though, whenever there has been a need to heal a rift between the police and the public, this basic principle has gotten watchword status.

headline: The Dark Days of Donald Trump
abstract: The half-minute candidate takes care of business.
lead_paragraph: Do you think Donald Trump has given up?

headline: Speaking While Female, and at a Disadvantage
abstract: Women are often cut off or ignored in the public sphere, research finds. But there are some possible solutions.
lead_paragraph: Women’s voices are often missing and discounted in public affairs, even when they have seats at the tables of power. They speak less, make fewer motions and are more often subject to negative interruptions. Similar patterns prevail online.

lead_paragraph: Clowns have been a recurring theme on fashion’s runways

headline: The Creepy Clown in Your Closet
abstract: Before scary clowns were a news phenomenon, they were a fashion trend. The strange story of our common clothing language.
lead_paragraph: We all know by now of the creepy clown trend/phenomenon/scare that has been sweeping the globe since it started in Greenville, S.C., in August. It’s spread to Canada, Britain, Germany and Australia, creating an existential image crisis not only among those who see their job as bringing fun and laughter to the world, but also among those trying to shop for Halloween.

headline: South Korea Plans to Revive Talks With Japan on Sharing Intelligence
abstract: Such an agreement would allow the South to better address the growing nuclear and missile threats from the North, South Korean defense officials said.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea said on Thursday that it would restart talks with Japan about a military intelligence-sharing pact, four years after a similar agreement was canceled in the face of a domestic furor.

headline: Fall Foliage
abstract: Why does fall foliage turn so red and fiery? Give us your explanation.
lead_paragraph: The Times asks, “Why does fall foliage turn so red and fiery?”

headline: Haunted Houses Are About More Than Just Ghosts
abstract: What compels Colin Dickey in his appealing book “Ghostland” is the meaning of haunted places in contemporary American culture.
lead_paragraph: GHOSTLANDAn American History in Haunted PlacesBy Colin Dickey320 pp. Viking. $27.

headline: Their Inner Beasts: ‘Lord of the Flies’ Six Decades Later
abstract: Rereading William Golding’s classic, Lois Lowry finds herself despairing that circumstances led the children to such a hell.
lead_paragraph: “Lord of the Flies” was published in 1954, the year that I turned 17, and I read it not long after. I was in the habit then (as I still am today) of finding, in each book I read, the fictional character with whom I identified — the one with whom I would travel. If you are new to this book, as I was then, you will meet Ralph right up front. I felt an immediate kinship with Ralph, even before I knew his name. He is the first character introduced, and for a few pages he is called only by his description: “the fair boy.” I could relate to that. I was also “fair,” which I took to mean blond, and, though I wouldn’t have thought this through at the time, I played fair. I followed the rules. It seemed Ralph did too.

headline: When Does a Halloween Costume Cross the Line?
abstract: What advice would you give to someone who is unsure whether a planned costume is offensive?
lead_paragraph: Will you be dressing up this Halloween? How about your friends and siblings? What will you be wearing — and how did you decide what costume to wear?

headline: A Twist on Grandmother’s Singaporean Braised Duck
abstract: A mix of memory and cultures in the tastes of an island nation.
lead_paragraph: “I can already hear my mother scolding me: ‘You should find something more special to cook!’ ” Cheryl Lu-Lien Tan confessed. “But, you know, Asian parents — you’ll find a thousand ways to disappoint them before breakfast.” Or dinner, depending on the time of day. Just off a publicity tour for her novel, “Sarong Party Girls,” set in Singapore, Tan and I were talking about making the sweet soy-sauce-braised duck she grew up eating there. Special or not, it was a dish I was excited to make with her, because Singaporean food isn’t easy to find in New York, or in the United States, for that matter.

headline: Boko Haram Attacks Signal Resilience of ISIS and Its Branches
abstract: Renewed violence by a Boko Haram faction in Nigeria and Niger restores a deadly urgency to the conflict just as it seemed the militants were losing traction.
lead_paragraph: DIFFA, Niger — The military convoy was rumbling across a river near the border last month when soldiers suddenly realized they were surrounded. More than 100 Boko Haram fighters, some of them on horseback, had encircled the vehicles, ready to strike.

headline: Jail Time for Using South Africa’s Worst Racial Slur?
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Hate Crimes', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: A South African woman is on trial after a racist tirade was caught on video, and lawmakers are moving to make hate speech a crime punishable by imprisonment.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — After thieves broke into her car, a white South African motorist lashed out at the responding black police officers. She called black people “plain and simple useless” before unleashing the most offensive racial slur around.

headline: The East Village for Dog and Owner
abstract: Caroline Turner sought a place big enough for her and her pet — but not too big.

headline: For Unclaimed Dead, Grim Delays Before the Final Stop
abstract: Twenty-two bodies slated for burial on Hart Island were kept in storage, sometimes for years, before being laid to rest. Some of the deceased had families who were searching for them in vain.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-two bodies slated for burial on Hart Island were kept in storage, sometimes for years, before being laid to rest. Some of the deceased had families who were searching for them in vain.

lead_paragraph: Every month or two, the young woman would type her father’s name into an internet search field, hoping for any sign that he was dead or alive.

headline: How China’s Politics of Control Shape the Debate on Deserts
abstract: Troy Sternberg, an Oxford researcher, shares his views on why government efforts to hold back the growth of deserts are exacerbating the problem.
lead_paragraph: In the coming decades, millions of people around the world are expected to be displaced from their homes because of climate change. China has already been grappling with environmental resettlement for many years, particularly in the north, where drought, poor industrial and water policies, and other factors have resulted in rapid degradation of the land. This week, The New York Times published two stories from the deserts of northern China that look at the plight of what the government calls “ecological migrants.” The first of these is a visual narrative about people living on the eastern edge of the expanding Tengger Desert. The second is on the world’s largest environmental migrant resettlement project, in Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region.

headline: Deutsche Bank Returns to Profit, While Regulatory Pressures Continue
abstract: The bank, Germany’s largest, said concerns about its legal troubles in the United States had overshadowed positive developments in its turnaround.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of turmoil in the markets, Deutsche Bank has provided some balm on concerns about its stability as a settlement with United States authorities looms.

headline: Montreal’s Green Alleyways Take Visitors Backstage
abstract: In Montreal, back alleys have been growing into surprisingly lovely neighborhood hubs, and hundreds have recently banded together as green alleyways.
lead_paragraph: The back alleys of most cities are ugly, collecting puddles and trash. In Montreal, by contrast, they’ve been growing into surprisingly lovely neighborhood hubs, and more than 250 blocks of them have recently banded together as official Ruelles Vertes, or green alleyways. They feature gardens that give residents leafy space for trick-or-treating, block parties, pop-up restaurants and more. Now the alleys are not only providing gathering places, but also giving visitors back-door peeks into Montreal’s daily life.

headline: Michelle Obama to Join Hillary Clinton at North Carolina Rally
abstract: Barack Obama won the state in 2008, but he lost it in 2012. Today, polls show it to be in play again, with the Democratic candidate seven points ahead.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama will make her first appearance with Hillary Clinton on the campaign trail on Thursday, attending a rally to try to encourage early voting in North Carolina.

headline: In Saint John in Canada, Exploring the Legacy of the Loyalists
abstract: Americans loyal to the British during the American Revolution fled to Saint John in Canada after the war. You can see pieces of that history, if you know where to look.
lead_paragraph: Oh, Canada. Not our home and native land; but: so close. But also: so not.

headline: Morning Agenda: Finance Gets Chatty, 2016’s Biggest American I.P.O., EpiPen Rival Returns, Commercials Just for You
abstract: Bank of America, MasterCard and some financial start-ups have been trying out chatbots that can initiate transactions and give financial advice.

headline: Search for Chinese Sailor Attempting Record Is Suspended
abstract: Guo Chuan had set off from San Francisco last week hoping to reach Shanghai in 20 days. The American Coast Guard found his trimaran drifting and unmanned.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Guo Chuan, an oceangoing Chinese adventurer, set off on a trimaran from San Francisco last week, hoping to establish his latest sailing record with a 20-day sprint to Shanghai.

headline: I Would Never Run a Women-Only Race. Until I Did.
abstract: I had always scoffed at women’s running events. But my politics were malleable when a potential P.R. was on the line.
lead_paragraph: I’ve avoided registering for women-only races the same way I avoid wearing that running bra that seems like it should fit perfectly, but chafes under my arms just enough to be annoying. I consider myself a feminist, but it’s always felt to me as though women-only events, with their finish-line pampering that screams of stereotypes — massages, chocolate, mimosas, men in tuxes offering congratulations — do nothing to actually advance the cause of feminism.

headline: Rethinking Franco-German Relations
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: With Britain quitting the E.U., its two founding partners must breathe new life into the idea of Europe.
lead_paragraph: Europeans are coming to realize that Brexit is changing Europe. Britain has long been a semidetached part of Europe, but in that capacity it played a crucial role. It was partly a balancing power, partly a therapist for the Franco-German couple that constituted the core of European politics. In Germany and France, it is a common refrain that they each need Britain as a counterweight to the other.

headline: A Male Nudity Breakthrough (and Also Obama)
abstract: We discuss our recent magazine pieces: Wesley’s about penises in popular culture and Jenna’s about Barack Obama as the first digital-age president.
lead_paragraph: Popular culture is having something of a male nudity breakthrough. In the last couple of years, there has been a surprising boomlet of penises on television and at the movies. Although it begins (barely) to catch men up to decades of topless (and bottomless) women, there’s still inequality at play: The penises deemed safe enough to see tend to be white ones. Seeing a black penis is rare. So is experiencing healthy black sexuality in popular culture.

headline: America’s Dangerous ‘China Fantasy’
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Trade and economic growth is making Beijing more repressive, not less.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the 1990s and early 2000s, American business executives and political leaders of both parties repeatedly put forward what I label the “China fantasy”: the view that trade, foreign investment and increasing prosperity would lead to political liberalization in the world’s most populous country.

headline: Democrats’ Unity at Risk

abstract: A reader condemns anger in all its forms.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How a Run-Walk Strategy Might Help Your Marathon
abstract: Marathon participants who walked part of their course were fresher and had faster average miles than those who ran all the way.
lead_paragraph: Completing a marathon can be triumphant — but also heart-rending, in a surprisingly literal sense. Immediately after a race, many recreational marathoners have been found to have high levels of enzymes in their blood that indicate cardiac damage. These runners have “stunned” their hearts, as some exercise cardiologists put it. Enzyme levels generally return to normal within a week or so, suggesting that hearts recover quickly, but some experts have still wondered if there are less-stressful ways to get through a marathon. For example, should nonelite runners deliberately walk part of the way?

headline: Will the Next President Face a Recession? Don’t Assume So
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Recession and Depression', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: You can’t predict a recession based on the length of an expansion; it doesn’t work that way.
lead_paragraph: The economic expansion that has been underway in the United States since 2009 is getting old, and soon will die.

headline: ‘Paint the Revolution’ Offers Mexican Muralist Muscle and Delicate Beauty
abstract: This Philadelphia show of political art from 1910-15 focuses on pioneers of the Mexican movement for artistic nationalism.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Politics or beauty? Take your choice. Conventional wisdom says they don’t mix. But “Paint the Revolution: Mexican Modernism, 1910-1950” at the Philadelphia Museum of Art argues, with reservations, otherwise. The show is the first all-out attempt in the United States in seven decades to grapple with the contradictions of early-20th-century Mexican political art. (The last one was also at this museum.) It has plenty of pumped muralist muscle — all those clenched fists — but offsets it with pictures as pretty as valentines.

headline: How Do You Explain Trump in Russia?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Teaching English is easy compared with answering questions about the G.O.P. presidential nominee.
lead_paragraph: YEKATERINBURG, Russia — Not long ago, I was invited to a sauna in Yekaterinburg, the fourth-largest city in Russia, just on the Asian side of the Urals. Going to the sauna is a full-day event in Russia, and I was not alone. The owner of the sauna had also invited his burly, self-assured, middle-aged friends.

headline: Pakistan’s Honor-Killing Law Isn’t Enough
abstract: Upending misogynistic tribal codes is the real key to finally ending the most egregious gender crime.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — In Pakistan today, it’s a sad reality that regressive societal attitudes toward women label us as commodities, second-class citizens and financial liabilities to our families. This leaves us open to abusive and violent traditions, dictated by tribal codes and enforced by social and religious conservatism: child marriages, forced marriages, bartering of women to appease feuds and the most egregious gender crime, honor killings.

headline: India to Expel Officer From Pakistani Mission, Calling Him a Spy

lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India announced on Thursday that it was expelling a Pakistani officer at the country’s diplomatic mission in New Delhi, accusing him of using his consular position to develop an espionage ring, a move likely to worsen tensions between the nuclear-armed neighbors.

headline: The U.S. Is Standing in the Way of Cheaper Drugs for the Poor
keywords: ['Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Medicine doesn’t need to be too expensive. But Washington seems intent on keeping it that way.
lead_paragraph: Every few months, a drug company gets caught cranking up prices. Most recently, Mylan, the maker of EpiPen, took its turn in the hot seat for raising the price of a lifesaving allergy treatment by 500 percent. Congress was rightly enraged and opened yet another inquiry into pharmaceutical price gouging. Mylan offered discount coupons.

headline: Clearing the Jungle in Calais
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: The encampment was a symbol of Europe’s continuing failure to solve the refugee crisis.
lead_paragraph: The Jungle, a sprawling migrant camp in northern France that had come to symbolize Europe’s dismal failure to cope with the waves of desperate people fleeing violence and hunger in the Middle East and Africa, is finally gone, cleared in a three-day French operation that will disperse the migrants and refugees among centers across France. But the greater problem that brought them there in the first place is far from cleared.

headline: 1916: Great Verdun Victory Related by Eye-Witness
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: A military report of the taking of the village of Douaumont by the French Army during World War I in October 1916.
lead_paragraph: The following graphic story of the great French victory at Verdun is extracted from a report compiled by a French military eye-witness: “In less than four hours, between 11.40 a.m. and 3 p.m., we wrested from the enemy ground which he had taken eight months to conquer, at the price of several hundred thousand men, and threw him back on the right bank of the Meuse to the line which he occupied on the evening of Feb. 24, the day before the Germans took Douaumont and four days after the commencement of the battle of Verdun. At the same time as they captured Douaumont, our admirable troops carried the Haudromont quarries, the work and farm of Thiaumont, the slopes of the Dame and Couleuvre ravines, the Nawé wood, the village of Douaumont, the Caillette wood, the Bazil ravine and penetrated the Fausse-Côte ravine as far as the Vaux pond. On the extreme right, another regiment carried the Damloup battery.” — The New York Herald, European Edition, Oct. 27, 1916

headline: Broadband Providers Will Need Permission to Collect Private Data
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: The new rules require broadband providers to get permission to collect data on a subscriber’s web browsing, app use, location and financial information.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal officials approved broad new privacy rules on Thursday that prevent companies like AT&T and Comcast from collecting and giving out digital information about individuals — such as the websites they visited and the apps they used — in a move that creates landmark protections for internet users.

headline: What Are Some Good Background Shows?

abstract: Omar Delgado, who was one of the police officers who responded to the Pulse nightclub massacre in Orlando, Fla., in June, is now being treated for post-traumatic stress disorder. Here, he describes what happened when he returned to the nightclub for the first time with his therapists.
lead_paragraph: Omar Delgado, who was one of the police officers who responded to the Pulse nightclub massacre in Orlando, Fla., in June, is now being treated for post-traumatic stress disorder. Here, he describes what happened when he returned to the nightclub for the first time with his therapists.

headline: Orlando Officers Grapple With Trauma and Red Tape After Massacre
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Police', "Workers' Compensation Insurance", 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder']
abstract: While compensation programs can help victims of mass shootings, it is often less clear what help is available for those who are first to respond to the scene.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The sound of a ringing iPhone makes Omar Delgado sweat and freeze in place. His heart pounds. He closes his eyes to fight back the ghastly images that no one should ever have to see.
