lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historical insights from The New York Times.

headline: Who’ll Start the Bidding? Learning the Ropes of Auctioneering
abstract: Higher math isn’t required to wield a hammer, but you do have to be able to count. Fast. And in increments. A tutorial on the art of selling.
lead_paragraph: For those of us who are terrified by numbers, the idea of presiding over an auction is more than enough reason to run screaming from the room.

headline: A Close Race for Darrell Issa, the House Mini-Trump
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Representative Darrell Issa, elected to the House in 2000, is one of two California Republicans whose re-election bids are imperiled by their embrace of Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: MODESTO, Calif. — For more than 15 years, Representative Darrell Issa has not so much as put out a yard sign. A Republican comfortably ensconced in his Southern California seat, he has blown by one challenger after another since being elected in 2000.

headline: When in India, Make Your Own Block-Printed Fabrics
abstract: Bertie and Victoria Dyer, a husband-and-wife team of trip planners, facilitate half-day workshops outside Jaipur.
lead_paragraph: One of the great thrills of visiting India is realizing how much is still made by hand and on the spot, from jewelry to rugs to furniture. But if merely watching an artisan create a made-to-order shawl isn’t enough, one company offers travelers the chance to do it themselves. India Beat, owned by Bertie and Victoria Dyer, a husband-and-wife team of trip-planners, facilitates half-day workshops in hand-block-printing in Bagru, a village outside Jaipur. The couple works with a single family of artisans who have been practicing their craft for generations and who help guests choose a design (whether traditional or newfangled) and color scheme (brick reds and deep indigos are popular picks). After practicing on a cotton prototype, the printmakers-in-training stamp their final designs onto a piece of cotton-silk cloth using custom-carved wooden blocks. The hope is that, in addition to a unique souvenir, people leave with a deeper connection to the country’s material culture. For all its glorious chaos, Victoria says, “India remains a place where intimate moments are still the most special.” From $175.

headline: Yoko Ono’s Vintage Sonic Blasts Still Sound Like the Future
abstract: Ms. Ono’s early albums, which brought the worlds of rock music and avant-garde art together in an inventive head-on collision, are being reissued.
lead_paragraph: The recording starts with a jolt: A pounding bass line from the Beatles’ old friend Klaus Voorman fuses with the drummer Ringo Starr’s crisp, steady beat. John Lennon’s frenzied guitar slashes against this careening rhythm section, and then comes the explosion: Yoko Ono’s voice, a tsunami of shrieks, wails, ululations and guttural eruptions interpreting a single word and the song’s only lyric: “Why.”

headline: The Cure for UTIs? It’s Not Cranberries
abstract: A yearlong study of female nursing home patients who took high-dose cranberry capsules showed no reduction in urinary tract infections.
lead_paragraph: Actually: You may enjoy the taste (see: vodka) but it won’t cure and, probably, won’t prevent recurrence.

headline: European Union Trade Deal With Canada Moves Forward
abstract: The Belgian prime minister said on Thursday that the country’s leaders had reached a compromise, but the deal could still run into problems.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A stalled deal to deepen commercial ties between the European Union and Canada appears back on track, after Belgium overcame objections that had threatened to derail the region’s entire trade agenda.

headline: In the Art World, Globalism’s New Spin
abstract: It feels like the right time to reassert global consciousness in the universe of art. Even some of New York’s large and conservative museums have been thinking this.
lead_paragraph: When the American economy bottomed out in the early 1990s, the contemporary-art market fell apart, and some gate-crashing occurred. Artists who were once denied entry, many of them nonwhite, came in. So did new kinds of art, much of it with roots outside Western traditions. An expansive new age of globalist art had begun, and it felt excitingly utopian. By forging links among far-flung people and cultures, art could do what politics could not: bring everyone to a communal table for share-the-wealth feasts, with museums serving as hosts.

headline: Pete Burns, Frontman for the Band Dead or Alive, Dies at 57
abstract: Mr. Burns gained fame for the 1985 hit “You Spin Me Round (Like a Record)” and later became known for his plastic surgery.
lead_paragraph: Pete Burns, the androgynous frontman for the British new wave band Dead or Alive, best known for the 1985 hit “You Spin Me Round (Like a Record),” died on Sunday. He was 57.

headline: Video Review: Ford Fusion Hybrid Combines Savings and Style
abstract: The Fusion may not be as miserly on gasoline as the Toyota Prius, but the Ford has the handsome chiseled lines that many hybrids lack.
lead_paragraph: There was a time not so very long ago when a vehicle’s high fuel economy was something worth bragging about (you know who you are, Prius owners). Then gasoline became cheap and hybrids began stacking up like so much cordwood on dealership lots. Some buyers still seek lofty miles-per-gallon numbers, but the clear trend has been toward bigger, thirsty vehicles. At least until gas hits $4 again.

headline: 13 Essential Barbecue Stops (and What to Order)
abstract: From Harrisburg, Pa., to Memphis, Tenn., the brisket, sausage, pulled and chopped pork, and fried okra you should put on your plate.
lead_paragraph: If you’re near Harrisburg, make a pit stop for sandwiches at the well-hidden ShakeDown BBQ (668 Firehouse Road, Grantville, Pa.; shakedownbbq.com). The menu changes regularly, but the sausage is always good. It is open all day Friday and Saturday and for lunch only on Thursday and Sunday.

headline: How a Car Lease-Transfer Broker Works — or May Not
abstract: A driver looking to end a car lease early might turn to a broker, but using such a service comes with its own costs and restrictions.
lead_paragraph: When a consumer wants to end a car lease early, and the leasing company isn’t willing to budge, brokers like Swapalease.com may provide a way out.

headline: Let the Lessee Beware: Car Leases Can Be the Most Binding of Contracts
abstract: An auto lease, a common alternative to buying a vehicle, is a three-party contract that can be hard to break.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Allie Mangel learned that she was losing some of her vision because of a rare condition called Susac’s Syndrome, the last thing on her mind was figuring out how to make her car lease payments.

headline: Flying for 10 Months Without a Layover
abstract: Researchers attached tiny logging devices to common swifts to confirm that the birds stay aloft when they aren’t nesting.
lead_paragraph: The common swift is a bird shaped by and for the air. In flight it looks like a crescent moon, with just a hint of head and a tail that, when spread, echoes the curve of its wings.

headline: Introducing Watching, a New TV and Film Website
abstract: It’s easy to watch things. It’s often difficult to find them. Let our new recommendation site help you.
lead_paragraph: There are more movies and TV shows to watch — and more ways to watch them — than ever before.

headline: Judge in Bridge Case Abruptly Adjourns Trial Before Closing Arguments
abstract: The sudden adjournment raised the possibility of a major hiccup at the end of a six-week trial over the closing of access lanes to the George Washington Bridge.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The judge presiding over the trial of two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey in the George Washington Bridge lane closing case abruptly sent the jury home and adjourned court on Thursday morning just as lawyers were about to begin their closing arguments.

headline: Making It: Dana Barnes
abstract: The artisan finds inspiration in the former New York synagogue where she now creates her striking textiles.
lead_paragraph: The artisan finds inspiration in the former New York synagogue where she now creates her striking textiles.

headline: Otherworldly Art, Created in a 19th-Century Synagogue
abstract: On Forsyth Street, Dana Barnes and her team of artisans create vivid, knotty textiles next to stone walls that once housed thousands-year-old rituals.
lead_paragraph: Over 100 years ago, European Jews worshiped and bathed in the rooms of a building on New York City’s Forsyth Street that housed both a synagogue and a mikvah, a small, rainwater-filled pool considered a gateway to purity and holiness. Today Dana Barnes and her staff of artisans create handmade textiles of vivid hues and knotty textures next to the stone walls where that thousands-year-old ritual was once performed. It took Barnes some time to feel comfortable working here: “I wanted to make sure I wasn’t violating the space.”

headline: AT&T’s Bid for Time Warner Could Bolster Boutique Advisers
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: An increase in new deals would help reverse a decline in revenue for independent advisory companies.
lead_paragraph: AT&T’s audacious $85 billion bid for Time Warner may help more independent advisory companies handle mergers and acquisitions.

headline: One Photographer’s Vibrant, Color-Saturated Landscapes
abstract: Sanja Marusic’s “Flowers in December” is a series of portraits in which human presence is almost incidental: The real subjects are their environments.
lead_paragraph: Sanja Marusic’s “Flowers in December” is a series of portraits in which human presence is almost incidental: The real subjects are their environments.

headline: How the Brown Rat Conquered New York City (and Every Other One, Too)
abstract: Brown rats were confined to Asia until 300 years ago, a DNA study found. Then European colonizers helped them take over the world.
lead_paragraph: Millions of them live in New York, and billions more in cities and on farms across the globe. And wherever they scurry, they wreak havoc.

headline: An AIDS-Era Musical in an Age of Marriage Equality
abstract: Times have changed for gay rights, leading the makers of “Falsettos” to wonder how the show will be received compared with its Broadway debut in 1992.
lead_paragraph: In 1992, the musical “Falsettos” arrived on Broadway, bringing to the world’s biggest stage a self-centered nebbish named Marvin, who, having left his wife and son for another man, was nevertheless pining in song for “a tight-knit family” of “kid, wife and lover.” That year, Pat Robertson, at the Republican National Convention, was inveighing against Bill Clinton’s “radical plan to destroy the traditional family” and to “appoint homosexuals to his administration.”

headline: Make Firefox Open Gmail to Send a Message
abstract: If Mozilla’s browser automatically calls up that stand-alone mail software you never use when you click a “mailto” link, here’s how to fix it.
lead_paragraph: Q. When I click an email address link on a web page to send a new message on my PC, Firefox tries to open the separate mail program I never use, instead of switching to the Gmail page I have open in another tab and creating the new message there. Can I fix this?

headline: Review: In ‘Good Girls Revolt,’ the ‘Nasty’ Women of the 1960s Fight Job Discrimination
abstract: Amazon’s new show, about a group of young journalists, has serendipitous parallels to the contentious gender politics dominating the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: One of the most quotable scenes in “Mad Men” comes after Joan (Christina Hendricks) endures a meeting with male colleagues who harass her with sexual innuendos. Afterward, she tells her co-worker Peggy (Elisabeth Moss), “I want to burn this place down.”

headline: 8 New Nonfiction Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading by book critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Fall is an excellent time for serious nonfiction. We all have that lingering back-to-school imperative that makes us more inclined to learn something new or delve deep into a favorite subject. And the weather is finally accommodating, allowing for that seasonal desire to snuggle into a big armchair in front of the fire with a good book.

headline: Emails With My Favorite Trump Supporter
abstract: I tell my old friend that he’s revolting and dangerous and to tell his wife that I say hi.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco — I have an old friend. If I need something, he’s the guy I call. A good father, a good husband. He’s got a Ph.D. and is a well-respected college professor. That I also believe he’s a racist, misogynist, homophobic lunatic, I’ll get to in a moment, because I first want to make very clear that I love him like a brother.

headline: ‘Get Off Me. I Can’t Breathe.’ Philadelphia Teenager Dies After Struggle at Treatment Center
abstract: Pennsylvania has moved to shut down the Wordsworth Academy, a residential treatment center for troubled young people.
lead_paragraph: Citing “gross incompetence,” Pennsylvania has moved to revoke the license of a treatment center for troubled young people and to relocate dozens of residents after a 17-year-old boy died in a confrontation with staff members, according to documents from the state.

headline: Daily Report: Every Big Deal Must Have a Great Tech Angle
abstract: AT&T’s chief executive says a pillar of his company’s acquisition of Time Warner is networking technology called 5G. But it could be years away.
lead_paragraph: When you are spending $85.4 billion on a company, it’s probably wise to have a rationale that includes a whole bunch of futuristic technology.

headline: ‘Coffee Murder’ Case That Gripped Indonesia Ends With a Guilty Verdict
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Jessica Kumala Wongso was sentenced to 20 years in prison on Wednesday for poisoning her friend’s iced coffee with cyanide at a cafe in Jakarta.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The quiet afternoon coffee date nine months ago at an upscale Jakarta cafe ended when Wayan Mirna Salihin, after one sip of her iced Vietnamese coffee, collapsed suddenly. Hours later, she was dead.

headline: The Work, and Communities, of Mark di Suvero
abstract: The artist is one of the last remaining Abstract Expressionists — and has also spent six decades fostering alternative, communal working spaces.
lead_paragraph: The artist is one of the last remaining Abstract Expressionists — and has also spent six decades fostering alternative, communal working spaces.

headline: A Contemporary Art Titan’s (Almost) Secret Commune
abstract: Mark di Suvero, virtually the only Abstract Expressionist still working, has spent his career building large-scale sculptures — and even larger communities.
lead_paragraph: The sculptor Mark di Suvero’s New York studio occupies a complex of warehouses on an isolated stretch of the East River in Astoria, Queens. But the outward anonymity belies what’s inside: something like a bustling artists’ commune, over which di Suvero presides. There are large, live-in studios set aside for younger artists, and several glossy exhibition spaces display his work. (The legendary dealer Richard Bellamy, who gave di Suvero his first show and helped find the studio, which the artist purchased in 1980, ran a little-known gallery out of one of these rooms for close to 15 years.) There’s a touch of luxury outdoors — a small vineyard near the bank of the river — but it’s buffered by di Suvero’s brutal workroom, which functions as a kind of graveyard of unfinished sculptures, scattered among forklifts and laser cutters. In a common room, stacks of books stretch to the ceiling.

headline: The Lonely Life of a Republican Woman
abstract: Women would have to be lobotomized to believe anything the party of Trump tells them.
lead_paragraph: As has become typical in an election marked by its often unpleasant surprises, I awoke to a storm of outrage on Twitter on Wednesday morning. Newt Gingrich had told Fox’s Megyn Kelly that she was “fascinated with sex” and didn’t “care about public policy.”

headline: When We Hear ‘Bigly’ …
abstract: What Donald Trump really means to say.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Buzz Is Back in Edmonton? The Oilers Must Have a Prodigy
abstract: Connor McDavid, 19, who has been compared to Wayne Gretzky, has led the team to its best start since the 1985-86 season.
lead_paragraph: EDMONTON, Alberta — At stoplights around town, motorists honk at the owner of a 2009 black Ford F-150 and snap photographs of its license plate, the one that reads, “McDavid,” in red uppercase letters. Then they speed up, straining to see the driver through the window.

headline: Why Women Shy Away From Running for Office
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers discuss an Upshot article analyzing the reasons for the lack of women in politics.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Abandoning Donald Trump and, for Some Women, the G.O.P., Too
abstract: The Republican Party is in the midst of a gender war, with men and women taking sharply different stances over accusations of groping by Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has polarized men and women, with the sexes parting ways to such a degree that Election Day could produce the biggest gender gap in decades.

headline: Divine Flavored Nigerian Food Truck
abstract: Spicy African flavors make a weekday appearance outside the Nigerian Consulate in Midtown East.
lead_paragraph: Spicy African flavors make a weekday appearance outside the Nigerian Consulate in Midtown East.

headline: Meals for (Mostly) Everyone at Divine Flavored Nigerian Food Truck
abstract: An African chef brings the likes of gizdodo and moi moi to Midtown Manhattan — with just a few accommodations.
lead_paragraph: First, a snack: asun, dark, smoky goat meat sifted with what looks like crimson dust and proves to be Scotch bonnets, smashed into powder and weaponized. This is a fine thing to gnaw on the sidewalk, mouth burning, by a food truck with bright green hubcaps and a beach scene with silhouetted palms on its flank.

headline: Must Politicians Always Be Truthful?
abstract: Readers discuss an article that argued, “In politics, hypocrisy and doublespeak are tools.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: East Hampton Bar Is Set to Close, Taking More Than Its Stools
abstract: Wolfie’s Tavern, a bar that caters to the year-rounders on the East End of Long Island, is shutting its doors, and some patrons feel their way of life is also slipping away.
lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — “Jungle Pete’s Will Remain Open All Winter,” reads the 1945 advertisement for an East Hampton bar in a local newspaper, setting it apart from the host of establishments in the gilded hamlets on the East End of Long Island that catered then, as they do now, to the summer set.

headline: ‘Why? Why? Why?’ Man Asks, Stabbing U.S. Embassy Guard in Kenya
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: No one could offer an explanation for why a lone man confronted a Kenyan police officer by the embassy in Nairobi. The attacker was shot to death.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The shots rang out in front of the American Embassy on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Hugh Johnson’s Lifelong Journey Among the Trees
abstract: The writer has spent decades as an inspirational authority on wine and trees, and his enchantment endures.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Johnson, the venerable English wine writer, had just arrived in New York City on a trip he tries to make every year, especially in the fall when “the elms start to fire up.”

headline: Do I Fight for Child Visitation, or Pick a Job Transfer?
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Child Custody and Support', 'Drivers Education', 'Vegetarianism', 'Friendship']
abstract: Also, loyalty to an accountant, and a daughter who drives too ... slowly?
lead_paragraph: My wife and I divorced last year. It wasn’t great, but it wasn’t “The War of the Roses,” either. The court set a visitation schedule for our young son. I am supposed to take him one night a week and on alternate weekends. At the time, my wife said that she would be flexible; my work is unpredictable. But not only does she refuse changes, she sometimes refuses to give me my regular visits. This has been frustrating. My employer has now offered me a transfer to a city several hours away. If my wife were living up to the visitation schedule, I wouldn’t consider a move. But she’s not. So I’m thinking of taking the transfer. My parents are surprised. Thoughts?

headline: Venus Loses Thumb in Encounter With Caterer (but She Has It Back)
abstract: The British Museum confirmed a report that a catering company worker had knocked the thumb off the roughly 2,000-year-old Townley Venus, last Dec. 10.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Blame the caterer.

headline: 3 Mental Images From Calais: Hope, Hate and Happiness
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: A Times Paris correspondent reflects on his fifth and final visit to France’s “Jungle” migrant camp.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Adam Nossiter, a Times Paris correspondent, looks back on the week when the French government finally demolished the “Jungle” camp, the “vast, frigid no-man’s land” where thousands of African and Afghan refugees had slept in filth for months.

headline: He Was Convicted for Being Gay. 42 Years Later, He Wants an Apology.
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity', 'vis-dispatch', 'Apologies']
abstract: George Montague, 93, who is working to get apologies instead of pardons for as many as 65,000 other gay men, spoke about his life experiences.
lead_paragraph: George Montague has been many things during his long and colorful life: World War II veteran, entrepreneur, father, grandfather, Scout leader — and criminal.  In 1974, he was convicted of gross indecency under a British law that targeted gay men.

headline: Roommate in Tyler Clementi Case Pleads Guilty to Attempted Invasion of Privacy
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Hate Crimes', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Dharun Ravi, a former Rutgers student who used a webcam to spy on Mr. Clementi while he was having sex, accepted a deal with prosecutors to drop all other charges.
lead_paragraph: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — The former roommate of Tyler Clementi, the Rutgers University freshman who killed himself six years ago, pleaded guilty on Thursday to attempted invasion of privacy, one of the original 15 counts against him, ending a long and tortuous prosecution in a case that drew international attention.

headline: First Fossilized Dinosaur Brain Found
abstract: An amateur fossil hunter found something that looked like a pebble more than 10 years ago. Turns out, it was a dinosaur brain.
lead_paragraph: Paleontologists have uncovered what they believe to be the first ever fossilized brain tissue from a dinosaur.

headline: Vine Is Closing Down, and the Internet Can’t Stand It
abstract: One theory about the six-second video app’s demise says it was dead weight for its owner, Twitter, which is struggling to become profitable.
lead_paragraph: If you picture social video as a colorful ecosystem full of emoji and chat bubbles, you really should try to think of it more as a jungle — a place where the strong eat the weak.

headline: A Sculptor Reaps the Rewards of Art Deals Brokered in the Bedroom
abstract: Five years ago, the artist Skye Ferrante found a direct line to wealthy clients through a few new business partners: models who also worked as high-end prostitutes.
lead_paragraph: About five years ago, in a Brooklyn loft overlooking the East River, the artist Skye Ferrante was working on his latest creation, studying a nude model and twisting an elongated piece of wire to create an intricate sculpture.

headline: How France Won the Hearts, and the Art, of 2 American Collectors
abstract: The donation of the world-class collection of Spencer and Marlene Hays will transform the Musée d’Orsay.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For nearly a decade, Spencer and Marlene Hays, who live in Nashville and New York, debated what to do with their world-class art collection, centered on works by Bonnard, Vuillard and other French Nabis painters. Would they leave it in the United States? Or sell it and donate the money to charity?

headline: Ukrainian Hackers Release Emails Tying Top Russian Official to Uprising
abstract: Documents released by the hackers, which appeared to be genuine, showed a direct Kremlin role in creating and directing the rebel uprising in eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A group of Ukrainian hackers has released what it says are the emails of a senior Kremlin official that show a direct Russian role in creating and directing the rebel uprising in eastern Ukraine in 2014.

headline: The Freewheelin’ Bob Dylan and the Nobel Mystery
keywords: ['Nobel Prizes', 'Books and Literature', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: Readers suggest reasons the singer has not acknowledged his Nobel Prize.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Think You Know China? ‘Tales of Our Time’ Will Make You Think Again
abstract: Eight projects commissioned by younger artists from Hong Kong, Taiwan and China present startlingly fresh points of view in this show at the Guggenheim Museum.
lead_paragraph: Pop Art portraits of Mao Zedong and installations of Qing dynasty furniture have long represented the Chinese art world in New York and other cultural centers in the United States.

headline: U.S. Indicts Dozens in $300 Million Indian Call Center Scheme
abstract: Prosecutors said the operators of the scheme bilked thousands of Americans by posing as authority figures demanding payments for bogus debts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors brought charges on Thursday against dozens of people accused of taking part in a giant international crime ring that relied on Indian telephone call centers to bilk thousands of Americans out of more than $300 million.

headline: The Best Way to Save Obamacare
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The public option is the simplest route to a more stable, affordable and popular health care system.
lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act has faced a rocky six months. First, major national insurers scaled back their participation, leaving about one in five people buying coverage through health exchanges with only one plan to choose from. Then this week, the Obama administration announced that exchange plans would post an average premium increase of more than 20 percent (though most enrollees would be insulated from the full increase by subsidies for their coverage).

headline: Has Opioid Abuse Affected You?
abstract: Has the opioid epidemic touched you, a relative or a member of your community? The New York Times would like to hear your story.
lead_paragraph: Has the opioid epidemic touched you, a relative or a member of your community? The New York Times would like to hear your story.

headline: Hillary Clinton Basks in First Lady’s Soaring Popularity on the Campaign Trail
abstract: The candidate and first lady took obvious delight in singing each other’s praises as they campaigned together in the hotly contested state of North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. — The two women, once adversaries, embraced like best friends, calling each other “inspiring” and “amazing” and “my girl.”

headline: King Kong’s Latest Victim: The Writer
abstract: Marsha Norman, the Pulitzer Prize-winning book writer for the musical “King Kong,” has left the project.
lead_paragraph: “King Kong,” a much-delayed big-budget musical born in Australia but dreaming of Broadway, has parted ways with its Pulitzer Prize-winning book writer as the producers once again seek to retool the show.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
abstract: Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on Newt Gingrich, gun control and the World Series. Susan Lehman is host.
lead_paragraph: Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on Newt Gingrich, gun control and the World Series. Susan Lehman is host.

headline: Fantasy Football: Players to Start in Week 8
abstract: Look for productive games from quarterback Jameis Winston, running back Christine Michael and receiver T.Y. Hilton.
lead_paragraph: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
abstract: The Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on Newt Gingrich, gun control and the World Series.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, Andrew Rosenthal, a Times Op-Ed columnist, talks about the news — the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.

headline: 10 Things You Need to Know Before Seeing ‘Doctor Strange’
abstract: In this new film, Benedict Cumberbatch stars as the title character, who arrived unheralded in 1963 as a back-of-the-book feature to the Human Torch.
lead_paragraph: Even though he’s about to get the full Hollywood C.G.I. treatment, Doctor Strange has never been a superstar of the Marvel Universe — more like an endearing benchwarmer with a knuckleball personality and a wacky Cloak of Levitation.

headline: Review: ‘Request Concert,’ an Eleanor Rigby, at Least in Spirit
abstract: The German playwright Franz Xaver Kroetz’s 1973 drama takes naturalism to its extreme, showing a quiet woman passing through her evening.
lead_paragraph: A woman enters her small studio apartment after work. She neatly puts her shopping away and changes into loungewear. She prepares a light dinner, listens to the radio, flips through a catalog, uses the bathroom. Bedtime awaits.

headline: Guess What’s Back From the Grave? ‘Night of the Living Dead’
abstract: George A. Romero’s classic shuffler from 1968 has been restored and will be shown at MoMA. The original investors might even make a little money out of it.
lead_paragraph: When “Night of the Living Dead” opened in 1968, mostly in grindhouse theaters, Vincent Canby of The New York Times dismissed it in a three-sentence review as “a grainy little movie acted by what appear to be nonprofessional actors, who are besieged in a farmhouse by some other nonprofessional actors who stagger around, stiff-legged, pretending to be flesh-eating ghouls.” He said the filmmakers were “some people in Pittsburgh.”

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from Times critics.
lead_paragraph: Thierry Goldberg 103 Norfolk Street Lower East Side Through Nov. 13

headline: Review: A Sunny but Disappointing Take on the Tower of Babel
abstract: “Babel (words),” a dance-theater work from Damien Jalet and Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui had its New York premiere as part of the White Light Festival.
lead_paragraph: In the biblical story of the Tower of Babel, mankind’s coordinated efforts to build a tower to heaven are thwarted by the divinely sent obstacle of mutually incomprehensible languages. Diversity, in this telling, is a curse. But the creators of the dance-theater work “Babel (words)” have a sunnier view of cultural differences and the possibilities for cross-cultural communication. This would be cheering, especially in this political moment, if only “Babel” were less dull.

headline: At the Quai Branly, ‘Each Exhibition We Do Is a Book Telling a Story’
abstract: Since it opened 10 years ago, this Paris museum has promoted globalism, embracing diverse cultural elements from Chinese cuisine to tattoos to American jazz.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When the Musée du Quai Branly opened here in 2006, there were outraged predictions that this $295 million project was doomed to fail.

headline: Sound of the Strident Vowel in !Xoon
abstract: This sentence in !Xoon, translated as “I eat porridge,” includes a strident vowel at the end.
lead_paragraph: This sentence in !Xoon, translated as “I eat porridge,” includes a strident vowel at the end.

headline: A Jewish Exodus to a New Nation
abstract: The story of the havens Jews established in the Americas is the focus of a show at the New-York Historical Society.
lead_paragraph: IF such events can be said to have an upside, the Inquisition had one for Spanish and Portuguese Jews: It propelled them to the Americas, where they largely found the tolerance and opportunities denied them in Europe.

headline: Bow Aquiver, a Calligraphic Violinist Comes to Lincoln Center
abstract: Alexi Kenney, a rising musician who will perform at Alice Tully Hall on Friday, has been influenced by Japanese exoticism and attention to detail.
lead_paragraph: I first heard the violinist Alexi Kenney this summer, under adverse circumstances. He was giving a poorly attended recital at David Geffen Hall, an appetizer to a full-orchestra main course during the Mostly Mozart Festival. Onstage, he was surrounded by empty chairs and crowds of black music stands; in the audience, some people rustled plastic bags between their feet while others energetically shushed them.

headline: Twitter Has an Old Media Problem. Here’s a Solution.
abstract: The company has become an indispensable news source for millions but as a business, it needs a white knight to swoop in.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Twitter is a communications marvel, with 317 million active users who instantaneously convey a collective reaction to news.

headline: Review: Another Look at Donald Trump’s Scottish Dealings
abstract: “You’ve Been Trumped Too,” from Anthony Baxter, follows up on what happened to residents of Balmedie after Mr. Trump built a golf resort there.
lead_paragraph: Before he became a presidential candidate, Donald J. Trump began a lengthy campaign of chicken with the residents of Balmedie, Scotland, near Aberdeen, where his plans to build a golf resort went forward after a contentious approval process.

headline: Boo? Halloween Used to Be About Finding True Love
abstract: Forget blood, gore and scary monsters. In the early 20th century, games like Snap Apple kept the holiday’s focus on romance.
lead_paragraph: Halloween wasn’t always so scary. It was once less about fright and more about flirtation.

headline: Review: ‘The Unspoken’: If You Move Here, Find a Realtor Fast
abstract: This thriller features a creaky building where something eerie once happened, and where Jodelle Ferland plays the nanny to a boy who has just moved in.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard these days to make a memorable cursed-house movie. There have been so dang many of them, and the format is so limiting — you can slam doors, make staircases creak, have the kitchen knives come alive — and then what?

headline: In a New Show, Carrie Mae Weems Takes on Hollywood
abstract: Carrie Mae Weems’s coming exhibition at the Jack Shainman Gallery offers, among other things, views of sets from shows like “Empire” and “Scandal.”
lead_paragraph: Dressed in dark flowing clothes with her back to the camera, the artist Carrie Mae Weems has made images of herself standing before monumental architecture and world-renowned museums, directing attention to these sites and inviting viewers to see them through her eyes.

headline: Review: ‘Thank You for Your Service,’ Stories of Soldiers and Suicide
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Veterans', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Movies']
abstract: This documentary spotlights the lack of support for combat veterans struggling with mental health problems and the tragic consequences of that neglect.
lead_paragraph: “Thank You for Your Service” starts with a frantic, tear-filled 911 call reporting a suicide. It’s a gut-wrenching moment in a documentary that’s filled with them, and with scenes that make you want to scream in frustration at the bureaucracy faced by combat veterans seeking mental health services.

headline: Sound of the 5 Basic Click Types in !Xoon
abstract: Hear the five basic click types: dental, alveolar, palatal, lateral and bilabial.
lead_paragraph: Hear the five basic click types: dental, alveolar, palatal, lateral and bilabial.

headline: Review: In ‘Mr. Donkey,’ a Village School’s Ruse Farcically Backfires
abstract: A parable about China’s past and perhaps its present underlies this mildly stagy and intermittently manic adaptation.
lead_paragraph: Zhou Shen and Liu Lu’s bleak farce “Mr. Donkey,” adapted from their play, has a sentimental streak, and, as farce can, a tendency to overheat. But beneath its mild staginess and intermittent mania lies a cynical, piercing parable about China’s past and perhaps its present.

headline: Moonlit Landscapes From a Tormented Painter’s Lucid Moments
abstract: Ralph Albert Blakelock spent two decades in mental hospitals, starting around 1900. At the same time, he created, and often destroyed, his now-sought-after works.
lead_paragraph: Although the landscape painter Ralph Albert Blakelock spent two decades in mental hospitals in and near New York, he still managed to keep working. Starting around 1900, as he cycled in and out of lucid periods at the hospitals, he captured scenes of moonlit skies, glades of leafless trees and multicolored streaks of clouds. For art supplies, he had to forage. He dismantled window shades and wooden cigar boxes to create fabric and panel backings for his paintings. He formulated watercolor pigments with tobacco juice. His paintbrushes were made from cat hair that he wired into bundles.

headline: Review: ‘The Greasy Strangler’ Pairs Father and Son in Tours and Gore
abstract: The two revel in Los Angeles disco history by day, and the dad stalks by night in this midnight-movie-esque work from Jim Hosking.
lead_paragraph: Thank heavens Jim Hosking’s lurid live-action cartoon, “The Greasy Strangler,” found financing, because this oddity — borrowing liberally from a precious, vanishing institution, midnight movies — invites strong reactions. Yet its willful determination to be outré proves its undoing.

headline: Xi Jinping, Hillary Clinton, Syria: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Review: ‘Finding Babel’ Retraces a Celebrated Grandfather’s Footsteps
abstract: This documentary examines the life and work of the renowned Soviet writer Isaac Babel, who was executed by Stalin in 1940.
lead_paragraph: “Finding Babel” follows Andrei Malaev-Babel, a Florida acting teacher, as he retraces the steps of his grandfather, Isaac Babel, the author of “Red Cavalry” and “The Odessa Tales” and a vivid chronicler of the early years of the Soviet Union. A Jew who, working for a newspaper, had gone riding among Cossacks, Babel is discussed as a voracious observer of details and ambiguities. Arrested in 1939 by the Stalinist secret police and executed in 1940, he was granted posthumous official rehabilitation in 1954. Much of his work is lost.

headline: Review: In ‘Crosscurrent,’ a Melancholy Journey Along the Yangtze
abstract: Yang Chao’s tale of a cargo boat owner’s trip from port to port is a meditation of China’s economic rebirth that pushes against the tide of prosperity.
lead_paragraph: Buckling beneath the weight of its director’s ambitions, Yang Chao’s “Crosscurrent” is spectacular to look at and a devil to decode. Cramming fantasy and mysticism, faith and history into a single riverboat journey, this dirgelike meditation on China’s painful economic rebirth dispenses with narrative in favor of semiotics.

headline: The Day a Cubs Manager Told Fans at Wrigley to Get a Job
abstract: Lee Elia, whose tantrum in 1983 went viral without social media, stands as a reminder that baseball on the North Side of Chicago was not always a love story.
lead_paragraph: Lee Elia will be watching Game 3 of the World Series on television Friday night, rooting for the Chicago Cubs while trying hard to forget one fateful afternoon at Wrigley Field when his tantrum turned into a pre-internet meme.

headline: Zombie, Vampire, Slasher? Choose Your Halloween Villain and Celebrate
abstract: A roundup of events and films for Halloween weekend.
lead_paragraph: Christmas has St. Nick. Easter has its bunny. But Halloween has a lunatic asylum’s worth of mascots. What’s the best way to map out your holiday weekend? The idea behind this curated planner is simple: Let your favorite villain be your guide.

headline: ‘Pipilotti Rist: Pixel Forest,’ Deep in the Wilds of Video
abstract: A show where viewers can relax on pillows while watching and listening, and perhaps leave with a sense of encountering nature as never before.
lead_paragraph: The Swiss artist Pipilotti Rist has gone supernova at the New Museum. A 30-year survey, “Pipilotti Rist: Pixel Forest,” traces her ever-expanding journey into the wilds of video, with a rapturous fusion of lights, sights and music that ebbs and flows through the museum’s main gallery floors.

headline: Two Drugs for Adult Migraines May Not Help Children
abstract: Researchers said it was clear that amitriptyline and topiramate hadn’t done better than a placebo. But some doctors were not ready to give up on drug treatment.
lead_paragraph: Neither of the two drugs used most frequently to prevent migraines in children is more effective than a sugar pill, according to a study published on Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline: Review: ‘A Billion Lives’ Claims There’s a Conspiracy Against Vaping
abstract: Aaron Biebert’s documentary argues that e-cigarettes could help smokers quit, if only powerful forces weren’t trying to discredit them.
lead_paragraph: “A Billion Lives” is the kind of documentary that seeks to get you all worked up about an injustice but leaves you feeling as if there were nothing you could do about it. It’s also the kind of documentary that asks you to accept one set of experts’ version of things and reject another’s, when you suspect that disinterested parties are probably rare on either side.

headline: What You Should Watch Thursday Night
abstract: There’s some great comedy and a not-bad doctor show airing tonight.
lead_paragraph: TV could use a new, good doctor show. “Pure Genius,” above, is not that. But it’s not all bad either, and given that it hails from Jason Katims, the executive producer of “Parenthood” and “Friday Night Lights,” hope springs eternal.

headline: ‘Pipilotti Rist: Pixel Forest’
abstract: Scenes from the Swiss artist’s video-centered show at the New Museum.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Swiss artist’s video-centered show at the New Museum.

headline: Review: ‘Into the Inferno,’ Staring Down the Terrors of Nature
abstract: Werner Herzog’s documentary, a collaboration with a buoyant scientist, takes you to the precipice of volcanoes from Iceland to North Korea to Vanuatu.
lead_paragraph: Few filmmakers make the world seem more wondrous than Werner Herzog, more worthy of exploration and veneration. For decades, he has been probing the limits of existence, charting its mysteries and madness in fiction and nonfiction movies that together have created an extraordinary body of work. Part cinematic magus, part cosmic philosopher, he takes you places you never knew you wanted to go, asks questions you never considered and introduces you to characters who suggest the worst and the very best about us. There’s a strain of melancholia in this searching. I’m not sure if Mr. Herzog thinks that we can be saved — or are worth saving — but his restlessness suggests perhaps.

headline: Review: Iggy Pop Bares All, and Nothing, in ‘Gimme Danger’
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Movies', 'Music']
abstract: Jim Jarmusch’s reverent documentary on Iggy Pop, a provocateur, is prim: It includes no retrospective scenes of drug use or the bandmates’ fights.
lead_paragraph: Considering the frenzied psychedelic circus it might have been, “Gimme Danger,” Jim Jarmusch’s reverent documentary portrait of Iggy Pop, one of rock’s ultimate daredevil provocateurs, is downright prim. There are casual confessions of self-destructive, out-of-control behavior by Iggy Pop and his band, the Stooges. But you don’t see it. You only hear about it, and it’s glossed over as yesterday’s bad-boy antics.

headline: !Xoon Vocabulary: ǂqùhm ǁhûũ
abstract: ǂqùhm ǁhûũ means the sound of a sharp object falling point-first into sand.
lead_paragraph: ǂqùhm ǁhûũ means the sound of a sharp object falling point-first into sand.

headline: Marcus Samuelsson Knows (Almost) Everyone
abstract: The chef takes a stroll through Harlem before a party to celebrate his new cookbook.
lead_paragraph: As he made his way down Lenox Avenue, sporting a brightly colored shirt and tie, a gray tailored vest and a Louis Vuitton messenger bag, Marcus Samuelsson couldn’t seem to stop greeting people.

headline: Judi Dench, Shoplifter? Tracey Ullman Returns to Sketch Comedy
abstract: In “Tracey Ullman’s Show,” a six-episode HBO series, the comedian plays many characters, from the down-and-out to the famous.
lead_paragraph: Tracey Ullman must have a soft spot in her heart for makeup artists, because she is keeping a crew of them employed with her new sketch comedy series, “Tracey Ullman’s Show,” which receives its American premiere Friday night on HBO. Not all of the sketches are home runs, but even in the weaker ones, it can be fun just trying to figure out which character she’s playing and how the crew managed to effect such a transformation.

headline: A Presidential Friendship Has Many South Koreans Crying Foul
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: A scandal is growing over President Park Geun-hye’s ties to a shadowy adviser whose father’s relationship with Ms. Park has aroused lurid rumors.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Koreans have been riveted for weeks by a scandal involving the president and a shadowy adviser accused of being a “shaman fortuneteller” by opposition politicians.

headline: Theater Listings for Oct. 28-Nov. 3
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

headline: Comedy Listings for Oct. 28-Nov. 3
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: Review: ‘By Sidney Lumet’ Puts the Director in Front of the Camera
abstract: The documentary began as a series of interviews shot in 2008 in which the director talks about his life and work.
lead_paragraph: Movies about great directors rarely live up to their subjects. Still, there are dividends. A documentary like “By Sidney Lumet,” for instance, gives you a chance to hang out with a favorite filmmaker, to listen to him talk about his life and work, to hear the cadences and occasional cracks in his voice. True, there are moments when you wish you were watching one of his movies instead, but there’s something to be said for a tribute that inspires you to revisit the films and again seek out “Long Day’s Journey Into Night,” “Serpico,” “Q&A” and his masterpiece, “Dog Day Afternoon.” (Mr. Lumet died in 2011 at 86.)

headline: The Gallery Invasion: More Foreign-Based Businesses Extend to U.S.
abstract: Seeking to enlarge their audience base, more and more galleries from Europe and Latin America are opening or expanding in New York and Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: The gallery world is undergoing rapid change this year, as big international dealers expand their presence in the United States and abroad, and smaller European and Latin American art businesses establish their first outposts in New York and Los Angeles.

headline: Review: In ‘Inferno,’ Breathlessly Globe-Trotting and Decoding to Save the World
abstract: The symbologist played by Tom Hanks returns in another Dan Brown tale told at Ron Howard speed.
lead_paragraph: Late in “Inferno,” Tom Hanks blurts out, “My God, this is a labyrinth.” Well, of course it is, because Mr. Hanks is running (and running) through another muddled Dan Brown maze. Once again, this one comes to you from the director Ron Howard and his producing partner, Brian Grazer, who bring clenched-jaw commitment and a whole mess of filmmaking to every project, even the most disposable. In this case, the story may not make any sense, but they’re going to throw so much at you — so many jumpy moves, so many tangled threads — that you might not notice (or care).

headline: Measure in Florida That Claims to Back Solar Power May Discourage It
abstract: Opponents of the proposed constitutional amendment on the Nov. 8 ballot say that it was written to fool voters and could make panels more costly.
lead_paragraph: Florida’s biggest electric utility companies are backing a proposed constitutional amendment that, the campaign says, “promotes solar in the Sunshine State.” Not so: If Florida voters approve the ballot measure, it could pave the way for utilities to raise fees on solar customers and cast a heavy cloud over the future of rooftop solar energy in Florida.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Oct. 27, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Inferno,” “By Sidney Lumet” and “Into the Inferno.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Inferno,” “By Sidney Lumet” and “Into the Inferno.”

lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Boos, Boogieing and David Bowie at a Halloween Revel for Children
abstract: “Let All the Children Boogie,” a David Bowie tribute concert and album release party, will be the highlight of the LC Kids Trick-or-Treat event at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: As David Bowie once sang, “Let’s dance.” Or, as his musical heirs will put it this weekend, “Let all the children boogie.”

headline: Growing Up in New York, the City That Never Naps
abstract: The New York Times asked readers to recall a moment when their child, or a child they knew well, said or did something that made them think, “This is a New York City kid.” Here is a selection of those responses.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it was their first word, like “bagel,” or the detailed subway directions they gave to tourists. Or maybe it was when they didn’t know what something was; a mall, for instance.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates Asks: Who’s French? Who’s American?
abstract: Mr. Coates, curator of Festival Albertine, a celebration of French and American culture, discusses race, identity and the arts in France and the U.S.
lead_paragraph: WHEN James Baldwin arrived in Paris in 1948, at the age of 24, he was a little-known writer with $40 in his pocket. When Ta-Nehisi Coates arrived there last fall, at the age of 40, he was the author of a huge best seller, “Between the World and Me,” which won comparisons to Baldwin and upended his plan for a quiet, exploratory year abroad.

headline: Gallery Owner Accuses Alec Baldwin of Dodging Tax in Disputed Art Purchase
abstract: The art world feud between the actor and the gallery owner Mary Boone has taken a new turn.
lead_paragraph: The art world feud between the actor Alec Baldwin and the gallery owner Mary Boone took another turn on Thursday when lawyers for Ms. Boone filed a motion in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan accusing Mr. Baldwin of committing fraud by failing to pay sales tax on a painting he bought from her six years ago.

headline: Review: ‘Another Day in the Death of America,’ on Guns Killing Children
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Books and Literature', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Gary Younge examines the lives of 10 young Americans, ages 9 to 19, whose lives were snuffed out by firearms over 24 hours in 2013.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, between the wee hours of Nov. 23 and the wee hours of Nov. 24, 10 American children and teenagers were killed by guns. The youngest, Jaiden Dixon, was 9, shot by the deranged father of his eldest brother. The oldest, Kenneth Mills-Tucker, was 19, shot in a car under circumstances that are still unclear.

lead_paragraph: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

headline: ‘Cat People’ and a Gallery of Horror Predators
abstract: “Cat People,” produced by Val Lewton and directed by Jacques Tourneur, used a feline predator as a metaphor for a stifled libido.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of his brief career, the Russian-born producer Val Lewton (1904-1951) pioneered a new sort of horror movie. Shock ran second to atmosphere. The supernatural was a function of the psychological.

headline: TripAdvisor to Start Booking Travel to Cuba
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Travelers will soon be able to book through one of the world’s largest travel websites, the latest development in an American travel industry that is slowly normalizing tourism to Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Travelers will soon be able to book accommodations to Cuba through TripAdvisor, one of the world’s largest travel websites. It’s the latest development in an American travel industry that is slowly expanding tourism to the Communist nation.

headline: Apple’s New MacBook Pro Gets More Touchy
abstract: The new laptops feature a Touch Bar where function keys used to be. It works differently depending on the app in use.
lead_paragraph: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Apple’s high-end laptop, the MacBook Pro, which hasn’t had a major overhaul in four years, is getting a little more like the iPhone.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for Oct. 28-Nov. 3
abstract: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

headline: Amazon Comes Up Short on Profits, Focusing on Warehouses and Movies
abstract: The company said to expect as much as $1.25 billion in operating income for the fourth quarter and as little as nothing, a remarkably wide range.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — For the last several quarters, Amazon delighted investors by delivering something unusual for the company: a bumper crop of profits.

headline: Amtrak Agrees to $265 Million Settlement in Philadelphia Crash That Killed Eight
abstract: The settlement, outlined in a federal judge’s order on Thursday, is one of the largest involving a rail crash, a plaintiffs’ lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: Amtrak has agreed to pay up to $265 million in one of the largest rail crash settlements in the United States, for claims related to a high-speed derailment in Philadelphia last year that killed eight and injured more than 200, according to a court order issued on Thursday.

headline: The Profound Empathy of Yoko Tawada
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'German Language', 'Polar Bears', 'Empathy']
abstract: Through the stories of polar bears, dogs and other animals, the novelist makes us see “the other” — including ourselves.
lead_paragraph: Through the stories of polar bears, dogs and other animals, the novelist makes us see “the other” — including ourselves.

headline: Bundy Brothers Acquitted in Takeover of Oregon Wildlife Refuge
keywords: ['Federal Lands', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Land Use Policies', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves']
abstract: Ammon and Ryan Bundy and five of their followers faced federal felony charges stemming from the six-week takeover in January.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Armed antigovernment protesters led by Ammon and Ryan Bundy were acquitted Thursday of federal conspiracy and weapons charges stemming from the takeover of a federally owned wildlife sanctuary in Oregon last winter.

headline: Why You’re Still Stuck on the Bus
abstract: New York's buses are moving slower than ever, and activists want the city and the M.T.A. to use tactics from other cities to speed them up.
lead_paragraph: At the last second, I bought a ticket for the Bx12 bus on Fordham Road in the Bronx. About 30 people were waiting at the stop, near the gates of Fordham University, two miles from my destination across the Harlem River in Upper Manhattan.

headline: Mike McQueary Is Awarded $7.3 Million in Penn State Defamation Case
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Football (College)', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Libel and Slander', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: A jury found that the university defamed McQueary, a former assistant coach, after it became public that his testimony helped prosecutors charge Jerry Sandusky with child molestation.
lead_paragraph: A Pennsylvania jury on Thursday, in a defamation case against Penn State University, awarded $7.3 million to Mike McQueary, the former assistant football coach who in 2001 told Coach Joe Paterno that he had witnessed Jerry Sandusky sexually abusing a child in the locker room shower.

headline: Rival Palestinian Leaders Agree to Agree, but Not on the Details
abstract: The president of the Palestinian Authority, whose leadership has been questioned at home and abroad, met with Hamas leaders to try to mend an ongoing rift.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The leaders of the two main Palestinian factions met on Thursday in the latest attempt to reconcile after a nine-year schism that has divided their people and complicated efforts to negotiate peace with Israel.

headline: A More Money-Conscious Alphabet Emerges
abstract: In its otherwise solid third-quarter results, the company went some distance to reassure investors on its “other bets,” in-house visionary projects that have yet to make money.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google turned 18 years old in September and there are signs that as it gets older it is learning to be responsible with its money.

headline: More Wretched News for Newspapers as Advertising Woes Drive Anxiety
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Newspapers', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Company Reports', 'News and News Media']
abstract: News publications continue to be pummeled by rapidly declining print advertising revenue, and newsrooms everywhere are scrambling.
lead_paragraph: The gloom began earlier this month, when Gerard Baker, the editor in chief of The Wall Street Journal, sent a memo to employees that said, in part, “every story should be as short as it needs to be.” The next week, William Lewis, the chief executive of Dow Jones, which owns The Journal, announced a newsroom review that he said would be “underpinned by a series of cost-management initiatives.”

headline: Michigan’s Jabrill Peppers Has Many Positions and a Singular Role
abstract: In the undefeated Wolverines’ seven games this season, Peppers, a leading Heisman Trophy candidate, has played 12 positions, including defensive back, quarterback and punt returner.
lead_paragraph: In the jack-of-all-trades football universe of Jabrill Peppers, the strategic options appear unlimited.

headline: Courtesy and Homesickness on the E
abstract: Feeling awkward after a polite gesture is declined, but only for a few minutes.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Carlyle Group Turns Focus From Hedge Funds to Lending
abstract: An effort to diversify goes awry as hedge fund investments weigh on the bottom line.
lead_paragraph: Prominent public pension funds have turned their backs on hedge funds, and so have a few big insurance companies. Now, one of the world’s biggest private equity firms, the Carlyle Group, is walking away, too.

headline: Lawyer Accuses Justice Thomas of Groping Her at Party in 1999
abstract: The lawyer, Moira Smith, who was a 23-year-old Truman Foundation scholar at the time, said the justice had squeezed her buttocks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An Alaska lawyer has accused Justice Clarence Thomas of groping her at a dinner party in 1999, a claim that Justice Thomas called “preposterous.”

headline: Gavin MacFadyen, 76, Mentor and Defender of WikiLeaks Founder, Dies
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'News and News Media', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: The American investigative journalist and documentarian was a core supporter of WikiLeaks and Julian Assange and provided support of whistle-blowers.
lead_paragraph: Gavin MacFadyen, an American investigative journalist who became an early mentor and defender of the founder of WikiLeaks, Julian Assange, died on Saturday in London, where he lived and spent much of his professional life. He was 76.

headline: Criminal Complaint Against Alec Cook
abstract: The Dane County District Attorney’s Office filed a criminal complaint Thursday in the case of State of Wisconsin v. Alec Cook.
lead_paragraph: The Dane County District Attorney’s Office filed a criminal complaint Thursday in the case of State of Wisconsin v. Alec Cook.

headline: At Least 6 Women Accuse University of Wisconsin Student of Assault
abstract: The student, Alec Cook, 20, was charged with 14 felonies and one misdemeanor. “Dozens” have contacted the authorities, all “wanting to speak” about Mr. Cook.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — One woman told investigators that the college senior invited her this month to his apartment, where he raped her and choked her until her vision blurred.

headline: Rebirth of Bronx Housing Complex Aims to Cut Crime and Increase Homes
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Demolition', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: The Lambert Houses complex was celebrated when it opened in the mid-1970s, but now its owner considers it outdated and poorly designed. A $600 million plan will try to change that.
lead_paragraph: Soon after it opened in the mid-1970s, the Lambert Houses near the Bronx Zoo was praised as an innovative example of low-income housing, with urban planning experts cheering the complex for shattering the stereotypes of subsidized housing.

headline: Plane With Mike Pence Aboard Skids Off La Guardia Runway
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: No one was injured as the plane landed, according to social media.
lead_paragraph: A plane carrying Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, skidded off a runway in heavy rain at La Guardia Airport on Thursday night, but no one was injured, according to the authorities.

headline: Ewen Whitaker, Who Guided NASA to the Moon, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Whitaker had no formal training as an astronomer, but he used his unparalleled knowledge of the lunar surface to select landing sites for spacecraft.
lead_paragraph: Ewen A. Whitaker, a British-born astronomer who drew on his unparalleled knowledge of the lunar surface to select landing sites for unmanned NASA spacecraft in the 1960s, guide the footsteps of the Apollo 12 astronauts and develop accurate maps of the moon, died on Oct. 11 in Tucson. He was 94.

headline: Donald Trump Campaign Seeks ‘Voter Suppression,’ Report Says, but It’s Legal
abstract: The campaign dismissed concerns over a reported effort to reduce turnout among white liberals, young women and African-Americans who might vote for Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s campaign set off a wave of concern about its tactics on Thursday after a senior campaign official was quoted describing a sophisticated “voter suppression” effort, a term that usually connotes aggressive attempts to keep people from polling places.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, October 28, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Unfortunately, I’m not a man of vigilante violence.”

headline: Chelsea Clinton’s Frustrations and Devotion Shown in Hacked Emails
abstract: The emails paint a detailed portrait of Ms. Clinton as she set about her goal of “protecting my father and the nonprofit status” of the Clinton Foundation.
lead_paragraph: Chelsea Clinton was alarmed.

headline: President Duterte’s Confusing Behavior
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Editorials']
abstract: Statements by the Philippine leader leave uncertainty about the future of ties to the United States and to China.
lead_paragraph: This much we know: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines dislikes the United States, and is really angry that American officials have criticized his abhorrent extrajudicial killings of drug addicts and drug lords, which have left more than 1,400 people dead. What we don’t know is how far he intends to push his vision of a more independent foreign policy that is not tied to the strategic objectives of his country’s most important ally.

headline: As Freelancers’ Ranks Grow, New York Moves to See They Get What They’re Due
keywords: ['Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: The City Council passed the Freelance Isn’t Free Act, requiring written timetables and procedures for payment to clamp down on wage theft by employers.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Council voted unanimously on Thursday to give freelance workers a set of protections against wage theft that are believed to be the first of their kind in the country.

headline: A Baseball Writer Looks Back on 20 World Series
abstract: The Times’ Tyler Kepner attended his first World Series at age 8. On Sunday, he will see his 100th Series game in person.
lead_paragraph: The first time I went to a World Series game, in 1983, I woke up in a state of panic. I was 8 years old. Whenever I wore my lucky Phillies hat to Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia, the home team won. I could not find it anywhere.

headline: Where Are Baseball’s Minority Managers?
abstract: Commissioner Rob Manfred speaks of pipelines and entry-level positions while seemingly qualified black and Latino candidates wait for a chance to fill a void.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Gary Jones came jogging over during a cool, autumnal batting practice at Wrigley Field. An athletic-looking man with a thin trace of a gray-flecked mustache, he is the infield and third-base coach on the Cubs’ roundhouse punch of a World Series team.

headline: Michael Massee, 64, Screen Villain Haunted by the Accidental Death of Brandon Lee, Dies
abstract: Mr. Massee, a character actor, took a long sabbatical after the deadly shooting on the set of “The Crow” in 1993 and then appeared in many TV and film roles.
lead_paragraph: Michael Massee, a character actor who played villains on television and film and who fired the gun on the set of “The Crow” that accidentally killed Brandon Lee in 1993, died on Oct. 20 in Los Angeles. He was 64.

headline: Playing Rugby, Representing ... Multiple Countries
abstract: Players’ ability to switch nationalities has small countries sensing an opening to reclaim veterans and boost their teams.
lead_paragraph: Nationality is a fluid concept in the modern world. It is certainly that way for Cooper Vuna.

headline: Everyday Productivity Enhancer
abstract: Mary Lou Guizzo and Jeff Chen get our solving weekend started.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — You don’t have to be a fan of the Harry Potter series of novels to know how terrifying He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named is, and crossing LORD VOLDEMORT with ALL HALLOWS’ EVE is a perfect way to not only start our solving weekend, but to also prepare for Halloween, as we call it here in the United States.

headline: Review: ‘Falsettos,’ a Perfect Musical, an Imperfect Family
abstract: This revival of William Finn and James Lapine’s show has so much vitality that it feels as fresh and startling as it did back in 1992.
lead_paragraph: There’s hardly a moment in the exhilarating, devastating revival of the musical “Falsettos” that doesn’t approach, or even achieve, perfection. This singular show, about an unorthodox family grappling with the complexities of, well, just being a family — unorthodox or otherwise — has been restored to life, some 25 years after it was first produced, with such vitality that it feels as fresh and startling as it did back in 1992.

headline: Bitter Rift Deepens as Russia Rejects Findings on Syria’s Use of Chlorine Bombs
abstract: Adding to tensions between Russia and the West, Russia’s United Nations ambassador said a report that Syrian forces had used chemical weapons was unconvincing.
lead_paragraph: Russia on Thursday rejected the findings of a chemical weapons investigation led by the United Nations that found Syrian forces had used chlorine bombs at least three times in the past two years.

headline: Coast of Antarctica Will Host World’s Largest Marine Reserve
keywords: ['Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: Representatives from 24 nations agreed to create a zone that will encompass 600,000 square miles of ocean in the Ross Sea in Antarctica.

headline: An Exiled Editor Traces the Roots of Democratic Thought in China
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Cultural Revolution', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The veteran democracy campaigner Hu Ping says that Chinese concepts of freedom are not imports from the West, but a response to oppression at home.
lead_paragraph: Hu Ping is the editor of the pro-democracy journal Beijing Spring, based in New York. But in 1975, he was 28 and living in the southwestern Chinese city of Chengdu, a recently returned “educated youth” who had been sent down to labor in the countryside during the Cultural Revolution.

headline: Donald Trump in Bollywood
abstract: It’s not surprising that he would go after Indian voters.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India was seeking office more than two years ago, one of his favorite sayings was, “Ab ki baar, Modi sarkar,” or, “This time, a Modi government.” Now, Donald Trump and some die-hard supporters are using that very slogan in a new TV ad, in Hindi no less, to try to win over voters of Indian descent.

headline: Maggie Hassan Is the Right Choice for New Hampshire
abstract: The popular Democratic governor, running for Senate, is a pragmatist who puts her state before party politics.
lead_paragraph: The Senate race in New Hampshire is the only one this year in which both incumbent and challenger are women (the first such race was in 1960, next door in Maine). Senator Kelly Ayotte, a Republican, is struggling to close a widening gap with Maggie Hassan, the state’s popular Democratic governor. The seat is a beachhead in the battle for the Senate, with Democrats, Republicans and special-interest groups pouring upward of $102 million into the race, or about $114 for each registered voter.

headline: The Problem With Elizabeth Warren
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The senator doesn’t understand the proper role of regulation.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Remember Tom Lehrer’s quip after Robert F. Kennedy moved to New York and won election to the United States Senate — that Massachusetts was special because it was “the only state with three senators”? Well, nowadays Massachusetts might be the only state with a senator in the Oval Office.

headline: ‘I’m the Dumbest Guy You Ever Met’: Gary Johnson Fades Away

lead_paragraph: At least one of my siblings, and some of my friends from high school, will be among the 50 million or so Americans waking up on Nov. 9 after giving their vote to a man who thinks very little of them, and even less of the country he wants to lead.

keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Sex Crimes', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)', 'Wrestling', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Football (College)']

lead_paragraph: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — As the fallout from the Jerry Sandusky pedophilia scandal at Penn State continues to play out in the prosecution of former university officials, state investigators have begun examining whether the school mishandled the case of a student wrestler who went on to become a Hollywood actor and director.

headline: How to Ride a Unicycle
abstract: Don’t stop pedaling. Use your arms to turn.
lead_paragraph: “You’re going to fall a lot,” says Scott Wilton, vice president of the International Unicycling Federation. “It takes a long time to learn, and it takes the willingness to fall down and get back up.” Make sure the unicycle is the right size for you. Next, get on: “Stand behind the unicycle, not to the side of it like you would a bicycle,” Wilton says. Put the saddle between your legs and, with the pedal for your dominant foot at the 9 o’clock position, step up onto the unicycle as if you were climbing stairs; as the unicycle moves underneath you, put the other foot on its pedal. Hold onto a wall or a fence for support. (Dismounting is easy, Wilton says: “Step off backward — do the exact same thing you did to get on the unicycle, but in reverse.”)

headline: Spirited Away
abstract: A cocktail can help tap into our more indecorous desires.
lead_paragraph: A couple of Halloweens ago, I decided to switch out my lazy, customary Frida Kahlo costume (thrown together in five minutes with an embroidered Mexican dress, a few dollar-store roses and an eyebrow pencil) and instead become Frida of the Damned, so I added stage blood and fangs to my usual get-up. I really tried to be scary.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on a Married Couple’s Bigger Bed
abstract: Sometimes distance in a marriage can be a good thing. Especially when your husband seems to be impersonating the Tasmanian devil in his sleep.
lead_paragraph: Jeff writes: My wife and I sleep on an old full-size bed and are in need of a new one. I would like to buy another full because I am afraid if we start allowing space between us now, we will begin an exponential pattern of ever-widening distance. But my wife wants a queen, citing my occasional sleepwalking/night terrors, which hardly happen anymore.

headline: Brazil’s Mythical ‘Super-Chicken’: What, Exactly, Is a Chester?
abstract: It is a dinner staple in Brazil at Christmastime, but few have seen a Chester alive. The mystery has allowed fanciful stories to swirl, to the delight of the company that sells the bird.
lead_paragraph: The urban legends abound. Do they really migrate all the way to Brazil each year from the North Pole? Do they really gorge on hormone-laced feed? Do they even have heads?

headline: My Biological Clock Can’t Tick Fast Enough
abstract: A woman with no maternal desire wrestles with the expectation that married couples should try to have children.
lead_paragraph: I wasn’t lying when I told my first husband I was leaving in large part because he was ready for a family, and I just wasn’t there yet.

headline: For Rent (as Long as You’re Slavic)
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Discrimination', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: In Moscow, housing discrimination has become a fact of life.
lead_paragraph: Last March, I had to move out of the apartment on Oktyabrskaya Street in Moscow where I lived for 10 years. In a big city with lots of available places, I did not expect it to be hard to find a new room, and I made my first pick shortly after going online. There was one thing that I more or less ignored: Like many of the listings, the description of the rental contained the phrase “Slavs only.”

headline: Still Hunting Jack
abstract: “The Big Book of Jack the Ripper” includes original stories by Jeffery Deaver, Lyndsay Faye, Anne Perry and others.
lead_paragraph: We know many chilling names by heart — Ted Bundy, Jeffrey Dahmer, Charles Manson — but will they be familiar a century from now? Jack the Ripper has managed only to grow in name recognition since he committed his crimes in the late 1880s. “It is reasonable to ask why this remains true after more than a century and a quarter,” Otto Penzler writes in his introduction to “The Big Book of Jack the Ripper.” Topping 800 pages, the book collects nonfiction and fiction about the killer, including original stories by Jeffery Deaver, Lyndsay Faye, Anne Perry and others. (Penzler, the editor of many crime and mystery anthologies, answers our By the Book questions this week.)

headline: An Ann Arbor Restaurant Serving ‘Food of Substance’

lead_paragraph: Home to a major university and the Zingerman’s Delicatessen empire, Ann Arbor isn’t exactly a dining wasteland. But until recently, it wasn’t the kind of town where you’d walk into a restaurant and find dill flowers in your cherry soup or fennel pollen in your semolina cookies.
