headline: Finally, at Port in the Caribbean. Now, How to Escape it?
abstract: Spending time, and not much money, away from a new cruise port, in and around Puerto Plata.
lead_paragraph: When I disembarked and took a look at Amber Cove, my initial thought was: “Oh, no.” We had just docked in the Dominican Republic after a full travel day at sea — a fairly smooth, tranquil journey (this was, thankfully, weeks before Hurricane Matthew struck the region) through the Caribbean on our ship, the Adonia. I was on the third day of a weeklong Fathom “impact” cruise, the goal of which is to engage the several hundred passengers in on-the-ground volunteer activities in and around the Dominican town of Puerto Plata, on the northern coast of the country.

headline: A Few Words, and Lots of Love
abstract: Tosin Akinnagbe was at his wit’s end with online dating until he came across Geneviève DeBose’s profile on OkCupid. The couple were married on Oct. 9 at the International House in Upper Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Tosin Akinnagbe was at his wit’s end with online dating until he came across Geneviève DeBose’s profile on OkCupid. The couple were married on Oct. 9 at the International House in Upper Manhattan.

headline: Geneviève DeBose and Tosin Akinnagbe: He’s No Shakespeare. Romeo? Maybe.
abstract: He was a bit too brief in his OkCupid overture, but love wins with song.
lead_paragraph: If Geneviève DeBose were something other than a seventh- and eighth-grade English teacher, she might have been less dismissive of the all-too-brief message she received from Tosin Akinnagbe via OkCupid in September 2015.

headline: Creep or Craftsman? Alfred Hitchcock Was Both
abstract: Peter Ackroyd’s life of Alfred Hitchcock reveals the vulnerabilities beneath the calculating exterior.
lead_paragraph: These are good times for Alfred Hitchcock. The refurbishment of the director’s reputation, which began in 1966 when François Truffaut published his landmark book of interviews, “Hitchcock/Truffaut,” reached its conclusion in 2012 when the film critics polled by Sight and Sound voted “Vertigo” the greatest film of all time, kicking Orson Welles’s “Citizen Kane” from a top spot it had enjoyed for decades. Wellesians bit their knuckles, and the rest of us scratched our heads. “Vertigo” is not Hitchcock’s best, but rather, with its lush morbidity, somnolent pace, poor box office and relative scarcity of jokes, the Hitchcock film for those who most wish he were French. Flops make film critics feel useful — they are the film-crit equivalent of the deserving poor. What else can you do with a gleaming hit maker except overpraise his misses?

headline: Our Precious Urban Lives
abstract: Many Sydney neighborhoods, once diverse melting pots, have become shiny, wealthy and inward-looking.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Down the hill from my house, there is an old building with a saw-toothed roof that once warehoused trams, back when the bay was heavy with industrial waste and working-class people could afford to buy a home this close to the city and harbor of Sydney.

abstract: Some customers call for people to stop drinking the brand after its owner says he backs the Republican presidential nominee.
lead_paragraph: Throughout much of Pennsylvania, no one orders a Yuengling at the bar. People order a “lager,” and the server knows to bring a Yuengling Lager. There’s no need to specify.

headline: Austin McChord of Datto: It’s Not Awesome Till It’s Awesome
abstract: Austin McChord, C.E.O. of the data protection company Datto, says he resists the trend of automatically handing out praise and instead saves it for exceptional achievements.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Austin McChord, C.E.O. of Datto, a data protection company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Why Couldn’t I Give My Child My Last Name?
abstract: My grandfather’s family was all but wiped out in the Holocaust and I was the last person in my line to hold my family’s name.
lead_paragraph: As the mercury dipped below 30 degrees one night in my second trimester, my husband, Dave, and I ordered in Sichuan and started talking names. We wanted one that was classic, and to honor our families in some way. But we didn’t want to saddle our wee one with the Old World names that started appearing just a few branches up each of our family trees. Little Moshe, Yehuda and Golda had as much chance as did a Moon Unit, Apple or North.

headline: Ads That Use Candidates’ Own Words, to Powerful Effect
abstract: It’s been an unusual presidential campaign season in many ways, and some of the ads are also a departure from established norms.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s campaign released an ad in late September called “Mirrors.” The ad shows young girls looking carefully at themselves in a mirror or on their mobile phones. A piano tune accompanies the images. Then a surprising thing happens. Donald J. Trump, in his own voice, says, “I’d look her right in that fat, ugly face of hers. … She’s a slob, she ate like a pig. … A person who is flat-chested is very hard to be a 10. … Did she have a good body? No.”

headline: A Museum for Street Art

headline: Seeing What the Wildfires Took, and What They Left Behind
abstract: Once the fire in Fort McMurray died, we came back to find neighborhoods reduced to ashes but our house untouched. How do we live now?
lead_paragraph: FORT McMURRAY, ALBERTA — Fort McMurray is a community of people from elsewhere. More than 150 nationalities are represented here, along with every province in Canada, and more than 80 languages are spoken. The two traditional questions are — “Where are you from?” and “How long have you been here?”

headline: The Plot Against America or the Plot by America?
abstract: From Turkey to Trump Tower, demagogues love conspiracy theories.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — I recently traveled to Park City, Utah, as a guest of the Cato Institute, for a talk on Islam and liberalism. In the airport, as I waited for a flight back to Istanbul, where I live, I picked up a copy of The New York Times and read an article about the accusations raised by the Republican presidential candidate, Donald J. Trump, against his Democratic rival. “Hillary Clinton meets in secret with international banks,” the article quoted Mr. Trump saying, “to plot the destruction of U.S. sovereignty in order to enrich these global financial powers.”

headline: 3 TVs and No Food: Growing Up Poor in America

headline: How to Pick a Group Trip
abstract: If you are planning a group trip, consider the schedule (lots of activities or plenty of free time) and whether you want to travel with others your age.
lead_paragraph: Going on a group trip for your next vacation is a way to meet like-minded travelers and get more from your money, according to Heidi Podjavorsek, the vice president for sales and marketing at the Signature Travel Network and a specialist in group vacations. “Since the others on your trip are interested in the itinerary, you’re with people who share a common interest,” she said, “and the cost of the trip usually covers some meals, tours of popular attractions and other inclusions, which add up to a big money savings.”

keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']

headline: U.S. Economy Grew 2.9% in 3rd Quarter, Picking Up the Pace
abstract: This report and the monthly unemployment figures next week are the last snapshots of the overall economy before voters go to the polls on Nov. 8.
lead_paragraph: The American economy moved into a higher gear last quarter, expanding at an annual rate of 2.9 percent and riding continued strength among consumers and a better performance in global trade.

headline: Once Devoted to Suicide Bombing, She Now Embraces a Peaceful Jihad
abstract: At 25, Shifa al-Qudsi wanted to kill Israelis. She failed at that, ending up in jail instead. Now, she says, “I want to stop the bloodshed.”
lead_paragraph: TULKARM, West Bank

headline: Conan O’Brien Thinks Alien Life Exists. And That It Will Disappoint.
abstract: His latest gig is as an executive producer of “People of Earth,” about a reporter who checks out a support group for alien abductees, on TBS.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a quarter-century into his career as a late-night host, Conan O’Brien isn’t about to set his cruise control and coast. “In some ways, I’m much more active than I was 10 years ago,” the 53-year-old Mr. O’Brien said. “I’m very fortunate that I can still be discovering things and feeling like a kid again.”

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Richard Serra
abstract: The artist shares the titles he’d most want with him on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the artist Richard Serra. He shares his list exclusively with T.

headline: Syrian Rebels Launch Offensive to Break Siege of Aleppo
abstract: A coalition of insurgent groups said it had begun a major effort to break the monthslong siege of eastern parts of the city, and at least 15 people were reportedly killed.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A coalition of Syrian insurgent groups said it had begun a major offensive on Friday to break the monthslong siege of eastern parts of Aleppo by government and Russian forces, and at least 15 people were reportedly killed in fighting in government-controlled parts of the city.

headline: Can the G.O.P. Survive a Trump Loss?
abstract: We start by exploring the state of the Republican establishment. We end by examining the rebels trying to tear it down.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the dilemma for the Republican Party: Tens of millions of its voters support a candidate, Donald J. Trump, who rejects the organization’s values, reviles its policies and wants to kick its leaders out of power.

headline: A Conveyor Belt of Dropouts and Debt at For-Profit Colleges
abstract: How Congress and the Department of Education can fix an increasingly important system in which graduation rates are low and default rates are high.
lead_paragraph: As college attendance has risen and investment in public institutions has flagged, the United States has relied increasingly on for-profit colleges, with disastrous consequences for many students.

headline: The Story Behind This Week’s Best Sellers
abstract: The YouTube star Hannah Hart’s memoir, “Buffering,” enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No.4. It’s a sunny reckoning with some dark subjects.
lead_paragraph: Cheers: When Hannah Hart was a senior at Berkeley, in 2009, she wrote her literature thesis about memory and autobiography. “I’m really a big fan of nonfiction,” she said in a recent phone call from Los Angeles, where she lives. “I’ve always been really interested in it from an intellectual perspective as a genre. But then as a consumer, and as a person, I’ve always gotten so much from someone sharing their story.”

headline: The Man Behind ‘A Man Called Ove,’ Sweden’s Latest Hit Novel
abstract: Fredrik Backman’s book is among his country’s most popular literary exports since “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo.” Here, he talks about rejection.
lead_paragraph: Fredrik Backman got tepid responses when he sent out the manuscript for his debut novel, “A Man Called Ove.” Most publishers ignored him, and several turned it down.

headline: ISIS Kills More Than 200 as Battle for Mosul Intensifies
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Terrorism', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']

lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Islamic State fighters have killed scores of people and are using tens of thousands more as human shields as government and Kurdish forces battle to reclaim Mosul, United Nations human rights investigators reported on Friday.

headline: 1966: China Reports Perfect Test Of a Guided A-Missile
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The Communist government announces that it possesses nuclear weapons in October 1966, during the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese Communists announced today that they had test-fired a guided missile fitted with a nuclear warhead which exploded on target. China thus became a full-fledged member of the nuclear weapons club. The official New China News Agency declared that the test had taken place today “over China’s own territory” in a brief announcement claiming for the first time that China possessed “nuclear weapons.” Announcements of the previous three tests had referred only to “nuclear explosions.”

headline: Married to Their Smartphones (Oh, and to Each Other, Too)
abstract: Some couples are finding that an addiction to technology is putting a strain on their marriages.
lead_paragraph: Sherry Zheng was cleaning up from dinner, ready to toss out the remaining fried rice, when she grabbed her phone from the counter to text her husband, Chris. He was upstairs bathing their three children. “Should I save you the leftovers?”

headline: No One Is Looking at This Headline
abstract: You’re looking at Phil Heath, the six-time Mr. Olympia, who eats a lot of tilapia and works out in a strip-mall gym.
lead_paragraph: WHEAT RIDGE, Colo. — It was a few minutes before midnight when Mr. Olympia, the top bodybuilder in the world, finished his workout at a nondescript gym in a tired strip mall. He lifted one of his 22-inch biceps and flipped the light switch, tapped the alarm panel and turned the key to lock the glass front door.

headline: Kirk’s Retort About Duckworth’s Race at Senate Debate Draws Criticism
abstract: A day after the debate, the senator apologized for saying, “I had forgotten that your parents came all the way from Thailand to serve George Washington.”
lead_paragraph: An embattled first-term United States senator, Mark S. Kirk of Illinois, faced sharp criticism after seeming to mock his Democratic challenger’s ethnicity and her family’s history of military service at a debate on Thursday night.

abstract: It’s getting cold at last. Why not slow-cook a picnic ham?
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Once a year, Vogue and the Council of Fashion Designers of America pack up the young designers they’ve anointed the best and brightest, a few choice staff members and some friends, and ship the whole lot westward to Los Angeles.

headline: Florida Voters With the Longest Memories Don’t Like What They See
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Elderly']
abstract: Older residents of the swing state, with the nation’s highest percentage of voters 65 and over, can only shake their heads about the bad manners on display in the 2016 race.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — Sixteen. That’s the number of times that Ellen Chrouch, a bird-loving Republican at the Shell Point Retirement Community here, has cast a vote for president, starting with Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1956 and, this year, a reluctant ballot for Donald J. Trump. During that time, America’s political landscape has been turned inside out and upside down, and to hear many older voters tell it, is now marked only by low roads.

headline: Rachel Maclean’s Troubling Candy-Colored World
abstract: Several exhibitions feature her works that skewer sociopolitical tendencies.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Rachel Maclean makes for a dashing David Cameron. Dressed in a colonial pith helmet, ecclesiastical collar, camouflage-patterned kilt and prosthetic lion’s muzzle, the Scottish artist delivers one of the former prime minister’s more impassioned speeches as part of her 2014 video work “A Whole New World.” Behind her, the Union Flag flutters against an industrial wasteland bathed in preposterously tangerine CGI twilight.

headline: Oysters, Cloaked in Potatoes and Cream
abstract: This savory oyster pie brings the bivalves together with crème fraîche, leeks and bacon, under a mashed potato lid.
lead_paragraph: In Britain, not all savory pies are alike. Some are wrapped in pastry while others are topped with “mash,” the affectionate nickname for mashed potatoes. There is cottage pie (mash-covered minced beef stew) and shepherd’s pie (the same thing, but with lamb). And there is fish pie, the inspiration for the rich, satisfying oyster pie here.

headline: No More Data From Pluto
abstract: NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft made more than 400 scientific observations of the dwarf planet. Now scientists can analyze them all.
lead_paragraph: Most of the scientific investigations of Pluto by NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft took place over the course of a single day, when it zipped within 8,000 miles of the dwarf planet in July of last year.

lead_paragraph: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines, who told President Obama in October he “can go to hell” and has unleashed epithets at the pope, said on Thursday that the voice of God told him to stop cursing.

headline: N.F.L. Schedule: Here’s Who We Think Will Win in Week 8
abstract: The Patriots look to avenge their only loss, to Buffalo, and two exciting rookie quarterbacks clash in a game with N.F.C. East implications. Here’s what to expect.
lead_paragraph: Tom Brady will try to prevent the Buffalo Bills from securing a season sweep over the New England Patriots. Later Sunday, Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers and the Atlanta Falcons’ Matt Ryan will face off in what could be an epic shootout. But those veterans are merely a warm-up for the prime-time clash of two exciting rookie quarterbacks in a game with N.F.C. East implications:

headline: Five Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now
abstract: A by-no-means exhaustive list of items we like.
lead_paragraph: The architect and designer Emilio Terry could have been a household name — he counted socialites and royalty among his clients, and Salvador Dalí and Jean-Michel Frank among his friends — if he hadn’t resisted publicity, preferring to fly under the radar. A new exhibition, “In Search of Emilio Terry,” fills in some of the blanks, combining his own work with pieces from his collection created by his influences and collaborators. The show is helped along with a big assist by T’s beloved contributing editor Konstantin Kakanias, who created a series of new paintings starring Mrs. Tependris, the fictional society doyenne he has been drawing for the last 20 years. On view through Nov. 12 at Eerdmans Fine Art, 14 E. 10th St., eerdmansfineart.com. — ALEXANDRIA SYMONDS

headline: Regional Japanese Fare Comes to America
abstract: A crop of new restaurants goes beyond sushi, bringing hyperlocal specialties stateside.
lead_paragraph: In the States, we’ve tended to think of Japanese food as a single cuisine that includes raw fish, teriyaki, tempura and ramen. In Japan, as elsewhere, there are hyperlocal specialties: fried chicken in Nagoya, grilled oysters from Miyajima, tangerines and green tea in Shizuoka. Now, a crop of new restaurants is finally introducing some of this regional nuance to American diners. Ichiran, which opened last month in Brooklyn, has only one thing on the menu: tonkotsu ramen served Fukuoka-style, with straight, thin noodles and a rich pork-bone broth. TsuruTonTan in Manhattan specializes in udon from the Kansai region, served hot in a fish-based dashi or twisted over a bed of ice with a soy dipping sauce. Over in L.A., Shibumi offers kappo, a tradition in which the chef presents seasonal small plates — like Nagano-inspired fresh soba noodles in November — to diners at the counter.

headline: Keeping Your Affordable Care Act Plan Affordable
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Many with health insurance through government marketplaces are eligible for financial help that can significantly lower those premiums.
lead_paragraph: INSURER defections and double-digit premium increases may be making consumers wary of seeking health insurance through Affordable Care Act marketplaces. But despite the turmoil, health care advocates are still urging people to shop for 2017 coverage when the annual open enrollment period begins on Tuesday.

headline: Review: ‘The Pumpkin Pie Show,’ Night of the Voting Dead
abstract: Clay McLeod Chapman uses the bloody tools of horror to satirize this political season.
lead_paragraph: There is no shortage of comedians weighing in on the current election, but it often seems like the tools of satire are insufficient to comment on this absurd and exhausting campaign. Perhaps we need to look to a darker corner of the culture, where the punch lines end with bruises.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Half an hour? Six hours? Margaret Lyons has recommendations on what to watch.

headline: Blasting Out of a Trump Trap
abstract: The de Blasio administration has explored the possibility of getting out of its contracts with the Trump Organization at Ferry Point, Wollman Rink and other sites.
lead_paragraph: For anyone who predicted at the infancy of Donald J. Trump’s presidential bid — so many mean, vengeful, condemning, deranged remarks ago — that the unhinged nature his candidacy revealed would surely serve his business interests poorly, the past few weeks have delivered gratifying confirmation. Residents of a row of Trump buildings on Riverside Boulevard on the Upper West Side are rallying to have the Republican nominee’s name expunged from the facades. Simultaneously, protests have mounted against the United States Golf Association’s plan to hold the United States Women’s Open next year  at a Trump course in New Jersey, where it was scheduled four years ago, on the theory that holding it there would be like celebrating Earth Day in a pesticide factory.

headline: Tension Between Police and Standing Rock Protesters Reaches Boiling Point
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Land Use Policies', 'Native Americans', 'Pipelines', 'Police']
abstract: The tension had been building for months, with Native Americans who had camped out saying that the Dakota Access pipeline threatens the region’s water supply.
lead_paragraph: CANNON BALL, N.D. — For months, tensions had mounted between protesters and law enforcement officials over the fate of an oil pipeline not far from the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation. Late this week, the strained relations boiled over as officers tried to force the protesters out of an area where they had been camping.

headline: Images of a Less Crowded New York
abstract: Philip Trager’s photographs of the city in the 1970s, published in a new book, show a sparer skyline and streets less traveled.
lead_paragraph: “If you ask me my favorite place, it was probably Times Square,” said the photographer Philip Trager, whose book “New York in the 1970s” was published last week.

abstract: Philip Trager, now 81, found a box of his old negatives of the city from a decade known as raucous. The photographs appear in a newly published book.

lead_paragraph: Wall Street is on track to reverse three consecutive years of profit declines, but bonuses and jobs continue to shrink as the industry adjusts to a postcrisis world, a new report shows.

headline: Coastal Jointweed Brings Fall Blooms to City’s Barrens
abstract: Autumn is the perfect time to seek out this hearty, elegant plant, a natural anomaly whose blooms bring a stark beauty to the city’s driest landscapes.
lead_paragraph: It is interesting how the driest, most barren landscapes are often graced by plants as elegant as coastal jointweed.

headline: Chinese Vessels Leave Disputed Fishing Grounds in South China Sea
abstract: China’s Coast Guard had chased Filipino fishermen from the grounds, but has abandoned them since a visit from the Philippine president, Rodrigo Duterte, to Beijing.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Chinese vessels have quietly abandoned the contested Scarborough Shoal, the Philippine government said Friday, apparently a concession by Beijing after a visit to China by President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines.

headline: Soylent Says It Will Remake Two of Its Meal Replacers After Customers Became Ill
abstract: The announcement is the latest in a string of setbacks by the company that wants powders to replace meals, but many customers remain faithful.
lead_paragraph: Soylent, the company that made beige meal replacement products a Silicon Valley favorite, said on Thursday that it would reformulate its line of protein bars and a powder mix, the latest in a string of updates the company has issued after customers reported gastrointestinal issues.

headline: Review: ‘To Pixar and Beyond’ Plumbs New Depth in Oft-Told Tale
abstract: Lawrence Levy tackles a long list of complex subjects that have been covered elsewhere but uses his personal story as vehicle to add a new dimension.
lead_paragraph: The most successful animated films have made their fortune not just from endless repeat viewing by children, but from simultaneously engaging an adult audience.

headline: In Line for Blessings and Sweets at Hindu Temple Canteen
abstract: The annual Diwali holiday attracts thousands to a temple in Queens, where people wait up to an hour to try dosas, tamarind rice and other savory and sweet snacks.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday afternoon at a Hindu temple in Queens, a crowd assembled there was spilling out onto Holly Avenue. It was two weeks before Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, and the din from inside sounded more like a busy train station than a serene temple.

headline: Why Israel Still Refuses to Choose
abstract: It’s easier to leave Palestinians in limbo waiting for a “peace process” that goes nowhere.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — There is agreement on very little in the fractious Holy Land, but on one issue there is near unanimity these days: A two-state resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is more distant than ever, so unimaginable that it appears little more than an illusion sustained by lazy thinking, interest in the status quo or plain exhaustion.

headline: What New York Hoaxes Have Rivaled the One on the Scary Clowns?
abstract: There have been a few, including ones about moon creatures and another about a bottomless subway ride.
lead_paragraph: Q. I worry more about the creepy clowns in the news lately than about the ghouls, goblins and mini-Trumps and mini-Clintons who will soon be knocking at my door. Now I’m told it’s all a big hoax. Have any New York hoaxes rivaled that of the clowns?

headline: Immigrant New York’s Birth Over 4 Centuries
abstract: In “City of Dreams: The 400-Year Epic History of Immigrant New York,” Tyler Anbinder reviews the city’s relationship with new arrivals and the tale of the demographic upheaval.
lead_paragraph: Within a few decades of founding New Amsterdam, the Dutch built a wall, first to keep out the Indians, then the British. But because the Dutch came to the New World to make money — rather than to proselytize or escape religious persecution — they let in just about everybody else.

headline: A Scaredy-Cat’s Investigation Into Why People Enjoy Fear
abstract: Each person’s threshold for experiences that provoke fear, like Halloween haunted houses, is made up of a unique recipe that blends nature and nurture.
lead_paragraph: Halloween is here again. That means your co-workers have planted surprise spiders around the office. You’ve been invited to a haunted hayride. Your neighbor’s yard has a full cemetery, rigged with motion detectors and pop-up zombies. Chicken-livered from the start, I have always dreaded this time of year. Haunted houses, ghost tours and horror film fests are not my thing, and why people love having the daylights scared out of them completely escapes me.

headline: Daily Report: When Your Company is Famous but Unprofitable
abstract: Few tech outfits have been in the center of international news like Twitter. But despite the attention, the company still isn’t profitable.

The candidates post their opinions there, sometimes in the middle of the night. Reporters go there. Voters go there. And what is said there is often more important than what is said at campaign rallies.
