headline: Go to Borussia Dortmund, Young Man. And Maybe Even Stay.
abstract: Ousmane Dembélé did his research and concluded what other coveted players had: Dortmund has become soccer’s premier destination for young talent.
lead_paragraph: DORTMUND, Germany — The choice in front of Ousmane Dembélé, a teenage French forward of almost limitless promise, was flattering and bewildering in equal measure. He had just turned 19, and he had only one season of senior-level soccer — with Rennes, a modest team in France’s top division — under his belt. Yet by last summer, he had become one of the most coveted players on the planet.

headline: New Condos and Rentals on East Houston Street
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Condominiums', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: In the last few years, a spate of rental and condominium projects have appeared up and down the once-ignored East Houston Street.
lead_paragraph: For decades, East Houston Street was more a place to cross — and quickly, to avoid speeding cars — than a destination. Residential developers, too, seemed to shun it, wary of its commercial character and odd-shaped scraps of lots.

headline: Facebook Can Tell You What to Expect in the Voting Booth
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Social Media', 'Elections', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The tool was created with data collected from election officials by the nonpartisan research group Center for Technology and Civic Life.
lead_paragraph: Facebook is using its enormous reach to get out the informed vote on Election Day.

headline: Exxon Concedes It May Need to Declare Lower Value for Oil in Ground
abstract: The company may have to concede that 3.6 billion barrels of oil-sand reserves and a billion barrels of other reserves are currently not profitable to produce.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Exxon Mobil, in a concession to market and regulatory pressures, said Friday that it might be forced to write down the value of some of its oil and gas assets in Canada and elsewhere if energy prices remain low through the end of the year.

headline: In ‘Lucky Penny,’ a Life in Bits and Pieces
abstract: David Deblinger’s one-man show is a patchwork of personal stories, his relationship with his father serving as a binding thread.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to pinpoint when exactly David Deblinger’s “Lucky Penny” was born, since he has been collecting the stories in his one-man show over many years, like loose change found on the sidewalk.

headline: Jérôme Bel: Naked and Alive, Then Clothed and Dead
abstract: Two pieces by Mr. Bel, one old and one new, illustrate how his choreography has shrunken from genuine provocation to lazy formulas.
lead_paragraph: Many years ago, Jérôme Bel had some genuinely provocative ideas. In the second and final week that the Crossing The Line festival has been focusing on this French choreographer, those ideas were the revelation in the New York premiere of his early work “Jérôme Bel,” even as the premiere of his new, festival-commissioned “MoMA Dance Company” exhibited how his recent art has shrunken into lazy formulas.

headline: Visiting Cold Spring, Where the Path to Ruins Goes Uphill
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Leaving the village’s Main Street behind, a highlands hike offers tumbling leaves, glimpses of the sparkling Hudson River below and the mysterious remnants of a wealthy estate.
lead_paragraph: A wooded footpath winding up to the mysterious ruins of a mansion is one of the more striking marvels of Cold Spring, N.Y., a Putnam County village just over an hour north of Grand Central Terminal by rail. From the station, it’s a short walk to Main Street, a picture postcard of 19th- and early 20th-century commercial facades with an alluring mix of antique shops, art galleries and restaurants.

headline: Baker Hughes Could Be a Good Fit for General Electric
abstract: G.E. has sold off $200 billion of financial assets since the financial crisis, but it is now prepared for an offensive.
lead_paragraph: General Electric says it is not planning to acquire the $23 billion oil-services company Baker Hughes, contrary to news reports. But shareholders should not be shocked by the idea that G.E. might take a look.

headline: That’s a Lot of Rabbits
abstract: A bunny fancier awaiting criminal trial rebuilds her large herd in a vacant lot next to a Brooklyn tire shop.
lead_paragraph: The rabbit lady of Gowanus opened the gate onto a lunar landscape of gray dirt and holes. Rabbits of every possible size and color hopped and groomed and basked in the sun.

headline: Long Before Twitter, Martin Luther Was a Media Pioneer
abstract: The 500th anniversary of Luther’s 95 theses is being celebrated at institutions across the country, showing how deftly he used the media of his day.
lead_paragraph: Americans may know the basics of how Martin Luther was said to have nailed his 95 theses to a church door in Wittenberg, Germany, in 1517, condemning the Roman Catholic Church’s sale of indulgences, but they probably don’t realize how Luther strategically used the media of his time: books, paintings, prints and music.

headline: How Dylan Thuras, a Founder of Atlas Obscura, Spends His Sundays
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The 34-year-old Brooklyn resident’s approach to Sundays is much like the idea behind his company: If you make yourself get out there, you’ll find stuff.
lead_paragraph: For someone who catalogs strange and unexplored corners of the globe, Dylan Thuras, a founder of Atlas Obscura and an author of “Atlas Obscura: An Explorer’s Guide to the World’s Hidden Wonders,” keeps it pretty local. Mr. Thuras, 34, lives in the Greenpoint neighborhood of Brooklyn with his wife, Michelle J. Enemark, 34, an animator, and their 22-month-old son, Phineas. The Atlas Obscura office is in the Pencil Factory, and Mr. Thuras’s apartment is just three blocks away, in a building that used to house employees of Astral Oil Works. One of their slogans, he said, was “Will not explode!”

headline: Opioid Addiction Study
abstract: Data show that patients with chronic pain show greater receptivity to post-treatment support and long-term recovery from addiction.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there’s much more where these came from.

headline: A Cure for Liberal Worries
abstract: An academic discusses a study that found “the highest incidence of insomnia and stomach ulcers” among inactive liberals.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Unrest in Kashmir Claims New Casualties: Schools
abstract: Over the past weeks, 24 schools have been set ablaze, dashing hopes for a return to normalcy in the region after months of protests and curfews.
lead_paragraph: HABBER, Kashmir — It happened again on Thursday night: Another village school was burned to the ground.

headline: Pork Stew Gets a Chile Kick
abstract: Coconut milk, garam masala and cayenne make for a luscious, fragrant pork stew.
lead_paragraph: Beef stews are homey. Lamb stews are fancy. But only rarely do I consider the pork stew.

headline: ISIS Using Human Shields in Mosul, U.N. Reports
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Islamic State fighters are using tens of thousands of people as human shields while government and Kurdish forces battle to reclaim Mosul, United Nations human rights investigators reported on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Islamic State fighters are using tens of thousands of people as human shields while government and Kurdish forces battle to reclaim Mosul, United Nations human rights investigators reported on Friday.

headline: New York Theater Artists’ Latest Muse: Donald Trump
abstract: Mr. Trump’s presidential run has inspired operas and violin concertos, and has breathed new life into a 1941 Bertolt Brecht play about a mobster’s rise.
lead_paragraph: The volunteers worked busily in a campaign office for Donald J. Trump in Manhattan decorated with Trump posters and other campaign materials. One worker was reading Mr. Trump’s book “The Art of the Deal.”

headline: Russia Loses Seat on U.N. Human Rights Council
abstract: A vote in the United Nations General Assembly was seen as signaling dismay over Russia’s conduct in the war in Syria, including the bombardment of Aleppo.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Russia narrowly lost its seat on the main United Nations body devoted to human rights on Friday, signaling international dismay over the military power’s conduct in Syria.

headline: Review: ‘The Fall’ Returns, but Will the Deadly Hunt Continue?
abstract: This serial-killer drama, starring Gillian Anderson and Jamie Dornan, comes back for Season 3 on Netflix. It was created for Irish and British television.
lead_paragraph: “The Fall,” Allan Cubitt’s somber, slow-brewing serial-killer drama for Irish and British television — and Netflix, where its third season goes up on Saturday — leads a kind of double existence. It’s a crime drama that’s also a treatise on violence against women and the sources of male rage, and there are frequently times when it works better as case study than as storytelling.

headline: Every Family Has a Witching Hour
abstract: Every parent knows that at certain times of day — the time between naps or after dinner — life gets a little more challenging.
lead_paragraph: Every parent knows that at certain times of day — the time between naps or after dinner — life gets a little more challenging.

headline: Letter to Congress From F.B.I. Director on Clinton Email Case
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: In the letter, the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said that new emails had surfaced in a case unrelated to the closed investigation into whether Hillary Clinton or her aides had mishandled classified information, and that the messages “appear to be pertinent to the investigation.”
lead_paragraph: In the letter, the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said that new emails had surfaced in a case unrelated to the closed investigation into whether Hillary Clinton or her aides had mishandled classified information, and that the messages “appear to be pertinent to the investigation.”

headline: Putin Ally Died in U.S. After Drunken Fall, Not Foul Play, Prosecutors Say
abstract: After months of speculation that Mikhail Y. Lesin had been killed, investigators said he died alone in his hotel room from injuries sustained after a bout of drinking.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The mysterious death here of a prominent Russian businessman and former government minister last year was an accident caused by a drunken fall inside his hotel room, the prosecutor’s office announced on Friday as investigators officially closed the case.

headline: What Was Your First Brush With a Gender Barrier?
abstract: The New York Times would like to hear from women about their experience with a gender barrier.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times would like to hear from women about their experience with a gender barrier.

headline: The Playlist: Shakira Takes Charge and Protest Rap Is Still Alive
abstract: Hear the new songs that caught our critics’ attention this week, from YG’s “One Time Comin’” to Kenny Chesney’s “Rich and Miserable.”
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter (coming soon!) here.

headline: Why Halloween at College Is So Frightening
abstract: Costume crackdowns at universities reveal an absence of moral guidance from administrators who should be mentoring students.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — We’re coming up on Halloween, the most frightening time of the year — for college administrators. The debate over what costumes are too offensive to be worn on campus prompts some outsize emotions. Yale last year lost valuable faculty members because of a letter one of them wrote questioning prohibitions on Halloween costumes. The ensuing dispute was a national embarrassment, and it set Yale back $50 million in new diversity initiatives.

headline: With Headgear Here, Girls’ Lacrosse Just Got Safer. Or Did It?
abstract: The recent availability of headgear certified by the sport’s governing body comes amid a debate over whether the equipment will actually make the game rougher.
lead_paragraph: Addressing growing concerns about head injuries, two companies this month became the first to sell lacrosse headgear that is built specifically for girls and that complies with new standards from the sport’s governing body. But the availability of the equipment has only made the touchy debate over whether girls should wear it even more stark.

headline: Talk of Violence if Donald Trump Is Defeated
abstract: Readers discuss interviews with Mr. Trump’s supporters about how they might react to a loss.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Camille Becerra Finds a Home via Instagram
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The chef found her apartment with help from her 76,600 followers.
lead_paragraph: In 17 years of renting in New York, Camille Becerra found all her apartments through friends or word of mouth. But last November, when the man from whom she was renting an apartment in Chinatown gave her just 30 days to leave, she turned to a much larger social network: the photo-sharing site Instagram.

headline: Reviewing Toaster Ovens, and Selling Them, Too
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The Times is dipping a toe into the waters of “affiliate links.” It hopes to make money off products it writes about. It needs to tread carefully.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times grabbed a few modest headlines earlier this week when it purchased a popular website called The Wirecutter that recommends a variety of consumer products to its customers. The Times paid an estimated $30 million, a relatively small sum for a media giant that takes in that much revenue every seven days.

headline: Diverse Looks in the Indian Capital
abstract: Bright colors and dark, wild-patterned and plain, traditional and modern: the men of New Delhi and environs have a sharp, distinctive style.
lead_paragraph: Bright colors and dark, wild-patterned and plain, traditional and modern: the men of New Delhi and environs have a sharp, distinctive style.

headline: Distinctly New Delhi
abstract: Bright colors and dark, wild-patterned and plain, traditional and modern: the men of New Delhi and environs have a sharp, distinctive style.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to find stylish men in New Delhi and its environs. Whether dressed in wild-patterned clothes or plain, traditional or modern, men from all walks of life in this city — as diverse as fashion designers and carnival workers — have achieved a distinctive blend of ease and fashion sense.

headline: Technology Invites a Deep Dive Into Art
abstract: Step inside a Dalí painting or travel through the Garden of Eden on the back of a fish. Museums are enhancing technology to break down boundaries in the imagination.
lead_paragraph: For many years, patrons were asked to turn off their cellphones when they entered a museum. Now, they’re encouraged to use them with technologies like augmented and virtual reality, touch-screen tables and customized audio tours. The goal is to enhance the visitor’s experience while keeping the artwork front and center. Here are some examples.

headline: Canada Today: New Challenges for Syrian Refugees
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Hockey, Ice', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Elderly', 'Nursing Homes', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Pleas from the relatives of Syrian refugees are testing the limits of Canadian sponsors. Jodi Kantor and Catrin Einhorn of The Times took a long-term look.
lead_paragraph: The struggles and dangers that refugees from Syria endure before reaching safe havens are now well known. For the second part of their insightful and often moving long-term look at Syrian refugees in Canada, Jodi Kantor and Catrin Einhorn were in Toronto, where they found an additional stress factor that newcomers faced after they arrived at their new homes.

headline: Mary Halvorson on Guitar: Unflinching and Full of Grace
abstract: The jazz musician leads an octet for her show at ShapeShifter Lab in Brooklyn and looks forward to a new album.
lead_paragraph: There’s no other sound in music precisely like Mary Halvorson’s guitar, which she plays with a flinty attack, a spidery finesse and a shiver of wobbly delay. At National Sawdust in Brooklyn last Saturday, that sound was an unmistakable force during a prime-time stretch of John Zorn’s bagatelles marathon, which featured 20 groupings of musicians over a 10-hour concert sprawl.

headline: Review: The Philharmonic’s Concertmaster Steps Into the Spotlight
abstract: The violinist Frank Huang stole the show as the soloist in Bruch’s Violin Concerto in the orchestra’s latest program.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic’s selection of Frank Huang as its concertmaster last year was a critical decision in Alan Gilbert’s tenure as music director. “I’ve made a lot of appointments,” Mr. Gilbert said at the time, “but this is obviously the most crucial.”

headline: Miller’s Wipeout Slider
abstract: Andrew Miller, the versatile and dominant reliever for the Indians, throws a slider that gives hitters fits. Here’s what makes it so tough to hit.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Miller, the versatile and dominant reliever for the Indians, throws a slider that gives hitters fits. Here’s what makes it so tough to hit.

headline: Supreme Court to Rule in Transgender Access Case
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: The question at issue involves a Virginia high school student and a federal directive that effectively expanded a Title IX definition of discrimination.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday entered the national debate over transgender rights, announcing that it would decide whether a transgender boy may use the boys’ bathroom in a Virginia high school.

headline: ‘Drugs Were Around Me Every Day’
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Methamphetamines', 'Native Americans', 'Rural Areas', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Nicholas Kristof’s annual win-a-trip winner reports on meth and inequality.
lead_paragraph: Cassidy McDonald is the 2016 win-a-trip winner. This month she traveled with Nicholas Kristof through Arkansas and Oklahoma to report on domestic poverty.

headline: Ballet and Folk Art Nights
abstract: Last week’s fall galas and parties included the American Ballet Theatre, Tefaf opening, Studio Museum in Harlem, Aperture Foundation and the American Folk Art Museum.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s fall galas and parties included the American Ballet Theatre, Tefaf opening, Studio Museum in Harlem, Aperture Foundation and the American Folk Art Museum.

headline: Ballet and Folk Art Nights
abstract: Last week’s fall galas and parties included the American Ballet Theater, Tefaf opening, Studio Museum in Harlem, Aperture Foundation and the American Folk Art Museum.
lead_paragraph: Like the colors of fall, the charity season neared its peak last week, with five or more galas vying for support on a single night. The American Ballet Theater held its fall gala on Oct. 20, with a premiere of Benjamin Millepied’s “Daphnis and Chloe” at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center. Tefaf New York, the American debut of the European art fair, held an opening-night preview at the Park Avenue Armory on Oct. 21, benefiting the Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering.

headline: Soccer Without Headers? New Research Shows It’s Worth Discussing
abstract: A study has found that a single session of heading the ball can significantly affect a player’s brain function and memory for 24 hours.
lead_paragraph: WEST NEWBURY, Mass. — Soccer without headers? My team has experienced it for the last two months, and we may not be ahead of the curve for long.

headline: In Rare New Jersey Swing District, House Race Becomes a Brawl
abstract: Representative Scott Garrett, a Republican, is facing a well-financed Democratic opponent, Josh Gottheimer, to serve the state’s Fifth Congressional District.
lead_paragraph: RIDGEWOOD, N.J. — With a barrage of negative ads and copious outside spending, the congressional race in a crescent of Norman Rockwell-style suburbs and tidy rural villages in northern New Jersey represents one of the region’s most bare-knuckle political fights.

headline: How Pepe the Frog and Nasty Woman Are Shaping the Election
abstract: Viral internet in-jokes have become a dog whistle and potent force in the 2016 presidential race, says Brad Kim of Know Your Meme.
lead_paragraph: Pepe the Frog, Nasty Woman, #NeverTrump.

headline: Why Dakota Is the New Keystone
keywords: ['Pipelines', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Water', 'Native Americans', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Land Use Policies', 'Environment']
abstract: The Standing Rock protest against a new oil pipeline is about safeguarding clean water and a safe climate for all.
lead_paragraph: MIDDLEBURY, Vt. — The Native Americans who have spent the last months in peaceful protest against an oil pipeline along the banks of the Missouri are standing up for tribal rights. They’re also standing up for clean water, environmental justice and a working climate. And it’s time that everyone else joined in.

headline: Licensed to Eat Fire (Valid One Year Only)
abstract: In light of New York City’s requirement of licenses for fire eaters, Ilise S. Carter (stage name: the Lady Aye) explains why she is a sideshow performer.
lead_paragraph: If you wanted to run away with the circus, it would be as easy right now as it has ever been. But you would have to provide a lot of paperwork: photo ID, proof of professional insurance and an E29 fire performer’s license from the New York Fire Department.

headline: Review: What Would Sophocles Do? Pucker Up, Perhaps
abstract: Both plays in “Two Class Acts” by A.R. Gurney look at how Hellenic-studies students and instructors explore the effect of changing times on tradition.
lead_paragraph: A tickling breeze of possibilities ripples through “Two Class Acts,” short plays of modern love and ancient days in repertory at the Flea Theater. That spirit, with its enthusiastic sense of art’s potential to portray and effect transformations, is youthful in nature. And it feels appropriate that the performers in these productions would all seem to be on the sunny side of 30.

headline: Gerard Alessandrini: Man of Many Broadway Spoofs
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Theater', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The creator of the theatrical spoof “Spamilton” has a home in Ivoryton, Conn.
lead_paragraph: It was a four-hour commute from Needham, Mass., Gerard Alessandrini’s longtime home, to Manhattan, his frequent place of business. The trip was becoming burdensome for Mr. Alessandrini, 62, a one-time actor and singer who struck a chord — and gold — with his musical-theater spoof “Forbidden Broadway.”

headline: What I Love | Gerard Alessandrini
abstract: Gerard Alessandrini, the creator of the “Spamilton,” and his partner, Glenn Bassett, share a weekend getaway in Eastern Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Gerard Alessandrini, the creator of the “Spamilton,” and his partner, Glenn Bassett, share a weekend getaway in Eastern Connecticut.

headline: The F.B.I. and the Clinton Emails
abstract: A reader writes: “By releasing his letter 11 days before the election, the F.B.I. director is meddling in politics at Hooveresque levels.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: A Group of Young Dancers, Conversing With their Feet
abstract: Troy Schumacher’s troupe, BalletCollective, cultivated a spontaneous mood in “What’s Next,” a triple bill of his works.
lead_paragraph: The seven New York City Ballet dancers who performed in BalletCollective’s “What Comes Next” program looked fresh, unaffected, contemporary. They (five women, two men) walked onto the stage on their heels, their manner casual. After a step or a sequence, they let their arms swing and stood on flat feet. They were not improvising, but the mood was spontaneous.

headline: Museums, the New Social Media Darlings
abstract: Institutions are reaching out to younger and global audiences, using emoji-style art history and innovative Snapchats.
lead_paragraph: Talk about a mash-up. Perhaps the most ephemeral of social media channels, Snapchat, is being used to pair pop lyrics with images of centuries-old paintings or artifacts. The images last on a device for up to 10 seconds.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Hiroko Diaa Hadid, Hiroko Tabuchi and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Review: A Low-Key Debut for the New Jersey Symphony’s Director
abstract: Xian Zhang’s first concert as music director was a matinee on Thursday afternoon in Newark, conducting an all-Tchaikovsky program.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Xian Zhang’s debut as music director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra on Thursday afternoon was in some ways oddly understated.

headline: Barnes Foundation’s Director Aims ‘to Unpack the Ideas’ in the Art
abstract: Thomas Collins, the organization’s new leader, is pursuing its founder’s educational goals with a fresh focus on context, including the works’ social history.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The ghost of Dr. Albert C. Barnes, the visionary collector and undisputed eccentric who once replied “Nuts” to T. S. Eliot’s request for a visit to his renowned holdings, still hovers here at the Barnes Foundation, even in the new building by the architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, which opened in 2012.

headline: Dispute at ‘Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812’ Leads to a Lawsuit
abstract: The small nonprofit theater Ars Nova has accused the show’s lead commercial producer of violating an agreement over the show’s Playbill wording.
lead_paragraph: The nonprofit theater that commissioned “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812” says it has filed suit against the show’s commercial producer after unsuccessful attempts to settle an  ugly dispute that is casting a shadow over one of the Broadway season’s most promising musicals.

headline: 5 Vine Stars Share Why They Loved, and Outgrew, Platform
abstract: Vine was a place for people with talents across different disciplines — it allowed artists-slash-comedians-slash-musicians to flourish.
lead_paragraph: When Vine announced on Thursday that it would close down in the coming months, thousands of the video platform’s greatest hits were shared across the internet in six-second bursts.

headline: Art and Politics Meet in Boston, Sometimes All Night
abstract: “Political Intent,” a show at the Museum of Fine Arts, is part of an initiative using art, discussion and even 24-hour parties to bring political discourse into a rarefied world.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — This fall, “Political Intent,” a new exhibition at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, is conducting an experiment on how to talk politics with gallery visitors. The show, by eight female artists from four continents, is part of #mfaNOW, an initiative aimed at dissolving the starchy separations between museum and community, politics and art, contemporary work and older pieces. The goal is to push visitors’ experience beyond the rarefied gallery walls and encourage discourse on complex topics inside the museum and in the surrounding world.

headline: Craving a Hot TV Show in China? Start Scouring the Web
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'E-Commerce', 'Intellectual Property', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Television', 'Movies', 'Computer and Video Games']
abstract: The success of a web-only novel shows how China’s entertainment industry is mining the internet for promising intellectual properties.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — “The Journey of Flower” is a novel that has never been sold in bookstores. It was first published on a literature website in 2009, but its story, a martial arts fantasy, is now one of China’s most successful brands.

headline: ‘Icons of Modern Art’: Picassos, Matisses, Monets, Oh, My!
abstract: This exhibition in Paris assembles 127 works of French painting from the unrivaled art collection of the Russian magnate Sergei Shchukin.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The history of collecting, the development of painterly style, the changing fortunes of individuals and nations: You will think about all these things on your second go-through of “Icons of Modern Art: The Shchukin Collection,” which opened last week at the Fondation Louis Vuitton here.

headline: Review: ‘In the Room,’ About Lessons Learned at a Writing Workshop
abstract: Staged by the Slant Theater Project, Lawrence Dial’s drama tracks the connections among a motley collection of students and the plays they write.
lead_paragraph: All six of them are instantly hateable. The way they enter, slam their books and things on the table and angrily take their seats, in unison. Then Rainer (Suzy Jane Hunt) arrives, inconsiderately late, and she turns out to be married to a movie star.

headline: First Baby in Puerto Rico With Zika-Related Microcephaly Born
abstract: The mosquito-borne virus has swept the island, and many pregnant women have been infected.
lead_paragraph: The first child in Puerto Rico with Zika-related microcephaly has been born, the territory’s secretary of health announced Friday.

headline: Clinton, Trump, Halloween: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Founder Says Rolling Stone Erred in Retracting Rape Article
abstract: “We did everything reasonable, appropriate up to the highest standards of journalism to check on this thing,” the founder, Jann S. Wenner, testified.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — In a defiant defense of the magazine he founded and owns, Jann S. Wenner said Rolling Stone was wrong to fully retract a discredited 2014 article about allegations of a gang rape at the University of Virginia, asserting in videotaped testimony shown on Friday that much of the material in the article was correct.

headline: The Kind of Thinking Cities Need
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Environment', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Urban Areas', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: In an era of climate change, cities no longer look like the problem.
lead_paragraph: Quito, Ecuador — Day after day, under a bright sun, hourslong security lines snaked out of El Ejido Park into the surrounding streets. Enterprising women in multicolored skirts and brown hats sold water and folding umbrellas for shade. Inside, representatives at the German pavilion seduced passers-by with beer and apples to spread propaganda on the “circular economy,’’ while the incongruous sound of a mariachi band playing Frank Sinatra music wafted from Ecuador’s booth, nearly drowning out a speech by an architect from California describing her company’s projects to improve a slum in Kenya.

headline: John Zacherle, Host With a Ghoulish Perspective, Dies at 98
abstract: Mr. Zacherle was one of early television’s horror-movie hosts, playing an undertaker and other characters on stations in Philadelphia and New York in the 1950s and ’60s.
lead_paragraph: John Zacherle, one of the first of the late-night television horror-movie hosts, who played a crypt-dwelling undertaker with a booming graveyard laugh on stations in Philadelphia and New York in the late 1950s and early ’60s, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

headline: How Dairy Farmers in Belgium Held Up a Big E.U. Trade Deal
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Farmers in the Wallonia region threatened to derail, at least temporarily, a landmark international accord amid growing skepticism about globalization and free trade.
lead_paragraph: SIPPENAEKEN, Belgium — Christian Wiertz worked his usual 14 hours on Thursday, milking 85 cows at his family farm in this village in eastern Belgium, near the border with the Netherlands.

headline: François Hollande, His Ratings Poor, Speaks Candidly. The Hole Gets Deeper.
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A book based on a series of interviews with the French president, full of name-calling candor, has provoked horror in his own Socialist Party and glee in the opposition.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The living dead have long haunted French politics. Some resurrect themselves after near-death experiences in politics, while others continue to appear politically alive even when they have actually died.

headline: Medicaid Finds Opportune Time to Offer Birth Control: Right After Birth
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: In South Carolina, the program offers long-acting contraceptives during a new mother’s hospital stay, while she is still eligible for the benefit. Other states are following suit.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Last month, Akia Gayle gave birth to her third child. Sixteen hours later, while she was still in her hospital bed, a doctor implanted a matchstick-size plastic rod in her left arm because she did not want to have a fourth.

headline: Key Moments in the Downfall of Anthony Weiner
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail', 'Sexting']
abstract: The personal troubles of Mr. Weiner began to come into public view in 2011, and matters have gotten worse.
lead_paragraph: The revelation that the federal authorities had found a trove of emails related to their investigation into Hillary Clinton’s private email server appear to be the latest fallout from an unlikely source: Anthony D. Weiner, a Democrat who once represented New York in Congress and also ran for mayor.

headline: Venezuela Slowed by Strike in Campaign to Oust President Nicolás Maduro
abstract: The president’s ruling party and the opposition tried to spin the effectiveness of the 12-hour strike, which was weaker than Wednesday’s mobilization.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Much of Caracas and other cities slowed to a Sunday crawl on Friday as many Venezuelans heeded the opposition’s call for a general strike, a step in its campaign to force a referendum to remove President Nicolás Maduro.

headline: Bob Dylan Speaks, at Last, on His Nobel
abstract: Mr. Dylan told the British news organization The Telegraph that he would “absolutely” attend the Nobel ceremony “if it’s at all possible.”
lead_paragraph: We finally have an answer. Bob Dylan will, indeed, accept his Nobel Prize in Literature — probably.

headline: Plane Preparing to Take Off at O’Hare Catches Fire
abstract: About 20 people were taken to hospitals with minor injuries after the American Airlines jet caught fire.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — About 20 people were taken to hospitals with minor injuries Friday after an American Airlines jet preparing to take off for Miami caught fire on the runway at O’Hare International Airport, officials said.

headline: Flint, and Michigan, Brace for More Charges in Water Inquiry
keywords: ['Lead', 'Water', 'Water Pollution', 'Government Employees', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', "Legionnaires' Disease"]
abstract: There are growing signs that investigators are focusing on bigger targets and looking more intently on the deaths of 12 people from Legionnaires’ disease.
lead_paragraph: LANSING, Mich. — As Flint continues to suffer from a water crisis, one question percolates here in Michigan’s capital: Who will be charged next?

headline: World Series: Here’s How the Indians Won Game 3
abstract: Cleveland got great pitching from Josh Tomlin and Andrew Miller to shut out the Cubs and take a 2-1 Series lead.
lead_paragraph: Chicago Cubs fans waited 71 years for the World Series to return to Wrigley Field. But when it did on Friday night, the result was not what they were looking for.

headline: ‘This Changes Everything’: Donald Trump Exults as Hillary Clinton’s Team Scrambles
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail']
abstract: The F.B.I. director’s disclosure of an investigation of new emails interrupted Mrs. Clinton’s momentum as Mr. Trump and other Republicans sought to take advantage.
lead_paragraph: Everything was looking up for Hillary Clinton. She was riding high in the polls, even seeing an improvement on trustworthiness. She was sitting on $153 million in cash. At 12:37 p.m. Friday, her aides announced that she planned to campaign in Arizona, a state that a Democratic presidential candidate has carried only once since 1948.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, October 29, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “It is extraordinary that we would see something like this just 11 days out from a presidential election.”

headline: Emails Again, This Time With Anthony Weiner
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail', 'Editorials']
abstract: James Comey’s failure to provide specifics about a new, potentially important development, less than two weeks before Election Day, is confounding.
lead_paragraph: Every time Americans start thinking nothing more can surprise them in this presidential campaign, something detonates to prove them wrong. So it was that on Friday, 11 days from Election Day, the F.B.I. director, James Comey, sent a cryptic letter to Congress saying, “In connection with an unrelated case, the F.B.I. has learned of the existence of emails that appear pertinent” to its investigation of Hillary Clinton’s private email server.

headline: Knicks Need Time to Regroup (or Just to Group)
abstract: An opening-night rout at Cleveland showed that the team remains a work in progress, with new players not yet meshing and the triangle offense still a puzzlement.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks were disjointed and scattered on opening night in Cleveland, like a high-profile jam band not yet in tune. The 29-point loss to the Cavaliers on Tuesday provided evidence of their disconnection, in the form of myriad missed shots and impotent defense. It also left them hankering to play again — with nearly four days to digest their disappointment.

headline: Campaign to Bring Casino Gambling to North Jersey Appears Doomed
abstract: Even supporters of a referendum that would allow gambling halls to open outside Atlantic City concede that they are headed for defeat. The only question seems to be how large the margin will be.
lead_paragraph: For those looking for a good bet on election night results, the smart money in New Jersey says a referendum on whether to expand casino gambling in the state is headed for defeat.

headline: Telecoms’ Ambitions on Targeted Ads Seen Curbed by F.C.C.’s New Privacy Rules
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Privacy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: AT&T’s and Verizon’s hopes of collecting and analyzing customer data to sell advertising may be dashed if they have to ask customers’ permission.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, companies like Verizon and AT&T have made no secret of their ambitions to build online advertising businesses that can take on the behemoths of Silicon Valley.

headline: Twitter’s 4-Year Odyssey With the 6-Second Video App Vine
keywords: ['Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Mobile Applications', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Social Media']
abstract: Twitter built up Vine to leapfrog Instagram and cultivated star users. But as competition stiffened, and employees and users peeled off, Vine lost its hold.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Twitter bought Vine in 2012, it was a three-man company planning an app of six-second videos that had yet to even launch. Still, Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s co-founder who had pushed for the deal, thought he had found the next big thing in social media — an Instagram with video.

headline: For First Time in 17 Years, Women Will Compete in Top Big-Wave Surfing Contest
abstract: Organizers of the Titans of Mavericks, held off the northern coast of California, agreed to invite six women to compete for a $30,000 purse.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in the competition’s 17-year history, women will be allowed to compete at Mavericks, the nation’s premier big-wave surfing contest, held off the northern coast of California.

headline: Chicago Cubs’ Fortunes Have Changed, but Wrigley Field Remains a Site of Pilgrimage
abstract: Some Chicago taverns are charging hundreds of dollars for fans to watch the Cubs’ home games in the World Series.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — So much has changed since the Chicago Cubs last appeared in the World Series, but their home is the same as it was in 1945: Wrigley Field, at the corner of Clark and Addison, on the North Side of town.

headline: In Closing Words at Bridge Trial, Prosecution Returns to a Familiar Email
abstract: The email, sent by a former aide to Gov. Chris Christie before the lane closings in 2013, was magnified on a screen in the courtroom: “Time for some traffic problems in Fort Lee.”
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Three years after the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge and at the end of a six-week trial against two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey who are accused of orchestrating them, the prosecution closed its case here on Friday by returning to the stark directive that started the whole thing.

headline: F.B.I. Chief James Comey Is in Political Crossfire Again Over Emails
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail']
abstract: Mr. Comey faced a dilemma: Inform Congress of the new developments, and be accused of harming Hillary Clinton, or wait, and be accused of lacking transparency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director, faced a dilemma on Thursday when deputies briefed him about the discovery of a trove of emails that might be linked to the inquiry into Hillary Clinton’s private email server that was closed months ago.

headline: New Trend in Baseball: Custom Cleats for the Polished Player
abstract: Over the past few years, players have increasingly shown their personality by what they wear on their feet during games.
lead_paragraph: Javier Baez, the Chicago Cubs’ flashy second baseman, loves sneakers so much, and has such an extensive collection, that he had them converted into cleats to use on the baseball diamond. Indians shortstop Francisco Lindor has worn jazzed-up, red-and-blue cleats throughout the playoffs that feature the Cleveland skyline and the word Believeland written in gold across a side.

headline: Endorsements in New York and New Jersey
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Endorsements', 'Editorials']
abstract: There are a number of congressional and state races where voters can make a difference.
lead_paragraph: This election’s most dire priority is averting a national and planetary calamity (two words: President Trump). But Nov. 8 is also about good government at all levels. Here are some congressional and state races in New York  and New Jersey where voters can make a difference.

headline: The Ultimate Protest Vote
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Third-Party Politics (US)', 'Socialism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: What it means to support the Socialist Workers Party.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 8 I will be going to the polls and voting, without hesitation or disinclination, for Hillary Clinton. But what a treacherous and unforgivable act this will be for my father, who will no doubt be supporting the only presidential candidate he believes has any chance of saving the United States from almost certain ruin: Alyson Kennedy.

headline: Bready Bunch
abstract: It’s a Berry nice Saturday puzzle by Patrick Berry.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — A tough one by Patrick Berry today, and the cluing is ramped up to what one would expect in a Saturday crossword. This one was a three-separate-tries puzzle for me, but I finally cracked it.

headline: The Pleasure and Pain of the Climbing Life
abstract: The mountains bring me joy, but they scare me, too.
lead_paragraph: As a runt kid in a college town in Pennsylvania, I dreamed of grand adventures. Hidden treasures, human flight and sports, of course. I was going to be a football star. But in 10th grade, I weighed 85 pounds. The coaches refused to issue me equipment, breaking my heart but surely saving my life. Weight-class sports suited me better. I started boxing. My ethos was: train hard, never quit. It was enough to carry me to a collegiate national boxing title in 1990 (by then at 132 pounds). Then I moved to Montana for graduate school.

headline: Arrests and Violence at Pipeline Protest
abstract: Demonstrators at the Dakota Access pipeline were shot at with beanbag bag rounds, hit with pepper spray and taken into custody by the police.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators at the Dakota Access pipeline were shot at with beanbag bag rounds, hit with pepper spray and taken into custody by the police.

headline: Style, Not Age
abstract: Not all women listen to the advice to “dress your age” — i.e., prim and dull.
lead_paragraph: Not all women listen to the advice to “dress your age” — i.e., prim and dull.

headline: Echo of Jeremy Lin’s Glory Days as Nets Win Home Opener
abstract: The Nets, unsung and inexperienced, engineered a 103-94 victory over the Indiana Pacers, and Lin finished with 21 points, 9 rebounds and 9 assists.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Lin’s work for the Nets began about five minutes before the tip. He grabbed a microphone and thanked the fans at Barclays Center for coming to the Nets’ home opener on Friday against the Indiana Pacers. The crowd cheered. The building was brimming with hope.

headline: Sophia Cranshaw, MTV Producer of Social-Issue Campaigns, Dies at 45
abstract: Ms. Cranshaw won awards for public service announcements and campaigns that dealt with everything from genocide in Darfur to depression on campus.
lead_paragraph: Sophia Cranshaw, an MTV producer, director and writer who was honored for her campaigns against genocide, the stigma of mental illness and other sweeping social crises, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 45.

headline: Susan Lindquist, Scientist Who Made Genetic Discoveries Using Yeast, Dies at 67
abstract: The conceptually daring work of Dr. Lindquist, a National Medal of Science recipient, opened new paths to understanding Parkinson’s and other diseases.
lead_paragraph: Susan Lindquist, a molecular biologist whose conceptually daring work with yeast proteins opened new avenues to understanding gene functioning and degenerative diseases like Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s, died on Thursday in Boston. She was 67.

headline: Mexico’s Formula One Evokes Go-Karts at Slippery Speeds
abstract: Drivers look forward to the second race at the redesigned course, where high altitude poses special challenges.
lead_paragraph: Slippery and like a go-kart track. That might be the best way to describe driving conditions on the newly renovated Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez track, when the Mexican Grand Prix returned there last year after a 23-year absence.

headline: The 1970 Mexican Grand Prix Was One of Passion and Chaos
abstract: The fans were so fired up that two star drivers spoke to them to restore order. That didn’t prevent an invasion of the track at the finish.
lead_paragraph: “Most people would rather forget Mexico 1970” were the last words of the contemporary race report in Motor Sport magazine, summing up the feeling after that running of the Mexican Grand Prix.

headline: A Young Driver’s Defensive Tactics Divide Rivals
abstract: The Dutchman Max Verstappen of the Red Bull team makes last-second moves that earn scorn and praise from other drivers.
lead_paragraph: There is no purer moment in auto racing than the instant when a car pulls out from inches behind a competitor and powers past, gaining a position.

headline: Why Some Drivers Are Hired, Despite Their Records
abstract: Teams turn to data, not just wins and losses, to determine the best fit. ‘You can analyze everything. And you can’t fool the data.’
lead_paragraph: As Formula One prepares for the Mexican Grand Prix this weekend, only three races remain in the 2016 season and most teams have decided who will drive for them next year.

headline: Grand Prix Royalty, Looking to Rebound
abstract: The Williams race team has won one event in 11 years, but refuses to be counted out — even if no one’s making any promises.
lead_paragraph: The Williams Grand Prix team may not have scored a Formula One title since 1997, but it is still the series’ third most successful outfit and remains one of the famous names at the pinnacle of auto racing.

headline: For Race Fans in Mexico, Native Sons on Overlapping Paths
abstract: A homecoming for Sergio Pérez and Esteban Gutiérrez, who have followed similar journeys from go-karts to the Mexican Grand Prix.
lead_paragraph: Not since the brothers Pedro and Ricardo Rodríguez raced in Formula One in the 1960s have two Mexicans whipped up as much passion for the series as have Sergio Pérez and Esteban Gutiérrez.

headline: Corrections: October 29, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, October 29, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Richard Pittman, Marine Who Fended Off Vietnam Ambush, Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Pittman earned the Medal of Honor for charging into heavy North Vietnamese fire to aid wounded fellow Marines.
lead_paragraph: Richard A. Pittman, a Marine who earned the Medal of Honor for charging into a North Vietnamese ambush under heavy fire and fending off dozens of enemy troops in 1966, died on Oct. 13 in Stockton, Calif. He was 71.

headline: Miming Photo in End Zone? Negative, the N.F.L. Says
abstract: The N.F.L. fined Giants defensive end Owa Odighizuwa $12,154 for an unsportsmanlike-conduct penalty issued after he pretended to take a picture in the end zone after a touchdown.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. fined Giants defensive end Owa Odighizuwa $12,154 for an unsportsmanlike-conduct penalty issued after he pretended to take a picture in the end zone of safety Landon Collins, who returned an interception for a touchdown against Los Angeles in London last Sunday.

headline: Indians’ Pitchers Roar to Life, and the Cubs’ Bats Fall Silent
abstract: The one thing that could betray the Cubs in their quest to end a 108-year championship drought is their hitting.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When the Cleveland Indians arrived in town, they were viewed as a prop. The city was buzzing on Friday, bars in Wrigleyville were hopping before lunch and ticket prices for the Chicago Cubs’ first World Series home game in 71 years were approaching the cost of a college tuition payment.

headline: Andrew Miller Is Called Upon for the Fifth Inning. Rollie Fingers Can Relate.
abstract: Fingers, a reliever who earned 341 saves over 17 seasons, set the precedent for the strategy used by Indians Manager Terry Francona in Game 3.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As he watched Game 3 of the World Series on Friday from his home in Las Vegas, Rollie Fingers thought back to some of the moments that defined his Hall of Fame career. At a raucous Wrigley Field, the Cleveland Indians were calling for their best reliever, Andrew Miller, with a runner on second in a scoreless game against the Cubs — in the fifth inning. Fingers could relate.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Fall’ and ‘Pride and Prejudice and Zombies’
abstract: “The Fall,” a British serial-killer drama, steps off into its final season. And “Pride and Prejudice and Zombies” bloodies up Jane Austen’s classic.
lead_paragraph: Who’s dead? No one but the victims, or so it seems, as “The Fall” returns. “Pride and Prejudice and Zombies” bloodies up Jane Austen’s classic as Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy battle the undead. And “48 Hours” examines a case cracked by a butt dial.

headline: Police Shoot Armed Man at Queens Housing Complex
abstract: The authorities said that two officers fired after a man ignored orders to drop his gun, wounding the suspect in the leg.
lead_paragraph: Police officers patrolling a public housing complex in Queens shot an armed man in the leg on Friday night after he failed to obey their orders to drop his gun, the police said.

headline: ‘Trump’s Going to Bake an Inauguration Cake Out of This’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers discuss Anthony Weiner’s involvement in the Hillary Clinton email inquiry, the Bundys’ acquittal and the grieving process.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: For AT&T Chief, Time Warner Deal Is the Peak of an Ambitious Climb
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Randall Stephenson has a history of staking out risky business propositions, including speaking up on divisive subjects and aggressively going after acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: Randall L. Stephenson, the chief executive of AT&T, could easily be pigeonholed as just another empire-building executive with a white-bread résumé. He is a 56-year-old Republican from Oklahoma atop a 140-year-old company, whose extracurricular highlights include serving as president of the Boy Scouts of America and shaping professional golf as a policy board member for the PGA Tour.

headline: No Kegs, No Liquor: College Crackdown Targets Drinking and Sexual Assault
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Sex Crimes', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'Parties (Social)', 'Football (College)']
abstract: Dozens of universities have introduced stricter rules on alcohol, especially at fraternities. We sent reporters to five campuses to examine the new measures.
lead_paragraph: The backyard fraternity party was in full dancing, drinking mode on a recent Saturday morning. To the sounds of “No Problem” by Chance the Rapper, Breanna DeCocker, 20, a junior at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, Mich., ducked through the crowd holding a clipboard.

headline: Judging Others by Their Email Tics
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'Language and Languages', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Emojis and Emoticons']
abstract: Signoffs, the well-placed emoji, the use of exclamation points (or not). It’s a minefield out there.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it was the lack of sleep, but I recently found myself having a full-fledged meltdown, prompted by an email signature. Specifically, my own email signature (or lack of one): that little one-line signoff that comes at the end of your iPhone message, telling the person on the other end that you’ve sent the message from your mobile device.

headline: After Scandal, and With Staff Intact, Baylor Remains a Big 12 Power
abstract: The Bears are facing new revelations from a sexual assault scandal, but at 6-1 they continue to nurture big aspirations on the field.
lead_paragraph: WACO, Tex. — When Baylor University released a damning summary in May of an investigation into sexual assault accusations and convictions involving football players, the consequences were swift. The university’s president, Kenneth W. Starr, was demoted. The athletic director, Ian McCaw, resigned. The football coach, Art Briles, was effectively fired.

headline: Rachel Maddow and Doris Kearns Goodwin on a Presidential Race for the History Books
abstract: The two women discuss the temperamental forebears of Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump, the ambitions of candidates and their skills for the job.
lead_paragraph: History offers strange consolation: No matter how alarming current events (or a presidential election) may be, historians can usually point to analogous episodes we survived in the past.

headline: Fast Times on the Campaign Trail in ‘Embeds’
keywords: ['Television', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The show will take a comic look at young political reporters against the backdrop of covering a presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: This month, a group of 20-somethings assembled in Des Moines to sustain themselves on gas station pizza; cover the Faith, Freedom, Family and Fudge Pops Forum; chase a long-shot presidential candidate who irons his own bluejeans; and huddle at a rotating cast of hotel bars each night.

headline: The Breakaway Bride
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Dresses', 'Youth']
abstract: Millennial brides, with their free-spirited tastes, are rewriting the style rules to suit themselves. The industry is taking note.
lead_paragraph: When Susannah Cahalan, the author of the popular memoir “Brain on Fire,” shopped for a wedding dress late last year, she ventured well off the beaten path, stopping in at Stone Fox Bride for a cropped top and flowing skirt. Her chief consideration, she said, “was that I be able to wear my dress more than one time.”

headline: In Myanmar, Military Action Forces Some to Flee: ‘We Just Had to Run Away to Save Our Lives’
abstract: Ko Thu Ya, a member of the Rohingya minority, felt forced to leave his home with his family amid a military lockdown in the western part of the country.
lead_paragraph: The owner of a small grocery store in western Myanmar, Ko Thu Ya fled his home nearly three weeks ago with his family and has been on the run ever since.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Stark Choice for Syrians in Rebel Areas: ‘Doom’ or the Green Bus
abstract: Distinctive vehicles, once a symbol of national hopes, carry besieged rebels and civilians toward an uncertain fate as they yield land to government forces.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The lime-green buses once ferried Syrians to school, work and dates at Damascus cafes. Now they pull up at moments of defeat, when rebel fighters and civilians, besieged and bombarded, give up their territory to government forces and board the vehicles en route to an uncertain future.

headline: Donald Trump Kicks In $10 Million to Campaign
abstract: The candidate’s donation to his own campaign, which was running low on cash, came at a critical time in the race.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump contributed another $10 million to his presidential campaign on Friday, providing a needed financial boost to his bid at a critical juncture.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Microsoft, Apple and Halloween!
abstract: Farhad is going as sexy Donald Trump and Mike as Guy Fieri. Amazon gets them reminiscing about Matthew McConaughey in a 1990s stoner movie.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Josh Tomlin Found Inspiration in Opponents’ Stands
abstract: The Indians’ starter in their Game 3 World Series victory was calmed by the presence of his father, who has used a wheelchair since he was partially paralyzed in August.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Josh Tomlin, the Cleveland Indians’ starting pitcher on Friday night, looked into the stands at Wrigley Field before the biggest game of his life and spotted his mother and father.

headline: Can You Hire the Super for Odd Jobs?
keywords: ['Building Service Employees', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Cooperatives', 'Home Repairs and Improvements']
abstract: Some buildings prohibit residents from hiring building staff for private jobs because of potential liability issues.
lead_paragraph: For decades, shareholders in my co-op in Morningside Heights, Manhattan,  have hired building maintenance staff to do private handyman jobs on their own time, like installing shelving and making repairs. Last summer, the co-op board changed the house rules. Building employees can no longer do such jobs because of concerns about liability and misuse of co-op time. Many shareholders are upset. Can co-ops dictate what employees do in their private time and whom shareholders hire?

headline: Cleveland’s Unthinking Racism
abstract: How good baseball fans casually accept a slur.
lead_paragraph: For many of Cleveland’s passionate, patient baseball fans, their team’s logo is a joyful connection to the past. It’s a reminder of the players from their childhood and from generations earlier. The logo — which was the centerpiece of a 28-foot-high sign that welcomed fans to Cleveland’s old ballpark for many seasons — is one of the few constants across the decades.

headline: Greek Homeowners Scramble as Repossession Looms: ‘It’s Like a Horror Movie’
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Foreclosures', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Greece’s creditors have pressed to allow debtors’ properties to be seized and auctioned. Though officials insist homes are safe, owners are panicking.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Even after retiring as an accountant, Michalis Hanis dutifully kept up with the mortgage payments on the small house in a suburb of Athens where he has lived for 23 years. That was until several years ago, when Greece’s economic crisis hit.

headline: Javier Baez Is Conquered, This Time, in a Game Bursting With Pressure
abstract: Baez, an exuberant young slugger, embodied the Cubs’ nagging problems with patient hitting as he struck out to end the game in the bottom of the ninth.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The World Series is a dragon that can consume the young and inexperienced, even the acolytes blessed with a profusion of talents.

headline: Antique Teddy Bears and an Artist’s Trash: An ‘Art Dork’ in Her Element
abstract: Emily Weiss earned an art degree, but instead of becoming a starving artist, she got an insurance broker’s license and assesses works by major art world figures.
lead_paragraph: Emily Weiss, 30, is a senior account executive at DeWitt Stern, an insurance brokerage firm in New York

headline: With City of Towers, China Puts Its Economic Stamp on Caucasus
abstract: What had been a fight for influence in Georgia between Moscow and Washington has expanded into a three-ring event that has left China with the most visible role.
lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia — Scott Mi, a businessman from western China, stood on a balcony on one of the nine completed towers of 27 that his company plans to build and gestured toward the distant hilltop boundary of his improbable domain — a new, Chinese-built city rising atop one of the most volatile geopolitical fault lines left by the collapse of the Soviet Union.

headline: Unhittable? Aroldis Chapman and His 105-M.P.H. Fastball
abstract: Even major league hitters struggle against the blazing pitches of the Chicago Cubs’ closer. But no pitcher can rely on velocity alone.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Aroldis Chapman threw 13 pitches in his World Series debut on Wednesday in Cleveland. The fastest was clocked at 102.5 miles per hour by Major League Baseball’s Statcast radar gun. The batter, Coco Crisp of the Indians, put it in play.

headline: Popcast: What’s Next for Kesha?
abstract: The pop star has been locked in an ugly contract dispute with Dr. Luke; two writers who have examined her case break down the pop star’s situation.
lead_paragraph: The pop star has been locked in an ugly contract dispute with Dr. Luke; two writers who have examined her case break down the pop star’s situation.

headline: Seeking Clues to ISIS Strategy in Corpses and Cellphones Left in Kirkuk
abstract: The militants’ sudden move against Kirkuk provides a window into their strategy of taking sniper positions, stirring Sunni grievances and keeping forces in reserve.
lead_paragraph: KIRKUK, Iraq — Eighty-four bodies of Islamic State fighters were piled high at the Kirkuk hospital morgue, as the pathologists went through the gruesome work of gathering intelligence on the group’s sudden counterattack on the city.

headline: What’s Next for Kesha?
abstract: The pop star has been locked in an ugly contract dispute with Dr. Luke; two writers who have examined her case break down the pop star’s situation.
lead_paragraph: Listen to this week’s podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Another winner from Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Once again, we open by issuing an abject apology to a large group of people occupying a land mass, due to the nature of the acrostic quote. We’re sorry, Florida. But I’ve been there, and you do have insects the size of Buicks.

headline: Doubts About the Promised Bounty of Genetically Modified Crops
keywords: ['Genetically Modified Food (GMOs)', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'Defoliants and Herbicides', 'Pesticides', 'Series', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: Higher yields with less pesticides was the sales pitch for genetically modified seeds. But that has not proved to be the outcome in the United States.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The controversy over genetically modified crops has long focused on largely unsubstantiated fears that they are unsafe to eat.

headline: Broken Promises of Genetically Modified Crops
abstract: About 20 years ago, the United States and Canada began introducing genetic modifications in agriculture. Europe did not embrace the technology. This is how it has played out.
lead_paragraph: About 20 years ago, the United States and Canada began introducing genetic modifications in agriculture. Europe did not embrace the technology. This is how it has played out.

headline: A Scandal Too Far? Huma Abedin, Hillary Clinton, and a Test of Loyalty
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Ms. Abedin once seemed like a sure thing for a Clinton White House. But when your estranged husband calls himself “Carlos Danger,” all bets are off.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2013, Hillary Clinton had just left the State Department and returned to New York. She planned a quiet year, basking in sky-high approval ratings and enjoying a respite from the media spotlight as she laid the groundwork for a second presidential run.

headline: On the Trail: Week of Oct. 23
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump campaigned in swing states, and Mrs. Clinton turned 69 on Wednesday, two days before the F.B.I. added a chapter to her email case.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump campaigned in swing states, and Mrs. Clinton turned 69 on Wednesday, two days before the F.B.I. added a chapter to her email case.

headline: Justice Dept. Strongly Discouraged Comey on Move in Clinton Email Case
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail']
abstract: Senior officials warned the F.B.I. director on policies against talking about current criminal investigations or being seen as meddling in elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day before the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, sent a letter to Congress announcing that new evidence had been discovered that might be related to the completed Hillary Clinton email investigation, the Justice Department strongly discouraged the step and told him that he would be breaking with longstanding policy, three law enforcement officials said on Saturday.

headline: Hillary Clinton Assails James Comey, Calling Email Decision ‘Deeply Troubling’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s campaign opened a coordinated attack on Mr. Comey, the F.B.I. director, accusing him of smearing her with innuendo late in the race.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and her allies sprang onto a war footing on Saturday, opening a ferocious attack on the F.B.I.’s director, James B. Comey, a day after he disclosed that his agency was looking into a potential new batch of messages from her private email server.

headline: Jets Look to Recapture Passing Magic
abstract: Brandon Marshall is hoping to recreate last year’s on-field success with Ryan Fitzpatrick on Sunday in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Brandon Marshall strode into the Jets’ locker room Wednesday wearing a green T-shirt featuring the bearded outline of a familiar face. It belonged to the Jets’ once and future quarterback, Ryan Fitzpatrick.

headline: Who Owns Cheerleader Uniform Designs? It’s up to the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Uniforms', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Cheerleaders']
abstract: The court will hear a case about whether Varsity Brands, the giant of cheerleading apparel, should keep its copyrights on certain decorations, like chevrons or stripes.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court will spend part of Halloween hearing arguments about fashion, in a case that aims to determine whether anyone can own the stripes on cheerleader uniforms.

headline: Pashtana’s Lesson
abstract: A teenage girl resists her arranged marriage so she can stay in school.
lead_paragraph: When I first met Pashtana, she was a 15-year-old in the seventh grade — the oldest student in her classroom. She was caught in the awkward moment between being a girl and becoming a woman, and not quite comfortable in either role. But she was an eager class clown.

headline: APTN, a TV Voice for Largely Ignored Indigenous Canadians
abstract: The Aboriginal Peoples Television Network has become a powerful platform for hundreds of communities united in their demands for greater recognition.
lead_paragraph: WINNIPEG, Manitoba — The day’s top news stories are beamed from a round studio that evokes a tepee. Adventurous chefs teach viewers how to hunt, skin and cook beaver in a stew. Cartoons about a powerful superhero are broadcast in the Algonquin language.

headline: N.F.L. Offenses Are Changing, So Some Offensive Linemen Are Shrinking
abstract: Undersize linemen, akin to baby grand pianos, appear to be a growing demographic thanks in part to changing styles that require quicker players.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Joe Berger remembers the feeling. It was February 2005 and Berger, along with hundreds of other N.F.L. hopefuls, was at the combine, the league’s annual scouting carnival. Many of the players were nervous or anxious, fretting about their bench-press repetitions or their sprint times. Berger, on the other hand, mostly felt bloated.

headline: No Concession, No Sleep: Glued to the TV on Election Night 1960
abstract: The shifting returns of the Kennedy-Nixon race tested the fledgling television news operations and kept viewers in suspense until well past dawn.
lead_paragraph: The contest between Senator John F. Kennedy and Vice President Richard M. Nixon on Tuesday, Nov. 8, 1960, was expected to be close, and Americans were glued to their televisions until long after dawn. Coverage of the changing returns revealed some of the stresses and growing pains of early television news, which was little more than a decade old at the time.

headline: Populist Wave Likely to Lift Iceland’s Pirate Party
abstract: The anti-establishment party is poised to make big gains in Iceland’s general election, with voters expressing anger over government corruption.
lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — Spain has Podemos. Italy has its Five Star Movement, and Greece its Syriza. Now, the populist insurgency sweeping through Europe is finding a foothold in Iceland, where the Pirate Party, with its pirate flag logo and anarchist leanings, is poised to make big gains in a general election on Saturday.

headline: Increase in Health Act Premiums May Affect Arizona Vote
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Republican candidates here seized on the rate hikes, counting on the issue to buoy them with Election Day imminent and Donald J. Trump losing ground.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Arizona was shaping up to be one of the more unlikely battlegrounds of the 2016 campaign when a political bombshell appeared to explode last week: The Obama administration revealed that the cost of midlevel plans on the Affordable Care Act’s health insurance marketplace here would increase next year by 116 percent on average.

headline: N.S.A. Appears to Have Missed ‘Big Red Flags’ in Suspect’s Behavior
abstract: Harold T. Martin III kept his security clearance despite a record that included drinking problems, unpaid tax bills and an episode in which he posed as a police officer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Year after year, both in his messy personal life and his brazen theft of classified documents from the National Security Agency, Harold T. Martin III put to the test the government’s costly system for protecting secrets.

headline: Singing Hillary Clinton’s Praises, in Morgan Freeman’s Voice
abstract: A new ad, with the theme “Our Children,” presents Mrs. Clinton as “the steady hand” and Donald J. Trump as “a loose cannon.”
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton, looking to close her general election campaign against Donald J. Trump by establishing a strong contrast with her opponent, is out with a new ad titled “Example,” which highlights her experience and criticizes his temperament.

headline: At Yale, Theo Epstein Made a Splash as Newspaper’s Sports Editor
abstract: In 1993, just before Yale’s football game against Harvard, Epstein, then the student paper’s sports editor, wrote that it was time for Carmen Cozza to step down as Yale’s coach.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As fans poured into the Yale Bowl for the 1993 football game with Harvard, a traditional season finale that embodies Ivy League rivalry, a provocative issue of The Yale Daily News circulated in the crowd.

lead_paragraph: ما يقرب من 6000 امرأة استجابت لطلب النيويورك تايمز للحديث عن حياتهن في مجتمع ذكوري يجل الخصوصية، وأعربن عن مخاوفهن وإحباطاتهن وطموحاتهن.

headline: Comey, Clinton and This Steaming Mess
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: In the email saga, a fresh twist summons familiar hysteria.
lead_paragraph: “Bigger than Watergate!” Donald Trump exulted about the discovery of new emails from Hillary Clinton’s time as secretary of state. Sure, they could be. They could also be pleas from Clinton that Huma Abedin fetch her a skinny latte from Starbucks. We don’t know. And the horrifying thing is that the F.B.I. director, James Comey, didn’t seem to know, either, even as he disclosed their existence to the world.

headline: A Back Door Into the Marathon Connects Runners With a Cause
keywords: ['Running', 'Philanthropy', 'New York City Marathon', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: Running for charity has helped runners beat the lottery and secure a bib in the New York City Marathon. Many say they have found a sense of purpose along the way.
lead_paragraph: When Katie Quan received an email informing her that she had not been selected in the lottery for the 2016 New York City Marathon, she was disappointed but not surprised. After all, the competition to secure a spot in the race is always intense: This year, only about one in four runners (19,083 out of 82,172) was selected in the drawing.

headline: Nudges That Help Struggling Students Succeed
abstract: Small interventions can help underperforming students thrive in the classroom and even rethink their place in the world.
lead_paragraph: When I was in high school, I earned A’s in all my math classes — until I took calculus. In algebra and geometry, I could coast on memorizing formulas, but now I had to think for myself.

headline: Poverty in Unexpected Places
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Poverty', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'States (US)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Editorials', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: By one intriguing measure, the West, not the South, has the highest poverty rate in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Grinding poverty in the United States has long been synonymous with the Deep South, where low wages, poor health and diminished opportunity are more pervasive than in other parts of the country.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
