keywords: ['Ex-Convicts', 'Voting and Voters', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Editorials', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: A national survey shows that Americans think people who have committed felonies and served their sentences should be able to vote.
lead_paragraph: The bitterly fought presidential campaign has underscored yet again that conservative and liberal Americans are deeply divided on just about every aspect of social policy.

headline: How to Make Sense of College Rankings
abstract: As systems for rating colleges multiply like mad, here’s a guide for consulting — and ignoring — them.
lead_paragraph: Willard Dix is one of the crankiest observers of the college admissions process I know; he’s also one of the smartest. He worked at Amherst, his alma mater, then advised college-bound students at a private secondary school in Chicago. He now blogs about higher education.

headline: The Dangers of Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Economy']
abstract: At home and abroad, some risks are fairly easy to predict, but they’re not the worst-case scenarios.
lead_paragraph: IN last Sunday’s column, I wrote about the dangers that a Hillary Clinton presidency poses for the country. Since this is the final week for Hillary skeptics to agonize over whether to cast a vote for Donald Trump, it seems appropriate to outline why the risks of Trump are so distinctive as to throw the perils of a Clinton presidency into relative eclipse.

headline: The Ethics of Hunting Down ‘Patient Zero’
keywords: ['Epidemics', 'Swine Influenza', 'Ebola Virus', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Medicine and Health', 'SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)']
abstract: The debunking of an AIDS myth raises a moral question: When is justifiable to seek out the source of a disease outbreak?
lead_paragraph: The alleged “Patient Zero” of the American AIDS epidemic — a French Canadian flight attendant named Gaétan Dugas, who died of AIDS in 1984 — was exonerated last week.

headline: Waking Up to Shorter Commutes
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Transit Systems', 'Transportation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Local Government', 'Referendums', 'Elections', 'Editorials']
abstract: Transportation projects on ballots across the country are good investments for the future.
lead_paragraph: This could be a record year for transportation ballot proposals, because local politicians and voters have realized that Congress is not coming to rescue America’s aging bridges, roads and transit systems. On Nov. 8, there will be about 45 ballot proposals across the country that could raise nearly $200 billion for transportation improvements.

headline: Husbands With Guns
abstract: In the South, we have a story about a witch, and the man who kills her.
lead_paragraph: We were still married then. It was 2008, and we bought an abandoned farmstead in the mountains of North Carolina, on the backside of Tennessee. We loved its 300-year-old trees — enormous white oaks with great gnarled arms — and my husband loved that it was off the grid.

headline: 2008 Was a Celebration. 2016 Is the Opposite.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Now it’s eight years later, at the end of a revolution that has not yet happened.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 4, 2008, I was 26 years old and had just started working on an oral history project at a museum in Brooklyn. A co-worker and I were asked to interview people at polling places, to memorialize their thoughts about an election that might put the first African-American president in the White House.

headline: Push to Tweak Time Zone Gains Momentum in Spain
abstract: Lawmakers have argued that an extra hour of afternoon sunlight would have social and health benefits and help the nation save millions on electricity.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Rodgers and Hart song “I Didn’t Know What Time It Was” has nothing to do with time zones, but it may soon resonate for many Spaniards.

headline: Peter Thiel Defends His Most Contrarian Move Yet: Supporting Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Campaign Finance', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The tech billionaire is known for bucking convention, but his backing of Mr. Trump’s presidential bid has outraged much of Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Peter Thiel likes to take the path not taken. He has paid students to drop out of college, thinks Silicon Valley is overrated, backed a plan to build cities on the high seas and helped propel an electronic form of money into general use. His contrarian approach to investing and to life has made him rich and celebrated.

headline: Rangers’ Jimmy Vesey Shows His Skill, and Toughness
abstract: Vesey, a Harvard star who has four goals this season, takes great pride in being more than a prolific scorer. He can be physical and punishing.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Jimmy Vesey scored the fourth goal of his fledgling N.H.L. career for the Rangers on Wednesday night, but Boston Bruins forward David Pastrnak crosschecked him into the end boards before Vesey had much of a chance to celebrate.

headline: Mariano Rajoy Re-elected as Spain’s Prime Minister
abstract: Mr. Rajoy is set to form a new conservative government next week, after two inconclusive national elections and 10 months of stalemate.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Mariano Rajoy was re-elected as Spain’s prime minister on Saturday, ending a bitter period of political deadlock.

headline: In Defense of Politics, Now More Than Ever
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It has been, and can again be, “the greatest and most honorable adventure.”
lead_paragraph: ONE of John F. Kennedy’s favorite books was John Buchan’s 1940 memoir, “Pilgrim’s Way.” Buchan, who served as a member of Parliament for the combined Scottish universities, wrote, “Public life is regarded as the crown of a career, and to young men it is the worthiest ambition.” Politics, he added, “is still the greatest and most honorable adventure.”

headline: America, Your Election Is Not Rigged
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Elections', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: If Donald Trump wants to know what a fake democracy is, he should visit his friend Vladimir Putin in Russia.
lead_paragraph: For the last few weeks, the Republican nominee for president, Donald J. Trump, has been talking a lot about how the Nov. 8 election is rigged against him. In fact, he sounds convinced that the entire campaign season is rigged in favor of his Democratic opponent, Hillary Clinton. These are serious charges, or they would be if Mr. Trump had any idea what he was talking about.

headline: WikiLeaks Lays Bare a Clinton Insider’s Emphatic Cheers and Jeers
abstract: Neera Tanden, through her leaked emails, has emerged as a loyal but insistent straight-talker and acute assessor of her candidate’s stubbornness and weaknesses.
lead_paragraph: In one note, Neera Tanden groused that whoever had let Hillary Clinton use a private email address for her State Department correspondence should be “drawn and quartered.”

headline: How Hillary Clinton Met Satan
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', "Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: She has been deranging conservatives since ’92, when wounded Republican invincibility merged with wounded male prerogative.
lead_paragraph: It was my third day at the Republican National Convention in 1996, and my notebook overflowed with a one-note theme: “You do know that Hillary Clinton is funding the whole radical feminist agenda?” “She had Vince Foster killed.” “She’s behind many more murders than that.” “It’s well-established that Hillary Clinton belonged to a satanic cult, still does.” The consensus among Pat Buchanan’s supporters seemed ardent and universal, though the object of this obloquy wasn’t even on the opposing ticket.

headline: Richer but Not Better Off
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Income Inequality', 'Infant Mortality', 'Recession and Depression', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Longevity']
abstract: The poverty rate has improved, but inequality is still dragging our economy down.
lead_paragraph: It has been a long, painful slog out of the Great Recession. More than seven years into a halting recovery, fewer than 60 percent of working-age Americans hold a job — not much more than at the trough of the recession in the spring of 2009.

headline: I Registered to Vote... For This?
abstract: What Clinton vs. Trump feels like for first-time voters.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the United States hit a new benchmark in an already historic presidential campaign: For the first time in the country’s history, 200 million Americans are registered to vote. Over the past eight years, more than 50 million people have registered. That could mean that more Americans are voting for the first time this year than ever before.

headline: Why Trump Stays Afloat
abstract: The same forces that propel a radical candidate to a party’s nomination also provide a floor through which he is unlikely to fall.
lead_paragraph: In one of the most emotionally wrenching presidential races in living memory, Donald J. Trump’s support is as level as a pond. In polls, it is holding steady around 41 percent, right where it was after the first debate in late September. This plateau has persisted through the second and third debates with his opponent, Hillary Clinton, and the revelation of his recorded boasts of sexual assault. Even the stunning public rebuke of Mr. Trump by the parents of the Iraq war hero Capt. Humayun Khan in late July was followed by a swing of just a few percentage points, quite small by historical standards. Why has Mr. Trump’s support not collapsed further in the face of some fairly damning revelations?

headline: Spain’s Bullfighting Fight
keywords: ['Bullfighting and Bull Runs', 'Spanish Civil War (1936-39)', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: First, Barcelona banned it. Now, Madrid says it must go on.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — When the Parliament of Catalonia, an autonomous region in northeastern Spain, solemnly banned bullfighting in 2010, it was not simply a victory for animal rights. There was a political angle, as well, involving a battle over regional and national identity.

headline: Tal Afar, West of Mosul, Becomes Center of Battle for Influence in Iraq
abstract: Iraq’s Shiite militias aimed to take the city, a move that would essentially cut off the Islamic State fighters there from their bases in Syria.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — The city of Tal Afar, a former Ottoman outpost not far from Mosul that has a mostly ethnic Turkmen population and has been home to a corps of Islamic State leaders, on Saturday became the focus of a growing struggle between Turkey and Iran for influence in northern Iraq.

lead_paragraph: EAST LANSING, Mich. — Everything seemed a touch muted, a bit awkward, in the state of Michigan this past week. The usual rancor on sports talk radio and in fan memes before the annual football game between Michigan and Michigan State was not overly heated.

headline: An Engaged Electorate

headline: Tarred by Trump, Paul Ryan Tries to Safeguard Both Party and Job
abstract: This election season constitutes a shift in which Republicans must come to grips with the factions tearing it apart, a fight Mr. Ryan may not survive.
lead_paragraph: MODESTO, Calif. — This should have been a victory lap for Speaker Paul D. Ryan. Summoned by his party to heal its fractious majority in the House, Mr. Ryan grudgingly agreed to lead. Asked by House members to help them win re-election, he raised money by the millions and traveled thousands of miles to campaign at their side.

headline: Bossy vs. Buddy: Two Leadership Styles, Each With Its Place
abstract: Some managers lead by dominating employees; others try to win them over. But the most effective leaders deploy the style best suited to the situation.
lead_paragraph: Which is more important to your boss: to dominate people or to be liked by them?

headline: How Important Is Art History in Today’s Market?
abstract: There’s a perception that studying Rembrandt or Rothko is not a “serious” academic discipline, but that seems to be at odds with the prestige conferred on art and artists.

headline: Two Candidates Vie for One House Seat (for the Fourth Time)

lead_paragraph: In 2014, I wrote an article about New Hampshire’s very swingy congressional districts. With the same Democrat and Republican facing off in the First District for the fourth — yes, fourth — time, I couldn’t resist another visit.

lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — We have a list theme today by Caleb Madison, and I got this one pretty quickly because I am a complete and total Mac fangirl, except for iTunes, which could certainly use some work.

headline: Donald Trump Questions Veracity of Ballot Counting in Colorado
abstract: Mr. Trump, pantomiming a ballot collector tossing some over his shoulder while counting others, found a new reason to question the legitimacy of the election.
lead_paragraph: GOLDEN, Colo. — Donald J. Trump has found a new reason to question the legitimacy of the 2016 election — ballots — and he wasted little time here on Saturday before taking issue with the voting system in this largely vote-by-mail state.

headline: Powder Tossed at Metropolitan Opera May Have Been Human Ashes, Police Say
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera canceled a show before the final act after a man sprinkled a powdery substance into the orchestra pit.
lead_paragraph: An audience member at the Metropolitan Opera sprinkled a powdery substance — what the police said may have been the ashes of his mentor — into the orchestra pit during an intermission of a performance on Saturday, setting off a police investigation and the cancellation of the rest of that opera and a production that evening.

headline: Clintons Did Not Obtain Permits to Renovate Their New Chappaqua Home, Records Show
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: In the final days of the presidential race, the Clintons’ new house in Westchester County, N.Y., and its run-in with the local building permit office are giving them something of a headache.

headline: Indians Closer Cody Allen Takes His Game to Another Level
abstract: With 10 scoreless innings, 18 strikeouts and six saves in this postseason, he is reaching the heights of Andrew Miller, his more celebrated teammate.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Cleveland Indians have a custom: Whenever they sign a draft pick, they bring him to Cleveland and take him to dinner. Cody Allen, though, was in a hurry.

headline: Knicks Let Lead Slip Against Grizzlies, but Still Hold On
abstract: In a 111-104 win over Memphis, the Knicks turned what appeared to be a triumphant homecoming into a white-knuckle affair as an 18-point lead wasted away.
lead_paragraph: The feting of the Knicks began early during their home opener against the Grizzlies at Madison Square Garden. As Joakim Noah celebrated and sneered in the second quarter, the fans chanted his name, prolonging each syllable. After a highlight-worthy dunk in the third, Kristaps Porzingis was met with a rousing ovation. When, moments later, Derrick Rose crossed over Mike Conley and then bounced off contact at the basket to finish a layup, there was ample applause.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, October 30, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “There’s a longstanding policy of not doing anything that could influence an election. Those guidelines exist for a reason.”

headline: Indians Defeat Sloppy Cubs to Take a 3-1 World Series Lead
abstract: Cleveland’s Corey Kluber, who pitched well on three days’ rest, and Jason Kipnis, who homered to put the game out of reach, left Chicago a loss from another agonizing finish.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — All day long on the North Side of this baseball-obsessed city, fans in blue Cubs sweatshirts and caps moved nervously about town. There was still a festive buzz and a sense of excitement, but it was cut with a palpable edginess.

headline: A Narrow Path of Hope Remains for the Cubs
abstract: “It’s just been abnormal in some ways,” Cubs Manager Joe Maddon said of how the Indians have flummoxed opponents while marching through the playoffs and to within one win of claiming the World Series.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — If the Chicago Cubs rally to win this World Series, the degree of difficulty will make the victory even sweeter. They would need to win three in a row from the Cleveland Indians, including two on the road, to make it happen.

headline: South Korean President Dismisses Aides in Bid to Stem Worsening Scandal
abstract: President Park Geun-hye fired eight aides on Sunday amid rising public anger over accusations that a private citizen was given undue influence in matters of policy.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The shadowy woman at the center of President Park Geun-hye’s worst political scandal apologized on Sunday for her “wrongdoings.” Hours later, Ms. Park fired her chief of staff and seven other presidential aides in an effort to regain public trust, a day after thousands of South Koreans took to the streets to call for her removal from office.

headline: Fire, Film, Tweet: The Taliban’s New Way of War
keywords: ['vis-multimedia', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Social Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Increasingly, the Taliban rely on their front-line fighters not only to strike at the Afghan security forces, but also to record the moment and share it.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban fighters posed for the camera, their shawls and bandannas covering their identities but not their jubilation, as they captured the main roundabout in the northern Afghan city of Kunduz early this month in what could have been called “operation hoist the flag and pull out a smartphone.”

headline: Italy, Already Rattled, Is Struck by Another Powerful Quake
abstract: The temblor, with a reported magnitude of 6.5, caused fresh damage to towns hit by recent quakes, but few injuries were reported.
lead_paragraph: ROME — An earthquake, believed to be the strongest to hit Italy since 1980, struck the center of the country on Sunday, four days after two back-to-back quakes severely damaged buildings and left thousands homeless in the area. The temblor on Sunday also caused fresh damage to the towns destroyed by a quake that killed nearly 300 people in August.

headline: Airstrikes by Saudi-Led Coalition Kill Dozens in Western Yemen

lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Dozens of people, including many prisoners, were killed after airstrikes by a Saudi-led military coalition struck a security facility in western Yemen, local security officials and news reports said on Sunday.

lead_paragraph: Thousands of opposition supporters have been forced to leave their cities as part of a deal with the Syrian government, boarding green buses that once symbolized a step toward modernization in Syria. lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union and Canada signed a far-reaching trade agreement on Sunday that commits them to opening their markets to greater competition, after overcoming a last-minute political obstacle that reflected the growing skepticism toward globalization in much of the developed world.

lead_paragraph: “Ladies and gentlemen, I am Sylvester the eye-tester!” a man whose real name is Andrew Jones bellowed in an outdoor plaza in the Bronx last week. “For all of you who have not had your eyes tested in the last year or so, I am here for you!”

headline: What to Cook This Week

headline: My University Is on Fire
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The #FeesMustFall movement is in a tragic standoff between students who want to close colleges and administrators determined to keep them open.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The university where I work is in crisis. Campuses across South Africa are on fire — in some cases literally — as students protesting impossibly high fees lock horns with reckless police officers. Students run a gantlet of rubber bullets, water cannons, stun grenades and tear gas just to make it to the library. Attendance has been sparse, with students, lecturers and other employees staying home in fear. Some universities have turned to overzealous police officers and the infamous private security industry in a bid to bring campuses under control.

headline: For Democrats, Anthony Weiner Makes an Unwelcome Return

lead_paragraph: Hey, Derrick Rose: Forget about Stephen Curry, Russell Westbrook, Damian Lillard and the other volume-scoring point guards. At this stage of your career, on this particular team in New York, the guy you really want to be like is Mike.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']

Trump’s entire presidential run: chaotic, turbulent and skittering just on the edge of disaster.

lead_paragraph: The Bracero Program, which drew hundreds of thousands of Mexican laborers to toil in American fields from 1942 to 1964, left a searing memory of injustice. The program has been blamed for depressing farm wages and abusing immigrant workers.

Meanwhile, a director at the start of his career, Barry Jenkins, blew off the art-house doors with his “Moonlight.”

headline: Review: The Alien Abductees of ‘People of Earth’ Keep the Humor Grounded
abstract: This new TBS comedy, starring Wayne Cenac, concerns a recovery group whose members have survived extraterrestrial captivity.
lead_paragraph: It’s only a mild spoiler to reveal that the main characters of the new TBS comedy “People of Earth” — members of an Alcoholics Anonymous-like support group for alien abductees — are actual alien abductees. They’ve seen the bright lights overhead and been sucked up into the hovering ship. And they all agree on one peculiar aspect of their experience: Before sending their captives back to Earth, the aliens took the trouble to tell them “You. Are. Special.”

headline: Listening Clubs Tantalize Audiophiles in London
keywords: ['Music', 'Speakers (Audio)', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Disc Jockeys', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: By emphasizing audio quality above all else, clubs with rarefied hi-fi equipment have become a mecca for listeners who crave an emotional connection to music.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One Sunday evening in September, the main hall of a community center here was decked out with ribbons, balloons and a gyrating disco ball that marked a sonic sweet spot — the optimal position for partygoers to enjoy the clean, punchy (and not too loud) sound of five towering speakers arranged strategically around the room, piping a playlist of pop, funk, rock and dance floor gems for all generations.

headline: Review: Mark Morris Is a Citizen of the World at the White Light Festival
abstract: In four pieces, Mr. Morris’s troupe drew from South Asian idioms as well as Native American and other influences.
lead_paragraph: Because Mark Morris pays close attention to music in his choreography, you can hardly miss the sanity in his method. But his choice of movement often shows a streak of lunacy, a naïve and eccentric singularity that makes you think, Who else in the world would have thought of something so completely nutty? It’s this aspect of him that can seem magically inspired.

headline: Philip Guston and His Barbed-Pen Nixon Years
abstract: Guston and his friend Philip Roth made Richard M. Nixon the object of satire. Scores of Guston’s Nixon drawings will be featured in a show at Hauser & Wirth.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1971, the artist Philip Guston and the writer Philip Roth were refugees of a sort in Woodstock, N.Y. Mr. Roth was fleeing what he called his “overnight notoriety as a sexual freak,” after the publication of “Portnoy’s Complaint.” Guston, in a crisis of self-doubt, was turning his back on practically the entire art world.

headline: Black Voters, Aghast at Trump, Find a Place of Food and Comfort
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'United States Economy', 'Series']
abstract: The struggling African-Americans who visit a Philadelphia food pantry recoil at Donald Trump’s appeals to voters hit hard by economic troubles.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Natalie Solomon was always an early riser. Back in her days at a Ford-owned auto electronics plant, managing production schedules and bringing in $60,000 a year with overtime, she would be behind the wheel of her Ford Explorer by 4 a.m. — in time to grab coffee at Wawa, swing by her locker, grab her smock and get on the factory floor before 5.

headline: Early Turnout Tilts Toward Democrats in Swing States
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s campaign, leveraging its advantage in state-level organization, may be mitigating the fallout from her latest scrap with the F.B.I.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has established a slim edge over Donald J. Trump in early-voter turnout in several vital swing states, pressing her longstanding advantages in state-level organization and potentially mitigating the fallout from her campaign’s latest scrap with the F.B.I.

headline: Final Fed Meeting and Final Jobs Report Before Election Day
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The consequences of the presidential election are uncertain, so Fed officials are unlikely to raise rates for now. And the Labor Department’s report on hiring could embolden one of the candidates.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week:

headline: Witchcraft on the Campaign Trail
abstract: It’s 2016, but people still seem to believe Hillary Clinton practices the dark arts.
lead_paragraph: The idea has been flying about for a while now, at least since the summer’s cries to lock up or hang the Democratic presidential candidate. Earlier on, Ben Carson helpfully linked her to Lucifer. After the first debate, Rush Limbaugh made the designation official: In a double-barreled attack, he declared that Hillary Clinton came off “exactly as many people see her — a witch with a capital ‘B.’”

headline: World Series: Here’s How the Chicago Cubs Won Game 5
abstract: The Cubs got an offensive boost from Kris Bryant and Anthony Rizzo, and Aroldis Chapman nailed down the final eight outs to preserve the win.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live Game 6 coverage here.

headline: Publishers Are Rethinking Those ‘Around the Web’ Ads
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'News and News Media', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The ads, which appear mostly via the services Outbrain and Taboola, can lead to questionable websites. Now some publishers wonder about the effect on their readers.
lead_paragraph: You see them everywhere, and maybe, sometimes, you click: those rows of links under web articles, often augmented with eye-catching photos and curiosity-stoking headlines about the latest health tips, celebrity news or ways to escape financial stress.

headline: Ikea Strategy Ditches the Dream Home for the Daily Grind
keywords: ['Furniture', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Television', 'Social Media', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The furniture maker’s new campaign focuses on the struggles of families to make it in postrecession America instead of on acquisitions and aspirational gloss.
lead_paragraph: THE settings for the vignettes are workaday and unassuming: a living room where a man surrounded by file boxes and paperwork nods off on the sofa, a compact bedroom where two brothers’ very different personalities are on display, an apartment where a father tiptoes from a crib in the single bedroom to a loft bed in the living room.

headline: Review: ‘Canticles of the Holy Wind’ Summons the Elements at the Met
abstract: John Luther Adams’s hourlong suite, evoking wind, sky and birdsong with human (but wordless) voices, was an ethereally beautiful experience.
lead_paragraph: It’s no wonder that birdsong should be central to the work of John Luther Adams, a composer and an environmental activist whose music often draws inspiration from the unspoiled Arctic wilderness that he has fought to preserve. Throughout the ’70s he worked on “songbirdsongs,” a cycle that translates his field observations into crystalline instrumental miniatures for flutes and percussion. Later works sometimes incorporated ornithological quotations, like the different types of thrushes heard in “A Northern Suite.”

headline: The World’s Political Power Couples
abstract: Female heads of state or government are often members of political dynasties. Sometimes they follow their husbands into office, and occasionally their husbands follow them.
lead_paragraph: Female heads of state or government are often members of political dynasties. Sometimes they follow their husbands into office, and occasionally their husbands follow them.

headline: Wife and Running Mate: A Real-Life ‘House of Cards’ in Nicaragua
abstract: Rosario Murillo, President Daniel Ortega’s wife, has risen by winning over the poor and the public, but also by pushing out many in Mr. Ortega’s inner circle.
lead_paragraph: MANAGUA, Nicaragua — She started out as a teenage mother working as a newspaper secretary, then spent decades of revolution, conflict, power and public scandal at the side of one of the region’s most influential men.

abstract: The vast majority, about 220 million, live in South Asia, in places where air pollution is at least six times the level considered safe, the United Nations Children’s Fund said.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — About 300 million children in the world breathe highly toxic air, the United Nations Children’s Fund said in a report on Monday that used satellite imagery to illustrate the magnitude of the problem.

headline: Bridge Scandal Has Become Thorny Issue for Another Governor: Cuomo

lead_paragraph: The monumental traffic jam at the foot of the George Washington Bridge was never supposed to be Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s problem.

headline: Beyond Silicon: Squeezing More Out of Chips
keywords: ['Computer Chips', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Quantum Computing', 'Silicon', 'Energy Efficiency']
abstract: Moore’s Law, the axiom that chips will ever be more powerful and cheaper, is reaching its limits. But human ingenuity, with better algorithms and new hardware circuits, is pushing ahead.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Ali Farhadi holds a puny $5 computer, called a Raspberry Pi, comfortably in his palm and exults that his team of researchers has managed to squeeze into it a powerful program that can recognize thousands of objects.

headline: Six Concussions Later, Jordan Reed Fears Heartache of Losing Football
abstract: The Redskins’ Jordan Reed recognizes the health risks of head injuries, but he eagerly returned to the field Sunday to continue his emerging N.F.L. career.
lead_paragraph: ASHBURN, Va. — Jordan Reed, the Washington Redskins tight end, said he felt better. So much better. The headaches are gone. The nausea, too. No more uncontrollable crankiness. No more lost sleep.

headline: As Health Premiums Jump, Obama Wields an Imperfect Shield
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The president cited federal subsidies as protection against huge premium increases, but economists and health policy experts say there could still be problems.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Urging people to sign up for coverage under the Affordable Care Act, President Obama said last week that while premiums might be rising, most consumers need not worry. “Premiums going up,” he said, “don’t necessarily translate into higher premiums for people who are getting tax credits.”

headline: Ari Shavit, Celebrated Israeli Columnist, Resigns After Sexual Harassment Accusations
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Mr. Shavit, known for his a deeply introspective look at Israel’s remarkable rise, said he was “ashamed” of his actions toward women.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The author Ari Shavit attained international celebrity with a deeply introspective look at Israel’s remarkable rise and its controversial moments. With passion and authority, he helped make it possible for many liberal supporters of Israel to admire the nation while questioning its policies.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, October 31, 2016.

keywords: ['Solar Energy', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Electric Light and Power']

lead_paragraph: More than 10,000 New York City residents are using solar power to reduce their electric bills. But hardly any of those people converting the sun’s rays into savings are poor.

abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, October 31, 2016.

headline: How Often Has Terry Francona Thought About His Legacy? ‘Never’
abstract: “Never once,” Francona, the Indians manager, said. “You know why? I don’t care. I like what I’m doing.” Then he reconsidered.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Terry Francona ducked under a drain pipe and headed up the dank and narrow tunnel leading to the visitors’ clubhouse at Wrigley Field, the ancient baseball shrine. The clubhouse — any clubhouse — is his sanctuary, his favorite spot in the world, the place where he starts his day preparing for a game, well before his players arrive, so he can give them his full attention when they do.

headline: Lessons From Europe on Using Contactless Cards
keywords: ['Debit Cards', 'Credit Cards', 'Identity Theft', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: As banks prepare to roll out this technology, the experience on the other side of the Atlantic shows how to avoid fraudulent activity on these new types of credit and debit cards.
lead_paragraph: For banks and retailers, there is a fine line between making people’s use of credit and debit cards as painless as possible and protecting individuals’ financial details from swindlers.

headline: Review: ‘Les Liaisons Dangereuses’ Uses Sex as a Weapon
abstract: Janet McTeer and Liev Schreiber star in this adaptation of Choderlos de Laclos’s 1782 novel full of duplicity and score settling.
lead_paragraph: In the high-stakes sport of extreme stage acting, Janet McTeer and Liev Schreiber are champion cliff divers. Give them an emotional precipice to jump from, and they’ll soar through the air and stick the landing.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 7, Episode 2: Greetings From the Kingdom
abstract: Carol and Morgan meet a new settlement that expands both the cast and the show’s philosophy.
lead_paragraph: Sorry about all the violence and death last week, “Walking Dead” fans. Here, have a tiger.

headline: ‘Westworld’ Season 1, Episode 5: The Search for Meaning
abstract: Regardless of your theories, there is at least one thing that William and the Man in Black have in common.
lead_paragraph: The paradox of Westworld as a theme park is that guests come seeking a taste of freedom — no laws, no standards of decency, no limits beyond the horizon — but are, in fact, submitting themselves to a world that’s controlled, surveilled and quite literally programmed. It’s a fantasy of Old West freedom, and a potent one for thrill-seekers who give themselves over to it passively, chasing their animal desire for realistic shoot-‘em-ups and readily available android sex. But the more time spent in Westworld, the more the seams begin to show, and the behavioral patterns and loops start to look just as mundane and predictable as the domestic routines they’ve left behind.

headline: Review: In ‘Coriolanus,’ a Politician for a Campaign Season
abstract: Red Bull Theater’s impressive production of Shakespeare’s late tragedy doesn’t skimp on the election metaphors.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to squint too hard to discern unsettling contemporary relevance in the Red Bull Theater’s gripping new production of Shakespeare’s “Coriolanus,” which opened on Sunday at the Barrow Street Theater. The director, Michael Sexton, all but pulls out a pen and starts highlighting from the get-go.

headline: This Election Grows Scarier by the Day
abstract: From Trump’s “Nasty Woman” to Ken Bone, some of the political costumes this Halloween.
lead_paragraph: From Trump’s “Nasty Woman” to Ken Bone, some of the political costumes this Halloween.

headline: W. Dudley Johnson, Heart Bypass Surgery Pioneer, Dies at 86
abstract: Dr. Johnson, who applied crocheting and needlecraft skills, went on to perform more than 8,500 bypass operations over four decades.
lead_paragraph: Dr. W. Dudley Johnson, who pioneered and popularized lifesaving cardiac bypass surgery and was considered a healer of last resort for heart patients around the world, died on Oct. 24 in Milwaukee. He was 86.

headline: Pro-Russian Candidate Leads Moldova Presidential Vote but Faces Runoff
abstract: The candidate, Igor Dodon, finished far ahead of pro-Western challengers, but failed to win the outright majority needed to avoid a runoff election next month.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In a blow to Western efforts to tug former Soviet lands out of Moscow’s orbit, a strong supporter of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia finished far ahead of pro-Western candidates in a presidential election on Sunday in Moldova.

headline: Kris Bryant Takes Lessons From Ted Williams’s Batting Bible
abstract: Even if Williams becomes a little more lost to history with each passing year, his philosophies are alive and well in his 1971 book, “The Science of Hitting.”
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Dig through a public library or the reference shelf of your neighborhood hitting coach, and you might find a relic. Decades before heat maps and swing paths became part of baseball’s vernacular and the value of getting on base was truly embraced, Ted Williams laid out many of the hitting philosophies that are in vogue today. He did so in a book titled “The Science of Hitting.”

headline: A Somber Charleston Reflects on Race as 2 Murder Trials Begin
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The trials of a police officer and a white supremacist will draw renewed attention to South Carolina, where many still struggle with killings that rattled the nation.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Seventy-four days separated the fatal bursts of gunfire: the eight rounds a white police officer fired at Walter L. Scott, a black man in North Charleston, and then the shots that killed nine black churchgoers at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church here.

headline: Indians Starter Corey Kluber Emerges as a Postseason Powerhouse
abstract: Kluber, who won the 2014 American League Cy Young Award, has a 4-1 record in five playoff starts, with a 0.89 E.R.A.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — To properly appreciate the postseason of the Cleveland Indians ace Corey Kluber, first consider that only two other pitchers have started on short rest more than once in the same postseason over the past 10 years: C. C. Sabathia of the Yankees in 2009 and Clayton Kershaw of the Los Angeles Dodgers this year.

headline: ‘Insecure’ Season 1, Episode 4: Career Day
abstract: Issa and Molly face a divide between the life they dream of and the life they actually lead.
lead_paragraph: Episode 4 of “Insecure” feels, at first, like the most minor one yet. But if you peer closer, it’s looking at the same theme from different angles: the sharp divide between the life we dream of and the life we’re actually living. This is never more clear than when Daniel is in Issa’s orbit.

headline: Leafs Phenom Auston Matthews Stirs Cheers in Islanders’ Building
abstract: Matthews and his Toronto teammates will probably prefer to forget his first New York foray.
lead_paragraph: Auston Matthews skated onto the Barclays Center ice Sunday, and Toronto fans — braving the pulsating pregame music and wearing his No. 34 — broke into big smiles when they saw the teenage visitor.

headline: Cubs Aren’t History as Chicago Denies Indians a Title in Game 5
abstract: Kris Bryant homered as part of a three-run rally, and the Cubs’ pitchers made it hold up in a 3-2 victory in Game 5 to send the World Series back to Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A few blocks north of Wrigley Field sits the final resting place of Ernie Banks, the eternally ebullient Mr. Cub. His grave site, on the edges of a pond and shaded by leafy trees at Graceland Cemetery, was adorned Sunday with several bouquets of wilting red roses and yellow mums, and a small white towel emblazoned with a blue W.

headline: New York Senate Debate Becomes Proxy War for Presidential Hopefuls
abstract: Senator Chuck Schumer, a Democrat, and Wendy E. Long, his Republican challenger, often appeared to be fighting for the candidates at the top of the ticket as often as discussing their own differences.
lead_paragraph: During a debate on Sunday, Senator Chuck Schumer of New York pronounced himself “appalled” — at least four times — that the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had disclosed that he was again looking into the matter of Hillary Clinton’s emails without yet knowing the significance of a newly discovered batch.

headline: 3 Japanese Shipping Companies to Merge Container Businesses
abstract: The three largest shipping companies in Japan will combine their container lines as a slowdown in trade crimps their industry worldwide.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In a fresh sign of the economic fallout from weaker global trade, Japan’s three largest shipping companies agreed on Monday to merge a major portion of their businesses, saying they needed to join forces to survive.

headline: James Galanos, Fashion Designer for the Elite, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Galanos, who outfitted Nancy Reagan for inaugural events, earned numerous accolades even as he evaded celebrity and shunned the fashion establishment.
lead_paragraph: James Galanos, a fashion designer who spent decades dressing America’s social elite, most notably Nancy Reagan, died on Sunday at his home in West Hollywood, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Emails, Genitalia and the F.B.I.

headline: Chicago’s Grim Era of Police Torture
keywords: ['Torture', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Archives and Records', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Editorials']
abstract: Documents that will be available for research are a reminder of the extremes to which abuse of suspects can reach.
lead_paragraph: Americans who think of officially sanctioned torture as something that happens in other countries will be shaken when they confront the grim holdings of the Chicago Torture Archive, an online research repository set to open early next year. The archive — which includes testimony and documents from criminal trials and civil rights cases — was collected by the People’s Law Office, which represented numerous survivors of police torture. The trove will give researchers chilling insight into the grisly period from the 1970s to the 1990s when the Chicago Police Department’s infamous torture crew rounded up more than 100 African-American men who were shocked with cattle prods, beaten with telephone books and suffocated with plastic bags until many confessed to crimes.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Bad Promise on Debt
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'National Debt (US)']
abstract: To make the economy grow, she should add a penny or two to the national debt.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has made the American public a promise she shouldn’t keep.

headline: The R.N.C.’s ‘Don’t Get Out the Vote’ Drives
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Minorities', 'Editorials', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: Trump’s abhorrent efforts to keep black and other minority citizens from voting are only the latest example of a long-running Republican strategy.
lead_paragraph: By now, most people have heard Donald Trump’s fact-free claims that the election is “rigged” against him and his dangerous calls for supporters to act as poll-watchers and thwart alleged voter fraud in “certain areas” — by which he means minority communities in big cities like Philadelphia and Chicago.

headline: Chavismo Full Circle
abstract: Chavismo has itself become an entrenched elite blocking electoral democracy from upending it.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Venezuela’s opposition movement is promising to follow its huge march last week with a march this week to the Presidential Palace to demand the restitution of the recently shut down recall referendum. The government of President Nicolás Maduro has mobilized its followers to defend the revolution in the streets. It is a confrontation unlikely to have a happy ending.

headline: When a Masterpiece Is Not
abstract: A painting accepted as the work of a Dutch master was so good that it was only discovered to be a new work with the aid of science.
lead_paragraph: When a previously unknown painting by a 17th-century Dutch master is authenticated by some of the finest curators and experts, sold for $10 million and then abruptly discovered to be a fake, questions arise. Many of them.

headline: Working the Refs
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: How the right uses the weak-minded.
lead_paragraph: The cryptic letter James Comey, the F.B.I. director, sent to Congress on Friday looked bizarre at the time — seeming to hint at a major new Clinton scandal, but offering no substance. Given what we know now, however, it was worse than bizarre, it was outrageous. Mr. Comey apparently had no evidence suggesting any wrongdoing by Hillary Clinton; he violated longstanding rules about commenting on politically sensitive investigations close to an election; and he did so despite being warned by other officials that he was doing something terribly wrong.

headline: We Don’t Need a ‘War’ on Climate Change, We Need a Revolution
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Global Warming', 'United States International Relations', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Language and Languages', 'Philosophy']
abstract: The language of combat obscures the real enemy.
lead_paragraph: This year is on track to become the hottest ever recorded, and a growing number of environmentalists are using a particular type of language in response. Some are calling for a huge “mobilization” to “combat” climate change. In an article in the New Republic in August, Bill McKibben, the unofficial spokesperson of the climate movement in the United States, insisted in very literal terms that, we are at war with climate change.

headline: Behind the Mask: Scenes From Nicaragua’s Sandinista Revolution
abstract: A commemorative reissue of Susan Meiselas’s book “Nicaragua” brings to life the young revolutionaries who toppled the Somoza dictatorship.
lead_paragraph: A photo of three men wearing traditional Nicaraguan folk masks and holding homemade contact bombs graced the cover of The New York Times Magazine on July 30, 1978. Alan Riding’s article, with photos by Susan Meiselas, chronicled the popular uprising against the dictatorship of Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

headline: Of Jacks and Jennets: Facts About Donkeys

headline: Pigeon: From the Wild to the French Table
abstract: In pursuit of the delicately gamy palombe, a rising favorite at top restaurants in Paris.
lead_paragraph: In pursuit of the delicately gamy palombe, a rising favorite at top restaurants in Paris.

headline: Hunting Pigeon in the Pyrenees — for Supper
abstract: For centuries, the men of the Basque Country have hunted wild pigeon. Their weapons of choice: paddles and nets.
lead_paragraph: FALL IS WILD GAME SEASON in France, and discerning diners at Parisian outposts like L’Ami Jean, La Régalade and Spring come especially for the composed dishes of just-hunted, rich-tasting game. That one might bite into one’s mallard or grouse and land on stray birdshot is perhaps a badge of honor, proof that what’s on your plate has a woodsier back story than the steak. And palombe, or wood pigeon, has a better back story than most. “As a chef, you want something that tastes delicious, but also that’s coherent and has its own tradition,” says Daniel Rose, who serves it rare-roasted at his First Arrondissement restaurant Spring during the bird’s month-and-a-half season from mid-October to the end of November. Generally grayer than its close cousin, the standard pigeon, with distinctive white marks on its neck and wings, the wild-caught palombe is more delicately gamy and less rich. Rose serves his with braised foie gras and cabbage, and a purée of smoked beet. At L’Ami Jean, Stéphane Jégo goes a more traditional route, roasting the birds with thyme and garlic, or stewed in salmi, a mixture of giblets, wine and foie gras. “Wild palombe brings a rustic, old-fashioned moment to the table,” Rose notes. “It evokes the deliciousness of nature and cooking on an open fire.”

Not because they were now rich and had gained scientific immortality, but because they would get to meet the legendary troubadour himself at the festivities in Stockholm.

Rain is falling and leaves are falling and my youngest son, like his brothers, has received his Selective Service card in the mail, and today I have returned to my house to find a lone black vulture standing in my front yard.

headline: 1916: Hindenburg Makes Boast on the War
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: German Field Marshal von Hindenburg boasts about World War I and speculates on how long it might last, in October 1916.
lead_paragraph: Field-Marshal von Hindenburg has been interviewed at General Headquarters by a representative of the Vienna “Neue Freie Presse.” Questioned as to the military situation, he replied: “It is as favorable as possible, and everything will continue to go well.” “But how long will the war last?” asked the correspondent. “That depends on our adversaries,” said Hindenburg. “It is useless to prophesy. In war time especially, it is preferable to abstain from doing so. It is possible that the year 1917 may bring about fighting which will decide the war. I can say nothing as to this, but what I can say is that we shall never give in until a decision is reached.”

headline: Opioid Poisonings Rise Sharply Among Toddlers and Teenagers

lead_paragraph: The number of children being hospitalized because of prescription opioid poisoning has risen sharply since 1997, especially among toddlers and older teenagers, researchers from the Yale School of Medicine reported.

headline: Noam Chomsky and the Bicycle Theory
abstract: The academic and activist talks about his critics, his celebrity and his legacy.
lead_paragraph: At 87, Noam Chomsky, the founder of modern linguistics, remains a vital presence in American intellectual life. An emeritus professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he still teaches, he has a dual identity, reflected in his several dozen books. Many are on theoretical linguistics and the philosophy of mind. Others are sharp, leftish polemics on American politics. Dr. Chomsky is back in the news, thanks to a pair of high-profile attacks. In “The Kingdom of Speech,” Tom Wolfe pairs Dr. Chomsky (“Noam Charisma”) with Darwin as the malign Ur-theorists of evolution. In “Decoding Chomsky: Science and Revolutionary Politics,” the British anthropologist Chris Knight explores “the Chomsky problem” — the paradox of a thinker who belongs to the “professional and scientific elite” even as he espouses populist political ideas.

headline: A Numberplay Farewell
abstract: Gary Antonick, outgoing writer of The Times’s Numberplay column, shares a lesson learned from seven years of puzzle-solving.
lead_paragraph: This – after seven years – is my last Numberplay column for The Times. It’s been a terrific, wild ride, full of new friendships and rewarding discovery. But it’s now time to focus on new projects: teaching a course on the art of logic in Shanghai, developing an online program on the psychology of reasoning at Stanford and helping to create a national math tournament in Nigeria.

headline: Two Books Unlock the Secrets of Spice
abstract: The television personality Padma Lakshmi and the spice purveyor Lior Lev Sercarz have published books on seasonings.
lead_paragraph: Two of the city’s best spice purveyors now have reference guides. Padma Lakshmi, the television personality and cookbook author, has collaborated with Kalustyan’s, a magic carpet of ingredients on Lexington Avenue and 29th Street, on an A-to-Z guide to spices and herbs. Color photos illustrate many of the entries and typical uses, but no recipes are given. Lior Lev Sercarz, who owns La Boîte, a spice shop on 11th Avenue and 51st Street, and who custom-blends spices for chefs, has also done a guide. The handsome book comes in a box, is lavishly photographed and is organized alphabetically to cover spices and herbs. There are no recipes, but suggested uses are given for each product. Mr. Sercarz explains how to best buy, blend, roast and store seasonings, and how spices are sanitized to be sold: “The Encyclopedia of Spices & Herbs: An Essential Guide to the Flavors of the World,” by Padma Lakshmi with Judith Sutton and Kalustyan’s (Harper Collins, $25); “The Spice Companion: A Guide to the World of Spices,” by Lior Lev Sercarz (Clarkson Potter, $40, $50 with slipcase).

headline: A Brandy for the Last Whig President
keywords: ['ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: An American brandy company honors the nation’s 13th president with a smooth, gentle blend.
lead_paragraph: The folks at Germain-Robin, a craft distillery in Northern California, honored the 13th president of the United States, Millard Fillmore, with their latest brandy because, like American brandies, they consider him to be not very well known or appreciated. I confess little knowledge of President Fillmore, the last Whig Party president (1850 to 1853), but I have been an admirer of the Cognac-style brandies the company keeps producing. You may call this new one an entry-level brandy, a gentle blend that delivers smooth, floral and dried-fruit notes on the palate and sells for a reasonable price: Millard Fillmore United States Brandy, $35, Caddell & Williams, 800-575-9997, caddellwilliams.com.

keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Arms Trade']

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Malaysia’s prime minister, miffed by a Justice Department investigation into his nation’s sovereign wealth fund, arrived in Beijing on Monday ready to buy Chinese military hardware, a deal that will rattle his relationship with the United States.

headline: Make Room for a Cheese Cave in Your Fridge
abstract: The Cheese Grotto promises a better storage solution for your cheeses.
lead_paragraph: Storing fine cheeses properly at home has long been a challenge. You can invest in special double-ply wrapping paper, but the temperature and humidity of a refrigerator do not flatter them. Working with an engineer and an industrial designer, Jessica Sennett, who has been behind the counters at Cowgirl Creamery and Bedford Cheese Shop, has developed a solution. Her Cheese Grotto is a sturdy box with removable wooden shelves, a clay slab in the bottom and ventilation ducts in the back. Moisture is maintained by periodically soaking the clay. Cheeses are stored unwrapped. The box’s footprint is around the size of a standard sheet of copy paper, and at 8½ inches high, it can fit in a refrigerator or sit comfortably on a kitchen counter. It can be ordered for $350 and will ship four weeks after the order date: cheesegrotto.com.

headline: Daily Report: Google’s Day in Europe’s Court Highlights Nature of New Tech
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Cloud Computing', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: The search giant is one of several American tech companies facing inspections overseas for the way they do business.
lead_paragraph: Europe has a big headache: the current state of American technology companies. And it may take a long time to go away.

headline: Escape the Web and Get Things Done
abstract: If you find yourself wasting too much time online when you really need to be working, you have many ways to force yourself (temporarily) offline.
lead_paragraph: Q. I’m going to take up the NaNoWriMo challenge, but am worried about giving in to internet distractions and not finishing the novel by the end of November. I only need discipline for a month, so what free or cheap software would work to temporarily lock me out of the Facebook and other time-sapping sites?

headline: Strangers on a Strange Election
abstract: The 2016 presidential campaign as experienced by four writers originally from somewhere else.
lead_paragraph: The 2016 U.S. presidential campaign as experienced by four writers originally from somewhere else.

headline: Delmonico’s Welcomes a White House Chef
abstract: John Moeller, a veteran of three administrations, has created a Presidential Palate menu with the executive chef of Delmonico’s, Billy Oliva.
lead_paragraph: Over the decades, Delmonico’s Restaurant has counted heads of state among its customers, including more than a dozen American presidents. Now the restaurant has turned to John Moeller, a former White House chef (from 1992 to 2005), to work with its executive chef, Billy Oliva, on a menu of dishes that have been served to commanders in chief at Delmonico’s and at the White House. The menu, including roast duck and sweet potato bisque, crab à la Newburg, turkey à la king, goulash and baked alaska, will be available from Tuesday to Nov. 8 for lunch and dinner: Presidential Palates menu, Delmonico’s Restaurant, 56 Beaver Street (South William Street), 212-509-1144, delmonicosrestaurant.com.

headline: Gabriel Kreuther’s Chocolate Shop Opens
abstract: Across from Bryant Park, a playground for chocolate makers and lovers from the pastry chef Marc Aumont.
lead_paragraph: The chocolate shop adjacent to Gabriel Kreuther’s restaurant has some compelling features. Chefs in a glass-encased space enrobe chocolates as visitors watch them work. The two display cases in the soaring shop tempt with chocolates and pastries, among them macarons with a series of fillings based on cheesecakes, a sort of France-meets-America concept, as the pastry chef, Marc Aumont, put it. Among the flavors, there is the inevitable pumpkin spice. A few cafe tables are set out in the metallic-flecked room for customers to enjoy coffee and sweets but not much else: Kreuther Handcrafted Chocolate, 43 West 42nd Street, 212-201-1985.

headline: Anson Mills Grains Now Available in New York
abstract: Il Buco Alimentari e Vineria is selling the heirloom grains in NoLIta.
lead_paragraph: For cornmeal, farro, oats or other grains from Anson Mills, the Columbia, S.C., company renowned for its high-quality heirloom products, you used to place your order on the website. But now, a few of the items, including popping corn and cornmeal for polenta, are being sold at the retail counter at Il Buco Alimentari e Vineria, in the East Village. The new baker on the premises, Sheena Otto (below), who was at Bien Cuit, is introducing some breads using Anson Mills grains, including a crusty dark rye and a buckwheat rye. Ms. Otto, who believes in a slow fermentation with no added yeast, is also baking a complex seed-studded multigrain in two sizes, and fragrant bourbon and raisin bread: Anson Mills products, $5.50 to $8; new breads, $6 to $12. Il Buco Alimentari e Vineria, 53 Great Jones Street (Bowery), 212-837-2622, ilbucovineria.com.

lead_paragraph: Consider the season’s striking dangling designs.

headline: Want to Quit Office Life to Work With Your Hands? Ask These Guys
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Men and Boys', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: Meet the men who quit the grind of white-collar work and found job satisfaction in hauling leaves, building walls, hanging drapes and baking bread.
lead_paragraph: Ben Schickel walked into the offices of a software firm in Boston, where he had worked in sales for more than a year. It wasn’t easy. He was coming back from a two-week vacation, time he had spent not on some faraway beach but indulging his passion for landscaping work.

headline: The Store Putting Tijuana on the Design Map
abstract: Object brings together influences from all over Mexico — much like the city itself.
lead_paragraph: Within Mexico, Tijuana’s mestizo culture is renowned: The city’s booming manufacturing industry attracts migrant workers from all over the country, who bring with them disparate cultural traditions whose influence has long been felt in the music and food scenes. Now, it is on display at Object, a pioneering design shop in the city. “Most of the designers we carry work directly with traditional Mexican artisans from all over Mexico,” says its owner, Verónica Hernández. She and the store’s other co-owners travel throughout the country to source designs that often reflect regional manufacturing methods.

headline: Study Finds Some Uber and Lyft Drivers Racially Discriminate
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Researchers who studied trips in Seattle and Boston said African-American users might wait up to 35 percent longer for rides than white users.
lead_paragraph: By tapping into new technologies and the ubiquitous use of smartphones, the likes of Uber and Lyft — rival ride-booking services — were supposed to solve many of the problems that litter the traditional economy.

abstract: The Philippine president’s anti-American vitriol might have paid off in the South China Sea.

headline: Why Clinton’s Emails Matter

abstract: Sure, this isn’t Watergate. But James Comey and the F.B.I. are right to demand a fuller explanation.
lead_paragraph: It may come as a surprise that one of this country’s greatest experts on Richard M. Nixon’s many crimes is, in fact, Hillary Clinton. In 1974 she was, by many accounts, among the brightest members of the staff of the House Judiciary Committee that investigated Nixon and prepared the articles of impeachment. In this bizarre election year, it must be painful to her that she should find herself at the center of a scandal described by her hyperbolic political opponent, Donald J. Trump, as “worse than Watergate.”

headline: Review: A Musical Homage to Aviation, From Plato to Earhart
abstract: JACK Quartet’s multimedia concoction, “Flight,” featured readings, video projections and music by the composer Roger Reynolds.
lead_paragraph: The armchairs in the Board of Officers Room at the Park Avenue Armory are surely the most comfortable concert-hall seats in New York. And yet I couldn’t stop squirming during Sunday afternoon’s performance there of “Flight,” a multimedia concoction for string quartet, electronics and video conceived by the composer Roger Reynolds. Billed as a tribute to humanity’s fascination with flying, the work draws on images and texts spanning some 3,000 years, and that’s about how long it felt, thanks to the flat-footed and dispiriting way in which it was all cobbled together.

headline: A 9/11 Parable, Resurrected in Newfoundland
abstract: Residents of Gander are treated to an early look at “Come From Away,” a Broadway-bound musical about how they welcomed travelers grounded amid the Sept. 11 chaos.
lead_paragraph: GANDER, Newfoundland — Memories of Sept. 11 are a little different here. That was the morning 38 planes were diverted to this tight-knit town with a large airfield, where they were required to land because of fear about how many flights might be targeted in the terrorist attacks unfolding south of the border. The day 6,700 bewildered passengers arrived, upset and tired, unsure why they were here or how long it would take them to get out.

headline: Viacom Names Its Second Acting C.E.O. as Tumult Continues
abstract: Effective Nov. 15, Robert Bakish will step in to the role. He succeeds Thomas E. Dooley, who was appointed acting chief executive in August after the ousting of Philippe P. Dauman.
lead_paragraph: Viacom on Monday named Robert Bakish its acting chief executive, effective Nov. 15. Mr. Bakish, who started at Viacom in 1997, most recently served as chief executive of the company’s international unit.

headline: Unreleased Report Raises Questions About AIBA, Boxing’s Governing Body
abstract: An investigation into AIBA that was completed more than a year ago focused on a $10 million loan from a company in Azerbaijan to help pay for a new league in North America.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure by Olympic officials to address possible financial problems in his organization, the president of boxing’s international governing body in 2015 ordered an investigation by the accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers.

headline: Safe for Now, Canadian Dairy Farmers Fret Over E.U. Trade Deal
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Dairy Products', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: A new trade agreement with the European Union could threaten the country’s “supply management” system, under which dairy farms are almost guaranteed to prosper.
lead_paragraph: THAMES CENTRE, Ontario — On both sides of the Atlantic, many of the people who are most upset about the new free trade deal between Canada and the European Union are dairy farmers. But they have opposite worries.

headline: Stringer Faults Mayor de Blasio Again as 2017 Race Nears
abstract: Scott M. Stringer, the New York City comptroller, issued a second straight D-plus for agencies citywide in his third annual report on procurement with minority-owned businesses.
lead_paragraph: Glaciers. Dinosaurs. The challenge of putting genies back into the bottles from which they came.
